titleStmt.title: A sure guide, or, The best and nearest way to physick and chyrurgery that is to say, the arts of healing by medicine and manual operation : being an anatomical description of the whol body of man and its parts : with their respective diseases demonstrated from the fabrick and vse of the said parts : in six books ... at the end of the six books, are added twenty four tables, cut in brass, containing one hundred eighty four figures, with an explanation of them : which are referred to in above a thousand places in the books for the help of young artists / written in Latine by Johannes Riolanus ...; Englished by Nich. Culpeper ... and W.R. ...
Encheiridium anatomicum et pathologicum. English

titleStmt.title: A sure guide, or, The best and nearest way to physick and chyrurgery that is to say, the arts of healing by medicine and manual operation : being an anatomical description of the whol body of man and its parts : with their respective diseases demonstrated from the fabrick and vse of the said parts : in six books ... at the end of the six books, are added twenty four tables, cut in brass, containing one hundred eighty four figures, with an explanation of them : which are referred to in above a thousand places in the books for the help of young artists / written in Latine by Johannes Riolanus ...; Englished by Nich. notesStmt.note: Plates accompanied by 24 captions or 24 unsigned, unpaged leaves.
Translation of Encheiridium anatomicum et pathologicum, first published in Paris in 1648.
Includes p. [11]: "Mris [sic] Culpepers information, vindication, and testimony concerning her husbands books to be published after his death," dated 1655.
W.R. is William Rand. Cf. DNB.
Reproduction of original in Cambridge University Library.

1. Describing all and every of the bones of mans body according to the ancient method -- 2. Describing the belly and all its parts and bowels with their respective diseases -- 3. Describing the chest and all its parts and contents with their respective diseases -- 4. Describing the head and face with all their parts containing and contained and their respective diseases -- 5. Describing the limbs of the body with the many regiments of muscles and their diseases -- 6. Containing a new description of the bones by a method first invented by our author handling al the diseases and symptomes of the said bones.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.head: The Ue of the Letters and Figures, directing to the twenty four Tables, or Bras Cuts; and the hundred eighty four Figures in thoe Tables, repreenting the Parts of the Body.
div.p: EVery Bras Cut, or Print, is called a Table; and the aid Prints or Tables, are twenty four, and have their repective Numbers et at the Foot of the Table, or Print, on the corner that is outmot, and againt the Readers right hand. Each particular Figure is alo numbred, and the Number et over its Head, and the everal parts of each Figure, are ditinguihed by Letters of the Alphabet, for the eaier finding. To compare therefore, the Dicoure with the Tables, I hall teach you by an Example or two. In Chap. 8. page 9. line 21. The word Coronalis, is marked with the Letter a; to which Letter, looking at the end of the aid Chapter, you find a T. 15. f. 3. a a a. intimating that you mut turn to Table 15. Figure 3. and that part of the Figure which is marked a a a. which repreents the Coronal Suture of the Skull: The Mark hews that the former Citation is ended. Again, in the next line of page 9. by the word Lambdoides, you find Letter b, to which looking at the end of the aid Chapter, you find b f. 4. b b. to teach you that in the 15 Table foregoing, Figure 4. and on that part of the Figure marked b b. you hall find the Suture of the Skull called Lambdoides: and this mark after b b. hews again that the Citation is ended. Again, in the ame line, by the word Sagittalis, you find Letter c, to which turning at the end of the Chapter, you hall there find c f. 3. b b. f. 4. a a. intimating that in Figure 3. of the forenamed Table 15. and in that part of the Figure which is marked b b. Alo in Figure 4. of the ame Table, on that part which is marked a a you hall find the Sagittal Suture decribed. The mark hews the Citation is ended.

Note that where you find not among the Directory Letters, T. for Table, that Figure belongs to the fore-mentioned Table. Alo you are to take notice that between two Citations, you hall find this mark .

Finally. He that would make his mot advantage by the ue of this Book, hould, having been preent at ome Anatomical Diections of the whol Body; tudy the Tables firt, with their Explanations on the oppoite Pages; and then read the Dicoure of Riolanus, and compare it all along with the Tables, which may be bet done, if the Tables be bound up by themelves, o as to lie open alwaies while he is reading the repective Chapters, referring to each Table.

A SURE GUIDE OR, The BEST and NEAREST Way TO Phyick and Chyrurgery: That is to ay, The Arts of Healing by Medicine, and MANUAL OPERATION. Being An Anatomical Decription of the whol Body of Man, and its Parts, with their Repective Dieaes, demontrated from the Fabrick and e of the aid Parts. In Six Books. VIZ.
1 Decribing all, and every of the Bones of Mans Body, according to the Ancient Method.
2 Decribing the Belly, and all its Parts and Bowels, with their repective Dieaes.
3 Decribing the Chet, and all its Parts and Contents, with their repective Dieaes.
4 Decribing the Head, and Face, with all their Parts Containing and Contained, and their repective Dieaes.
5 Decribing the Limbs of the Body, with the many Regiments of Mucles, and their Dieaes.
6. Containing a new Decription of the Bones, by a Method firt invented by our Author, handling al the Dieaes and Symptomes of the aid Bones.

At the End of the Six Books, are added twenty four Tables, cut in Bras, containing one hundred eighty four Figures, with an Explanation of them; which are referred to in above a thouand places in the Books, for the Help of yong Artits.

Written in Latine, by Johannes Riolanus, Junior; Doctor of Phyick, Phyitian in ordinary to the Queen Mother of France many years together, and the lat he had: And alo the Kings Profeor of Anatomy and Herbarim, in the Univerity of Paris.
Englihed by Nich. Culpeper, Gent. and W. R. Doctor of the Liberal Arts, and of Phyick.
London: Printed by Peter Cole, and are to be old at his Shop, at the Sign of the Printing-Pres in Cornhil, neer the Royal Exchange. 1657.

div.head: To the Right Honorable, HENRY LAWRENCE, Equire; Lord Preident of the Councel to his Highness, the Lord Protector.
div.p: IT being my hap ome years ince to find in the Stationers hop at Amterdam, your Lordhips Elegant Treatie of Baptime, and being upon Enquiry, informed touching the quality of the Author; I wondred what Gentleman it was, that having a tock of Honor & Repute in the world, had withal o much Chritian Courage, as to venture it in that kind. For I judged (and I uppoe rightly) that for a Gentleman of name and note, at that time to dare to vindicate the true Chritian Baptime, contemning the clamorous cenures of the weake Multitude of Pretenders to Religion and Learning, was an Act of more true and high Courage than to torm a Town. And I humbly conceive, Experience has evidenced the Truth hereof, ince hundreds (not to ay thouands) that have adventured their Lives to gain Honor and Riches in the Field, have in their hearts found it too hard an Adventure (however otherwie convinc't in their undertandings) to own and acknowledg the true Chritian Baptime, and ubject themelves to the corned practice thereof, with the evident hazard of much of their acquired Honor, and of their future Repute, and the advacement depending there upon.

That this action, nevertheles, of yours (my Lord) has not been attended, with al that Ignominy and Prejudice, which was only to be expected from Men; is the ingular providence of God, giving Courage and Ingenuity, to many others of note, oon after (much animated doubtles by o noble and generous a Leader as your Lordhip) to acknowledg and ubmit to the Divine verity, and beautiful, and mot
lovely Rationality of that olemn Intitution of our Mr. Chrit and his eminent blesing that part of the oldiery, Characteried thereby. Much affected therefore with your Lordhips Chritian Vertue in this kind, and deirous to commend the ame to Poterity; It has not been ince that time in my power to do it more effectually, than by prefixing your truly honorable Name in the Front of this excellent Anatomical Treatie, and bet Foundation of the Art of Healing, commonly though corruptly called Phyick. The fitnes of which Dedication, I hal with your Honors gentle Patience, thus demontrate

Seeing this book is nothing (for the mot part) but a Declaration and Expoition of the tupendiouly admirable widom of the Eternal our Maker, hining forth in the mot curious Fabrick of Mans body; to confirm and eal the beleefe of the Reurrection whereof (which is the very Foundation of1 Cor. 13. 15, 16. 17. 18. 30. 31. 32. Chritianity) baptime eems (by the Scripture) to have been cheifly ordained, by our great Mr. Chrit; that as we had one olemn Ceremony to repreent his ufferings and death, we might not want another to et forth and olemnize his burial and Reurrection (without which his own death and his Diciples Faith had been in vain) and to take poesion in and by a Figure of our own Reurrection to come (For, we Colo. 2. 12. are, aith Paul, Buryed with Chrit, in our Baptime, and therein alo rien with him; That is, in a figure, being through a olemn Ceremonious poesion of our future Reurrection from the grave, intated into eternal life.) This being o (my Lord) to whom hould this excellent Decription of the body of Man in general, with al its parts, and their Repective Dieaes, be dedicated, rather than to him that has vindicated to the Chritian world, that excellent pledge of the Reurrection thereof; to wit, the Baptime of Chrit rightly olemnized: whereby al true beleevers are mightily aured, that though this curiouly built Houe of our Earthly Tabernacle, be owen in the dut, yet it hal not there abide for ever, as the beats that perih. Accept therefore (Generous Sir) from your mot humble ervant, this Tetimony of your Chritian
Courage and incerity, and uffer this excelleut Treatie to helter it elf under your honorable Patronage. And though this tetimony of your vertue o publickly given, may (I fear) afford ome digut to your Modety, yet I beeech your Lordhip to let it pas, for the glory of our great Mr. Chrit, and the Edification of Chritendom. And I have much reaon to hope, it may be a Monument of your honorable Memory, when probably the royal and Magnificent combes at Wetminter, hal pledge the Fate of them in Pauls, and be overwhelmed with Dut and Ruins. Such is the deire and Hopes (my Lord) of him that craves leave to ubcribe himelf,

closer.signed:
Your Honors,
Mot humble Servant, and true Admirer of your Chritian Ingenuity, Sincerity, and Courage, WILLIAM RAND.
closer.dateline:
From my Houe neer Cripple-Gate in London.
December, 22. 1656.

div.head: Mris. Culpepers Information, Vindication, and Tetimony, concerning her Husbands Books to be Publihed after his Death.
div.p:
SO great are the Afflictions wherewith our Heavenly Father hath been pleaed to exercie me his poor Handmaid, that I have not only lived to ee my dear Husband, (the Stay
•• d Solace of my Life) taken from me: but it hath been my hard hap alo to ee his Reputation, and Memory (which wil be dear to al Poterity, for the Works he hath written for the Common Good of this Nation) blemihed, and Ecliped, by the covetous and unjut Forgeries of one, who, though he calls himelf Nathaniel, is far from being an Iraelite in whom there is no guile; who was not content to publih a Hodgpodg of undigeted Collections, and Obervations of my deer Husband deceaed, under the Title of Culpeper's lat Legacy; but to make the Deceit more taking, he teeled his Forehead o far, and braed it o hard, as not to be ahamed to forge two Epitles, one in mine, and the other in my Husbands Name; of the penning of which, he nor I, never o much as dreamed: And yet he impudently affirmeth in my Name, that my Husband Laid a evere Injunction on me to publih them for the general good, after his deceae; and that they are his lat Experiences in Phyick and Chyrurgery. And in the Title of his Book, he aid, They are the choycet, and mot profitable ecrets, reolved never to be publihed til after his Death. Al which Expreions in the Title and Epitles, are as fal as the Father of Lyes; and every word in them, forged and feigned. And he knew wel enough, that no dicreet, honet man, that was a friend to my Husband, or me, would ever have agreed to uch infamous and dihonet practices; and therefore I deire all courteous Readers of the Writings of my Husband, to take notice of this Deceit, and to aure themelvs that it never entred into his head, to publih uch an undigeted Gallimoffery, under the promiing and olemn Name of his Lat Legacy, and that whereby he gained his Reputation in the World, as the Impoter makes him speak in his forged Epitle. And I deire any in different Reader, that hath oberved my Husbands lofty, and Maculine manner of expreing himelf in his Prefaces, and Epitles Dedicatory, whether in cae he had been minded or dipoed to take o olemn a farewel of the world, as the Forger makes him to do; whether, I ay, he would have done it in uch a whining fahion, and o in the Stile of a Balade-maker, as to ay, And now, if it pleae Heaven to put a period to my Life, and Studies, that I mut bid al things under the Sun farewel: Farewel to my dear Wife and Child, farewel Arts and Sciences, farewel al worldly Glories, adiew Readers. Certainly my Husband would have been far more erious, and material, in uch a cae, as any dicreet man wil Judg. Neither can it be thought, that in uch a olemn Valediction, he could poibly forget his wonted repects to the Colledg of Doctors, to whom he did o frequently addres himelf, in divers of his writings.

Courteous Reader, I hal ay no more touching the abue of the Book-eller, only to prevent (as much as concerns me) thy being abued for the future, know, That my Husband left eventy-nine Books of his own making, or Tranlating, in my hand, and I have depoited them into the hands of his, and my much honored Friend, Mr. Peter Cole, Book-eller, at the Printing-Pres, neer the Royal Exchange (for the good of my Child) from whom thou mayet expect to receive in print, uch of them as hal be thought fit to erve thee in due eaon, without any Diguies or Forgeries, unto which I do hereby give my attetation. Alo my Husband left eventeen Books compleatly perfected, in the hands of the aid Mr. Cole, for which he paid my Husband in his life-time: And Mr. Cole is ready and willing (on any good occaion) to hew any of the aid eventy-nine Books, or the eventeen, to uch as doubt thereof.

And if any Peron hal quetion the Truth of any part of this Vindication, or Epitle; if they wil take pains to come to me, I wil face to face, jutifie the truth of every word thereof, as I have ubcribed my Hand thereunto in the preence of many witnees.

I profes in the preence of the great God, the earcher of al hearts, before whom Mr. Brooks and I mut one day give an account of al our Actions: That I have not publihed this Epitle or Vindication, out of any di • repect to Mr. Brooks (for I much rep • t the man, and would be glad to erve him to my power) but only to cleer my Husband from the olly and weaknes cat upon him by the means above expreed. And out of tendernes to Mr. Brooks, I firt tried other means of keeping, and afterwards of repairing my Husbands Credit, and then tayed long to ee if he would repair (in any meaure) the wrong done to my Husband, and myelf. I deire to be.

closer.signed:
Your Servant (in,
and for the Truth) Alice Culpeper.
closer.dateline: From my Houe, next door to the Red Lyon in Spittle-fields, October, 18. 1655.

postscript.p: Mris. Culpeper did the 18. of October, ubcribe this Epitle in Vindication of her Husband's Reputation, before Ten Witnees, as he had done another Epitle on the ninth of October, almot in the ame words with this, except neer the Concluion.

div.head: THE FIRST BOOK OF ANATOMY AND PHYSICK, OF John Riolanus.
Chap. 1. The Intent of the Author is declared.
div.p: ANatomy, is conidered and handled two waies, Philoophically, The Conideration of Anatomy is. Philoophical. and Phyically, Galen, Lib. 1. Anat. The Philoopher earcheth out the tructure of the Parts, their action, and ue, that he may know himelf, & that the * Work-mater may be admired in his(* Viz. God) work; and therefore the knowledg of the Parts alone does content him. But the Phyitian, beides thePhyical, knowledg of this, brings al into a Practical way, and earcheth after the Natural dipoitions of every Part, that o by veiwing the Anatomy of the Carkaes of ound and ick men, he may more eaily know the accidents againt Nature; which happen to thoe Parts, in uch as are alive.

By Dipoitions againt Nature, is to be undertood Dieaes, whoe generation and end, whether it wil be good or bad, the way and manner of Curing, he that would know exactly, mut be skilled both in Philoophical, and PhyicalBoth which are neceary. •
Anatomy; and I dare boldly affirm, that he wil be an abler, and more skilful Phiitian that is wel skiled in this Anatomy, than he that contents himelf, with the bare knowledg of the Parts.

This manner of hewing, and teaching Anatomy is new, but gives great light, & is wonderful neceary for a Phiitian, and I wil lay it down intermixed with the order of Anatomy in al the Parts, and hew particularly in every Part, what profit wil thereby redound unto a Phiitian, in his Practice. And
eeing the Natural Contitution of every Part which Hippocrates cals Euphuian, and is commonly called Health, is three-fold, Similar, Organical, and common, The Preternatural Contitution of the Parts, called Sicknes, mut likewie be three-fold and make three kinds of Dieaes, Viz. A Dieae of the Similar, a Dieae of the Organical Parts, and a Dieae common to both. The Similar Contitution, according to Nature, conits in Subtance, and Temper; The Organical Contitution, which pertains to the contruction of the Organ, is placed, in number, Magnitude, Scituation, and hape or Conformation; which Conformation is again divided into Figure, Paage, Cavity, Roughnes, and moothnes; The common Contitution of Similar, and Organical Parts, conits in nion and Connexion. This three-fold Natural Contitution, I wil declare in al the Parts; afterwards I wil lay down in a few words, what may be gathered from this Sound Contitution, for the Knowledg, fore knowledg, and Cure of a Dieaed Contitution; And Anatomy handled in this Method, wil be the beginning, Middle, and end of the whol Art of Phyick. This is a hort, eaie, and clear Method, Quickly, and rightly to learn the Art of Curing; which propounds the ame, viible to the Eyes of uch as are wel vert in my Fathers writings, or in the Intitutions of Sennertus. for by this Method, I hal unlock, & diplay the treaures in Anatomy of Phyick: But perhaps ome Fool, that is unskilled, wil reprove our Diigne, & Object, that we confound the whol Art of Medicine, eing Anatomy is a Part of Phyiology, ditinct from the ret; and therefore ought to be taught apart, eeing Galen himelf, in the beginning of his diection of Mucles, reproves the Anatomical Book of Lycus; becaue in his Treatie of Mucles he inerted the Dieaes of the Parts. If any prattle uch things againt us, they wil quickly hold their peace, if they read Gal. Lib. 2 admin. Anatom. Relateing, That Antient Phyitians regarded Anatomy o much, that in al Hippocrates did in al his Books. Many are the Sorts of the Figures, both within, and without the Body, (aith Hippocrates, in Lib. de vet. Med.) Which have much different qualifications in the Sick, and the Sound; all which you mut perfectly ditinguih one from another, that you may rightly know, and oberve the caues of every one of them.

According to Aritotle, Health, and Sicknes, are the Fundamental And Profitable in Medicine. Parts of Medicine: Both of them are contained in the Parts; and Sicknes compared with Health is the better dicerned. Ad to this, That Aritotle Writes, that he that would Cure the Eyes, mut firt know the Structure of the Eye. Again, Hippocrates held, that Dieaes were ditinguihed according to the Parts they were in • ierent in; and the principal Curative indications, were taken from the Affect, and the Part affected; and Remedies both Medicinal, and Chyrurgical were Precribed and adminitred diverly, according to the Parts Afflicted. Therefore Galen wrote his Therapeuticks of the compoition of Medicines, according to the Parts afflicted: and Avicenna did wiely, when perceving that the Seats of Dieaes could not be known without skil in Anatomy, Before the Dieaes of the particular Parts he et down their Anatomy. And if we beleeve Galen in Lib. de Part med. The firt Matter or Subject of Medicine, is the Body, as it is the Subject of Health and Sicknes.

Our intent then is by a hort and eaie Method, To deliver in writing, andThe Intent of the Author. demontrate in dead Bodies, of the eats of al Dieaes, and Symptomes, both Internal, and External; and the particular way of Cure according to the order of Anatomy, which is publickly oberved. A notable peice of Workmanhip to learn Phyick by, by which 'tis eaie to manifet, and bring to light the Errours, in the Cures of Dieaes and to intruct and inform uch as are Studious in Phyick, by that time they have been hearers and beholders two yeares, of two Anatomies in a year, with diligent reading of
Books, and excercize of the knowing of Plants, and other Drugs, and viiting of the Sick with him that is their teacher. Excellently aid Johannes Fernelius in the beginning of his Pathology, I hal never think any man wel skilled in the knowledg of Dieaes, unles he have been an Eye witnes of the eats of them, in the Body of man, and know how they are affected againt Nature; neither can be come to this unles he be skilful and exquiite in Anatomy, and whatoever he reads or hears, let him eriouly contemplate it in the Body of man, and ettle the cheif knowledg of things in his mind.

div.head: Chap. 2. Why we begin our Anatomy with the Treatie of Bones.
div.p: THat kind of tile is two-fold, which is ued in the explication of any thing, Gal. Com. ad Part. q. Lib. 1. de fract. et Cap. 1. Lib. The Method of teaching double. Synops. de Puls. The firt is called Synopticus, when the Matter is briefly laid down; The other Diexodicus, when it is Copiouly unfolded, nothing being paed by which is profitable to be declared: The former helps the memory; the latter cleers the matter to the undertanding. For which Caue Galen divided his Books into Iagogical, and perfect; the firt being fitted to young beginners, the other to proficients, as himelf tetifies. Lib. de libris Propriis. This is alo confirmed by the authority of Hippocrates; Lib. de vet. Med. Where he advieth Phyitians to teach eaie things to young tudents, and uch as may be quickly learned; ad hereunto; That al men deire to learn apace, according to Aritor. Lib. 2 de Rhetor. Chap. 10. And the Method of breife teaching, is alwaies grateful, both to young tudents, and to perfect Maters; for it teacheth the former what things mut be learned; and in the latter cals back to their memory what they have learned before, and almot forgotten, Gal. Lib. 4. de diff. puls.

Wiely, and Elegantly, did the Emperor Jutinian judg, That a compendium of the Lawes was firt to be propounded, to invite Novices to knowledg. Then are al things delivered mot commodiouly when they are firt delivered by a plain and imple way, and then by an exact and diligent interpretation; for if we burden weak, though tudious minds at beginning, with variety and Multiplicity of things, we either make them deert their tudies, or ele young Men to great labor and ditrut, and bring them by a longer way to what might be learned with more peed, les labor, and no ditrut.

Therefore following the precepts of Galen, and Hippocrates, I wil decribeWhy the Author wrote a Synopis. a briefe, and cleer Manual of Anatomy, following the counel of Galen, who had rather write a Synopis of his Books of Pules himelf, then to leave the buines to another, who by not undertanding his mind, and ene, hould pervert or confound his meaning.

I begin with the Bones, becaue they are the foundation of al the Parts of the whol Body, which is ubtained, Included, Preerved, and moved by theWhy he begins with the Bones. Bones; which, according to Hippocrates, give tability, and form to the Body.

Therefore he that is tudious in Phyick, ought to be intructed in the perfectThe neceity of writing of the Bones. knowledg of the Bones, before he come to behold the Anatomy of the whole Body: otherwie he wil be ignorant in deigning the original, and inertion of the Mucles, and the ticking of other Parts to certain Conceptacles of the Bones, unles he be skilled in the Hitory of Bones; at which Anatomy is to begin, as Hippocrates taught, and after him, Galen.

div.head: Chap. 3. The Diviion of Oteology, or the Hitory of the Bones.
div.p: THe Hitory of the Bones is called. Oteology, of which are two Parts:The Parts of Oteology. Practice, and Theory. I cal that the Theory, which is converant in the knowledg of their conformation and ue. The Practice is the manual operation which comprehends both Oilegium, and Oifragium; Oilegium, is the manner of preparing Bones to make a Sceleton; Oifragium is that which earches out the joining, and knitting together of the Bones, and Joynts, by Ligaments, and Cartilages, and by breaking, and deviding them; earches out their internal, and hiden Parts.
div.note: See Chap. 26. and 27. Lib. 6. Of this Book.

div.head: Chap. 4. Of the Compoition, and Definition of a Bone.
div.p: THat the Nature of a Bone may be perfectly undertood, there are fourFour Confiderations. things to be conidered in it: The Matter, Efficient, Form, and End.
The Matter of the Bone is Proper, or Divere.1. Matter, Proper. Generation.
Proper is conidered Generally, or Specially.

Proper Matter, taken Generally, is double; the one for Generation, the other for Nourihment; the Bones are made of the Seed by conent of al Phyitians. The Seed conits of Humor, and Spirit: The Humors are of two Parts; the one thinner, of which the noble Parts are formed; the other thicker, of which the Bones are ingendred.

The matter of Nourihment is alo two fold; Remote, and Neer: Remote, is Blood, by which al the Parts of our Body are nourihed: Neer, is the MarrowNourihment. contained in the Cavity of the Bones, or a Marrowy Juyce hut up in the Spongious Bones.

The Proper Matter conidered pecially, regards the Bone already made, which is various in repect of ubtance, and quality; and o the ubtance ofContitution. one Bone is divere, by reaon of the Epiphyis, which is Softer then the ret of the Bone; or the Apophyis, which is harder then the ret of the Bone: alo the whol Bone, if it be Sollid, is harder without, then it is within. If it be hollow, the Internal Superficies is hardet.
As for what belongs to Quality, and Namely Color; the Bone, the more <> it is, the more White it is; that which is hollow, is pale or reddih.

By the divere Matter of the Bone, undertand that which compaeth itMatter divere. about; and it is a Membrane, and a Cartilage. The Membrane which compaeth about the Bone, is called Periotion, and ticks firmly to it. By benefit of which, it Obcurely feels. The extremities of the Bones are covered with a Cartilage, which Facilitaces the Motion of the Bone, and hinders its wearing.

The Efficient Caue of the Bone, is the Implanted Generative Spirit, or2. Efficient caue. rather heat, which • orre •• es and dryes the Matter of the Bone. Gal Lib. 1. • e fac • l. natural. acknowledgeth the faculty which forms the Bones; to which Heat and Spirit, do adminiter.
The form of a Bone is double; Eential, and accidental: That is called3. Form, Eential. Eential, which makes it to be a Bone, Namely, the Vegetable Soul.

The Face, aith Aritotle Lib. 2. de Generat. animal, is no Face, if it want the Soul; and o is the Fleh and Bone. But with Phyitians, the form of Similar Parts, is nothing ele then their temper. The temper of the Bone, is cold and dry; therefore Coldnes and Drines contitute the form of the Bone. The accidental form, is the Figure of them, which is Proper, and peculiarAccidental. to every Bone, and is mot commonly round in al Bones, both in Longitude, and Latitude.

The end of the Bones, is their Ue; and this is general, and particular;4. End. General. Special. That is called General, which erves for the whol Body; and that is three fold, 1. To etablih, and make firm the oft Parts. 2. To give hape, and Figure to the Parts. 3. To help the Motion, and Progres of the Body. The Particular end, or ue, is that which is Proper to every everal Bone.

From what hath been written, this Definition of a Bone, may be gathered; It is a Similar Part, mot cold and dry, Formed by heat of the thick and Fat Definition. ubtance of the Seed; for the form and ettlement of the whole Body.

div.head: Chap. 5. Of the Qualities, or Natural Dipoition of the Bones.
div.p: THe Doctrine of Bones, ought to be double; one which treats of theDoctrine of Bones Double, Of Infants and men grown up. Bones of infants, which from their Birth til even years of Age, differ in many things from uch as are grown up: the other of men of perfect Age, which we now handle.
And eeing al Doctrin of Bones, is referred to Phyical ue, we mut know the Condieions, and affections of Bones, wel and Naturally affected, which are either common to al, or Proper to ome.

The common are nine which hal be Decribed, and Demontrated, in ourAffection of the •… ones are. Common. new Oteology, at the latter end of this Manual. In dry Bones wel Prepared, are five things hewed. 1. Hardnes and olidity. 2. They have holes outwardly, Epecially toward the Extremities, by which is ingres given to the little Veines, and arteries, for Nourihment and life. 3. A cartilaginous Crut at the Extremities, and the Periotion, which compaeth about the whol Bone, the Cartilaginous extremities excepted. 4. Continuity, and Equallity in its whol ubtance; wherefore the callous, by which broken Bones are united, is not Natural. 5. A fit and convenient joyning of one Bone with another.
The affections Proper to the everal Bones, are twofold; either uch as regardProper, every Bone everally; or uch as regard more Bones then one, joyned together.

1. The affections of the firt ort, are four; Hollownes, Prominence,2. of Bones eperated. Roughnes, and Smoothnes; which affections are conidered in the extreme uperficies of the Bone, in as much as Bones are referred to mutual conjunction becaue they cannot ubit alone by themelves. The Head of the T. 21. f. 2. C. Omoplata is hollow; the f. 1. a. Shoulder Bone ticks out; the f. 4. B. Ichium, or Huckle-bone, is hollow; the f. 1. D. Bone of the Thigh ticks out; the Skul is rough behind for the T. 15. f 4. C. inertion of Mucles, in other places 'tis mooth, and Polihed: Al which affections, if they are uch as Nature made them, they are according to Nature; if otherwie, they are beide Nature.

Alo a Cavity is deep, or uperficiary; that which is deep, is called T. 21. f. 4. B. Cotyle; the uperficiary f. 4. F. f. 2. F c Glene. A Prominency, or Parts ticking out, is called Apophyis, or Epiphyis: Both of them are round, or long, or hollow: If it be round, it is called a Head; if it be large and long, it is abolutely Named a f. 1. dd. f 4. a. Head; but if it be hort, and depreed, it is called f. 2. II. Condylu • . The Heads or Condyli of mal Bones, are not Epiphyis, but Apiphy • is as in the nether Jaw, and in the Ribs, and the Bones of the Fingers, and Toes.
A long Apophyis, is either with a poynt, and called Corone; or imply long, and that according to the Figure of it, hath divere Names; or T. 15. f. b. D. Styloides T. 21. f. 2. d. Coracoides, T. 13. f. 21. a. Odontoides; or ele tis terminated in a Head, and then is called T. 21. f. 2. c. Cervix or a Neck.

It is not aburd, that ome Apophyis hould be hollow, Seeing al Cavitieswhether Apophyes have hollownees. are, as it were, ingraved in the Apophyis; or ele are made of two or three Apophyes, as in the Cavity of the Ichium, or Huckle-bone: and although omtimes a Cavity make the Body of the Bone, yet it is formed by a bony Circumference; which Seeing it ticks out obliquely, and orbicularly, without the plain uperficies, it is worthily accounted an Apophyis; Gal. Lib. de Oibus acknowledgeth the Omoplata to be an Apophyfis, which is a Cervix, the extremity of which, ends in the ibid Glene; therefore Cavities ought to be referred to Apophyis; and a Cavity if it be round and large, may be called a Head, for the Neck is alwaies ubjected to the Head Gal. Proem. Lib. de Oib.

In every Bone, which being joyned to another makes a Joynt, I oberve the Body and the extremities, which are Adnata, or Enata; The body isThe Body the principal Part, formed of Nature, that it may be the foundation of the extream Parts; for Nature ever-more begins the formation of the Bones in theand middle, and produceth them towards the extremities. The extremities of the bones called Enata, are T. 2. f. 1. aa. f. 2. b c d. T. 15. f. 3. M N d. Apophyes; Adnata are T. 21. f. 1. 2. q. T. 13. f. 21. a. T. 15. f. 6. D. Epiphyes: theExtremities, which are Apophyis, and Epithyis. Treatie of the Epiphyes pertains to the Oteology of Infants, therefore we wil not peak of it here.

Yet this you may know, that Epiphyes belong to the extremity of the Joynts of the bones; and that their Nature is to be ought out in Children; for in men grown up, they degenerate into Apophyes, no Foot-teps of the antient Diviion remaining; and yet inwardly they keep the condition of their Proper Nature, which ought to be like a pumice, and bloody; but the Apophyes are alwais harder.
The econd ort of Affections are, the Articulations of bones, one with another,2. The Joynting of Bones. which in divere bones, are different; which now we come to peak of, in General.

div.head: Chap. 6. Of the Conjunction of Bones.
div.p: SEeing it is not afe, nor comly for man, that Divine Creature, to creepWhy there are many Bones in man. along like Worms, and Serpents; Nature hath et his body bolt upright, with firm, and ollid bones; not only three, or four in number, but very many various, and ditinct, whereby he may bow, and move himelf every way; And that this Workmanhip might be the more Elegant, the Bones are o Joyned together, that the extremity of one, enters into the Cavity of the other.

This tructure is called a Joynt, the Nature of which, is much controverted amongt Anatomits; ome contending that the touching of two bones one with another, makes a Joynt; others, beides touching, ad motion. So that it is the movable touching of two bones, which makes a Joynt.

If Motion be removed from the Definition of a Joynt, Galens Doctrine may eaily be defended. He contitutes two kinds of Articulation; Diarthrois,
with mainfet Motion; Synarthrois, with Obcure, or no Motion: and he aigns the differences of Synarthrois, which are altogether immovable, to beConjunction of Bones is either by Articulation the Differences of which are Diarthrois & Synarthrois. Sutura, Harmonia, and Gomphois; with thoe which take away Motion in the Definition of Articulation, refer to the third peeies of Articulation, which they cal Neutral, or mean, between Diarthrois and Synarthrois. Some give it a new Name, Amphiarthrois, to wit, when the tructure is o Obcure, and the Motion o hidden, that you know not whether it appertain to Diarthrois, or Synarthrois. But that place of Galen being il undertood, deceives many Anatomits. This Doctrine of Galen eems more probable, thus.

The bones are knit together by Articulations, and Symphyes: Articulation, is the knittings, or touching of two bones; the differences of which are Diarthrois, and Synarthrois; the one hath evident Motion, the other Obcure, or none at al; and therefore the differences of each, are equal: but the one, for example ake, is called Enarthrois Diarthrodes, with a manifet Motion; the other Enarthrois Synarthrodes, with an Obcure Motion;The common pecies of which are. 1, Enarthrois. Judg the like of the other differences.

Enarthrois, is when a large, and long Head, goes into a deep Cavity; which eeing it is common both to Diarthrois, and Synarthrois, we wil give an example of them Both. The Motion of Enarthrois Diarthrodes, is manifet in the Joynt of the Ichium: the Motion of Enarthrois Synarthrodes, is Obcure in the Articulation of the Ancle with the Scaphois.

When a depreed, and plain Head, is received by a hallow and uperficial2. Arthrodia. Cavity, this Joynting is called Arthrodia. an exemple of Arthrodia Diarthrodes, is in the conjunction of the Shoulder with the Omoplata. An example of Arthrodia Synarthrodes, is in the Bones of the Writ, with the Metacarpus.

Ginglymos, is a mutual ingres of the bones, uch as you hal uually ee in3. Ginglymus. the hinges of Doors and Windows; in which that Part of the Hinge which bears and that which circles about, have a Mutual ingres one into another. The Motion of Ginglymus Diarthrodes, is manifet in the Elbow; the Motion of Ginglymus Synarthrades, is Obcure in the joyning of the Ancle to the Heel. Modern writers add a fourth to thoe three, which they cal Trochois, in which the Motion of converion is apparent: uch is the joyning of the firt Vertebra with the econd, but it is to be referred to Arthrodia; As for what belongs to Ginglimus, and its various differences, we wil thus Methodically handle them: Ginglimus is an Articulation of bones, by mutual reception;Which is Simple or Compound. and is imple, or compound: that is called imple, which is made of two bones, by one only and imple Articulation in the ame Part, as in the juncture off the Elbow and Arm. Compound Ginglymus conits of a double Articulation, which is performed either in the ame extremities, or in places ditant, of two or three Bones, which by a double Articulation end in the ame extremities. It is een in the Vertebrae of the Neck. A compound Ginglymos by a double Articulation in places ditant is een in the Cubitus and Radius, in ditant places of three bones is een in al the Vertebrae of the Back and Loynes.

Beides Synarthrois, containes under it, Harmonia, Sutura, and Gomphois, Proper pecies of Synarthrois. 1. Harmonia. which are without Motion. T. 15. f. 3. R. &c. Harmonia, is a Conjunction of bones, by imple touching without mutual ingres; and is ditinguihed by a Line, either right, or oblique, or many fold. f. 4. a. b. Sutura, is the joyning of bones: as though the Teeth of two Jawes, or two Combs were thrut one within the other, and is altogether of one and the ame form. Gomphois, is when one bone ticks fat, and immovably in another, like a Naile in a Pot.

Oppoite to Articulation; is Symphyis, which is an immovable conjuntion3. Gomphois. Or by Symphyts whoe differences are three. of bones, as though they were united, which Nature brings forth at firt
divided, yet afterward in proces of time, they grow together. Som are united without any dicernable f. b. m. n. o. Medium, others with a Medium interpoed. And therefore, the imple differences of Symphyis are three; Syarcois Syneurois, Synchondrois. A mixed or compound Symphyis; is only one, viz. By a Nerve and Cartilage, which Galen cals Neurochondrodis. See ch. 5. Lib. 6. of this Book. Of thee you may ee more in. Com. at Gal. Lib. de Oibus.

According to Galen, I thus expound the Doctrine of Joynts, Methodically.Galens Doctrine of Joynts. The Conjunction of al Joynts is made by the touching of their extremities: This touching is either Articulus or Symphyis: Articulus is a Natural joyning of Bones; which are divided amongt themelves, to the ame ue, for which they were formed; this ue is either for Motion, or perpiration, or paage of ome ubtance, or ditinguihing of parts, or to ecure them from hurting, as apeares by the Articulations, Harmonia, Sutura, and Gomphois. Symphyis is a Natural Union of bones which were at firt divided, which grow together either with, or without an apparent Medium, becaue it is Obliterated, as in the Sternum, O-acrum, or Ichium, and the bony portions of the inferiour Jaw: and therefore the Conjunction of bones is divided into Articulus, and Symphyis, as it were into two pecies. Otherwie if Symphyis, be taken according to the mind of Modern Anatomits, and not according to the mind of Galen, whereoever Articulation is, there mut Symphyis needs be; for the Collection of bones, and Galen had ridiculouly oppoed Symphyis, to Articulation.

div.head: Chap. 7. The Diviion of a Sceleton.
div.p: THe whole Fabrick of the bones ticking together, is by Galen, called SCELETOS, It is vulgarly divided into the Head, the trunk and the limbs. Hippocrates, in his Book of the Nature of bones, contitutes ix parts of the Sceleton; The Head, Neck, Breat, Back-bone, Hands, and Feet. Galen, into five, the Head, Back-bone, Breat, Hands, and Feet, as may eaily be gathered from the eries of his dicoure, We follow the common diviion, and according to the example of Galen, begin at the Head, which is the firt bone formed by Nature; and as it were the foundation of al the ret: which are framed in repect of largnes, according to the proportion of the Head.

div.head: Chap. 8. Of the Head, being the firt Part of the Sceleton.
div.p: THe Head is defined by Galen, to be that whole ubtance which is aboveWhat the Head is. It's Diviton. What the Skul is. the Neck, and the dwelling place of the Brain.
It is divided into the Skul, and the Face, which latter comprehends both the Jaws.

The Skul, is a globous, and round body; hollow within, but this roundnes is not exactly, poehircal, by Reaon of thoe Eminencies, which tick out before, and behind, which make the Skul omwhat longih, and compreed on the ides towards the Temples. If the Skul be not omwhat longih, it isIts Natural • igure. depraved and this depravation is four-fold. 1. When it ticks not out before, 2. When it ticks not out behind. 3. When both Prominencies, are deparved, and then it is exactly round, 4. When its Longitude is turned into Latitude, which is inconitent with life, becaue the Structure of the Brain, is perverted.

Not only one Bone, but many make the tructure of the Skul, the numberThe number of the Bones of the Skul: of which is various in Authors, Galen Atributes even thereto, and Sylvius follows him: others hold 14. As Bauhinus, by adding the ix bones, of each eare, which are Parts of the rocky bone, and included in the Cavities of the Eare, and add nothing at al to make the globe of the Scul. But more rightly Paraeus ads fourteen bones to the Skul, but ditinguiheth them, into containing, and contained, the containing are eight, the contained are the ix mal bones, of the Eares. Hippocrates, Lib. de O. Contitutes the Skul o • eight bones, and yet he eems to comprehend ome bones of the Face, this number the mot excellent Anatomits follow; as Vealius, Columbus, Fallopius, from whom we wil not dient, becaue this number our Eyes can witnes, in Diections.
The intervails, or connections of thoe bones; are called Suturae, whichSutura what. knit and unite the Bones together.

Of Sutura's, ome are Proper, others common: They are Proper, whichHow manyold. Proper are. Three true ones. 1. Coronalis. 2. Lamdoides. 3. Sagittalis. ditinguih the bones of the Skul one from another: they are common, which ditinguih the bones of the Skul from thoe of the uper Jaw. The Proper are divided into true, and fal • e: the true, are the Saw-like Conjunctions of the bones intertexed, like the Teech of a Comb. They are held by Anatomits, to be in number three. 1. T. 15. f. 3. aaa. Coronalis is on the forepart of the Skul, which paeth tranverly from one temple to the other. 2. oppoite to this is, f 4. bb. Lambdoides, placed in the hinder part of the Head. 3. f 3. bb. f 4. aa. Sagittalis knits both thee together, paing from the top of the Lambdois, by the longitude of the Skul, and omtimes comes even to the top of the Noe. The concoure of the agittal and coronal uture, the Greeks cal Bregma; commonly 'tis called Fontanella, to which we apply cauticks. Above the Ears, are to Sutures not like others, and therefore they are called fale, or Batard; they are called F 15. f. 3. cc. Squamoae, from their caly likenes, and joyn the bones of theTwo fale ones. Common are three. 1. Frontalis. 2. Sphenoidea. 3. Ethmoidea. Temples, to the bones of the top of the Head. Modern Anatomits hold the common utures to be three: The firt is called T. 15. f. 3. Supra K. Frontalis, beginning at the outward Angle of the Eye, and paing by the middle of the Orbita, even to the Eye-brow, and keeps the ame way by the other Eye. The econd is called T. 15. f. 5. aa. f. 6. oo. Sphenoidea, which Circumcribes the O-phenois, beginning at the hinder par • of the Head, and ending at the furthermot Tooth of the upper Jaw. The third is called f 4. AB. Ethmoidea, and compaeth about the Os Ethmois, on every ide; it eems rather to be Proper than Common, and belongs rather to Harmonia than Sutura.

The Sutures being wel known, 'tis an eaie matter to ditinguih the bonesThe Eight Bones of the Skul. of the Skul; which are eight in number, and omtimes nine when the Sagittal Suture paeth to the Notrels, and paeth through the middle of the Frontal bone; which is often een in the Skuls of uch as are grown up: al of them are Proper, none common, unles the Sphenois, according to Galen.

1. The bone of the f. 3. D. Forehead ditinguihed by the firt, Common, and coronalOs Frontis. Suture, which omtime is Cut into two part sby the Sagittal Suture is that Eminent eat of the Eye-brows; it includes two Cavities derived into the Notrels.

The Second and third are called the bones of the f. 6. cc. f 3. d. fote part of the Head, andOs Sintipitis. are eperated from one another by the agittal Suture; below, by the Scaly Suture; before by the coronal: behind by the Lambdois.

Under thee are the bones of the f. 6. DD. Temples, which on the uper part ar • attenuatedThe Bones of the Temple. like a Scale, but the inferior Part is hard, and rough, and called rocky; therefore it is commonly divided into the Scaly, and Rocky Parts.

In the Rocky part are four Apophyes; l f 6. EE. f 3. F. Matoides T. 15. f. 5. • f. Styloides and T. 20. f. 6. A. f 3. B. Lygomatica; Its Apophyes. and the fourth is placed in the bais of the Skul, and may be called f. 6. B. C. Auricularis; in little Children it is an Epiphyis, and may eaily be pulled off from the Rocky Bones.

In this lat Apophyis, are the three Cavities of the Eare contained: TheThe Cavities of the Eare. 1. paage of hearing. 2. Concha 3. Labyrinthus. 4. C • clea. Os Occipitale. firt is external, and called the f. 7. ABC. Paage of hearing, The econd is called f. 6. B. Concha, and containes the internal Aire, and the three mal bones called f. 9. BB. Malleolus Incus and Stapes, as alo a hole paing into the Cavity of the Matois. The extremity of this Cavity is directly oppoite to the Timpanum and hath two mall holes; of which the greater is called the f. 6. C. oval window and is the ingres into the third Cavity, which is called the f. 9. AA. Labirinth, by reaon of its various Circulations and turnings; the other hole is narrower, and is the Paage to the fourth T. 15. f 4. C. Cavity which is called f. 5. B. f. 6. F. Cochlea, from its rough and wreathed Figure.

The ixt bone of the Skul is called f. 5. Supra inferius B. Lambdoides and Occipitale, and is compaed about with the Suture Lambdois, the Extremities of which, are called Horns by the Antients; but by Galen, Aditions to the Lambdois. To thee are Cauticks omtimes applyed.

The eventh Bone is f. 5. aa. f. 6. G. H. Sphenoides; in which we mut conider the external,
• s-Spheneides. and internal table: In the internal table, are three Apophyes, which are called T. 15. f. 6. G. H. Clinoides; between thee is a Cavity i • terjected, which is T. 15. f. 5. B. called Sella Its Apophyes. Sphenoidis. The external Table hath fo •…
Apophyes; of which, two reembling the hollownes of a hip, are called T. 15. f. 5. CC. Naviculares, by Galen they are called Pterigoides: the other pas under the Zygomata, to the Temples, and are called Temporalls. Between the two Tables, or Plates, is an empty ibid. Cavity paable to the Noe by a double hole, and evered within by a Bridg in the midt; this is alwaies wanting when the bone of the Forehead is ollid.

The eight bone is called Ethmoides, or according to Galen Spongides; itOs Ethmoides. conits of even different portions, The firt is pierced thorugh like a T. 15. f. 6. I. Sieve: from which, within the Skul, arieth an Apophyis, which is the econd portionTabula cribroa. Crita galli. of the bone, and is like a T. 15. f. 5. CC. Cocks Comb; without the Notrells, from the ame Sieve-like Table, depends that bony ubtance, which makes the f. 5. aa. bridg between the Notrels; and this is accounted the third portion of the bone: ToSeptum Na • . Two Spongy Bones. this Bridg of the Noe, tick two Spongy bones, which make the fourth; and fift part of the Ethmoides: The ixt, and eventh p •… ions of the Ethmoides, are thin Scales, plain, and mooth, as broad as a mans Thumb; which make the internal ide of each Orbita, beide the great Canthus, and underneath they cover three, and omtimes four cells, dipoed from the great Canthus, even to the lower-mot Orbita.

In the bais of the Skul, both internally and externally, certain Cavities are oberved; of which ome are called Sinus, others holes, others Foa or pits; of which, ee Sylvius, who was the firt that handled them Methodically: we give them here Names according to their places, and Natures.

The Sinus are eight; two Maxillares in the uper Jaw, as many Frontals Eight Sinus. in the bone of the Forehead, o many Sphenoides in the bone Sphenois, and no fewer Maiioides in the Apophyes of the Matois.

Holes are internal, or external; Internal are twenty five commonly, omtimesHoles internal. 27. twenty even; twelve or thirteen on each ide, and one without a fellow; which gives Egres to the Marrow of the Back. The firt, is f. 5. aa. Ethmcides; the the econd, f. 5. bb. Sphenoideus; the third, f. 5. cc. Opticus; the ourth, f. 5. dd. Sciura Orbitalis; the fift, f. 5. ee. Temporal, from the nerve of the third conjugation which paeth to the temporal mucle; the ixt, f. 5. †† Gutativus; the eventh, Gutativus Secundus; the eight, f. 5. hh. Cervical; the ninth, Caroticus; the tenth, f. 5. ibid. Aridi • orium; the Eleventh, T. 15. oo. Jugulare; the twelfth, f. 16. BB. Motivum Linguae, or Linguoum; the thirteenth, and lat, s Impar, or Occipitale. The externalExternal holes. 10. holes are ten on each ide, according to Silvius; to which I ad an eleventh, to wit, the external hole of the Eare; beides, a • the Root of the Stilois, in the extremity of the auricular Apophyis, on the external part, is a hole divided into two within, divided with a very thin Scale. Of the external holes
the firt is called, Superciliare: the econd Lacrimale, the third, Orbitarium externum; the fourth, Orbitarium Ethmoideum; the fift, above the palat; the ixt in the extremity of the Pallat; the eventh, the cleft under the Zygoma; the eight, and ninth, Supra Pterigoides; the tenth Matodes; the eleventh, the external hole of the Eare.

The pits are internal, and external: ix are in the internal bais of the Skul;Pi • s internal External. two frontals, two temporals, and two occipitals. The external are even on each ide, to which I add an eight, to wit, the Cavity of the Noe: The firt, Orbitaria; the econd, Naalia; the third, Zygomatica, the fourth, above the Pallat; the fift, under the Pallat; the ixt, Pterigoidea; the eventh, in the joynting of the inner jaw; the eight, in the hole of the ixt Conjugation.

div.head: Chap. 9. Of the uper Jaw.
div.p: THe other Parts of the Head, is called the Face; it comprehends both Jaws,The Fa • e what and is eparated from the Skul, by the firt common Suture.

The uper Jaw conits of many bones, about the number ofHow many Bones in the uper Jaw. which is ome controverie amongt Anatomits; but paing by the vain and foolih opinions of modern Authors, I admit only of Eleven, paing by thoe portions of the Ethmoides, which • ome Anatomits reckon for everal Bones: for thoe Bones only belong to the Jaw which are eparated from the Bones of the Skul; neither are portions of them, but ome of thoe bones contained within the Orbita, and form the Orbita of the Jaw; with other bones are portions of the bones of the head, as the productions of the Sphenois, the broad portion of the Ethmois; and therefore they are Childihly referred to the Jaw.

If any object, That they do belong to the Jaw, becaue they are beneath the common Suture that divides the Skul from the Jaw; wherefore eeing they are placed Beneath the aid Suture, they may be attributed to the Jaw. But if the Apophyes of the bones of the Skul, which tick out beyond the roundnes of it, be referred to the Face; by the ame rule the Apophyes, called Pterigodes, which tick out without the Globe, and r • t • ndity of the Skul, and are placed in the Same plain with the Vomer, and the Angles which utain the Jaw, are to be reduced to the Jaw it elf. And when Galen reckons the Os Sphenois amongt the bones of the Jaw, he reckons it as a Supernumerary. And therefore we mut reckon but Eleven bones of the Jaw.

Five bones are placed on each ide, and one without a fellow, which utainsThe firt Bone of the Jaw. the midt of the Pallat. The firt, Galen Lib. de O. Cals T. 15. f3. E. Melon: It may be called Zygomaticus, becaue it contitutes the greatet part of the Zygoma, and a great part of the Orbita, and Angles of the Eye: now Zygoma, is nothing ele than a bony Semicircle made of two Apophyes, by the oblique Suture; of which the one paeth from the rocky bone; the other from the bone of the Cheek. The Second is called f. 3. G. Os unguis, or Oiculum Lacrimale. The • .
The third is called the f3. I. greatet bone, and containes the middle part3. of the Teeth; and finiheth the inferior part of the Orbita, and the internal part of the Noe. The fourth bone forms the f. 3. K. Noe, and o the Noe is formed4. of four bones, two are Proper, which we mentioned lat; and two common. Modern Anatomits ad the bone called f. 6. j. Vomer, which is placed under the Sphenois, and Palat, which was not unknown to Hippocraces. It is like a Plow-hare, and holds up the bridg of the Noe, to which it is Joyned by Sutura, or Harmonia.

div.head: Chap. 10. Of the Orbitary Bone.
div.p: THe orbitary bones, which Hippocrates Lib. de Oibus cals Hypopia byThe Orbitary Bones of the Eye how many. which the Eye holes are made, were firt of al by Picolominus propounded to be five; but he ignorantly pretermitted a portion of the maxillar bone, which joyned to the ret makes ix, of which the hole of the Eye is made; but thee bones are not Proper, excepting the ungular, or Lacrymal bone, but partly portions of the bones of the Skul, partly portions of the bones of the uper Jaw. The firt is the T. 15. f. 3. A. Frontal bone, which makes the fornace ofThe error of Picolominus, touching their number. this vault. The econd is a portion of the Sphenois, ituated in the deep external ide of the Eye hole, even to the leer corner. The third is T. 15. f. 3. E. Lygomaticum, which makes the leer corner, and the middle pavement of the Orbita, or Eye hole. The fourth is T. 15. f. 3. j. Maxillare. The fit T. 15. f. 3. G. Lacrimale. The ixt the Scaly table, of the os Ethmois which makes the other ide of the Orbita, and the greater Corner: thee bones are to be dicerned within the Orbita, with their Proper and common Sutures.

div.head: Chap. 11. Of the inferior Jaw.
div.p: THe inferior Jaw in uch as are grown up, is but one bone; in which is toIts Parts. Bais. be noted, its bais, and its extremities. Its bais is the middle part of it, hollow within ticking out outwardly and is called the T. 15. f. 3. L. Chin. The extremities are Angles, each extremity leads out two Apophyes, of which one isApophyes. Sharp called T. 15. f. 3. M. Corone, and receive the tendon of the temporal Mucle; the other is a f. 3. N. Condyle, and may be called Articulatoria, becaue it erves for Articulation of the Jaw. Below thee Apophyes is a Singular f. 3. Infra M. hole by which Veins, Arteries, and Nerves pas to the Teeth; one portion of which paeth back again, neer the f. 3. L. l. Chin; and is dipered to the Mucles of the Lips.

div.head: Chap. 12. Of the Os Hyois:
div.p:
THe Os Hyois may be refered to the bones of the Head, becaue it is fatnedIts parts. by Nervous bones to the Apophyes of the Stylois. It is Compounded of five mal bones, of which that which is greatet and hollow is called the T. 13. f. 11. 12. A A. bais,Bais. they which ad a ixt and a eventh bone undertand the Ligaments wherewith this bone is tyed which as they are uually Nervous, o in ome they are oberved to be Cartilaginous. From the extream parts of the greater and Fundamental
bone, one Cartilaginous T. 13. f. 11. 12. B B. Horn, which is eldom bony, prings on the top,Horn. on each ide it is fatned to the Cartilage Tyrois, which two Horns are uually numbred for the eight and ninth bones.

The Os Hyois is the foundation of the Larinx and Tongue and by the Judgment of al Anatomats receives the Tongue in its Cavity, but if a man may beleeve his ownEror of Anatomits. Eyes, they wil hew him that the Epiglottis only is received in its Cavity, and that the Tongue reteth on the uper ide of its Bais.

div.head: Chap 13. Of the Teeth.
div.p: THe Teeth, are the intruments of Chewing the Meat, and forming the voyce.Their Nature They are bones although they differ in Nature from other bones.

They conit of two parts, one of which ticks out without the Gum, and is calledParts, Bais and Root. the Bais. The other is hid within the Gum, and called the Root, the Root is not ollid but hollow, and o hollow, that it receives a mal Vein, a mal artery, and a mal Nerve.

The Roots of the Teeth are various in number and divere in figure. The RootThe number of the Roots of the Teeth. of the Cutters is alwaies imple and right, ditinguihed only with a mal cleft for their firmer ticking. Alo the Roots of the Dog-teeth are imple. The uperior grinders have a threefold Root and Crooked, becaue they hang downwards, in the inferior grinders they are double and omtimes treble.

The number of the Teeth is various in regard of Age. In Children from theThe number of the Teeth. eventh Month even til they are two years Old and upwards; twenty of them uually come out by degrees one after another, and before they are wel towards four years of Age, they have no more, afterwards eight, or twelve others come out: So that they have twenty eight, or thirty two in both Jawes.

This number is ditinguihed into three orders by reaon of their Situation andTheir Orders. bignes, the firt four Teeth are called T. 15. f. 6. M. Cutters. Thoe two which are next thee, one on each ide, are called T. 15. f. 6. n. Dog-teeth. The ret being eight, or ten, are called T. 15. f. 6. oo. Grinders, They are placed in the Cavities of each Jaw, which Cavities are not continual but divided into Cells, and their conjunction, or Articulation is called Gomphois.

div.head: Chap. 14. Of the Trunk, being the Second Part of the Sceleton.
div.p: THe Trunk comprehends the Back-bone and uch bones as are fatened thereunto.Of what is conits.
It is compounded of the Back-bone and the Chet.

The Back-bone is a bony Channel which gives paage to the Marrow of the Back,The Backbone what. and is tretched even from the Head, to the Os Coccyx. It conits of very many bones for its ecurity and that it may not eaily be hurt, as alo that a man may bow himelf, for neceity of action, thee bones the Greeks cal Spondils, and the latins Vertebrae.

In every Vertebra you may oberve two parts of which the one is internal, thick andTwo parts of a Vertebra. round, and is called the body: the other external with various Apophyes and hath no Name, the differences of the Apophyes are three, right, Oblique, and tranvere,Difference of the Apophyes. the hindmot is harp and is Properly called T. 2. f. 2. d. Spina that which is f. 2. bb. Lateral, and tranvere is double, the f. 2. c c c c. Oblique fourfold by which they are joyned together by Ginglymos in which three bones are required.

In the Oblique Apophyes two are above, and as many below; and therefore in al the Vertebrae, are even Apophyes found. The whol Rachis or Back-bone, is divided into four Parts. The Neck, Back, Loyns and Os Sacrum: The Neck hath even Vertebae, the Back twelve, the Loyns five, the Os Sacrum is either one, or three-fold in uch as are grown up; in Children it is divided into five or ix Parts: Wherefore the Back-bone in uch as are grown up, is compoed of twenty four Vertebrae; to which, if you add the Os Sacrum, which is a great Vertebra, it makes twenty five or twenty even. The crooked-treight Figure of the Back-bone, which is admirably decribed by Hippocrates in Lib. 3. de Articulis, from vere 33. to 35. Cannot be noted in a Sceleton, though never o exactly made; but in aThe Vertebrae of the Neck, Carkas the Fleh of the Back being taken away it may; in the Vertebrae oft lie Neck, this peculiar thing is to be noted, That al the tranvere T. 13. f. 20. bb. Apophyes are peirced through, that o they may give paage to the cervical Veins and Arteries; they have Cavities in the extremities, through which the Nerve being yet oft, is deduced: The f. 21. b. hindermot Apophyes, are double, for the rie and inertion of Nerves; but the two uperiors have another tructure and conformation, by reaon of the motion of the Head; for the firt wants a f. 20. Spina, and hath a thick round Body; the econd ends out a f. 21. • . Tooth like Apophyis. Al the Vertebrae of the Neck are tricktly joyned and implicated let they hould lip a • under in the vehement Motions of the Neck.

The twelve T. 10. f. 3. Vertebrae of the Back, are altogether one like the other: their Apophyes The vertebrae of the Back. are al ollid, and continual, without any hole or diviion. The twelfth, or eleventh Vertebra, hath a different Articulation from the ret; al the ret are joyned by Ginglymos; the eleventh, or twelfth, only by Arthrodia. And therefore the whol Motion of the Back-bone, bowing, extending, and Obliquation, is performed by that Vertebra.

The five Vertebrae of the Loyns, differ in Apophyes from thoe of the Back; forThe Vertebrae of the Loyns. the hinder Apophyes, or T. 2. f. 2. d. Spinae, do not decend as they do in the Back, but are traight, and broad: the T. 2. f. 1. aa. tranvere Apophyes are longer, and tand intead of Ribs.

Under the Loyns is the T. 2. f. 5. 6. Os Sacrum, which though it Seem one imple bone at theOs Sacrum. firt view, yet being boyled a long time in Oyl, it is divided into five parts, and omtimes into ix.
To the extremity of the Os Sacrum, is another cartilaginous bone joyned, whichCoccyx. is divided into three, eldom into fo •… Parts and is called T. 2. f. 5. bb. c. Coccyx, the Crupperbone.

div.head: Chap. 15. Of the Chet.
div.p: THe Chet, together with the Back-bone, make up the trunk of theThe Breat what. Sceleton.

The Chet is a bony Circumference, which holds the vital Parts, and is contitutedIt is four-fold. of a four-fold kind of bones; the Sternum before the Ribs on each ide, the Claviculae at top, and the Back-bone behind, to which the Ribs tick.

The T. 10. f. 2. A A. Sternum or Bret-bone, in uch as are grown up, is one only continuedThe Sternum. bone, ditinguihed by three or four tranvere lines, which are but the footteps of the Antient divi • ions; and thee lines are more conpicuous on the inide, than on the out. On the extremity of this bone, depends the Cartilage or Gritles calledThe Cartilage called Swordlike. The Ribs. f. 2. B. Xyphoides, or the word-like Cartilage; it repreents a Shield in bruites.

The Ribs are twenty four, twelve on each ide; of which, the even uper mot are called f. 2. 1. 2. 3. 4. 5. 6. 7. True, becaue they are committed to the Sternum; the other five inferior
are called f. 2. 8. 9. 10. 11. 12. Batard, becaue they are never joyned to the Breat-bone, but are joyned in a Cartilage, that they may the better give way to the wellings of the Liver and Spleen, and yeild to the Motions of the Diaphragma.
The f. 1. f. T. 21. f. 2. A. Claviculae are two, one on each ide; whoe Figure repreents an Italica Clavicul • . S. They retain the Scapula in its Proper eat that it fal not upon the Breat.

div.head: Chap. 16. Of the Limbs, being the Third Part of the Sceleton: and firt, of the Scapula.
div.p: SEeing the Scapula Omoplata, or houlder-blade, belongs nothing at al to the contitution of the Breat, I eperate it from the Trunk, and et it at the beginning of the hands. In the Omoplata many Parts come to be noted for the originalIts Parts. and Inertion of Mucles. A very Neceary Part of the Omoplata being tretched to the Longitude of the Back, is called the T. 21. f. 2. hh. Bais, the extremities of which areBais. Angles. called Angles; one is f. 2. f. Superior, the other f. 2. g. Inferior. The Bais is the ides of the Ribs; of which, the one is horter and thinner, which is called the f. 2. ab. f. ad. d. Superior Rib; the other longer, and thicker which is called the f. 2. ag. ad. • . Inferior Rib. The wholRibs. Latitude of the Scapula is called the table; The ex • ernal Part of which, is Gibbous;Proces. the internal hollow, that o it may receive the Mucle. The famous proces or Apophyis acending upwards from the bais, is called f. 2. e. Spina, the broad extremity of which, is called Acromium; which according to Galen and Hippocrates, is a ditinct bone, and Cartilaginous in Children; but hard, and bony, in uch as are grown up. Which after the twentieth year, and omthing ooner is turned into an Apophyis of the Spina. The pits on each ide of the Spina are called Intercapulium; one pit is above it, the other below it, but the middle prominence of the Spina Pit • . which is bowed, is commonly called Pterygium or the crit. The other extremity of the Scapula, which is great, ubject to the Acromium, and oppoite to the Bais, is called the f. 2. c. Neck; in it you hal note, that Apophyes called f. 2. d. Coracoides, which was made for the ecurity, and firmnes of the Joynt of the Shoulder, the Cavity of the Neck, is called Glenoides.

div.head: Chap. 17. Of the Shoulder.
div.p: THe Arm hangs upon the Omoplata or Scapula, which is divided into threeThe three Parts of the Hand. The Head of the Bones of the Shoulder. Parts; the Shoulder, the Cubit and the Hand. In the Shoulder are two extremities for the inertion of Mucles; the upermot is called the Head, which a membranous Ligament, bred from the Cavity of the Glenois, compaeth about, beides the four Mucles which it involves: a little below this, the Orbicular narrow place, is called the Neck: In the Head is a long Chink, by which the NervousThe Neck. Head of the Mucle Biceps arieth. In the other extremity of the Arm, you may oberve the Trochlea, about which the Cubit is turned: About the Trochlea areTroclea Cavities. Apophyes two f. 2. f. Cavities, of which the external, is wider than the internal; in thee are the Coronal Apophyes of the Cubit received: with the Trochlea are two Apophyes, which are called Condili the one inferior, and interior; the other uperior, and exterior.

div.head: Chap. 18. Of the Cubitus, and Radius.
div.p: THe econd Part of the hand is called Cubitus, & conits of two bones; of which the one which is uperior and horter, is called f. 2. E. Radius; the other, which isRadius Cubitus why there are two bones. inferior, and ubject to the former, is called by the Name of the whol f. 2. D. Cubitus, and by ome lna. Two bones are neceary in this Part of the Arm by reaon of their double and contrary Motions, which could not be performed by one bone united by Ginglymus; for Ginglymus uffers only bowing and extending, and in no wie invertion; which the Radius being joyned by Arthrodia performs. The Obliquation of the Radius cannot perfectly be dicerned unles in a new carcas, all the Mucles being taken away; for with great admiration you hal ee the Radius turned about, upward and downward, upon the Cubit, being unmoved and alo moved together with the Cubitus, when it is bowed and extended.

There is omthing worthy the noting in the extremity of the Cubitus: For in the uper extremity, is the Cavity, called Sygmoides, which embraceth the Trochlea ofCavity. Apophyes. the Arm; about this, are two Apophyes, called Corone; the lowermot is called T. 21. f. 2. g. Olecranum: In the inferior Part the Cubitus, is an Apophyis, which is called f. 2. e. regione. Styloides; the extremities of thee bones alone, are joyned together by that Ginglymus, which coniteth of two Bones, paing into one another, in divere, and ditant places.

div.head: Chap. 19. Of the Hand.
div.p: THe Hand is divided into three Parts Carpus, Metacarpus, and the Fingers.Diviion.

f. 1. FF. f. 2. F. Carpus conits of eight bones, ditributed into two orders, which are joynedCarpus. amongt themelves by Symphyis, by a kind of Harmonia; becaue the bones of the Carpus are moved the one from the other, either obcurely, or not at al: the firt order makes Arthrodia Diarthrodis, with the inferior Cubit; the ame order is joyned with the econd order of the bones of the Writ, or Carpus, by Arthrodia; which econd order is joyned with the Metacarpus, by Arthrodia Synarthrodis: So that this Motion, is either none at al, or inenible; but the firt order with the econd is moved obcurely.

The T. 21. f. 1. GG. f. 2. G. Metacarpus, ucceeds the Carpus, and is framed of five bones, if we addMetacarpus. the firt bone of the Thumb, which ome reject, becaue it is Obliquely added to the Metacarpus, and endewed with manifet Motion and contrary to the Nature of other bones of the Metacarpus, which make Arthrodia with the Writ, and Enarthrois with the Fingers; and yet the fourth bone of the Metacarpus, which utains the Ring Finger, hath manifet Motion.

From the everal bones of the Metacarpus, are everal F. 8. f. 12. CDE. Fingers tretched; onlyFingers. the Thumb excepted, the Fingers conit of three bones which are joyned to one another by Ginglymos; and therefore they admit only of bowing, and extending; the oblique Motion of them depends upon the Enarthrois of the firt bone with the Metacarpus.

div.head: Chap. 20. Of the Bones of the Ilium.
div.p: THe greatet and larget bones of the body, which being joyned with the Os Sacrum, utain and erect the whol Trunk, are by the greatet Part called Osa Ilium: In uch as are grown up, they are one bone but in Children divided intoT. 8. f. 12. CDE. three parts; which yet hold their antient appellations, though the very FoottepsIts Parts. of them be obliterated by Age. The broader Part of the bone which frames the latitude of it, and is tretched out to the middle of the funnnel; is called T. 2. f. 3. A. Ilium; Ilium. Pubis. Ichium. the other halfe, and uperior Part, is called f. 3. C. Pubis; the other inferior Part f. 3. BB. Ichium: Of thee three portions, is made that great hole called the T. 21. f. 4. B. the Funnel.

In thee bones ome particular things are to be noted; for Anatomits call the external Face of the Os Ilium, the Back; the uperior internal Cavity, they cal the Belly; the extremity of which, is called the Reb; the brims of which, both external,Back. Rib. Lips. and internal, are called Lips, or Brows, o as one is external, the other internal. The extremity of the Rib, which ticks out, and is joyned to the Os Sacrum, is called the hinder Spine. And the other T2. f. 4. aa. extremity of the Rib towards the Funnel,Spines. is called the foremot, upermot Spine. There is under this, another called the former and nether Spine.
In the Os Pubis, a Spine is oberved neer the Spmphyis, by its top: In the Ichium, a Spine, and a Bunch is noted; which Bunch is called Condylus.

div.head: Chap. 21. Of the • Bone of the Thigh.
div.p: THe Feer, as wel as the Hands, are divided into three Parts; the Thigh, Leg, and Foot.

The Bone of the Thigh is but one, and the greatet in al the Body. In the uperiorThe Thigh Bone. Head. Neck. Apophyes. excremity, the T. 21. f. 1. dd. f4. a. Head is round, to which a lender part is added, called the Neck: from the Neck are two Apophyes produced, to which, the Mucles called Rotatores, are fatned; and therefore they are called Trochanters; the foremot is called the leer f. 1. gg. f4. c. Trochanter; the upermot, on the ide, the greater f. 1. ff. f. 4. b. Trochanter. The other extremity of the Thigh, hath two f. 1. hh. f. 4. ee. Condyli: a f. 4. d. Cavity being left between, which admits the f4. f. middle, and eminents Apophyis of the Leg; and in like manner the Condyli are received by the f. 1. hh. f4. ee. Cavities of the Leg, by a looe f. 8. cc. Ginglymus, the fore Part of which, is called the Knee, the hinder Part the Ham: thisKnee. Ham. Knee-pan Articulation is trenghtned before, with a mal bone, called the f. 1. LL. f. 8. d. Knee-pan, which is Articulated to no bone.

div.head: Chap. 22. Of the Leg.
div.p: THe Leg is compoed of two bones; of which, the greater, and internal, isTwo Bones of the Leg. Tibia. Fibula. called f. 1. M. f. 4. D. Tibia; The leer, and external, f. i. M. f4. D. Fibula. The Fibia is Articuluted by Ginglymos to the Thigh; the Fibula ticks to the Tibia, and toucheth not the Thigh. The inferior, and bunchy Parts of them both, are called Ancles; of which, the Fibia makes the f. 1. ii. f4. gg. internal, and the Fibula, the f. 1. KK. f4. h. external.

div.head: Chap. 23. Of the Foot.
div.p: THe Foot is divided into the Tarus, Metatarus, and Toes. The Tarus Diviion. Tarus. conits of even Bones, which Ruffius Epheius cals Otracodea, by reaon of their hardnes: The firt Bone Articulated with the Tibia, is called Atragalus, or f. 5. A. Talus: The Bone under this, Pterna, or f. 5. B. Calcaneum: The third joyned to the Atragalus, Schaphoides: The fourth f. 5. C. Naviculare; to which is joyned the inner, and foremot portion of the Heel, which is called f. 5. D. Cuboides; the other three have no Names, or Ele are called f. 5. eee. Calcoidea. The f. 4. g. Metatarus follows the Tarus, and is formed of five Bones, and anwers to the Metacarpus of theMetatarus. Toes. Hand.

The Toes ucceed the Metatarus coutituted of f. 4. three Bones apiece, except the great Toe, which hath only two Bones: mal Bones fil up and trengthen the internodes of the Fingers and Toes in uch as are grown up, which are uncertain in number, and called T. 21. f. 6. Seamoidea.

In the econd Articulation of the great Toe, are two mal Bones worth the noting, and indifferent big, which are alwaies found in al Carcaes, and two at the original of the two Mucles of the Feet, mentioned by Vealius, which are but eldom found, and are to be numbred with the Seamoidea.

div.head: Chap. 24. In what Particulars the Bones of Men differ from thoe of Women.
div.p: THe Bones of Men and Women, differ in ome parts, which Platerus firt noted,Thoe which differ are. and Bauhinus follows him; but by their leaves, they noted many differences which are not found, and omitted ome that are: we hal peak of them both everally.

It is true, al the bones of Women, are les then thoe in Men, both in weight, andIn Subtance. of the Bone. thicknes, as alo in length. Galen adds they are not o hard, but faith, that in al living Creatures, the Bones of the Females, are ofter then thoe of the Males; and Aritotle held o before him.

The bones of the Head, are altogether alik, having neither more, nor fewer Sutures;The Bones of the Head. although Aritotle thought otherwie; Namely, that Males had more Sutures then Females, Ch. 7. Lib. 1. de hit. animal. and 7. Lib. 3. ejud, operis, and Chap. 7. Lib. 3. de part animal. Yet the T. 15. f. 3. bb. Sagittal Suture, more often in Woman, paeth to the Nae, dividing the f. 3. A. Bone of the Fore-head in the middle.
It is fal • e that Aritotle held, Viz. That Males have more f. 6. mno. Teeth, then Females,Teeth. as is cleer in Men, Sheep, Hogs, and Goats.
The T. 13. adf. 10. Larinx (if it may be numbred amongt the Bones) is les in Women, andLarynx. the Cartilage f. 8. A. Thyroides, ticks out les.
