The T. 10. Bret in Women is depreed in the fore part, and ticks not out as it dothBreat. in Men, for the more accomodation of the Dugs.
The T. 21. f. 1. R. Claviculae in Women are not o crooked, for the more comlines of theirClaviculae. Neck and Breat.

The inferior Part of the T. 10. f. 2. AA. Sternum, is broader then in Men, and many times hathSternum. a manifet hole in it; and the lower Bone upon which the f. 2. B. Sword-like Cartilige depends, is clet like a crecent Moon and makes a large hole for the Egres of the Mammaria Interna.

It is fale that the f. 2. CC. Cartilages, which in men become bony about the forty orCartilages of the Ribs. fifty yearts of their Age, become bony in Women o oon as their Breats grow; Though it be true in Women when they are old.
In Women with great Breats, Thorax is narrow, and almot poynted, by reaon of the weight of their Breats.
That Part of the Back above the Loyns, is no more bowed Backwards in Women, then it is in Men.Back.
The T. 2 f. 5. and 6. Os Sacrum is horter, broader, and more bowed outwards in Women,Os Sacrun. then it is in Men.

The Os f. 5. and 6. b. c. Coccyx, or Crupper Bone, is more movable, and not o trongly knit,Coccix. and more bowed Backwards in Women; not according to the opinion of Galen, but of Later writers. Galen: Lib. 1. de Semine.

The Buttocks of Women are broader and according to Aritotle, Lib. 4. de hit animal. Women are tronger in their lower Parts, and therefore the Os f. 3. and 4. A. Ilium Buttocks. mot commonly is larger, but that largnes bends more outward; by which means the Oa Ilium are more hollowed outwardly.Os Ilium.

Upon this largnes of the Bones, the Womb when it is great with Child leans as it were, upon Pillows, and its as it were in a Saddle. Elegantly aid Galen Lib. 14. deuu Partium, when he called the concoure of thee Bones with the Os Sacrum, THE GREAT BONY VAULT or Arch. The oval hole is Smaller in Women that the portion of the Os Pubis, neer the Symphyis, may be larger; butOs Pubis. the Spina of the Os Pubis is turned outwards.

The inferior, or tuberous Parts, of the f. 3. 4. b. Os Ichium, it fitted with a doubleOs Iehium. Cartilage, thicker ofter; and this commiure is perfected by a hort line, that in the travail, it being oftned and looed, the Bones of the Pubis may part.

The pace between the Os Sacrum, Ilium, and f. 3. 4. C. Pubis, where they are joyned together, is arger in Women then in Men, leat the narrownes of the Paage hould hinder the comming out of the Child. The ret of the tructure of Bones in Women, is like thoe in Men.

div.head: Chap. 25. Of the number of the Bones in a Mans Body.
div.p: THe number of the Bones of mans Body amongt Anatomits is uncertain Vealius held 307. Galen 242. But in the Sceleton of a perfect man, there are two hundred and fifty ix neceary Bones for the tructure of it; which are thus numbred. Of the Skul, eight; of the upper Jaw, eleven; of the nether Jaw, one; of the Os Hyois, three; Teeth, thirty two; Back-bone, twenty four; Os Sacrum, three; Coccyx, three; Claviculae, two; Ribs, twenty four; of the Sternum, three; of each Hand, divided into four Parts, ixty two; Omoplata, two; Armes, two; Cubits, four; both Writs, ixteen; both Metacarpus, eight; of al the Fingers, thirty; of each Foot, divided into four parts, ixty two; Namely the Bones of the Ilium, two; Thigh, two; Legs, four; Kneepans, two; Tarus, fourteen; Metatarus, ten; Toes, twenty eight.

Beides thee Bones, where of the Sceleton is made, there are eighteen other manifet mal Bones, In each great Toe four, Seamoida; in the Head of the Mucles, called Gemeli, on each ide, four. The ret of the Seamoida are o mal that they conum or vanih away in boyling the Bones to make a Sceleton.

There is in each Eare three mal Bones, which ought to be kept apart with the Seamoida; neither come they into the tructure of the Sceleton. So that if you add the firt number to the econd, you hall find two hundred and fifty ix Bones.

div.head: Chap. 26. The History of an Infants Bones, till the Age of even years.
div.p:
SEeing the Bones of Infants, from their Birth til even years of Age, differ much from the Bones of uch as are grown up, both in number, and figure, and
epecially in the Multitude of Epiphyes, and deectof Apophyes, therefore I thought it wel worth the while, to ad the Bones of Infants, to the Bones of men grown up, that the difference between them may apear more evidently, for this comparion makes much to take away the differences amongt Anatomits; and to unty the difficult knots, you hal find in Galens Doctrine of the Bones.

That this Oteology, was known to Galen, is manifet by various places in him; in which he declares the Bones of Infants, in his Book of the formation of the ChildIs Ancient. in the Womb, he decribes the Head of the Infant, In the firt book De emine, he treats of the Teeth of Infants, but before Galen, Hippocrates, was a diligent tudier and oberver of this Oteology; as his divine monuments of the Nature of Children, and of their breeding Teeth witnes.

And the profit of this Doctrine is very great: not only in the education of Children,And profitable. which are marred, by the unskilfulnes either of the Midwife, or Nure. We ee divere Children at this day Borne, with great Heads, Bunches, Bow-Legs, great Ancles, Vneemly knees, and at lat are Lame when they begin to go, which deformities in the beginning of their Age, whilt their Bones are oft, may be amended, and how can a man amend them rightly, unles he know the Bones at that time exactly?

Excellently aid Galen, in Lib. de cauis Morborum Chap. 7. When he decribeth the deformities of Bones, which are in Children. The Natural figure, (aith he) of the members, and of the whol Body, is changed either in the Womb, or at the Birth, or after the Birth; It is depraved in the Womb when the formation is vitiated, by reaon of abounding, or unfit matter, It is depraved in the Birth, when the Midwife takes it not righly, or binds it not up rightly, being born, after the birth the Nure, in taking of it up laying it down, or carrying of it, or wahing of it, or binding it up; in al thee the Nature of every member is eaily turned out of its coure, and corrupted. Thee alo happen in unfit Motions, whilt it is et to tand or walk, before its time, or expoed to vehement Motions. For uneaonable, and vehement motions weaken the Limbs, and the Legs, are turned inwards or outwards by the waight of the Body; and thoe Limbs which hould be traight are made crooked, the Parts of the breat are uually inverted by Nures, by binding them too bard, in their firt education; this we ee almot continually in Virgins, whilt Nures tudy to encreae thoe parts, which are about the Hips and Bowels that, they may exceed the bignes of the Breat, they bind the Parts about the Breat o vehement heard, that the breat becomes harp, and they look as though they were broken backt; and omtimes are crook Shouldred.

You ee by Galen, what mieries and deformities little Children are ubject too; by reaon of ill forming the Bones, which may be corrected whilt they are Young, and Flexible, and brought into what form you will.

Hippocrates Lib. de Septimetri Partu, gives the reaon, why Children are Born Blind, Lame, or other wile ill formed The Women that go with uch Children are ill, or like to micarry, in the eight month, for the maimed Embrion was greavous Sick, in the eight month; and the Dieae, Caued, Impotumation, as it doth in men, but when the Embrion is main ick, at any other time it rather dies then uffers Apotumation: Hitherto Hippocrates, and Aritotle writes Sect. 10. Probl. 40. That Children may be hurt in the Womb, becaue their Legs are o tender.

The greather Bones of Infants are hollow, and the Marrow Bloody. After ixThe Marrow of the Bones Bloody. Months, the Marrow waxeth white, they have a Periotion, and a Cartilage at the ends, the extremities of the Bones, are Epiphyes, ome few Apophyes they have, but a great number of Epiphyes, that according to Ingraias they amount to, three hundred twenty one. But I think tis no uch matter, neither indeed, have I yet been very ollicitus about, the counting of the number.

I never oberved any Bone, of any bignes or length; which ended not in anTheir Epiphyes. How they wax hard. Epiphyes; now al the Epiphyes of Infants are Cartilaginous, and grow hard and are turned into Bones by degrees: Their hardnes begins not at the Bone, to which
they are joyned, but they take their bony ubtance firt at the Centre beginning at the internal part and encreaing by degrees to the external. Or from the Centre to the circumference, outwardly they grow dry and hard by heat which is tirred up by Motion and rubbing the Joynts one againt another in walking.

div.head: Chap. 27. Of the Head.
div.p: THe Sutures of the Head eem to be rather Harmonioe, ditinguihed by aThe Sutures Line, and not joyned together like Teeth of a Saw by mutual ingres. The joynings of the Skul are looe, o looe that they uffer the Dura Mater to pasSagittal. out for the forming of the Pericranium. The Sagittal Suture alwaies paeth to the extremities of the Notrils, but very eldom decends by the hinder part of the Head to the hole of the Marrow of the Back. The coronal Suture hath a membranous gaping at which place the pulation of the Brain may be both een and felt, this place is vulgarly called T. 15. f. 4. C. Fontanella Coronal. Fontanella.

The temperal Bone eeing it is framed of two parts caly and rocky, the parts of it are ditinguihed by Harmonia, which is not dianulled above the hole of the Eare, but beyond it, about the Apophyis Matois.

The Bones of the Skul are very thin, neither hal you find the two tables or platesBones of the Skul. Their thicknes. in them, before one year be Elaped, between the Bones is ome diparity becaue the Bones of the hinder Part of the Head are the thinnet, contrary to what they are in uch as are grown up, at the concoure of the agittal and coronal Suture is a cleft called Rhomboides, which a thick and hard membrane huts and grows bony in proces of time.

The T. 8. f. 4. A A. Frontal bone is alwaies two without any inuous Cavity, the bone of theOf the Forehead. hinder Part of the Head in Children new born; mot commonly conits of four bones even til they are a year Old. The firt is the whol and uperiour breadth of the bone which compaeth and embraceth the Cerebellum, this is rarely divided, and yet there is a certain cleft in the top, caued by the agittal Suture produced thither. The Second and third portion make the ides of the hole of the Marrow of the Back, and the middle part of the Circle. The fourth bone is placed in the extremity of this, and makes a portion of the great hole, this as yet I never oberved. A tranvere Line interects the circle as though it were two. The Bones of c Bregma, atBregma. the concoures of the agittal and coronal Suture, are imperfect by reaon of the Fontanella.

The Bones of the Temples are manifetly eperated into two Parts, caly andBones of the Temples. rocky, neither the Epiphyis called Stylois not the Apophyis called Matois appear in it, only the Zygomatica is een, but that part of the rocky Bone ubject to the hole of the Eare, makes the bais of the Skul, it is called next to the Sphenois and next to the Lithois by ome, but may be called Auricularis, becaue it comprehends the whol tructure of the Eare, in Children it is an Epiphyis which eaily is evered, and this is often oberved in the Sculs of bruit Beats that are grown up,Paage of the Eare. in which not with tanding it is other wie framed.

In this auricular Epiphyes many things come to view, the paage of hearing is altogether Cartilaginous, about the fift or ixt month it begins to be bony, and yet it may be eperated even to the eventh month, but in the bais it is hollowet; even to the third year and longer.

But proceeding inwards to the extremity of this paage their is a bony f. 4. B B. circle toBony Circle. which the Timpanum is fatned, this alo is eaily evered, but when the paag of hearing grows hard, the bony circle is o trongly knit to it, that it is ineperable. The T. 8. f. 5. Cavities are very traight, neither can the admirable tructure of the Labyrinth be perceived in Boies, and yet that which is wonderful the three little Bones of the Eare f. 7. and 8. Malleolus f. 6. A. Incus and f. 6. A. Stapes, are of the ame ubtance, bignes and form, even from the birth to extrame Old Age.

The Os Sphenois is divided into four Parts according to Fallopius of which theOs Sphenois.
proces called Pterigoides, contitute two; the eat which receives the Glandula Pituitaria, a third; The fourth part is ubervient to the optick Nerves, which portions grow together, not long after the Nativity: but Fallopius very ill decribed thee portions of the Sphenois; for the third comprehends the eat, or Saddle, and alo is ubervient to the optick Nerves: The fourth is treched out below the Saddle, even to the Corone of the hinder part of the Head, and that diviion remains Conpicuous, even til three or four years be paed. In this Bone, are no winding Cavities; and the Os Ethmois, is totally Cartilaginous; the bridg of the Noe is bony at firt, but grows hard along time after the other parts.

In the Eye-hole of uch as are grown up, are ix bones noted, Zygomaticum, The Bones of the Eye-holes. Sphenoides, Frontal, Ethmoides, Lacrymal, and Maxillare: The portion of which makes the pavement in Children, and is evered with a kind of Suture, which remains even till three or four years of Age.

The Lines, or Harmoniae of the upper Jaw, are like thoe, in uch as are grown pper Jaw. up, a certain cleft only apears in the brim of the Inferior Orbita. In the beginning of the Pallat is a tranvere line epied, which is tretched from one of the Teeth, called Cutters, to the other; and comprehends the four Cutters. As for the bones they are like the bones of uch as are grown up, both in figure, number, and Scituation. The Jaw-bone is not hollow, and the cels of the Teeth are covered, and as it were topped up with a membrane.
The f. T. 8. f. 6. C. Inferior Jaw in the midt, where the Chin is, is divided by Harmonia, andInferior Jaw. o conits of two parts, o continuing til two years be pat.

The Teeth are ingendred in the Womb, when the ret of the parts are ingendred;Teeth. but within the holes of the Jaws: they are in number twenty, ten in each Jaw; of which, are four Cutters, two Dog Teeth, and ix Grinders, they al want Roots.
They begin to pas out of the Gums about the eventh Month, omtimes ooner if the Nures Milk be very hot. Some few have Teeth when they are borne as, Cneus Papyrius Carbo and M. Curtius.

They do not break out altogether, but by degrees, in two years pace; and theAt what time they apear. upper Teeth uually, come out ooner then the lower: firt of al the Cutters, afterwards two Grinders, then the Dog Teeth; the breeding of which, is mot painful to Children.
When Children have twenty Teeth, then they uually ay, they have al their Teeth; neither indeed have they more, before they are three or four years of Age.

But when Anatomits ay, that there is only twenty Teeth contained in the Gums, They do not tel you where the other Eight or twelve reide; neither dothWhere the hinder Teethly. it eem like a truth, that new Teeth hould be bred after the other are formed, and lie hid in the Gums. In the upper Jaw I have oberved the other four, or ix, hid under the Zygoma; but thoe of the lower Jaw under the extremity of the ame, where they lie hid like points. Under the coronal Apophyes, becaue the pace of each, eems at the Narrowet, to comprehend twenty eight, or thirty two Teeth.

Neither do thee eight or twelve Teeth break out before the Jaws are made larger,When they break out. which hapen about the fourth year of the Age: but contrary to the Nature of other Teeth, they continue as long as life continues: neither do they come out, as the other twenty teeth do; neither being plucked out, do they grow again.

Their generation is two-fold; one in the Womb, the other without the Womb;Their generation. for in the Womb the Teeth are formed with the other parts, but are imperfect. Within each hole, is contained a Mucous, and hardih ubtance, concluded in a little white Membrane, which grows dry, and take a bony Nature by degrees, and to get out pierceth the Gum with its top; the Membrane compaeth the hole round, and like Glue retains the Tooth: The other portion, namely, the Root of the Tooth, remaines til within the hole, being oft and Mucous, as the Feathers of
Birds are; but it grows hard by degrees, and is parted in the middle, into three or, four Rots.

Under thee Teeth, in every hole, is ubjected the Seminal matter of another Tooth, a Membrane paing betwen them; which whilt it is fermented by the formative faculty, and growing up, it expels the former. This econd matter thus included with a membrane, hath deceived many Anatomits, which thought the Teeth conited of two Parts; and that other Part of the Tooth, was an Epiphyis of the Root: therefore Vealius, and Columbus, held the Teeth in Children, ought not to be pulled out by the Roots, but tranverly to be broken off, as thinking that a new Tooth grew up from the ame Root, which could never be, if the former were pulled up by the Root. But Celus in my Judgment wrote more truly, that there was a new Tooth in Children, which did expel the former, and omtimes grew out beides it, either aboue, or below it.

The middle part of the Hyois, being the bais of the whol bone, is Cartilaginous,Hyois. but oon becomes bony; and yet the ides remain Cartilaginous a good time.
b T. 8. f. 4. G.
k T. 8. f. 4. D.

div.head: Chap. 28. Of the Back and Breat-bones.
div.p: THe Back-bone conits of twenty four Vertebrae, the Os Sacrum excepted! alThe Vertebrae of them for one years pace, are divided into T. 8. f. 9. A B C. three parts, the two firt of the Neck excepted: the firt part contitutes the Body; the other two make the ides of the hole, neither do they end out any proces. Fallopius hath een the firtFallopius his Obervation. Vertebra of Children contituted of five parts; but the ret, of three only. The firt part was where it was joyned with the Tooth of the econd. Vertebra, called Pyrenois; the econd, and third parts, were on the ides, in which both the uperior, and inferior Cavities of the Joynts were; the fourth, and fifth parts perfected the ret of the hole. The econd Vertebra of the Neck, beides the three parts common with the ret, hath a fourth eminent Epiphyis, called Pyrenois or the Tooth.

In al the Vertebrae, the hinder part is f. 11. Acute, and altogether Cartilaginous, and then grows bony, and like an Appendix is joyned to the other parts. The tranvere procees, are alo Cartilaginous, but oon acquire a bony Nature.
The Os Sacrum conits of f. 12. B. five Vertebrae, with Cartilages between: So as theyOs Sacrum. may eaily be dicerned the one from the other: the hinder harpnes is totally Cartilaginous.

Al the Vertebrae conit of three parts, as al the Spines of the Vertebrae. The Os Coccix is altogether Cartilaginous, and undivided; Age divides it into threeOs Coccix. or four parts, which remain Cartilaginous til even years be expired.

The extremities of the Ribs that are f. 10. 11. A. joynted to the Back, are altogether Cartilaginous,Ribs Sternum. yet they oon grow hard: the Sternum of Infants, is at firt. Cartilaginous, and yet divided by no line, and yet the Superior are Sooner bony, then the inferior, and the middle parts of them before the extremities, whence it comes to pas that the bony part is compaed about with a Cartilage one each ide, and reembles o many bony Knots in a board.

So oon as the Child is born, the inferrior part of the Sternum is Cartilaginous, and hath no diviion; then it grows bony, as I hewed you before; at lat it is cut into ix particulars, by a tranvere line drawn from the Cartilages of the Ribs, to which you mut number that which is by the Sword-like Cartilage.

Fallopius in his Obervations, notes eight bones in the Sternum of Children whichFalopius his Obervations. afterwards are brought to even, the two lat being reduced into one: afterwards they are brought to fewer, ix only apearing by that time the Child is even years of Age; and though Fallopius think ix alwaies remain, yet I have alwaies oberved fewer.

Fallopius thus decribes the Union of the bones. After even years the bones of the Sternum are joyned together and become fewer by degrees, o that ix only apear, one bone being made of the fourth and fifth and another of the ixt and eventh. Beides this Union increaing, there are only four found, the third fourth fifth ixth and eventh growing together. Of the Sternum of Infants Read Sylvius, com. ad ch. 2. Lib. Gal. de Oibus.

div.head: Chap. 29. Of the upper Limbs.
div.p: IN the Omoplata both Apophyes, and Epiphyes, are Cartilaginous, aloScapula. the Neck with the Cartilage Glenois are of the ame Nature. The eminence called Coracoides is an Epiphyis, yet the bone Acromium doth not eem eperated but it is an Apophyis incru •• ed and terminated with much Cartilage, which is dryed after three or four years, and changed into a bony Epiphyes. called Acromium, as it is, decribed by Hypocraetes and Galen, at lat that Epiphyis is turned into an Apophyis.

T. 8. f. 13. a b. The appendices of the houlders in each extremity are Cartilaginous, and grow hard by degrees. Alo the Trochlea is Cartilaginous, but is ooner turned into bone then the uperior parts: the uperior part of the Cubit called Olecramen, is an Epiphyis and after one years time grows hard and is joyned to the bone.

The T. 8. f. 13. c. bones of the Writ when the Child is born: are compoed of one Cartilage,Writ. afterward they grow bony and are ditinguihed from one another. But firt they are pongy as the ret of the bones are, which from Cartilages become bones. The eight bone of the Writ, turns bony lat of al.
The extremities of the f. 13. d. bones of the Metacarpus and Writ are Cartilaginous,Metacarpus and Fingers. which are hardned within les then a year.

div.head: Chap. 30. Of the Inferior Limbs.
div.p: THe Ilium in Children is compoed, of three bones even til they are even yearsIlium. of Age, to which the Ancients gave proper Names. T. 8. f. 12. C C. The firt bone comprehends that widnes which paeth to the midt of the Funnel, the other part is equally divided into two parts, a line being drawn by that Cleft of the Funnel Cros the Oval hole, and makes the Symphyis of the Os Pubis, the uperior Part of this diviion is called T. 8. f. 12. D D. Os Pubis, the inferior f. 12. E E. Os Ichium, the Lips of which arePubis. Ichium. Cartilaginous.

f. 14. a. b. The Thigh on the uperior part ends out three appendices; a Head, and twoThigh. Trochanters which remain Cartilaginous Epiphyes, a good time, the inferior part of the Thigh hath two knobs, the appendix in Cartilaginous.
The Knee-pan at firt is totally Cartilaginous; and is a long time ere it growPatella. bony.

The bones of the Tibia and Fibula, differ nothing from thoe that are grown upTibia. Fibula. ave only in their appendices, both above and below, which are Cartilaginous, then grow hard, and remain eperated even to the tenth year and upwards.
In the Foot al the bones of the f. 14. c. Tarus are Cartilaginous for ome months, theTarus. bone of the Heel excepted which is Bony within, though covered with Cartilages, without.
The Seamoides remain Cartilaginous almot to conitent Age, two only excepted,Seamoides. which are in the firt Joynt of the great Toe, for thee grow bony preently after the Birth,

div.head: Chap. 31. Of the Number of Bones.
div.p: INgraias, Propounds a fourfold number of the bones of Infants, the firt containsThe Number. two hundred thirty even. The econd three hundred fourty five. The third two hundred fifty nine. The fourth one hundred ninety two. But this lat Number I doubt is devied, or ele I do not undertand what Ingraias means.
Thee Numbers he thus compoeth.

In uch Children as are grown up are found three hundred five bones, in the Head eventy, to wit, eight in the Skul, twelve of the upper Jaw, one of the lower Jaw, ix of the Ears, thirty two Teeth, eleven mal bones of the Os Hyois, which al joyned together make eventy. The Trunk comprehends ixty even, Vertebrae twenty four, Scapulae two, Ingulae two, Sternum three, Ilium two. Thee joyned together make ixty even. But if the Os Sacrum conit of five and the Coccyx of three, (as often it doth) then there wil be only ixty ix. In both hands, eighty four, (adding the twenty four Seamoides) in both Feet eighty four, the twenty four Seamoides being alo added, the total Number of bones wil be three hundred and five; form this Number if you take away thirty two Teeth which doth not appear in Infants, the reult is two hundred eventy three, although the Teeth being formed lie hid in the Gums, yet becaue there is no ue of them, they are not reckoned amongt the bones.

In reckoning the econd Number he proceeds thus, the Vertebrae of the Back-bone and Os Sacrum in Infants are divided into three Parts, the econd excepted which is divided into four by reaon of the Teeth, the Ilium is divided into three bones the Sternum into eight, the inferior Jaw of two, and the Frontal bone is double.

Thee diligently conidered you hould find amount to eventy two, which added to two hundred eventy three make three hundred fourty five, from which if you take away the bones which deerve rather the Names of Cartilages than bones, as the bones of the Writ ixteen, of the Intep eight, of the Coccyx four, Seamoides fourty eight; each Knee-pan and Hyois eight (the three mal bones remaining) which are in number eighty ix, there remains two hundred fifty nine. In thee Numbers the three hundred fitty one Appendices are not Numbred which if you ad to three hunded fourty five, the Body of the Infant wil be compoed of ix hundred eventy Bones.

div.trailer: The End of the Firt Book:

div.head: THE SECOND BOOK OF ANATOMY AND PHYSICK, OF John Riolanus.
Chap. 1. General Precepts, which he that would be an Anatomit, mut be firt Acquainted with.
div.p: SEeing that according to Aritotle Chap. 1. Lib. 1. pot. Analyt. Every Doctrine and dicipline which conits in reaon and intelligence, is perfected by fore-knowledg, and Tullius Lib. 1. de nat. Deorum, aith that without fore-knowledg, neither any thing can be undertood nor tudyed, nor diputed. Before I et about my Anatomical work I thought good to premie certain general Precepts, which are the foundations of Anatomy, and wil give great light to our proceeding.

The Body of man is conidered by Anatomits as compoed of manyHow Anatomits Conider the Body of Man. Parts, which they examine Limb by Limb, and by a diligent Diection, they divide the whol Body, into its mallet Parts. They divide it firt into three grand Parts, Containing, Contained, and Impelling; that is into the Parts, humors, and Spirits. But in the Anatomical diection of a dead Body, the HumorsIts Parts. and Spirits, are not conidered, the Speculation of which belongs to Phyiology, only the Sollid Parts are regarded, which are either uch as make, or uchSollid Parts how many fold. as contain Humors and Spirits or the intruments of Motion, which is the Chief Action of a living Creature, for which it was made. The ollid Parts are imilar or diimilar. They are called imilar Parts becaue they are mot imple, fromSimilar Parts what how many. which, as from a principle, the diimilar Parts are compoed. The imilar Parts according to Anatomits are Bones, Cartilages, Ligaments, Membranes, Fibres, Veins, Arteries, Nerves, Fleh, Fat. Thee are found almot in al Compound and diimilar Parts, and the Corpulency of the Parts is formed of them. The Hairs, and Naills are excrements of the external Parts: Therefore an Anatomit ought to
be wel intructed what thee imilar Parts are, that when he earcheth out the tructure of the organical parts, Limb by Limb, he may know the Fundamentals of this tructure.
1. A bone is a part of the Body, mot cold and dry, Terretial; and therefore1. A Bone. hardet, that o it may prop up the other parts of the body.

2. A Cartilage, or Gritle, is not o hard as a bone, which in Old Men omtimes2. A Cartilage. degenerates into a bone: The Cartilages are placed about the extremities of the bone, to eae them in their Motion; ome are found eparated from the bones, as the Cartilages of the inferior Jaw, in the Articulation of the Claviculae, in the Sternum, in the Articulation of the Tibia to the Thigh; beides the Cartilages of the Larinx, Wind-pipe, and uch as are placed to prop up other oft Parts, as the Notrels, and Ears.
3. A Ligament, or bond, is a part which binds the bones together, being of a3. Ligament. middle ubtance, between a Cartilage, and a Membrane; ofter than a Cartilage, harder than a Membrane.

4. A Membrane, Skin, or Coat, is very oft, and ubject to dilation. It is the4. Membrane. covering of other parts, or the Receptacle of omthing; as the Stomach, Bladder of Gal: I • being a hollow body, it receiving omthing, it may be called Tunica, a Coat; If it Embrace and cover a ollid body, it is propperly called Membrana.

5. A Fibrae is like a threed tretched over a Membrane, or Interwoven therewith,5. Fibra. to trengthen it: and becaue of its various Scituation, it is called Right, Oblique, and Tranvere; not only to help the Membrane, but alo to trenghten it. Every ort of Fibres, is thought to perform a everal action; as the Right, to draw to; the Tranvere, to retain; and the Oblique, to expel. Which Motions notwithtanding, abolutely depend upon the inbred faculty of the Part; which as it hath a violent dilation, o hath it a willing, and Natural contraction, and is helped in thee by the Fibres.
6. A vein, is a Membranous Veel, round and hollow, allotted to contain6. A Vein. Blood, and ditribute it for the Nourihment of the whol Body.

7. An Artery is a Membranous Channel of the ame Nature, but omthing7. Artery. harder, and thicker; ordained for the containing and Ditributing of the Arterious blood: The original of both which, Aritotle thought was from the heart; but wier Phyitians, hold the beginning of the Veins to be in the liver; but of the Arteries in the heart.
8. A Nerve is a Channel made to carry animal Spirit; and becaue this pirit is8. Nerve. mot ubtil, therefore the Cavity is o mal, that it is not dicernable.

9. The Fleh is the foundation of organical, and diimilary Parts, where bone9. Fleh. is wanting, and makes up the chief Part of our bulk. The fleh is in ubtance, oft and thick; made of blood alone, compacted together, and wel concocted, if it be red; but of blood, and Seed, if it be white.

A four-fold ort of fleh, is oberved in the Parts; Vicerous, and Muculous, both of them very red; Membranous, and Glandulous, both of them white. For every ubtance of the bowels is called Fleh, or Parenchyma. The thicker ubtance of certain Membranes, which are the containers of omthing, which by dilating and contracting their bodies, they attract, retain, and expel, are alo called Fleh, or a Fleh-like ubtance. The thick, and pongy ubtance of the Glandulae, is called Fleh; but epecially the ubtance of the Mucles deerves the Name of Fleh.

10. The Fat although it appear not til the whol body be formed, and when the10. Fat. Child is big, and grows to the Parts; yet becaue in the compoition of organical Parts, it often concurs to make up the bulk, it is Numbered amongt the imilar Parts. Fat is the thinnet ubtance of blood, Fat, and Oyly, weating out through the tender Coats of the Veins, and hardning between the Membranes: It is two-fold, according to Aritotle; Soft, and external; Hard and internal. The one is Greae, The other Suet.

Thee three imilar Parts; Bones, Cartilages, and Ligaments, hal be treated of, as they are hewed in a Carcas, from top to Toe, after we have hewed the Mucles; becaue they are o joyned together, that one cannot be hewed without another.

But I deire al uch as are tudious in Phyick, firt to be wel acquainted in the Oteology or Hitory of the dry bones in the Skeleton of a Man, before they come to the inpection of a Carcas; for o they wil the better undertand the whol anatomical dicoure of the diection, and find out the reaon of my other Oteology in the bones of Carcaes.

The Ret of the imilar Parts hal be hewed everally in the explication of the diimilar Parts, eeing of the imilary Parts aforeaid, viz. Bones, Cartilages, Ligaments, Membranes, Fibres, Veins, Arteries, Nerves, Fleh and Fat, the Bulk, or Material ubtance of the diimilar Parts, is made up, and therefore you hal hear imilary Parts often mentioned, in the explication of them; howbeit, in ome places they exit apart, no waies joined, or united unto others, to contitute an Organ; but are conidered with reference to their Particular ues.

But they concur together, and are united one with another, in organical Parts,Organical Parts, what? that they may perform their various Offices: for the effect of which, they are divided into four orders: For in every Organ there is the principal Part by which the Action is performed: Another, without which the Action cannot be done: A third, by which the action is preerved. But in every Organ, the principal Part ought to be imilar and proper to it, uch as is not found in another Organ. But this imilar Part cannot perform its action alone, unles it be helped by others; and therefore the concoure and Union of imilary Parts is neceary. Wherefore, every Movable action, belongs truly, and poperly to an Organical Part; and none unles it be alteration, belongs to a imilar Part; which out of the compoition of the Organical, hath only ue, which notwithtanding, it contributes to perfect the action of the Organical.

More over, organical Parts according to the dignity of their action, are dividedHow many. into Principal, and Adminitring. They are called principal, which upply the whol body with matter and faculty: Phyitians hold them to be three; the Liver, Heart, and Brain: Aritotle held but one principal Part of the body, viz. The Heart, which is King and Ruler of al others. The ret of the Parts Miniter, and are ubervient to the principal. According to the various compoition of the Organical they are divided into compound, more compound, and mot compound: For the Finger is compound; the Hand, or Foot, more compound; the Limbs, are mot compound.

But that we may eek out the tructure of eath Part exactly; we mut oberveWhat is to be oberved in each Part. the Name, Subtance, Temperature, Original, Scituation, Quantity, Number, Figure, Color, Connexion, Communion, Action, and e. Connection differs from communion; for Connexion is the ticking of one Part to anther, of one or more Parts by which they depend; it is omtimes taken for the Original of the part it elf, and yet the Original of ome Parts is ditinguihed from Connexion: But communion is either univeral, with Parts remote and neer, which is done by Veins, Arteries, and Nerves, by intervening of which, al the Parts have community with one another; or Particular, when ome Particular Part communitates its elf to ome neer, or remote Parts, and o the Gal communicates it elf by the Biliar paages to the Liver, and the Gut Duodenum: The Reins, and Bladder have communion by the reters. In this Method you may comprehend whatoever may be poken, or demanded of any Part: But in the Hitory of Parts we mut begin firt of al with thoe things that are common to the whol Organ, then with thoe things which are Proper to the ame Organ: but in decribing the Fabrick of the body of Man, we wil follow the common order of Diection.

div.head: Chap. 2. Of the Natural and Legitimate Conformation of the Body.
div.p: SEeing my deign and intent of handling Anatomy, doth not conit in a bear andThe necearines of it. imple comtemplation of the Parts of the Body, but is alo referred to the ue of Medicine; before we come to the diection of the body of man, we wil decribe in a few words the Legitimate and natural conformation of the Body of Man when it is alive, which is the bais whereby we judg of the Sicknees and imperfections of Men or Women: this was neceary of Old in buying of Servants, in joyning Men and Women in Marriage that they might have Children, and in chuing elect Men for Soldiers. And this knowledg is neceary even to this day; for in ome Monateries uch as deire to lead a Religious life, the Phyitian views them Naked from the Crown of the Head, to the Sole of the foot; and notes their repiration, and pule, and voice in inging. This is done in buying Slaves in divers Countries, and alo in buying Hores; and alo Nures are exactly viewed by Phyitians for the education of Children, I mean the Children of Princes.

Therefore in Man-kind, you may conider the difference of Sex: Subtance of Coniderations in a Man wel formed. Body, Temperature, Greatnes, Color, form, or Figure; as they are convenient in a perfect and wel formed body, that o by this, the difference of a body not wel formed may be known.

As for that which belongs to Sex, Man-kind is twofold: Male and Female. The Latin1. Sex. word Homo comprehends both: and a Women has been called Vira, and therefore a tout Women is called Virago: the differences of both I have Accurately expounded in my Anthopographiae. Lib. 2.
The ubtance of the Boby in Man ought to be flehy not Fat; firm and ollid, not2. Subtance. oft: the Limbs meanly hairy, for moothnes in Men, uch as is in Women, argues effeminate conditions.

A healthful temper ought to be hot and moit, becaue life conits in, and is3. Temper. preerved by uch a temper, yet is there a peculiar temper in every peron, which by Phyitians is called Idioyncraia; which if Galen could exactly have known, he would have thought himelf equal with Aeculapius: but we mut reduce this to the General. But by what igns this may be known, Galen hath declared in his little book of Art of Phyick, and other Authors.

The Magnitude of the body is threefold, according to the threefold Dimenion of4. Magnitude. the body. We hal conider cheifly the Longitude and Latitude: The natural and decent Longitude of the body ought to be four Cubits, the Latitude one Cubit as Goropius Becanus teacheth: this alo is confirmed by Vitruvius who defined the jut Longitude of the body of man to be ix Roman Feet. And Agellius Lib. 3. ex Varrone, Noted that the highet pitch of a Mans height was even Foot: but more Men are horter, than taller than this. Vegetius Writes that Soldiers ought to be choon ix Foot high, yet by Reaon of difference of ex, Region, and Dieaes, Men are either taller or horter, for each oyl hath its Particular Nature: o the people of Aia are taller than thoe of Europe, and in Europe, thoe of the North parts, as Denmark, the Low-Countries and thoe of upper Germany are tallet.
The various Menuration of bodies Hippocrates hath decribed Leb. de aer. aq. et loc. Commonly men are taller then Women; whereas in ome other living creatures, Foemales are greatet.

The Latitude or thicknes in a wel Proportioned body ought to be, almot half the Longitude, o that if the Longitude be ix Foot, the Latitude ought to be almot three: lendernes of body is ubject to Conumptions, neither can the body be trong and fit for labor unles it be thick.

In the bignes of the body is Magnanimity and beauty, quoth Aritotle, Ethic. Lib. 4. For a man of a little and mal body cannot be fair; yet if you regard,
undertanding, there is little Wit commonly in thoe Tal bodies.
Elegantly aid Celus, Lib. 2. Ch. 1. The bet dipoed body is wel et, neither lender nor Fat, a tal tature is comely in youth but not o in Age, a lender body is weak, a Fat body dul.

The Color of the body is diligently to be marked, for uch a Color as flouriheth5. Color. in the Skin and countenance, the ame is predominant in the Humors, and therefore anguine people are Red, Chollerick Yellow, Mellancholly Black or brown and dusky, Flegmatick are pale: a brown and ruddy Color are preferred before pale, which argues oftnes of body.
There is ome difference in Authors about the Color to be Choen in a Nure, Aritotle perfers brown, others a Mingled Color of Red and white.

Now the Natural and Legitimate form of the Head, Bret, Belly, and Limbs, is to6. Form. of the Head. be conidered. The Head ought to be round, and not Copped, unles the Neck be very thick: a great Head is preferred before a little one: from the Head ought the Nature of the Nerves, Veins, Fleh, and Humors to be collected.

A great Head requires a great Neck, which gives indication of a great breat, by reaon of the Parts contained in the Neck: a great breat makes a large belly, and therefore the proportion of the ret of the Cavities depends upon the Head.
The Chet ought to be large, of an Oval Figure, and the Back-bone traight, theBreat. breat ought to be omwhat convex, not harp, nor flat, nor depreed.

The Papps of Men, ought to be depreed, but in Women welling round, and Glandulous, rather than Fatty, or Flehy, becaue they are the Emunctories of the breat if the Woman give not Suck. If the Duggs be mal the Women are ickly, and if the Nipples look pale the Womb is Dieaed, according to Hippocrates.

Whether are large breats to be choen in Nures, or uch as are mean in bignes?What Breats are to be choen in Nures. Great breats pleae not Mochio, becaue they are Fat, neither have they plenty of Milk; and therefore Fat Nures are not to be preferred before uch as are Lean, and Juicy; neither uch as are tal, before uch as are of a mean Stature: Aritotle Lib. 3. de hit. animal.
White colored Women, becaue they are Flegmatick, have but bad Milk.

From the breat, we pas to the belly, which ought to be round and ticking out:Belly. Women that have uch bellies, the Poets praie, and ay Venus had uch a one. Hipp. Lib. de ve • Med. Notes that long and round bellies, ought to be conidered of Phyitians, becaue by looking upon them, 'tis eaie to know which are fit for trong Purgations; for uch whoe Parts in the Abdomen are trong, and wel dipoed, may eaily Purge; but uch as are lender, take trong Medicines with danger.
Very Fat Women are hard to conceive with Child, Hippoc. Aph. 4. Lib. 5.

As for what belongs to the Privities; Heliogabalus choe uch for Soldiers asPrivities. had large Privities, becaue he thought they were luty, tout Men. A very long yard is not fit for Venery, either becaue the trength of the Seed paeth out, by reaon of the length of the Yard, if you wil beleeve Galen; or becaue the Mucles are tyred, by erecting a great, and long Yard. A mean Yard is mot fruitful, andLimbs. gives mot & longet pleaure in the act of Copulation. A long Yard, though indeed it fil the Neck of the Womb, yet it makes it not o fruitful; and is hurtful to uch Women as are ubject to the fits of the Mother, by tretching the Genitals: Neither are the Teticles when they are great and Pendulous, to be commended.

We pas to the Limbs, viz. The Hands and Feet, which ought to be equal in proportion to the ret of the Body: The Longitude of the Foot, from the Os Pubis, to the extremity of the Heel, ought to be equal to that of the Hand, from the Ala, to the top of the middle Finger. If the whol body be ix Foot long, the Foot is three: both Hands and Feet, are omwhat flehy in trong bodies; for although lendernes of Legs be commended in Hores, 'tis not o in Men.

An example of a perfect and abolute body wel formed, is to be Read in Sidonius
Apollinaris, Lib. 1. Epit. 2. de Theodorico rege, wherein is one remarkable fault to be amended, not Noted by interpreters, for Excrementa read Extrema. Inter Extrema Cotarum pi • a dicriminat.

div.head: Chap. 3. The Diviion of Mans Body.
div.p: BEfore we expoe the whol Body of Man, to Anatomical diection, it ought to be divided into its Parts, or principal regions, that the Number and order of the regions, and where they begin, may be known.
A mongt the various diviions of the Body of Man, this in my mind eems theDiviion of the Body. bet, and to be preferred before the ret.
The body is divided into the Trunk, and the Limbs.
The Trunk is divided into three Principal Regions; the Head, Breat, and Belly.
The Head obtains the Superior place; The Breat, the middle: and the Belly, the lowermot.
The Members or Limbs are four branches ticking out from the Body, two Arms, and two Legs.
What are the bands of thee Regions, I hal hew, when I come to peak of each Region apart.

div.head: The Medicinal Conideration.
div.p: I wil not tand here in rehearing & deigning the external Parts of the whol body, which are expounded in every Region of the ame; but only conider the corporature, or flehy habit, which is covered with the Skin, like a Garment; which though it look for the mot part beautifully without, it looks ill favoredly within. This habit of the whol body, makes the third Region of the body, to which the Humors come from the deepet Parts; the ill effects of which, are cleerly een in the Dieaes, and Symptomes which appear outwardly. The juyce which is een in the leaf and branch comes from the Root.

I hal reckon up the cheife Dieaes which ue to infet the outward habit of the body. Viz. Immoderate Fatnes, or Leannes, Defluxions, Gouts, Dropy, Cachexia, the whores Pocks, Plenty, or defect of Sweat, by reaon of the opennes, or cloenes of the pores, Palie, Convulion, Unquietnes, and wearines and al kind of wellings.
The Fleh of man, becaue its Nourihed by purer Blood, is delicater than the fleh of other Creatures, and prefered before it by Canibals, or Man-Eaters.

Fleh, eeing it is Porous and Muculous, it hath empty paces, which in men in health are filled with pirit and blood, but in uch as are ick, with Water and wind; thence come Defluxions over the whol body, and other Dieaes of the Skin.

The Habit of the whol body, is Purged and emptyed by weating, by Cupping-Glaes, Scarrification, and Rubbing, according to the Doctrine of Galen, Lib. de Sanitate; by Bathings, Whippings, and Beatings, and blitering, and Rubifying, or Pimple-raiing Applications.

Therefore eeing the mal Pocks and Meaes, are but the cum of the whol habit of body, that is, of the Fleh, and ollid parts, their coming out is to be furthered, either at the beginning, or at any other time, with Sweating Medicamants, and uch things as draw to the external Parts. Neither need you let blood o often, though the Patient be trong, twice if need be, is enough, becaue it hinders the Motion of Nature in expelling, unles either a dead leep, or trangling with a Feaver, or bloody Flux, which is for the mot part deadly, draw us to that remedy; not neglecting young Pidgeons Cut alive through the middle, laid to the Hands and Feet,: and omtimes to the Heart, and mal Cupping-Glaes fatned al about the body,
with light Scarification. And omtimes bathing the Body in Luke warm Water profits, if the eaon of the year be convenient, to make the Meaes and mal Packs come out the better.

div.head: Chap. 4. Of the lower Ventricle.
div.p: THe Diection and Anatomical demontration, mut be begun at the belly, becaueWhy the Diection begins a • the lower Ventriole. it is the ink and Kitchin of the body: and therefore oonnet Putrifies and tinks.
It is called in Greek Coilia becaue it is coile that is hollow; in latin Venter, in Englih the Belly.
Its ubtance is flehy compoed of various imilar parts, which we hal propoundIts Subtance. in order hereafter.
The belly eeing it is a mot compound part, its own temperature is none at al, butTemperature. it follows the temperament of the parts contained in it, and epecially of the Liver.
It hath its Original from the firt comformation with the ret of the Parts.Original. Scituation. Quantity.
It is Scituated in the inferior part of the Trunk of the Body.
Its Quantity or widnes is from the batard Ribs, or Diaphragma to the Os Pubis or hare Bone; and with thee bounds it is Circumcribed above and below.

The whol widnes of the belly is ditinguihed into three Regions; the uperior called T. 1. f. 1. A. B. Stomacbal, the middle called f. 1. C C.
mbiliar, and the lower called f. 1. E E. Hypogatrica.

Again in every part, both the lateral and middle parts ought to be oberved; the lateral parts of the tomachal Region are called T. 1. f. 1. A B. Hypochondria, of the middle Region f. 1. D D. Ilia. The middle is called the infra. C C. Navil which is the centre both of the belly and of the whol body.

The lateral parts of the Hypogatrick Region are called f. 1. F F. Groyns, the middle f. 1. g. f 2. D D. Pubis, the hare which after the fourteenth year both in men and Women is adorned with Hair, as a natural covering for thoe parts, which the common Law of bahfulnes commands us to conceal.

In repect of number, the belly is but one; yet by the Peritonaeum it is divided into to Cavities; The greater holds the parts which prepare for nourihment. The leer holds the bladder, and Genitals in men; and the Womb alo in Women which never bear Children.

It is divided into parts containing, and contained. Parts containing, are proper,Parts containing. Common. common, and divere: common are five; f. 2. B B. Cuticula, or carf Skin; f. 2. C C. the Skin, f. 2. D D. the Fatty Membrane,
T. 2. f. 8. 9. the Flehy Membrane, and the Common Membrane of the Mucles.
Proper are, the Mucles of the T. 2. f. 3. and 4. Abdomen, and the T. 10. f. 10. O O. Peritoneum. Proper. Divere.

Divere are, partly Flehy, partly bony: bony are the T 23. f. 1. A. Vertebrae, and T. 14. f. 2. L L. f. 3. B B. Pelvis, which are parts of the Os Sacrum, and Ilium. Flehy are, the Mucles T. 14. f. 1. C C. D D. Poas, f. 4. B B. Sacrolumbus f. 3. D D. f. 4. A A. Latiimus, f. 2. O O. Sacer f. 4. C C. Semipinutus, T. 10. f. 1. N N. Quadratus. I cal them divere, becaue thoe bones and Mucles, being Scituared in the hinder part of the belly, do make omthing toward the contituting of the belly, though they are referred to another part, and pertain to another ue.

The parts contained, are manifold; which are divided into uch as nourih, andContained • Parts. Figure. uch as engender; uch as nourih are uch as make Chyle, and uch as make blood. The Genitals are of men, and of Women. The Figure of the belly, is Oval, by reaon of the parts contained; which if removed, it is hollow, that it may be the eat of the Veels dedicated to nourihment, and Generation; and therefore the latins cal it Abdomen, and the Greeks Epigatrion.
The color of the uperficies of the belly, is like the color of the ret of the body;Color. in men of ripe Age it is Hairy from the Pubis, up to the Navil.
It is outwardly knit to the breat, and inferior limbs by the Skin; inwardly byConnexion. the Peritoneum.
It communicats with the principal parts, by Veins Arteries, and Nerves.
The ue of the Belly is, to comprehend, and involve the parts of nourihment, e. and generation; take it individually, it conits of Muculous Fleh.
It hath action to compres the parts contained within its elf, for the expultionAction. of excrements, upwards and downwards; and to force the Child out of the Womb.

div.head: The Medicinal Conideration.
div.p: From this dicoure, a Phyitian collects many things, in his Practice, ueful. 1. That the Belly is the Sink of the Body, in which the vices of our intemperance reide; the Mother of all micheifs, and the Nure of Phyicians; in which condition 'cis called Collatibus Venter, an Aldermans Belly.

He whoe Belly grows to a great bignes, is called Ventrous, Fat Guts. Some we read of, whoe Bellies grew to a montrous bignes, as Nichomachus Smyrnaeus, in Galen; in Athenaeus, Lib. 12. Deipnoophit, we read of a King that was choked with fatnes. But famous is that Hitory in Michael Neander, in Erot. Hebr. ex. Talmud. in Jona. Rabbi. Imael, and Rabbi Eliazer, had uch great Bellies, that when they tood with their Faces together and their Bellies touched, two great Oxen might pas between them, and touch neither of them.

By reaon of the Flehy, and fatty ubtance of the Belly, it is ubject to divereSwelling in the Abdomen. wellings, Epecially Apothemes, either from the liver by the Vmbilicar Vein; or ele the matter is ent from the Suppuration of the Reins; which being hut up in the Doublings of the Peritonaeum, may end their impurities into the external parts of the Belly.

This flehy and fatty ubtance, ought to be mean; if it be greater, 'tis a dicomdityIts Contitution what it hould be. to life, if leer it hews an ill Dipoition of the Bowels: Therefore Hippocrates wrote, that in every Dieae, the parts belonging to the Belly, had better be om what gros, then to lender; for if they conume, tis very evil: therefore Phyitians were wont to handle the whol belly, epecially the Hypochondria, which ought to be oft, equal, and flehy.

div.head: The Scituation of the Parts in the Belly.
div.p: The largenes of the Belly is conidered, according to longitude and depth, thatThe Scituation of the Parts in the lower entricle. o the Phyitian may know in pains and wounds in the belly, which part is afflicted, or wounded.
According to depth, the parts are divided into upper, and lower; and therefore according to Hippocrates the pains in the upper part, are more light; thoe in the lower, more trong and dangerous.

According to Longitude by the diviion of the places, you may undertand by theViz. bare looking upon them, or feeling them with the hand, what parts are afflicted, pained, or wounded. In the right Hypochondria is the liver, which paeth even to the Cartilage Xyphois; It paeth a fingers breadth beyond the batard Ribs, on the ides forewards, two fingers. In the middle region, is the Stomach placed,Liver. Stomath. which inclines more to the left Hypochondrium, and decends four fingers breadth below the batard Ribs.
In the left Hypochondria, lies the Spleen, which Naturally hangs under theSpleen. batard Ribs, the breadth of a mans Thumb.

The umbilicar Region, the Navel poeeth, above which, is the Gut calledColon. Colon, tranverly eated; and in the whol compas of that Region, is the Gut called Jejunum, dipoed: Toward the Back-bone, are the Kidneies. The beginningJejunum. of the Colon being bowed back from the right Kidney, under the Liver and
Stomach, to the Spleen; afterwards paeth obliquely to the left Kidney: andKidneies. therefore the pains of the Colick, mut diligently be ditinguihed from thoe of the tone.
In the middle, and ide-Region of the Hypogatrick, in the Gut called Ilium concontained;Ilium. Bladder. Right Gut. In the bottom of the belly, the bladder, under which lies the right Gut.

In Women, the Womb lies betwen the bladder, and the right Gut: under theVVomb. Guts, lies the Meenterium, as the Sweat-bread doth under the Stomach. A little below the Navel, the Omentum is tretched about al the Guts, and divides all the internal parts with the Peritonaeum, from the external; thoe that lie deep, from thoe that lie at top.

div.head: The Medicinal Conideration.
div.p: In the Belly, are frequently al ortsof Tumors, Impotumes, Rumblings of theDieaes of the Abdomen. Guts, and Croaking; which proceed either from Tumors of the Parts conteined, or from wind, or collection of Water.

It is Cut on the ides towards the Hypogatrium, in the Caearian diection, to draw out the Child in a difficult labor. It is pricked neer the Os Pubis, to draw out Vrine, when a Catheter cannot be put in. It is pierced in the bottom of the Hypogatrium, neer the Navel, to draw out Water in the Dropie Acites, which Operation is called Paracenteis.

div.head: Chap. 5. Of the Scarfe Skin.
div.p: AMongt the parts which make the Abdomen, the firt that comes to view, the Greeks cal Epidermis, the Latins Cuticula and we the Scarf-Skin.
Although, by its ubtance it eems to be Spermatical yet it differs muchSubtance. from it.

It's Temperature is none at al, and therefore no more words about it, but for itsOriginal. original, it is framed of the Excrementitious and Vicous Vapors of the Skin, which Sweating, out grow dry by the coldnes of the Air, and like a thin Skin, compaeth the Skin round, and therefore it ticks to the Skin firmly and univerally, and hath no other bounds then the Skin hath.

And although to the ight its ubtance appeares imple, yet Fabricius ab Aquae pendente wil have it double, one which is ineperably fixed to the pores of the Skin, the other eperable, without any offence to the Skin it elf, but the thicknes of the Cuticula, be it more or les, doth not encreae it's number, for though in ome places it may be divided into many mal Skins, yet in no place can one be pulled off without another.
It hath no Proper figure beides what it borrows from the Skin it elf, from whichFigure. it differs in this, that it is no way porous.
It is thought to partake alwaies of the ame color with the Skin, and yet in BlackColor. Mores this being pulled of, the Skin it elf is white.

It ticks firmely to the true Skin, and is an Excrementitious part as the HairsConnexion. are, and hath no communion with the principal parts, by Veins, Arteries, nor Nerves, becaue it wants them, and is inenible, as you may find, if you pleae to crape it off from your hands, or any parts, or thrut a Pin or Needle under it.

It hath no action, only ue, which is to hut the pores of the Skin, to make it
• e. mooth, and bewtiful, polihed and even.

div.head: The Medicinal Conideration.
div.p:
By thee things thus conidered, a Phyitian may ee that the care Skin hath alo its Dieaes, though Hippocrates thought them to be only deformities, He makes
a ditinction whether they may be called Impotumes or dieaes, at the end of Lib. 2. Prorrheticorum, becaue uch as belong to the Scarfe-skin, pertain mot of al to the dignotion and Cure of Affects.

It is infected with divers Spots, both natural, and ickly; natural, are thoe many deformities of the Skin; Sickly, are the Meazles, mal Pocks, purple pots in Feavers, or any Spots of other Color; omtimes without a Feaver, when Nature ends any Wheyih ubtance of another Color into the Scarf-Skin.
Dieaed pots of the Scarf-Skin may, and ought to be cured: but uch as are Original from the birth, are very difficultly taken away, becaue they tick firmely to the Skin, as wel as to the Scarf-Skin.

This Scarf-Skin may be beautified; which Galen denies to be done, by an honet,It may be Beautified. and honorable Phyitian; but allowes it to be done, by Court Phyitians, and Bauds, and Chamber-Maids that wait upon their Ladies. In Women, the Cuticula is thick, mooth, and many time tops the pores of the Skin, and hinders free perpiration. In men it's uually ful of pores, that o the Hairs may pas out.

Latly, as the Scarf-Skin of the Body, being wel looked after, and adorned, procures beauty and and comlines to the Body; o being made rough with Spots, or burnt by the Sun, it unhandoms a man. It is ridiculous to draw it off with bliters, that o it may come again the cleerer, you looe your labor as much as though you wahed a Black-more.

The Scarf-Skin peels off in divers perons whilt it is dried or burnt, and the Skin it elf in Leproies, and divere that have the french pocks; The Skin it elf comes off by fleakes in uch as are Leprous, and in ome that are troubled with the Whorematers Pox.

div.head: Chap. 6. Of the Skin.
div.p: AFter the Scarf-Skin, followes the Skin called in Greek Derma; it hath a ubtance divere from other Membranes, the like of which you halIts Names. never find in the whole Body, becaue it conits of Seed and Blood mixed together;Subtance. yet o as that portion of Seed is predominant, which may be bowed, and ditended: from which the Skin is accounted Spermatical.
Its temperature is cold and dry, or more properly, exquiitly temperate, yet oTemperature. it may be the Judg of feeling.
It is extended over the whol body, and on wraps it like a garment, and therefore its dimention is as the dimention of the Body is.

Although it eem but one, both to ight and touching, yet ome hold it to conitNumber. of two Skins; but I could never find them to be eperable, only it may be cut into many parts by reaon of its thicknes.

It hath the ame Figure which the body hath, that it cloatheth. Its texturFigure. is Slight, and very ful of mal holes, for inenible tranpiration, and the paing out of excrements: and in divere places, it hath viible great holes; as in the eares, Eyes, Noe, mouth, fundament, and privities of Men and Women.
It takes its Color from the predominant humor; for of what color the HumorColor. predominant in the Body is, of that color is the Skin, unles it be uch from their birth, as in Ethiopia.
It is traightly knit to the Parts under it, and therefore immovable, excepting theConnexion. Skin of the Forehead.

It hath communion with the principal Parts, by innumerable veins, Arteries,Communion. and Nerves; the extremities of which, it takes on every ide, for it hath neither of them all three peculiar to its elf.

Whether by reaon of its feeling, it perform action, a man may make a doubt;Action. for otherwie the membranes, which are the intruments of inward feeling, perform action alo; but what Author ever aid that the Membranes performed action?
We grant that it hath an excellent, and particular ue, to defend and adorn theue. body, to receive the exc • ements of the third concoction to clene the Body of fil • h fuliginous Vapors, and Sweat.

div.head: The Medicinal Conideration.
div.p: Let us now reduce this ame conformation of the Skin, to a Phyical ue. ItsActects in Subtance. Temper. ubtance againt Nature, conits in i • s over thicknes.
Its temperature is changed in divere di • eaes.
It's number is viciated, when the Cuticula is viciated, or gnawn through; or theNumber. Skin it elf lot.
Often times its moothnes, is turned into roughnes; or it is difigured byFigure. putles.
Somtimes its paages are topped, or more open then they hould be.
Its connexion, is marred in wounds, and Ulcers.Connextion. ue.
Somtimes it's ue is hurt, when it is inenible; or when it receives not only the excrements of the third concoction, but alo of the whol Body.

Therefore the Skin, eeing it is the breathing place of the whol body, is ubject to an infinite number of Dieaes; and if the pores be hut, the Body uffers great dicommodities, by reaon tranpiration is hindered; for the Body ought to eae it elf that way, according to Hippocrates, Lib. de Alimento: The motion of the Body, to perpiration, the w • der it is, the healthfuller are men; the les perpiration men have, the more ickly are they; they which have quick perpration, are weaker, though better in health, and oonet recover when they are ick: uch whoe perpiration is bad, are tronget before they are ick; but when they are ick, their Cure is mot difficult.

Dieaes proceeding from diorder of the Skin, are more dangerous in winter; and in mal • gnant Feavers, by reaon of the interc • ption of the tranpiration, the Native heat is choaked. Breathing a Vein is a remedy for uch.
From the ubtance, and Color of the Skin, Hippocrates propounded two prognoticks: Lib. 5 Aph. 71. and Lib proegn. Part. 7. and 8.
Of the pots of the Skin, read Soranus, Chap. 38.
The Skin is like in Color, to the predominate humors, in the Body Hippoc. de humoribus.
Of divination by the Moles of the Skin, wrote Polemon, a Greek Author; and and amongt modern writers, Ludovicus • eptalius, Mediolanenis, Wrote mot accurately.
Aritotle concluded the ubtilty of a perons wit, from the ubtilty and thinnes of the Skin, rather than of the blood.
The thinne • s of the Skin, is the caue why man alone is troubled with the Leproie, according to Aritotle, Prol. 5. Sect. 10.
It is certain that concagious Dieaes, may be drawn in through the pores of the Skin.

The Skin grows hard and dry, through burning Feavers, and omtimes it becomesWhether Skin l • t, can be regained. as thick as an Elephants Hide: epecially about the Back, Limbs, and Thighs, as I have een it in many, like a tand Hide. The Skin lot, grows not again, but degenerates into a Scarre: For it is made by the firt in • ention of Nature, but repaired by the econd.

div.head: Chap. 7. Of the Fatty Membrane.
div.p:
THe Greeks cal it Stear, and
• imele i • makes a common membrane, by reaonIts Names. of its conitence: in <> is called
<> ; and why not o then in men?

p.U:
ubtance, although it be omthing <> , yet is it oft, and Oyly, as you maySubtance.
perceive if you handle it with your Fingers, or lay it by the Fire.

div.p: It arieth from the thinner portion of the Blood, ditilling through the VeinsOriginal. like dew, and congealing about the Fleh: this is the certain matter of the Fat; of the efficient caue only is the quetion made, Namely, Whether it obtaine its conitence by heat, or cold. Al acknowledg a moderate heat about the membranes, compelling, and applying this ame fatty, and Oyly Liquor.
The Temperature then of the Fat, is moderately hot and moit.Temper. Scituation.
It is contained uuder the Skin, univer • ally over the whol body; the Forehead, Cods, and yard, (where there is no Fat) excepted.
Therefore the Fatty memb • ane, is large, as the Skin is.
In Number it is only one, unles you connex the Flehy membrane, internexedNumber. with it, as Sylvius doth.
It hath no Proper Figure.Figure. Color.
In Color it is white; if at any time it be red, it is becaue blood, by reaon of ome Laceration, is mixed with it.
It ticks firmly to the Skin, neither can it be divided from it without craping; and o it doth to the Flehy Membrane.

The Fat cannot communicate with the principal Parts, becaue it is not truly nourihed; nor yet lives, unles by appoition as tones do; neither yet is it enible: therefore it wants both Veins, Arteries, and Nerves; and yet al three of them pas through the Fat, that o they may come at the Skin.

As for the ue of it; it warms the body in Winter like a Garment, and cools itue. in Summer, by hindring the penetrating of the heat: It is like a Cuhion for men to it on, and in long fating, it is turned to Nourihment of the Flehy Parts neer to it, which Suck out its juyce.

div.head: Chap. 8. Of the Flehy Membrane.
div.p: THe Flehy Membrane lies under the Fat, and ticks to it, and is conpicuous in young Children newly born, where it is not hid with Fat. It is more obcure in uch as are grown up, and yet it retains it Flehy ubtance, as is evidentSubtance. about the Loynes, Cods, Forehead, and Neck.
Its temperature, is like the ret of the Fleh, ho • and moit; and it hath itsTemperature original from the Blood.

It is cituated under the Fat, and tretched out over the whol body univerally,Scituation. and is the fourth covering of the body. In bruits it is next to the Skin, which often moves by the intervening of this Membrane.
It is one ingle Membrane.Number. Figure. Color.
It hath no proper Figure, unles the Figure of the body which it covers.
It hath various colors in Divere places; for it is more red in the Neck, Forehead, and Cods, than ele where.
It is joyned to the Fat ineperably in ome places; o that the <> , andConnexion. Fatty Membrane, eem to make but one: in other places it may be eperated.

It communicates with the principal parts, by the extremities of the Ve •• s, Arteries,
<> . and Nerves.

And that it is very Senible, the rigor, and trembling of the body, which dependsAction. upon this Membrane, witneeth: beides it hath a peculiar Motion in the Neck, Forehead, and Cods, where it is Muculous, and endued with Nervous Fibres.
Its ue is to give foundation to the collecting and generating the Fat, to Cloath e. the Body, and cherih the internal heat, and defend it from external injuries.

div.head: The Medicinal Conideration.
div.p:
Although, Cutaneous Dieaes eem to belong to the Skin; yet if they continue
long they have their foundation in the flehy and fatty Membrane; hivering, haking and trembling, belong epecially to the Flehy Membrane.

div.head: Chap. 9. Of the Common Membrane of the Mucles.
div.p: THe Flehy Membrane being taken away, the common Membrane of the Mucles of the Abdomen follows next, being the fi • t common covering of the body, which comprehends al the Mucles in the body, (beides the proper Membrane of every Mucle) leat in their Motion, they hould pas out of their places.
Its Subtance is very trong, yet thin and Nervous.Subtance. Temper. Original. Scituation. Quantity.
It is perma •• cal, cold and dry, in temperature.
It hath its original, from the firt formation.
It immediatly covers, and traitly binds in the Mucles, over which it is tretched.
Its widenes is thought to equal the dimenion of the whol body; but in the Face, Neck, and uperior Limbs, it is not eaily found; and in the Legs, the Facia Lata performes its Office.
Seeing it is admirable thin, it cannot be divided into two Membranes.Number. Figure. Color. Connexion.
It acquires its Figure, from the Parts it contains.
In Color, it is whitih.
It ticks toutly to the Mucles, which it compaeth, neither can it be pulled off, but by a Skilful Diector.
It hath no peculiar Nerves, Veins, nor Arteries
It is nourihed, and is enible, like the other common parts,Communion. e.

It is of admirable ue, for it compaeth the Mucles like a girdle, and together with the Flehy Membrane, is the foundation of the Fat; therefore, where it, or omthing like it, which performs its Office, is wanting, there the Fat alo is wanting; as in the Forehead, Head, Face, and Cods, where the Flehy Membrane immediatly toucheth the Skin, without any Fat: between them.

div.head: Chap. 10. Of a Mucle in the general.
div.p: BEfore I treat of the Mucles of the Belly, I wil premie the general Doctrine of the Mucles.

A Mucle is an intrument of voluntary motion, which depends upon our ownDefinition. Subtance. wil, and becaue it governs the actions It is a diimila • part, compounded of many imilar ones; but of thoe Parts, Fleh is predomina • te. So that the ubtance of the Mucle, is judged to be Flehy: Yea and the Mucles are to be undertood by the word Fleh in antient Authors; as Hippocrates, and Aritotle.
Beides, the Fleh, a Vein, an Artery, a Nerve, Fibres, a Membrane, a Ligament, or • endon, help to make up the compoition of a Mucle.
<> they are Flehy, their Temperature it hot and moit.Temperature. Original. and • nertion.

The true original of a Mucle, is from blood in the conformation of the firt Parts; but by reaon of its Connexion, in two extremes, It is aid to arie from a table Part, and to be inerted into a movable part, becaue it is ordained for motion, and al motion is caued by that which moves not.

This original and inertion, is known by the ducture and eries of the Fibres, by which you may Judg of the Scituation of the Mucle, whether right, Oblique, or tranvere for in thee poitions al the Mucles in the body of man, both internal, and external, lie.
Their quantity and magnitude, is various, according to the variety of places,Quantity. and parts to be moved, which require either greater, or maller Mucles.

There are aboundance of them in number, which according to my ObervationNumber. and computation, are four hundred thirty one: but becaue our body is double, the Mucles alo are double; few their are without fellows, uch as are the Sphincters;
and the Diaphragma, or Midrif.

Their Figure is various, T. 10. f. 1. N N. T. 14. f. 2. O O. Square, T. 10. f. 1. Triangular, T. 22. f. 1. C D. round, T. 14. f. 2. M M. T. 15. f. 18. A A. Long, T. 14. f. 1. A A. Trapezia, Figure. Lozing fa • ond, T. 22. f. 1. A. Deltois, like the Greek Delta T. 13. f. 18. B B. Scalena: uually they are round, whether you regard their Circumference, or bulk in long and thick Mucles: Therefore Hippocrates in Lib. de art. Defines a Mucle to be Fleh Circumducted in an orb: but the greatet Parts of the Mucles have a longih figure.

For the mot parts, you hal oberve the middle Part welled, the extremitiesBelly. Head Tendon. narrow. The middle part is called the Belly; in the immovable extremity; the Head, the moveable extremity, the Tendon, or Aponeurois, which is the end, or inertion of the Mucle into the Part to be moved. Each extremity of the Mucle for the mot Part, is Nervous; but the Tendon is Nervous in almot al the long Mucles: the Belly is flehy, and Seldom Nervous.
The Color of a Mucle, for the mot Part, is red; of a leaden Color in omeColor. few, by reaon of their impure Scituation, in ome fil • hy place.

The Connexion of the Mucles is twofold; in the two extremities, and in divereConnexion. Parts; the one of which tands til, the other moves: alo the Mucles move the Parts to which they tick, though they were not appointed for that ue.
All the Mucles have communion with the Parts, by Veins, Arteries, and Nerves;Communion. which they admit above the Belly or middle part of their Body, by which they obtain their motive power.

The Action of the Mucles, is either univeral, or particular. Univeral action,Action is that which agrees to al of them, Viz. Motion: particular action, is the motion of ome one certain Part; this motion is performed by contraction of the Mucle whilt it is drawn back, towards its beginning, made horter, and wels outwardly; and this agrees withal the Mucles, thoe of the Abdomen excepted, which being drawn back, wel within, becaue they have no oppoite bone to with-hold them.

Therefore the true action of a Mucle, is contraction, or conervation of what is drawn; which motion is called Tonicus, in one Mucle remaining long in on figure; or in more Mucles extended, and acting together, as when the whol hand is long held elevated, and extended.

The motion of others Mucles, as extention and relaxation, are only by accident; from thee motions depend the motions of the parts, which are not only ditinguihed by difference of place before, behind, upwards, downwards; but alo by figure.

Their Scituation is either larger, and that right, and is called Exten • io; or Oblique,Diverity. and that is either lateral, as the Abductor, and Adductor of the fingers; or with inverion, as the Pronatio, and Supinatio in the hand and Radius.

Alo the Mucles, by reaon of their like motion, are called fellows, Or pairs; fellows are omtimes in divere & oppoite places, & • et perform the ame actionas; the Mucles which bow the Arms: uch Mucles as perform a contrary motion are called Antagonits, and o uch as bow the Arm, are antagonits to thoe that extend it.
Such as are fellows are alike for the mot Part in Magnitude, Number, and trength; uch as are antagonits differ according to the waight of the Part moved, or the vehemence of the action.
The ducture of the Fibres, hews the manner of action in every Mucle; and byHow it is known. them you may eaily ditinguih a right Mucle from a tranvere, and Oblique.

The ducture of the Fibres is various alo in the ame Mucle, according to the diverity of its ries or inertions; and therefore one Mucle performs divere actions, as the Tranpezium; for by the extremities of the Fibres, you may know the Head and Tendon.
The Tendon is directly oppoite to the Head.
If the Mucle act but one action, or many; according to the variety of its originals, it obtains various Connexions, to wit, Heads and Tendons.

div.head: Chap. 11. Of a Tendon.
div.p: A Tendon is the leat Part of a Mucle, by which we bend and move the bones. It is thought to conit of a Nerve, and a Ligament mixed together; o as that a Tendon is not found, unles it be in that Part of the Mucle where it is affixed to the Parts moved.

But a mans Eyes (if he wil beleeve them) tels him, that they are from the firt forOriginal. mation, and that they are the cheifet Part of the Mucle, and take their beginning where the Mucle begins, and are dieminated through its whol Body. if it be a Nervous Tendon in the beginning, uch it is in the end; if it be like mal trings at beginning, they are united to forme the Tendon afterwards. Such Tendons thoe Mucles have which perform trong actions, in bowing and extending, and tonical motion; as in the uperior and inferior Limbs, and in the back to uphold the Trunk of the body. The ret of the Mucles, as they are fibrous at the beginning, o they are at the end.

The hard and tiff Tendons have much Fat about them to often them, that they may the eaier be moved; and therefore thoe Fibres dipered amongt the Fleh, are nothing ele but the Tendon divided, and the Tendon nothing ele but the Fibres united; and therefore a Tendon is either compact and olid, or ele divided into Fibres.

Alo Tendons are ollid or plain, or Membranous or round, or hort or long. If they are Nervous at the beginning of the Mucle, o they are at the end. Somtimes they are Nervous at the end of the Mucle, though the Head of it be Flehy.

The hardnes of a Sollid, long and Membranous Tendon, its thicknes and Silver color is excellent: So that Fallopius affirmed, nothing was more beautiful in the Body of man, than a Tendon, and the Chrytalline Humor of the Eye.

Wherefore a Tendon, eeing it is a Similary Part, is bred of Seed, and is of a peculiar ubtance, no where to be found out of a Mucle. It wel deerves to be called the cheifet part of the Mucle, upon which the action of the Mucle depends; the other Parts work together with the Tendon in the ame action.

div.head: Chap. 12. Of the Mucles of the Belly.
div.p: THe Fleh extended over the Belly, is Muculous, which being joyned together, do make the Flehy covering, which is Proper to it.

They are divided into twelve Mucles, ix on each ide, which have names partlyNumber. from their Scituation and rie, and partly from their Figure; of which Sort are Obliquus Decendens, Obliquus Acendens, Rectus, Tranverus, Pyramidalis, and Cremater.
Of thee ten are ordained to compel the internal Parts, and ome to move the Os Sacrum, and Ilium; the two Crematers hold up the tones.

Every one of them hath his proper Figure; the Oblique ones, in regard of theirFigure. Scituation action and Fibres, are divided into acending and decending; the acending and Tranvere, carry a plain Figure like a Membrane.

Their largenes is as great as the Latitude and bignes of half the Belly, and yetLargenes. the decending Oblique Mucle is larger then the Acending, and the Acending then the tranvere: the lenght of the right Mucle, reacheth from the word-like Cartilage to the Os Pubis.

Although their Original be different, yet they al joyn o at the white line, thatOriginal. The white line. they eem to be but one Mucle. The White Line paeth from the Sword-like Cartilage by the Navel, to the Os Pubis, and makes a difference between the Mucles.

Although the Mucles of the Belly tick to divere parts, from which they are aidConnexion. to arie, yet are they al inerted at the white line of the Belly; and at the Os Pubis, each of them receives peculiar Veins, Arteries, and Nervs.

The action of the Belly, is common, or particular. That is common which alAction. Common. Particular. of them equally act, Namely, to compres the Belly on every Part; neither can they act aunder in this. The particular action is, when Mucles that are parrs act apart, viz. Acending or decending Mucles; thoe compres the breat, thee move the Os Pubis, Ilium, and Sacrum, being joyned together, without any the leat compreion of the Abdomen; but thee bones remain unmoved whilt the Abdomen is compreed.
The ue of the Mucles of the Abdomen, is whilt they lie til, to cover the internal e. parts, and defend them from external injuries, to cherih and conerve the internal heat.
Pas we now to a particular decription of the Mucles of the Abdomen, then of the Mucles that move the Os Pubis, and Sacrum. Particular Decription. Oblique decending.

The T. 1. f. 2. G G. H H. I I. Oblique decending being cituate Obliquely, by reaon of its Fibres, Oblique decending arieth from the T. 2. f. 2. G. H H. f. 8. a a. even or eight inferior Ribs, by certain flehy interections or Fibres intertexed with the Flehy Fibres of the Serratus Major, and ticking to the Os Ilium, and Pubis, it ends in a broad T. 1. f. 2. I I I I. T. 2. f. 8. B B. Tendon in the white line, and together with its fellow, makes one individual Tendon.

The Oblique T. 2. f. 8. B. Acending, arieth from the T. 2. f. 8. c c c c.
