Os Pubis, and Ilium, and beingOblique acending. knit to the brims of al the batard and true Ribs, even to the word-like Cartilage, it ends in the T. 2. f. 8. d d. white line dy a broad Tendon. In this Mucle the late Anatomits oberve a double Tendon embracing the right Mucle like a heath; but the duplicity of the Tendon appears only above the Navel; for below, it is altogether ineperable.

The right Mucle remains f flehy from the Sternum, neer the T. 2. f. 8. e e. f. 9. B. Sword-like Cartilage,Right. and being extended along the longitude of the Belly, it is inerted with a Nervous end into the Os Pubis.

In it you may oberve three Nervous T. 2. f. 9. c. Interections which trengthen it, and Veins which run a long the longitude of it; and the f. 9. c. Mammary decending, and the f. 9. d d d d. Epigatrick acending, meet about the
• . 2. f. 9. d. middle of this Mucle.
By this Anatomois, Galen thought the conent of the Womb with the Dugs, was caued, and many modern Anatomits after him, which indeed is true.

Upon the extremities of the right Mucles, ly two mal Mucles, called T. 2. f. 9. f. Pyramidales, Pyramidales. which ometimes are wanting, epecial lie the right; but fleh makes up the defect. Their office is to compres the Bladder, and therefore they end their Tendons between the right Mucles, into that Part of the Peritoneum which includes the Bladder. And in the Child in the Womb, the T. 2. f. 9. e.
rachus is a production of the Pyramidal Tendons, which in Men of Age, makes but one tring affixed to the bottom of the Bladder, and paing to the hole of the Navel, and remains til in uch as are grown up.

The T. 2. f. 9. D D. tranvere Mucle, ariing from the T. 8. f. 2. C. tranvere Apophyes of the Vertebrae ofTranvere. the loyns, and being fixed to the Os Ilium, and the batard Ribs, ends under the right Mucle, by a broad f. 9. A. Tendon in the white line, and is tricktly united with his fellow.

Beides the Mucles which compres the Belly, neer the Pubis, by the tranveralCremater. Longitude of the groin, is the Mucle f. 9. a a a. Cremater, prepared for the holding up of the tones. It is ditinguihed from the fleh of the Oblique acending Mucle, becaue it hath red fleh, is thinner, and disjoyned from it a ingers breadth; it is involved with the Peritoneum, even til it come to the Teticle, and makes the Tunicle called s f. 9. b. b. Erithrois.
You hal perceive in the groin, the perforation of the Tendons of the Mucles of the Abdomen, that they may give paage <…> the Peritoneum, and the Crematers:

Seeing ome of the Mucles of the Abdomen, conduce to the motion of the Os How the motion of the Os Ilinm and Sacrum is performed. Ilium, and Sacrum, I hal faithfully decribe the motion of them, and the Mucles appoynted for that motion. Thee bones are cloely joyned by Symphyis, and lie above the Thigh-bones, and under the bones of the loyns, for the procreation of man in the act of Copulation; in which action, the Thighs, and Back-bone remaining immovable, only thee bones move forewards, and backwards; the right and Oblique decending Mucles move them forewards, the breat reting; or very lightly moving, and that by longer intervals; the Mucles, b. f. 2. D D. Sacer, and T. 14. f. 4. B B. f. 3. D D. f. 4. A A. Semipinatus, move them Backwards.

And therefore acred Scripture, contitutes the Seat of lut to be in the Loyns, becaue by the motion of the Loyns, the Reins wax hot, which provokes the Genitalls to Eiaculation of Seed: Gen. 36. It is written, Kings hal come out of thy Loynes; and Pal. 73. The Kingly Prophet complains, His loynes were filled with deluions, that is, with lutful Concupicence, as St. Jerom interprets it; and in Luke, Let your Loyns be girded, that is, preerve your Chatity.

div.head: The Medicinal Conideration.
div.p: In the Mucles of the Belly, are often Inflamations, Impothumes, and pains ariing of wind; for according to Hippocrates, the pores of the fleh, and pace between the Mucles, are filled with Blood and Spirit in uch as are healthy; but with Wheyih ubtance, and wind in uch as are Sick; and therefore Cramps happen in thee Mucles, as is decribed by Sennertus Lib. 3. Part. 10. Chap. 8. Med Pract. And therefore thee Mucles are omtimes troubled with a windy Spirit, ariing from the Hypochondriacal Parts, being filled with Melancholly.

div.head: Chap. 13. Of the Peritoneum.
div.p: THe Mueles of the Belly being taken away, the Peritoneum comes to view, which is a T. 2. f. 9. g g. Membrane tretched out over al the Parts of the Bowels, or Guts; from which extenion, it hath it's Greek Name.
Seeing it is permatieal, Its temperature can be no other than cold and dry.Temperature. Subtance.

Its Subtance is not imple, and uniform; but double, and unequal in thicknes: for it is a double Membrane, joyned in ome places, and disjoyned in other Some, to give paage to the Navel Veels; and in the Hypogatrium, it is o doubled that it contains the Bladder and the Genitals, the Reins and Vreters, the Vena Cava, and the great Artery, and the Seminal Veels in its duobling.

The inequallity of the ubtance of it is oberved in Women, to be thicket from the Navel to the Pubis, that in the conception it may be tretched as the Womb is. But in men it is thicket from the Navel to the Sword-like Cartilage, that in Gluttons it may tretch when their paunch is ful.

It takes its original from the firt formation, unles, as ome think, it take its originalOriginal. from the Dura Mater, which as they produce the Pleura, o the Pleura hould the Peritoneum; and o their hould be a continuation of thee Membranes throughout the Body, as their is of the Skin.
Its Scituation is immediatly after the Mucles, and compaeth about all the BowelsScituation. of the Abdomen.
It is the larget Membrane in the whol Body, and mot capacious, and anwers toQuantity. the inferior Ventricle both in Longitude and Latitude,

It is double every where, becaue it conits of two Membranes; of which, ••• internal is the hortet; not o much becaue it betows a Membrans upon every Part of the Belly and produceth the Meenterium; but b • caue it doth <…> accompany the external to the Teticles, but ends in the Cavi •••• o • the Abdomen.
The external paeth even to the Cods, and wraps the Teticles round and ••• kes that tunicle called Erythrois, and in its progres makes a mal Channel by when the Spermatick Veels pas.

The ame production of the external tunicle, is oberved in the groin of Women, and is diduced even to the T. 7. f. 4. I I. K. f. 5. A. Clitoris, and the round and lower Ligament of the T. 7. f. 2. S S. f. 4. F F. Womb.
The Figure of the Peritoneum is Oval, and longih, by reaon of the Belly, forFigure. of it elf it hath no Figure at al.

Its continuity is not pierced, it being an admirable piece of workmanhip; for although Veels pas into it, and out from it, yet al this is performed through the doubling of it, o that the internal Tunicle remains unpierced, which comprehends the Parts of the firt Region, as the external doth the Parts of the econd Region, which are placed within the Belly.
The Color of the Peritoneum is white, as the Color of other Membranes i • .Color. Connexion.

It is firmely knit to the Vertebrae of the loyns, I mean the external Membrane, the internal hath no Connexion with them, but is disjoyned to receive the Rein, and redoubled to make the Meenterium; alo it gives a covering to the Diaphragma, and the Liver, and produceth the Ligament which holds it, and depends upon the Sword-iike Cartilage.

Beides the general communion it hath with the principal Parts, by Veins,Communion. Arteries, and Nerves; It hath a particular communion with al the Parts contained; to which it gives Membranes, either thick or thin; and therefore it may be called the Mother of al the Membranes in the Belly.

It performs no action; but its ue is great through out the Belly. e.
b T. 6. f. 2. C C. E E.

div.head: The Medicinal Conideration.
div.p: Let us now bring this contemplation of the Peritoneum, to a Phyicalue. By reaon of its doubling, you hall perceive Serous and harp Cholerick Humors • o to get into thoe paces, which make a batard Collick, but have no foundation at al within the Guts, as a true Collick hath, but between the Peritoneum and the Guts; whence the Dieae is bitter, and uually lating: of which ee Fernelius in his Pathology.

Somtimes other Humors flowing from the Liver, or from the Reins, get withinCollick. this Duplication, towards the Navel, or groyn, or Os Sacrum, and there impotumate, unles they were turned into Quittor before they fel into this Part.

Such Collical pains lie uually on the top of the Belly, and not deep; neither wil they uffer the Belly to be handled never o gently. Somtimes they come up even to the Diaphragma, by reaon of the continuation of the Peritoneum, and then the danger is the greater.
Somtimes, by reaon of thoe Productions of the Peritoneum which reach theRuptures. Stones, Serous Humors pas down to the Cods, and make a watry Rupture.

You mut diligently oberve the production of the Peritoneum by the groyn; which being dilated (for it is eldom broken) receiveth the Gut Ilium, or the Call, whence is bred that welling in the Groine, called Entero-Cele, or that called Epiplo-Cele; or when both the Gut and the Call do fal down, that other called Entero-Epiplo-Cele.

div.head: Cha. 14. The Diviion of the Parts of the Belly.
div.p:
THe Parts of the Paunch included within the Peritoneum, I thus divide. TheyParts firt. al pertain to the firt Region, which are nourihed by the branches of the Vena Porta; therefore the T. 2. f. 10. E. Omentum, the Hollow T. 4. f. 1. A. Part of the Liver, the f. 1. C. Gal, T. 2. f 10. C. Stomach, T. 4. f. 1. • . Spleen, f. 1. E E. Sweet-bread,
T. 3. f. 1. and 4. Bowels, f. 1. A A. Meenterium, and T. 4. f. 1. F F. f. 6. A A. Vena Po • ta, and the F. 5. K. Coeliacal Artery, make the Firt Region of the Body, contained within the Abdomen. The other Parts which are included within the doubling of the Peritoneum, are referred to the Second Region, which comprehends the T. 5. f. 1. B C. Reins, Second. f. 1. F F. G G. Vreters, f. 1. K. Bladder, T. 6. tota. Genitals in Men; and the t. 7. tota. Womb, with the Parts annexed, in Women.

It is extended even to the upper Part of the Breat, and T. 7. f. 1. II. f. 6. A A. F F. comprehends the Diaphragma, f. 4. A A. Mediatinum, t. 11. f. 2. B. f. 5. I. the Heart, and f. 1. A. f. 2. A. Pericardium, f. 1. B B. f. 2. K K. f. 7. F F. Lungs,
f. 7. E. f. 8. A B C. T. 13. f. 10. 9. Trachea Arteria, T. 3. f. 2. E E. Oeophag • s, T. 13. f. 14. A. Tongue, T. 13. f. 9. 10. Larinx, with the Trunks of the Vena Cava, and great Artery, even from the Throat to the groyn, according to Fernelius: but I extend it farther, even to the Limbs; whither o ever the greater Channels of the Aorta or Cava, the T. 12. f. 1. 4. B B. Axillars, and <note n="" place="bottom"> f. 1. 4. D D. Crurals pas.

div.head: Chap. 15. Of the Navel.
div.p: THe Navel from the birth, even to extream Age, is a knotty T. 8. f. 2. D. D. Coition of theWhat it is. four Navel T. 8. f. 2. A B B C. Veels; by which the Child is nourihed in the Womb. That they hould tick out on the out-ide of the Belly, is impro • itable; therefore they are Cut off the T. 9. f. 2. P. Child being born.

The continuation of the Veels within the Abdomen remains, which grows dry by degrees, being deprived of its a • cient Office; and therefore it is to be conidered u • der another Notion, in one that is grown up.

We hal treat of the Umbilicar Veels, as they are found in the Carcas of a man
• mbilicar Veels. grown up; they are like Ligaments, included in the doubling of the Per • toneum; that which outwardly appears is the middle both of the Belly, and Body.

The T. 2. f. 8. G. T. 4. f. 1. a f. 6. a a. T. 8. f. 2. A. Umbilicar Vein paeth to the T. 4. f. 5. C. cleft of the Liver, The Umbilicar f. T. 8. f. 2. B B. f. 4. e • . A • teties are T. 2. f. 10. two, and decend to the Iliack f. 4. dd. Arteries, Somtimes creeping along the ides of the Bladder to the f. 4. vel. . Hypogatricks, between the Arteries lies the T. 8. f. 2. C. T. 9. f. 2 O.
rachus fixed to the ides of the Bladder, and this is the original and inertion of the Umbilica • Veels. The rachos is like a long and round Ligament, and its ue is to hold up the Bladder.

The Umbilicar Vein puls the Liver foreward, let by its waight it hould depresue. the Parts under it, The Umbilicar Artery upholds the t. 2. f. 10. • . I. Bladder that it fal not down, although it be included in the doubling of the Peritonum.

div.head: The Medicinal Conideration.
div.p:
To reduce that is aid to Medici • al ue; this hews that the Cutting of the Navel Vein is dangerous, that the place of the Navel is very perpirable becaue it penetrates the containing Parts, Neither is there any thing either within or without, that tops that paage, and therefore purging Medicines applyed, to the Navel Purge, and weet things applyed to the Navel of Women pene • rate to the Womb: The Water in Dropies many times breakes out at the Navel and the affects thereof are grievous, not o much by reaon of the enibility of the Part, but the uddain hu •
ting of thoe Parts whoe Office it is to nourih the whol Body.

Therefore conider whether the Navel be the centre of the Belly or not, for otherwie, if the Parts below the Navel be longer than thoe above it, A multitude of Dieaes are bred in the lower Part, becaue the Umbilicar Vein being horter doth not ufficiently, pul back the Liver, which, by its waight, compreeth the Stomach and Parts under it.

div.head: Chap. 16. Of the Omentum, or Call.
div.p: BEfore you proceed to the Omentum or cal you mut view how it covers al the Parts of the Belly, then their Scituation, which is of no mal moment to the art of Phy • ick.

The T. 2. f. 10. E. b c d. T. 3. f. 1. D D. Omentum, or Epiploon, or Cal, is a thin Membrane endewed with muchNumber. Fat, neither is it ingle but double, and o disjoyned in ome places, that you may thrut your hand between, this you may ee in that Part which is tretched out above the Guts, but about the Stomach and Spleen neer the Diaphragma, the pace is not o evident, but it hath certain hid • ng places as the Poet Lucan aith, which not appearing was a bad Omen.
It was held to be an ill Omen alo amongt the ooth aiers if it were not extended over the Guts.

The portion of it which is ubject to view, is Naturally tretched out even to theScituation. Navel, omtimes to the groyn and Cods in Women between the Neck of the Womb and the Bladder, the greater portion is hidden in the left Hypocondrium.

It may be divided into four Parts, the firt is called T. 2. f. 10. d d. Intetinal which is tretched out over the Guts; the Second f. 10. b. Hepatical, which arieth from the Cavity of the Liver, including the mal Lobe of the Liver, and turns down to the deep Cavities thereof, the third is called f. 10. c. Lienal, becaue it lies upon the Spleen, the fourth T. 3. f. 1. T. 4. f. 1. Meenterical, being a production of the Meenterium to the external Parts, andOriginal. from it is its original to be fetched.

div.head: The Medicinal Conideration.
div.p: The Omentum hath its Dieaes, both Similar, Organical, and Common, forDieaes. Similar. omtimes it is ditempered and inflamed, and ye • but eldome, it is oftner troubled with Impothumes or Apothemes which you wil, becaue it receives the filth of of the Liver and Spleen. Somtimes its mightily encreaed with Flegm gathered together, and grows to a huge bignes; neither is this welling eaily allayed either by internal, or external Medicines. If it be oft, Suppuration is to be ought, which eldom ucceeds as i • hould do, although you open the Part with a Cautic.

Somtimes a dropical Water is concluded in the Cavities of the Omentum accordingOrganical to the Judgment of Hippocrates, and this is wore then if it were within the Abdomen, becaue it is eaier drunck up by the Meeraick Veins; or by the Spungines of the Spleen, the paages being firt opened, and thoe Parts tirred up to it by ome convenient Medicine.

The Omentum Fals down into the g • oine or Cods: and caueth thoe wellings which are commonly called • uptures: the Belly being wounded, the Omentum Common. breaks forth: and then a great portion of it may be tyed with a tring neer the Belly and o cut of, becaue it oon putriies, neither is it • afe to put it back again.

The firt Concoction is made never the weaker by cuttings off Part of the Omentum, (though Galen thought otherwie) For the Concoction is made in the Stomach: and the Omentum doth not cover the Stomach, But is only knit to the bottom of it.

div.head: Chap. 17. Of the Guts.
div.p: THe Guts follow next according to the order of diection, which are organical e. Parts, hollow, appointed to carry the Chyle and to receive the Excrements. The thin Guts are appointed for the Chyle, the thick for the Excrements.

Their ubtance is Membranous and ful of trings, which may be divided into twoSubtance. Fl • hy. proper Membranes, of which, the T. 2. f. b. R. Inner is Flehy, the f. 5. Q. outward Nervous. But the Inner is rugged, and as it were • oulded that it may tay the Chyle in its wrinckles. that o the Mearaick Veins may draw it the better, which like Hore-leeches draw the thinner Part of the Chyle from the Guts.
Beides the wrinkles, the Inide of the Guts is bedewed, And as it were deendedNervous. with a certa •• e Flegmatick Slime, leat the Membrane hould be hu • t by the paage of Choler.
Beides thee two proper Membranes there is a T. 3. f. 5. P P. common one, added from the Peritoneum, Slimy. which it betowes upon a • the Parts it contai • es.

The Guts are placed in the Abdomen and fil its whol Cavity without any confuion;Scituation. the Hypochondria excepted; and are dipoed in various turnings by reaon of the Connexion they have with the f. 1. A A. Meenterium.
They are even times as long as the Body, and omthing longer.Longitude. General Diviion.

This Longitude is divided into f. 4. • rom B. to I. thin, and f. 4. from 1. to • . thick, not according to Scituation, but in repect of the Membranes: The thin which is taken from the inferiore Orifice of the Stomach, is the firt & upreme in order, it conits of thin Membranes, the thick, is the Inferior in order, But the uperior and horter in Scituation, and more Capacious and hath thicker Membranes.

Again, the thin is ditinguihed into three Parts, or three Guts; of which the firtSpecial. is called f. 4. F. Duodenum, the econd f. 4. G G. Jejunum, the third f. 4. H H. Ilium. The thick Gut is alo divided into o many Parts or Guts: The firt T. 2. f. 4. H H. Caecum: The econd f. 4. K. Colon. The third f. 4. M. Rectum.

Al the Guts are hollow, that they may give paag to Chyle and Excrements. TheyCavity. are n f. 6. R.
n T. 3. f. 4. F. wrinckled round about within, al along their Longitude, even from the Stomach to the Fundament, that o they may tay the Chyle and Ex • rements of the firt Conco • tion; but for expelling the Excrements, they have a kind of motion which prees downward by degrees. And thus much to wha • is common to al the Guts: It remains that we peak of them al everally.
The firt Gut is called T. 4. f. 5. H H. Duodenum; becaue in length it is twelve Fingers1. Duod • num. bread • h.

The finding of this Gut is hard, for towards the back bone it mut be ought for under the Sweet-bread with the beginning of the Jejunum; this poition and Intertexture is diligently to be noted, becaue oftentimes the caue of obtructions & vomitings is without any failing of the Pylorus but the choler flowing by the f. 3. D D. Biliar Pore is hindred in his paage, and returning back into the Stomach caueth vomiting.

In the very con • ines of the Duodenum and Jejunum, the paage of CholerBi • iar Pore. pierce •• the Gu • , and creeps downward a little way between the Membranes before i • pe •• ceth the Inner Membrane, nee • which the f. 3. C. f. 5. H H. Channel of the Sweet-bread i • oberved by Vir • ngus.

Where the Guts begin to be turned toward the left ide, their the T. 3. f. 4. G G. Jejunum begins,2. Jejunum. which is thought to be emptier than the Ilium, by reaon of his neernes to the Liver, and its Multitude of Mearaick Veins: It lies altogeather in the umbilical Region, and is in length about a Cubit, and an half.

The f. 3. E. Ilium follows, which is more lender, but in length urpaes al the ret3. Ilium. of the Guts. It occupies the Ilium, and Hypogatrium, and compaeth about the Jejunum it elf with its inferior Part. In this Gut is that Dieae which is called the twiting of the Guts, and the Iliack paion.

The fourth Gut in order, and the firt of the thick Guts, is called f. 3. B B. Caecum byThick Guts. 1. Caecum. Ancient Anatomits, and does retaine this Name, although it is altogether unlike to the Ancient decription of it. It is not large like a Sack, neither doth it perform the Office of a econd Stomach to Concoct the Chyle, which was not perfected before: the Ingres and Egres, are by one hole. Now in its place, a Membranous Appendix is hewed, which is larger in a Child new born, than in a man grown up: and thence Sylvius took occaion to write, That many things were changed in ou • Bodies, both in regard of growth; and of the Guts, Duodenum and Caecum.

The Gut T. 3. f. 4. H H. Colon ucceeds this; in which are many things worth our Conideration,2. Colon. to wit, its Largnes, Scituation, Ue, S • utters two Ligaments, Its fringes of Fa • , and its Connexion.

Of al the Guts, none more large, and Capacious, then this. It begins atLargnes. the right Kidney neer the f. 4. I. Appendix; and being turned upwards, it lies under the Liver and Stomach, and paeth to the left Hypochondrium, where it is wrea
• hed, and made • arrower.
In its Obliquation decending, it touches the left Kidney; and a little below, beingScituation. bowed like a Roman S. it ends in the top of the Os Sacrum.

In it, the Dunge and filth of the Guts, is kept: as alo the wind of the firt Region.
• e.

Leat it hould be dilated too much by Multitude of Dung, and Violence of wind,Ligaments. Nature hath trengthened this Gut with two trong Ligaments; which being tretched along its Longitude, they make greater foldings, and wrinckles in this Gut, then in any other. Inomuch that they eem like Ce • s to retain the Dung and becaue it wants the bond of the Meenterium, and conequently that Humor which proceeds from the Fat of it; Nature hath placed about it, here and there,Fat. certain fringes of Fat to Moiten it.

That f. 4. K K. Volve, or Shutter which Authors quarrel o much about, is not to beShutters. paed by, being fatned to the beginning of the Colon, like a Membranous Circle, which hinders the flowing back of the Dunge into the Ilium and the acending of a Gliter to the ame place. Therefore it opens towards the Inferior Parts; that it may let the Dung pas out, and hinder it from flowing back.
It is knit to the Membrane of the Peritoneum, by a Membranous • ye, whatoeverCon •• xion. Laurembergus wrote, accuing Riol • n • s of Ignorance or dul-ightednes.

The lat of the Guts is called f. 1. C C. right, be • aue it paes traight from the top of the3. Right Gut. O • Sacrum, to the Fundament. This Gut, contrary to the Nature of others, beides the Internal flehy Membrane, hath alo an external f. 4. • . flehy Muculous covering, like a heath; that o it may the more forceably expel the D •• g, which ueth to clod in the extremity of the Colon, and right Gut. Therefore beides the compreion of the Mucles of the Abdomen and the Natural motion of the Colon, this ame flehy Sheath, cruheth the Dung; as it were with ones hand that o it may pas out.

div.head: The Medicinal Conideration.
div.p: I pas now to the Dieaes and Symptomes of the Guts. They uffer DieaesGeneral Dieaes of the Guts. boch Similar Organical and Common. For they are ditempered by heat and cold, either with or without Humor. They are inflamed, wounded, Ulcerated, dryed, bound, looened, made mooth the wrinckles being taken away as in fluxes and bloody fluxes. Somtimes they are o topped that the Excrements are Vomited up.
Beides thee the common Dieaes, the Guts everally conidered, have their peculiarPeculiar Dieaes. Of the Duodenum. Dieaes.
The Duodenum may be topped by compreion of the Sweet-bread, and then the food is Vomited up again two or three houres after it is eaten; becaue the paage is topped.

The Ilium is ubject to the Iliack paion, which is an Inflamation and not aIlium. twiting of that Gut; Somtime it fals down into the groyn, and omtimes into the Gods, which caueth Ruptures in thoe places.
Somtimes the Peritoneum being looed or broken neer the Navel, the Dieae calledJejunum. Omphalocele commeth, in which the Jejunum lipps down.

The Colon is ubject to the Collick, which arieth either through harp Humors,Colon. or wind, or extream cold Air. In it wormes are bred, which omtimes creep up into the Stomach and are Vomited out; This Gut alone is ubject to Ulcerations, which caueth Putrefaction: which many think, comes from the Meenterium, and mot unfortunately ue purging Medicines and Glyters which increae the evil and no way help it: Becaue the extremity of the Colon which is joyned to the right Gut is more flehy, painful Impotums are bred there, which uppurate and are ooner cured then they would be, if they came from the Meentery.
Somtimes Melancholy hard wellings are bred there which caue difficulty in going to the tool and haten death.

The right Gut hath its peculiar Dieaes, Tenamus, Inflamation, Impotumes,Right Gut •…
which end in Ulcers and fitulas, which are difficult to be cured and require, the help of the Chirurgion.

The Peritalcick motion of the Guts is Somtimes o perverted, that the Dung flowes upward, and Glyters are cat up at the Mouth. And o are uppoitaries alo, if you wil believe ome Practitioners, but then the hutter of the Colon mut needs be broken.

Al the Symptomes of the Guts are to be referred to the Excrements when they areSymptomes. exceive, as in Fluxes, or deficient, as when men go not to tool unles they be provoked by Medicine, both which Symptomes impair the health.

Fluxes are called Diarrhea, which is either Chylous or humoral: humoral is either Caeliacal, or Meenterical, or Intetinal. When it comes with Ulceration Paine and Blood, it is called a Bloody Flux. If it come without pain, and be like the Water in which raw fleh has bin waht, it comes from the Liver, and is called Hepatica. If it come through moothnes of the Guts, It is called Lienteria: if it come with Quitter it is called Meenterical. The caues of al thee Dieaes yea may find in al Practtioners, and therefore we will make no longer tay upon them.

The internal Tunicle of the Guts Somtimes is evered & lot, which is thought to be turned into a long worm of two or three Cubits long, caled Tania, of which you may read in Spigelius Lib. de Lumbrico lato.

div.head: Chap. 18. Of the Meenterium
div.p:
THe T. 3. f. 1. A A. T. 4. f. 1. H H. Meenterium is the bond of the Guts, which keeps them in there places,
• What it is. that they pas not into confuion and be thereby deprived of there action and ue.
It is a double Membrane, between which, is Fat, and many T. 3. f. 1. a a a a. Glandulae, orIts Structure. Kernels, and a four-fold kind of f. 1. B B. Veels. This is the tructure of it.
It is feared in the midt of the Belly, becaue it ticks to the tranvere proceesScituation of the Vertebrae by Lygaments: thence is its original.

It ticks o firmely to the T. 9. f. 1. M M. Guts, that no diviion at al appears: between its twoVeels. Membraines, innumerable T. 4. f. 1. a a a. T. 9. f. 1. c c c. Veins pas, which are called meeraick or Meenterick. Alo an infinite number of f. 1. b b b b. Arteries from the Caeliacal Artery. Alo it hath f Nerves from the Lumbals, or Nerves of the Loines.
The fourth kind of Veels, are called f. 8. n n. Venae lacteae, by Aelbus, the firt finderVena Lactcae of them out; of which we need not doubt, eeing it is now a common received truth.

This one thing troubles many, Namely, the diverity of their ditribution: For in a beat ful fed, that is opened alive, thee milky Veins are noted cattered about the Meenterium; but ome pas to the Sweet-bread, others to the Liver, others to the Trunck of the Vena Cava, none of them to the Spleen; neither like other, veins are they gathered into one Head; they eem rather to have their Root, and Foundation in the Sweet-bread, and from thence to be ditributed this way, and that way.

Thee Milky Veins being granted, al difficulties which were formerly about the
•
ditribution of Chyle and blood by the ame Channel, ceae. For the Milky Veins carry the Chyle to the Liver, and the Meeraick Veins carry back the Blood to the Nourihing of the Guts. Therefore both thee Channels may be topped everally; which is to be noted of a Phyitian, in curing of the Dieaes of the Bowels.

The Meenterium, eeing it communicates with the Liver by the t. 9. f. 1. a a a. b b b. Vena Porta; with the Spleen by the T. 4. f. 1. F F. f. b. A A A. Caeliacal Arteries; and the Splenical f. 5. K. &c. I I. Vein; with the Guts by their Connexions, and hath a fatty Glandulous ubtance fit to receive Humors, and to retain al the impurities of the firt Region; Phyitians well cal it the Nure of Dieaes; for from that, as from a Fountain, do al the Dieaes of the Bowels proceed: and al Phyitians in precribing Purges, and Remedies, have a pecial eye to that.

div.head: The Medicinal Conideration.
div.p: The Meenterium labours under Dieaes, both Simple, and Compound; it isDieaes of the Meenterium. inflamed, and oftentimes uffers impotumes. It is Ulcerated, and by reaon of its Veels, often obtructed.
By reaon of his fatty and Glandulous ubtance, it often wels to a great hard welling, and is the Foundation of al Kings evil Swellings; which eldom come in great Number, but the Foundacion is here.

It is ubject to batard Collicks, which proceed of harp Choler, and degenerate into Palies in the inferior Limbs, and omtimes in the uperior; and hence comes the Morbus Ructuous, mentioned by Hippocrates, and Morbus Siccatorius. Of the Dieaes of the Meenterium, you may read Daniel Sennertus, and Matthews Martinius, who treats expresly of the Dieaes thereof. Although the Mearaick, and Milky Veins, which carry Chyle, are fatned to the Guts like Hore-Le • ches, yet the matter is diverly drawn by thoe Channels, For the Liver draws Chyle by the Milky Veins from the Guts, but ends Blood by the Mearaick Veins to the Guts; therefore both of them may be diverly obtructed.
For the milky Veins may be obtructed either al along through the thicknes of Chyle; or ele in their Roots within the Liver.How the Milky Veins are affected.
If the obtruction be in the whol paage al along, then there arieth a Chylous
Flux, either white, or tauny in Color. If in their Roots, either within, or neer the Liver, the Chyle hath a light Tincture of Blood.

If the Mearick Veins be topped within the Liver, the Liver cannot disburden itHow the Meeraick. elf of his Excrements, but they remaine either in the Liver, or in the Mearaick Veins, and make mot terrible obtructions, by reaon of the multitude of the Veins, both within, and without the Liver.

The Milky Veins have no Trunck, but are eperated when they enter the hollow Part of the Liver; and therefore they are not o eaily obtructed. And therefore al Humoral Fluxes of the Belly flow from the Liver or from ditempers of the Mearaick Veins. Thick Fluxes proceed from the Milky Veins, by reaon of corrupted Chyle.

The Cure of both ort of Fluxes is the ame, Namely, by uch Medicines as cut,Cure. and purge out thick Humors: but in Liquid Fluxes of the Me • araick Veins, you mut omtimes ue trengthening Medicines, And omtimes bleeding and Vomiting is more proper for thee Fluxes, than for thoe of the Milky Veins.

div.head: Chap: 19. Of the Sweet-bread, or Pancreas.
div.p: THe T. 4. f. 1. E E. Sweet-bread is a body neither truly f. 2. A A. f. 3. A A. flehy, nor truly Glandulous, butSubtance. in a middle betwen both: Yet it is very Syongy, that o it may receive the Excrements of the Spleen and Liver.
It lies under the Stomach like a oft Cuhion and is tretched from the f. 1. A. Liver toScituation. the f. 1. D. Spleen; and if it have its Natural conformation, it is as broad as the Palm of the Hand.
It receives the T. 4. f. 1. F F. Trunck of the Vena Porta; the Milky Veins, and the T. 9. f. 1. a a a. b b b. SplenicalVeels. Vein, paeth to the f. 1. I. Spleen through its Cavity.

Beides, Virungus Dicovered a new f. 1. D. f. 3. E E. Channel in the Sweet-bread, paing aA new Channel long the length of it; which is inferred into the f. 3. B B. Jejunum, neer the f. 3. D D. paage of Cho • er: but for what end this was framed is yet uncertaine, whether it be to cleane the Excrements of the Sweet-bread; or rather of the pleen, which are carried thither.

So Fallopius found the Channels in the Sweet-bread, no way to communicateIts e. with the Veins, but that being filled with Choler, they empty themelves into the Bowels: o • whether rather, they carry a portion of Chyle to the Spleen, for a particular making of Blood: but if this Channel do not touch the Spleen, then this Office is void, and it mut be to cleane the Sweet-bread of the Excrements it receives, either from the Liver or Spleen; o • to carry away the fi • th of the Chyle, which happily may remain there.

It is oberved, that this Part increaeth, when the Spleen decreaeth; o that it may wel be called the Spleens deputy. There is the Seat of Hypochondriacal Melancholy, & it is the entertainer of many Dieaes, as wel as the Meenterium both of them breed Sicknees to the Body, if they be filled with evil, and filthy Humors.

div.head: Chap. 20. Of the Vena Porta.
div.p:
WIthin the Belly, are two notable Veins contained; both of them takeTwo Veins. Porta. their original from the Liver: The one is called T. 4. f. 1. F F. Porta, which is ubervient to the Places dedicated to nourihment, nether paeth it further. Theand Cav •…
other is called T. 5. f. 2. F. T. 12. f. 1. C. Cava, which nouriheth the whol Body, from the Crown of the Head to the ole of the Foot, and paeth out of the Peritoneum, and creeps along
the Back and Loines, with the great T. 5. f. 2. G. T. 12. f. 2. C. Artery: Some think it is produced from the Heart, and not from the Liver. The Vena Porta arieth from the hollow. Part of the Liver, which it filleth, and is called the Gate of the Liver, or the Vein which is eated at the Gates of the Liver.

The Trunk of the Vena Porta decending into the Belly, ends out a branch calledBranches of the Vena Porta. Gatro Epiploon, which is ditributed to the Stomach, and Omentum. The econd T. 4. f. 6. m. branch is called Intetinal, which is carried to the Duodenum: after that,Superior. it ends f. 6. d d. two branches to the Gal, and the lat f. 6. B. branch it ends to the right ide of the Stomach.

Thee branches thus produced, the Trunck is divided into two famous branches; the f. 6. g g. Splenical and f. 6. C D. Meenterical. This again, is divided into fower branches, ofInferior. which, the greatet keeps the name Meenterical: The econd is called f. 6. I I. Haemorrhoida, and paeth to the right Gut: The third is called C • calis, and paeth to the Gut Cae • um, or ele to the beginning of the Colon: and the fourth paeth to, and nouriheth the remainder of the Colon.

The plenical branch, when it hath paed through the Sweet-bread, produceth four oppoite Veins, aboue and below. The firt is called T. 4. f. 6. e e Gatrica Major, which acends to the left ide of the Stomack. Oppoite to this is the right f. 6. e. Epiploica, which is ditributed to the Omentum. The Coronaria ucceeds this, and is ditributed to the Somach, and the left Epiploica, to the Omentum.

div.head: Chap. 21. What is to be conidered in the Vena Porta.
div.p: MAny things come to be conidered in the Vena Porta.
1. It makes the firt Region of the Body, with thoe Parts which it nouriheth, and paeth with its Blood.

2. It contains a peculiar ort of blood, which is not circled, as the Blood of thePlace. Vena Cava is; and yet it may with the branches of the Caeliacal Artery, have aBlood. have transflux, and tranvaation.
3. That it carries only Blood, and not Chyle, which is done by the Milky Veins, as alo the impurities of the Liver and Spleen, to the Meenterium, Sweet-bread,Office. and Guts.

4. That within the Liver, it hath either very mal, or no Communion at al by its Roots, with the Roots of the Vena Cava; and therefore each Vein carries itsCommunion. peculiar Blood. The blood of the Vena Porta is thick, and nouriheth the parts of the firt Region. The blood of the Vena Cava, is ubtile, fit for circulation, which nouriheth the parts of the econd, and third Region.
5. That the branches of the Vena Porta within the Liver, are larger than thoe of the Vena Cava, if that do arie from thence.Larg •… .

6. That in a Dieaed body, it is uually filled with Caco-Chymia; which, whether it ought to be emptied by breathing a Vein, a man may wel make a cruple, let the Circulation of blood infect the whol Mas.
7. Whether the Vena Porta, after two or three Evacuations by the Arm, may not better be purged by the Hemorrhoids, or opening a Vein in one of theEvacuation. Feet?
8. That al impurities of the Belly, are contained in this Vein, from whence come terrible obtructions of the Spleen, and Meenterium. Obtructions.
9. That there are no Shutters found in this Vein, as there are in the branches of the Vena Cava.

10. That the Vena Porta hath waies, whereby it disburdens it elf, as the Veins
of the Hemorrhoids: its reflux into the great Artery by the Caeliacal, and Vomiting of Blood againt Nature, in Plethorick Bodies.

div.head: Chap. 22. Of the Caeliacal Artery.
div.p: THis is a branch of the great Artery decending, and accompanies the branchesOriginal. of the VenaPorta: for look how many branches the Vena Porta is divided into, o many alo, is the T. 12. f. 2. p. q. r. Caeliacal Artery divided; which notwithtanding, hath Pule from the heart, and follows the motion thereof, as other Arteries do: but eeing his blood injoyes not the benifit of circulacion, as other Arteries do, o that it eems like a eperated Artery, Somtimes his motion is hindered, when thereMotion. is an Inflamation in the Abdomen; the ret of the A •• eries gently mooving, as is often oberved in Hypocondriack Melancholy, and other inflamations of the Hypoc • ondrium.

Notwithtanding it hath Communion with the Vena Porta by mutual conjunctionAnatomois. of their mouths; by which means there is a conflux of blood between them, whereby the vital Spirit of the Abdomen, is preerved.

This Pul • ation, or Palpitation, was known to Hippocrates, in Lib. 7. Epid. In that Hitory of his, about the pulation of the belly, neer the Navel; and in his Pr • gnoticks he makes mention of the ame; If the Veins about the Midrife • eat, they forehew either trouble of mind, or Madnes.
The Caeliacal Artery in Hippocrates Book of the Dieaes of Women, is called, the breathing place of the inferior Belly: See Duretus in Coacis. Page, 183.

The f. 2. t. Splenical Artery, is notable; which is not brought by the Sweet-bread,Doctrine of the Splenical Artery. but creeps along the Longitude of the Diaphragma, neer the back bone: it is as big as the Splenical Vein, but Ambiguous in his progres, and gives no branches to the Parts neer it.

It is inerted into the Spleen by a double branch, as the Splenical Vein is; and therefore when the Caeliacal Artery is taken away, it is in vain to look for the Splenical; for there remains none, but two or three inal Arteries, which pas to the Stomach.

From the Splenical Artery, neer the Spleen, pas two mal Arteries to the Stomach. From this faithful and true relation, you may eaily know how malignant Vapours are carried from the Spleen and Meenterium, to the Heart; whence in Pla • tus, he complained, that he had a Splenitick Heart, it leaped, and beat his Bret.

div.head: Chap. 23. Of the Stomach.
div.p:
THe Stomach is the Kitchin of the firt Concoction; it conits of proper Membranes,Membranes of the Stomach. and one T. 12. f. 2. t.
common, one which it receivs from the Peritoneum. The T. 3. f. 4. C C.
internal is rugged, and hairy, like a peice of Silk: The T. 3. f. 4. E.
External is flehy, that it may receive the heat of the Bowels which lie upon it, to wit, of the Liver and Spleen which heat it. And that it may the more eaily compres, and hold together the internal, it hath a threefold ort of trings, which trengthen it to that end; and alo when it is lackened with tore of Meat, they do contract it again, o oon as the digeted Aliment is forced out of the Stomach.Its Scituation.

It is T. 2. f. 10. C.
Scituate between the Liver, and the Spleen, as it were between two fires, bending a little towards the left Hypochondrium, if the Spleen hold its natural bignes; otherwie, when the Spleen is bigger than ordinary, it thruts the StomachIts Size. into the middle.

The greatnes of the Stomach cannot be exactly defined, becaue being empty, and exhaut, if trong, it is o contracted, that it is no bigger than a mans Fit. Being tretched and widened with tore of Beily Chea • , it wi • containe ix pints of Drink, with a Pound or two of Meat, as is daily een in Gluttons, and To-Pots.

There is but one Stomach in Mankind, which is omtimes divided according toNumber. the Longitude into two Cavities; which have their Ingres and Egres, like the Stomachus, and Pylorus. And uch perons do vomit with great difficulty; and when they do, they cat up Excrementitious Humors without that broth which they took the ame moment. Shal we ay the eparating faculty can work o quick, or rather that the broath is lipt down into the Lower diviion of the Stomach from whence it cannot eaily returne, becaue of the narrownes of the upper Orifice.
If the Stomach be ingle and rightly haped, it is of a longih Spherical Figure, Figure. and is compared to the Belly of a Bag-Pipe, etting aide the Oeophagus and Guts.

The Egres of the Stomach is equal in height unto its Ingres; that is to ay, theTwo Orifices. two Orifices thereof, are equal in height, leat the Meat and Drink hould lip through, before they be digeted; and then being digeted by the trength of the Stomach Contracting it elf, the Pylorus is opened, and the Chylus ent into the Gut.

The Ingres, or upper T. 3. f. 2. H. f. 4. A.
Orifice of the Stomach, is in a pecial manner termedThe upper. Somachus, being the Seat of Hunger and Thirt, becaue it is crowned with two Nerves, called f. 2. F G.
Stomachici Nervi; and is conequently of an Exquiite ene.

The lower Orifice, is called f. 2. K. f. 4. B.
Pylorus; in which you hal oberve a Valve, The Lower round in hape, and as viible and remarkable as the Valve in the Gut Colon. This Valve is to hinder the Chyle from returning back again into the Stomach.

Beides thee two Orifices in the Stomach, there is obervable its f. 2. III.
Bottom, orIts Bottom Inferior Part, more flehy than the ret; becaue therein the Meat is boyled or digeted.
The internal f. 4. E. urface of the Stomach is wrinckled, and tored with fibres, thatInner Surface it may thereby retain what is taken in for nourihment.

The Action of the Stomach is the Coction of Aliments; which though they beAction. Digetion how Caued. many, and of divers kinds; yet the Stomach, by a propriety, or inbred faculty which it has, does diolv •• and as it were melt them, and turne them into a ubtance like Creme; which is <> Chylu • . How that is done, I have already examined in my Anthropographia; and in my Anwer to Wallaeus, a very learned Phyitian of Leyden.

The Stomach has Communion, by reaon of neighbour hood, with the Liver, Communion with other parts. the Gal, the Spleen, the Sweet-bread, the uppermot Guts, upper Part of the Meentery; and alo by the veynes which it has from the Trunk of Vena Porta, and the Splenical Branch. It Communicates alo with the Heart and Lungs, by the Stomachicat Nerves; of which ome Part is Communicated to the Heart and Lungs: it Communicates alo with the Brain, by theT. 3. f. 2. F G. f. • . III. Stomachical Nerves, which proceed from the ixt Conjugation.

It does chiefly Sympathie with the Kidneis, when they are miaffected, eitherGreat Sympathy with the Kidnies. by want of Appe • ite, or by frequent Vomiting, by reaon of T. 3. f. 8. a complication of the Cotal and Stomachical Nerves, dipoed between the two Kidneis. From whence are derived Nerves, that are dipered into al Parts of the Belly.

By reaon of its Nervous ubtance, it has Communion with the whol Body;Communion with the whol Body. whence it is the in the Dieae Cholera, the Ancles are contracted; & there is anxiety, and Unquietnes of the whol Body, when the Stomach is diordered.

div.head: The Medicinal Conideration.
div.p: THe Stomach is afflicted with divere Dieaes, Simi • ar, Organick, and Common. Stomachs Ditemper. For it is troubled with a Simple, or Compound detemper, while it is over cooled, over heated, over-dried, or over-moitned: of which, Galen dicoures accurately, in the eventh of his Method.

Alo, it is Inflamed, Impotumated, and lcerated; and thee three happenInflamation. Apotumation. lcer. Inciion of its Bottom. cheifly in the upper, or lower Orifices, becaue of their flehynes: omtimes they may happen in the bottom, which is wounded, and healed, yea, and can bear inciion, that any Iron, or other hard thing which hurts the Stomach may be taken out, when it cannot otherwie be voided, either upward or down ward: as we read in that tory of a Pruian, who had wallowed a Knife.

Hippocrates oberved a burning Heat about the Stomach, in his Aphorimes:
• urning. which is dangerous, by reaon of Choler hed between the Coates of the Stomach; or by reaon of the neighbouring Parts burning, and Inflamed.

Somtimes the Gall touches thoe Parts of the Stomach which are next it, and
• red by the Gall. corches the ame, as if it were burnt with a Fire brand red hot.

It is alo troubled with Dieaes of Magnitude, Increaed o •
Diminihed; Dieaes in Scituation, in Cavity, in Figure, and in Smoothnes.

The Magnitude of the Stomach, Augmented, and Widened, as in Gluttons,Ditended. does over much tretch the Stomach, and looen its Fibres. So that afterwards, it cannot be ufficiently contracted to imbrace the Meat in uch ort, as to turn the ame into good Chylus: which is the Caue of crudity, and weaknes in the Stomach.

And when the Subtance thereof is o treitghned, through drynes or Swelling ofStra •• ned. the Membranes, that it cannot ufficiently widen it elf to contain the Meat; then is it pained after Eating, though but a little Meat be taken.

But the Stomach is more frequently Dieaed by Dilatation, and Exolution, Widened and and lackned. or Flaggynes, and Slapnes, both in perons otherwie in health, and uch as are ick; while with Broaths and plenty of cold drink the Tone or <> vigor of the Stomach, is o diolved, that a loones of the Belly is thereby caued: which is a • tributed to the Corruption of the Meat through an hot ditemper of the Stomach; or to the Obtruction of the Mearaick Veins: which Symptome, notwithtanding, is often Caued by the over great Laxity of the Stomach, which Fernelius calls Morbum Materiaea a Dieae in the matter; and it mut be Cured with trengthning and atringent things. This has been • erved in the opening of dead Bodies, where the Stomach is found o <> , and o widened, that it would contain the Head of an Infant. And therefore it is very neceary for a Practitioner to oberve the Dieaes of the Matter, which are Cured with drying and atringent things, both given in, and applied outwardly. This was the Doctrine of that ect of Antient Phyitians, which were termed Methodici, who made Laxity, and Atriction, the Cheife things obervable in al Dieaes.

Somtime the Stomach changes its natural Scituation, and is drawn back towardsChanges po
•• ure. the Midrife, which Caues hortnes of Breath after Meales. Somtimes it hangs down as low as the Navel, as has been oberved in Bodies diected, which makes a bad life, and a bad Concoction.
It is obtructed when its upper, or lower Orifice, is troubled with ome welling,Obtructed. which hinders the coming in of Nutriment into the tomach, and its going out after digetion.

It is alo Dieaed with Smoothnes, when the Inner Surface, which naturallyMade mooth. hould be wrinkled, is become mooth, which Caues that ymptome which is termed Lienteria, which is, when there is uch loones of the Belly, that the Meat comes away unchanged, jut as it was Eaten.

Divers Symptomes infet the Stomach in repect of its Action being hurt, and in regard of the diorder of uch things as are Evacuated therefrom. The A • tion ofAction Hurt. the Stomach is, Appetite, Concoction and Chylification. The Appetite is hurt, when it is Abolihed, Diminihed, or Depraved. It is Abolihed, when there is no Stomach or Appet • te, or when Meat is loathed, epecially fleh, which is theWant of Appetite. wort. Appetite is often Diminihed in Dieaes, which is not o bad. But the Depravation of Appetite is wore.

Now it is depraved, when there is a Dog-like Appetite which cannot be atified;Dog appetite. A • urd longings. or when evil things are deired; which kind of depraved Appetite, Pliny termes Malacia; and Galen, cally it Citta; in Latin Pica, the Mag-p • e

Chylification Abolihed, or Diminihed, is called, Apepia, Inconcoction; andUndig • tion. S • ow d • g • tion. Ill dig • tion. by vulgar Phyitians, Corruptio Chyli, a corruption of the Chyle. When Meat is long in digetion, tis called Bradu • epia, low Digetion. When the Meat is corrupted, its called Dyp • pia, ill digetion.

To Action hurt, belong the Feeling, Motion, and Pain of the Stomach. There is feling in the whol Stomach, but it is exquiite in the upper Orifice, by reaon of certain Nerves of the Six Pare, which are there interwoven with admirable workmanhip.

Feeling, is Abolihed, and Diminihed, when there is need of hungring andRe •• ing Meat. thirting, and yet the Stomach perceives it not, but refues both Meat and drink. This proceeds from a great di • temper of Heat, or Cold; which caues Mor • ification, unles the Patient be ditracted.

The ence of feeling is depraved in the Pain of the whol Stomach, or of the upperHeart-burning Orifice thereof, which drawes the Heart and noble Parts to Sympathie therewith: wherefore this pain of the Stomach, is called Cardiogmos, Cardialgia and the aking of the Heart, or Heart-burning; and caues that kind of wouning, which is called Syncope Stomachica, the Stomach wouning; and comes through the Hearts Sympathiing with the S • omach.

And to this Pain of the Stomach, belongs Anxiety, and U • quiet tumblings andAnxiety.
• oings; which the Greekes terme Riptam • s, or Ae; from whence the Feaver Aodes, has its Name; in which the Sick are ful of unquietnes,

The motion of the Stomach, is Relaxation, Coarctation; By theWant of Contraction upon the Meat H • ccuping. Bel • hing. latter, it huts it elf upon the Meat to diget the ame, and when that motion failes, there is nothing but •• uctuations, and riings, both when a man is ful and fating.

The motion of the Stomach is depraved in Hiccupings, and Bel • hings. Hiccuping is more trouble ome then Belching, and is an il ign in feavers, whether it come by fault of the Stomach it elf, or by its Sympathiing with ome other Part, epecially the Li • er. Hippocrates mentions a Dieae called Morbus Ru •• uous, the Belching Dieae.

Diorders in point of Excret • on are frequent in the Stomach; either upwards, inSymptomes in excretion a • e. Vomitings, and Spawlings; or downwards, in the Lienteria, Diarr •• a, and Coel • a • a Affectio.

Vomiting happens, either by reaon of obtruction of the upper, or of the lowerVomiting. Orifice; if the upper be obtructed, the Meat is topped in the upper Orifice a while, and preently after Vomited: if the fault be in the lower, the Meat is retained a longer time, and at lat Vomited up.

A daily Vomiti • g up of Choler, without further trouble, is no Dieae, nor illOf Ch • ler. Symptome; becaue it happens by reaon that a branch of the Choler carrying Veel, is carryed into the Stomach; as Galen oberves and proves by examples.

Vomiting of Blood is an evil Symptome, whe • her the Blood flow from the Liver,Of Blood. by the Veins which are branched from the porta, into the Stomach; or from the Spleen by theTa • . 4. Fig. 8. let. h. Vas Breve. Somtime the Patients life is Vomited up this waies, according to that expreion of a Poet.

p.hi: O • t of his Mouth, he perves his Purple Soul.

div.p: The frequent breaking up of wind with Belching, may be reduced to this SymptomeOf wind. of Vomiting; and this may be that which is termed Cholera Sicca, known to Hippocrates, and declared with its igns, by Ludovicus Dure • us in his Comment upon the Coick Praedictions of Hippocrates.

But there is a Malignant Symptome, called Cholera humida, Of Choler up and down. which is a violent, and plentyful voiding of Choler upwards and downwards, which kills within four daies; becaues very much Evacuation uddenly caued, is dangerous. H.p. 1. Book of Aphorimes; and al exces is an Enemy to Nature, according to the ame Hippocrates. It proceeds from an Inflamation of the Stomach, which is allayed by cooling aud atringent Remedies, inwardly taken, and outwardly applied, but epecially by the drinking of the paw Waters, and other Medicinal prings of the like Nature; and by Laudanum dicreetly given. We mut avoid the ue of cordial, and Stomach Pouders of an hot Nature, becaue they vex and fret the Stomach. The Phyitians of Paris do let Blood, in a mal Quantity, though the pule be very weak, leat the Stomach Heat being uffocated, a Gangraene hould arie.

Spawling, or Salivation, unles it be caued by anointing the Body with Quickilver2. Spawling. (which they cal Fluxing) comes either from the Brain, or ele (and that oftentimes) from the Spleen, whoe uperfluous eroity is received into the Stomach and voided at the Mouth by pitting and pawling.

The Cardiacus Morbus belongs to the Dieaes of the Stomach; of which, readMorbus Cardiacus. Trallianus Lib. 3. Chap. 5. 25. And Mercurialis in Varjis Lectionibus. Twas knowingly aid of Seneca in his 15 Epitle; Bibere et udare Vita Cardiaci et; drinking and weating, is the Life of a Cardiacal Peron. Pliny, in his 23. Book, Cap. 1. of his Natural Hitory, aies, that al Hope of Curing this Dieae conits in the ue of wine. Which he borrows from Varro, out of the 14. Chap. of the 13. Book. This Morbus Cardiacus, is an extreme Faintnes of the Stomach, joyned with much weating: it proceeds from an hot Ditemper thereof.

Among Dieaes of the Stomach Rumination ought to be reckoned, which is anRumination. inverion or turning of the Stomach, as it were Inide out, which in ome Living Creatures is no trouble, as in thoe that chew the • ud. Of this Dieae ee what Hortius aies in his Epitles.

Out of this Anatomical and Pathological Dicoure may be collected, what partsVomits warily to be ued. are purged through the Stomach by way of Vomit: whether it be afe to exagitate this Part by Violent Vomits: whether it be good to ue a mans elf to this kind of Evacuation; eeing no good Hu • wife makes a • lo • e-tool of her Pottage-Pot. The bet way is, diligently to preerve the Stomach and to Roborate • s Tone or contractive Vigor, rather than to diolue and •• cken the ame by Vomiting, unles Nature deire to di burthen her elf that way, and the patient be eaie to vomit, and uch preparatives be prem •• ed as the Antients were wont to ue.

Wherefore they deal unskilfully, not to ay wickedly, who after many otherVomits not to be given to perons very weak. Medicines tried, do give vomits to uch as are at Deaths door, as the lat help, which uffocate that little life which remaines, and bring a peedy death. But ome wil ay that Empericks and Mountebancks, do this with good ucces. I anwer, if you hould reckon up thoe patients who have taken them to their cot, you would find an hundred dead, for two robutions perons aved; who caped by their good fortune, not by help of the vomiting Medicament: it is better to ue vomits rather at the beginnings of Dieaes, while Choler works and ferments in places neer the Stomach, than when the Pangs of Death have eized upon the Patient. 'Tis Man laughter, to wrong People in their health. The dicreeter ort of Empericks, when they are called to uch Patients, are wont to find fault with what other Phyitians have acted, and to declare the Patient dangerouly ick, and there upon, warily to give their Aurum Potabile or om uch other. Medicine as a cordial and retorer of trength, until Nature being freed from al diturbance of Phyick, begins to gather trength: and then they take opportunity to give a gentle Vomit which Purges
erous, or uch like Excrements, up and down. In very many Dieaes, Hippocrates aies, 'tis better to be quiet, than to do any thing; that is, 'tis better to leave the work to Nature, than to give any Medicament. And if the Phyitian knew that he is the Servant and Aitant of Nature, he would cure more Patients than he does. See Valeius upon the 19. Text of Sect. 2. of the 6. Book of Hippocrates Epidemicks.
Sluggihnes of the Belly, and impurity of the Veels, brings al into confuion. Hippocrates.

div.head: Chap. 24. Of the Liver.
div.p: THe Liver, which is the Intrument of making Blood, conits of a SubtanceSubtance of the Liver. Its Color. proper to it elf, fitted, and ordained to that end; for it is like congealed blood, and therefore red, and the ame color it imprints upon the blood; howbeit the Liver of ome Fihes, is of another Color, viz. green, black, yellow as Saffron; in which Creatures, the blood receives its red color by paing through the ubtance of the Heart.

But in Men, and other living Creatures, which have the two Veins ditinct, calledBlood, where, and how made. Porta, and Cava, the whol Mas of blood is wrought in the Liver; but one part thereof, les perfect than the ret, is by the Vena Porta ditributed among thoe Parts which erve to nourih the Body; another part being conveighed by the Vena Cava, is perfected in the Heart, of which is made the Arterial blood, which is ditributed to al the parts, and afterwards is tranmitted into the Veins, that o in a Circular motion, it may pas again into the Heart, that by its flux, it may maintain the perpetual motion of the Heart; as the Wheels of a Mil, are continually turned about by force of the Wind, or Water-fal.
Such blood is furnihed to thoe parts, which having ence and motion, depend upon the Brain or Heart.

The Liver is T. a. f. 10. 1. D. T. 4. f. 1. A B. cituate in the right Hypochondrium, under the batard, or hortScituation of the Liver. Bignes. Ribs, and fils with its bulk, al that Cavity to the Sword-like Cartilage. Somtimes it is o enlarged, as to exceed thoe Natural Bounds, and then it rets upon the Stomach, reaching as far as the Spleen, and decends three or four fingers breadth below the batard, or hort Ribs: which happens, partly through relaxation of the bands wherewith it is bound to the Midrif, and hort Ribs, partly through welling of the Liver it elf, over loaded with Nutriment.

In Man-kind, there is one ingle Liver, which is not divided into Lobes, or Fingers,Number. as in bruit Beats; yet there is a certain T. 4. f. 5. C. Cleft to be een, where the Umbilical f. 1. a. f. 5. B. T. 2. f. 10. G. Vein creeps into the Liver; and many times two little Lobes, or Laps, are T. 4. f. 4. A A. eatedLobes, or laps. under the greater ones: omtimes there is only f. 5. B. one, which being hollowed, receives the Trunk of Vena f. 5. I. Porta, which is included in a Duplication of the Omentum, or Call, that the Excrements of the Liver might be derived thither.

Although the Liver be one continued Subtance, yet Anatomits divide the ameTwo Regions of the Liver. into two Regions; the one uperior, and exterior; the other inferior, and internal. The uperior, or upper, is called the f. 1. B. f. 4. A A. Gibbous, or bunching part of the Liver: the inferior is called the f. 1. A. f. A A. hollow part of the Liver. Into the upper Region, the Vena Its Veels. f. 4. D D. Cava prinkles its Roots: into the nether Region, the Vena f. 5. I. &c. Porta ows abroad its Suckers.

Beides thee Roots, there are obervable, certain Branches of the Channel of Choler, dipered among the Roots of Vena Porta; and certain little twigs of the Milky Veins, which neer the Trunk of Porta, do enter into the Cavity of the Liver. m T. 9. f. 1. a a a a.
l f. 15. H.

It is the mind of Phyitians, that both thee Regions ought diligently to be oberved,Diverity of the Regions, to be oberved in practice. becaue in either of thee Regions, the morbifick matter may be contained, which is diverly to be purged, according as it poees the one or other Region: for as much as the bunching part of the Liver, is purged by the Kidneys, through the Vena Cava, the hollow part is purged by the Guts, by means of the Branches of Porta, which are terminated in the Guts, conveighing blood, and the evil humors of the Liver. I have een Impotumes in the bunching part, when the hollow part has not been at al tainted: and on the other ide, I have een the hollow part impotumated, without any detriment to the bunching part.

Howbeit, inamuch as I cannot ee thoe two Regions eparated o much as by a Membrane; I cannot beleeve that one part can be ick, and the other ound, unles the morbifick humor be contained within the Pipes of the little Veins.

Many Anatomits do affirm, that the Roots of Vena Cava, and Vena Porta, doWhether the Roots of Cava and Po ••• , are united in the liver. meet together, and are united one unto another by many Anatomoes: others deny that there is any uch Conjunction; among which, I willingly acknowledg my elf for one, and give my voyce on their ide: my Reaons I have el-where laid down, and Nature would have it o, that natural, and vicious Humors might not be confuedly jumbled together in the Liver.

You hal oberve, how the Vein which is taken for Cava, takes its rie out ofHow blood is ditributed from the Liver the upper part of the Liver, and is inerted into the Trunk of Cava, neer the midrif, that the Cava may forth with powr out the blood which it hath received from the Liver, or rather tranmit the ame into the neighboring Heart, cituate only two or three fingers breadths off, and incloed in the Pericardium, which cleaveth circularly to the Nervous Centre of the Diaphragma: whereby thou maiet perceive, that the greater part of the blood, goes into the right Ventricle of the Heart, that it may become Arterial, by a double Circulation, Particular, and General. A double Circulation of the blood. I cal that the particular Circulation, which is made from the right Ventricle of the Heart through the midt of the Lungs, o as that the blood comes again into the left Ventricle of the Heart. The general Circulation, is that which is made through the Channels, or large Pipes of the Cava, and the Aorta, after that manner which is decribed in my Treatie of the Circulation of the Blood.

div.head: The Medicinal Conideration.
div.p: The Liver being affected contrary to Nature, is ubject to any ditemper, eitherDieaes of the liver in respect of Temper. ubtance Scituation. with, or without matter; and intead of good blood, it breeds that which is Cholerick, Flegmatick, or Melanchollick. It is altered, and corrupted in its ubtance, whiles it loes its Tone, and becomes flaggy, and faint.

It changes its Scituation, when it is placed in the left ide, and the Spleen on the right, which eldom happens: or when upon the lackning of thoe Ligaments wherewith it is fatened to the Midrif, and Sword-like Cartilage, it inks below the hort Ribs, as far as to the Navel.
Its Magnitude is changed, when it is o over-charged with Humors that it welsMagnitude. again.

It's Figure, or Shape, is alo changed, if we feel it to be round. Oftentimes itsShape. paages are topt, namely, the Roots of the Cava, and Porta; or the Roots of the Gall-Bladder are topt, though the other be open.

It has communion in regard of Neighborhood, with many parts which it touches,Communion with other parts: but epecially with the Stomach, which it often harms, being inflamed, or impotumated: and omtimes it exulcerates the ame, and makes an hole therein, to empty its elf that way of its Quittor. With its hollow part, it touches the Guts, which are offended in Dieaes of the Liver; and alo the Peritoneum it elf, by reaon of the Coate which it imparts, and the Midrif, by reaon of •… m Connexion they have with the Liver, are drawn to ympathize in its Diea •… .
The Action of the Liver, which is Sanguification, or Blood making, is here byAction. the fore-recited Dieaes: whereupon divers Dieaes, and divers Pains do arie.

Wherefore the Similary Dieaes of the Liver are al Ditempers, and the LaxityIts Similar Dieaes. thereof, from which ome are termed Hepatici, who having a looenes do void Excrementitious Blood, like the Water in which Raw fleh has been waht, or Excrementitious Humors of bad and divere Colors.

Its Organick Dieae is obtruction. Its Dieae common to the Similar andIts Organick, Common and Compound Dieaes. Organick Parts, is an Ulcer and a wound. Its Compound Dieae is al ort of Tumors, whence comes the Term of Inflamation of the Liver. alo a cirrhus and a purulent Impotum, which is frequent enough.

Its Symptomes are, Action hurt, and that manyfold: and firt of all, its attractionIts Symptoms. of Chyle being abolihed, breeds a looenes of the Belly, in which Chyle is voided. Its Retention abolihed, breeds the Liver looenes called Diarrhaea Hepatica. But the Principal Action of the Liver, viz. Sanguification or Bloodboiling is abolihed in the Dropie, is diminihed in Atrophia, and is depraved in Cachexia.

The Dropie is defined to be, a frutration of Sanguification in the Liver, whenDropie. in tead of blood or natural pirit, it produces nothing but Water and Wind, which are emptied forth into the Belly, whence come the Acites and Tympanites, that is the Bottle-bellied, and the Drum-bellyed Dropie; or ele they are conveighed into the Habit of the body, whence comes the Dropie Anaarca and Empneumatois, viz. The Bloat-fac'd, Puf-Cheek'd Dropie. Somtimes a Dropie is caued through fault of the Spleen and other Parts, but not without the Liver be hurt, and likewie the heart, by means of the Circulation of the blood.
Atrophia (or falling away of fleh) is an hindrance of the bodies nourihment,Atrophy. by reaon of the badnes of the blood which the Liver Makes.

Cachexia is a depraved kind of Nourihment, by reaon of bad Sanguification.Cachex • . Before thee, is wont to march a imple accident, viz. Badnes of Color in the Skin, either blewih white, or Yellow, by reaon of Seroity or Choler hed into the Habit of the whol Body, even as far as the face, by which we dicerne the evil dipoitions of the Liver.

div.head: Chap. 25. Of the Bladder of Gall.
div.p: NOw follows the Folliculus Fellis, or Cytis Billiaria, the Bladder whichIts Name. is ordained to containe that Excrementitious Choler which flowes from the Liver.
Its ubtance is Membranous, being ditinguihed into two Coates.Subtance. Scituation.
It is placed under T. 4. f. 1. C. f. 5. F. the Liver, & affixed to the greater Lobe or lap thereof, and as it were, overwhelmed therein.

The bottom of the Gal Bladder repects the inferior Parts, Its Neck, the uperiorBottom. Neck. Sinus. parts, and a pipe derived from the Gall-Bladder called Canalis Cyticus, is carried obliquely til it meet the Canalis Hepaticus. There is a Sinus, or bending neer the Orifice of the Bladder,

Its Magnitude varies according to the plenty or Scarity of Choler, It is only one.Bignes. Number. It has been found omtime double, but that was contrary to the intention of nature. It's divided into the bottom, which is the lower Part, and into the Neck which is the upper Part.
It has an oblong hape reembling a large Pear, broad at the bottom and traitterShape. towards the Neck.

It is hollow that it may receivve Choler, and retaine it til a convenient time ofPaages of Choler. emptying the ame: is has certaine pipes or Channels to carry Choler: the one f. 5. H H. f. 3. c. broader and longer, drawn out from the Liver to the beginnigng of the f. 3. D. Intetinum Jejunum, that is the Hungry Gut, or Gut termed Jejunum, by which the thickerMeatus Hepaticus. Choler paes directly away; the other Pipe is T. 4. f. 8. b. maller and horter, which is drawn Cros-waies, from the Neck of the bladder, to the foreaid paage. The former I cal Meatum Hepaticum, the Liver Channel; the latter I cal Cyticum
Meatum, the Bladder paage, by reaon of its Rie and Orifice. For the Meatus Cyticus carries the thinner Choler into the Meatus Hepaticus, which a porousMeatus Cyticus. Membrane, ful of little holes, rooted in the Liver had uckt therefrom.

Aud therefore we mut oberve, that there are two orts of Choler in the Liver,Two orts of Choler • in the Liver. Communion. and two Channels to Purge them away at divers times; which is a Conideration of great moment in the Cure of Dieaes.

The Gall Bladder communicates with the Stomach by touching the ame, which it heates o, as omtimes to burn the ame, when the Gall Is inflamed in its Bladder. Somtimes it ticks to the Gut Colon which paes along hard by, which it often Colers Yellow, and provokes it to expell the Excrements.
This expurgation of Choler, being liable to be topt, does vex the body with many Inconveniences.
There is eldom oberved a third channel of Choler, which goes into the Stomach, unles ome Part creep from the Meatus Hepaticus unto the Pylorus.
It has manifet Veins from the Porta called Venae Cyticae. Its Arteries and Its Veels. Nerves are not o viible.

div.head: The Medicinal Conideration.
div.p: THe Gall-Bladder is ubject to few Dieaes. The mot common are, when itsDieaes of the Gall-Bladder. Cavity or its Channels are obtructed. When its Cavity is ful of little tones, or filled with one great one, by reaon of thick Choler changed into a tony ubtance. Its paages are topped in the Liver, or in the Gut. Alo it is broken, through violeut motion in Vomiting; and ometime it is o ditended with Choler, when the paages are topped that hould Evacuate the ame, that it has been een as big as both a Mans Fits.

Somtimes, when it is empty of choler, it dries up, o that nothing therefore remaines aving the ductus Hepaticus. If we beleive Fernelius, there could be no other Caue found of the death of ome perons, than that their Gall-Bladder had no Choler in it: if o, the evil and venemous Quality of the uppreed Choler was o great, as to infect the heart, or to weaken and corrupt ome noble part.

The Symptomes of this Part are more manifet; which do conit in its actionIts Symptomes. hurt, or in the undue proportion or quantity of the Excrementitious Choler. The Action of the Gall-bladder is attraction of Choler, which is either diminihed, or abolihed. The undue proportions or quantity of the Choler is, when either too little or too much is voided forth.

Which Symptomes cheifly appear in thoe Parts which Sympathie with the Gallbladder,Their Signs. as in the Stomach, when Choler is vomited up; in the whol body, when Choler is hed abroad through the Veins into the habit of the Body, and deformes the Skin; or when it takes its Coure into the Guts and caues a dyentery, or a Cholerick looenes.
But the original of thee Symptomes is to be charged upon the Liver, being il dipoed.Their Original.

And Democritus had good Reaon to earch diligently into the eat and Nature of Choler, when he made diection of divers living Creatures, that he might be more able rightly to cure the Dieaes of Body and mind.

When I ee in an extream Yellow Jaundice, the whol Skin infected with Choler, &Diverity of Choler proved. that the Urins die cloaths Yellow, the tooles being in the mean time whitih; And when I ee in another ort of Jaundice, both the Urins and tooles Yellow; This confirmes to me, that there are two orts of Choler, and everal waies for the expurnation of each of them. In the Yellowet ort of Jaundice, in which the tooles areBy the different orts of Jaundice. whiteih, the Meatus Hepaticus or Liver paage of Choler is topped in the Cavity of the Liver. In the other ort of Jaundice when the tools are Yellow, it hews that a quantity of Choler paes away by the Urins and Guts, and the obtruction
is not o great nor o tubborn, as in the Yellowit ort of Jaundice, and therefore it is to be hoped the Cure will be more peedy.

div.head: Chap. 26. Of the Spleen.
div.p: THe Spleen is a Bowel placed right againt the Liver, as its Lieutenant, and aThe Spleen decribed. kind of Batard-Liver, that when the Liver is Dieaed, it may ait the ame in Sanguification or blood making.

It is of a T. 4. f. 7. C. Subtance pongy, oft, prinkled al over with very many Veels likeIts Subtance
Fibres or threds; yet it is altogether unlike the ubtance of the Liver. It is infolded in a Membrane f. 7. B B. proper to it elf, eeing it receives none from the Peritoneum.
Its Color is Black and Blew and obcurely Reddih.Color. Greatnes.

Its greatnes is uncertaine and not determinable, becaue it grows greater or les, according to the abundance, or defect of Humors which flow thither, & are collected therein. So that there is none of the Bowels which does o eaily grow bigger and leer, as the Spleen.
In repect of Number, it is wont to Be ingle; Somtimes it has been oberved toNumber. be double and threefold.
Conider in the Spleen its upper Part, which is termed the Head, and its netherParts. Part which is called the Taile.
Tis T. 4. f. 1. D. placed in the left Hypochondrium, under the hort Ribbs, oppoed as itScituation. were to weigh againt the Liver, that the Body might remaine equally ballanced.
When it keeps its Natural Contitution, its Temper is hot and moit enclining toTemper. drynes.

It is of an oblong hape, like a Tongue, in Brutes; but in Mankind, it is moreShape. like the Sole of a Mans Foot. In the fore Part towards the Stomach, it is T. 4. f. 8. A A A. hollowed, that it might receive the T. 4. f. 1. I. I. f. 8 B. and C. plenical Veins and Arteries, on the back part towards the Ribbs, its T. 4. f. 7. A. bunching.

Its knit into the Stomach by two or three Veines remarkable enough, which doConnexion. make that o famous T. 4. f. 6. h. Vas Breve, o called by reaon of the hortnes of the way. Through thoe Veins it disburthens it elf into the Stomach: by the Veins and Arteries Splenical, it Purges it elf into the Guts and Kidnies.
Ii's fatened to the batard Ribs by Membranous Fibres ufficiently trong: omtimes it's fatened to the Stomach, and is knit at its point to the Midrif or Diaphragma.
It Communicates with the Heart, by a remarkable peculiar and admirable Artery which it hath, which by a hort way carries thither, the Vapours or • l Juyces thereof.

The Action of the Spleen is much doubled and controverted among PhyitiansAction controverted, divers Opinions thereof. and Anatomits: o Many Men, o Many Minds: Hippocrates did beleeve that it drew uperfluous eroity out of the Stomach: which Opinion Aritotle followed, though others draw it to an attraction of Chyle, either out of the Pancreas and Meentery, or out of the Stomach.
Galen will have it emploied in Purging away Melancholy, which it draws from the Liver.
Others are of Opinion that it prepares Blood for the Heart that it may become Arterial, whether it be of the thicker parts of the Chyle, or of the dregs of the Blood carried thither.
Others ay it prepares a uperfluous wheyih matter, being the excrement of its own digetion, which it ends back again into the Stomach, to ferment the Meats when they are turned into Chyle.
The Arabian Phyitians acknowledg uch an Humor, but they aigne its office to be the provoking of Appetite. Galen thought that it did help to trengthen the Stomach.

In o great dient of Authors what hal we reolve upon? every one brings probable reaons for his Opinion. Hofmannus conceives he has o ufficiently etablhed his Opinion, that no wie man can contradict him. Shal I venter my Opinion among o many learned Champions?

I conceive that the Spleen does attract limy Blood to nourih it elf, and thatThe Authors Opinion. it heds a pecial kind of fermentative Seroity through the Splenick Arteries into the Stomach; and becaue its Parenchyma or ubtance is of a Spongy and oaking Nature, it does by the Veins attract and uck out the uperfluous humidity of the Stomach, that the Coction may be the better.

Howbeit, I deny not but that it may by Accident upply the Office of the Liver, when the ame hath lot its faculty of Sanguification; but Blood cannot be made o good and perfect in the Spleen as in the Liver, eeing it is but a batard Liver, and conequently makes but batard Blood and impure, becaue not Clarified.

Hofman makes himelf Ridiculous, while he eagerly contends in a little BookHofmans Opinion of the Spleens Sanguification examied. which he has put forth, and up and down in his other writings, that the muddy part of the Chylus, is carried by the Mearaick Arteries unto the Spleen; where it is turned into Blood, with which, the neighbouring Parts are nourihed: and that the Excrements of this Blood are voided by Urins, Stool, and Sweat. That good Old Man is to learn, that the thicker Parts of the Chyle are not ucked out, but eparated and ent away into the greater Guts; and that the Mearaick Arteries cannot do as he aies, becaue they containe Arterial Blood. neither do they reach any of them to the Spleen, becaue it has a peculiar Artery, which Arantius firt decribed, and which I my elf have often hown.
Again he ought to have rejected the Milky Veins of Aellius, which he allowes of; eeing none of them reach unto the Spleen.

Furthermore, that ame batard and impure Blood, bred of muddy Blood by a batard Liver, wil be unfit to nourih the neighbouring Parts which erve for Coction, though they appear filthy, for they need to be nourihed with pure Blood for their preervation

The Cholerick, Melancholick and Wheyih Excrements of the aid Blood, cannot be Purged away but by Veins and Arteries; the Arterics are allready taken up with carrying the muddy Parts of the Chyle. They mut therefore of neceity be carried by the Splenick Vein into the liver, that they may be voided through the Guts or by the Kidnies, which would breed very great confuion in the Liver.

If Hofman had conidered, that the ubtance of the Spleen is unlike the ubtance of the Liver, its bignes different, its number uncertain, Color divers, Scituation variable, becaue omtimes it inkes down to the Hypogatrium, more often acends towards the Midrif, omtimes decends upon the left Kidney, the Ligaments being lackned: and latly, its hape, quite contrary to that of the Liver, and omtimes there is no Spleen at all: alo that the tructure of the Veels of the Spleen, is altogether unlike that of the Veels of the Liver; he would never have o tifly affirmed, that that the Spleen made a peculiar kind of Blood out of the Chylus.

Nature does in none of the Bowels more port her elf, than in her haping of the Spleen o variouly and uncontantly. But the Structure of thoe Bowels which are neceary to the maintenance of life, is allwaies, one and the ame and uniform.

Furthermore you may know that the ubtance of the Liver & pleen are unlike, by boyling the one and the other: for the ubtance of the Liver is firme, ollid and Reddih; that of the Spleen is Spungy, oft, and black and blue in Color: The ubtance of the Liver of Animals boiled, as of an Ox, a Sheep, a Goat, is eaten with content: the ubtance of the Spleen is not Mans meat, neither will other Creatures eat it, unles they be very hungry. But if the Office of the Spleen and Liver were the ame in Brute as wel as in Men, they hould have both alike ubtance, and breed the ame blood.

Where will you find a place to clene away Choler in the Spleen, as their is in the Liver?
