If the Spleen draw the more thick Part of the Chyle, it ought to have larger Veins, but they are exceeding mal, like unto threds. Wherefore Hofman does foolihly to enquire the Dioti or Caue why it is o, before he knows the Hoti, that it is o, which ought to go before, and be diligently enquired into, when the natural Action of Parts is ought after, becaue the natural Contitution is Compounded and accommodated thereunto. What cannot an ingenious Wit imagine? But al uch peculations are ridiculous and void, unles they are approved by the Eye, and confirmed by diligent Section and Inpection of Bodies. See Aritotle in the third book of his Politicks, at the beginning of the 8. Chapter, who wil there intruct thee.

If Hofman had known out of Aritotle, that uch living Creatures as drink, have a Spleen, Reins and Bladder, he had more truly expounded that paage of Aritotle out of Hippocrates, of the true ence whereof he glories. The Spleen drawes out of the Belly uperfluous humidities, it elf being contituted of blood.

div.head: The Medicinal Conideration.
div.p: The Subtance of the Spleen is liable to alkinds of Ditemper, and to diversDieaes of the Spleen in Subtance. wellings, epecially that kind of hard welling which is termed Scirrhus. Somtimes it is inflamed, and then the ubtance thereof is perceived to pant, by reaon of the Multitude of Arteries, of which it is ful. It eldom impotumates. Its Coat does oftentimes grow thick and becomes Cartilaginous.
It often grows great by abundance of Humors, and grows •• al again, omtimeMagnitude. of it elf, and omtime by ue of Medicines. It is better that the Spleen be mal, than great.
A double or triple Spleen is not good, becaue it is a fault in the Conformation.Number.

The Scituation of the Spleen is omtimes changed, when its Ligaments beingScituation. lackened, its weight bears it downwards, or they being broke, it fals into the Hypogatrium or Parts beneath the Navel; and then it deceiveth unskilful and heedles Phyitians, who in Women take it for a Mole, or for a Scirrhus Tumor of the Womb, and in Men for a ort of Glandulous Tumor which lies hid in the Meentery. In four patients it has been my hap to ee the Spleen on this manner fallen down into the Belly.

Somtimes one or other of the Kidnies is een to fal down in the ame manner:Difference of the Spleen and Kidney when fallen. but it is eaie to know the one from the other. When the Kidney is fallen, the welling is round: when the Spleen is fallen the Tumor is oblong and an emptines is perceived on the left ide under the hort Ribbs. And if the Tumor be movable, as it is at firt, the Spleen or Kidney is eaily reduced unto its Natural place:The C ••• of both. otherwie, after the pace of ix months, it ticks o fat to the Peritoneum before, to the bottom of the Bladder, to the Guts, and in Women to the Womb, that it mut of neceity putrifie in that place; which it wil the ooner do, if either you give the patient Emollient Medicines inwardly or apply them outwardly. If you would prolong the patients life, you mut often let blood, and beare up the Tumor with a trus or Swathe band.

What if the Spleen fal from its natural place, hal we ear and burn it with a red hot Iron? when it lips into the Belly hal we take that Coure with it? It is a ticklih and dangerous peice of work, notwithtanding Old Farriers or Hore Doctors have written, that the Spleen has been by that means conumed in Hores; and in ome poor laves on whom they durt Experiment o cruel a Remedy.

Much more dangerous it is by opening the left Hypochondrium to take away the Spleen; neither can its thick uperfluous Humors be afely diolved by heating the
ame. I hould by uch a practie ear a contuion, after which an incurable uppuration of the whol ubtance would undoubtedly follow.
There is none of the Bowels which in Dieaes does more change its hape. SomtimeFigure. its long, omtime fourquare, omtimes round, according as it finds room to dilate it elf in.

when it rets upon the Stomach, it does much hurt and diturbe the action thereof;Communion. and if it be fatened to the Midrif, is opprees the ame, or if it reach thither in its Bulk, it hinders the free Motions thereof.

Upon the Spleen obtructed depend the Black Jaundice, Hypochondriacal Melancholy,Obtructed, what Dieaes it Caues. the ill Colors of Virgins and other Women, The Scurvy, or Hippocrates his great Spleens, out of which flowes a Malignant Wheyih Humor, which being pread into divers Parts of the Body, does in the Mouth caue Stomacace or Ocedo a orenes with loones of the Teeth &c. In the Thighs Scelotyrbe a orenes with pots, and wandring pains through the whol body, which are either fixed and abiding in certain Parts, which we cal Rheumatimes, and the Germans refer them to the curvy, as may be een in uch German Authors as have written of the Scurvy, epecially in the Treatie of Engalenus. And therefore after univeral Remedies, they ue other appropriate Scorbuticks, which are detined to the Cure of that Dieae.

div.head: Chap. 27. Of the Vena Cava and Aorta, within the Lower Belly.
div.p: THe Trunk of theT. 12. f. 1. A B C. Vena Cava is commonly reported to arie out of the Liver,Liver is not the Original of Vena Cava. and to be divided into the uperior and inferior Trunk, as if they were eparated, as it is in the tock of theT. 12. f. 4. A. Aorta pringing out of the Heart: but Ocular Inpection does demontrate, that the Trunk of Vena Cava is eparated from the Liver, which creepes beneath, and that near the top of the Liver by the Midrif it receives a branch which grows out of the f. 1. r r. Subtance of the Liver, which carries blood into the Trunk of the Cava, that it may be carryed unto the Heart with other blood which acends by Circulation.

Wherefore that ame Trunk of the Vena Cava, is extended al along without Interruption from thef. 1. B. Jugulum or Neck even to theT. 12. f. 1. D. Os Sacrum. There I make account is the Citern of Blood, becaue a great part of the Blood is contained therein.

The Trunk of Vena Cava, in regard of the Liver, which by a branch upplies i •
Vena Cava divided into Trunks. with Blood, may be divided into thef. 1. B. upper and lowerT. 12. f. 1. C D. Trunk. The inferior produces the Vena T. 5. f. a. g. Adepoa, which is dipered into the fatty Membrane of the Kidney; and then theT. 12. f. 1. x x. emulgent, which is ditributed into the Kidney: after that the f. 1. z. z. Spermatick Vein, whoe right-ide branch prings from the Trunk of Cava, and its left from the Emulgent; finally, it ends three or four branches called f. 1. a a a. Lumbares into the Loins, which are pred abroad unto the Marrow of the Back.

When the Trunk is come to the top of Os Sacrum, it is divided into two ChannelsDitribution of the inferior Trunk. or Pipes, which from their Scituation are termedf. 1. D D. Canales Iliaci, the Illiack Pipes. From thee on either hand are produced other Veins, epecially the a Sacra, b Hypogatrica, Ampliima c Epigatrica, and d Pudenda. In Women, the Hypogatrica, is longer than in Men, and Nourihes more Parts, and holds the Mentrual blood, till the time come that itmut be voided. Wherefore blood is conteined in greater plenty about the Genitals of Women, than of Men.
The Epigatrica is oberved to be two-fould in Women; the one acends into the Muculus Rectus, the other oppoite thereunto, decends as low as the Womb.

In this Trunk of Vena Cava, Fernelius after Galen, placed the eat of continualSeat of Feavers continual and I •… rmittent. Feavers, uppoing the Blood reted quietly therein: but eeing the blood is in perpetual motion, I make the eat of continual feavers to be in the Trunk of the Vena Cava, and in thoe great Pipes carryed along through the Limbs; as the
em •… ry • f intermittent Feavers or Agues, is in the Vena Porta, or in the Bowells, which are nourihed thereby.

Seeing the Veins are the Veels and Citerts to contain the blood, they have a thin coat, aving that the Trunk of Vena Cava has a thicker and tronger coatWhy Cava h •• a thick Coat. than ordinary, to avoid breaking, in cae the blood hould work or boyl therein, which by means of the tendernes of the Coat, can weat and breath thorough.

Tis a Quetion, whether the Veins have Fibres or no? ome ay yea, and omeWhether Veins have Fibres. no. But eeing the Blood is thrut forward by the pirits and Hear, it has a natural acent unto the Heart, and therefore it needs no Fibres to draw it, and if any were neceary, the right ones would uffice, but the circular ones are interpoed for trength, and ome threds are oberved in the Coat of a Vein, not to draw, but to trengthen the Coat. Wherefore the Contentions about the Fibres of Veins are but Vain Janglings; neither are we in Blood-letting o carefully and crupulou • ly to oberve the rectitude of the Fibres, as the Scituation of the Part affected.

Hippocrates in his Book de Morbo Sacro, does Elegantly call the Veins Spiracula Why the Veins are called the Bodies Wind-Doers. Corporis, the Wind-doers or Breathing places of the Body; becaue when they are opened, a Fuliginous or ooty Spirit Iues out with the Blood, and the Air is likewie by them received in, to Cool the Body.

In Antient t •… nes, and the daies of Yore, it was a Part of Sooth aying, to view the blood which flowed from their acrifices, which if it appeared pure and laudable, it was a token of happy and joyful ucces; i • bad and corrupted; it was an ill ign, according to Lucan.

l.hi: Nec Cruor emicuit olitus ed Vulnere Largo
Effluxit nig • um rutilo pro anguine Virus.

lg.head: That is,
lg.l: No uual Blood did pring from the large Wound,
But black and Venemous for Red and found.

div.head: The Medicinal Conideration.
div.p:
Seeing the Veins are the Citerns of blood, it comes here to be conidered howThe conditions of good Blood. the blood ought to be qualified in ound bodies, that o we may be able to judg of that which is corrup •…
Now inbodies that are healthy the blood is Red, Fibrous, and has a mal quantity of Whey •• h Watermingled with it.

Whether the Eabres are made of an earthy and flegmatick matter which is drawnHow the Fibres in the Blood are br ••• . out into threds within the Channels or greater Veins, and is made maller in the leer Veins, many doubt, uppoing the four Humors to be conteined in the Mas of blood. Some admit of blood, but evered from the other Humors, which in the firt Region are eparated from the blood. Others ditinguih the Alimentary Humors from the Excremen •• tions the former are confued and mingled with the Blood, the latter are to be een collected in everal Parts, as Choler in the Gallbladder; Melancholy in the Spleen; and Flegm is diffued through al the Parts of the Region of the belly, notwithtanding Hippocrates acknowledged two fountains of Flegm, the Head and the Stomach.

Now the Quality or temper of blood is hot and moit. Its Quantity cannot beThe natural Temper of the Blood. Quantity of the Blood. defined. The Arabian Phyicians, epecially Avicenna, do write, that in a Sanguine body wel contituted, there are twenty four pounds of blood, o that a Man may bleed twenty pounds and live but if he bleed more, Death follows inevitably. That which preerves our life is likewie the occaion of Death: for as good Blood in a moderate quantity preerves our life, o the ame being vitiated, or too much in quantity, is the Caue of Sicknes and Death it e •• .

When blood offends in quality, it is termed Cacochymia, when in quantity,Cacochymia & Plethora, what they are. it's called Plethora. Somtime the blood is corrupted and not the Serum o • Wheyih Water, Somtime the erum is corrupt and the blood remaines found. Now the erum or Wheyih Water being corrupted, is the wort Humor in the body,
grievouly infecting, weakening and detroying uch parts as are therewith dieaed.

Some Practitioners do make it a Quetion, Whether in the Veins, every Humor has its own proper Serum or not. I beleeve that there is but one kindCorruption of the Serum. of Serum, which according to the everal degrees of its Corruption and Tincture, appears omtimes yellow and Cholerick, omtimes green and livid, or black and blue; omtimes Melancholick, and omtimes Milky. Aritotle counts the Blood corrupted, when it is changed into Serum Somtimes the Putrefaction of Blood is o great, that the whol Mas is turned into a rotten putrefied Serum. When the Corruption of blood, is yet greater, omtimes Worms are bredWorms breed in the blood. therein, which I have een come away in the opening of a Vein. Such a Worm being bred in the Veins, may omtimes flow into the right Ear of the Heart, and growHeart eaten by worms bred in the blood. great, and at length gnaw, and eat upon the Heart, as has been often oberved in the Diection of dead Bodies.

The Veins have in them, a Retentive Faculty, whereby they hold fat the BloodRetentive faculty of the Veins being lot, what follows. within themelves: which Faculty being perihed, they uffer the blood to leak out through al the parts of the Body, yea, even to weat out, as I have een in ome Patients. But more often it flows out immediately by the Notrils, Mouth, Lungs, Guts, Bladder, by the Womb, and by vomiting.

I have divers times een in malignant burning Feavers, that the blood has beenBlood congealed. congealed within the Veins, like unto the pith of an Elder tick; which has been noted by Fernelius in his Phyiologia.

Aretaeus writes, That the Vena Cava is omtimes inflamed, and thereuponVena Cava inflamed. comes to break, which I have een my elf to happen. The Trunk of Vena Cava cannot be dilated, o long as the blood circulates freely. Neither is it ubject to wellings, termed Varices, which are wont to happen only in the Veins of the Thighs and Legs.

Of the Dieaes of this Vein, and of the Blood contained therein, there is a twofoldCure of the dieaes of Vena Cava, and the blood, twofold. Purgation Blood-letting. Cure; Purgation, and Blood-letting: but blood-letting is more neceary of the two in a Plethora, either ad vaa, or ad vires; or in a Plethorick Cacochymia, or in a very great and putrid Cacochymia, that a portion of the extreamly corrupted blood may be taken away.

Blood-letting takes away uch Obtructions as are caued by blood, but not thoe that are caued by Humors congeted in ome part of the Body: and therefore that ame Euro • a o often mentioned, that freenes of paage caued by blood-letting, mut be undertood of the motion, and free paage of the blood through the Veins, and not of the removal of an Humor that is gathered together, and wedged fat into any part of the body.

I • blood-letting cannot be put in practice, the Quetion is, Whether PurgationIf blood may be leened by other waies beide bloodlessing. alone, may upply its place, according to Galens Opinion, in his Book, de Sanitate tuenda; or pare eating, exerciing the body, frictions, weating? I uppoe, where there is no Feaver, the blood may be diminihed by the means aforeaid, and alo by uch Medicaments as draw the Serum out of the Veins; for o the Veins being emptied, the ret of the body may be extenuated and this is oberved, and put in practice in uch Nations where the People are afraid of blood-letting. Howbeit, to open a Vein twice or thrice, is a more peedy, and afe Remedy.

Foramuch as Sylvius, and Carolus Stephanus, have written, that there is a ValveA Valve in Vena Cava. within the Liver, by the Trunk of the Vena Cava, which hinders the blood from returning back; Conringius aies, that it is to be found in Oxen. This favors that Opinion of the bloods being carried from the Liver unto the Heart. It eems to me, that Nature has placed that Valve, that the filth of the mas of blood hould notIts ue. flow back into the Liver, and obtruct the ame: which filth, either he carries by ome way out of the Cava into the Porta; or ele he ends it forth into the habit of the Body.

div.head: Of the Aorta decending. Ditribution of the Aorta decendent. Arteria Litnalis. Its e.
div.p: The decending T. 12. f. 4. C. Trunk of the Aorta, ends forth o many branches, as the inferior trunk of the Vena Cava produces; but it ends withal, a remarkable Artery, called Lienalis Arteria, undivided, by an indirect Coure unto the Spleen.

That ame Artery, as large, and wide as a Gooe Quil, does furnih the Spleen with Arterial blood, that thereby the thick, and limy blood, might be attenuated, and made fit to nourih the Stomach, and it's neighboring bowels, and that it might afford a fermenting juyce to the Stomach, to help its Chylifaction, by that ame permixion of both orts of blood. Peradventure likewie, when the Liver is vitiated, and extreamly obtructed, Arterial blood may be brought unto it, by the Splenick Vein, as it were a Natural Tartarum Vitriolatum, to open its Obtructions.

Then it produces theT. 12. f. 4. p. Caeliacal Branch, which is divided into as many twigs as the Vena Porta is, and has communion therewith, by a mutual Anatomois of the Veels, that is to ay, by a mutual conjunction of their mouths.

This ame Arterial blood, is not circulated, yet may it have a reflux into the Trunk of the Aorta, to disburden the parts of uperfluous blood; which returning back into the Aorta, may conveniently be evacuated, by opening a Vein in the Foot.

The Trunk of the Aorta is made of a Membrane, ix times thicker than a Vein;Thicknes of the Membrane of the Aorta. and therefore it is not ubject to that kind of Tumor, called Aneurima, which the other maller Arteries are ubject unto, by reaon of dilatation of their Coat, or its Rupture, or apertion, when in the Arm, an Artery is opened intead of a Vein.

The Aorta, and Vena Cava, do contitute that Region, in which the matter ofThe Circulatory Veels. continual Feavers is contained; but the blood does not remain quiet in that place, eeing it is perpetually moved round by Circulation: wherefore thee two Veels, the Vena Cava, and Aorta, are ordained both to contain, and circulate the blood, and may be termed the Circulatory Veels.

div.head: Of the Nerves of the Lower Belly.
div.p: Between the two Kidneys, at the Bae of the Meentery, we mut earch diligentlyContexture of the meenteri • Nerves. for that ame T. 3. f. 8. . Intertexture of Nerves oberved by Fallopius, which is woven together of the f. 8. i i i. Stomachick and f. 8. B B. Q. r. Cotal Nerves, concurring on both ides to form this Contexture; from whence are derived al the T. 3. f. 8. l m n. Nerves, which are ditributed unto the parts of the lower belly.
When this Contexture of Nerves is ful of evil Humors, Convulions happen withwhat dieaes arie therefrom the Colick pains, both in men and women, though the brain be no waies miaffected.

div.head: Chap. 28. Of the Kidneys.
div.p: THe Kidneys, which are the Intruments of eparating, and drawing out the wheyih Excrement, do conit of a flehy ubtance, olid and proper toubtance of the Kidneys. themelves, o that the like is not to be found in the whol body.

They have a very thin f. 2. H I I. f. 5. B. Membrane, or skinny Coat, which ticks cloe to their fleh; but they have another Coat which is looe, covered with Fat, which is called Membrana f. 2. A A. adipoa, wraps, and infolds the Kidneys, and is produced from the Peritoneum.
Their Temper is hot and dry, that they may be the better dipoed to attract theTheir temper erous Humidities.

They areT. 5. f. 1. B C. cituate in the Loyns, between a duplication of the Peritonaeum, cituation. which is no other than the Membrana Adipoa, and they eem to be placed without the Cavity of the Belly. The Reins are aid to begin at the lat batard Rib.
They have in length, the breadth of four or five Fingers; their thicknes is twoGreatnes. fingers, and they are much about three fingers broad.

They are two in Number: omtimes, though rarely, there is but one, and thenNumber. it is commonly as big as two, and lies upon the back, the Channels of the Aorta and Cava being a little removed to afford a place for the ingle Kidney.
They are haped like thoe Beans we cal Kidney-beans.hape. Color. Veels.
Their Color is reddih.

You hal oberve in their hollow ide, the Emulgent Veels, and the Ureter pringing forth of that hollowed ide. Their Veels are the Emulgent T. 5. f. 6. D D. Veins and f. 2. a a b b. f. 5. C. Arteries, proceeding from the Trunk of the T. 5. f. 2. E. Cava, and f. 2. G. Aorta.

And this is the outward Conformation of the Kidneys in a grown man or woman:Kidneys, how haped in children. in Children it is otherwie til they are a yeer old, becaue the external face of the va being like a thick bunch of Grapes, does neatly reemble the Kidneys of a Calf: and upon the Kidneys, is placed the Glandula f. 2. A & C. T. 5. f. 1. A A. f. 2. B B. f. 3. & 4. A A. Renalis, which is haped like the Kidney, and in Children, dries up by little and little, til it become flat, being eparate from the Kidneys by a portion of the Membrana adipoa, though it be found not far off in either ide.

The internal Structure of the Kidney, is admirable; which that you may convenientlyIts internal tructure admirable. view, and earch into, you mut cut it artificially on the hollowed ide; and then there wil preent it elf to your view, the enwidened T. 5. f. 5. A A. ubtance of the Ureter, which forms the Pelvis, or Bain; into which, from the upper part, as itThe Bain. were from an Houe-top, the wheyih Humor rains down drop after drop, through nine little flehy Teats, called Carunculae f. 1. F G. f. 2. K K. Papillares, which are acuminatedThe Teats. without, and are encluded, and thrut into c nine Pipes, made of the ubtance of the Ureter dilated. Therefore that covering, through which the wheyih Excrement drops, may be called the Cribrum Renum, or Kidney-ieve.The ieve.

In thoe papillary Caruncles, or flehy Teats aforeaid, the Serum, or wheyih Excrement, is eparated from the blood; which blood pends it elf to nourih the Kidneys, or flows back again into the Emulgent Veins.
b T. 5. f. 6. E E.
g T. 9. f. 2. B D.
e f. 2. F.

div.head: The Medicinal Conideration.
div.p: The Similar Contitution of the Kidneys, contrary to Nature, conits in the DepravationInfirmities of the Kidneys are Ditemper. Impotume, lcer. of their Temper, and of their Subtance. A ditemper either ingle, or with matter, caues a Laxity or loones in the ubtance of the Kidneys, whence prings Atonia, or want of their wonted vigor to act by. By means of an hot ditemper, they come to be inflamed, whence follows an Impothume, and at lat an Ulcer, as wel in the internal, as external parts: for oftentimes a morbifick matter, is collected within the Membrana adipoa, which breeds Impotumes which compres the Kidneys.

Laxity proceeds from a cold and moit ditemper, or from an exceeding hot one,Laxity, how caued. Diabetes. Ichuria. which corrupts the Natural temper of the part; whence comes Atonia, or an impotency to contract it elf; and from thence comes Diabetes, which is the Piing icknes; or Ichuria, which is a total uppreion of Urine, not only in one Kidney, but in both, by reaon of Fraternity, and Co-partnerhip, by reaon of an afflux of a malignant air from one to the other; or by reaon of a reflux of corrupt and filthy blood. Somtimes want of Appetite to meat, is a fore-runner of this dieae, by reaon the Stomachs ympathizing with the Kidneys. Oberve diligently
when the Stomach is ill, if there be no Dieae in the Kidney; for if there be, that's the caue of the Stomachs diorder.

The Number of the Kidneys is eldom changed, and if there be but one, it cannot be known that there is more; neither can that one perform as much as two: and therefore thoe that have but one Kidney, enjoy not their health o wel as they that have both.

Although the Kidneys eem fat fixed unto the Loyns by the fat, as it were withFalling down of the Kidneys. glue; yet do they omtimes fal out of their place, and lean forward, omtime they lip into the belly, not without detriment to the Patients life and health: this is a truth not to be quetioned. Which comes to pas chiefly, not only by melting the fat in which they are wrapped up, but alo by their weight, when they are grown o great, by reaon of ome tumor or tone contained in their Cavities, that they can no longer be kept in their place by uch taies as were wont to hold them. Being fallen into the belly, they tay there a while, and at lat they putrifie, and impotumate.

Being in their natural Scituation, if they prove greater, or more weighty than ordinary,Their welling they caue a kind of numbnes in the the thigh, by compreing the Mucle Poa, and the Nerves, which decend into the Thighs, which are conveighed through the flehy parts of the Mucle Poa.
It the inner Paage of the Kidneys be topped moderately, either by an Humor,toppage. or by a tone, then the parties Urines are thin; or if the Obtruction be total, the Urine is wholly uppret.
If the inner Subtance of the Kidney be exulcerated, the Patient makes urine with lcer. Matter, or Quittor in it.

If a Vein be opened, or broken, bloody urines are made: and becaue the KidneysVein opened, or broke. communicate with the Stomach by the Stomachical Nerves, the Stomach does ympathize with them, being ick, and enclined to vomiting.

The Action of the Kidney, is to attract Serum, and to eparate, and expel theAction Hurt. ame: thee things it cannot do, unles it be ound and perfect; and therefore all the Dieaes aforeaid, may pervert the ame Action. The fleh of the Kidneys is dul of feeling, but the inward Membrane is very enible.

Stones are often bred in the Cavity of the Kidneys, either in the pipes, where theytones bred in the Kidneys. grow like Coral, or in the Bain, where a round tone is formed. If the Stone encreae o much as to caue a uppuration in the Kidney, towards the Loyns, by awhen curable by Inciion. deep iue made in this part, the Quittor may be purged forth, and the tone extracted; otherwie, unles Nature do go before us, and hew us the way, it were a wicked thing to attempt an Inciion of the Kidney, by reaon of the thicknes, and profundity of the fleh in thoe parts.

The Kidneys do omtimes conume away, and caue an univeral ConumptionConumptton of the kidneys. of the whol body; which comes either from putrefaction of the Kidneys, or through overmuch ejection of Seed or Sperm.

In new married Couples, and in uch as are more wantonly dipoed than ordinary,who mot ubject thereunto. this Conumption of the Kidneys happens; which would make ome man affirm, that the matter of Seed, comes from the Kidneys, and that they carry a great troak in the matter of Carnal Imbracements.

Oberve, That oftentimes through weaknes of the Kidneys, which cannot attractDropie from the kidneys weaknes. How to be cured. the wheyih Excrement, a dropie is caued without any fault of the Liver. Neither can the mot effectual Diureticks open thoe paages. And therefore our chief Care mut be to purge thoe, and the neighboring parts, and by Fomentations, to retore the lot Faculty of the Kidneys.

Whether or no, may we force in a harp pointed Iron, to one of the Kidneys, that a paage may be made for the Serum, which is dammed up within the greater Veins, in cae we cannot purge the ame away with Hydragogues, or Water-Purgers?

div.head: Chap. 29. Of the reters.
div.p: THe Ureters are Channels or Conduit Pipes ordained to conveigh the Urine toTheir Decription. Subtance. the bladder.
They conit of a ingle Membranous ubtance, which being encloed in a duplication of the Peritoneum, therefore Anatomits have aid, that they borrow another Coate of the Peritoneum.
They are as long as the Space between the Kidnies and the bladder.Length. Scituation.

Reting upon the T. 5. f. 1. F F. G G. Mucle T. 10. f. 1 o o. Poa, they are obliquely carryed towards the Oa Ilium, and riing up unto the bladder in the bottom thereof, they lip in between the two f. 7. F F. Coates almot as far as the T. 10. f. 7. D. Orifice, where they peirce theT. 6 f. 6. c c. bladder. They have no Valves placed in their Extremities, to hinder the going back of the Urine: but two Membranes meeting together, do exactly hut the Paage.

Naturally they are as thick as Goo-quils, but in uch as have the Stone and uewidenes. to void little ones from the Kidney, the hollownes of the Ureters is o widened, that they have been een as thick as a Mans Finger in the diection of dead bodies.

The Original of the Ureters is rather from the bladder than from the Kidnies, becaueOriginal. they are of a Membranous ubtance. Within the Cavity of the kidnies they are divided into nine Pipes, which are fitted to the little flehy Teates called Carunculae Papillares, that they may ditil the Serum into the Bain or large Cavity of the Ureters, within the Kidnies.
They are thought to have Nerves whereby they feel; but being of a MembranousNerves. Nature, their extream pain in the paage of a Stone, proceeds from the tretching of the Membrane.

Seeing therefore they are ordained to pas the Urine unto the Bladder, they areObtruction. offended with uch things as pas through them, whether it be harp Urine, or purulent matter, or a little Stone, or a thick and clammy Humor, by which they are obtructed. So that the mot uual Dieae of the Ureters is Obtruction.

And if within the duplicature of the Bladder either of them be obtructed, there isStone. bred a Stone, which grows by little and little, which is not movable, but remains fatned to the Bladder, which when thoe that Cut out the Stone endeavour to pul away, they tear the Bladder. Neither do I think there was any other difference of the Bladder in thee, in whom a double Cavity was oberved, and a Stone lying cloe in the one of them.

div.head: Chap. 30. Of the Pis-Bladder.
div.p: THe Pis-Bladder, is the Receptacle of Urine; being framed of a MembranousIts Subtance. Coates. ubtance coniting of two 2 Coates. The b third which they attribute thereunto, is a Duplication of the Peritoneum, within which it lies hid, hanging like a Bottel with its bottom upwards, and with this Partition it is evered from the Guts and other Parts, only in mankind, leat with the weight of the Guts bearing thereupon, it hould be forced out of its place.

Its natural ize is mal when empty, becaue it is widened and contracted accordingMagnitude. to the quantity of the Urine, The efficient Caue of its Contraction, is the econd and external Membrane, which is altogether flehy, which Fabricius ab Aqua Pendente took to be Muculous, and after him Spigelius, who cals it Muculum Detruorem Veicae. He might better have called it Expulorem, the Expulive Mucle of the Bladder.
Its hape repreents a bottle with the bottom upwards, whoe bottom is in theShape. lower Part of the Hypogatrium, and its Neck lies hid beneath, under the Bones of the Pubis.
The Pis-bladder is but one in Number, yet evered omtimes into two Cavities,Number. after the manner before expreed.

It is perforated with three holes near the Neck. The firt and greatet, is thatHoles. out of which the Urine paes: the other two being thoe by which the Urine comes into the Bladder, are the Ends of the Ureters.

Its Orifice is hut by the Mucle Sphincter, which is formed of the ubtance ofMucles. the bladder contracted. There is another Mucle called Externus Spleniatus, as broad as two Fingers, which is pla • ed about the Neck of the bladder and the Glandules or Kernels reting thereupon, termed a Protatae. The power of hutting and opening the bladder depends upon this Mucle.

The Pis-bladder has Veins and Arteries from the b Hypogatrical Veels; itVeels. has Nerves in its Neck, from the Os c Sacrum, and in its body from a Nerve of the d ix Pair. Which is diligently to be conidered in Dieaes of the bladder cauing toppage of Urine, which proceed from a fall caught upon the Loins or Os Sacrum

div.head: The Medicinal Conideration.
div.p: THe Pis-bladder is ubject to an infinite number of Dieaes. In its ubtanceDieaes of the Bladder. it is ubject to al kind of Ditempers, epecially hot and cold: it uffers Inflammation, Tumors, Ulcers, and Palie both in the Neck and whol Body thereof. Of which we hall Dicoure particularly.
Its temper is perverted, when the bladder naturally cold and dry, comes to waxIn its Temper. hot, and fils into an inflammation.

Its Scituation is changed, when that Part of the Peritoneum in which it is includedSaituation. is relaxed, whereby it lips a little downe; which caues a difficulty in piing, unles the lower Part of the Belly be lifted up with the Hand. Somtimes by the weight of many little Stones it comes to have an hollow nook, by the ide of the treight Gut near its Neck, and then the Stones do netle in that corner, o that they cannot be perceived by putting in a Catheter: but the bet way to feel them, is by putting ones Finger into the Fundament.

Its greatnes or widnes cannot certainly be defined unles it were empty; howbeitwidenes. it is enlarged and widened according to the quantity of Urine. But if it be o much enlarged as to exceed the natural meaure, then the Fibres of the Coates being broken or too much lacned, the party cannot make Water, becaue the flehy Membrane is deprived of that motion, by which the Urine ought to be expelled. And in this Cae the Water cannot be voided otherwie than by putting in of a Catheter, which omtimes for a Month or two, mut be done twice a day, until the Membrane have recovered its antient tone or contractive Vigour.

Somtimes the bladder is o contracted and traitned, by reaon of a painful exulceration in its inner Part, and then grows thicker and as it were Cartilaginous; which hinders its ditention: and in this Cae, the Patient mut often make Water with pain.

The Neck of the bladder comprehending its Orifice or the Channel of Urine, hasDieaes of the Nick of the Bladder. alo its Dieaes. It is frequently inflamed, welled Ulcerated, obtructed, and is weakened by the Palie, when it can neither be contracted not relaxed, eeing it is thicker and more flehy than the bottom of the bladder. It is eaily inflamed, and Fernelius was of Opinion that no other Part of the bladder is ubject to inflammation: from whence proceeds an Ulcer, which is not o hard to Cure, as that which happens within the body of the bladder, becaue injections and convenient Candles may be conveighed thereunto.

It is frequently obtructed by the Stone lying hid in the bladder, or by aHow Obtructed.
fungous body which grows therein. Yea and omtimes beyond the Neck, within the bladder, fungous or Sp •• gy carnoities do arie, which do much trouble the bladder and fil the • ame. They arie often • rom a flux of blood, or a welling Vein, which being opened caues a • incu • able Iue of blood, which • oon caues a Gangrene by rea • on of Clotte • s of Blood remaining there
Spungy Carnoities do grow without the Neck within the Ureter, which are te •• ed Hype • a ••• es, which are eaily Eaten away with Medicinal Wax Candles, made and fitte • for that purpoe.
Oftentimes they happen in the Paage of the Urine after a Venemous Gonorrbea not wel Cured.

Al • o • he Neck of the bladder is obtructed by another external Caue, Namely by welling of the Kernels • ermed Prot ••• , which ret upon the bladder. But the Urine is often topped by a Palie in the Neck of the bladder, o that the Sphincter Mucles cannot contract no • dila • e themelves.

To open the Bladder and to earch out the Dieaes which are bred within o •
The Key of the • ladder, an Intrument o called. without the ame, a wonderful new Intrument has been invented, which I cal the Key of the bladder; its commonly te •• ed a Catheter, and is u • ed by uch as Cut Men for the Stone, being different from the Antient common Catheter. So long as this Intrument can eaily be put in, o long there is great Hopes in Dieaes of the Bladder: but when it will not Penetrate, all Hope as gone.

In uch a Cae, either the bladder is perfo • ated in the bottom of the belly by theBladder perforated. Perin • um opened. rine let out with a Knife. Os Pu • is, to let out the Urine, or the Perinaeum is opened. But when a Catheter with grates in it, upon which the Section is wont to be made, cannot be thrut in, to depres the Neck of the bladder which lies hid u • der th Os Pubis, a mal Knife is thrut deep in as far as the bladder idewaies, until the Urine comes away: for o I have often • eed many from imm •• ent Peril.

In perons far in years, who are greivouly troubled to make Water by reaonEae for old M •• that have the Stone. of a great Stone, which cannot be taken out without manifet danger of Death, to give them ome releife in their Miery, the Perinaeum is out in the ame manner, as is ued to take out the tone, and the hole is kept open with a little Pipe. So long as the Pa • ient can be kept alive, the little Pipe is topped with a Tent, and a Spunge is applied to receive the droppings of the Urine, if any be, until uch time as the patient mut needs make Water, and then the topp • e is taken out, and afterwards put in again, and thus the cruel pain and continual provocation to pis, is Mitigated in uch as have the tone.
Alo by th • s means Ulcers of the bladder may be clened and dried, if there be noUlcers of the Bladder clened. Zecchi • s his Vain Brag. Stone, to fret upon the Ulcer.

Zecchi • s brags in his Counels, that he invented this way of giving eae to Aged perons vexed with the Stone but the Phyitians of Paris did ue this Pal • iative Cure long before Zecchi • s was born, it having been practied this hundred years.

If a Stone in the bladder be little, and tick to the Neck of the bladder, or in theThe Stone Su • kt out. beginning of the Ureter, it may be drawn forth by a trong and continual • ucking of the yard, or it may be drawn out by an •• ciion made in the Ureter.

If the Stone • e great it cannot be taken out ••• by Cutting of the bladder, theCut out of the Bladder. In • ection being made upon the Perinaeum, as our Stone-Cutters are wont to do for the way ued by the Antients as it is decribed by Ce • us is difficult and dangerous.

And I beleive that kind of operation ued in E • ypt, when they would take out theThe Aegyption Operation • aught. Stone, <> difficult, which is by blowing up the bladder with a Pare of Bellows. For this operation decribed by P • oper Alpi ••• , is o aburd, that I doubt the truth of the tory, becaue it is exceeding cruel and painful by reaon of the extream tretching of the bladder, which cannot indu • e ditention, neither in its Neck, nor in the Ureter.

That way which F •• b •• cius Hild ••••
goes to take out the Stone, is alo ab •• rdAnd that of Hild •••• is • aught. and dangerous. The way ued by the Operators of Paris and by ome Italians of
the Nu • ion Family, is the only afe and eaie way, by reaon of the IntrumentsThe French & Italian w • y the bet to take out the Stone. and of the Indutrious Dexterity of the Artits; wherefore I wih other Nations had uch Operators. a T. 5. f. 1. F F. G G. b T. 10. f. 1. O O. c f. 7. F F. d T. 10. f. 7. D. e T. 6. f. 6. c c.
a T. 5. f. 7. B. and C. b f. 7. A A. c f. 7. B B. d f. 7. B. e f. 7. E E. f f. 7. D g T. 6. f. 6. c c.
a T. 6. f. 5. F F. b T. 12. f. 1. and 4. . c T. 3. f. 8. o. T. 18. f. 50 d T. 8. f. 8. A B.

div.head: Chap. 31. Of the Genitals of a Man; and firt of the Yard.
div.p: I Proceed to the Genitals of a Man, among which, the Yard, which is aociatedA Mans Yard with the Pi • s-bladder, becaue it cats out Urine through the Pipe of the Ureter, ought in the firt place to be explained.

It is made up only of Skin for thinnes ake, of two hollow Ligaments, of theIts Parts
retbra, the Glans or Nut, certain Mucles, Membranous bands, Nerves, Arteries and Veins.

The Skin is by it elf, has no Scarf-skin, and is terminated at the Root of the Nut.Skin Being looe, it is there doubled in manner of an Headtal, that it may infold the Nut or Head of the Yard and make the Fore-skin, which the Jews and MahometansFore-Skin do cut off, out of a Religious Ceremony. Such Circumcied Perons cannot give that delight to Women in their carnal Embraces, as thoe can who have the Fore-Skin entire. And therefore their Women are better pleaed with the carnal ociety of Chritians.

The Fore-Skin is tied to the Nut by a little band which is termed Fraenulum, The Bridle. the Bridle: it is extended in the nether Part unto the O •• fice of the Nut, in you • g Men that have not had to do with a Narrow-board Virgin.
The Skin being removed, there appeares a Membrane which cloly girds in theThe Membrane Ligaments of the Yard, which may be a production of the Panniculis Ca • nous.

This being taken away, the Veels are een which run along the Back of the YardThe Veels. viz. Nerves, Veins and Arteries. The Nerves come from the Os Sacrum, the Veins and Arteries are portions of thoe termed Pudenda, which are pred out into the external Parts.

Then follow the Mucles of the Yard, two of which are erectors, and two areThe Mucles. Ejaculators. The Erectors do arie from the Tuberous Part of the Huckle-bone and are idelong fatened to the Ligaments of the Yard; the Ejaculators pringing out of the Tranvere Ligament placed between the Huckle-bones, and from a portion of the Sphincter Mucle, are pread along the rethra, to pres the Drops of Water or Seed which happen to ret there towards the O •• fice of the Blader.
Thee Mucles being taken away, three Bodies come to view which form the Yard, Viz. The two Ligaments and the rethra.

The a hollow Lig • ments being dis • oined beneath in the Perineum, do arieThe hollow Ligaments. from the Protuberancies of the Huckle-bone, and have in their progres, the b
rethra inter • ected. Neer the Os Pubis, being • oyned together they make a Pendulous Body terminated with the Nut, which is called c Penis, the Yard.

In thoe Ligaments we mut oberve the internal ubtance which is like the PithTheir internal Subtance. of Elder, being Spungy, blackih and bedewed with black Blood, that it may encreae and decreae in the Carnal Conjunction, for the erection of the Yard depends upon thee Ligamentss.

The rethra or Pis-Pipe, is a Channel of Spongy ubtance, that it may welThe Urethra or Pis-Pipe. and • al with the foreaid Ligaments in the Carnal Conjunction; and therefore it is
no continuation of the neck of the bladder, but is only fatened thereunto.

Oberve diligently, the Obliquation, or Reflection of the rethra in the Perinaeum, Its Obliquation in the Perineum. Impotumated hard to cure. and how the cituation of the Orifice of the bladder lies hid under the bones of the Pubes.

In the Perinaeum, divers Tumors are raied: but uch as adhere to the rethra, and impotumate, are dangerous, often degenerating into Fitulaes, becaue the rethra wil very hardly heal, and grow together. If it be eaten by a venemous and pocky Ulcer, it is not eaily cured, and retored, unles by an exact Sudorifick Diet, or by fluxing with Mercurial Medicaments.

Balanus, f the Nut of the Yard, is an hollowed Kernel, wider in the middle, thanThe Nut of the Yard. the largenes of the external Orifice comes to. a T. 6. f. 5. M. b f. 2. C. c f. 1. d. f. 5. L. d f. 5. L. e f. 5. M. f f. 7. A. g T. 13. f. 8. o o. T. 18. f. 5. o. h T. 12. f. 1. n n. f. 4. •
• . i T. 6. f. 1. a a. f. 5. H H. k f. 5. K K. l f. 1. b b. f. 5. II.
a T. 6. f. 5. K K. b f. 5. G G. c f. 1. c. d f. 7. B. e f. 5. G G. f f. 5 M. f. 7. C. g f. 5. infra. M.

div.head: The Medicinal Conideration.
div.p: The Action of the whol Yard, viz. voluntary erection, and tifnes, being ordainedDieaes of the whol Yard are, Priapimus, for carnal Conjunction, if it be unvoluntary, and painful, it is a Dieae which is called Priapimus.
It is caued by an inflamed dipoition of the Ligaments of the Yard, and alo of the rethra, or Pis-pipe, which is affected by reaon of vicinity, and communication in the ame Action.
Weaknes, and defect of Erection, is an imbecillity of the whol Yard withoutWant of Erection. pain: It aries from a weaknes, or a paralytick dipoition of the Mucles, or Nerves of the Yard.

Somtimes the whol Yard is bowed, and crooked to one ide or another; or bendedCrookednes upwards or downwards; which proceeds from a Convulion of one of the Mucles, or from a repletion, and induration of the Nervous Ligaments of the Yard. Somtimes the Tumor called Ganglion, in the hollow Ligaments, is a caue of this Conterion, or crookednes of the Yard: of which Infirmity, Hollerius in his Comment upon the 63. Aphorim, of Book 5. and Caear Arantius in Chap. 50. of his Book of Tumors, have treated.
Furthermore, The whol Yard is ubject to Inflamations, Tumors, and Ulcers.Inflamation, Tumors, and Ulcers
The Yard is but one in Number, for two had been needles: if we find two, it is Montrous, and they are both ueles; or one is but the rudiment of a Yard, or ome flehy Excrecence.

The jut, and fitting length of the Yard, ought to be ix or eight fingers breadth;Too long, if it be longer, 'tis inconvenient, and hurts the Woman in Carnal Conjunction, and mut be hortened by a ring of wool put about it.
If we beleeve Galen, the extraordinary length of the Yard hinders Generation, becaue the Seed loeth its vertue in o long a paage; which I do not beleeve.

If the Yard be too hort, it caues little, or no titillation, and is unfruitful.Too short Fallopius in his Book de Decoratione, teaches us how to make the Yard longer. Marteal mentions one that had o large a Yard, that when it tood erected, he could mel to it with his Noe.

The Fore-skin has its Dieaes; omtimes it is too hort, and omtimes tooOf the Fore-skin. long, and is incommodious. The Jews have it cut off, for which caue they are termed Apellae, that is, skin-les. If it cover the Nut of the Yard o cloe that it cannot be put back, the Dieae is termed Phymois: If it be depreed to the rootPhymois Paraphymois, of the Nut, and cannot be drawn upwards, 'tis termed Paraphymois.

Both thee Dieaes, if they proceed from • ervency of Carnal Conjunction, whereby the Nut of the Yard remains welled, if it be for a long time toge • her, fomented with extream cold Water, its welling wil abate, and then the Fore-skin may freely be drawn up or down. An admirable Secret.

It is exulcerated with pocky Putles; which being cured, if they leave any hardnesExulcerated. behind them, it is a upicious Argument that the Venom of the Whores Pox, does yet • e lu • king in the body. Seeing the Fore-skin is double, when it is • ut, both the internal, and external Membrane, mut be equally cu • .

The band of the Fore-skin termed Fraenulum, if it be more thick than ordinary,Thicknes of the Fraenulum. and goes unto the hole of the Nut, and makes the ame crooked, it makes men uch as Galen cals Hypopadicos; o that they cannot ingender, becaue they do not cat their Seed directly into the Womb, unles it be cut.

The Nut is ub • ect to divers Tumors, and Ulcers, both internal and external. InUlcers of the Nut. its middle, where 'tis hollowed, it is often exulcerated, by reaon of a harp matter abiding there, and often putre • ying. But in the Whore-maters Pox, it is ful ofDe • ormation with warts. Warts, and deformed; which warts may be eaten off, and eradicated with pouder of Savin; but they grow again, if the internal Caue be not removed, by Medicines accommodated to cure the Pox.

The rethra, or Pis-pipe, which lies along under the two Ligaments of theThe Urethra obtructed. Yard, has its Dieaes. It is obtructed by the tone, which is taken out by Inciion thereof. It is inflamed, by reaon of its Spungy, and blackih ubtance, like the hollow Ligament of the Yard. It oftentimes burns, and is pained by reaon ofInflamed. the acrimony of the Urine; it is inflamed by the harpnes of a putrid Humor, which paes through the ame, as in the virulent Gonorrhaea, and then it wels, and makes the Yard crooked, and tretches it with the Tentigo like a Rope; which dieae they term Gonorrhaea Chordata, the Corded, or Rope-tretched running of the Reins.

It is ulcerated by the Acrimony of Quittor, and purulent Matter; and omtimes lcerated. the Ulcer being not well cured, there grows up a pungy uperfluous fleh, which is termed Carnoitas; which mut be diminihed, or eaten away, with Corroive Candles; otherwie it wels o as to hut up that paage, and top the Urine, not without pain to the Patient.

To the rethra, and Cods, belongs that dipoition which makes men termed Hermaphrodites, when the Teticles are hidden within the Septum of the Peritoneum, Hermaphrodites. and the Cod is empty, or open in its middle part, by reaon of the rethra being there perforated, eeing the ides of the Cod are like the Lips of the Womb, and the Yard is very mal. Thee things have deceived unskilful Midwives, and made them • udg Children o born to be Females.

Somtime the rethra is perforated above the Cod, or neer the Nut of the Yard, which is then hut up, and olid, which hinders the right e • aculation of the Seed, unles the rethra be opened, and a little pipe be put in, to make a paage. But when the Parties grow into yeers, the heat of the body being augmented, alo by violent exercies, and by plucking the ame oftentimes, the Yard comes to be augmented, and the Stones which lay hid in the Groins, do fal into the Cod, unles it be per • orated as aforeaid; or the Stones remain in the Groyns, and often deceive Phyitians, making them to think the Perons are burten.

Such Perons having been accounted Women, do at lat become Men. Howbeit,A woman is never changed into a man. there never was any Woman turned into a Man, unles he abued her Clytoris, being prolonged, or ome uperfluous Fleh have grown out of her Womb, which may have the form and tifnes of a Mans Yard, but is no way compounded as a true Yard. And therfore Women are rather delighted with the mutual rubbing of their bodies one againt another, and by the lying of the one upon the other, than by the vain titillation, and unprofitable intruion of thoe Parts.

div.head: Chap. 32. Of the Groyns.
div.p: BEfore we proceed unto the Stones, we are to take notice of the Groyns; inThings to be oberved. Crural veels. Proces of Peritonaeum. Mucle Cremater. which are to be een, the Crural T. 24. f. 4. A A. Vein, and f. 5. A A. Artery, with the T. 18. f. 5. K L M N. Nerves decending into the Thigh, whereupon does ret the Production of the T. 2. f. 9. E E Peritoneum, drawn through the holes of the oblique Tendons, and tranvere Mucles.

Over this is pread the Mucle T. 6. f. 2. D D. Cremater, being carried athwart through the Groyn into the Cod, and o unto the Teticle, which it encloes with two Coats; the one whereof is called T. 6. f. 2. Erythrois, and the other f. 2. C C E E. Elythrois.

Above the bending of the Groyn, you may ee thoe Glandules, or Kernels, whichKernels. lie cloe to the proces of the Peritoneum: below the Groyn, neer the Veels, you may ee other Glandules, or Kernels, bordering upon the Veels.

Within the Proces are contained, Vas T. 6. f. 1. A. f. 3. and 4. A A. Spermaticum, the Spermatick Veel,Spermatick Veels. which carries matter to make Seed of, unto the Teticle; and another f. 1. V V. f. 3. C C E. f. 3. C C D. f. 5. C C. Spermatick Veel returning from above, and carrying the Seed from the Teticle, to the Seed- f. 5. and 6. E E. bladders. In the Groyn, within the Proces of the Peritoneum, decends the Gut T. 3. f. 4. H H. Ileon, the inward Coat of the Peritoneum being relaxed.

If it decend into the Cod, the aid Coat is broken, and the decent of the Gut isDecent of the Gut Ileum. to be oberved through the holes of the Tendons, which are interchangably dipoed, let in reducing the Gut by Chyrurgical Operation, it come to be placed among the Combinations of Nerves; for the hole of the lat Tendon ought to be cut in under, that the Gut may be reduced into the Cavity of the Belly; in which work, many of the very skilfullet Chyrurgeons have erred, to the los of their Patients Lives.

Note that among the Kernels above the Groyn, do arie the Whore-pock buboesBuboes. or Swellings: among the Glandules, or Kernels, below the Groyn, petilential wellings do arie; ordinary wellings do arie a little higher.

Here you hal conider whether it be afe to ue that prick, or Thread of Gold or Lead about the Production of the Peritoneum, that the proces which in the Rupture called Ocheocele, is broken, may be drawn together: or a Cautick to produce an Echar, may be applied above the Groyn, to produce a Callous, or hard ubtance, which may top the paage of the falling Gut. But care mut be taken that the Cautick pierce not to the Veels which lie beneath, viz. The Veins and Arteries, which being touched, the Patient dies for it.

The Seminal Veels may be feared, and o a man become inviibly gelded, becaueInenible gelding. the Stones wanting their nourihment, do conume, and loe their Vigor. But I ee on every ide, great difficulties in thee kind of Operations, which I judg to be dangerous; and therefore I conceive the bet way is, to let them alone.

div.head: Chap. 33. Of the Fundament.
div.p: AT the ame time, when the Cod is diected, in the Order of Anatomy, by reaonOrder of Section. of Neighbor-hood, the Fundament is to be diected, and demontrated.

The Fundament therefore, called Anus, and Podex, is the outermot end of theIts Name. T. 3. f. 7. M. Intetinum rectum, or treight Gut, which is hut, and pured together by a T. 3. f. 7. O. round Mucle, called Sphincter.

It is two-fold; the one is skinny, and narrow, the other is broader, and more flehy; which adheres to a tranvere Ligament, which is placed between the Protuberances
of the Huckle-bone, and the extremity of the Coccyx, or Crupperbone.

The Fundament has four Mucles, called Levatores; two of which are broad,Mucles. and two narrow: The broad do arie from the T. 3. f. 7. N N. Os Sacrum, and Os Ilium, and are inerted into the larger Sphincter: As for the other two, the former aries from the tranvere Ligament, the hindermot from the Crupper-bone, whereinto they are terminated.

Thee four Mucles do relieve, and raie up the Fundament when it pouchesTheir ue. forwards, and is ready to fal out in the expelling of Excrements which are more hard and ollid than ordinary. The Circular Mucles do hut, and contract the Fundament, let our Excrements hould come away againt our wils: for by means of thee Mucles, we may take our own time, and regulate this kind of Evacution according to our own pleaures.

div.head: The Medicinal Conideration.
div.p: The Fundament is liable to very many Dieaes. It is omtimes poeed withIts dieaes. Tenemus. Falling out. an hot ditemper, with a troubleom, and almot intollerable itching, which caues a continual deire of going to tool, which is called Tenemus.
In the Expulion of the Dung, omtimes the Fundament fals out, which is reduced into its place with extream trouble and difficulty.
Somtimes it is palied, and the Excrements come away whether the Patient wil orPalie. no: and omtimes it is o traitened, that a man can hardly void his Excrements.
Within, and without it wels, the mouths of the Veins being wollen and knobbed,Hemorhoids. which are called Haemorrhoides, both internal, and external.
Somtime 'tis inflamed, but it is more often impotumated; from whence proceedsInflamation. an hollow Ulcer, termed Fitula Ani.

It is made rough with Warts, which are called, Condylomata, or Maricae. ItWarts. Clifts. is exulcerated with mal Clifts, which are called Rhagades. It may afely be cut, according to Hippocrates, after any fahion, without hurting the Sphincter. Finally, 'tis troubled with al kinds of Dieaes.

Somtime it has a Scirrhous Tumor, which huts up the paage of the Excrements,Scirrhous tumor. and caues a difficulty in piing, by reaon of the neer neighborhood of the Are-Gut, and the Neck of the Bladder; which Parts do communicate their Infirmities one to the other.
It is omtimes found cloed up in new-born Infants, and it is cut open: but ifCloed up. the Gut be found ollid, having no Cavity, there is no way but death.

div.head: Chap. 34. Of the Cod, and Stones.
div.p: WE are now come unto the T. 6. f. 1. x x. Cod, which is the Cae of the Stones. It conitsThe Cods, their Coats. of two Skins, the outermot beingf. 2. A A. Cuticular, and grown with hair in uch as are of ripe yeers; it has the Epidermis, or Scarf-skin upon it. Under the hairy Skin, there is a flehy Membrane which called Dartos; it is a Continuation of the Membrana Carnoa of the Belly, tretched down unto the Cod; by help whereof, the Cod is widened, or contracted into wrinkles. For the Stones ake, it is by a Membranous Portion divided into two Cavities, which receive the twoCavities. Stones.
The Cod has Veins and Arteries from the Privy Parts, and Nerves from the Os Veels. Sacrum.

A Stone, or Teticle, is a Glandulous, or Kernellih Body, ordained to makeThe Stones, their Coats. Seed. It is compounded of many parts, of which, the firt are three proper Membranes, for each Stone has two common ones, viz. the Cutis, and Dartos. The firt of the three proper Membranes, is called Erythroides, which has its Original
from an expanion, or widening of the Mucle Cremater, which holds up the Stone.
The Second is the f. 2 C C. E E. Production of the Peritonaeum, which infolds the Teticle.
The Third immediately infolds the ubtance of the Teticle, and is called f. 2. F F. Nervea, the Nervous Membrane.

The Membranes being taken away, the Subtance of the Teticle comes in ight,Subtance. which is f. 2. G. glandulous, white, pretty firm; and upon the ame, overthwart, is placed a mal body like a Silk-worm, which is called T. 6. f. 2. I I. f. 3. and 4. B B. Epididymis; to the one endEpididymis. Sperm Carrier. whereof, there cleaves Vas Spermaticum f. 1. T T. f. 3. and 4. A A. deferens, the carrying Spermatick Veel, which enters into the ubtance of the Teticle, and empties the Seminal matter thereinto: From the other end of the Epididymis, aries the Vas f. 2. B B. Ejaculatorium, Ejaculator. the Ejaculatory Veel, which in its beginning, is f. 3. D. ful of turnings and windings, as is the Body of the Epididymis, and firmly cleaves unto the Teticle by its ends, being looe, and eparate in its middle.

The Teticles are excluded from the Cavity of the Belly, being placed in theScituation. Figure. Action. Cods. They are about the bignes of a Pigeons, or yong Pullets Egg. They are of an Oval hape, and their work, is to elaborate the Seed.

div.head: The Medicinal Conideration.
div.p: The Natural Contitution of the Cod, and Stones, being explained, let us nowDieaes of the Cods. examine the Preternatural diorder thereof. The Cod is apt to be welled with divers fluxions, which flow either immediately into it, or into the Stones.
If the Gut fal into the Cod, or into the Cal, it makes that kind of Rupture whichOcheocele. is called Ocheocele.
If water or wind flow from the Cavity of the belly, into the Cod, they make thoe Ruptures which are termed Hydrocele, and Pneumatocele. Hydrocele.

If in the Spermatick Veels, both Deferent, and Jaculatory, where they are fulCirocele. of turnings and windings heer the Stones, thick blood be inrercepted, it breeds a tumor, which is called Circocele.
If Spongy fleh breed, and grow to the Membrane called Dartos, it is termedSarcocele. Sarcocele.
If the Teticle adhere to the aid pongy fleh, it has the ame name.
If the Stone wel, and exceed its natural bulk, it caues a welling in the Cod.

If wind or water ininuate themelves into the Membranes of the Teticles, they produce thoe Tumors which are called Hydrocele, and Pneumatocele Teticulorum, Pneumatocele. which are familiar to Children.
Moreover, The Cod is inflamed, overrmuch widened, or contracted; bothInflamation. which dipoitions, are inconvenient, and hinderom to life and Generation.

The Laxity thereof, is termed Rhagois; Howbeit, it is naturally more lax onRhagois. the left ide, whether by reaon of the weight of the le • t Teticle, or by reaon of the weaknes, and coldnes of the left ide.

The Stones are faulty in point of Scituation, while they lie out of ight in the belly,Dieaes of the Stones in Scituation. or when they are in the Groyns. By reaon of the former Scituation, in quetions of Divorce, men are pronounced impotent, though trong otherwie, becaue the Stones are not in their Natural place.

By reaon of il Conformation in the Womb, they are faulty in point of number,Number. when there is but one, or when there are three, as in thoe who are called Triorches, who are by ome thought to be very lecherous; which fault goes in ome Families from Father to Son, and therefore it is a Dieae.
They are faulty in hape, when they are uneven, by reaon of the welling, relaxation,Figure. or divulion of the Epididymis.

If there be a fault in the Color, there is a fault in the Subtance, which ought toColor. be pretty ollid; when it is over-flaggy, and oft, it is faulty. If the Stones exceed the greatnes of an Hens Egg, they are never the better, becaue they are liable toGreatnes fluxions: and being wollen, or altered in their temper, they cannot rightly perform
their Office: if they are mal as Hazel Nuts, they have no power to engender.

Now the Action of the Teticles is to elaborate the Seed by their inbred virtueTheir Action implanted in them to that end: wherefore they receive the eminal matter, and when it is ufficiently prepared, that is to ay when it is impregnated with the Generative Spirit, they tranmit the ame into the Jaculatory Veels, and the Jaculatory Veels carry it into the Seminary Bladders. e f. 2. D D.
c f. 1. V V. f. 3. E. f. 4. D D.
d f. 1. c c. f. 3. and 4. c c c.

div.head: Chap. 35. Of the Veels which carry the true Seed, of the Seed-Bladders and the Protatae or Auriliaries.
div.p: IT remaines now that we Speak of the Veels which carry the Seed to the Bladder, and of the T. 6. f. 5. F F. f. 6. G G. Protatae or Aitants. That ame T. 6. f. 1. V V. f. 3. E. f. 4. D. carrying Veel which isEjeculatory Veels. called Ejaculatorium, and takes its original from the Epididymis, is in its Rie very ful of f. 3. and 4. c c. f. 5. C. windings and wrinckled.

Thoe Wrinkles being moothed out do make the Veel twice as long as before.Why Wrinkled Thoe Wrinkles are made to retain the mot ubtile Spirit of Generation, whichHow the Seed is voided. breakes forth violently in the act of Generation with a thin ubtile and pirituous matter, which is mixed with that ame other Excrementitious Seminal matter, which is conteined in the little T. 6. f. 5. and 6. E E. Seed-Bladders, o that they flow both together into the f. 5. K K.
rethra or Pis-Pipe.

And as in the Act of Generation that ame mot thin and pure Spirit leaps forcibly with the matter out of the Teticls: o by help of the f. 1. a a. b b. f. 5. H H. I I. Mucles of the Yard, the Seminal matter which is conteined in the littlie Bladders is alo cat forth.

For I make account that their is a three-fold Seminal matter, one mot pure,Matter of the Seed threefold. which is made and kept in the Stone; the other is Superfluous and Excrementitious, yet of ue for the forming of the Conception, which is thrut away by the Stones and lides leaurly into the little Seed-Bladders: for it is not probable that the mot pure Seminal matter and the Spirit which is the Auther of Generation, hould be conteined amids the Natynes of the Dung and Urine.

The third Seminal matter, is an Oyly Subtance, which leaurely dropping out, does moiten the T. 6. f. 5. K K.
rethra or Pis-Pipe in Men and the T. 7. f. 2. y. Sheath of the Womb in Women; alo it comes away by it elf when the Yard is ditended through lut, and in trong imaginations of the matters tending to Generation and omtimes at the ight of a beautyful Woman.

It is a Quetion whether this Oyly ubtance do flow out of the little Seed-Bladders or from the T. 6. f. 6. f. 5. F F. f. 6. G. G. Glandules of the Protatae, which contein in them a Seminal matter, which is ent forth through mal pores beneath the Knob of the rethra.
The Matter which is conteined in the little Bladders, is forcibly cat out by way of Ejaculation or Squirting, through the holes which are near the foreaid knobby wart of the rethra.

Before the little Bladders be removed, you hal oberve, how they are coveredWhence the Texture of Veins among the Seed-Bladders. round about and hidden under a Multitude of little Veins cattered round about them. Whether they be Veins or Arteries, what they erve for is not yet certainly known. Whether to upply matter to thoe Parts viz. The Seed-bladders, that it may be thence tranmitted to the Protatae to be further Elaborated?
Touching this wonderful Intertexture of Veels, we can as yet determine nothing.

In the Protatae and in the Seed-Bladders, is the eat of the venemous Genorrhea: The eat of a Virulent Gonorrhea. which if it be uneaonably topped, the venom is communicated to the whol body,
or flowes back into the tones and caues a Tumor in them: or if it extend o far as the Perineum, unles it be naturly repelled, it caues an Impotum and eates into the rethra or Pis-Pipe.

You hal do wel to conider whether it be afe in a virulent Gonorrhea, to open a Vein in the Arm, if the arder in thee places be light and without a Feaver? In mywhat Vein to be opened in the Cure thereof. opinion it is better to take blood from the Foot, becaue the Saphena takes its rie near the Groin, and betowes two branches upon thoe Parts, and therefore large bleeding in the Foot, when the Buboes break out, does powerfully revel.

Few or none except Julianus Palmarius a Phyitian of Paris and Fallopius an Italian, are for Blood-letting in the Arm in uch Caes, for it is held unafe, for fear of the Whores-Pocks, by reflux of the venemous Humor into the Bowels and habit of the Body.

div.head: The Medicinal Conideration.
div.p: The Dieaes of thoe Seed-Veels, Seed-Bladders and of the Auniliary GlandulesDieaes of thee Parts are, Ditempers. or Protatae, are, an hot or cold Ditemper, which caue a corruption of the Seminal matter, either from an internal or an external Caue.

Alo the Laxity of thoe Parts caues an involentary hedding of the Seed, whichLaxite whence Gonorrhea. is called a Simple or ingle Gonerrhea: or when it is with pain and inflamation, being caued by infection of a Pocky Whore it is called Gonrrhaea Virulenta, the venemous Gonerrheae.
The flux of Seed which happens to ome in their leep is called Oxynorrigmos, it comes from the aboundance of hot and Spirituous Seed.

The Oyly ubctance is exceeding needful, for in Men through want of the aid Humor,The Oyly Subtance how needful. either the harpnes of Urine hurts the rethra or Pis-Pipe, or it cannot freely pas, neither can the Seed be forcibly cat out, as Galen hints and I have known in many; who were cured with a liberal moitening Diet, a Bath to it in, and Oyl of weet Almonds, Squirted into the rethra with a Syringe. With the ame Humor the Womans heath is moitened in uch as are lutful, and it drops away by it elf without the Ejaculation of Seed.

The Action of the Yard, is not to tranmit the Urine, but to Ejaculte or SquirtAction hurt, whence Barrennes. the Seed into the Womb of the Woman. If it cannot perform that Office it caues Barrennes, which depends either upon the Yard, by reaon of the Ligaments which cannot be blown up o as to raie the Yard; or becaue of the weaknes or Palie of the Mucles of the Yard: or upon the Stones being colder then they ought to be, or being too Flaggy, or les or greater then is uual: or upon the ill hapeing of the Spermatick Veels, as in cae the Arteries be wanting; or upon the defect or faultines of the matter. If the Man be Sickly or the Women have not her health, the Caue of Barrennes is attribted to an evil dipoition of the whol Body: which makes that fitting and convenient matter to make Seed of, Cannot be from thence upplied to the genital Parts.
Neither is fruitfulnes and Conception to be expected, unles the Man and Woman be retored to perfect health; and unles the fault of the Genitals (if there be any) be amended,

div.head: Chap. 36. Of the Genital Parts of a Woman, and firt of the External.
div.p:
THe Genital parts of a Woman are divided into the external and internal. TheExternal Genital Parts. internal prepar Seed, or omwhat like eed, and aford place for the Conception.
The External Parts are viible and mut be viewed before we come to Section. Let us therefore tay a whil in the porch, before we pas into that acred Cave or Cloet of the Womb.

That outward Part which is adorned with Hair is called Pubis the Share: thatPubis. Cunnus I conceive th • Term Cunnus derived from the Greck Connos a beard, does properly ignifie the Hair about the Female Privity & not the Orifice it elf, but only by a Metonymy of the Adjunct for the Subject. Carunculae Myrtiformes. Paage which is hut with two Valves or folding Doors (whence the name ulva) is called in Latin T. 7. f. 5. F F. Cunnus, in Englih the Cunny, or Water-Gate. The Valves are termed Labra Cunni, the f. 5. B B. Lips of the Cunny, or the Doors of the Water-Gate. Thee Lips being drawn aide, the f. 5. C C. Nymphae come in ight, which are pretty firm Membranous excrecences, broader towards the top. At the top of the Nymphes we meet with a little flehy Knob, covered with a thin Skin, which is called f. 4. I I. K f. 5. A. Clitoris. The Nymphae being drawn aunder, the Carunculae f. 5. D. E E. Myrtiformes [that is mal portions of fleh like Myrtle-berries] come to be een, whereof two are lateral, eated on each ide, the third lies beneath toward the Fundament, and the fourth is alwaies placed at the extremity of the rethra or Pis-pipe.

In Virgins, the Lips are, traiter then in other Females, and when their Thighs are opened wide, they appear tretched or bent. The inferior Membrane of the Nymphes is alo in Virgins bent and tretched out; but in their defloration and by frequent carnal conjunction, it is depreed: thoe Connexions are wholly Obliterated in Women which have brougth forth Children.

And thee Parts may be een in thoe which are living. And if you hal thrutNeck of the tromb. your Finger into a Womans T. 7. f. 2. Y. heath or Scabberd [that is the Neck of her Womb] you wil feel it T. 7. f. 3. E E. Wrinkled, and if you carry your Finger higher, you wil find the T. 7. f. 3. D. in mot Orifice of the Womb, for o fa • a long Finger is able to reach. All that pace is called Collum T. 7. f. 2. Y. f. 3. E E.
teri, the Neck of the Womb or the Sheath of the Mans Yard, becaue it receives the Yard like a heath or Scabbard, in the Act of Generation.

In Virgins, after the Nymphes we meet with a Membrane or thin Skin drawn beforeHymen. the Orifice, peirced through with a very little hole. This Membrane is called T. 7. f. 7. A. f. T, 7. f. 5. B B Hymen. If this be found, we find no Carunculae Myrtiformes, if this be not found, thoe Myrtle formed mal portions of fleh, are o welled, that they fil the whol Orifice or paage into the Womb, • o that you can Scare put in your little Finger, without paining the party: o great is the narrownes of this paage, by reaon of the foreaid Caruncles or Myrtle-Shap'd flehy Excre • cences, being united together by certain Membranes.

It is to be oberved, that thoe Myrtle-hap'd little bitts of fleh, are wholly obliterated in Child-birth and not to be een, until the external Orifice of the Womb begin to contract it elf again and to grow trait; which argues that they are nothing but plaites or Fouldings-in of this Orifice; which are unfolded and tretched or moothed in the time of Travail, that the Child may more freely come forth; even as the Neck of the Womb is very thick, that it may be the more eaily widened in the Birth. Hence I conjecture and conclude, that thee Carunculae may more fitly be termed Carnoitates and Plicaturas Orificii externi, certain flehynees and foldings of the external Orifice of the Womb.

Thee things being thus oberved, we mut proceed to diection, that the tructureLips of the Womb. of thee Parts may be dicovered. The f Lips of the Womb are made up of the Cuticula or Scarf-Skin and the Skin on which the Haires grow, and they have underneath Fat and a flehy Membrane which eemes to be of the Nature of a Mucle. It eemes to be pred in that place, that it may erve to draw the Lips together; but inamuch as it reaches into the Clitoris, it does in ome ort reemble the Mucles of a Mans Yard, Yet thoe in the Clitoris are different from the other.
Thoe who have their Privity plumpe and Pappy, and the Lips thereof thick, the motion of their Mucles is very mal and hard to be dicerned.

The Nympha T. 7. f. 5. C C in young Women is oft, but as they grow in Years and by frequentThe Nympha Copulation, it is hardened and becomes almot like a Gritle. It is a production of the Skin of the Lips, or by Nature o made and there placed, to direct the tream of the Urine.

T. 7. f. 4. I I. K. f. 5. A Clitoris being the eat of Laciviounes and Lut in Women that delight inThe Clitoris. mutual confrictions, is termed Tontigo, or the Womans Yard. It is made up of two Nervous Ligaments, not at al hollow as thoe of the Mans Yard; they proceed from the Tuberous or bunching Part of the Huckle-bone, and when they are come o far as where the bones of the Pubes are joyned together, they receive another body placed between them, which is white, and being joyned together they make up the Clitoris, which imitates a Mans Yard, as the Brets of Men have a reemblance to Womens Dugs.

The Ligaments of the Clitoris have Mucles fatened unto them, as in Men proceeding from the ame place as thoe in Men, and they are covered with Skin, and that Skin in the extremity or end thereof is folded back, like a Mans Fore-Skin. Not without caue therefore is this Part called the Womans Yard or Prick.

The round T. 7. f. 2. S S. f. 3. and 4. F F. Ligaments of the Womb do reach unto this Part: whence it comes toThe Wombs Ligaments. pas that the Clitoris being rubbed with the hand, the ends of thoe Ligaments are likewie chated and heated, and the Tickling is extended as far as the Womb and Teticles, whence they arie and through which they have paage.

Thoe Ligaments of the Womb are omwhat hollow, as far as to the Groines, whence it comes to pae that a virulent matter being •• om the Genitals expelled hither, does breed Pockie Buboes or Swellings, and other Tumors which are not at al Malignant.

The Sheath is Compounded or made up of two Coates: the one is internal and Membranous, the other is external and altogether flehy, like a Mucle, that it may open and contract it elfe, and in the Act of Generation Squeeze and Milk the mans Yard. But the inner Coat is wrinkled, like the Roofe of an Oxes Mouth.
a T. 7. f. 2. Y. f. 3. E E.

div.head: The Medicinal Conideration.
div.p: Having diligently urveyed thee Parts, you hal now conider the DieaesCommon Dieaes of thee Parts. Cloure which are wont to happen upon them. And in the firt place the external Orifice or paage into the Womb, is omtimes naturally hut up, the Lips being cloed together. This often happnes in Girles newly borne. But this cloure is more frequently found to be in the Nymphes; or intead of the Myrtle-hap'd Carnoities, we meet with the Hymen flehy and unboared. Somtime after hard labour in Child-birth, thee Parts being torne do grow to one another. This natural growing together of thoe Parts in Children mut be eparated, and o it mut in Women when it comes by accident.

I have een ome women conceive notwithtanding this growing together, there being a little hole left for the Seed to enter at, being eagerly attracted by the hungry womb. When the time of their delivery was come, by reaon of much moiture flowing unto thoe Parts, this cloure did of it elf open. Maides and women that are thus cloed up, are termed in Greek Atretae imperforated perons, uch as are unboared or unbroached.

Somtimes the widenes and opennes of thee Parts is o great that it provesLaxity. loathome and hurtful to Women, Namely uch as have undergone hard Labor in Child-Birth; o that it is needful to traiten the ame with Medicaments.

Somtimes in Women that have never had Children, by reaon of over-frequent carnal Conjunctions, thee Parts are o opened and widened, that they eek to Phyitians, that they may recover their former traitnes, and o bring their Hogs
to a better Market. Howbeit, Virginity lot cannot be repaired, it may be couterfeited by Art, but it is not the Part of an honet Phyitian to teach thoe Arts: it belongs only to Adulterers and Bawds, or uch as get their living by protitution of the Bodies of yong Women.

Furthermore, the Lips have their peculiar Dieaes, they are Inflamed, Swelled, Peculiar Dieaes of the Lips.
lcerated from a common or extraordinary Caue viz. The Whores-Pocks. Alo they are ubject on their inner ide to Warts, Puhes termed Thymi, reembling the Color of Flowers of Time, and certain mal Tumors called Condylomata reembling the Joynts of a Mans Fingers.Of the Nymphs.

The Nymphoe in omè Women, yea and in ome nations do grow to uch a filthy greatnes, that they hang without the Lips, and then they mut be cut. They are made ruff with Putles or Puhes, but more often defiled and made ugly with the foreaid Thymi, Warts and lcers pringing from the Whorematers Pocks. Of the Clitoris

The Clitoris is omtimes exceeding long, reembling a Mans Yard: it is then termed Cercois, Caudatio, the Long-Taile Dieae; o that ome Women do abue that Part one with another when it is longer and thicker than ordinary. Such are thoe which are termed Hermaphrodites or Rubters: for it was never known, neither is it poible, that a Woman hould be turned or tranformed into a Man.
But a Man being at his Birth reputed for a Woman, as aforeaid, by the coming forth of his Genital Parts, may be turned into a Man, that is to ay, be acknowledged for uch.

Somtimes within the Sheath there hangs a flehy Excrecence which reachesOf the Sheath. as far as the Lips and farther, very deformed and troubleome, and omwhat like a Mans Yard. It is rooted near the inner Orifice of the Womb, or it ries from the ides of the heath, far within. It mut be cut up by the Roots, or ele it wil grow again, being a great trouble to marryed Women, becaue it hinders the entrance of a Mans Yard, in the carnal Embracement.

Near the Caruncles or Carnoities before mentioned, there appeares within, aOf the Caruncles. Vein, two or three, which are pretty ful, and drop Blood out like the Haemorrhoides, and are omtimes exulcerated, and may degenerate into Malignant Ulcers, unles they be wel looked to.

Within the Sheath, in the upper Part, in the very Orifice of the Womb, a MalignantAn lcer. Scirrhous Tumor is bred, which at lat degenerates into a Cancerous Ulcer. A ad and mierable Dieae, if it arie through fault of the Womb and other Parts of the Body. If the aid Ulcer proceed from the Whorematers-Pocks, as oftentimes it fals out, it is curable, provided the foreaid Orifice be not wholly eaten up, and that the Ulcer have not crept into the inner Parts of the Womb. That may be perceived not only by the Intrument called Speculum Matricis, with which we look into the Womb, but alo by putting up of a bodies Finger.

div.head: Chap. 37. Of the internal Parts of a Woman which erve for Generation.
div.p: THe external Parts being diligently viewed and accurately diected, the PartsThe Way of hewing thee Parts. of the Fundament come next to be cut up: and then the Symphyis or growing together of the bones of the Pubis being dicovered, the Gritle placed between the bones, mut be cut aunder with a very harp Pen-Knife, that the Thighs may be more eaily diplayed, and that their may be room enough made to handle the internal Parts.
The internal Parts may be divided into thoe which make up or belong unto theInternal Parts twofold. Body of the Womb, and thoe which prepare the Seminal matter. We mut begin with the latter.

The Vaa Spermatica deferentia, that is, the T. 7. f. 1. a b. carrying Spermatick Veels,Vaa Deferentia. are made up, like thoe in Men, of the Spermatick T. 7. f. 2. I M. Veine and the Spermatick
T. 7. f. 2. K L. Artery. They have the ame Rie in Women as in Men. Herein only they differ, that they are not o traitly united, nor with o many turnings, as to make a broad T. 6. f. 3. and 4. A A. T. 7. f. 2. c c. Paratata, which is not in Women,
