They are divided into three Parts, whereof one is carryed into the Stones; the other to the Bottom of the Womb: and the third creeps along to the beginning of the Sheath.

The Teticles in T. 7. f. 2. o o. f. 4 A C. Women are otherwie framed than in Men: they have noTeticles. Epididymis; have but one Coat; their ubtance is oft, made up of little Bladders, wherein is contained a Wheyih ubtance, which is wont to pirt out upon the face of the diector, if he take not heed.

Such a tructure of the Tetices in women and uch a conformation of their Spermatick Veels, made Aritotle to doubt and others of his followers, whether the Female Sex were Proliick and afforded Seed to the making of the infant, as well as the Male, as Galen after Hippocrates, maintaines they do.

From the Body of the Teticle the ame Spermatick f. 2. d d. f. 4. b b. Veels preparatory are carryed to the bottom of the f. 2. R. f. 4. E. f. 3. A. womb, and to the f. 2. Q Q. f. 4. D D. Hornes or Trumpets of the womb, which Veels are far different from thoe in Men.

Thee things thus oberved, let us take a View of the Body of the womb with theHorns of the Womb. Its Ligaments. external Parts thereof. Out of it there aries in its upper Part, the Hornes and four Ligaments, two broad and f. 2. P P. Membranous, which are productions of the Peritonaeum. They are tretched out in Virgins and women that have not bore Children, reembling the diplaid wings of Bats or Flitter-Mice. They hold the womb that it fal not down.

The other two Ligaments are round & omwhat f. 2. S S. f. 3. and 4. F F. longih, which arie from the bottome of the womb near the Hornes. In their Rie they are hollow, and in their progres as far as the Oa Pubis, we find them hollowed.

When they are come as far as the Clitoris, they are cloven and pred forth in the hape of a Gooe-foot through al the fore part of the Thigh. I was the firt that made dicovery of that ame Cavity and of the formerly unknown ue of thee Ligaments. According to the Opinion of the Ancient and latter Anatomits, they keep the womb from acending upwards: but without thee Ligaments, the womb cannot acend, unles it hould pluck away the Sheath and the Privities, which are contiuations of the body of the womb.

The Horn T. 7. f. 2. Q Q. f. 4. D D. of the womb being fitulous or hollowih, is oberved in the lower Part thereof to be torne and jagged, as if the Rats had gnaw'd it: it conteins within it, a certain hard and round texture, which reembles the ubtance of the Jaculatory Veels in Men, and white Seed is there preerved and found.

Having oberved thee things, you hal proceed to the body of the womb;The Wombs. Subtance. Coat. the Subtance whereof is flehy and Syungy, and as thick as a mans Finger. It is Cloathed with a Membranous Coat, whether it be proper or received from the Peritonaeum.

The womb is of an hot and moit Complexion: it is Scituated in the lower T. 7. f. 1. d. PartTemper. Scituation. of the Belly, beneath the Navel, jut in the middle betwen the T. 7. f. 1. e. Intetinum Rectum or Are-Gut and the T. 7. f. 1. e Pis-Bladder.
In Virgins until they have their Coures it is little and hard, after they have hadGreatnes. their Coures, it grows ofter: in women which have had Children it is greater and thicker.
It is haped like a mal Gourd, a Pear or a Cupping-Glas.Shape. Number.
It is one in number and no more, yet omtimes divided into two Cavities by a Partition in the middle, which is the Caue that ome women bring orth two or three Children at a Birth.
The Cavity of the T. 7. f, 3. B B. Womb in Virgins and in thoe which have never conceived,Cavity. is o mal as to contain only a peae or a very little bean; In uch as have born Children, it is larger.

The Action of the womb is conception, or attracting the Seed, and reducing theAction. ame into Act, by cauing the ame to ferment and proceed to formation. And although this be that for which the Womb was ordained, yet it is by accident the Sluce or Outlet of Superfluous Humors in the Body, which do either continually flow unto this place, as in the Whites, or at certain eaons; as the Mentruous Blood, which being more than the woman needs for her Nourihment, is ordained to nourih the Child in the womb, and when it is born, it drops out of the Dugs in the form of Milk.

div.head: The Medicinal Conideration.
div.p: By out knowledg of the Natural Contitution of the Genital Parts of womenDiorders of the. we come more certainly to undertand their departure from the aid natural Contitution by everal orts of Infirmities.
The Spermatick Veels are liable to obtructions, whereby the uual Flux ofSpermatick Veels. Stones. Humors is topped, which is very hurtful to women.
They wel together with the Stones, and become as big as a mans Fit; by a collection of Humors reembling Tallow or uet.
This is known by a welling in the bottom of the Belly at the ides.

The Trumpet or Horn of the Womb is widened and moved by Seed, which beingTrumpet. there corrupted, eekes its paage out. But wonderful it is that the mans Seed hould come thither, and that as Hitories report, a Child hould be conceived there. 'Tis very trang that a Child hould be formed out of the Cavity of the womb; and it favours the Opinion of Paracelus and Amatus Luitanus, that a Child may be made in a Glas of a Mans Seed and mentrual blood, placed in Hores Dung, unles both of them, the one being an Athiet the other a Jew, were known to be Impotors.
The womb is the Root, Seed plot and foundation of very near al womens Dieaes,Womb it elf. being either bred in the womb, or occaioned thereby.

It it be troubled with an hot ditemper and inflamed, it caues intollerable burnings,Ditemper. the Feaver Synochos and the burning Feaver, very troubleome Itchings? and finally it brings exulcerations, the Cancer and Gangraena.

If it be tung with ervent Lut, it becomes enraged, caues Uterine fury and Madnes; wil not let the Patients ret, but invites them to hake and agitate their Loins, that they may be disburthened of their Seed; and at lat, they become hameles and ask men to lie with them.

Somtime it is drawn out of its place towards the ides, and is carryed this way andMotion depraved. that way, as far as the Ligaments and Connexions of the Womb wil give leave; and it wil rie directly to the Liver, Stomach and Midrif, that it may be moitened and fanned; it Caues Choaking and Stranglings, and raies terrible and violent motions and Convulions in the Body.
In a word, the Womb is a furious Live-wight in a Live-wight; punnihing Poor women with many Sorrows.

Although Hippocrates hath written and Fernelius confirmd the ame, that the womb like a Globe does rowle it elf in the Cavity of the Belly; yet are they rather the Horns of the womb, which are receptacles of Seed Spirituous and hot or putrified, which being welled do move themelves this way & that way, til they have hed their Seed into the Cavity of the Belly: which Seed being dipered, brings very cruel pains and tretches the Belly, until the force of the Spirits be Evaporated: hence comes that ame welling of the Belly and tifling about the Midrif.

Somtimes malignant Vapors acending from the Womb by the Veins T. 7. f. 2. V V X X. and Arteries,Suffocation unto the Lungs and Kernels of the Throat, may caue choaking and tifling: and the malignant vapor of the Seed being o pernicious, is violently darted into the Brain, and al parts of the Body, from the VVomb, as from a Beat that pits poyon.

The VVomb is but little when empty; but when it is illed with evil Humors, it wels above meaure; and it has been een to equal the Head of a new-born ChildCancerous Scirrhus. which is an incurable Infirmity, becaue it is a Cancerous Scirrhus, which is the wore for being tampered with by Medicines.

Somtimes the Orifice of the Womb being cloed, and firmly ealed up, WaterDropie flows out of the Belly into the Cavity thereof, and coming to a quantity, it brings the Dropie of the Womb. Somtimes evil Humors are collected there, and by the force of Nature, do afterwards break forth. This often happens to Virgins, and others, from the uppreion of their Coures, the internal Orifice being topped, as I aid before.

The Womb is watered with a two-fold Humor, Seed, and Mentrual Blood; theWhether eed uppreed hurteth women? uppreion of both which, does many waies afflict Woman-kind, and the evacuation thereof, does them much good in many repects. Howbeit, we do not read in Hippocrates any where, that the retention of their Seed, is hurtful unto Women: he writes indeed, that the Womb being dry, does acend to the uperior parts to receive moiture (which Galen laughs at) and that it deires to receive the Mans Seed to moiten it elf; and that therefore marriagable Virgins that are troubled with fits of the Mother, hould be married, and have the carnal ociety of Men. And therefore he makes the retention, or over-great flux of the Coures, the only general caue of Womens Dieaes, and aies that Women cannot be in Health, unles they play the Women, that is, void their Mentrual Blood. In cae therefore, that aWhat mut be oberved in letting blood to move the coures? Woman, or a Virgin have her Coures topt, whether or no may we hope by bloodletting, three or four times repeated from the Arm or Foot, to draw the blood unto the Womb? I remember the Story of a Woman in a Conumption, becaue of the toppage of her Coures, from whom Galen drew blood in a large quantity.

That we may know to reolve this Quetion, three things are to be noted; The Matter, the Place, and the Expulive Faculty. The Matter is Blood, which remains1 The ufficiency of matter. over, and above what was neceary to nourih a woman for a months time, which was ordained to conceive Child, and to nourih it being born: wherefore we mut conider, whether the woman abound with blood, o that he has what to pare, and void forth; for if he want blood, by reaon of ome fore-going dieae, or becaue he eats little, we are not to expect that he hould have her Coures.

The place through which it ought to flow, is the womb, with the Hypogatrick2 Fitnes of the place and Spermatick Veins: for thee Veels do contain the uperfluous blood, until the due time appointed for this Purgation, and they end it forth either by the Cavity of the womb, or by the Spermatick Veels, into the neck thereof. But if o be the Womb hal be dry, or hard, and the Spermatick Veels and Veins obtructed, we cannot hope to procure the Coures to flow, by often blood-letting. And the Expulive Faculty is not eated in the Genital Parts, which receive this blood,3 Strength of the faculty but depends upon the general trength of Nature, which thruts this uperfluous blood out of doors.

Thee three things ought therefore to concur, that a woman may have her Coures, Matter, Place, and the Expulive Faculty; and Medicaments ought to have aMedicaments, & other means to accomplih the Cure repect thereunto. A Vein is to be opened in the Foot, rather than in the Arm; Cupping-glaes mut be applied without Scarrification to the inner part of the Thighs, above the Veels: Convenient Purges mut be given, with Apozemes that move Urine, attenuate, and open the mouths of the Veins. Pils of Steel, Mirrh, and Aloes, mut omtimes be given, and Baths made to it in: or a Vaporary mut be ued omtimes of blood-warm Water alone, and omtimes boyled with Hyterical
and opening Herbs, the team whereof, the Patient mut receive into her Womb. Alo Fomentations mut be applied to the Os Sacrum, and the lower part of the Belly, and good Diet appointed, not heating, but attenuating and opening.

The Action of the Womb, is Conception; if it be abolihed, the Patient is barren:Symptoms in the Actions hurt. Sterilitie Which barrennes, depends either upon the ditemper of the womb, or upon the il hape thereof, or the hardnes of the inner Orifice, or the ditortion thereof, or from fault of the Stones, and Spermatick Veels, in which omwhat is wanting, either in point of tructure, or of matter: and if a woman be ickly, he cannot make good Seed fitting to caue a Conception, til he recover the oundnes of her health, and til the faults of her womb (if not incurable) hal be amended.

But foramuch as the Womb is ordained, not only for Conception, but to evacuateSuppreion of blood or eed. the Superfluicy of Natural Humors in the Body, uch as are, uperfluous Seed, and Mentrual blood: if they be totally, or in part uppreed, the woman cannot be in Health, nor if they flow too much. Hence comes the Gonorrhoea Over-great flux thereof. implex [imple running of the Reins] or the Feminine Flux, either of blood, or Humoral, when only Humors come away: which lat, if it be malignant, and the Humor be harp, exulcerating, and of evil color, it is dangerous, and comes omtimes from an outward, venemous, and contagious caue; and therfore women ought dicreetly to be quetioned touching that matter, that they may be brought to acknowledg their Dieae, and not deceive the Phyitian under a pretence that they have the ordinary whites, to their own hurt, unles they acknowledg themelves faulty, or lay it upon their Husbands, whom it is better to accue, if they be in any meaure upected, than to cal the womans Chatity in quetion.

Becaue we are treating of the Action of the Womb, which is Conception, I will peak a little touching the ame, and hew, How a woman is dipoed during Conception: What is the fruit, or work of Conception, v.z. how the Infant comes out of the womb, and how the woman is contituted in the time of her Travel, and what happens unto her after her Travel, until he be wel, and upon her Legs again.
Touching other Dieaes, whereunto • he is ubject, I wil peak nothing, becaue they differ not from uch of the ame kind as he is troubled with, when he is not with Child.

Wherefore, as the Abolition, or taking away of the Action of the womb, is Barrennes;Moles, Abortion, &c. o the Action thereof being depraved, brings forth a Mole, or a fal • e Conception, or an Efflux of the Seed, after eight daies, or Abortion.

If the Conception be true, and legitimate, a Child is thereby begotten; for theThe Childe Conception Mans Seed being quirted into the T. 7. f. 2. Y. Sheath, is ucked, and retained by the f. 2. K. f. 3. A A. womb; and then the f. 3. D. internal Orifice being hut by its heat, and inbred vertue, it tirs up the forming Faculty of the Seed, and ets it on working: VVhereupon, of both Seeds mingled, the Child is framed; which is begun by a certain point, or littleRight haping peck; which upon the third day is perceived to pant, in Egs that a Hen its upon. Afterward, certain Skins are formed, within which, the foundations, or firt threds of the Veels, and al parts, are drawn out of the Seed, and the woof, or uper-tructure, is produced out of the Mentrual blood, which comes upon it: and then the Placenta is made, being a Mas, or Lump of Fleh, termed alo the T. 8. f. 3. A A. VVomb-Liver,The Placenta or womb-liver. which being glued to the ides of the VVomb, interpoes it elf between the f. 2. A B C D G. Navel-trings of the Child, and the Veels of the Mothers womb, which before were joyned together.

Now the Conformation of the Infant, is different in the parts thereof; but the aid difference, does more manifetly appear in the Veels of the T. 9. f. 4. D Heart, which are united by a double Anatomois, or Union of the mouths of the aid Veels, as I have decribed them, in my Hitory of the Child in the Womb.

Some ickly VVomen, while they go with Child, have their health better thanWhy ome childing women are ickly, others not ordinary; but the Child fares the wore for it, becaue it ucks up the impurities of the Mothers blood. Others are wore at that time, becaue the impurity of the mas of blood, is carried into divers parts; and if it tick in the Stomach, it caues either trange longings, or frequent vomiting; in ome, al the while they are big, in others,
to the middle of the time of their Belly-bearing.
If a Woman, during the whol time of her Conception, can make the Child partake of her paions, it wil partake both of her Health and Sicknes.

Whether or no, may we let blood, or purge a ick woman that is with Child?Whether a bigbellied woman may be let blood? Affir. Blood may be taken away at any time, epecially in the firt months, in which the Child being mal, needs little blood to nourih it; but in other months alo, blood is taken away, if the greatnes of the Dieae require it, to ave both Mother and Child.
And if any ill happen after blood-letting in uch a Cae, it mut be attributed rather to the violence of the Dieae, than to the blood-letting, or any other Remedy applied.

But if a VVoman with Child, be taken with the dieae Cholera [a violent purgingWhether in the dieae Cholera he may bleed? Neg. upwards and downwards of corrupt Humors] when he is in her eventh or eighth month; whether in uch a cae, is it afe to let her blood? If it be upected as hurtful in uch women as are not with Child, let their trength being by much Evacuation weakened, hould be more perihed, and decayed, much les is it to be allowed in uch as are big-bellied, who have uffered plentiful, and immoderate Evacuation out of their Veins; becaue it inclines the Patient to micarry, while it defrauds the Child of its nutriment, and impoverihes the mother; o to go about to Cure a VVoman with Child, is a dangerous, and unheard of Practice. For if al Practitioners di-allow the ame in Men, and VVomen not with Child, both Greeks, Arabians, and Latines, both Antient and Modern; much more is it to be di-liked in a woman even or eight months gone with Child. If it be done in a mal quantity, it is to no purpoe: what can the taking away of one little Porrenger of blood do, to reit the furious agitation of Humors, and to extinguih a Feaver, eeing the blood is wont to come very lowly away, drop by drop, and the bet firt.

I ay no more, let I hould eem with affectation to handle this Quetion, which hal be more accurately dicued in another place. He that deires to be acquainted with the Cure of VVomens Dieaes, let him read Hippocrates his fift Book of that Subject.

It is worthy Obervation, That the greater the Child grows in the VVomb, theWhether in bigbellied women, the womb grows thinner? Neg. more does the VVomb, and the Placenta, or VVomb-Cake, or VVomb-Liver encreae; o that neer the time of Travel, it is as thick as a mans Thumb, contrary to the Nature of other Bodies, which by how much the more they are ditended, by o much the thinner they grow. If the thicknes of the VVomb be les, either thoe VVomen are lean, or have little blood, or had a flux of blood a little before their Child-birth; and uch do void little or no blood by way of the Child-bed Purgations.

Now the Child in the VVomb, lies round like a Foot-ball, floats in Water, beingThe poture, & acco¯modation of the child in the womb. compaed with two T. 8. f. 1. C C C C. Membranes, the one called f. 2. E E. Amnion, the other f. 2. F E. f 3. B B. Chorion, has the f. 3. A A. Placenta, or VVomb-Liver fatened to the ides of the VVomb, as a Mattres, or Bed to ret upon, in which the Mothers womb is purified, and in which the Unbilical, or Navel-Veels are rooted, viz. f. 2. A. a Vein and two f. 2. B B. Arteries, which carry blood to the Liver and Heart.
The Vena Porta has blood proper thereunto; and the Cava has alo blood of its own, which mut go unto the Heart to be circulated.

The Child in the womb, is nourihed by the f. 2. D D. Navel; it breaths a little, its Heart T. 9. f. 3. B. T. 11. f. . moves, and exercies its vital Faculty, it feels, and is moved, and has been heard alo to cry.

At lat, when it finds it elf perfect, whether in the eventh, or in the ninthThe Natural Birth. month, which is the ordinary time for a Child to be born, being impatient to be any longer there imprioned, it breaks its bands, and prion doors, and eeking to come
out, makes its own way, with the Head T. 8. f. 1 D. foremot; and uch an Egres is termed a Natural, and right fahion'd Birth.

Before that Nature begins to work, he moitens the waies before the Birth, with aWhat precedes the ame. Clammy, and gluih Humor. The internal Orifice of the womb, and the whol Sheath, which in the lat months, do by little and little grow thick, are moitened with the ame clammy, glutinous Humor, that they may eaily be enlarged to uch a widnes as hal be neceary for the going out of the Infant.

That the Child be rightly born, it ought to come out with its Head firt, and its Face towards the Mothers Breech, the Membranes being firt broken, and the water run out: After the Child, the Secondine, or After-birth, mut come forth, viz. What follows the Placenta Carnea, or Womb-Liver, whol, and untorn. VVhen the Child is come forth, the Navel is tied T. 9. f. 2. P. a Thumbs breadth from the Skin, and after it is tied, it is cut of, leaving only another Thumbs breadth.

The Infant being wiped and clened, with its Head gently preed together, and cloed, is delivered unto the Nure. The Midwife takes care of the Mother, who is careful of her privy parts, being pained, and to recover her languihing trength.

If the Birth prove hard and painful, a Feaver is raied, and the privy Parts are welled, by laboring, and endeavoring in vain to bring forth the Child. SomtimesHelps to further hard labor her trength falls her, and other whiles Convulions do arie. Then is blood drawn from the Arm, and the Foor, and the Genital Parts are fomented with Emollient, and laxative Fomentations, and are anointed within with opening Oyls, and freh Butter. The Patient is put into a bath of luke-warm water, and harp Clyters are given, to provoke the womb to excretion: and the inferior parts are provoked by Aperitive, and provoking Potions to open themelves.

Finally: when all wil not do, and the woman has paed over two or three daies in thee Torments, if he appear like to die, and ready to faint away, if tokens of a Gangrene in the Privities do appear, although we are not ure that the Infant is dead, it is drawn out with an Hook, that the Mothers life may be aved; it is better thatDrawing the Infant out by an Hook. one die, than two, and the life of the Mother is to be preferred before the life of the Child. The Mother ought not to die to ave the Child, and therefore the Caearean Section [ripping the Child out of the Mothers Belly] ought not to be practied.

'Twas elegantly aid by Tertullian in his Book de Anima, cap. 25. Necearia crudelitate trucidatur Infans ma • ricida ni moriturus; that is, It is a neceary kind of Cruelty, to kill that Child, which otherwie would kill its own Mother.

VVhen the Infant has broke prion, and ecaped, if the Placenta, or After-birth do not follow, the Midwife mut thrut her hand into the Cavity of the womb, and pul it • way gently, let the bottom of the womb be drawn down.

If in a woman dead preently after her Delivery, you view the privy Parts, you hal oberve the Caruncles obliterated and defaced, the Nymphes much diminihed o that only ome Rudiments of them, are to be een, and the inmot Orifice o wide, that it wil receive a mans four fingers bended together.
The widening of thoe Parts to let out the Infant, and the traitening of them again,Admirable power of Nature. Child-bed Purgations what they are a while after, is an admirable work of Nature.

The widnes and thicknes of the womb, are diminihed by little and little, by the coming away of the Loches, or Child-bed Purgations, which is nothing but that blood queezed out, which had been hut up between the Spongy ides of the womb. But if the largenes of the womb be not diminihed, nor the blood evacuated, it putre • ies,
and caues an Inflamation, and the womb continues tretched, and bard, as is the Child were yet within it, and at length a Gangrene aries, which brings unavoidable death after it.

But if the whol Placenta be not drawn forth, it is no neceary caue of Death; and the place from whence it was pulled by force, for a while appears rough and uneven, til the whol womb be dried, and reduced unto its natural Figure: al which ought diligently to be oberved, epecially in Child-bed women that are ick.

The largenes and hardnes of the Body of the womb continuing with a Feaver, isChild-bed Purgations retained, how to be evacuated a very dangerous, and doubtful Dieae; and a great Quetion it is towards the Cure, whether we hould open a Vein in the Arm, or in the Foot. Fernelius confidently lets blood in the Arm: Pereda a Spaniard, tels us, That we hould not regard from whence the blood comes, but into what part it is collected, and bids us open the Vein which is next that part.

Corteius in his Micellanies, has ifted this Quetion, and favors the Opinion of Fernelius: howbeit, more profitable it is, and more ecure, to take blood out of the Foot liberally, repect being had to the Patients trength, not neglecting cooling Clyters, Epithems, Fomentations, and Pearies, made to provoke the womb to cat forth that putrified, and death-cauing blood; and the rather to avoid the Calumny, and prating of il-tongu'd Goips, by whom Remedies are defamed, which have been the means to ave many peoples lives.

The Infant has no Dieaes proper to it elf, aving Teeth-breeding, Smal Pox,Dieaes proper to Infants and Meazles. Hippocrates under the name of Tooth-breeding, comprehends al Childrens Dieaes, becaue chiefly when they breed their Teeth, Infants are o ick that many times they are taken away by death.

Many Dieaes are raied by the pain of the Childrens Tooth-breeding. ThereTeeth-icknes are two times in which the Tooth-icknes does vex, and endanger the lives of Children, viz. When the Teeth firt prout, and when they break out of the Gums.

The Meazles, and mal Pox, are new Dieaes, unknown to the Antient Phyitians,Meazles. Smal pox which are thought to be contracted, and bred in the Mothers womb, by the Mothers corrupt, and Mentrual blood; the fault whereof, Nature is wont to purge out, and cum away by thoe Eruptions. I ay no more, let I hould eem to go beyond the bounds of an Anatomical Dicoure. Neither is it my Deign to deliver an exact Pathology, or Decription of Dieaes; but only to hint at uch Dieaes as are known by knowing the Natural Contitution of the parts of the whol Body.

div.head: Chap. 37. Of the Pains of the Loyns.
div.p: THere is nothing which we more frequently meet with in Hippocrates, and in the Practice of Phyick, than Pains of the Loyns, whether they be primary, or econdary; that is to ay, Attendants of other Dieaes; which are oftentimes neglected by Phyitians as Symptomatical, unles they be very tubborn, and olitary without a Feaver. The Caues of which pains, are not accurately enough declared, neither is their Cure ufficiently explained by al Practitioners.

This knot I hal endeavor to unty, and illutrate. The parts therefore of theA muter of uch parts as are in the loyns lower Belly, being demontrated, and the Guts taken away, we hal ee the Loyns T. 10. f. 1. T. 14. all the Tabl. covered with Mucles, both within and without, and flehy T. 10. f. 7. H H. portions of the Midrif reaching down to the Os Sacrum, and the Trunk of the Vena T. 12. f. 1. c. Cava decendent, alo the T. 12. f. 4. C. Aorta, and the two T. 5. f. 5. B C. T. 5. f. 5 B C. Kidneys. And if you hal cal to mind the cleaving of the Meentery to the Loyns, and hal oberve the Lumbary, or Loyn T. 12. f. 1. a a. T. 12. f. 1. a a. Veins, produced from the Trunk of the Vena Cava, and the Arteries proceeding from the T. 12. f. 4. C. T. 12. f. 4. a a. Aorta, both conveighed into the holes of the Vertebra's as far as the marrow of the Back. Al thee things being diligently viewed, and conidered, wil give great light to our Conultation.

Galen complains in his Commentary upon Text 7. of the Second Book of Pro
• heticks; and upon Text 8. of the Third Book of the ame Work, of the Obcurity of the pains of the Loyns, becaue of the Ignorance of thoe Parts which compound
and work upon the Loines; yet ome caues he aignes of thoe pains, and Ludovicus Duretus that ame ublime Interpreter of Hippocrates has added others, but they have not aigned all. I wil therefore do my endeavour to clear this point.

And in the firt place, it is fit to take notice, that this pain is by the Greeks calledThe Name with its Elymology. in one word Ophualgia: the Latines term it Lumbago, and he that is made weak by pain in his Loins, is called Elumbis vel Elumbatus, diloined or unloined. In the French 'tis termed Erne as it were a Rene from the Kidney, which lies in the Loines; and when the pain aries from a Convulion of the Fibres, the common people ay their Kidneys are torn in under.
If this pain of the Loins be eaed with Clyters, the Humors being emptied which were hut up in the Guts or Meentery, the Common People ay, that their Reins or Kidneys are wel di-burthened.

Now that our enquiry touching pains of the Loins may be clear and Methodical,The Authors Method. it is neceary in the firt place to ditinguih the Parts contituting the Loins, which are pained, and the bordering Parts which as efficient Caues do give occaion to thoe pains, not neglecting the more remote Parts. Then we hal enquire into the common internal and external Caues of thoe pains, and to um up al in a word, we hall conider the Parts which end the Humor, and the Parts which receive the ame.

The Parts therefore which make up the Loines and are the ubject of the pains,Parts which contitute the Loins. and Are the ubjects of Pains. are thee. The T. 1. f. 2. B B. Skin with the f. 2. D D. flehy Membrane, the T. 10. and 14. &c. Mucles which are pread upon the five T. 2. f. 1. Vertebraes, both without and within with the f. 5. and 6 Os Sacrum. Within the f. 2. a. Cavities of the Vertebraes, the Marrow of the back with its Membranes, and a numerous company of T. 18. f. 5. 11. 14. branches of Nerves, and the Membranous Ligaments, which knit the Vertebra's one unto another. Alo we mut oberve how the f. 5. A. Marrow of the back is in the Loins parted into an innumerable company of f. 5. o. threads, like an Hore-Tail, and that the whol Back-bone is moved in the Loines, by an Articulation of the firt Vertebra of the Loines, with the lat Vertebra of the Back.

They are deceived who think that by the word Loins Hippocrates undertands only the Parts included viz. The T. 18. f. 5. II. o. T. 3. f. 8 o. p. &c. Nerves, the T. 10. f. 2. T. 14. Mucles of the Loins, the Spinal T. 18. f. 5. A. Marrow with its Membranes, and the T. 5. f. 1. B C. f. 2. C D. Kidneys: for beides al thee Hippocrates comprehends under the term Loins, the f. 1. D. f. 2. F. great Vein and f. 1. E. f. 2. G. Artery, and the f. 1. H I. f. 2. L L. N N. Spermatick Veels, and the f. 2. H I. a a. b b. &c. Veels of the Kidneys, the f. 7. F F. T. 12. f. 1. and 4. &c. Bladder, the T. 7. f. 1. X X V V. Womb, the T. 4. f. 6. II. Hemorrhoides and the thick T. 3. f. 4. I K M. Guts. But I would fain ee the places which everally demontrate thoe Parts.

Now the neighbouring Parts, which are able to hurt the Loins, by reaon of theirParts bordering upon the Loins which are The pecial Caues of their Pains. nearnes, or heavynes, or by disburthening their Humors into them, are the Meentery f. L A A. &c. which is knit unto the Loins, the lower Part of the f. 4. K. Gut Colon, the two T. 5. f. 1. B C. f. 2. C D. Kidnys which touch upon and cleave unto the Loins, by their f. 2. A A. fatty Membrane, the Trunks of f. 1. D. f. 2. F. Vena Cava and f. 1. E. f. 2. G. Aorta which are pread along in the Loines, and the Veels pringing out of them, which are propagated into the Mucles of the Loins and the Back-bone. Of which ort are the Veins and Arteries of the T. 12. f. 1. and 4. a a a. Loins,
al • o the Haemorrhoid T. 4. f. 6. I I. Veins, which pas down al a long the Loins into the Fundament; as alo the T. 6. f. 1. 2. . &c. Spermatick Veels which wel with Spermatick Humor, which in their progres do end branches unto the Loines. In Women, the T. 7. f 1. d f. 2. R T &c. Womb with its f. 2. Q Q. S S. Ligaments and f. 2. o o. f. 4. A A. Teticles may hurt the Loins, but epecialy in a Woman with Child, by reaon of the weight of the Womb and Child. The Veins and Arteries of the Iliac T. 12. f. 1. and 4. D D. branches, which are pread abroad through the Os Sacrum, may vex the Loines.

The remote Parts which hurt the Loines, are, the T. 4. f. 1. A B. Liver by the Vena f. 1. F F f. 6. the whol Porta, Remote Parts and f. 1. G H. Meentery, and the T. 17. and 18. Head whils it disburthens it elf of its Superfluities into the T. 18. f. 5. A. Marrow of the Back according to Hippocrates in his Book de Glandulis. The Humor decends through the Cavity of the Spinal Marrow, as far as the Loines, and it cannot eaily go farther, by reaon that the Marrow of the Back is their divided into a f. 5. o. Million of Threds.

We mut alo oberve the common Caues of the Pains, which are frequentlyCommon Caues of Pains. found in Pains of the Loines, as internal Rheumatimes or Fluxes of Humors, and external by the Veins, or an Humor between the Skin, whith flowes from the Head betwixt the Mucles and Flehy Membane,

Oftentimes the btanches of the Vena Cava and Aorta do carry a Patt of boiling and Superfluous Blood, out of the greater Channels into the Loines, which they Dieae either in the Mucly Parts, or in the Membranous Parts, or in the marrow of the Back; which is the Caue that a Palie follows the Colick, or an Arthritis degenerates into the Colick and the Colick is changed into the Sciatica. Alo, outward Impotumes of the Kidneys, and paions of the Gut Colon being either ditended or exulcerated, are Communicated to the Loines. within and without in the Loines may arie Tumors, Impotumes, and Ulcers, yea, and the Loins are ditorted by flux of Rheum, or ome welling. Their Fibres are ditended by the Cramp. Many times pains of the Loines are tirred up by external Caues, asExternal Caues. a fall on the Back, or a Blow with a thick Stick, or ome other maie thing.

Thee things being premied and wel undertood, it is eaie to explain very obcureCertain places in Hippocrates expounded. places in Hippocrates, touching pains of the Loines, which you hal find in the Commentaries of Duretus upon the Coick Prognoticks of Hippocrates, and others collected together in the Commentaries of Marinellus upon Hippocrates, in the word Lumbi.
There are two kinds of Loine Symptomes: for ome are in the Loines, and others pring from the Loines: both of them are by Hippocrates judged to be very tubborn and hard to deal with,

In his Coicks he hath pronounced abolutly and without exception, Such as have pains in their Loines are in a very bad condition. And in the ame Book, Dieaes which arie from pain of the Back, are hard to cure. And how wil you undertand thoe places, unles by a clear knowledg of the the Parts ending and Parts receiving, as I declared before.

Certain it is, if in the beginning of Dieaes their be pain in the Loines, with heavynes and a Feaver, Blood very hot or in great plenty is contained within the greater Veels, which being more inflamed, if not timely prevented, may be carried into the Head or into the Lungs, from whence greivous Dieaes may follow. In other places he does particularly explain the Caues of Lung pains.

If I hould recite thoe places, I hould fil twenty Leaves and upwards, wherefore I wil take in my Sailes and dipatch al in a word. Pains of the Loines in acute MalignantDanger of thee pains in Feavers. Feavers or other Feavers in the beginning are dangerous for they ignifie a great Tumult in the Blood, and irritation of Humor within the greater Veels, which is much to be feared if a peedy coure be not taken to prevent what may follow, by a plentyful blood letting, epecially in the Feet, to hinder the recoure of the blood to the upper Parts of the Chet or Head, where it is wont to produce divers terrible and deadly Symptomes.

We ought therefore to be very fearful of pains in the Loines which perevere in Feavers, although Blood have been often let, becaue in the Region of the Belly, Humors lie extreme deep, which may take their coure uddenly to ome of the nobler Parts, if they be not diligently Purged forth.

And therefore to cure uch like pains of the Loins, Hippocrates was went toTheir Cure. open the Veins of the Ham or Foot: which is confirmed by him, in his Coicks: the pains of the Loins proceed from aboundance of blood there, and blood-lettings that are caued by pains of the Loins are large and plentyful. Thee things declare the neceity of blood-letting, when the Loins are pained with a Feaver.

Purging mut not be omitted that the Vault of the lower Belly being loaded with Excrements may be emptied and clened; out of Aphor. 20. Book 4. Though Hippocrates has written that uch as complain of pains in their Loins, are loo • e • bellyed than ordinary; that aying does not take away the neceity of Purging in thee caes.
Bleeding at the Hemorrhoid Veins is good both for the Kidneis and for pains of the Loins; and therefore the Hemorrhoids are to be provoked.

A lating pain of the Loins without Heat or any Inflammatory dipoition, unles it can be dicued with Fomentations, after purging & blood-letting often repeated, the Humor mut be drawn out with Cupping-Glaes and Scarification, and by Application of Veicatories, or making Iues on each ide of the Back-bone; alo with a Bath of freh water qualified with Herbs, or by itting in natural Baths, or having their water Pumped from on high upon the Parts affected. For the pains of the Loins are more vehement and tubborn if the erous matter be conteined within the Mucles as far as the Vertebras: and they are yet wore and harder to be cured, if they come to the Marrow of the Back.

But thoe Symptomes which are thought to arie from the Loins, do not arie from the Parts which contitute or make up the Loins, but from the neighbouring Parts, which being pread upon the Loins, do caue pain, and transfer their Humors into other Parts, by a quick or low motion, by the Veins and Arteries, uch as are Vena Cava and Aorta, the Haemorrhoid Veins and the Mearaicks. Out of Galen.

div.trailer: The End of the Second Book:

div.head: THE THIRD BOOK OF THE ANATOMY AND PATHOLOGY OF John Riolanus, THE KINGS PROFESSOR OF PHYSICK.
Chap. 1. Of the Chet.
div.p: LET us proceed unto the Parts of the Chet. Now the ChetIts Bounds is the Manion Houe of the Vital Parts It is bounded, and circumcribed below, by the T. 10. f. 2. 11, 12, &c. batard Ribs, and f. 1. I I. f. 6, 7, &c. Midrif; above by the f. 1. f. T. 12. f. 1. B B. Claviculae, and the whol Circumference, and bulk thereof is made up of al the T. 10. f. 1, 2, 3, &c. Ribs, the Vertebra's of the f. 3. Back, and the f. 2. A A. Breat-bone. And becaue the Neck comptehends the beginnings of certain Parts which belong unto the Chet, it is referred thereunto, rather than to the the Head, though it be the prop and Pillar thereof.

That the Chet may be wel haped, it ought to be of an Oval Figure, and notShape. flat before, which is termed Pectus Tabellatum, a Table-hap'd Breat, and is a token that the Party o Breated, wil fal into a Conumption.

The Chet is Compounded of divers Parts, which are divided into external andParts. internal, that is to ay into Parts conteining, and Parts contained. The conteining Parts are common and proper. The Common are five. The Scarf-Skin, the Skin, the fatty Membrane, the flehy Membrane, and the Membrane common to the Mucles, which were explained in our Anatomy of the lower Belly.

The Membrane of Fat and the flehy Membrane have one thing proper and peculiar in the Chet, that they receive the Paps in Men and Women. In Men there are only the marks of Paps or Dugs, in Women they are Parts made not only for a • eminine ornament, but to nourih the Infant, of which we are now to treat before we pas any further.

div.head: Chap. 2. Of the Dugs of Women.
div.p: THe Dugs are made up of a company of Kernels very like the Kernels of Prune-Stones,Their Subtance clutered together, and dipoed confuedly in heapes upon a Membrane proper to themelves, in the middet of which there lies one Kernel greater than the ret, under the Teat.

The Dugs are placed upon the Bret, not to defend the Heart not to adorne andScituation beautifie the Woman, but that the Infant may be more conveniently nourihed, while the Mother embracing it in her Arms laies it to the Dug, and the Child T ••
kling her Nipple with its • ucking provoks her the more to love it, and to expres her Love by frequent Kies.

The largenes of the Dugs is different, according as the Woman is of a more or lesMagnitude flehy and la • civious contitution of Body: for the lutful heat of the Womb does puff up and wel a Womans Dugs. In a Marriagable Virgin they become more large, if he enjoy carnal Embracements with more than ordinary pleaure and content,

Nature, our bountyful Mother, has given a Woman two Dugs, that he may nureNumber. two Children; or if one bret be ore, the other may erve the turn for a time. And for this Caue they communicate Veels one with another.

The hape of the Dugs is not flat but bunching out, that they might contein theShape greater Quantity of Milk. At the end of the Dugs, are the Teats, out of which drops the Milk, which the Infant ucks.
The Teat or Nipple is made of the Skin drawn together and boared with littleThe Teats. holes. It is wrinkled on the out-ide that the Infant may more eaily lay hold upon it, and keep it in its Mouth.

Round obout the Teat there goes a Ring or Circle of different Colors in Women,The Circle about the Teats. in repect of their Age and of their being with Child or not with Child &c. In Virgins it is red, in uch as are devirginated it is Black and Blew. In Women with Child it is larger than ordinary; and if they go with a Boy it is Black and Blew or red; if they go with a Girle, it is of a whiteih Color.

div.head: The Medicinal Conideration.
div.p: The largnes of the Chet is commended as ound and healthful; but a narrowMi-hapen Chet. Chet is blamed becaue it occaions hortnes of Breath, becaue the Lungs are ill houed wanting Room to diplay themelves. The hape of the Chet ought diligently to be conidered by a Phyitian when he ees any troubled with hortnes of Breath. In healthy Perons, that the Chet may be perfectly haped, it is requiite that it be round in the forepart and not harp, and that it be treight before and behind; if it prove crooked, there is a fault in the Back-bone, of which we hal peak in our Doctrin of bones.

Terence blames the affected Care of Mothers who traitned the Chets of their yong Daughters, that they might become Slender and mal in the wat. [Such are •… ghtly termed Wap-wated We • ches, becaue they eem divided in the middle like a Wape or Bee.]

A mis-hapen Chet by reaon of the Crookednes of the Back-bone is more frequentlyBy Crookednes of the Back-bone. een in Women than in Men, becaue they are the weaker Veels. Thee Crookednees we endeavour to correct with a firm Pair of Bodies, made either of hard Leather, or of trong Linnen with Whale-bones owed between, or of very thin Plates of Iron. Alo the Back-bone is daily by contrary motious bowed the other way.
Some are born thus Mi-hapen, and they are incurable, let the Rectifiers of Crookednes do what they c •…

Many times Rhewmes fal upon the Mucles of the Backbone, which draw the Vertebraes awry, whence proceeds a mis-hapen B •… -bone and conequently a Crooked Chet, becaue their hape depends upon the hape of the Back-bone.

To the evil haping of the Chet appertains the falling down of the Bret, or theBy falling of the Bret. bowing in of the Sword-like Gritle, which hurts the Stomach and provokes vomiting, and alo hortnes of Breath by hurting the Midrif; therefore this Gritle ought peedily to be lifted up and retored to its place. Baptita Codron •• us and Ludov • cus Septalius have treated of this Dieae.

The Dieaes of the Cavity of the Chet are Empyema, or a collection of quittorEmpyema. Dropie. within the aid Cavity, and the Dropie of the Bret: all which Dieaes require a perforation to be made between the fourth and fift Rib of the Chet on that ide in which the Humor is conteined.

Somtimes winds do o violently ditend the Lungs, that the Patient is in danger of Choaking, unles the Chet be opened by the Perforation afore aid, which is often practied at Paris to the great benefit of the Patients and eaing of the Chet; although no watry Humors come forth, but only wind, which Iues violently, with a noie. Thoe whoe Chets are ditended with wind, are by Hippocrates termed Pneumatiai.

The Dugs are to be conidered at divers eaons, in a Virgin Marriagable, in aCondition of the Dugs. Married Woman, in a woman with Child, and in one that lies in Childbed and gives Suck: becaue in thee everal times they are ubject to everal Dieaes. In ripe Virgins fully Marrigable, the Dugs are firm and olid. They become more oft andIn a marriagable Virgin. welling, when they are tranported with a burning deire of carnal Embracements: and by how much the higher they wel without pain, and the fuller Orbe that they make, trow • ing and Ki • ing one another, the greater is their deire after bodily Pleaure, and it may be gueed that they have tated the Sweetnes of Mans-Fleh.

If when the Dugs are preed, Milk drop forth, it is a ign of the Parties being withIn a married Woman. Child, though Hippocrates accounts it but an uncertain Sign. The Dugs of a Marryed woman which were raied with the Ardency of flehly lut, do ink and fa • by little and li • tle. Women that have large trouting Dugs are termed in Latine Mammoae Mulieres, and they are of an ho • Con plexion, lutful and lovers of Wine and good Liquor. If they happen to be of a cold Complexion, the wel • ing of their Dugs, comes from an Wheyih Humor which they uck in like Spunges. So aies Hippocrates.

Large and ponderous Dugs, do hinder Breathing, by burthening the Chet. So the welled Breaths of Ancient Virgins and married women, are liable to the ame Dieaes. For either by reaon of a Flux of Humors or of ome bruie, they areInflamation of the Dugs. Impotum. inflamed and impotumate: omtime they become Scirrhous and Knobbed as it were with the Kings-Evil, by reaon of the Kernels; and then a Kernel or two, if they be movable, ought to be taken clean away, by cutting the Skin before theyScirrhus. cleave to the Fat, the Dieae encreaing and creeping on to infect other Kernels: Hence comes an incurable Cancer; Becaue the Dugs are ful of Kernels and pungy,Cancer. and therefore ordained by Nature to receive uperfluous Humors. So that uch Women as have them dried and hrunken up, are unhealthy and much troubled with pitting.

The Dugs of a Woman with Child, ome time after her Conception, do wel byIn a woman with child. Ditention by blood. little and little, by reaon of the flowing back of the Mentrual blood, and they drop a mil • y Whey: but in Child bed women, they become yet bigger, by reaon of a greater afflux of blood, than the Dugs are able to contain. From this ditention prings a Feaver, on the third day after they are delivered, which lats a day or two, or longer; unles the Milk be forced back, or ome Child uck the Dugs.

This Milk is called in Latine, Colotrum, and many are afraid to nourih the Child therewith. Yet Spigelius has proved, That this firt Milk is no bad milk, and that a Mother ought not to refue to nourih her Child therewith.
Hippocrates in his Epidemicks, has this Saying: If the Nipples of Womens Dugs, and that which is red in them, be pale, their Womb is dieaed.

There is a great League, and fellow-feeling, between the Dugs, and the Womb,Conent of the wom • & dugs how caued? by reaon of two Veins, viz. The Vena T. 2. f. 9. d. T. 12. f. 1. C C.
Mammaria, or Dug-Vein; and the T. 2. f. 9. e. T. 12. f. 1. E E. Epigatrica: and alo by the Venae f. 1. l l o o. Thoracicae, or Breat-Veins, which are Branches of the Vena f. 1. A B. &c. Cava, which in the bottom of the Belly, affords the Hypogatrick f. 1. . Vein unto the Womb.

The Ancient Chyrurgeons were wont to cut off Cancerous Dugs with the Inciion Knife; but becaue it lucks not well, women are not willing to undergo o cruel a Remedy, neither do our Chyrurgeons practice it.

div.head: Chap. 3. Of the External Parts of the Chet.
div.p:
THe proper Containing Parts are boney, muculous, or membranous. TheProper containing parts. boney Parts are of four orts, viz. Twelve T. 10. f. 2. 1, 2, 3, &c. Ribs, two Claviculae, or f. 1. f. T. 21. f. 1. B B. Channel-bones, the Sternum, or T. 10. f. 2. A A. Breat-bone, and the twelve Vertebrae, or T. 10. f. 3. turning Joynts of the Back-bone, of which we have poken in ou •
Oteologia, or Hitory of the Bones.

The Muculous parts, are either external, or internal, at leat placed between the bones. The External muculous parts, are divided into Mucles proper to the Chet, or uch as are referred to other parts; uch as the Muculus T. 10. f. 1. A B. Pectorali • , or Breat-Mucle; Serratus
f. 1. E. minor anti •• s, or the maller fore-ide Saw-Mucle; and the greater Saw
f. 1. C D. Mucle, or Serratus major; the ret belong unto the Chet, of which we hal peak in our Myologia, or Hitory of the Mucles.
The Internal muculous Parts are, the Intercotal Mucles, both f. 1. H H. internal, and f. • . G G. external; which are placed in the paces between the Ribs, as their name imports.

div.head: Chap 4. Of the Pleura, Mediatinum, and Pericardium.
div.p:
THat continued membranous Part which incloes al the internal parts of the The Pleur •
what it i • . Chet, and betows Membranes upon every one of them, like the Peritoneum,
is termed f. 5. A A. Pleura; which being every where f. 5. C C. tretched out under al the Ribs, is firmly joyned to the bony Parts, and to the Midrif. Becaue of its thicknes, it isIts thicknes accounted double; but it cannot be demontrated to be o, without tearing.

In Dieaes of the Chet, when it wels, its doublenes is eaily eparated. Being on either ide reflexed unto the Back, and riing up unto the Breat-bone, it is f. 4. B B. reduplicated, and makes the f. 4. A A. Mediatinum, and leaves within it elf a certain voidThe Mediatinum, what it is? pace, ful of threds, which alo comprehends the Heart, and the Pericardium: it is noths • g ele, ave a Production, or a doubling and folding of the Mediatinum.

This Cavity of the Mediatinum, is diligently to be oberved, as that which helpsIts Cavity. to form the voyce as an Eccho to beat back the ound: it does likewie eparate the bulk of the Chet into two Cavities, and divide the Lungs one from another.

The Mediatinum is fatened unto the Claves, and the Midrif, by reaon of the Pericardium, which is circularly knit unto the T. 10. f. 6. F F. f. 7. G G. Circulus Nerveus, and the Breatbone; and by this Artifice, the Mediatinum, by help of the Pericardium, does hold the heart upended, and becomes the band of the Midrif it elf. Now the T. 11. f. 1. A. f. 2. A. Pericardium is the Bag, or Cae of the Heart, which contains a watery HumorThe Pericardium, what it is? to moiten the Heart, from which it is round about o far ditant, as is requiite that the Heart may freely move it elf. If the Pericardium, or Heart-cae has no proper Coat of its own, yet it does at leat borrow one from the Mediatinum, which compaeth it about. By reaon of the neer conjunction of the one unto the other, the membranous ubtance is no thicker, than the Membrane of the Mediatinum in other places.

div.head: The Medicinal Conideration.
div.p:
Becaue Contraries compared together, are the better undertood, having eenDieaes of the Cotal mucles, i •
the Natural Contitution of thee Parts, let us now take a view of their Preternatural Dipoitions, or Dieaes.

The Mucles, as wel thoe that are pred upon the Ribs, as thoe which are placed between the aid Ribs, which are ubject to divers Dieaes, caued either by the Flux of Humors from other parts, or by Humors collected in, and about the aid Mucles.

They undergo divers Tumors, Inflamations, Impotumes, Rheumatick pains, pringing from a erous, or wheyih Humor; al which do produce harp pains inPains of the •• des. How known from the Pleuriie. the ides, with a Feaver, and omtimes with a dry Cough, which imitate the Pleuriie; wherefore the difference mut diligently be marked, let we apply the ame Remedies to thee pains of the ides, which are proper to a Pleuriie.

Hippocrates has oberved this Difference; and after him Duretus, the Ghot of Hippocrates, and his Faithful Interpreter: For every Pleuriie is a pain of the ide; but every pain of the ide, is not a Pleuriie, or at mot, but a batard Pleuriie.

But ome wil ay, both Dieaes require the ame Cure in repect of blood-letting, becaue the paage is eaie for the Humors to go from the external parts, unto the internal. I do not deny that blood is to be taken away, but not o much, and o often, as in a true Pleuriy. And therefore Hippocrates in a pain of the ide, was wont firt to make ue of Fomentations, that he might try whether the pain was in the ide, or in the Membrane called Pleura; for a imple pain of the ide is eaed byHow they differ in Fomentations, but the Pleuriie is thereby enraged the more, in which there is a continual Feaver, an In •• amation, a Cough, and a pricking pain of the ide.

And therefore the pains of the ide differ in Scituation, and in matter; becaueScituation, one is • eated in the Membrane T. 10. f. 5. A A. Pleurd, and the f. 1. G G. H H. Intercotal Mucles; another in the grea ••• Mucles, which are pred upon the Ribs, uch as are the T. 10. f. 1. A B. Pectoral Mucle
the f. 1. C D. Serratus major, and T. 10. f. 1. E. minor, the T. 14. f. 1. C C D D. Latiimus, and the Mucles of the T. 14. f. 1, 2, &c. Back.

They differ alo in Matter, becaue wind, or wheyih Humors, or blood doesMatter. ininuate it elf into the greater external Mucles, and is carried likewie, or lips down from the Brain, by the Veins termed T. 12. f. 1. l l. o o. Thoracicae, or Chet-Veins: But the Humor which does poes the Intercotal Mucles, is brought by the mal Branches of the Vena T. 12. f. 1. a a a &c. Azygos, or Vein without a Fellow, and does produce the true Pleureie.

It is not neceary that the Humor be contained within the Membrane Pleura, becaue it is not capable, nor apt to receive the Flux when the pain begins; but the Humor being hed abroad into the pace which is between the Mucles, and the Pleura, it becomes partaker of the pain, which is more harp in the Pleura it elf, by reaon of its Nervous, or Sinewy Nature, than it is in the Muculous Fleh.

The Action of the Chet, is motion, ordained for Repiration; which motion, is governed by Mucles and Nerves which are ubject to the Paley and Convulion. To the Convulion of the Mucles of the Chet, does belong the toppage of the breath, difficult breathing, and Hippocrates his double-troak'd fetching in of the wind.

The Membrane Pleura being inflamed with a continual Feaver, a pricking pain in Whether there may be a Peripneumonia, or no? the ide, and a Cough, makes a Pleuriie, which ome late Phyitians do think, never lats long, without a tranmiion of the Humor into the Lungs, which often cleave to the Pleura, yea, and that the Humor paes over by a Metatais into the Lungs and caues a Peripneumonia, or Inflamation of the Lungs.

Zecchius was the firt that broached this Doctrine in his Counels, building upon the Authority of Hippocrates; others did in their writings, confirm it by reaons, as Vincentius Baronius, in his Book de Pleuropneumonia. And this Combination of two Dieaes of the Chet in one, they term Pleuropneumonia, that is, the Side-and-Lung-icknes; which thing I gave an hint of, before them, in my Anthropography, or Decription of Mans Body, in the Chapter which treats of the Lungs. That place of Hippocrates, is worthy conideration, which many have undertaken to explain: I for my part do thus interpret the ame.

Oft-times the Lungs in one, or both the ides, do cleave unto the Membrane whichHow it is caued, according to our Author. covers the Ribs: or if they do not cleave thereunto when the ide is firt inflamed; the Membrane Pleura being oaked, and made ofter by the afflux of Humors, does weat out a clammy wheyih Humor; o that the Lungs when breath is drawn in, filling the whol Chet, do at length tick unto the aid membrane Pleura, and there cleaving is made the fater by the heat of the Feaver. Neither does the motion of the Lungs hinder that ame cleaving too aforeaid, becaue when the pain is encreaed, the Patient breaths hort for fear of augmenting the ame, and o the Lungs are moved very little: whereupon the Lungs are fatened to the part pained, and then the Pleuriy turns into a Peripneumonia, or Inflamation of the Lungs, or both thee Dieaes are joyned together; and therefore there follows an eay Expectoration, firt of a bloody Humor, by reaon of a light Exulceration both of the Pleura, and of the membrane of the Lungs, and then of the ret of the matter, which comes partly out of the ide, partly from the Excrement of the Lungs Nutriment, or from the impurity of the mas of blood, paing by its circular motion through the Lungs: whence it is, that o great a quantity of a Cholerick and Flegmatick Humor flows, which is pit up with Coughing.

But if the Lungs do not cleave to the ide, the blood-watry Humor being hed into the Cavity of the Chet, and carce ever drawn back again, there is bred an Empyema; which if it be not voided of it elf, it mut be let out by opening the ide; which Operation omtimes lucks wel.

So that according to the Doctrine of Hippocrates, whom Herophilus (as Caelius The difference of a Pleuriie, and Peripneumonia. Aurelianus relates) and Cornelius Celus do follow, there is a true Pleuriie, if there be joyned thereunto, an Inflamation of one ide of the Lungs; if both ides be pained, it is a true Peripneumonia, or Univeral Inflamation of the Lungs, becaue the whol Lungs are affected both in the right, and left ide; and continually beating upon the Ribs, they are apt to infect them with the blood-watry Humor wherewith they abound. Wherefore the Pleuriy, and the Inflamation of the Lungs, are Dieaes of a brotherly Kindred, which help one another to detroy the Patient, or to comfort him, according as the Contitution of the Lungs is weak or trong; and as they are aited with Remedies, epecially, liberal blood-letting.

Neither can the matter cauing the Pleuriy, be transferred, or propagated by any other waies into the Lungs by any Metatais, or Epigeneis. Howbeit, we ee in dead bodies, the dieaed Pleura ten times thicker than ordinary, which argues that the eat of the Dieae was there. I deny not but that it may be communicated to the Lungs, and that the Pleuriie may degenerate into a Peripneumonia, or Inflamation of the Lungs, after the manner aforeaid.

Touching blood-letting, there has been for an hundred and fifty yeers, an eagerOn which ide the blood is to be taken away in a Pleuriie? contention between the Modern Phyitians of France, Italy, and Germany, from what part blood is to be drawn in a true Pleuriie, whether on the ame ide that is pained, or on the other ide. At lat, the Opinion of Hippocrates confirmed with the Authority of Galen, has prevailed, and got Victory over the Doctrine of the Arabian Phyitians. The Phyitians of Paris, and al true Artits, do follow Hippocrates; for they let blood on the Arm, of the ame ide which is pained. After three or four times letting blood in the Arm, for Revulion ake, a Vein may be opened in the Foot; but the dieaed ide mut be firt disburdened.

In blood-letting, we chue our Vein, becaue the Patient is ooner eaed by openingOut of what Vein? the T. 24. f. 1. C C. Bailica Vena, if we conider the Rectitude of the Veels by the Fibres: for this Vein is a continuation of the T. 12. f. 1. B B. Axillary Trunk, which produces the f. 1. l l. o o. Chet-Vein, which glides through the external parts of the Chet, and is joyned to the Extremities of the Solitary Vein called Azygos. This was formerly declared by Gordonius, a Phyitian of Montpelier. Ludovicus Duretus has confirmed the ame with Hitories, in his Commentaries upon the Practice of Hollerius.

The Mediatinum is ubject to divers Dieaes. Its Membranes are inflamed asDieaes of the Mediatinum. Inflamation, Impotume, in the Pleuriie, becaue of the neer Neighbor-hood of the Heart, and the communion of ubtance with the Pericardium. The Quittor therein collected, makes an Impotume, which is drawn out by perforation of the Breat-bone, or by an Intrument fitted for that purpoe. Winds alo are omtimes hut up within the CavityWind, of thee parts, which do vex, and torment the Chet, and pierce it through as it were.

The Pericardium may alo be inflamed, with much pain, and no little danger, becauePericardium Inflamed, it is neer the Heart; which therefore is ubject to frequent Swounings; and then the pule is quicker, the Feaver tronger, the thirt more vehement than in the Pleuriie, or in the Inflamation of the Lungs.

Oftentimes abundance of moiture is collected therein, which caues Suffocation,Full of Humor and over-whelms the Heart. If thou cant not draw away the aid moiture with uch Medicines as purge wheyih Humors; what if you hould boar an hole in the breat-bone, a Thumbs breadth ditant from the Sword-like Gritle? becaue the Pericardium is there fatened, that the heart may hang pendulous. A doubtful Cure, is better than certain Desperation: it is better to try a doubtful Remedy than none at all, where there is no hope of help, ave in ome extraordinary providence of God.
If there be no water at al in the Pericardium, the Heart pines away by little andDeficient of Humor. Worms. little, as it has been oberved in many Patients.

Certain it is, that Worms are bred in the Pericardium, which feed upon the Heart, and are detroyed by the ue of Scordium. Petrus Salius Diverus has
treated of this Dieae. Neither is it any aburdity, that worms hould be ound within the Ventricles of the Heart; howbeit they are bred in the Vena Cava, and come from thence into the Heart.

Seeing the Heart hangs upon the Breat-bone, it wil not be unprofitable to apply Topick Medicaments, and Fomentations, whether hot or cold, made to trengthen the Heart, unto this part, according as the Dieae wherewith the heart is troubled, hal require.
d f. 1. a a a.

div.head: Chap. 5. Of the Midrif, or Diaphragma.
div.p: THe Method of Diection has brought us to the a Midrif, the principal IntrumentMidrifs of free Breathing, which eparates the Chet from the Belly like a Partition wall, being tied to al the batard Ribs, to two of the true Ribs, and to theScituation. Sword-like Gritle; and being on this manner oblickly tretched round about, it ends forth two b flehy Productions omewhat longih, even to the utmot Vertebra's of the Loyns.

It is made up of Fleh, and a c Sinewy membrane, which is placed in the CentreSubtance. thereof, the ret of its compas being flehy, and of the Nature of d mucle. On that part which is towards the belly, it is covered with a membrane of the Peritoneum: on the other ide, towards the Chet, it is compaed with the Pleura.

The Sinewy Circle is placed in the midt, to trengthen that part, that it may bear the point of the Heart beating thereupon, and that it may bear up the Liver: for the Liver hangs fatened to the Diaphragma, which is drawn upwards within the Chet, by help of the Mediatinum: for the Figure of the Diaphragma, or midrif,Shape. towards the belly, is hollow, within the Chet, it is bunching out.

It receives T. 10. f. 6. C C. Veins, and T. 10. f. 6. B B. Arteries, termed Phrenicae, from the Cava, and Aorta. Veels It has two notable T. 10. f. 7. A B. Nerves, which taking their Rie between the fourth and fi • t Vertebra's of the Neck, are inerted into the Sinewy Centre of the Diaphragma.

Seeing the midrif is a mucle of a peculiar Nature by it elf, o that there is notMotion. uch another in the whol Body, it has a perpetual motion like the Hea ••
if not o fat an one: for it is dilated and contracted; omtimes lowly, and oftly; other whiles wiftly, and violently. Somtimes it is moved alone with low and oft breathing, but more often with the Lungs, when the body is tirred with exercie; but in violent Repiration, it is compelled to follow the motion of the Chet.
Hippocrates cals the midrif, the Fan of the Belly, becaue by its motion of dilatation and contraction, decending and acending, it fans both thoe Cavities.

Seeing therefore there are two parts of Repiration; Inpiration, and Expiration,How it moves in Repiration. it is worth our Enquiry in which part the midrif is moved. By motion I undertand contraction.

In the Inpiration, or drawing in the wind, while it is brought unto a right line, that is to ay, of hollow, is made treight, then the midrif is contracted. In the Expiration, or letting go of our breath, it is lackened, raieth it elf upwards, and of treight or even, becomes hollow. When it is moved alone, it directs our free Repiration, which is done by an inenible, and inviible motion of the Chet, while the whol body does ret in peace; otherwie, in violent fetching the breath, it follows the motion of the Chet, which is elevated, and depreed (as we ee after running) not only by the Intercotal mucles, but alo by the greater mucles tretched out upon the Chet, and by the mucles of the Abdomen. In which cae the midrif is haled, and forced to follow the violent motion of the Chet.

div.head: The Medicinal Conideration.
div.p: The Midrife is omtimes Dieaed of it elf, omtimes by accident as SympathiingIts Dieaes are. Ditemper. with the Dieaes of other Parts,

Of it elf it is troubled with an hot or cold Ditemper, alo with Inflammations and Impotumes. And it communicates its diorders to other Parts neighbouring thereupon, and to the Brain, and upon this Account it is wont to caue a Phrenzy.

p.U: aw hard Tumors fixed in the Root of the Midrif, which watedTumors. away the Patients by a low Conumption, without any Phrenzy or other Dotage.

div.p: When the Midrife is Inflamed, an acute Feaver does begin to hew it elf: underInflamation. the hort Ribs towards the Midrif a palpitation or panting is felt, the Hypochondria are drawn together by reaon of the Membrane of the Peritonaeum: the Breathing is unequal, omtimes wift, omtimes low, omtimes great and omtimes little, and at length Convulions happen.
The Midrif being wounded caues the Patient to die laughing, if we beleive Hippocrates, Wounds. Pliny and other later Phyitians.

Wounds inflicted upon the flehy Part of the Midrif are not o dangerous and deadly, as thoe in the inewy or Nervous Part, and therefore lies (in Homer) intending to give the Cyclops a deadly wound, choe the place where the Liver is fatened unto the Midrif, as Galen has oberved.
In an univeral Paley of the whol Body the Midrif is affected, which is known by dificulty of breathing,

div.head: Chap. 6. Of the Lungs or Lights.
div.p: THe Lungs or Lights are the Intruments of breathing and framing the Voyce:Their to which end they are framed of a ubtance light, oft, Spungy, whitihSubtance. without, and reddih within, interwoven with many Veels which are pred through the whol ubtance thereof; uch as are the Bronchia Veels. or a Pip •• of the Wezand, and the Pipes of the Vena b Arterioa and of the Arteria c Venoa, which go o in company, that the Bronchia or Wind-Pipes are interpoedScituation. between the Veins and Arteries.

The d Lungs are Scituate within the Chet, and do with the Heart fil up Both the Cavities thereof, while they are dilated to fetch in breath; but they leave the Chet Empty, while they are contracted to expel the ooty or uperfluousMotion. breath.
Thee interchangable motions of the Lungs are perpetual and never ceae fromDiviion. the beginning of our Life until we Breath our lat.

Nature has Ditinguihed the Lungs into two Parts, placed in the everal Cavities of the Chet, and he has divided each Part into undry Lobes, Laps, or Scollops, for the facility of motion and for their preervation, for by this means they do more eaily pread abroad (as it were) their wings; and one Lap or Scollop being hurt orShape. corrupted, the other may remain whol and ound.

If you take a diligent view of the Lungs after they are taken out of the Chet, you hal ee that each Part of each Cavity does in its hape repreent the form of an Oxes Hoofe, for it is cloven and convex or bunching out in the external Part, and hollowMembrane. in that Part on which it touches the Back.

It is girt about with a very thin • Membrane, which is manifetly porous and ful of little holes, that being preed and overburthened in uffocations, it may disburthen it elf into the Cavity of the Chet, and alo uck in again uch Excrementitious moiture, as hal there at any time abound.

This Bowel alone is nourihed after another fahion than the ret of the Body,Peculiar manner of nourihment. for it borrows its blood from the Heart, from whence it has Veels and not from the Vena Cava. And therefore thoe Phyitians are hamefully over een who in Dieaes of the Lungs, are wont to ay that they are oppreed by an afflux of blood, hed thereinto by an innumerable company of Veins.
They cannot receive Humors from the Head unles with coughing, o that where there is no cough, the Lungs are affected only by that blood which comes from the Heart.

div.head: The Medicinal Conideration.
div.p: The Lungs are extreamly neceary for the maintenance of Life, For we live Excellency of the Lungs. o long as we Breath, and no longer: Nor is it enough meerly to breath we mut breath eaily, or it wil go ill with our Heart and our whol body. For in Dieaes, difficult breathing is of great moment, and was more regarded by Hippocrates than the pule: And Galen compoed three admirable Bookes of Difficult Breathing, according to the Doctrin of Hippocrates, howbeit they are obcure and not to be undertood ave by skilful Phyitians and Anatomits.
I wil give you a little tat of them, after that I have laid open the Dieaes of the Lungs.

Becaue the ubtance of the Lungs is oft and Spungy above that of the otherWhy the Lungs are o ubject to Fluxions. Bowels, therefore it is more ubject to Fluxions than the ret which flow either from the Brain, or from the Bowels, by way of the Heart.

They lie in the middle pace between the Head and the Midrif, not only between the Hammer and the Anvil, as the Proverb is, but between two Hammers, wherewith they are beat upon and hurt on both ides: whil the Head ditils upon the Lungs, and the Liver affords impure or over plentyful Blood unto the Heart, whichthe Heart pues and cats back into the Lungs, whereby they are infected and overwhelmed.

Which infection of the Lungs prings not from the Heart, but from the ditempered and ill dipoed Bowels, which ugget unto the Heart very impure blood, whoe vitiounes the Heart is not able to correct, ave after many Circulations.

In the mean whil the Lungs are greivouly offended by the foreaid blood paingThe chief Dieaes of the Lungs. through the ubtance thereof, for they are ubervient unto the Heart as it were in the Nature of an Emunctory Emiary or Common-hore, whiles the filth of the Heart flowes unto the Lungs with the Blood, whereupon the Lungs are ubject to undry Dieaes.

For they are troubled with an hot or cold ditemper, with a Cholerick andDitemper. Inflamation. Conumtion. Flegmatick Tumor, and a frequent Inflammation called Peripneumonia, or at leat with an inflammatory dipoition; alo with Impotumes and Ulcers, which bring the Conumption: for from pitting of Blood comes pitting of quitter, and from thence the Conumption.
Alo they are ubject to a certain kind of Puh or riing which in the endPuh. Vomica. turnes into a ecret michievous Impotum termed Vomica, of which few ecape.

If the Quitter be derived from the Lungs into the Heart, unles it pas readily into the Aorta, it uddainly choakes or tifles the Patient. If it be carried into the right ventricle, it Caues the greater danger, becaue it cannot be o eaily Purged out.

Furthermore the Lungs are obtructed in the Athma either perpetual or comingAthma by fits, which caues difficulty of breathing, which as it is more or les, is ditinguihed with different names. The leer is termed Dypnea; the greater,Its Kinds. when the Patien cannot breath ave tanding or itting upright, is termed Orthopnaea.

Oftentimes the Patient is vexed alo with a cough, which is omtimes moderateCough and omtimes vehement, with great wheezing and ready to choak the Patient, which Springs from a cruel feirce Catarrh or udden and plentyful Defluxion. Whereupon by reaon of the extreme troubleomnes of the Cough which hake • the Lungs, there aries that dipoition termed Spadon Vaorum, or a dilatation of the Veels, being a dangerous and formidable • ort of A • e •
rima.

In the Peripneumonia or Inflammation of the Lungs, there is no mal diputeWhether Bloodletting is good in thee Caes? about Blood-letting, for it is written that Blood mut be drawn from the common Veins. Now there is none of thoe Veins which are uually opened, that communicates with the Veins of the Lungs; neither are there any branches ditributed from the Vena Cava into the Lungs: which has by Galen in many places been diputed againt Eraitratus.

The motion likewie of Nature hewes the ame: for whereas in Dieaes of the Bowels and in burning Feavers the Criis is wont to happen by bleeding at the Note; in a Peripneumonia there is no uch Criis, becaue the Veins of the Noe from whence blood is wont to Iue, have no Communion with the Lungs.

If it be true that Blood naturally does pas from the right Ventricle of the Heart unto the Lungs, that it may be brought into the left Ventricle, and from thence into the Aorta: and if the Circulation of the Blood be acknowledged, who ees not that in Dieaes of the Lungs, the blood flowes thither in greater quantity than ordinary, and opprees the Lungs, unles it be firt liberally taken away, and afterwardsAffermed. at everal times, a little at a time be let out, to eae the aid Lungs: which was the advice of Hippocrates, who when the Lungs were welled, did take blood from al Parts of the Body, from the Head, Noe, Tongue, Armes, Feet; that the quantity thereof might be diminihed, and the Coure thereof drawn from the Lungs.

He himelf in Dieaes of the Lungs, bids us draw blood, til the Body were Blood-les, and in one that had a Conumption, when he aw that the corruption of the Blood infected and corrupted the Lungs, he took away blood in o great a quantity, that the Patients body remained quite empty of the ame, in a manner.

Suppoing that the Blood circulates, the Lungs are eaily emptied by Phlebotomy. If the Circulation be denied, I cannot ee how blood may be from thence drawn back; for if it hould flow back by the Vena T. 11. f. 2. E E G. Arterioa into the T. 11. f. 3. D D. right Ventricle, the T. 11. f. 4. B B B. Sigma haped Valves do hinder it, and the T. 11. f. 3. C C C. three forked little Valves, do hinder the recoure thereof, from the right Ventricle of the Heart into the Vena Cava. And therefore when the Veins of the Armes and Feet are opened, blood is drawn from the Lungs by reaon of the Circulation thereof; and conequently the Opinion of Fernelius comes to nothing, namely that in Dieaes of the Lungs, blood hould be taken rather from the right Arm than the left; becaue the blood cannot return into the Vena Cava, ave by breaking two doors and Bolts, placed in the Heart.

Ulcers of the Lungs do often happen by reaon of a fierce cough, caued by verySome Caues of Conumption of the Lungs. harpe Seroities, or by pitting of Blood: which if it come from an opening of the mouthes of the Veines by reaon of Aboundance of blood, it is not o much to be feared, as when it proceeds from eating aunder the Coats of the Veins, by the acrimony of Humors.

Nature in this cae, out of Pitty, that our life might be preerved, ha • ditinguihedWhy the Lungs are ditinguihed into Lobes or Laps. the Lungs into divers pipes and undry Lobes, Laps or Scollups that the infection might not pread over the whol Body of the Lungs, which is uual in al continued or evenly united bodies. And therefore we ee many that have Ulcers in their Lungs do live long, if they have but an indifferent Care of themelves.

If the Circulation of the blood be allowed, o that it paes often through theA twofold Circulation of the Blood. Lungs, & not through the Septum Medium or Partition-Wal of the Heart, we mut maintain a two fold Circulation of the blood: the one is performed by the Heart and Lungs, whiles the blood pirting from the right Ventricle of the Heart is carried through the Lungs that it may come unto the left Ventricle of the Heart, (for it is quirted out of the Heart and returnes thither again) the other is a longer Circulation, by which the blood flowing from the left Ventricle of the Heart, compaes the whole body by the Arteries and Veins, that it may return into the right Ventricle of the Heart. He that approves of one of thee Circulations, cannot deny the other.

The Lungs as it were do hang upon and are fi • mly fatned to the claves and the Bret-bone, for they do not depend or hang by the Apera Arteria, for o in a violent Cough and when the Lungs are overburdened, the Weand or Windpipe and Parts fatened thereunto would be torn in peices. Howbeit the Lungs and Heart being inflamed (according to Hippocrates) if the Lungs fal to one ide, the Patient faints away, lies Cold and enceles and dies within the third or fourth day. If the Heart be not inflamed, the Patient lives longer, and ome ecape.

Seeing the Subtance of the Lungs ought to be light and oft to Facilitate repiration;Why Old People are hort Breathed. and in old, People it becomes dry and hard, either through the drynes of their temper, or by being filled with Flegm: this is the reaon of that hortnes of Breath we ee in Old Men, which uhers them to their Grave.

div.head: Chap. 7. Of Repiration, or fetching of Breath.
div.p: THe proper action of the Lungs is breathing: which we mut conider how itNeceity of Repiration. ought to be in bodies that are in health, that we may dicern faults thereof, when it is depraved. In our whole Practice, epecially if you regard acute Dieaes, their is no Dieae or Symptom o uual as difficulty in breathing. It is wel for the Patient, if in al Dieaes, epecially acute ones, he breath eaily, becaue life is ineparable from Repiration, according to Galen in his 6. Book of the Parts Dieaed. And if with al the Patient Sleeps kindly and weetly, aud feels no pain in the noble Parts of his body, it is to be hoped the Dieae wil end wel, becaue Hippocrates never knew any one die, in whom thee three conditions were found.

Now Repiration or breathing is twofold, free, or forced, free is that whereby theIts twofold. Air is gently drawn in and Iued out, without any remarkable motion of the Chet. And this depends only upon the Midrif, the Ribbs and whol Chet never moving:Free, and Forced. unles hapily the lower batard Ribs are gently tirred; and this kind of breathing is truly natural.

The econd ort of breathing, which is forced and violent: is partly natural, partly againt Nature. Natural, when it depends upon our own power, o that we can make it quicker or lower, as when we puf out our wind with a long blat, and when we hold our breath. It is againt Nature, when it depends not upon o • r wil, but upon the violence of the Dieae. In this kind of Repiration the whol Chet is moved by al the Mucles, and the Midrif, to avoid the oppreion and uffocation of the Lungs and Heart, which deire Air to cool them, and that their moaky Sooty Vapours may be expelled.

There are two parts of Natural Repiration; Inspiration, and Expiration. Inpiration is caued by drawing in the Air, and the dilatation of the • het by theParts of Natural respiration Inpiration Expiration Acent thereof: Expiration, is a breathing out of fuliginous, or ooty Vapors, the Chet being drawn together by the decent thereof. Between thee two motions, is interpoed a two-fold Pau • e, or Ret, viz.
