The pace between the drawing in, and blowing out of the breath; and the like pace between the blowing out of the breath, and the drawing it in again, as in the Pul • e there is a two-fold Ret, termed Periytole.

In Repiration, or breathing, Galen writes that three Organs are to be conidered:Its three Organs. The Principal Mover, viz. the Heart; The Secondary Movers, namely, the Mucles; and the Things moved, viz. the Chet and Lungs. The Organs by which the motion is performed, are the Animal Spirits, and the Nerves.

Now that unnatural, and diordered breathing, may be dicerned, we mut principallyWherein Natural Repiration conits. learn to know, wherein the Natural manner of • erching breath, does conit, viz. In the moderation, and equability of Inpiration, and Ex • piration, and of thoe things whereby Repiration is performed.

Now thee are four; Motion, Ret, that which is moved, and that which by the motion, is drawn in, and carried forth. That Repiration wil therefore be moderate, wherein we hal oberve a Mediocrity of motion and Ret, and of the ditention of the Chet, and of the matter it elf, which is drawn in, a • d breathed out, and wherein Perons in Health appear no waies changed from what they were wo • t to be.

And this Natural Repiration ought to be the Rule of the contrary, which is notDifferences of unnatural Repiration. natural, viz. of the hurt Repiration, and of that which is in moderate. Now Repiration is hurt as many wa • es as there are parts which make up Natural. Repiration, viz. Motion, Ret, Swiftnes, or Slownes. So that he hurts of Repiration, are thee following, namely, Defections from Natural Motion; Rarity, and Frequency of the Ret; Greatnes, and • ma • ne • s of Inpiration and Expiration; Plenty, and penury of the matter drawn in, or breathed out, with cold, or heat.

Wherefore al difficulty of breathing, conits in Magnitude, or Paucity; Frequence, or Rarity; Swiftnes, or Slownes; and conequently, Repiration is aid to be faulty, when it is too great, or too little; too low, or two wift; too frequent, or too rare; too hot, or too cold.

Alo thee Defections, as wel in exces, as defect, are to be conidered, either in both parts of Repiration, or in one alone; alo ome are little without, and great within; others great without, and little within: and ome ar • great, wift and frequent; others con • rarily, are little, eldom, and low; and ome are doubled, both in drawing, and rendring back the breath. Thee are the Compound Differences of Repiration hurt.

If Repiration fail, the Quetion is, Whether Perpiration can upply the defectWhether Perpiration may upply the ue of Repiration? thereof? Galen
• aies it may, and he decribes Perpiration, to be an eva • uation of Spirit, or Air, by the Arteries which are dipered into the Habit of the Body, by receiving in of Air, and expelling fuliginous Vapors. For Hippocrates has written that the whol body is perpirable, within and without. And the Author of Tranpiration, or Perpiration, is counted to be the Heart, the Intruments are the Arteries; the Pores of the Skin, are the Paages by which the Tranpiration is made.

But I very much doubt, whether Perpiration can upply the Office of Repiration for a time, the Heart not being moved, becaue I cannot perwade my elf, that the Air can pas o far as the Heart, by the mal Arteries, unles they did gape very wide, eeing it would meet with the Arterial blood, to top its coure. The Arteries may indeed expel the ooty vapors of their blood, but it is hard for them to draw the A • r in again.

And if Perpiration be hindred by uppreion of the moaky vapors, then putrid Feavers are wont to arie; as Galen has oberved in Book 11. of his Method. In
which cae, blood letting is good for Ventilation, and mut be repeated, if need be.

Unnatural Repiration, is omtimes neceary in thoe that have their Health, to nnatural Repiration omtimes <> in healthy perons. expel moaky vapors by forcible blowing out of the breath; or to expel the Excrements of the Bell • , or to force out a Child by holding the breath. • x •• fflation, or forcible puffing out of the breath, anwers to Expiration; and holding of the breath is a long Inpiration, as much as the party is able to endure, for ome neceary ue; and it is performed (which is trange) by one very mal mucle, which huts the Arythenois, and the Glottis.

div.head: Chap. 8. Of the Heart.
div.p: THe Heart is the Principal, and mot Noble Bowel of the whol Body, theNobility of the Heart. Fountain of Life-giving Nectar; by the Influx whereof, the virality, or lively force of al • he parts, is recreated, and cherihed; It is the firt that lives, and the lat that dies: by the benefit whereof, al the parts of the body do live, and ubit.

And therefore it is, that Nature has framed this principal Part with admirable Workmanhip, both without and within, of a T. 11. f. • B. flehy ubtance, trong, and thick,Its Subtance interwoven with al orts of Fibres, and becaue it is the Seat of Native Heat, let it hould become dry, and parched up, he h • s • o • tened it with fat placed round about, and wa • ered the ame by cu • cumfuion of a whey • h Liquor.

It is cituate in the middle of the Chet, hanging by the T. 11. f. 4. A A.
Mediatinum, and
• . 11. f. 1. A.
Pericardium. Its Scit • ation. For thoe two parts do joyn in this Office, as hath been aid in our Chapter of the Mediatinum.

The Heart is alwa • es of the ame greatnes; in ome trong men it is more malBignes and olid, than ordinary: in feeb • er Per • ons i • is greater, and of a looer ubtance, as • n ome men, and frequently in women.

It is haped like a Pine-Apple: having a broad bottom, and growing pointed towardsShape the top. The broad end is called the Bais, or b • ttom, which receives four Veels; the Vena T. 11. f. 1 C.
Cava, running through the Breat, and opened neer the Heart,Veels. and fatened thereunto; the Vena f. 2. E E. G. Arterioa; the f. 1. M. f. 2. C. Ao •• a; and the Arteria f. 2. H H. Venoa.

In the Bais we find little Caes, or Covers placed by the Veels, which carry blood into • he Heart: They are called
<> Cordis the f. • . C C.
Ears of the Heart, Ears. and are hollow. In grown perons, the right Ear is larger than the left: but in the child in the womb, and al Infants, the left Ear is larger than the right.
The other end of the Heart is termed the Conus, or poin • ed end. There appear Veins and Arteries f. 2. by B. creeping upon the urface of the Heart, which eem ordained to repair the Fat as it pends.

Before we proceed to the inner Structure of the Heart, we are to conider how itAction, viz. the pule. is moved: For its Action is Motion, or Puliation; becaue look what blood it receives in, it drives the ame out by pulation.

There are therefore two parts of the Hearts motion; Sytole, and Diatole; orSytole. Diatole. Contraction, and Dilatation: when it takes in blood, it is dilated or widened; when it expels the ame, it is contracted, or drawn together: between both which motions, there intercedes a paue, or reting time, which is termed Peri-Sytole. How thee motions are caued, is a doubtful Quetion.

Rejecting the various Opinions of others, I wil tel you how I conceive this moti
• ionCaue of the pule, according to our Author. is performed. It is probable, that the Heart being widened, cannot receive the
blood, unles its dilatation be made by drawing back the Bais thereof to the Cone; that the Veels may hed their blood, and the heart draw the ame to it elf. In the Sytole the heart is contracted, and the blood received, is thrut out; and then the Heart becomes narrower, and longer than it was before. And becaue it is hut up in the Pericardium, or Heart-cae, which is fatened circular-wie to the Sinewy Centre of the Midrif, with its Cone, or pointed end, it mites the Nervy Centre of the Midrif, and with its Bais, or broad end, and the Aorta ticking out, it mites the Breat at the ame intant, when it is extended, and prolonged.

This perpetual motion of the Heart, though it depend in repect of its production,How neceary the circulation of the blood is to continue the motion of the Heart. upon the inbred faculty thereof, yet can it not alwaies continue, ave by the coming in of blood, out of which, the Heart frames the vital Spirit: and in cae at every pule the Heart receive one drop of blood, or two, which it cats into the Aorta, and that in an hours pace, the Heart pules two thouand times, it mut needs be, that a great quantity of blood, or al the blood in the Veels, hould pas through the Heart within the pace of twelve or fifteen hours.

Now this quantity may come to fifteen, or twenty pounds of blood, which is as much as is contained in the Veels, and therefore it mut needs be that in the pace of twenty four hours, the whol mas of Blood is twice or thrice paed through the Heart, according as the motion of the Heart is quicker, or lower.

And that this Circular Motion of the blood, might be performed with the greaterWhether the blood do pas from the right Ventricle of the Heart unto the Lungs. commodity, and facility, William Harvey, an Englih man, the Kings Phyitian, the Author and Inventor of this motion of the blood; and Joannes Walaeus, a Profeor of Leyden, and mot eager Defender, and Protector thereof, wil have the blood to be carried through the Lungs, from the right, unto the left Ventricle of the Heart, not allowing that it hould pas through the Septum, or Partition wal between the Ventricles of the Heart; and that the whol mas of Blood, in an hour, or two hours pace, is circulated through the Heart, and the whol Body: which I do not allow of, and I have el-where laid down my reaons of the impoibility, and inconveniency of uch a motion.The Heart is the Original of Vena Cava.

When I had oberved that the Trunk of the Vena Cava was eparated from the Liver, running continually from the Jugulum, to the Os Sacrum, without any interruption, and that it paed not through the Liver, as we may ee with our Eyes, and perceive alo by thruting a mal tick thereinto; I came to be of Opinion, thatThe Liver of Vena Porta. They have different blood in them. the Vena Cava did pring from the Heart, as the Vena Porta takes its rie from the Liver; and that two orts of blood were contained in thoe Veins, though both of thoe orts are labored, and wrought in the Liver: the one of thee orts of blood being ent into the Porta, the other by a branch rooted in the Liver, twice as mal as the Trunk of Vena Cava, carried unto the Heart.What kind of blood is circulated?

The blood which is contained in the Vena Porta, is not circulated, although it have a flux, and reflux within its own Channels, and communicate with the Caeliacal Arteries, which are joyned one to another by mutual Anatomoes.
Within thoe Veels, the blood may pas to and fro reciprocally; but it does not run out according to the longitude of the body; neither is it in uch a ene circulated.In what Veels?

And therefore the Circulation which is made in the Heart, does borrow its matter from the Liver by the Vena Cava. The Circulatory Veels, are the Aorta, and Cava; neither do their branches receive that Circulation, becaue the blood being hed into al the parts of the econd and third Region, does remain there to nourih the aid parts; neither does it flow back unto the greater Veels, unles it be revelled by force, when there is great want of blood in the larger Veels, or when it is timulated into ome violent motion, and o flows unto the greater Circulatory Veels.After what manner?
And o the blood which is brought from the Liver unto the right Ventricle of the Heart, does pas through the Partition wall of the two Ventricles, into the left Ventricle.

I confes that in a violent Circulation the blood is carried through the Lungs untoHow the circulation is performed? the left ventricle of the Heart, where it is forcibly ejected into the Aorta, that it may afterwards be carried into the greater Veins of the Limbs, which communicate by mutual Anatomoes with the Arteries; and then from the Veins it flows up into the right Ventricle of the Heart, and o there is made a perfect Circulation, by the continual flux and reflux of the blood.
So that the blood in the Veins, does naturally, and perpetually acend, or return unto the Heart, the blood of the Arteries naturally, and continually decends, or departs from the Heart.

Howbeit, if the maller Veins of the Arms aud Legs, hal be emptied of blood, the blood of the Veins may decend to ucceed in the place of that which is taken away, as I have cleerly demontrated againt Harvey, and Walaeus.
No man can deny the mutual Anatomoes of the Veins and Arteries, eeing that Galen has aid it, and demontrated the ame by Experiments, and our dayly Experience confirms the ame.
Hippocrates himelf, in his third Book of the Joynts, takes notice of this communion of the Veins and Arteries, in a Dicoure by it elf.How neceary the circulation of the blood is.

You ee how neceary it is for the blood to circulate, that the motion of the Heart may not ceae; and how this Circulation may be performed without confuion, and perturbation of the Humors, and without detroying the Ancient Art of Healing.

And therefore the Circular motion of the blood is neceary, to continue the motion of the heart; as in Mils, the Water mut perpetually fal upon the Wheel to make it turn about; alo to warm again, and retore the trength of the blood,The tility thereof. which is decayed by the los of Spirits dipered up and down the body; whereas in the Heart, it is refurnihed with new Spirits: and that the Heart being the Fountain of Native Heat, may be moitened with a perpetual Dew, let by little and little, it hould parch, and wither away, for want of that dewy moiture, or Lifegiving Nectar.

By the Circulation of the blood in the Heart, the Caues of Life and Death, are more eaily declared, than by the Humidum Primigenium, or Original Moiture bred in the Heart when the Child is formed; which is o little that it is oon conumed, and the perpetual motion of the Heart continuing day and night without ceaing, would at length wear away the Subtance of the Heart, unles by a perpetual flowing in of the circulated blood, it were moitened, and repaired.Whether the Heart and Arteries are moved at the ame time?

Howbeit, we mut hold that the Heart and Arteries do move by Coure, one after another, not being moved at the ame intant with the ame kind of motion; but taking their turns, and performing their work interchangably; for when the Heart ends out the blood, the Arteries receive it, and tranmit it into the Veins; not that which is expelled the ame intant, but that which is neeret the Veins.

This being granted, thee parts mut of neceity be moved one after another, and the welling motion of the Artery when it ries under our Finger, is dilatation, or widening, and not contraction; although it eem very like the pule which the Heart makes, when it contracts it elf.

Having explained the Circulation of the Blood, we mut now open the Heart,The right Ventricle of the Heart. which you hal ee divided into two Ventricles by the Septum Medianum, or T. 11. f. . D D. Middle Partition: The one is termed the f. . C C. f. 3. D D. f. 4. C C. Right Ventricle, being the wider and ofter: The other the f. . B. f. 5. C C. f. 6. D D. Left, being harder, narrower, and compaed with a thicker wal, reaching as far as the Cone, or Point of the Heart, which the Right does not. The Right Ventricle receives the Vena f. 1. C. f. . E. Cava, and the Vena f. 2. E E G. f. 4. A. T. 12. f. 3. all Arterioa. TheIts Veels. Cava pours blood into the Heart; the Vena Arterioa carries back all, or a part thereof into the Lungs.

To the Orifices of the Cava, are adjoyned certain three-pointed T. 11. f. 3. C C C. Valves, orTheir Valves. Shutters, which hinder the going back of the blood. The Orifice of the Vena Arterioa,
is compaed with three Valves, or Shutters, haped like an old fahioned f. 4. B B B. Greek Sigma, which hinder the reflux of the blood.

The Left Ventricle receives two Arterial Veels, the T. 11. f. 1. M. f. 2. C. f. 5. A. Aorta, and the Arteria f. 2. H H. f. 6. A. T. 1. e. f. 6. all Venoa. Which latter, according to the Doctrine of ome Anatomits, carriesThe left Ventricle of the Heart. Its Veels. blood from the Lungs into the left Ventricle of the Heart, or carries Air prepared in the Lungs, into the aid Ventricle, and likewie carries back fuliginous Vapors; howbeit, many do not allow the aid ue.

The Arteria Venoa hath in its Orifice, only two
T. 11. f. 6. C C. three-pointed Valves, or Shutters. The Aorta carries back Arterial blood out of the left Ventricle of theTheir Valves Heart, and its Orifice is topped by three f. 5. B B B. Sigma haped Valves, or Shutters, which hinder the blood from returning back again.

It is to be oberved that thee three-pointed Valves, or Shutters, are membranous neer their Veels; but they depend upon flehy Pillars, which within the Heart are like unto Mucles, being fatened to the ides of the partition wall, or Septum of the Heart, which remains unmovable, aving towards the Bais, where it is ofter, and gives way a little, when the Bais is drawn back, in the Diatole, or Dilatation of the Heart.

The Septum f O D D. medium, or Partition-wall of the Heart is porous, ful of little holes, which are omtimes manifetly dicerned towards the Cone, or Point of theThe Septum Medium of the Heart. Whether the blood pas through it, or no? Heart. It is more probable, according to the Doctrine of Galen, that the blood does naturally pas through the aid Septum. or partition wall, than through the Lungs. Howbeit, I deny not, but that in the violent Agitation of the Heart and Lungs, the blood is carried through the midt o • the aid Lungs.

div.head: The Med • cinal Conideration.
div.p: Having finihed thee Obervations, I proceed unto the Dieaes of the Heart. The Heart (as Pliny aies) cannot endure long Dieaes, nor uffer lingring torments. ual Dieaes of the Heart, art, And Galen tels us, That Phyitians have not been able to find out, or invent Medicines able to cure an evil, and malignant ditemper which has taken hold of the ubtance of the Heart. Wherefore this part is diligently to be preerved, which uffers not by its own fault, but by the Impurities of other parts wherewith it is infected and corrupted.

Wherefore, if the Heart be upplied with pure, and good blood, and be not infected by con • agion of the neighboring parts, he Lungs, and the Liver, it flourihesSwouning mot cheerfully, and caues a very long life. But by our Intemperance we uffer it not to continue in Health for the good of the whol Body. And therefore it is exercied with divers Dieaes, by the los of trength, that is to ay, of Spirits, or by their Diipation; uch as are Syncope, and Leipothymia, or wouning and faintingFainting. away, which differ only in degrees: Syncope being greater than Leipothumia.

Oftentimes the Heart does counterfeit, and make hew of a kind of Apoplexy, but without norting; neither does it leave a Paley after it, or any feebleneis of Body, or mind. If this Dieae return often with violence, at length it over-whelms and tifles the Heart, not only becaue the blood is topped from going forth, by reaon of the fulnes of the Veels, but by the Hearts being oppreed by ome gros ubtance of the blood, forcibly crowded into the Ventricies of the Heart, topping the pulative motion of the Heart and Arteries, and cauing omtime that the Patient cannot peak, and bringing him finally to his Grave.

This Dieae is as common among the Germans, as is the Apoplexy, by reaon of their full, and Champion-like habit of body, contracted by their dayly Featings, and liberal drinking, epecially at dinner, which lats til
within Night, they in the mean time taking no care to abate their Plethorick habit by liberal blood-letting. Nor is it any wonder, if from o great plenty of blood, they fal into an Apoplexy, or the Heart-woonings aforeaid. Hence depends the Explication of the 42. Aphorim of the Second Book.
The motion of the Heart is depraved in the Palpitation, or Panting thereof, andPalpitation it is interrupted in Syncope, and Leipothymia.

The Ventricles, and Partition, are oftentimes obtructed, being filled with littleThe Circulation intercepted by obtruction of the Ventricles, Or of bits of Fleh or Fat, wherewith the Heart is choaked, the Circular motion of the blood being topped. Somtimes they tick in the right Ear of the Heart: whence follows Palpitation, or inequality, or Interception of the Pule.
Worms are alo bred in the Heart, of which Salius treats. There is a memorable Story of a certain Englih man, whoe Heart was eaten into by a Worm. You may read the Story in Aurelius Severinus.

The Circulation of the blood is topped, not only in the Heart, but alo in theThe Velns. Veins, when they are topped with very thick blood, or with blood congealed like the pith of an Elder tick, as I have often een it after burning Feavers, and as it has been oberved by Fernelius.

The mot frequent Dieaes of the Heart are Feavers, wherewith it is inflamed,A Feaver. and roated as it were; o that the Original moiture thereof, becomes exhaut, and dried up: for as Ludovicus Duretus aies in his Commentary upon Hippocrates his Coick Dicoures. We loe more of our trength by a feaver of even daies continuance, than by the depraedation of our Natural Heat, in eventy yeers time: a yong man dies in even daies, conumed by a Feaver, who might have lived eventy yeers under the ole Regiment of his Natural Heat. Differences of Feavers. In respect of the Caue, a Feaver is, Spirital,

The Hitory of Feavers belongs to this place, which I hal dipatch in few words. The Hot Ditemper of the Heart, is termed a Feaver. The Differences of Feavers are taken from their conjunct Caue, which is three-fold; The Spirits, the Humors in the Veels, and the Humors fixed in the olid parts of the body.
From the Spirits, a Feaver is termed Spirituoa, or Spirital; from the Humors in the Veels, it is termed Humoralis; and from the Humors fixed in the olid parts, it is termed Hectica.

Though there be three orts of Spirits, Natural, Vital, Animal; yet is it the Vital Spirit alone, which being inflamed, caues the Spirital Feaver. There are fourHumoral Humors contained in the Veels, whence comes four orts of Humoral Feavers; the Sanguine, the Cholerick, the Flegmatick, and the Melanchollick. But the Hectick Feaver is ditinguihed by three degreee: For the imple Hectick aritesHectick, from the fixed Humor, being only inflamed; the middle Hectick is when the aid Humor begins to wat; and the Hectica Maramodes, when it is quite exhaut, and conumed.

The Modi of Feavers, or their manner of afflicting, is two-fold: for either theIn repect of the manner, Continual, Intermittent. Feaver is continual, or it intermits; it is putrid, or not putrid; malignant, or wel-affected. A continual Feaver never ceaes burning, til it go wholly away. An intermitting Feaver, leaves the Patient ome pace of time free from burning.

The Caue of the Continualnes of a Feaver, is the plenty of Morbiick matter and its nearnes to the Heart, and the ditance and paucity of the aid matter is the Caue of its Intermiion. A Putrid Feaver is caued by Putrefaction of the Humors:Putrid, Imputrid Malignant, An Imputrid Feaver is caued only by the fervency of the Spirits and Humors contained in the Veels, or fixed in the olid Parts. A Malignant Feaver is caued by extream Pucrefaction, or by divers Symptomes greivouly afflicting the noble Parts: a Well-affected Feaver, has none of al thee. A great Feaver is theNon-malignant. ame with a Malignant, and a little Feaver differs not from a Well affected. Hence are al the differences of Feavers taken; a pirital Feaver is continual indeed, yet lats but a Day, and is therefore termed Ephemera: a Sanguin Feaver is alo continual and threefold, Encreaing, tanding at a tay, and decreaing; Putrid or Imputrid: It is by ome termed continens to ditinguih it rom the ret of the Humoral Feavers. Cholerick, Melancholick and Flegmatick Feavers, are continual,
when the Humors from whence they arie do Putrifie in the great Veins: when they Putrifie in the little Veins, or out of the Veins, they make Intermitting Feavers. An Hectick Feaver is alo continual, but low and lingering.

The Return of intermitting Feavers is termed their fit; the more than ordinaryThe it of a Feaver. Its Exacerbation. Circuit Tertian Feaver. Quartans Quotidians violence of continual Feavers it called their Exacerbation. The beginning of a • i • is called Invaio, the time of Remiion and Exacerbation, of intermiion and acceion, is termed Periodus or Circuitus, the Period or Circuit.

Now the Acceions or exacerbations of Feavers are various according to the various motion of the Humor. They come every third day, by reaon of the proper motion of Choler, whence al bilious intermitting Feavers are called Tertians or third day Agues; as the Quartans come every fourth day, becaue the Melancholick Humor is moved upon that day; as Flegm is moved every day, whence quotidian Agues are Flegmatick.
Quintan, Septan, Nonan, or ift, eventh and ninth day Agues, as they are exceeding rare, o ate they not comprehended under any Rules of Art.

The Proper Symptomes of the beginnings of Ague-fits, do hew the ort of Ague what it is: o a haking hewes a Tertian Ague, A grinding cold fit that makes a man think it would break his bones, argues a Quartan; and for the fit to begin with a mere imple coldnes, is the token of a Quotidian.
A double tertian comes every day, as the Quotidian does, but with extream haking; whereas the Quotidian comes only with a coldnes.

Confued and implicated Feavers, are made of thoe Feavers, which we haveConfued. now explained. Confued or mixed Feavers, are made by mixiture of the Humors, as a Batard Tertian is made by a mixture of Choler and Flegm. But ImplicatedImplicated Feavers are tirred up by Viciitude of Humors put into Putrefaction or Commotion, where upon there is oberved in them, ditinct its one following another, as in a double Tertian, and in a double and triple Quartan, and in a Semitertian, which is nothing ele but a complication of a continual Quotidian and an Intermittent Tertian: and in the Feaver called Triteophyaea, which lats thitty hours and longer.

Two Agues are oberved to follow one another, o that the firt being not quiteErratick finihed, another which is wore ucceeds and follows the ame. But i • thee its are inordinat keeeping no certain Coure, and returning upon everal daies, they make uch Agues as are termed Erraticae, wandring giddy Agues.

There are other differences of Feavers taken from the Symptomes, yet o as theyIn repect of Symptomes. may be reduced to thee orts I have poken of: as the Feaver Epiala, Leipyria, Typhodis, Elodis, Petilens, Cauus, for they are al Humoral, and ditinguihed by ome remarkable Symptomes.

In the Feaver Epiala there is a ence of heat and cold by reaon of the unequalEpiala Leipyria motion of the Morbifick matter. In Leipyria, the outward Parts are cold, and the inner Parts burn with Heat, becaue the Feaverih Heat is drawn inwards. Typhodis and Eleodis are, in which the Patient weats much, without any eaeTyphodes. thereby. A Petilential Feaver is no other than a putrid, but it Springs from an extream and remarkable putrefaction, and o deadly, that more die than recover. Cauus is a name ignifying extream Heat and burnning, uch as is in a continualBurning Feaver. Feaver ariing from Choler, o that a Cholerick continiual Feaver by way of Eminency is o termed.

Cremnodes Febris the Feaver o called, is aid to proceed from an InflammationSymptomatical Feavers. of the Lungs: but uch Feavers as are caued by Inflammation of the Internal Parts, are Symptomatical, neither are they properly termed Feavers. For here we peak of a Feaver only as it is an hot ditemper of the Heart primarily affected.

div.head: Chap. 9. Of the Veels viz. Veins, Arteries and Nerves conteined within the Chet.
div.p: I Have a few things to peak of one Part of the Trunk of Vena Cava, forIn the Chet are Veins. the whol Trunk has been ufficiently explained in our Chapter of the lower Belly.

You hal oberve that the Trunk piercing through the Midrif, does receive that ameT. 12. f. 1. r r. &c. Hepatick branch which aries from the top of the Liver, and carries BloodHepatica into the Cava, and from that ame Oblique inertion, unto the opening of the Trunk, in the right Ventricle of the heart, there is the ditance of two Fingers breadth.

From whence we may gather, that Blood is carried directly from the Liver to the Heart, although it is mixed with other blood acending by Circulation. That ame opening of the Vena Cava, and its cleaving to the right Ventricle of the heart, is contained and to be een within the Pericardium: which when the Trunk has paed through, it acends unto the Claves.

And therefore you may know, that the blood acending unto the heart by Circulation, does alo come as far as the Throat, and is derived into the upper Limbes, with that blood which decends from the Head by the Veins.

You hal oberve, that this Trunk does afford no branches to the heart except the T. 12. f. 2. Coronaria but only to other parts of the Chet, and how blood hed out ofCoronaria the left Ventricle of the heart into the Lungs, may be revelled by Blood-letting, eeing it has two Doors to be broken open in the heart before it can come to the Trunk of Vena Cava, which hinder the flowing back of the Blood from the Lungs.

You hal conider if the T. 11. f. 3. and 6. B. Anatomois of the Arteria Venoa with Vena Cava he remaining, by which the foreaid Reflux may be made: or whether the blood of the Lungs, ought not to return into the left Ventricle of the heart, that it may be made vital, and then peedily to be cat into the Aorta, from thence to be forthwith delivered over into the Veins.

Then you are to earch for the Vena f. 1. D • t. 12. f. 1. a a a Azygos or Vein without a fellow, whichAzygos Its Valves nourihes the Ribs. In it you hal oberve two or four valves or hutters, not feigned and imaginary, but true, interchangably dipoed, which reit the blood flowing in abundantly. I have many times hewed thoe valves, and an inferior branch of this Vein, ending into the Trunk of the Vena Cava, below the Kidneys. For which caue it cannot drink up nor tranmit purulent matter into the Kidneys.

This branch erves to disburthen the Vena Cava above the Heart, if blood do any time there abound, or be contained in any great quantity, within the little branches or twigs of the Azygos, or olitary Vein.

Furthermore you hal earch out the mutual Anatomoes of the twigs of theAnatomoes. Azygos o • olitary Vein, with the twigs of the Chet Vein, under the leer awfahioned Mucle, near the Arm-Pi • ts. Hence it comes that in the Pleuriie, the pained ide is better disbur • hened and the pain ooner eaed, by opening the Vena Bailica, than any other Vein.

After the Azygos or olitary Vein, out of the Trunk of the Cava acending, the Intercotals arie, onT. 12. f. 2. b b. each ide one, if the branches of Vena Azygos, do not reachIntercotals unto the upper Ribs.

In the parting of the Vena Cava you hal under it oberve a great Kernel, placedThymus a Kernel o called. in the Throat under the Claves like a Pillow, that it may gently bear up and enfold the Subclavian branches. It is called Thymus. In yong Animals it is ot, as in Calves, and together with the great Kernel of the Pancreas or Sweet-bread, it is eaten as a dainty Dih.

By the welling of this Kernel, Strangulations or a ence of Choaking may happen even to Men, but in Women ubject to the Mother it is more frequently welled, and Choaks them if they be not releived by Blood-letting. Some do recken up three mal Veins which are termed Thymica, Capularis and T. 12. f. 4. C. &c. Mediatina: whereas notwithtanding the Capularis and Mediatina, are one and the ameMediatina Vein.

From the T. 12. f. 5. Ramus Subclavius, four notable branches do arie. The firt is cal-Anterior Cervicalis. T. 12. f. 4. A. Cervicalis the foremot Neck-Vein, which being drawn out upon the Muculi Matoides, acends unto the Chin and Waters the fore Parts of the Neck.

After this follows the T. 12. f. 4. C. Internal Jugular, being larger than the external, whichInternal Jugular. acends unto the Neck under the Muculus Matoides, and about the middle thereof, it is divided into three Branches, one of which being greatet and thicket, creeping along the ertebra's goes under the Scul making its entrance at the hole which is near the Apophyis Styloidea, o as being applied to the lateral Channels of the Meninx dura or Dura Mater, is poures out its Blood and goes no farther.
The Second branch creeps through the ides of the Neck and is ditributed under the Jaw.
The third goes into the Tongue and produces the Ranulae or Veins under the Tongue, the opening of which does wonderfully help in Dieaes of the Brain.

A Finger-breadth ditant from this Vein you have the Externa e Jugulatis, External Jugular. which creeping a • ant or loaping under the Clavicula, it ends forth two twigs, whereof the one paes Obliquely unto the Delta-haped Mucle under the Shoulder-point and is united unto the Vena Cephalica; the other aries to the lateral Parts of the Head; where at the corners of the Jaw-bone it is divided into two, and is ditributed into the Jaws and al the Parts which are ubjected unto the Jaw-bone.

The Other Portion, being carryed behind the Eares, is ditributed into the Fore-Head and hinder Part of the Head, and upon the Temples with manifold branches; and in thee Parts, by reaon of the Veins, Fernelius did conceive that a erous Humor was heaped together, which flowing down upon the Parts beneath, does breed Fluxions in the Habit of the Body: he conceived likwie that an Iue made, or a cautick applied to the Cavity behind the Eare, did more good, than if it had been made in the hinder part of the Head, becaue of a branch of the Jugular Vein, rea
• hing unto the Eye.

This external Jugular Vein being opened by a skilul Surgeon in leepy Dieaes,Whether and in what Cae it may profitably be opened. is very good, as many Hitories do tetifie: but many wil not allow of it, who prefer two or three Hor-Leeches fatened according to the Longitude of the Vein, as far as the corner of the lower Jaw, where it ticks out and is viible

Howbeit you mut oberve, that the internal Jugular does in the Neck communicate with the external; and there this external Vein being opened, although it reach not unto the Brain yet • ay it disburthen this Part, eeing the internal Jugular is hid, under the Mucu us Mato • d • us and cannot afely be opened. And therefore that a • e opening of the Jugulars which is o much poken of, is to be undertood of the external Jugula • , and not of the internal.

And becaue the Arteries and Veins are alwaies con • guous and coupled together,A •… ries. Cor •…
in the ame •… e you hal lo • k for the r •… k of the a A • rta acending. Spr •…
ging out of the left Ventricle of the Heart, it does preently even in its Rie produce the two b Corona • y or Crown Arteries, which do compa • s the Heart like a Crown

Thee you wil not ee exactly, unles you cut the Aorta and look into it through the left Ventricle of the heart: if there be only one, you hal • ind a little Valve plac • d at the O •• fice thereof, as in the Coronary Vein.
The T • unk of the Aorta after a little progres, is without the Perica • dium divided into Two Branches, the one whereof is termed c Acenden • , the other d Decendent.

The acendent is triparted, three Arteries being brought from the ame place; that on the right ide acending to the Claves, makes the T. 12. f. 4. B. Subolavia dexira; theSubclaviae other two a • cend unto the left •… de; the firt whereof, is called Ca •… tis f. 4 a. S •• t • a going upwards; the econd is named f. 4. B. Subclavia • init • a; and a T. 24. f. 2. A. hile a • te •
d Axillaris, Axillaris. when it is come as far as the Arm-pits, and • ends forth the T. 12. f. 4. dd. Arte •• a. Cervicalis,
•• er the Shoulder-point.

The Right Subclavian Artery having over-pat the Claves, does produce that Artery which i • termed Carotis f. 4. a. Dex • ra, which neer the corner of the lower Jawbone, is like the internal J • guiar Vein, divided into two no able B • anches the f. 4. c. Internal, and f. 4. b. External. They are termed Arteriae Carotides. Sleepy Arteries;Carotides. becaue they being compreed, do make a man • al into a • eep leep and take away he Voyce. Wh •… h I have often demontrated i • Dogs, and how the • ame is done b •
• ying a Nerve of the ixt Conjugation.

Ga • en. in his Book, of the Utility of Repiration, does conceive and proves byWhether the obtruction of the Carotides do caue deep Sleep? making experiment in Live Creatures, that Animalls are no way offended by •• ing o •
<…> the Jugular Arteries; and therefore he refers the Sleepy-Evil to the Jugular Veins. I hal • ather think, that in Apoplexies and Dead-leeps the Arteries are topped, than the Veins.
Valverda does <…> that Columbus made publick demontration in a youth, that deep leep is caued by compreion or contriction o • the Caro • ick Arteries: but he does not tell us how he did it.

That the a • cent of the Carotick Arteries and their penetration into the brain by the holes of the Skul may be plainly perceived, you hal put in a very mal • ras W • re that wil be • d, with a knob at the end, into the everal diviions of this Artery; which may be done and hewed, by the vulgar way of diecting the Brain, beginning from the upper Part, not from the lower Part a • ter the manner of Varoli • s, and in the Neck you hal put your Probe into the Catotick Artery.

The Tru • k of the Aorta being writhen towards the left ide, and bent downwardsThe Intercota • s. again, is born up by the Vertebraes of the back, and in its progres as far as the Os Sacr •… , ou • of each ide produces as many Arteries as there are Vertebraes, neither is there • ound any oliiary Artery to accompany the olitary Vein, but there are uch like petty Arteries which upply its place.

Within the Chet they may be termed a Intercoatal Arteries: beneath in theLumbal. lower be • ly, b the Lumbal or Loyn Arteries: they ininuate themelves in • o the pinal Marrow by the holes o • the Vertebra's which may be proved by a memorable example in Galen, in his fourth Book of the Parts affected.
One out of a vehement Inflamation of the Lungs, fel into a P • lie of his upper Limbs, and the upper intercotal Nerves being anointed, he was cu • ed.

I, and my mot learned fellow Collegiate, Dr. Merlet, have een a P • lie caued byCommunion of the Arteries & pinal Marrow. tranlation of the matter of a Pleuriie into the Marrow of the back, which Pal •• freed the Patient from the eminent danger he was in by reaon of the Pleuriie.

So Hippocrates, in his Coicks, oberves, that a Convulion takes away a Feaver, by tranlation of the Morbi • ick Matter into the Marrow of the Back. The hinder c Neck Artery may do as much, which waters the Marrow of the Neck.

I know not how the Humor which caues an Apoplexy, • alling through the fourth Ventricle of the Brain upon that Marrow of the back, hould bri • g the Palie into one ide more than another: by that way before mentioned, viz. The Cervical and Intercotal Arteries, the erous Humor may be derived into either ide.

By the ame Reaon, the erous matter may through the Celiack Artery return back into the Aorta, and by the little Arteries pene • rating the Marrow of the back, be derived into the Nerves of the inferior Limbs; and on the other ide, the matter of a true or batard Sciatica, by the continuation of the thicket Nerve, may return into the Marrow of the back, from whence it may be revelled by the Aorta into the Meentery.
In the Chet we are to take notice of eight remarkable Nerves or Sinnews. TwoNerves. of which are called Diaphragmatici, two are termed Recurrentes, two Stomachici, and two Cotales.

Diaphragmatici, the Midrif Nerves, taking their rie between the T. 10. f. 7. A B. fourth andDiaphragmatic
• i • t Vertebra's of the Neck, from that ame thick Nerve of the Neck which goes into the Arm; they de • cend between the • oldings of the Mediatinum unto the Nervous Centre of the Diaphragme, or Midrif.

The Recurrent
T. 3. f. 1.
< in non-Latin alphabet > . and Stomachic, are branches of a Nerve of the ixt ConjugationRecurrent. or pair, whoe Trunk you hal eek for in the Neck near the internal Jugular, by the Apophyis Matoides; where it is cle • t into two branches, the one of which is di • emmia • ed into the Superior Mu • cles of the Neck: the other being placed between the internal Jugular and the Carotis decends unto the Claves, where it is parted into two branche • , the Recurrent and the Stomachic.
The bending back of the left Recurrent Nerve is found about the place where theTheir bending Back where to be • ound. Aorta is bowed in, and that eaily before the Pericardium is opened.
You hal find the bending back of the right Nerve, about the right ubclavian Artery.

I have often een Dogs live and run, after their Recurrent Nerves were cut, and have my elf made publick demontration thereof, but they could not bark a • all; and when thee Nerves are tied they deprive the Animal of voyce, and being united the voyce returns: wherefore it is apparent, that thee Nerve • erve to make the voyce becaue they return upwards, that they may be inerted into the He • ds of the Mucles of the Laryn •• , Tongue, and Os Hyoide • , which arie from the Inferior Parts.

You hal earch for the Stomachic T. • . f. • . III. &c. Nerves beneath the Heart, near the Vertebra's, Stomachic. they •• e hid within the folding of the Mediatinum, and from them you hal perceive ten or twelve • wigs drawn into the T. 3. f. 8. h h. Lungs; and of the mal branches of the two Stomachick Nerve • folded and <> together, is made that • ame Nervorum Mir •• ilis Ple • us, wonderful contexture of Nerves in the upper Orifice of the tomach.

Afterwards the Stomachick Nerves creeping along the hinder Parts of the Stomach, are near the Back-bone between the two Kidney T. 3. f. 2. H. Joyned to the T. 3. f. 8. B B. Cotals, o as to make that T. 3. f. 8. . Contexture of Nerves, out of which al thoe Nerves are derived, which are ditributed into the Parts of the lower Belly.
All T. 3. f. 8. B B B. Anatomits derive • he Cotal Nerve from the ixt pair, when as in the meanCotal. while, it ari • es from the ame poin • of the B ••• n • rom which the •• xt pair aries.

The cotal Nerve, being come without the Scul, is trengthened as it were with a Knot tied about it, and it decends undivided upon the Neck; and when it is c ••• to the three lat Vertebra's of the Neck, it is de • ended by ano •• er Knot, and grows thicker by addition of three mal Nerves; and being lipped down within the • het, in its progres near the Back-bone, under the Membrane Pleura, it is aug • ented by additions of other two mal Nerves proceeding from the Marrow of the Back.
Having peirced the Mid • i •• , it is Joyned to the Stomachick Nerves, to make that ame Contexture of Nerves, ••• emb •• ng a Net which is between the two Kidneys.

div.trailer: The End of the Third Book.

div.head: THE FOURTH BOOK OF THE ANATOMY AND PATHOLOGY OF John Riolanus, THE KINGS PROFESSOR OF PHYSICK.
Chap. 1. Of the Head.
div.p:
THE H • ad being the Seat of the Soul, the Man • on Houe ofWhy the Head is placed in the • ig • et place? the br • in is placed a lo • t in the hig • et part of the Body, as it were the prime Catle, which co • m •• ds, and bears Rule over the whol •• y. <> aies •••
• ea • was th •• pl ••• d on the top of the Body; becaue of the Eyes, which are the • couts and Guides of the Body: Aritotle aies i • was for to cool the Heart, by that coldne • s which • he brain would hed down thereupon.
• A • Head that is wel • ramed, ought to be of an indifferent Size; for a great, andIts Size. a little Head, are diallowed, and diprai • ed.
The Natural Figure of the Head is round, or pherical, on what longi • h, bunchingShape. out before and behind, with two Eminences, and a little flat, or compre • ed towards the Temples.

The Head is divided into the hairy Part, and the • mooth Part, o long as it isDiviion. whol, and unparted: The mooth part is termed the Face, and thereunto is the
Forehead appertaining. The hairy part retains the Name of the Head.

The Head is otherwie conidered in the Hitory of the Bones: for it is divided into the T. 15. f. 3. A B C. Skul, and the two Jaws, the f. 5, and 6. upper, and the f. 3. L M N. lower; and the Forehead appertains unto the Scull.

Again, The whol Head is divided into two direct parts, and two ide parts. TheExternal parts of the Head. direct are the f. 3. A. fore part of the Head, which from the beginning of the Hair, aries four or five fingers breadth towards the top or Crown of the Head.

After which, the pace of two • ingers, and as much after the Vertical point of the Crown, where the Hairs turn, is termed f. 3. B C. Vertex: the hinder part is called f. 4. C. f. 6. A A. Occip • t; the lateral parts are called Tempora, f. 3. D. f. 6. B. the Temples, or Times; becaue they dicover the Times of a mans Age by their hollownes, hoarines, or baldne • s.

The Head is compounded, and made up of many parts, of which, ome a • e external,The conti ••
• ing parts. others internal; • ontaining, and contained.

The Containing, o • Membranous, or Bony; the contained, or internal, are the Brain, the Cerebellum, or petty brain, the four roots of the Spinal Marrow and uch Particles as are included in their Cavities.

The firt containing part we meet with, is the f. 1. A A. hairy Skin, which has alo its Epidermis, The hairy Skin. The fl • hy Membrane. or Scarf-skin. Under the Skin, lies the Flehy f. 1. B B. Membrane, which is the Foundation, & Seed-plot of the Hairs: which if it be Flehy, it makes the hairy Skin movable, becaue it ticks cloe hereunto without any fat coming between.

The Pericraneum follows, which does immediately compas the bony Skul. ItPericranium is produced from the thick Meninx, which in Children, goes through the Su • ures, at what time they are not firmly cloed, no • ioyned Tooth within Tooth.
k f. 1. C C.

Beides the Pericranium, there is craped from the Skul, as from other bones,Periotium the Periotium being a thin Skin, which immediately covers them. Wherefore the Pericranium is not the Perioteon of the Skul but is pread out upon the Skul by a great Providence of Nature, that it might hold fat the Mucles which arieIts ue, from the Skul, uch as are the temporal Mucle, the tronget in the whol Body, which with its companion, contracts, and lift • up the Jaw, and bears greater burdens in ome bodies, than the other Mucles acting al together.
Alo it trengthens, and cloely comprehends the Mucles of the hinder part of the He • d. Decending to the Eyes, and tretched out under the Eye-lids, it makes the Conjunctive Coat of the Eye.

Thee Membranes being eparated, and plucked off, and the T. 15. f. 1. D D. Skul having itsThe Skull Cap taken off, it preents it elf to ou • ight, being framed together of many bones, which are • oyned one to another, by looer, or fater Sutures, or Seams.

Somtimes there are no Sutures, or Seams to be een, when the Skul is one continued bone. But the Hitory of the Skul appertains to that double Oteology, or Bone-tory; the one of which has been pr • mied unto this Work, and the ot ••• hal be demontrated at the end hereof.

div.head: The Medicinal Conideration.
div.p:
The Head being the Fountain, and Original of almot al Dieaes, according toGeneral Dieaes of the head Hipyocrates, by reaon of Fluxes of Rhewm, which flow from the Head into the in • erior parts, even as low as the Feet, does condole, and has a fellow feeling with all parts. Being placed on the top of the Trunk of the Body, like a Cupping-glas it attracts, and receives vapors which mount from the inferior parts, according to Hippocrates in his fourth Book of Dieaes: which vapors, the brain being ••• gy like a kernel, does drink, and up in, according to the aid Hippocrates, in his Book of Glandules, or Kernels. The Vapors being con • ealed into Water, do fal down,
and return up again like a River that ebbs and flows, according to Aritotle; which Hippocrates had taught before him, having in that repect termed the Brain, the Metropolis of a cold, and moit, glutinous, and clammy Humor.

If the Shape of the Head be depraved, o that it be harp pointed, or the longitudeShape depraved. thereof be turned into latitude; uch an Head cannot be • ound and healthy: and therefore either it is dieaed, or the principal Faculties are weakened If in Children new born, • uch a Figure be oberved, it may • e corrected by Art, and with the Hand; as if it be great, and large, when the Child is a month or two old, d • ying Medicines being applied, and Fo •• anels, or Iues made in the Nape of the Neck, the over-great moiture of the Brain may be dried up; and conequently the Head wil become les; which cannot be effected when the Children are grown up. A narrow Head, cannot be by Art enlarged, many Age whatoever.

If the Sutures of the Skul are traiter tha • ordinary, o •
• f there be no Sutures,Over lax, or looe, &c. or they be wider than is • i • , the Head is ubject to Dieaes, becaue the moaky Ex •• ements of the Brain, have nor a free paage.
If the Head be more looe and open than is • it, it is the more expoed in the Injuries of the ambient Air.
Thee Inconveniencies may be remedied by help of Phyick, or by wearing a Cap, or by going bare-head, as occaion requires.

I proceed unto the Particular Dieaes of the Parts containing. And firt of theParticular dieaes. hairy Skin, whoe Action is the breeding of Hairs, the efficient cau • e wh •• eo • is a temper moderately hot and dry, and an indifferent Contitution of the Skin; and the internal caue is a ooty Excrement, which thruting it elf for •• bly by the mal Pores, gains the form of a thred. The hurting of this Action, is a Symptome of the hairy Skin. The hurt thereof is three- • old, it is diminihed in the Diea • e termed Ophiais, in which the Hairs fal off from the hinder part of the Head along to theOphiais. Fore-head, making bald wreaths like thoe of Serpents; or it is abolihed in baldnes, and the Alopecia, or Foxfal of the hairs.
The Caue of the falling off of the Hair of the Head, is the hot and dry ditemper of the Skin, with a naughty and harp Humor, eating away the roots of the Hairs.
The Naughtines of the Humor is known by the color of the Skin, and of the blood, which comes out of the Skin being pricked.

Baldnes is a deprivation of the Hair of the Head, by reaon of an Hectical dryBaldnes ditemper, and hard Contitution of the Skin. A defect of Nutriment, and profitable Humor, or of the • uligi • ous Excrement, caues this ditemper of the Skin. Hence it is that Eu • uchs, becaue very moit, do never wax bald.

Gray-hairednes is a Symptome of the Hairy Scalp or Skin of the Head, by whichGray Hairs the Generation of Hairs is depraved, o that they grow white before the time. The caue of both thee kinds of baldnes, as wel that which comes Symptomatically, as that caued by Age, is the cold and moit ditemper of the Skin, whereby the • uligi • ous Excrement of the Skin is allaied and tempered. When I ay a cold ditemper, I mean the weaknes of the Natural Heat: whence it comes to pa • s that by icknes and orrow, many become gray-hair'd, becaue the Natural Heat is by both diminihed.

Ulcers of the Head are either light, and poes the Scarf-skin only, which turnsDaddruf into little Scales, Scurf, or Dandruf, when the Head is combed: whence the Greeks term it Pituriais, the Latins Porrigo: uch like Ulcers are either dry and inviible; or they are viible, and manifetly to be een: their Caue is an hot and dry ditemper of the Skin, with a harp and thin Humor.

Ac • or, is a Dieae of the Skin of the Head, compounded of a tumor, and an Ulcer;Sor • Head the tumor is known by the inequality, the Ulcer by little holes, out of which flows a clammy Humor; which made Pliny cal the flowing Ulcers of the Head, Ceiron, or the Honey-comb. But the Honey-comb, though a tumor, and Ulcer of the Head, yet differs from the former, becaue it has greater holes, and the Humor that comes out is mattery like Honey, or of the Conitency of Honey. Pl • ny cals them Ulcers congealed together like an Honey-comb. The Caue of both thee
Dieaes, is an hot and dry ditemper of the Skin, with a harp and biting Humor, which invites one to cratch: by cratching, the welling is encreaed, and at length Ulcerated, o that the holes break out: Vulgarly 'tis called Tinea, the Moath, becaue the holes are like thoe of Moath-eaten Garments.

Hydrocephalos, or the Water-head, is a welling of the Head, caued by aHead-dro • ie. whey •• h Humor, collected and hed abroad between the Skul, and the Pericram
•• ; or between the Skul, and Dura Mater, or within the Ventricles of the Brain fi • led with whe •• h moiture, which runs over as it were on al ides.

In Infants 'tis caued by queezing of the Childs Head at the time of Birth. In thoe that are grown up, the caue hereof is a cold and moit ditemper of the Head and whol Body, or a tranlation of • erous humors unto the Head, which generally is welled, and rai • ed to a vat compa • s, by the humor under the Sk • n, or included within the Head.

P •• ir • ais, or the Louz • Evil, is a Symptome of the hairy Scalpe, when inteadLouzie Evil. of the • hicker Excrements, or together with them, L • ce are bred in the top of the Skin, or deep in the ame.
The Cau • e hereof, is an hot and moit ditemper of the Skin, with a putrified humor not very harp; which makes this Dieae commonly ubject to Children, and old Flegmatick Perons.
The Temple-Mucles are to be oberved, which cover a great part of the Skul, whoe wounds or bruies, do caue a Convulion, and contract, and traiten the Jaw.

div.head: Chap. 2. Of the Brain.
div.p: THe Skul being duly awed in under, and the covering removed, the T. 16. f. 1. BrainThe Brains. appears, proportionated to the Skul which contained it; uch as is the thing containing, uch is the contained. Or uppoe the Brain gives Figure to the bones when they are oft, then the Skul follows the quantity of the brain, be it great or little. But in cae the brain follow not the Natural figure and magnitude of the Head, its conformation is faulty; and conequently ickly and advere to the internal Sences, both principal, and ubervient, wh • ch it hurts in their Actions.

The Brain is compounded of a f. 3. A A. Subtance oft, waxy, or pliable, whitih:Subtance. which becaue, like a Kernel, it drinks and ucks up humidities, it is therefore by Hippocrates, termed the great Kernel.

It is divided into two parts. That which is three times as big as the other, retainsDiviion. the common name of the f. 6. A A. Brain: the leer part placed in the hinder part of the Head, is termed f. 6. D D. Cerebellum, or the Petty-brain. Both thee parts are coveredTwo Coats, viz. 1 Craa-meninx. 2 The Tenuis meninx. with common Coverings, termed Meninges. The firt Coat, or Covering, is called f. 1. A C. f. 2. B. f. 3. H. &c. Craa Meninx; the econd f. 1. B B. Tenuis Meninx. The Arabians termed thee Membranes, Matres, or Mothers, becaue they were perwaded, that the other Membranes of the Bo • y, were propagated from thee.

The firt Meninx f. 1. A A. &c. hard and thick, being united to the Sutures of the Head, upends the whol bulk of the brain; thee Connexions mut be viewed when the Skul is taken off. In the thick Meninx are oberved innumerable f. 1. a a. Veels, wherewith it is prinkled and trewed: they are rather Arterial than Venal, being produced from the Rere Mirabile, being drawn out from beneath upwards, as far as the Channels of the Meninx, where they unload their blood; and therefore it is the Membrane which is een to beat and pant, rather than the ubtance of the Brain.

Now the Pipes belonging to this Coat, are four; whereof two are lateral, whichThe Pipes. run along the ides of the Sutura Lambdoides, that they may receive the blood
from the internal Jugulars, and from the Neck Veins; or by them, according to the Doctrine of Circulation, the blood may flow back unto the Heart.

From the Union of thee two Channels, is formed a third, longwie, drawn out directly as far as the Notrils. In the Concoure of the three beneath, there prings a fourth f. 5. e e. Channel or Pipe, which goes into the Subtance of the Brain, between the Brain, and the Petty-Brain: it is not hut up in the • oldings of the Dura Mater, but there is a great Vein, o called by Galen, which decending into the f. 3. D E former Ventricles, makes the Plexus T. 17. f. 1. O O R R. T. 16. f. 3. F F. f. 5. f f. Choroides, which is di • pered t •• ough al the Ventricles,Plexus Choroides. Torcular unto the Bais of the Brain.

The Channel which runs longwie, deerves rather the name of Torcular, than the T. 17. f. 5. F. fourth: becaue from thence, is the blood ditributed into the lower parts, by innumerable little Veins, through the turnings and windings of the brain.

Thee lateral Channels, neither do the Veins, nor the Arteries go into, and pas through with their Coats, but are terminated at the entrance; and therefore thoe Channels are rather Arterial, than Venal: for the Brain being of its own Nature cold and oft, ought rather to be nourihed with hot, ubtile, and Arterial blood, than with uch as the Veins afford, being thick, and hard to penetrate.

And in cae the Vein, and A • terial blood were confued and mixed together in thee Channels, they would not pant or beat; and the Pulation of the Channels demontrates, that it depends not upon the Body of the Ar • eries; for there are no • e in that place, but upon the leaping of the blood, after the manner of Arteries.
a T. 16. f. 5. a, & b.
bf. 2. a a. f. 5. c c.

Now this Menbrane, namely, the Craa Meninx, divides the Brain into two parts, as far as the middle thereof, by the Corpus Calloum. This Partition is termed T. 16. f. 3. A A. f. 5. E E. Falx, and being doubled on both ides, it evers the Brain from the Petty-Brain.Falx

The Tenuis f. 1. B B. Meninx follows, which immediately incloes the brain, beingTenuis Meninx Why the Brain is full of windings and turnings? cloely conveighed into the windings and turnings thereof; for the ubtance of the brain, is f. 1. b b. without, after a wonderful manner, ful of deep turnings and windings, for the lighter paage of the Arteries, which dipere the blood here and there; and therefore Pelops, the Mater of Galen, eeing thoe little Arteries dipered up and down the Brain, did beleeve that there was the beginning of the Veins.

The Tenuis Meninx is three times o long as the Craa Meninx, becaue it paes into the inner Parts of the Brain, and as a Veil it covers and eparates, and divides the whol Bulk of the Brain into three Parts. For near upon the upper half of the Brain, which covers the Ventricles being placed upon the Corpus Calloum, it is on both ides Circularly eparated and lifted up as high as the Roots of the Marrow of the Back, which do knit together that ame upper portion. So that the Brain is divided into three Parts; on each ide one over the Ventricles, and the third which includes the Ventricles, being continued, and no waies disjoyned.

A mal quantity of the f. 2. B B. f. 3. B B. Corpus Calloum being cut of, the Two f. 3. D D. E E. f. 4. C C. D D. former and The two former Ventricles. upper Ventricles appear, which in their lower Part towards the bais of the Brain are larger, from whence they take their rie upward, being maller at the top.

They are eparated by a Thin Membranous Partition, which is framed of the Tenuis Meninx doubled together, and is called Speculum Lucidum, or the Bright Septum lucidu¯. Mirror, becaue it is tranparent.T. 16. f. 3. G.
The former Ventricles are perforated in the forepart towards Os Ethinoides, that the eroities may flow down from the uperior Part • to that place.

Above the foremot Ventricles there is pred out a T. 16. f. 3. b b. f. 4. B. Tripartite body, which is termed Corpus Palloides, or the Welch Harp, utained by three Pillars: whereofFornix. two are T. 17. f. 1. G G. Lateral: turned back about thoe T. 16. f. 4. b b. c c. &c. Eminencies which Galen calls the Chambers of the Optick Nerves:

The other foreward T. 17. f. 1. F. Colomne, is placed between the two Ventricles. If you hal follow thoe two lateral Columnes, you wil find them to be productions of the Optick Nerves, which within the Ventricles do Joyn themelves one to another, as in the Bais of the Brain; behind the Choana, they are again united; whence I conjecture that the power of undertanding and knowledg, is principally contained, in the former Part of the Brain, and that from thence the Animal pirit is drawn which is adminitred unto the Eyes.

By the Concoure of the two Ventricles Between the two large Hillocks aforeaid, and other ubequent Eminencies, is formed a Guttur or Channel, which makes the third T. 16. f. 4. E. Ventricle. In the Bais of which Channel there is een an T. 17. f. 1. below Q. hole,The third Ventricle. which penetrates into the Choana, to purge out Wheyih Flegm into the throat, near the Palate.

In the ides of this Channel, the Circumjacent Eminences do form, ome theNates Tetes: Anus. T. 16. f. 4. b b. Nates or Buttocks, others the Tetes or T. 16. f. 4. c c. T. 17. f. 1. M M. Stones. For o thoe Eminencies or bunchings out are termed, being interchangably dipoed, and from that Channel, the Hole which goes into the fourth Ventricle, is termed Anus or the T. 17. f. 1. above Q. f. 2. F. Are-hole.

In the upper Part of this Channel is uperincumbent that ame Kernel which isConarium. termed T. 16. f. 4. • . T. 17. f. 1. L. Conari • m the Pine-Apple Kernel, becaue tis haped like a Pine-Apple. And over this Channel and the fourth f. 2. N N. Ventricle, is a thin Membrane tretched out, derived from the Tenuis Meninx, upon which runs the T. 16. f. 3. F F. T. 17. f. 1. O O. R R. Plexus Chor • ides, deffued through the foremot Ventricles.

In the entrance of the fourth Ventricle, there is placed a certain portion of theProceu • Vermiformis. Brain more firm than ordinary which repreents the taile of a River-Crab when the hel is peeled off. It is called Scolicoides and Vermiformis T. 16. f. 6. E. T. 17. f. 2. C C. Proceus, the Wormfahioned Production: is opens and huts the paage into the fourth Ventricle. This is placed in the Cerebellum or Petty Brain; which contained within it elf the two hinder mot portions of the pinal Marrow, as the Brain contained the other two foremot, which I have named with Galen the beds of the Optick Nerves.

In that ame f. 1. N N. f. 2. D D. G G. T. 18. f. 4. F. fourth Ventricle, there appeares a certain T. 17. f. 2. H. T. 18. f. 4. • . Chink like a Writing-Pen,The fourth Ventricle. which is the Separation of the Marrow of the Back.

The Petty-Brain being pulled aunder, you hal ee how it conteins within it the fourth Ventricle, between the two aftermot Roots of the Marrow of the back; and how being drier than the Brain, it gives Original to T. 18. f. 3. even or eight pair of Nerves, aving the Optick Nerve.
It is not ful of windings above but beneath, according to the external form of the brain it elf. In like manner it is divided beneath into T. 18. f. 4. A A. two Parts, being continued above.

If you hal gently draw upwards the formot Part of the brain, as far as its bais,Pelvis. Glandula Pituitaria. you hal oberve the T. 17. f. 1. S. T. V. T. 18. f. 1. B. f. 3. B B. Optick Nerves, and the Nerves, erving for T. 18. f. 1. C C. f. 3. G G. Motion, and then the T. 18. f. 3. D. Choana or funnel dropping Wheyih moiture upon the c Glandula Pituitaria or Flegm-Kernel, which fils up and poees the Sella Equina or Hore-Saddle. In the Choana or Funnel you hal ee Four Pipes ditillingTubuli. Seven pair of Nerves. Wheyih moiture into the Palate and throat. Then you hal conider the order of thoe even pair of Nerves recorded in the following Veres.

lg.l: f. 1. D D. f. 3. H. H. Third and Fourth tat, f. 1. F F. f. 3. K K. Fift hears and makes us Wie.
The f. 1. G G. f. 3. L L. T. 3 f. 8 all Sixth is large and wanders all about:
f. 3. M M. Seventh Larynx moves a prating Tongue o tout.

div.p: Then you hal earch under the Dura Meninx in the bais of the brain about the Compas of the Sella Sphenoides, for the Rete Mirabile or wonderful f. 3. P P. Net of ArteriesRete Mirabile. interwoven one among another, being formed of the two f. 3. C C. Carotides or leep Arteries.

You hal oberve in the Bais of the brain, that Wheyih Humors of blood is powred forth, in extream pains of the Head coming with Inflammation, which while they eek to go forth by the Cavities of the Ears, they caue extream harp pains, which bring the Patient into Madnes and Sicknes. Whether or no in uch a deperate Cae, may we boar either ide of the Hindermot Part of the Head, to let out the uperfluous putrid Humor, which corrupts the ubtance of the Brain?

The T. 18. f. 1. F F. f. 3. K K. Auditory Nerve is worthy of Conideration, which is inerted into the Cavity of the Eare, and by a little Channel lides down into the Palate, and is ditributed into the inner Part of the Larynx: from whence comes that ame Concent that is between the Tongue and Teeth, the Larynx and the Lungs.
g f. 1. E E. f. 3. I I.
Oberve Whether or no they be interected Croe-wie, o as the right hould from its original be carryed unto the left Part, and the left unto the right, which I have never een.
Whether the Nerves in their Rie have Arteries Joyned in company with them? Whether the Nerves are made up of many mal threds? Whether the other Nerves differ from the Optick Nerve.

I wil not wholly pas over thoe four notable Quetions: Whether the brain be moved? Whether or no the brain does cool the Heart? Whether the Ventricles of the brain are ordained only to contein Excrements? Whether or no the blood be there Circulated and how?

As to the firt Quetion, I ay that the ubtance of the Brain is not moved of itWhether the Brain have any Motion? elf, by Diatole and Sitole, after the manner of the Arteries, but only the Craa Meninx, which is prinkled al over with Arteries, ariing from the wonderful Contexture of Arteries, unto the upper Channels of the aid Craa Meninx: alo the Channels do pant, and the brain is moved by elevation and depreion of the ubtance thereof, according as it is driven by the Animal pirits.
The brain does cool the Heart, in amuch as by Circulation, it ends back theWhether it cools the heart? blood unto the Heart being cooled in the Brain.

The foremot and uppermot Ventricles are Receptacles for pirits: the whey mayThe ue of the fore Ventricles. indeed decend into the upper Ventricles, from the whole Mas of the brain, but it
preently fals down into the lower Ventricles, that from thence it may flow through Os Ethmoides into the Notr • s: if the Os Ethmoides or Colauder-bone be obtructed, it ditils by the Choana or Funnel, or by the little holes over the Funnel, into the Palate and Jaws or Throat.

The Circulation of the blood is performed in the brain, with a low pace. TheWhether or n • and how th ulood is Circulated in th Brain. blood ries out of the Net like-Contexture, by the Arteries of Dura Meninx, unto the foure Channels; afterwards it decends by the Veins unto the Heart, having been plundred of its pirits, which the brain drank up. And o the blood being cooled, is aid to coole the Heart. Of al which I hall treat more fully in my Anthropographia, or large Decription of the body of Man.

The Brain, being of its own Nature cold and moit, is nourihed only with theWhat Bloo • the Brain nourih • with purer and more piritous arterial blood, which acends by the Carotides and paes peedily forth. And though the Spirits are tempered, they looe none of their ubtility, becaue they are not mingled with the Air. From the Plexus Mirabilis, blood acends by the Arteries which pring from the aid Plexus unto the Crown of the Head, where the blood Channels of the brain are Scituate. From whence it ditils into the lower and ide Parts of the brain, and alo by that ame great Vein mentioned by Galen, which makes the Plexus Choroides, it is ditributed into the inferior Parts.

And therefore in bleedings of the Noe, the mot pure blood does alwaies comeWhat Blood comes away in the Noe bleeding. away, whereas that which is taken away by opening the Veins of the Arms or feet, eems alwaies mot impure.

Whereby you may know, that it is only the Arterial blood which nourihes the brain and which comes away by the bleeding at Noe: and it was not without Caue that Fernelius would have it topped, after it had bleed a pound, to coole the body and extinguih the Feaver. And therefore refrigerating and atringent Medicaments are to be applied, not only to the hinder Part of the Neck, but alo before upon th Carotick or leepy Arteries.

You hal oberve that the Air drawn in by the Notrils, does not pas under, norWhether the Air goes which is drawa in at the Notrils? Whether it is mingled with the Spirits? enter into the foremot Ventricles of the brain, becaue they are void of any Inets, but being hed externally round about the Craa Meninx, it cools the Surface of the brain. Nor is it mingled with the Spirits, becaue they ought to be mot ubtile, otherwie by permition or mingling of the Air, they would become more thick and would not run o witly by the Nerves al the body over.
The ame I conceive touching the Air received into the Lungs; that it is not mixed with the vital Spirit but only cools the Lungs

Now that the brain may be demontrated after that manner, which Varolius decribesThe Manner of Diecting the brain and the Hitory of its Parts. in a particular Book: You hal aw in under the Scul of a body newly dead, round about near the Eyes, and the hollow of the hinder part of the Head, and with a pair of Piners you hal take of the upper portion of the Socket of the Eyes, that you may draw out the Eyes hanging at their Optick Nerves.

Afterwards having pulled the Dura T. 16. f. 1. A A. f. 2. D D. &c. T. 17. f. 1. A A. Meninx from the Scul round about with help of a Spatula, leave it at the Bais of the Scul, where it ticks exceeding fat to the Bones. Then you hal take out the Brain and as much of the Spinal Marrow as you can both at once, and let ome body hold the Brain turned upide down in both his hands whiles you hal diect it.

But you hal firt earch within the Dura Mater for thoe four bendings or T. 16. f. 5. a b c e. Hollownees, for the place of the f. 5. F. Pres, the great Vein decribed by Galen which makes the Plexus f. 5. f f. Choroides, and that diviion of the brain which reembles a f. 2. A A. f. 5. E E. Sickle: Afterwards returning to the Bais of the Brain, you hal oberve the Tenuis Meninx to be more eaily plucked and eparated in the lower than in the upper Part: becaue the Petty-Brain in its Bais or Bottom is not o ful of turnings, away, and windings, as on the top. And therefore the thick Meninx being firt taken we meet with that ame Rete Mirabite, or Miraculous T. 18. f. 3. P P P P. Net, made of Multitudes of
mal Arteries, pringing from the f. 3. C C. Carotick Arteries and two other f. 3. O O. acending through the holes of the Vertebraes of the Neck; but it will be torn, which cannot be prevented. Now each of the Carotick or Sleepy-Arteries enters within the Scul divided into two, to Weave that ame wonderful Net, and creeping upwards, through the windings of the brain it is dieminated up and down every way even as far as the Longitudinal Cavity of the Dura Meninx.

The Carotis is drawn obliquated and as it were crook backt, within that ame winding hole at the Bais of the Scul, and within its Cavity, containes certain very mal Bones, like thoe which are called Seamoidea.

Neither has Nature placed thee little bones only in thee Arteries, but he has likewie inerted them into other Arteries, where it was requiite, that they hould be kept open.
b T. 17. f. 2. I I.
Then you hal oberve that the Proceus T. 18. f 3. a a. Mammillares or Teat-like Productions do not run out o far as arolius has decribed them.

Then you hal ee the growing together of the T. 17. f. 1. T. Optick f. 1. S S. V V. Nerves near the Choana or Funnel. And therefore Maticatories may do good in the Dieaes thereof. Alo you hal oberve that the Veins of the Plexus f. 1. O O R R. Choroides decending to the Bais of the f. 1. P P. Brain, are interwoven with exceeding mal Kernels.
In that place the Plexus Choroides is more eaily dicerned, than upon the foremot Ventricles.

Afterward, you hal contemplate four tuberous Eminencies: two T. 16 f. 4. c c. before, cituate in the middle of the brain, and the other two f. 4. b b. behind, which contitute the Cerebellum, or petty Brain. Thoe Eminencies, or Riings, do receive four white and hard Roots of the Spinal Marrow, whereof the foremot, longet, and hardet, are drawn along between the greater Eminences of the Brain. The other two hort ones, are carried within the petty brain; which a thickened Portion of the Marrow of the aid petry-brain, placed athwart, as broad as a mans Thumb, does faten together like a Swath-band, and is by Varolius termed T. 18. f. 4. by C C C. Ponticulus: or rather it is the pavement of the Channel from the third, into the fourth Ventricle.

And the aid Channel lies above thoe foremot Roots of the Spinal Marrow, and is tretched out according to their longitude. Between the growing together of the Optick Nerves, and the foremot Roots of the Spinal Marrow, there appears a fourquate hole, which is taken for the f. 3. E. Choana, or Funnel, erving to dicharge the Excrements of the Ventricles of the Brain.

When you have viewed al thee things, you hal pas over unto the T. 16. f. 6. D D. T. 17. f. 2. A A. T. 18. f. 4. A A. Petty-brain, where you hal eparate from the Spinal Marrow the Proceus
T. 16. f. 6. E. T. 17. f. 2. C C. Vermiformis which lies between the two Tuberous Eminencies of the Petty-brain, by taking away the Membrana Choroides; that o you may ee the T. 17. f. 2. D D. &c. T. 18. f. 4. F. Chamber of the fourth Ventricle and the Citern of the Animal Spirits.

Then you hal cut a under T. 18. f. 4. by C C C. the little Bridg, or the Band of the Roots of the Spinal T. 18. f. 4. D D. Marrow, that the T. 16. f. 3. D D. E E. f. 4. C C. D D. &c. foremot and Superior Ventricles of the brain may appear, which you hal ee eparated by a partition T. 16. f. 3. G. as long as ones Finger, drawn from one End towards the Fore-head, as far as the Petty-brain: it cleaves to the T. 16. f. 3. b b. f. 4. B. T. 17. f. 1. F. G G. Arched Roofe of the Ventricles, but beneath it is looe, and free from al ties, that the paage of the Spirits might be free.

But you hal diligently note, that the Extremities of the aid partition are double forked: the hindermot bifurcation is longer than the foremot, and it cleaves unto that ame tranvere Ligament, which connects the two Tuberoities or bunchings out of the brain, and o being pread out like a beam it bears up the Vaulted Arch
of the Ventricles; the fore mot bifurcation cleaves unto a little tranvere cord, which reembles the Optick Nerve in thicknes and in Color.

The ame partition which is termed Septum
T. 16. f. 3. G. Lucidum, being pulled back, you hal manifetly decern the Vault of the Ventricles, which is called Corpus Palloides or Harpe fahioned body; alo you hal ee that the foremot Ventricles make but one continued Cavity.
k T. 16. f. 3. bb. f. 4. B. T. 17. f. 1. G G. F.

Mean while you hal oberve, that the inferior Ventricles placed at the Bais or bottom of the brain, are larger or at leat equal unto the uperior, and that the continuity of the uperior and inferior Ventricles is one and the ame: or rather that there are but two Ventricles which contain the whole brain. For the T. 17. f. 2. D D. T. 18. f. 4. F. fourth Ventricle lies concealed in the Petty-Brain, and is manifetly een to be wholly and only the • e.

Further you hal oberve that al the T. 18. f. 13. &c. Nerves even the Optick ones, do arie out of thoe ame Roots of the Spinal Marrow: and therefore al the Nerves in the body do arie out of the Spinal Marrow, within or without the brain.

For if thoe Prominencies, which are termed by Galen the beds of the Optick Nerves, are productions of the Roots of the Spinal Marrow within the brain: we may with good reaon aver, that the Optick nerves chemelves do pring from the Spinal Marrow.

Finally you hal ee that the moving Nerves that give motion to the Eyes, are continued, and make one Cord as it were: and that the Optick Nerves being bowed or turned back near the beds of the Optick Nerves, do acend unto the foremot Ventricles.

You hal likwie ee that the Tetes or Stones are T. 16. f. 4. c c. portions of the Roots of the Spinal Marrow, growing out of the brain: and the Nates or T. 16. f. 4. b b. buttocks are portions of thoe Roots which are derived from the Petty-brain.

And if you hal compare this my decription of the Parts which are to be een in the brain turned upide down, beginning from the bais, with that of Varolius, you wil find it larger and different from his. And he that wil take pains to do as much, after he has once or twice een me demontrate thee things, he wil acknowledg the truth of them with admiration.

Now that in the brain the Dieaes & Symptomes thereof, may be ditinguihed as much as may be by their proper places, the whol bulk of the brain mut be divided into three Parts, viz. The T. 16 f. 1. b b. brain properly o called, the Petty-brainT. 16. f. 6. D D. &c. T. 17. f. 2. A A. &c. and the f. 2. l l. T. 18. f. 4. D D. Marrow of the back.

But I divide the brain, as it is the ubject of diection into three Regions, theThe Parts of the Supreme Region. uppermot, the Middlemot, and the Lowet. In the uppermot you hal oberve the Turnings and Windings of the brain, the f. 2 A A. f. 5. E E. Sickle, and the Corpus f. 2. B B. f. 3. B B Calloum.

In the Middlemot which is beneath the f. 3. b b. f. 4. B. T. 17. f. 1. F G G. Vault, you hal oberve the ArchedOf the Middle Region. eeling of the aid Vault, being the Roof which is placed over the Ventricles; the Partition-Wal, born up by T. 16. f. 3. G. three Pillars; three f. 3. D E. f 4. C D. &c. f. 4. E. Ventricles with certain f. • . b b c c &c. Eminencies, which make up a Channel to the fourth Ventricle.

And then you hal oberve the Plexus
f. 5. & 6. f f. T. 17. f. 1. O O R R. Choroides, the T. 16. f. 4. a. T. 17. f. 1. L. Conarium, and the T. 16. f. 6. D D. T. 17. f. 2. A A. &c. Petty-brain, and the f. 2. D D. G G. T. 18. f. 4. F. fourth Ventricle therein concealed.

In the lowet Region, you hal mark the T. 18. f. 3. E. Choana, or Funnel, the Glandula, Of the lowet Region. or T. 18. f. 3. D. &c. Kernel; the Mammillary, or Teat-like f. 3. a a. Productions; the • even f. 3. B G H •
• L M. f. 1. B C D E F G. Pair of Nerves; the f. 3. P P P P. Re • e Mirable, or wonderful Net; and the Roots of the Spinal f. 4. D D. &c. Marrow.

And foramuch as Casparus Hofmannus, in his Book againt Montanus, and in his Intitutions, cals thoe Men Fools and Blockheads, who • uppoe that the Ventricles of the Brain, are the Shops, or Work-Houes where the Spirits are made; and o confidently, and arrogantly avers it to be impoible, that he accounts it a great Crime or Madnes to think otherwie: I hal briefly examine his, by him uppoed invincible Arguments, becaue no man has yet had the Courage to contradict them: only I hal in the firt place demontrate the contrary to be true.
