The Animal Spirit is made of the Vital, which is continually brought in greatThe place where the Animal Spirits are made according to our Auth • r. quantity, by the Carotick Arteries to the Bais of the Brain, where the branches meeting, and being woven together, do make the Rete Mirabile, from which innumerable branches are derived into the Craa Meninx; that the blood may a • cend on every hand to thoe blood-channels of the Dura Mater, which I co • ceive does alone palpitate, or pant; and I have een in Fractures of the Skul, that when that Membrane is broken, the brain remains immovable.

Seeing therefore the foremot Ventricles are opened in the Bais of Brain, and equal in their widnes to the upper Cavities of the aid Ventricles, and are cloe unto the Rete Mirabile, from it the Ventricles draw their Spirits, or the Spirits exhaling from that Texture, whoe Arter • es are exceeding tender and thin, they are brought along into the • oremot Ventricles; and oon after, by the third Ventricle which erves intead of a Channel or paage, they are forthwith carried by a treight coure into the fourth Ventricle, the Citern, or Conduit Head of Spirits; that from thence they may be ditribu • ed into the inferior Nerves, and into the Cavity of the Spinal Marrow.

But the even Pair of Nerves are propagated from thoe four Eminencies; of which the two greater do form, and encloe the ides of the foremot Ventricles; the other two make the ides of the fourth Ventricle, whoe Roof, and fore, and after parts, are made up by the double Apophyis Scolicoides.
Thoe four Eminencies are Spongy, and receive Spirits, which run directly into the Nerves of the Spinal Marrow by the • ourth Ventricle.

And no man can deny that the Nerves of • he brain are the off-prings of thoe four Eminencies: and o this Propoition is to be interpreted. All Nerves of the Body and Brain, do spring from the Spinal Marrow, either within, or without the brain.

I deny not that the Spirits are diffued through the whol ubtance of the brain, and not wholly contained in the Ventricles: but I aver that the Ventricles are the true Shops, or Work-Hou • es of • he Animal Spirit, which is ditributed unto the even Couple of Nerves, and to the Spinal Marrow.
That this is ab • u • d and impoible, Hofm • n does thus eek to prove:

div.head: 1. Arg.

p.hi: There is the Spirit made, where the Action is performed.

div.p:
I Anwer, many Actions are performed in parts, in which no Spirits are bred:The Arguments of Ho •
man to the contrary, anwered. and I deny that in the Body of the Brain, al Actions are performed. Again, there needs no other elaboration than their paage through the brain: for as the blood of the Veins, paing through the Hearts Ventricles, is in a moment made Vital; o the Vital Spirits running through the middle of the Brain, as far as the Ventricle, do become Animal.
For if it were needful that the Animal Spirit hould be elaborated in the Subtance of the Brain, it would loe much of its • ubtilty, becaue the brain is cold and moit.

div.head: 2d Arg. of Hofman. If the Spirit be to act, it mut needs be under the command of the Soul in the Veels; for after that it is entered into the Sea of the Ve • tricles, what is there to compel the ame to return into the tra • t paages of the Ne • ves?
div.p:
I • n • wer: If the Spirit be diff •• ed into the whol ubtance of the brain, being really oft as Wax, how can it return into the Nerves, eeing there are no Veels running through the • ubtance of the brain? Thoe bloody marks wherewith it is prin
•• ed, are poin • s of blood dropping down from above, out of the Arteries which runs between the winding ubtance of the brain. The great Providence of Nature, becaue the blood could not pie • ce, nor pas through the midt of the Subtance of the brain, hath carried the ame through the Channels of the Dura Mater, as far as the •• ood paages, whence •• lides into the •• ferior parts, and by the Pres, o • that great Vein which Conti • utes the Plexus Choroides, it •• ows into the Ven
• ricles.

More probable it were to aign the Seat, and Shop of the Animal Spirits in the Plexus Choroides, which is diffu • ed through al the Cavities of the brain, as far as the ba •• s thereof. But hew me (friend Hofman) the way by which the Animal Spirits made of the Vital, may be diffued into the ubtance of the brain, o as to flow back into the Nerves.

div.head: 3d Arg. The Ventricles are urrounded within, with the Pia Mater, which • inders the ingres and regre • of the Spirits.
div.p: I Anwer: If the Ventricles have for their Covering, the thin Meninx, the paage is thereby the a • er into the foremot Ventricles, without any los at all. I have already demontrated in an Entrance in the bais of the brain, being the way into the fourth Ventricle; there is no need of a reg • es for Arterial blood, which acends upwards by the Craa Meninx, ditilling into the brain, does on al ides afford Spirits to the whol brain; neither can the blood penetrate without Spirits.

div.head: 4. Arg. Hofmans tronget Argument is this: Seeing the two uperior Ventricles, open into the third, and that into the Funnel, and it into the Pallate, who will be Su • ety, that the Spirits will not ma • e their ecape this way?
div.p: I Anwer: This danger is eaily hunned by the continual flux and pule, or driving of the Spirits to the Ci •• ern; and that ame hole is exceeding mal, and o deep, even to the O • Sphen •• des, that it can equal the length of a mans ••• ger.

You who beleeve that the blood paes from the Right Ventricle of the Heart, through the Lungs, that it may return into the Left, are you not afraid let we hould loe our vital Spirits, when we blow ou • breath out in Repiration?

div.head: 5. Arg. The Ventricles are not continued with the Nerves, but with the whol Body.
div.p: I Anwer: If the Nerves proceed from thoe ame Eminencies, which are Roots o • the Spinal Marrow, between the Brain, and the Petty-brain, and they are principal portions of the Brain; do not the Nerves arie from the brain it elf? But you your elf have often times written, that the Nerves arie within the brain, from the • oots of the Spi • al Marrow.

div.head: 6. Arg. The Ventricles have now another Office, which cannot tand with that of the Spirits.
div.p: I Anwer: That I deny any uch Office. For the Choana, or Funnel, can p •• ge away any wheyih Excrements which hal be in the Ventricles; but the greatet part, flowing down by the external windings of the brain unto the bais, fals partly into the Os Ethmoides, or Colanderbone, partly it decends to the bais of the brain; and if not by the Choana, yet by other holes neer abouts, it is purged into the Pa •• ate.

But becaue Hofmans Spirits fail him in • andling this Qu • tion (can you forbear laughing) for they are his own words, we hal alo leave him to enjoy his elf-love, with a great flock of bleating Animals (o he aies) which follows his aburd Opinion, provided that he be the Bel-weather. Let him no more triumph before the Victory, nor let him be o ecure and undaunted, as not to fear Hercules himelf.

That ame new Tenent of Hofman, diturbs the whol Doctrine of Dieaes of theHofmans Tenent diturbs the •• actice of Phyick. Brain and that I may declare o much, I wil chue out only two Dieaes, which have their Seat in the Ventricles, viz. The Epilepie, and Apoplexy.

The Apoplexy he makes to be in the whol Subtance of the brain, not in the Ventricles: The Epilepie, he wil have to be caued only by vapors acending into the Head, and di •••• ed through the whol ubtance of the brain. He allows of no Epilepie from a primary affection of the Head, but only by Sympathy from other parts.

He aigns the Seat of the Apoplexy to be in the whol ubtance of the brain obtructed, and avers that it is caued only by blood hed forth of the Veins; and makes the Caue thereof to be the obtruction of the Pres introduced by Nymmanus. But if the Torcular, or Pres is obtructed, which is the fourth Channel carrying blood into the Plexus Choroides, the paage of the blood and Spirits is intercepted. But according to Hofman in an Apoplexy, only blood is found hed out of the veins within the Ventricles, and therefore the To • cular was not obtructed.

It is a certain, and undoubted thing confirmed by many Experiments, that in the Apoplexy, the Ventricles of the brain are obtructed, or there is an obtruction in the Choana, or Funnel. But epecially the hole of the fourth ventricle which is hut with the Apophyis Scolicoides, is topped by thick and clammy Flegm ticking there; which if it be not dicued, or removed, being evacuated through the Funnel, it caue • death.

If the Matter be erous, and pas into the Spinal Marrow, it caues the Palie intead of the Apoplexy; and o a greater Di • eae is cured by a leer, the matter being tranlated from one place to another. But if blood happen to be hed into the ventricles, preent death follows.

But if • o be the Apoplexy hould be produced by blood alone, as Hofman will have it; how could blood which was hed into the ventricles, pas into the Nerves without putre • action, and how could it enter into the Cavities of the Nerves?

In thee two Dieaes he hath be • rayed his own Ignorance, although he could find no uch difficulty in the falling icknes, as Cra • o acknowledged, whoe Wih was this: Would to God I could ee before I die, the Eence of this Dieae, together with the Cure thereof rightly explained.

div.head: The Medicinal Conideration.
div.p:
The brain is exercied with many kinds of Dieaes, with an hot, cold, moit Ditemper;Principal di
•• es of the Brain. Ditemper. with divers Humors, Flegmatick, Cholerick, Melanchollick, Sanguine, and Wheyih; which either do mo • et the Membranes of the brain, epecially the Craa Meninx, or are diffued into the Channels thereof, and being there topped of their coure, they caue mot acu • e pains: or they lide into the exterior windings of the • rain, and by little and little, they ditil into the ubtance of the brain, and the ventricles thereof; or into the hinder part of the Head, or the Petty-brain; or they decend into the lowet parts of the brain.

If the Humor acend by the Carotick Arteries unto the brain, it may produce the ame Dieaes; now al Dieaes that are caued by conent, or ympathy, withou • matter, only by evaporation, are not o dangerous, as if they were bred within the brain, o as that the morbi • ick Matter hould be therein contained.

The brain, beides imilar Dieaes in Ditemper, and Laxity, uffers alo DieaesObtruction of th • Cavities. in Conformation, when as, according to the motion of the Moon, its bulk is encreaed,
or diminihed; in the Diorder of its Paages, when the Channels of the Dura Meninx are obtructed, epecially the fourth, which is called Tor • ular, or the Pres: which being obtructed, is thought to caue the Apoplexy, the paage of the Spirits to and • ro being intercepted. Which I do not beleeve, becaue the Spirits are hed abroad into the inferior Veels from that admi • able Net of A •• e
•• es, called Rete mirabile, and that ame Cavity being topped, only the Plexus Choroides, being defrauded of its blood, is hurt.

The Ventricles are alo obtructed, epecially the fourth, which being • opped,Of the Ventricles. preent death follows, by reaon of the toppage of that continual influx of Spirits, which ought to be into the inferior parts, and the Marrow of the back.

The Choana may likewie be obtructed, which intercepts the Efflux of erousOf the Choana
••
• u ••••
and Flegma • ick Humors, whereby flowing back into the brain, they may caue the Epiep •• e, or Apoplexy, and induce divers deadly Dieaes.
If the anterior, or foremot ventricles, are perforated into the Notrils, the obtructions of thoe paages, wil be very • u •• ful to the brain.
A fault of evil Conformation, cannot be amended exactly: by trengthening, and drying the brain, both the fore-mentioned may be helped.
The brain is Inflamed, not only the Meninges, or Coats, but omtimes alo in theSiriais. proper ubtance thereof; whence comes the Phrenzy, and Siriais, or Dog day madnes; but not any Paraphrenitis.

Siriais is termed from the Dog-Star; for in the Dog-Daies chiefly, it afflictsFrenzy. both Boys, and elder perons; and therfore it comes rather from an ex • ernal Caue, as long abiding in the Sun, &c. than from any internal Caue: as a Phrenzy comes only from an internal Caue, whether it be Primary, or Secondary, by conent of other parts in a burning Feaver.

The brain may likewie wel, by reaon of a Commotion thereof from ome internalTumors. Caue, it is called Ecplexis. Stupidity of the Head after a blow, is a bad ign, according to Hippocrates. At length thee Dieaes bring a Sphacelim in the brain, cauing putrefaction, corruption, and mortiication.

Again, it is ubject to a wa • ry Tumor, either in its Circumference, or within the Ventricles. If in its Circumference it is termed Hydrocephalos, or the Water-Head; and at length the wheyih Humor lipping by little and little, within the Ventricles, caues the leepy Dieae, and after it the Apoplexy.
And thee I take to be Dieaes of the brain; however Fernelius has written, that al the Diorders of the Head, which have been oberved by Experience, are ymp • omes, and not Dieaes.

But he elegantly, according to his wonted fahion, does divide the Symptomes Symptomes of the bra • n. Or Membranes. into three Ranks, with reference to the parts affected. Some poes the Membranes; ome the Subtance of the Brain; and ome the hollow Paages.

In the Pericranium, and Meninges, Pains are caued. In the Subtance of the Brain, which is the Seat of the Animal chief Faculties, are contained the Symptomes of Fancy and Reaon depraved, uch as are, Dotage, Melancholly, Ectaies, Lyncanthropy, Madnes. Alo the Symptomes of Memory abolihed, uch as are Forgetfulnes, Foolihnes, Doltihnes, and blockihnes. Symptomes coniting Or in the Cavities, and paages. in the Cavities, and paages, are very many, appertaining to Sence and Motion; and to leeping and waking, as dead leep, leeping Trance. Symp • omes of Motion are, Walking in ones leep; to be taken tiff, as it were blated, or Planet-truck; the Night-Mare, Convulion, Falling-icknes, Unquietnes, and tumbling, S • ivering, Shaking, Trembling, Palies, Feeblenes of the Limbs, and Apoplexy.

Symptomes in the undue proportion of what hould be voided forth, do belongSymptomes of the Membranes Pain. to the paages and Cavities, as a Ca • arrh, Rbeumatimus, Bleeding at Noe. All thee Symptomes • foreaid, I wil now declare particularly.

The Head-ach, either occupies the Pericranium, or the Meninges; if the Pericranium, the pain is outwards; if the Meninges, the pain is inward. Each of thee pains reaches unto the Eyes; becaue the internal Membranes do produce the Coats of the Eye, called Cornea, and vea; and the Pericranium produces the Coat Conjunctiva.

The kind of the Pain hews the Nature of the Dieae. A harp and biting pain does argue a Cholerick Ditemper of the Head: a heavy preing pain, hews a Flegmatick Ditemper: a panting, or puling pain, argues omwhat of an Inflamation: A pricking pain hews an Eroion, or gnawing, caued by a harp Humor, or a Worm which is rare. A tretching pain, argues abundance of Humor, or of windy Spirits, which ditend the Membranes.

Now the Pain is either in the whol Head, or in the half, or in ome one particle thereof. If it infet the whol Head, it is called Cephalalgia: if half the Head, Hemicrania, becaue the brain is divided into two parts: If the pain poes one part, as if a Nail were driven in there, the Arabians call it Clavus, and Ovum; the Nail, or Egg. If the pain of the Head, be of long Continuance, it is termed Cephalaea; which together with the Hemicrania, is periodical; but the Cephalalgia is a continual univeral Head-ach.
A continual Pain of the Head joyned with a continual Feaver, and igns of malignity, is exceeding dangerous, according to Hippocrates in the Second of his Prognoticks.
Pains of the Head are, Primary, and Proper; or Secundary, and by Sympathy from other parts: Thee are not o dangerous as the former.

The Principal Actions of the Brain, Imagination, Ratiocination, and Memory,Symptomes of the Subtance of the brain. are diminihed, depraved, and abolihed. Depravation of the Fantaie and Reaon, is Raving; the Imminution thereof is Foolihnes.
There is a three-fold Hurt of the Memory; but the Abolition thereof has only found a name, being called Oblivion.
The Caue of Foolihnes, is every great ditemper of the brain, which is knownFoolihnes. by its Caues, as by igns; or ome ill haping of the Head, which is eaily dicerned.

Dotage, or Raving, conits in aburd Thoughts, Words, or Deeds. The SayingsDotage. of uch as rave, are etranged from Truth and Reaon, or not to the point in hand; their Deeds are either unuual, or undecent; their Thoughts are aburd, ridiculous, and Chymerical.

The manner of Raving, ought to be ditinguihed to know the differences of theMelancholy. Melancholly which caues the ame; for a Delirium, or raving with depravation of the Fanie, is termed Melancholly, which conits in a fale Opinion touching things pat, preent, and to come; which being manifold, it is defined by vain fear, anxiety, or orrow.

Again, Melancholly is either Primary, or Secondary: The Primary has its Original in the brain; the Secondary prings from the Hypochondriacal parts, whence it is termed Hypochondriaca Melancholia, which is either Humoral, or Flatulent: the former is the wore of the two, and brings at lat Madnes, and Out-ragiounes.

The Melancholy Ectaie, is an exces of Melancholy, which is three-fold: AnEctaie. Ectaie imply o called; an Ectaie with ilence; an Ectaie with a Frenzy: they are caued by black Choler, according to the divers degrees of its Adution:
Foolihnes with laughter is better and afer, than with eriounes and fiercenes. Raving without a Feaver, is o much the better by how much the Parts under the hort Ribs, or the Brain, are les heated.

The Reting, and binding up of the Sences, is Natural Sleep: The breaking off, or hindrance of leep, is Watching: Either of which being out of meaure, is hurtful.Coma, or Dead leep. If Sleep be profound, 'tis called Coma, or Carus, Dead-leep. If this Symptome be mixed of Sleep and Watching, o that the Patient eems to incline to leep, with his Eyes hut, but is not able to leep; it is termed Coma-Vigilans, the Drowzy Watch. But if one that has a leeping Dieae upon him, every time he is awakened, does rave, and talk idlely, the Dieae is called Typhomania.

And if a man lie tiff with his Eyes open, and when he comes to himelf, remembersThe Night-Mare. what was done about him, it is termed Incubus, the Mare; which is wont to
happen in the right to uch as lie upon their backs, or have glutted themelves with feating; and it eems that they are choaked, by ome Devil lying upon them, or by ome Theif that has laid hold upon them to Rob and Murther them.

The abolition of al ence and motion aving Repiration, is called Catalepis orCatalepis. Catoche: whereby a Man is Frozen as it were in that poture he was in when the fit eazed upon him. It prings from a Cold ditemper of the Brain with Flegm.
Carus is a deep Sleep, which comes upon Feavers and wounds of the temporalCarus. Mucles, or from an hot and moit ditemper, or from much evaporation with eroities, moitening the ubtance of the brain.

A Lethargy is an Imminution of ence and Motion and alo of the Memory ofA Lethargy. neceary things. It Springs from a Primary hot and moit ditemper of the brain, joyned with a putrid Humor which provoks a Feaver and cherihes and keepes it up a long time. There is alo Dotage adjoyned. Touching this Dieae there is a aying of Hyppocrates in his Coicks Page 75. Which explaines all the Symptomes thereof. The exitence or particular Nature of the Lethargy and Coma, conits in a loones, as that of the Catalepis in a Tenion or bending. Thoe that are in a Lethargick Sleep, at lat become Apoplectick.

An Apoplexy does oft times primarily and unexpectedly invade a Man, and omtimesAn Apoplexy. it followes ome other Sleepy dieae. It is an Abolition of ence and motion with repiration hurt, which at lat brings noring and uffocation, by reaon thick Flegm flowing out of the Funnel and obtructing the Larynx or Weand.

It is Caued by a Repletion of the Ventricles of the brain, either with a pituitous or Wheyih Humor, or with blood, ome mal Artery of the Rete Mirabile being broken in the Bais of the Brain, or blood being carried aloft in a Plethorick body by the fourth Channel, ruhes into the Ventricles.
If it be Simple and meer Whey, by trength of Nature out of the anterior Ventricles, it lips into the fourth Ventricle, and from thence into the Spinal Marrow and o Caues a Palie.
If it be a Flegmatick Humor topped in the fourth Ventricle, or in the third, it cannot be dicued, and the brain is overwhelmed thereby.
If the blood be hed out of the veels, it uddainly uffocates.
In the Carus or other Sleepy Dieae, only the foremot Ventricles of the brain, are overwhelmed with Seroities, o that there is yet freedom for the pirits to pas into all Parts of the body.
But in an Apoplexy, all the ventricles of the brain, but epecially the fourth, are obtructed, and unles the matter be dicued into the pinal Marrow Death fallows unavoidably.

Fernelius avouches that an Apoplexy is bred by an Obtructiou of that Rete Mirabile, the afflux of Arterial blood out of the Heart into the brain, being thereby intercepted. Therefore they are termed Carotides, becaue being obtructed they caue Carum or the Sleepy-Evil.

In the Apoplexy and Sleepy Dieaes, beides general Medicines, as blood-lettingCure of the Apoplexy, Carus and ucid like Dieaes. liberally twice or thrice repeted out of the Arm and foot; trong Purgation of watry Humors, Cupping-Glaes fixed unto the houlders and the hinder Part of the Head, Topical Remedies, are not be neglected, which draw and Evacuate near the Part affected; uch as is the opening of the Veins under the Tongue and of the external Jugular Vein, and likewie of the Temporal Artery: great Veicatories applied towards the top of the houlders to the Cephalick Vein, trong Medicines to provoke Sneezing, a Seton in the Neck, the tring being often drawn about and anointed with Oyl of Vitriol, that it may bite the more and attract: opening the Veins of the Noe after the manner ued by the Ancients, with a plit Toothed Quil thrut up as far as the bottom of the Colander: a harp injection into the Notrils
Notrils by a yring, and within the furrows placed between the paces of Os Vomeris: drawing out of the Flegmatick clammy matter which ticks in the Throat and tops the Larynx, but thruting a feather far into the throat: to which intent a trong vomit is good to cat forth any Humor that has flowed into the Wind-Pipe: neither mut we omit extream hard rubbings with alt, and continual tirring of the body, if it be poible.

All which remedies are to be applied with all poible peed one upon the Neck of another, in an Apoplexy, becaue there is danger in delay. In Sleepy Dieaes which proceed lowly, and are caued by matter falling down from the Parts above, they are more lowly adminitred, and without Precipitation.

You hal oberve alo, that a great Part of thee Humors is gathered together in the turnings & windings which are outmot in the upper ubtance of the brain, which do either putrifie there, or lip into the ventricles of the brain: and yet thee windings of the brain are not conidered.

The Palie is an Abolition of ence and motion, not in the whol body, as in the Apoplexy, but only in the greatet Part of the body, or in halfThe Palie. thereof, which is termed Hemiplegia, or in one Part, which is called Paraplegia.

Fernelius oberves, that ence is taken away, the motion remaining unhurt: and omtimes motion is taken away and the ence remains, becaue of the difference of the Nerves of the brain and the Spinal Marrow. In the Palie, the Nerves of the Spinal Marrow are obtructed, but thoe of the brain, not: and therefore many Parts remain unhurt, epecially the internal.
Somtimes the Palie happens without obtruction of the Nerves, becaue the otning and Humectation of the Nerves, brings a kind of Palie.

In an imperfect Palie when motion and ence are only dulled, the Dieae isStupor. termed Stupor or Nothrotis, which aries from a moit ditemper of the brain. A Stupidity or dulnes of ence and motion in a Feaver, is wont to foretel a leepy Dieae to follow. When it comes alone without Feaver, it foretels a Palie or an Apoplexy.

Vertigo, is a depravation of ence and motion, which makes the Patient thinkVertigo. that al things turn round: it prings from a windy Humor, which being agitated within the foremot Ventricles of the Brain, caues the foreaid Apprehenion of all things turning about. If it Caues a darknes before the Patients Eyes, it is called Vertigo Tenebricoa or Scotodinos. It aries from the Brain or from vapours acending from the inferior Parts. That is wort which aries primarily from the brain, and it is a fore-runner of the Falling Sicknes.

The convulion is a violent pulling back of the Mucles towards their Head orConvulion. beginning. It is threefold, Emprothotonos, when the body is bent foreward; Opithotonos, when the body is drawn backward: and Tetanos when both ides remain tif, by reaon of an equal bowing or tretching of the Mucles on both ides.

The Caue of a Convulion, is either an obtruction of the Nerves, or their being pricked by a harp Humor, or a dry ditemper, which dries the Nerves, and o makes them tif as a dried Lurtring; this is incurable. In one word, all Convulions are aid to arie either from too much emptynes, or over fulnes.

An Epilepie or Falling-icknes, is a Convulion of the whol body, coming byFalling-Sicknes. fits, and hurting the Mind and ences. It is caued by an obtruction of the foremot Ventricles of the brain, caued by an Abundance of harp Humors, either, Cholerick or Flegmatick. Either it comes from the brain Primarily affected, or from ome other Part ending Malignant Humors to the brain. If it proceed from the brain Primarily affected, it is the more dangerous: if by fault of the Spleen or ome other Bowel venemouly infected: the coming of the fits may
be foreeen and prevented. The former comes in a moment, the latter by degrees.

Fernelius, beides the Humor which is the common Caue, accounts the peculiar Caue to be a venemous Air or vapour, which is exceeding hurtful to the brain; and therefore he conceives, it mut be cured with pecificks and appropriate Remedies, as wel as thoe vulgar ones.

Trembling is a depravation of Motion through weaknes. It is caued by theTrembling. weaknes of the motive faculty and the bodies heavynes. So that look how much the motive faculty endeavours to lift up the Member, o much does the heavynes of the aid Member not ufficiently illutrated with pirits, pres it down again. And therefore it aries, from obtruction of the Nerves, or from their being over-much oftened, or from ome external Caue, as by anointing with Quick-ilver, or other Application thereof. There is a certain mixture of the Convulion and tremblings, which is called Spamo-Tromois.

Shivering and haking, are motions of the body, which happen in Feavers, andShivering and Shaking. they are forerunners of the fits of Agues, or of the Exacerbations of Feavers. They happen alo, to uch as have ripe Impotumes, when the Impotum is ready to break. And therefore Hippocrates oberves a threefold Shaking-fit; the one feaverih, the other Ulcerous, and the lat Symptomatical.

Unquietnes, Anxiety, tumbling and toing of the body this way and that way,Tumbling and Toing. called by the Greekes Ae; is a depravation of motion, which proceeds from a miaffection of the Stomach, by reaon of a harp Humor Nettling and Stinging the Nerves of the body, or the Membranes of the Back-bones Marrow. Which makes that the Sick cannot ret in one place or poture; but are forced every foot to change place and tumble here and there, and to change the poture of their Bodies.

Night-walking, ought to be reckoned among the Symptomes of motion depraved:Walking in ones Sleep. becaue it is not preformed by Judgment and Reaon, but by force of a Dieae, namely of harp Fumes which compel the Sick peron or the healthy to rie up and walk in their Sleep.

I proceed to the Irregularity of the Excrements. The proper excretion of theSymptomes of things voided forth. brain, is either an Exhalation of a thin Vapour by the eames of the Scul or the pores of the Skin, or it is an Efflux of a thick Humor by the Notrils and Palate of the Mouth. The Diproportion of this Excretion conits either in exces ot defect. That in defect has no Name, but it degenerates into a Caue of Dieaes of the brain, of which we have already poken.

The diproportion in Exces is various, either when blood does immoderatlyNoe bleeding. flow from the Noe, or by drops. Both which Symptomes are Malignant. The former decaies the bodies trength, by reaon of the los of blood and Spirits, the latter betokens a repletion of the Head, and a Vain endeavour of oppreed Nature, And therefore drops of Blood coming from the Noe, is bad in a Vaporous Feaver. both as a Caue, and as a Sign.

The diproportion in Excretion of a erous and Phlegmatick Humor, is manyfold.Catarrhs. Their general Name is a Catarrh, which is a ditillation of Humor from the Head into the Inferior Parts, from which Parts it receives divers Appellations. If it fal into the Notrils, it is called Coryza or Gravedo; if into the Throat Branchos, Hoarnes; if into the Mouth and Palate Ptyelimos, or the Spawle. And thee three orts of Catarrhs, are vulgarly comprehended under the Name of Rheum.

A Catarrh falling upon the outward Parts of the body is named Rheumatimus Rheumatimus or Rheumaticus affectus, the Rheumatick Pains. If it fal upon the Joynts it reembles the Gout, ave that it comes not by fits: wherefore an Eunuch may uffer upon the Rheumatick pains, but not the true Gout. See Galens Comment upon that Aphorime. Boys and Eunuchs are not troubled with the Gout.

Galen makes frequent mention of the Rheumatick Dieae, which was common at Rome, as it is with us in Paris: in his Second Book to Glauco: in his Book of Blood-letting, againt Eraitratus &c. This Dieae he cured by liberal Bloodletting. It is decribed by Hippocrates, in his Book of the internal Dieaes, under the Name of a Joynt-pain, which is wont to trouble young People more than Aged.
The other differences of Catarhs with Reference to the diverity of Parts on which they fal, are Vain. It uffices to know, that al Fluxions upon internal Parts, are called likewie Rheums.

The Caue of a Catarrh or Flux of Rheum, is a cold and moit ditemper, or an hot ditemper with an abundance of Humors working in the Veels, or without. Galen acknowledges both thee Caues, in his Comment upon the 24. Aphor. Of the third Book.
The latter Phyitians, following the Doctrin of the Arabians wil have the Humor which Caues the Catarrh, to be bred in the Head, only without the Veels, by reaon of Vapours acending.

Fernelius contends that the Conjunct Caue of a Catarrh, is a erous matter, collected under the Skin of the Head, without the Veels: and that the Antecedent Caue, is an Humor hut up in the Veins. If you deire to know more of this ubject, Read Fernelius, who wil give you abundant atisfaction.

div.head: Chap. 3. Of the Eyes.
div.p: BEcaue the Eye and the Ear may be demontrated without meddling toThe Eyes. diect the Face; I wil dipatch thee Parts, before I proceed unto the Countenance.

The Eye, the Intrument of the Sight, is the principal Part of the face, placedScituations. in the Fore-Part of the Head, to direct the Actions of the body, becaue al actions are directed forwards, by reaon of the Scituation of the Hands. Seeing it is anParts. Organical Part, made up of many Similar Parts; ome of thoe Parts are external and ome internal. The external are the T. 19. f. 1. Eye-lids, which are the Coverings of theThe Eye-lids. Eyes, wherewith they are covered, hut and opened. And therefore each Eyelid is movable, howbeit the motion is more evident in the upper Eye-lids, and is performed by help of Mucles, of which we hal treat in our fift Book containing the Hitory of Mucles. From whence the Reader may fetch what does appertain to the preent occaion.

The Eye-lid is made up, of the Skin, a Membrane and mucles. The MembraneIts Membrane. tretched out under the Skin, it produced from the Pericranium, which decending by the length of the Forehead unto the Eyes, is an underwofe for the Eyebrows, withal makes the conjunctive Coat of the Eye, which being fixed to the Brain of the Socket, detaines and binds the Eye in its Hole or Cavity.

The Extremities of al the Eye-lids, are terminated with a Cartilaginous orTarus. Gritle edging, which is called f. 1. C C. Tarus, whereupon one by one in a row are fatened the f. 1. beneath B. Hairs of the Eye-lids; which are born with us, and look how long they are at our Birth, the ame length they keep, during our whol life.
They eldom falt of by reaon of Sicknes, unles in a Malignant Whores-Pocks,Cilia. which mows down and makes wat of al the Hairs of the Body. Thee Hairs of the Eye-lids are termed Cilia.

The angular Extremities of the Eye-lids meeting together, are termed Anguli, Corners. the corners of the Eyes. The one is f. 1. by D. greater, towards the Noe; the other is f. 1. E. leer, towards the Temples.

In the Eye-lids by the greater Corners are oberved two little f. 1. d d. holes, which areTear-Spouts. termed Puncta Lachry malia, or the Tear-Spouts, becaue the uperfluous Humidities of the Eyes, or tears, do flow thither and Iue out of thoe Holes; which
Humidites to receive, the Glandula Lachrymalis or T. 19. f. 1. D. Tear-Kernel is ordained, being thrut into the little perforated bone, that the Humor might rather ditil through this Hole into the Notrils, than fal out upon the external Parts.

The upper Eye-lid has a Mucle that lifts it up termed therefore f. 1. A A. Levator orMucles. the Lifter, which aries from the bottom of the Orbita or Socket and being pred out upon the Mucle which lifts up the Eye, it is f. 1. B. widened into an Eye-lid, that when the Eye is lift up the Eyelid may therewith be raied.

The Muculus latus, or broad Mucle is common to the two Eye-lids; which being Circularly derived from the bony brim of the Socket, is pred out through both the Eye-lids, that it may erve to hut them both: and becaue it reaches in the upper Part as far as the Eye-brow it draws that likewie down, in a trong and cloe hutting of the Eye-lids. Unles any man wil contend, that there is a ditinct Mucle for that ue.

Now the Eye-brow is a Flehy Hillock, adorned with Hairs, which erves for aEye-brow. Penthoue to overhadow the Eyes; it is depreed by the Orbicular Mucle of the Eye-lids, and lifted up, by the frontal Mucle.

Thee things being oberved, the Eye-lids are cut away, and the Circular adheionParts of the Eye. Fat of the Conjunctive Coat unto the Eye; that the Eye may de viewed, which is compact and made into a round bal or Globe of the fat which is placed f. 2. A A. round about the ame, to top up the chinks and to make it more movable; and of ix Mucles for motion; and of Coats, Humors, Veins, Arteries and Nerves.

Before the Fat be removed, the two Glandules or Kernels are to be conidered inKernels. their Scituation, of which one is of the greatet moment, Viz. The Lachrymal or f. 1. D. Tear-Kernel; whoe ubtance you hal oberve to be Flehy, oft and mal; and its Scituation to be within a little bone, beneath the ame.
Then you hal look out the other Kernel which is wholly unlik the former, placed in the other f. 1. E. Corner; which is flat, White, and like other Kernels.

The Fat being carefully taken away, the T. 19. f. 2. B B B. ix Mucles preent themelves; in the invetigation whereof, we mut begin at the f. 3. F. f. 4. F. Trochleator, or the greater Oblique Mucle, Scituate at the greater f. 1. by D. Corner; and there we mut be careful to preerve the f. 3. G. pulley, being a little trong Gritle fatened to the bone, beneath and cloe by the Caruncula Lachrymalis or f. 1. D. Tear-pout; through which Gritle (like a Rope through a Pulley) the round Tendon of the Trochleator is drawn, and inerted into the upper Part of the Eye.

The other, Obliquus f. 3. and 4. E. Minor, mut be ought for in the inferior Part of the Socket, being rould back under the Eye, it is terminated by the leer f. 1. E. Corner. The other four, are right Mucles, whereof one f. 3. 4, 5. A. lifts up, and its oppoite f. 3. 4, 5. B. draws down; the remaining two draw towards the f. 3. 4, 5. C. D. Sides. They al take their original from the Cavity of the Socket, by the hole of the Optick Nerve, and each one is produced right forewards to the Conjunctiva.

Thee things being oberved, the Eye mut be pulled out, that the inward tructureTrue Coats. thereof may be made to appear: and in the firt place you hal oberve two true Coates of the Eyes, which are orbicular as the Eye it elf: the ret are imperfect coates: and before you cut aunder the Cornea or Horny-Coat, you hal take away the Nervous productions of the Mucles of the Eye, which ome would have to be a f. 5. a a a a. Coat, which is aburd.

You hal oberve that the Cornea or f. 6. A A. B B. Horny Coat is tranparent before, to erve
• Cornea. the ight, but behind and on the ides, it is dark.

Its thick f. 8. C C C. Subtance, is divided into little Skins, epecially on the fore-ide; when it is cut, preently the watery f. 9. D D. Humor Runs out, which is alo found Circumfued about the vea Tunica, or Grape-Skin q Coat, if the Cornea be divided in the hinder Part: this Humor cannot be topped, becaue it preently Occurs, fllowing out like Water.
l f. 2. C C.
p f. 7. A A. C C.

Afterwards you hal ee the T. 19. f. 7. A. C C. f. 8. B B B.
vea or Grape-Skin Coat, and its open hole,2 vea. Pupilla. Iris. which makes the f. 7. a. Pupilla or ight of the Eye; the external Face or Circle of the Pupilla is termed f. 5. b b. Iris, or the Rain-bow. The Circumference of the Pupilla is adorned with mal threds or little Fibres extended upon the Chrytalline Humor, which they retain in its Scituation.
The Pupilla, in Catts, is manifetly moved, in Men it is unmovable, unles it be omwhat lackened and traitned, by the Acces and Reces of ome extraordinary light.

Thee things being oberved, pour out the Humors, and you hal find the f. 9. A. Chritallin Humor overwhelmed in the Vitreous f. 9. C C. Humor, and then the interior f. 7. C C. Superficies of the vea Tunica wil appear black, and cleane; in Brute Beats it is varigated, beingtainted with Green Black and Sky-Color. Wherefore, when you are to demontrate the Eye, you hal have an Ox and a Sheeps-Eye in readynes, that you may compare them with the Eyes of Man-kind.
In the hinder Part of the vea you hal ee the Optick f. 3. I I. f. 4. K. f. 6. C. f. 8. D. Nerve fatened, and the Marrow thereof piercing within that Coate.

There are three Humors conteined in the Eye; the firt is the f. 9. D D. watry Humor,The three Humors of the Eyes. The Watry Chytallin. already run out, there remain two fatened together, the Chrytallin and the Vitreous. The Chrital is like a f. 9. A. Vetch, tranparent, and being placed upon letters in a Book, it makes them hew larger, as a pectacle is wont to do. There is a Membrane attributed thereunto, termed f. 9. within A. B. a Circle Chrytalloides. Hippocrates aies that in living Creatures it Runs like Water, or is more liquid at leat.

The Chritallin Humor being pulled out, there remaines the m Vitreous Humor,The Glaie. being compacted and not running about, by means of the Reticularis Tunica, or f. 8. A A. Net-like Coat Interwoven: which being T. 19. f. 8. a a. cut aunder, by frequent chopping of the Pen-Knife thereupon, it becomes Liquid and runs about, the threddy Fibres being cut in under.
The Veins and Arteries which accompany the Optick Nerve unto the Eye, areTheir Veels. more eaily oberved within the Brain, than in the Eye after it is pulled out.

Neither is the motive Nerve o eaily detected being dipered among the Mucles, as it is within the Brain, while you oberve its progres, even to the very Eye-hole.
d f. 7. B B. f. 9. B B.

div.head: The Medicinal Conideration.
div.p:
Although the Eye be but a mal Part of the body, yet is there no Part aflictedThere are diuers Dieaes •… e Eyes. and detroyed with more Dieaes. And therefore the ancient Phyitians, when they had diligently examined the tructure thereof, they oberved o many and o
divers diorders in its Parts, as did amount to about one hundred and twenty, partly Dieaes, and partly Symptomes, and ditinguihed them by their Proper Names; which in other Parts they did not do. And Rome and Alexandria had Phyitians that attended only the Cure of the Eyes. In imitation of them I hallOf which ome are general of the whol Eye. a •
declare the dipoition againt Nature happening to the Eyes. And becaue mot of the Names are Greek, few of them Latin, and our Chyrurgeons ue them: after the example of Leonardus Fuchius in his Medicinal Intitutions, I wil retain and ue them as Latin Names.

An Arabian Phyition, Haly by Name, has writ a Book by it elf of Dieaes of the Eyes: and there is a coniderable French Book of the ame Argument written by Jacobus Guillemeau the Kings Chyrurgeon: unto which you may add if you pleae the Author of Medicinal Definitions: the Book of Galen touching the differences and Caues of Symptomes; and a batard Book de Oculis attributed to him.
The Eye therefore is afflicted either by being encreaed, or diminihed in itsDieaes of Magnitude. Quantity.
The Eye is diminihed, when it conumes for want of nourihment: its Magnitude is augmented when it wels without the Eye-hole or Socket.

Its Scituation is changed, when it fals without the Eye-hole, which Dieae isOf Scituation. termed Ecpiemos: or if it turn to one ide or another, as in Squint-Eyed People, and in him that aw through his notrils and was therefore called Rhinoptis.
There ought to be two Eyes: and therefore he that wants one, is dieaed inNumber. Number, and is called Monoculus.

Furthermore the Eye is troubled by an hot and a cold Ditemper and by inflamationDitemper &c. of the whol body, which by putrefaction of the Humors is turned into an Impotume. It is omtimes Ulcerated, whence the Eye becomes poiled and the ight diminihed.

And in cae an Inflamation of the whol Eye turn to Suppuration, which is called Hypopyon, and tranparent matter be collected under the Cornea Tunica, hewing that the other Humors are not putrified, there is hopes the Patient may recover ight, the quittor being let out, by pricking the Cornea: which is happily practied at Paris; and o with the Quittor a watery Humor is let out, as in the couching of a Cataract.

Beides thee general Dieaes, al the Parts whereof the Eye is made up, have
• Special Dieaes of other Parts. their Dieaes and Symptomes, which I will particularly and briefly explain, beginning at the Eye-Lids.

A moit ditemper of the Eye-Lids with wind, or a flatulent Spirit, is called Emphyema. With much Wheyih Humors, its termed Hydatis, and by Celus Veica, and Aquula, which does o load and depres the upper Eye-Lid, that it cannot be lifted up.
An hot ditemper of the Eye-Lid, Joyned with a thick Humor, is cald Sclerophthalmia, Sclerophthalmia. Xerophthalmia. Porophthalima Hard-eyednes.
A dry ditemper without Humors, is Xerophthalmia: if it caue Itching, Porophthalmia. Unto which may be referred the Phthiriais, or Lowie-Evil of the Eye lid.
If the aid aid hot and dry ditemper Joyned with a harp Humor, do caue Rednes, pain, and falling of the Hairs, it is called Ptilois, Milphois, or Madarrhois. Ptilois

If it make the Inide of the Eye-Lid rough its called, Tracoma: which if it beTracoma Sycois. Tulois. Crithe Chalaion •
great, o as to reemble the mal Seeds that are in Figs, its cald Sycois; if it be hard and of long Continuance, its Name is Tulois.
A little Tumor upon the upper Eye-Lid pringing from a thick Homor, is called Crithe, the Barly-Corn. If it be greater and movable, becaue of its likenes to hail, it called Chalaion, the Hail-Stone.

A Dieae of the Eye-Lids in Contiguity is, when the Eye-Lids tick unto theAnchiloblepharon. Coat of the Eye, or to one another, which Dieae is called Anchiloblepharon: the caue whereof is an exulceration of the Coat or the Eyes, or the Eye Lids: the exulceration being caued by an hot and dry ditemper, with a harp Humor.

Lagophthalmia is a Convulion of the upper Eye-Lid, or a drawing back thereofLagophthalmia Ippos. by reaon of a Cicatrice or ome eam. Ippos is the trembling of the aid Eye-Lid: both thee Symptomes come by Conent of the Brain affected and therefore they are dangerous.
Ectropion, Inverion, is a Dieae of the lower Eye-lid in Scituation of Figure:Ectropion. it is caued by a Scar without, or by an excrecence of internal Fleh.

Chalais, or the loolnes of the Eye-Lid, is caued either by a Palie, throughChalais. conent with the Nerves of the Brain, or by a moit ditemper of the Eye-Lid: in both caes the Hairs are turned inwards.

The generation of the Hairs of the Eye-Lids being depraved, is called Trichiais, &Trichiais. Dytichiais. it is twofold: when more are bredthan ordinary, its called Dytichiais, when there is a row of Hairs more than uual. But when the natural Hairs are only longer and inverted, tis caled Phalangois: in both thee, the Hairs prick the Eyes: tis cauedPhalangois. by a moit ditemper of the EyeLids, with much Humor which is not harp.

div.head: Tear-Kernels Dieaes.
div.p: The Caruncle or little bit of Fleh in the greater corner of the Eye, makes a TumorEuchantis. againt Nature, which is called Euchantis: the Diminution of the aid Caruncle is termed Rhyas, which caues a dropping of moiture from theRhyas. Eye.

Near the aid Caruncle and the Noe, there breeds an Impotum through Inflamation, which is called Anchylops: which being broken and turned into a Fitula isAnchylops Aegylops. termed Aegylops. The Dieaes of the Mucles of the Eyes, as ditempers, Laxity and olution of Continuity, are ditinguihed by the Names of the Repective Symptomes.

div.head: Dieaes of the Tunica Conjunctiva.
div.p: The hot ditemper of the Conjunctive Coat with Humor as blood or Choler, if it be light and proceeding from an external caue, as the wind or dut, or a blow, isTaraxis. called Taraxis.

But if it pring from an internal caue as a Plethora or Cacochymia, it is termed Opththalmia. When it is but beginning, it is called Epiphora; which is a NameOphthalmia. Epiphora common to an Inflamation and fluxion.

And if the Inflamation be very great, o that it hinders the coming together of the Eye-Lids, and poiles their Evennes, o that the white of the Eye becomes higher than the Iris and Pupilla, it is called Chemois, as much as to ayChemois. Hypophagma Hiatus.

Hypophagma is a collection of Blood under the Adnata Tunica, or an effuion of blood out of the Capillary Veins into the Adnata, proceeding from a blow or bruie. There is a Dieae of Number, in the Tunica Adnata, called Pterygium: Pterygium and it is a certain Membranons Eminency reaching from the greater corner of the Eye to the Pupilla; or a certain hard knob of the Adnata it elf: both pringing from a moit ditemper Joyned with a clammy Humor.Phlyctena.
Phlyctena, is a putle or mal Tumor of the Adnata or the neighboring Cornea, proceeding from a thick and harp Tumor, o that it terminates in an Ulcer.Botrion. Epicauma.

And if it be hollow, it is called Botrion, or Foula; if it be become cruty tis named Epicauma. After the Ulcer follows a Scar, which is the Hardnes and thicknes of a Spermatick Part pringing from a wound or Ulcer.

div.head: Dieaes of the Cornea Tunica.
div.p: The Ulcers and Scars of the Cornea Tunica, have a great reemblance with theCheloma. Dieaes of the Adnata, in regard of neighborhood: yet are they ditinguihed, becaue the Ulcers and Scars in the black of the Eye, that is, in the tranparent Part of the Cornea, belong only to the Cornea: uch as is the Cheloma, which is a broad Ulcer of the Cornea, about the Iris.
Argemon, is a round Whitih Ulcer of the Cornea towards the Circle of theArgemon. Iris.

Scars in the Black of the Eye, or in the Tranparent Part of the Cornea, do differAlbugo. in the degrees of more or les. The greater Scar of the Cornea, about the Iris or Pupilla, becaue of its whitenes is called Leucoma and Albugo: if it be mal it is termed Nephelion or Nebula, the Cloud: if the Scar be thin, its calledNebula. Caligo. Achlys, Caligo, a Mit or Darknes.

div.head: Dieaes of the Uvea Tunica.
div.p:
The rupture and Exulceration of the Cornea, is attended by a Dieae of theProptois.
vea in Scituation, which is called Proptois, Procidentia, when the vea ticks out above the Cornea.

If the Extuberance of the vea be mal, its called Myocephalon or the Flie-Head,Myocephalon Staphyloma Melon Clavus. becaue it reembles the Head of a Flie: if it be great, tis termed Staphyloma, becaue it reembles a Grap-Stone, or Melon as being like an Apple. If their be an inveterate Ulcer of the Cornea through which the vea fals out, its called Elos, Clavus, the Nail.
The Ulcers of the Cornea and Adnata, if they be Malignant are termed Carcinomata.

div.head: Dieaes of the Pupilla.
div.p: The hole of the vea is termed Pupilla the Apple of the Eye. Between the Pupilla and Cornea there is a pace, ful of Spirit and Watry Humor.

There is a double Dieae of that pace: Zinifiis, pringing from a dry ditemper,Zinifiis. which conumes the Watry Humor and Diipates the Spirit; or from a wound, which lets out the Watry Humor, and uffers the Spirit to vanih and reek away.

The other Dieae of the pace, is an Obtruction from a corrupted Flegmatick or purulent Humor. If it proceed of a purulent Humor or Quittor, it is calledHypopium. Suffuio. Hypopium: if the Obtruction be caued by Flegm, its termed Hypochyma Suffuio. But Hypopium followes an Inflamation, and Hypochyma is caued for the mot Part by a Congetion or Concretion of a thick Humor: if the Dieae be proper or primary, and do not arie by conent from the Stomath, ending Vapors up into the Eye.

p.U: aw a thick and perfect Suffuion bred in one daies time; for if a thick Humor uddenly falling into the Optick Nerve do blind a man in a moment: why may not the ame Humor falling lower into the Pupilla, breed a udden and perfect Suffuion?

div.p: The narrownes of the Pupilla, prings either from the firt formation in theCorrugatio. Womb; or from a dry ditemper, and then it is called Phthiis or Corrugatio.
Galen writes that a mal Pupilla from from ones Birth is occaion of a very harp ight but when it happnes a whil after, tis bad. In his firt Book of the Caues of Symptomes. Chap. 2.
The Dilatation of the Pupilla is called Mydriais or Platu-Corie. It pringsMydriais. from a moit ditemper, or from a Rupture, or by breach of Continuity caued by a blow.

div.head: Dieaes of the Chrytallin and Glaie Humor.
div.p: Dieaes of the Vitreous and Chrytallin Humors, are either a ditemper impleDitemper or with Humors conjoyned; or uch as happen in the conitence of the aid Humors, viz. Thicknes and hardnes. The ditemper of the Humors and Coats of the Eye, if it happen without a Tumor or an Ulcer, is commonly attributed to the weaknes of the Faculty, and the quality and quantity of the pirits being miaffected: but neither of thee is a Dieae; they are rather effects of a Dieae: for what is the weaknes of a faculty other than Actio laea, the action hurt.
Thicknes of the Spirits is caued by a cold and moit ditemperature, either properThinnes of the Spirits. Their Paucity to the Eye, or by conent with the brain or ome inferior Parts.

Paucity of Spirits comes from a dry ditemper, either of the Eye or the brain: the Caue and fomenter of which ditemper may be a Cholerick Humor not purged out of the body, being the caue and Effect of a ditempered Liver.

The thicknes and hardnes of the Chrytallip Humor is properly termed Glaucois Glaucoma or Glaucoma, becaue the color thereof reembles that of an Owles Eyes: it proceeds from a cold and dry ditemper, and is therefore familiar to aged Perons.
The Dieae of the Chrytalline Humor in repect of its Scituation, has no name, but if it be omwhat higher and flatter than ordinary, it produces a Symptome, whereby all things appear double.

The watry Humor may run out, by a prick in the Eye, but it is bred again inRunning out of the watry Humor. Thicknes of the Viive pirit. Children, as Galen aw by experience, and as we may oberve in Chickens.

The Viive or eeing Spirit implanted in the Eye, may become thick, and urround the Chrytalline Humor with darknes and obcurity: as the implanted Hearing-Spirit of the Ear, being rendred thick, does caue deafnes or thicknes of Hearing.

div.head: Dieaes of the Optick Nerve.
div.p: The Optick Nerve may be troubled with any kind of ditemper, and with olutionObtruction of continuity; but the proper and uual Dieae thereof, is Obtruction, which is known by a udden blindnes, the other Parts of the Eye being al ound: which made the Neotericks cal this Dieae Gutta Serena, and omtimes Amaurois. Amaurois

div.head: Dieaes and Symptomes of the Sight.
div.p: Sight abolihed is called Caecitas Blindnes: when it is diminihed only, tisCaecitas Amblyopia Myopis Nyctalops termed Amblyopia, thick ightednes: and it is accounted twofold Myopis and Nyctalops: In the former the Patient is Pore-blind, and is fain to look cloe to what he would dicern and to hold his Eye-Lids almot hut together. In the latter, the Patient can ee only by day, but very little or nothing at al by night, or very obcurly: the other differences of ight diminihed are comprehended under the general name of Amblyopia.
Sight depraved, is a fal perception of things before the Eyes: its termed Parorais Hallucination or Hallucination.

The Caues of thee Symptomes, are no other than thoe Dieaes of the Eyes,Caues of blindnes. of Anchylo-Blepharon. which we have before recounted. For the Caue of blindnes is, the Obtruction of the Optick Nerve, Glaucoma, Leucoma, Hypopion, Hypochyma, Proptois, the larger Mydriais, a Pterygium or Film covering the whol ight of the Eye, Anchylo-Blepharon or Gluing together of the Eye-Lids.

Imminution or Impairing of the ight, is caued by the other Dieaes of the Eye-Lids. As by a thin Scar of the Cornea, called Nephelion and Achlys; and by a
Leucoma and a mal Mydriais, which touches but Part of the Sight.Myopis Nyct • uopis
Dry ditemper of the Humors of the Eyes caue Myopis: the over Humidity and thicknes of the aid Humors, makes a Man that he cannot ee in the Night.

The Caues of ight depraved is an Hypopion beginning; or an Hypochyma, Namely, when the Humor is not yet united and grown together, o that the viive Spirit can pas too and fro between the Parts of the Humor through the empty paces: whence it is that ome ee flies as it were, and certain dark bodies, move before their Eyes.
When true objects preented to the Eyes, have a fal Appearance, the ight isHallucination Amalops depraved, and termed Amalops: o al things appear Yellow, to uch as have the Jaundice.
But that kind of Symptome happens, when the Cornea which is pred out before the ight of the Eye, is infected with Blood or Choler.

The Animal action of the Eye is hurt omtimes, as Feeling and Motion: theEyes pain Feeling of the Eye is hurt by extream Pain thereof, which notwithtanding, according to the Judgment of Celus, remains within the Eyes, and draws not the Brain into conent, as Pain of the Eares is wont to do. The Caues of al Pains in the Eyes, is a ditemper, or Solution of Unity.

The hurting of the Eyes Motion, is either a Palie, Convulion, or Trembling.Palie Convulion Trembling In the Palie and Convulion, the Eyes become tif and fixed: in that ort of Convulion called Tetanus, they are untable, as in the Trembling.
The Natural Action of the Eyes, is likewie hurt, as Nutrition.

To the Jrregularity of the Excrements of the Eyes, does belong the Involuntary hedding of Tears. Its caued by a moit or cold ditemper of the Eyes, or fromFlowing out of tears. pricking by a harp Humor, or ome external Caue; or from the Eroion of that ame Caruncle, which is in the greater corner of the Eye.
Hereunto likewie belongs the filth of the Eyes, which is by the Greeks calledLaeimai Laeimai: they are caued by an extream ditemper of the Eye, which makes a diolution or melting down of matter.
The imple inirmities of the Eyes, are the potts and Scars of the ConjunctiveSpots and Horny Coates, which are both Dieaes and Symptomes.
The Duskynes and obcurity of the Eyes, is when the Bal of the Eye, does notObcurity repreent any outward object to him that looks upon it; which is a token of Death in an Acute Feaver.

div.head: Chap. 4. Of the Ear.
div.p: THe Ear, being the Intrument of hearing, is divided, into the T. 20. f. 1. and 2. ExternalThe Ears Parts Part, broad and gritly, and the f. 3 4. &c. Internal, which lies hid in the Os petroum.

The external Part is termed f. 1. and 2. Auricula, made up of a f. 2. B B. Gritle, which is covered with a Skin ful of f. 2. A A. Folds, and made hollow, with divers f. 1. A A. B B. windings; with an hole f. 1. G G. through the ame placed upon the ide of the Head, jut againt the hole ofWindings
f. 3. A. Os Petroum.
It is more beautyful, when mal: for a great pair of Aes Ears are uncomly.

The Ear was placed as it is, for the Conveniency of hearing: and if the Scituation of the Ear inverted would not have been deformed, it had been more commodious for hearing, then placed as it is upright and Joyned to the Temporal Bone. For we ee uch as are thick of hearing, put the hollow of their hand behind their Ear, that they may hear the better.
In the Ear you hal oberve two Parts; one is called f. 1. G. Tragus, andTragus Antitragus the other f. 1. D. Antitragus the Names of the other Particles of the Ear, are ueles.

In the Auricula is conteined the firt paage, or Hole of the Ear, and reachesHole of the Ear as far as the f. 4. B B. Tympanum or Drum: its entrance is fenced with Hairs, to keep out dut and crawling Bugs, that might otherwie enter in. There is T. 20. f. 3. C. collected, theEar-Wax Cholerick Excrement of the Ear, called Ear-Wax, which Bird-Limes and intangles any Dut or creeping thing that would pas that way. Its termed Marmoratum.

The internal Ear Concluded in the Os Petroum, is altogether boney, and dividedConcha into three Cavities. The firt Cavity is the f. 6. B. C. f. 7. within A. B. Concha: In the extremity of the firt f. 4. B B. f. 5. B. hole is the Membrane treched out, which terminates upon the f. 3 B. f. 4. A A. &c. Drum: it has a tring that runs cros it, as we ee the Military Drums have.The Drum
l f. 3. B. f. 4. A. &c.

Furthermore, we oberve three littel Bones, the f. 4. G. f. 5. E. f. 7. A. Maller, thef. 7. B. Anvil, and the f. 7. C. Stirrup:Four little Bones. others ad a f. 7. D. fourth, which is a little Scal of a bone, uch as is found in the Carotick Artery near the Os Sphenoides. But this is vain and unueful.

Fortunatus Plempius places another Membrane at the other extremity of the Concha, but how or where it is extended, he does not explain: whether at the two petty windores, whereof the one is the entrance of the labyrinth and the other of the Cochlea, or elewhere? It is a mot hard peice of Service to find out and demontrate the internal tructure of the Ear.

In the Skuls of T. 8. f. 5. 6, 7, 8. Infants, and in a Calves-Head, it is more eaily oberved, by lifting up with a Pen-Knifes Edge that ame portion of T. 20. f. 10. B B. Os Petroum, which within the Scul reaches unto the Bais of the Brain.
In the Concha you hal oberve on the left ide an Hole, which paes into the winding Cavity of the Apophyis Matoides, or Teat-like Production.

The Auditory T. 8. f. 1. F F. f. 3. R R. T. 20. f. 12. A A. B B. Nerve, being f. 10. A A. drawn through the f. 7. D D. f. 9. A. f. 11. B D. Cochlea, when it is come toThe Nerve the Concha, it lips through an hole or f. 8. A. B B. Channel, which opens on the right ide of the Concha, into the Pallate, by the Proces which is termed Apophyis Pterygoidea.

And this is the natural tructure of the internal Ear; for the finding out whereof we are obliged to Fallopius, after Carpus, who dicovered thoe little bones the the Hammer and the Anvil. The third, namely, the Stirrup, Philippus Ingraias brags to have himelf firt oberved.
In living-Creatures, there is an inbred and implanted Air in the Cavities of theImplanted Air Ears, as there is a viive Spirit in the Eye, hut up within the Cornea Tunica.

div.head: The Medicinal Conideration.
div.p: The Gritle of the external Ear if troubled with Putles or Puhes, is confued,Dieaes of the • ar. Swels, is inflamed and exulcerated. By cold it contracts Sphacelation, is contracted and djes do what a Man can: and its omtimes cut of both in ick and in ound Perons. Whence the Greek phrazes Colo • oma and Acrotiriamenoi, for perons that are Crop-Eard.

The greatnes of the external Eare, though it be ill favourd, cannot be helped.Parotis what it is. The Swelling and Inflamation of the Kernels which are beide the Ears, is termed Parotis, which in regard or the narrownes of the place and nearnes to the brain, is
not very afe, happening upon an acute feaver, though it have the name of Diocouros or Cator and Pollux, becaue of its good token, for uch it gives when it is critical; proceeding from the trength of Nature, and attended with light omnes of the Patient following the ame. In Children and young People a Parotis does many times break forth, void of danger; caued by the over great moiture of their brains.
In the hollow behind the Ear; according to the advice of Fernelius, a Cautick mut be applied, in Dieaes of the Ears and of the Eyes.

The firt Auditory paage of the Ear, becaue tis flehy is obtructed by a Tumor,Of the Auditory paage. by a Caruncle or bit of Fleh growing up, or by quittor Iuing out, or by Fi •• h, or omwhat from without. It is inflamed, and impotumated, and Exulcerated either of it elf, or by means of ome eating Medicine poured into the Ear: or by a Cholerick Humor: wherefore Hippocrates aies that when Deaf perons fal into Cholerick Loonees, their deafnes is leened, or taken away: and when their loones is topped, their deafnes returnes.

This paage is terminated inwardly by the Drum, which either of it elf and primarily, or econdarily and by accident through conent of the Bowels, but epecially through fault of the Head, is troubled with a very painful and dangerous Inflamation, which draws the brain into Sympathy.

The internal Cavities, becaue they have no Periotium, are not pained, unlesOf the inner Cavities. Of the Drum the Auditory Nerve be affected, whoe ofspring makes the Drum: from its inflamation proceeds an Impotum and from that an Ulcer: which tears aunder the Drum.

It is broken, not only by an Ulcer, but alo by a blow and a vehement ound; whence it is that thoe who dwel by the Fals of the River Nilus, are al deafe, by reaon of Lovd roaring and Headlong fal of the flowing Water.
Alo the loones and over great moiture of the Drum is to be conidered, becaue it may Caue Deafnes.
The proper Symptomes of the Ear, are thoe which belong to the hurts of hearing,Symptoms of the Action burt. Deafnes. and the Irregularity of Excrements.

The hea • ing is hurt in a threefold Manner. When it is abolihed, it is called Surdita • , Deafnes: which if it come from the Womb and is born with the Patient, it is incurable: if it come by accident, it may be curable.
Hearing diminihed is called Barucoia, thicknes of hearing.Thicknes of Hearing. Noie in the Ears. Their Caue
Hearing depraved conits in a noie and ringings or buzzings in the Ear; tis called Paracouis.
The Caues of Deafnes and Thicknes of Hearing are the ame, ave that they differ in Intenion and Remiion: and therefore the foreaid Dieaes of the Auditory paage and of the Drum may caue thee Symptomes.

Paracouis or Noie in the Ears prings from a ditemper of the drum, being more moit or more dry than is fitting: which, as it caues a more exquiite ence than ordinary, o alo does it caue a ringing in the Ear, as being affected with the very lightet motion of the internal implanted, or external Air, of while the pirits do continually flow into the Ears; which cannot be conteined in o cloe a Room of ome Spirit may tir it elf within the Dug-like Cavity.

Several ounds are imagined in the Ears according to the various motion and mode of the flatulent Spirit which caues the ame. So that if it be thick, whiperings are heard and Hummings if thin, Hiings: and when it moves by fits and tarts, it preents a tinkling, as it were of bells.

Somtimes noies are imagined without any fault of the internal Eare, by conent of the Head, whiles the internal and external Arteries being hotter than ordinary, do beat more violently than they are wont to do, and do make a great ound in the Ears, if the Patient do lie upon one of them.
The differences and Caues of this eeming Noie in the Ears, are neatly expreed by Fernelius in his Pathologia.

In natural Deafnes, pringing from mis-formation in the Womb, and not fromTheir Cn ••
any of the Caues aforeaid: whether may we experiment that which fel out unexpectedly
wel to a certain Deafe man: who thruting an Ear-Picker very far into his Ear, rent the Drum and Break aunder the mal bones and afterwards, attained hearing?
Whether in a ringing of the Ear may the teat like Proces be perforated, to let out the Spirits which make a tumult in that Cavity?

Whether does the thicknes of the Tympanum hinder Tranpiration? o that the flatulent Spirits cannot break out? whether or no wil it avail to rub the extremity of the Auditory Channel, behind the Grinding-Teeth, with Mutard of ome other opening Liquor?

The Irregulary of Excrements in the Ear, is not only of Cholerick and WheyihSymptomes of the Excrements. Excretion of blood Choler erum, quittor &c. Humors, but alo of quitter and blood, proceeding from the brain: neither is o great a quantity of quittor as is avoided, bred in the Cavities, but in the Brain.

If an intollerable inflamatory and pulatory pain does occupy the hinder parts of the head, and the matter flows thither and there tops, the pain abiding: it wil be afe to boar an hole in the hinder part of the Head, that Egres may be given to the quittor; when no great danger is like to follow from the aid operation.
The Ear-Worms termed Eblai, which are voided from the Ears, belong to theWorms. Irregularity of things voided from thee parts.
It is good in Children for the internal and external Parts of their Ears to run and void much Humor, becaue it purges their Brain and prevents great Dieaes.

There is in Dieaes oberved a great Sympathy between the Eares, Mouth, Lungs and Weand: and therefore when the Ears are hurt, the voyce is changed, by reaon of the Auditory Nerve, which being pread into the Throat, reaches as far as the Weand or Wind-Pipes Head.
And when Nature has been accutomed to Purge out the Excrements of the Brain, by the Ears: the toppage of that Purgation, has made many to die uddenly.

div.head: Chap. 5. Of the Face and outide of the Mouth.
div.p: THe Face is the broad and fore part of the head, comprehending the Fore-HeadThe Face decribed. in a living and dead Man without diection; and therefore the T. 15 f. 3. A. Fore-Head, f. 1. between F F. T. 19. al. Eyes, T. 15. f. 1. G I. Noe, and Mouth with its f. 1. N N. Lips, as far as the Chin, do belong unto the Face: which, as it is the ubject of Anatomical diection, is divided into the Parts internal and external.

The External Parts are the Scarf-Skin and the Skin, which are thin and veryIts Paris. mooth in Women. The internal Parts, are the Mucles of the f. 1. G H I. &c. Noe, f. 1. K L M N. Lips, and inferior jaw, whoe empty Spaces are filled up with fat.
Moreover the Muculus Latiimus, does cover the ide of the Face, as far as the Fore-Head; yea and it compaes the whol Neck, excepting the hinder Part thereof.

The Mucles of the Lips, are the Extremities of the Mouth: the other Mucles which belong to the lower Jaw, as the T. 15. f. 1. P P. Temperal Mucle, the Mucle called f. 1. S. Maeter, poeing the ides of the Face, hal be explained in our Hitory of the Mucles.
The Mouth therefore is a Slit in the Skin of the Face, neceary for breathing,The Mouth decribed. peech, and nourihment of the body: for by the Mouth we breath, peak and receive our Food.
The extremities of this Slit art termed f. 1. N N. Lips which are moved by Mucles in theirThe Lips. opening and hutting.
The utmot bound of the Face is called the f. 1. n. Chin, as the upper extremityThe Chin. thereof from the Eye-Brows to the beginning of the Hairs is termed the f. 3. A. Fore-Head.

The ides of the Face are the f. 1. O. Cheeks. The internal Parts of the Mouth, as theThe Cheeks. f. 1. R S T. &c. f. 2. A B C. &c. Teeth, Gums, T. 10. f. 1. g g. Palate, T. 13. f. 15. A. Throat, f 14. A &c. Tongue, hal be decribed in order. The f. 9. 10. &c. Larynx f. 11, 12, 23. Os Hyoides,
T. 3. f. 2. 3. Pharynx, and the f. 16, 17. &c. Glandules, appertain unto the Neck.

The Face, beides Veins and Arteries has a notable T. 18. f. 2. A. Nerve from the third pair,The Viels. which is carryed along between two f. 2. c c. &c. boney plates, under the pavement of the Orbita or Socket of the Eye, and is branched up and down like a Gooes Foot, through the whol Face, by the Noe, as far as the Lips.
gf. 6. m n o.
h f. 6. L L.

div.head: The Medicinal Conideration.
div.p: The Skin of the Face, is the Looking-Glas wherein are een the Dieaes of theDieaes of the Face. Body, epecially of the Liver, Spleen and Lungs: for look what Humor bears way in the bowels, the ame hews it elf forth in the Face. If there be a lating Ruddynes in the Cheeks, it is a Sign of an hot Liver: if the Rednes be eated upon upon the balls above the Cheeks, it argues an hot ditemper of the Lungs. If Choler tick in the pores of the Skin, it caues Freckles: if the Color proceed fromSunburning. The Roe. being in the Sun, it is termed Ephelis. If Rednes remain etled on a great Part of the Face, it is named Gutta Roacea, and thoe who are potted on that manner are termed Antirhoei.
Palenes is commonly een in Virgins and uch as are recovered out of ome Sicknes.Green-Sicknes
The Green-Sicknes, is a low Feaver in Virgins and other young Women that want their Coures.

In uch as are ickly and craie, the Color of the Face is without blood becaue the whol Mas of blood is Wheyih, and therefore the blood of the Face being uch, mut needs be of an Wheyih Color. Thoe that are o affected, are called Liphaemoi, blood-les. A bad Color of the Face, both in Sick and ound perons, is termed Cacochroia
Furthermore, the Face is made rough and deformed by burning Putles, Ionthi, Vari, Fici, Naevi, and Spilloi.
An hard Puh is called Ionthos, becaue it repreents a branch of the flowringIonthos. Violet.
Varus is an harder knob, and not o red and fiery as the Ionthos, Ficus is a certainVarus. Wart.
Lichen, Impetigo or Darta, is a roughnes or Scaly Eminence of the Skin, if itLichen. be dry; if it be moit, it Exulcerates and runs.

Naevi, Warts, are mooth knobs white or blewih: which if they be of aWarts. bad Color, they mut not be tampered with, leat ome wore and cancerous dipoition follow: and Seneca aies that a face without Warts or moles is not pleaing.

It is a wonderful thing how thee Warts of the Face do produce others in divers Parts of the body, which anwer the meaure of the Face as far as the Neck. Of which ubject Ludovicus Septalius has compoed a mot Elegant Book.
Black and blew Color in the Skin of the Face, proceeding from a bruie, is calledHypopium. Hypopium.

Spilloi are Sooty Excrements of the Skin, intruded into the pores thereof, whichSpilloi.
are pulled out, either by a pin, or by queeing the Skin, or by ome emollient Medicament or Pomatum, if they be hard and thick.
Pani, are carrs in the Face.Pani Mentagra.

Mentagra, an Impetigo or Dry-Scab of the Chin, which troubled the Gentlemen of Rome in Plinnies time, where it was a Popular Dieae: is a Malignant Scab, which remaines many years and is hardly curable, and to alters the Skin of the Chin and Lips, that a Man continues Beard-les al his Life long.

The Action of the Skin of the Face being hurt is termed Cynicus Spamus, TheCynicus pamus. Dog-like Convulion, or torture of the Mouth expreing the narling of a Dog: for it is a depraved motion of the Mucles of the Face, belonging to a Pal • e or Convulion.

It is be Paralytick the Retraction is made in the ound Part, becaue of the diolution of the oppoite Parts: If it be convulive, the Part affected is drawn back: Thoe Nerves which are affected in this Symptome, do arie from the pinal Marrow between the econd and third Vertebra of the Neck.
Galen attributed this depraved motion of the Mouth to the Mucle termed Latiimus.

Beides the Cynicus Spamus, there is another Convulion very ordinary, of the upper Lip towards the Eye, by the diorder of that ame Nerve of the third pair decribed above, which being cut a under, below the Socket of the Eye, the aid Convulion is healed.

The particular medicining of the Face beides the univeral, is twofold, the one called Commotice painting and platering with Fucues &c. The other Cometice Painting Beautifying beautyfing and adorning without any thing laid on: the latter Galen allowes to take away the ill favourednes of Women: but the former, he diallows in a Phyitian, and leaves it to panders, bawds and Whores
The Ue of thoe Fucues, unles skilfully mannaged does quickly wrinkle the Skin, uch as are the Spanih- White, and Purpurius or Lovly-Red.

The Dieaes of the Lips are very many, ditempers, Inflamation, Swelling, Ulcers,The ue of the Lips. and others coniting in evil conformation, al which pervert the ue and action of the Lips which erve to hut the Mouth, form the peech and for the eaie reception of meat and drink, to contein the Tongue within the Mouth, to cat forth the Spittle out of the Mouth, for Trumpeters to make a trong blat, for Infants to Suck with, and both in Men and Women to expres their mutual Affection by Kiing,Dieaes of the Lips. and to beautifie their Faces: and therefore if a Mans Lips were cut of, he would appear very deformed, jut like a narling Dog.

Such as have great Lips and ticking out, are called Labeones: uch as are bornIn their Shape with imperfect or cloven Lips, are aid to have an Hares Lip: this defect is amended by Surgery. If the Lips be looe and hanging, it proceeds from a Palie. He that has the inides of his Lips turned outwards is termed Brochus: and he that has welling Lips is called Cheilo. Thoe are by Arnobius termed Mentones, whoe Chins tick out.

The Chops of the Lips are called Rhagades. Somtimes Tumors and little bladdersChops Tumors break out upon the Lips, epecially in Feavers, when Nature drives the virulent Humor out of the Veins and Arteries into the Lips, which Avicen aies is a good ign, that the Feaver wil quickly ceae: and experience does many times confirms the ame. Yet omtimes Tumors and Ulcers in the Lips are in Dieaes ignes of lcers Death, as in the two Brothers Hermoptolemus and Andreas in Hippocrates.
Bad Color of the Lips in Dieaes is no good ign: in uch as are wel, it argues aBad Color fault in the Lungs or in the blood.
`Moles and Warts black and blew and Scirrhous ticking upon the Lips, areMoles and Warts. &c. things to be warily handled, and not to be tampered with by way of Inciion.
Somtimes the Lips do naturally Swel, epecially the lower Lip, when the Jaw is drawn out, and then the lower Teeth before are higher than the upper, and include them.
The principal hurt of the action of the Lips, is depraved Speech. But this Symptome wants a Name.Symptomes

The depraved trembling motion of the Lips, happens by conent of the StomachTrembling ditempered, by reaon of a Membrane common to the Lips and Stomach. Whence it is that thoe who are ready to vomit, have a trembling in their nether Lip: which trembling is called Seimos.

The opening of the Mouth is hurt, when the Jaw is become tif and immovable:Shutting its hutting is hurt when the Jaw is Palied, as in Feavers, by reaon of the Heat of the bowels and Lungs, and difficulty of breathing.

Much pawling, and want of Spittle, do belong to the Dieaes of the Mouth,Frequent pitting. though they have other remote Caues: for Spittle is neceary for chewing of meat, for peech and Tating; but immoderate Spittle is hurtful, and the voidance thereof is accounted filthy and undecent. Touching the Cure of Lips cut of, Taliacotius has written.

div.head: Chap. 6. Of the Noe.
div.p: THe Noe, the Intrument of Smelling and of clening the brain, is placed in theThe Noes Scituation. middet of the Face; dividing the Eyes and Face into two even Parts.
The length and breadth thereof is uncomly, if it exceed a Mans Thumb in length and thicknes.Magnitude
The Figure of a Mans Noe contributes much to his healthy living: for an highShape Noe is better than a flat Noe, and wide Notrils are to be preferred before narrow ones.
It is divided into two T. 15. f. 2. Cavities, which are called Notrils evered by a partition,Cavities and reaching as high as the Colander-bone.

The Depth and Widnes of the Noe, are greater within than they appear outwardly: for that ame pace which lies between the two tables or boards of the Palate and Os Sphenoides, divided into two Cavities by the Os Vomeris, reaching to the Partition of the Notrils, belongs unto the Noe.

That pace is filled up with Spungy Bones, which are portions of the Colanderbone.Spungy Bones Spungy Caruncles. And thoe Spungy bones are filled with Spungy bits of Fleh, which drink up the Flegm which flows from the Head, that Snevil might not be alwaies dropping out of the Noe.

Thee bones and Caruncles or Spungy bits of fleh do likewie erve to Filtrate and train the Air, which, the Mouth being hut, is drawn in at the Notrils, that it may be imparted pure unto the Lungs and brain.
The Noe therefore is compounded of bones, Gritles, Membranes and Mucles.Bones

It conits of T. 15. f. 3. K. Two Bones, which tick outwards and fahion the ame. Five Grities Gritles are dependant upon thoe bones, two being lateral placed by turnes, and movable through the help of Mucles. They are termed Pinnae and Alae Nai the Wings and Pinnacles of the Noe. There is a Gritle placed between them, which is called Septum, the partition, and it depends upon that ame boney T. 15. f. 6. • . partition, placed between the bones of the Noe, being a continuation of Os Vomeris.

The Noe is cloathed externally with the Cuticula and Cutis under which lie theMembrane Mucles T. 15. f. 1. G H. &c. Mucles. The inner Parts of the Noe are inveted with a Membrane prinkled with flehy Fibres, by the help of which, the Pinnacles of the Noe are contracted, when the breath is trongly drawn in; as the aid Pinnacles are widened by other external Mucles, the decription whereof you hal find in my Hitory of the Mucles. Book the 5.
To the Noe do belong, the Seive like plate of the Colander bone, and the Mamillary or Teat-like Productions ending at thee bones, and given out to be the Organs or Intruments of Smelling.

Some would doubt whither thoe Caruncles or little bits of Fleh which are thrut into the Spungy bones, are the proper Intruments of melling, or only ome
way ubervient thereunto; becaue when they are overmoitened, or by any Dieaes impaired, the melling is depraved, or wholly lot.
c T. 15. f. 5. C C.
d T. 18. f. 3. a a.

div.head: The Medicinal Conideration.
