div.p: The Gritly Parts of the Noe, are Inflamed, Bruied, and lcerated; theDieaes of the whole Noe. hony Parts are broken; al of them are troubled with ditempers, but epecially with organick Dieaes pringing from a bad Conformation, as when the Noe is crooked inwards like a addle; which is oftimes caued by external Caues: but if a Child be born with a Saddle-Noe, it may be then raied and rectified. For as Plato reports in his Alcibiades, if the King of Peria had a Daughter o born; they did thrut Pipes into the Childs Noe, and reduce it by little and little to its right hape, by widening the bones and Gritles, whiles they were yet Waxy and pliable.

An over great and high Noe, cannot be cut horter without making the party more deformed. If in perons grown up the Noe be Swelled with Tuberous Excrecencies of Fleh; that fault may be mended by cutting of the aid luxuriating Fleh.

The inide of the Noe is apt to Swel, and is infeted with Inflamatory bunches,Of the inide Tubercula Ozena which come to uppuration: but far within in the Spungy bones and their Caruncles, there is bred a filthy tinking Ulcer called Ozaena, which is offenive both to the Patients and al that come near them, and is very hard to cure. Somtimes the little bones are corrupted and come out at the Notrils. The Caruncles being welled with or without an Ulcer, caue the Polypus, which fals into the Notrils, or it filsPolypus the hollow places above the Palate, reaching as far as the Throat.

The Polipus is neatly dicribed by Celus in his ixt Book, Chapter the eight. Unles it be of a Malignant Color and painful, it may afely be cut away by the Roots, if poible, which is the true Cure, for otherwie it wil grow again, if any Part be left remaining after ection.
A Malignant Cancerous Polypus mut not be medled withaleither by cutting, burning, or cautick Medicaments, for if it be exaperated it eates and devours the whol Face.

Symptomes of the Noe are either its action hurt, or imple affections thereof,Symptomes of the Notrils. Smelling lot or the Irregulary of what is voided forth. The action of the Noe is Smelling, which is abolihed, diminihed or depraved. The Caues of the mel diminihed or abolihed, are the ame, to wit, the obtruction of the inward paages of the Colander-bones and the Mammillary productions, in which the • melling is exercied.Diminihed. If the foremot Ventricles be topped, other parts of the Noe remaining intire, it is known by the perfection of peech, which hews that the Colander and Spungy bones with the Mammillary Productions, are free.

The Smelling is depraved, when al things eem to tink, and when the Patientdepraved. perceives a tink in his Noe, which is likewie dicerned by the tanders by. The true Caue of this Symptome, is a putrified Humor congealed in thoe Cavities. If the Putrefaction be within the Scul, the tink is not perceived by the Patient, but is dicerned by thoe which convere with him, as Fernelius judiciouly oberves.
Simple affections of the external Noe, are pors which are black and blew or red,Spots and deforme the ame. They mut be taken away, or corrected with ome Fucus, if there be no other Remedy.

The Irregularity of Excretions, conits in Bleeding at the Noe, and in aNoe-bleeding Coryza Flux of Seroities therefrom, which caues the Coryza or Grauedo, or a continual Noe-dropping. Hippocrates in his ixt Book of Aphorimes aies, Such as have running Noes, are unhealthy.

In bleeding at the Noe, the blood either comes from the Notrils opened byCaue of Noebleeding. picking, or from that ame long Cavity of the Dura Mater, which reaches unto the Notrils: if the Veins be opened by the harpnes of the blood or the abudance thereof, after it has flowed a while, it mut be topped by opening a Vein in the Arm, unles the blood flow critically.

Fernelius would have al bleedings at the Noe to be topped, be they what they wil, and would have a Vein opened to that end, contrary to the Doctrine of Hippocrates. Blood coming from the inner Parts of the Noe may be topped: but it is very hard to top the ame when it comes from the Menings or Coates of the Brain.

Dropping of blood from the Noe in burning and Malignant Feavers, is bad, bothIts Cure. as a Caue and a igne: becaue it does not eae the Patient, and it hews a Plenitude in the brain, and that nature being weak is not able to disburthen herelf. In uch a cae, great care is to be taken of the head by Revulion, and Derivation of the blood, and by cooling of the Head, for fear of Inflamation or ome Sleepy Dieae.
If bleeding at the Noe be topped in young people accutomed thereunto, and their brains Ake through fullnes, they mut be let blood.
The Ancients did open the inward Veins of the Noe, which Practice is left off, becaue the way they did it, is to us unknown.

Fernelius writes that Wormes as long as ones Finger have been found in Saddle-Noes, being there bred which at lat made the Patients mad and killed them: thoe Wormes were thought to have been cat out of the brain, where as indeed they were born and bred in the Cavities of the Noe. For Wormes bred in the Ventricles of the brain, cannot come out, unles they hould eat a under or break the Sieve-like table of the Colander-bone.

That which Fernelius has written, is worthy of conideration in reference to Dieaes of the Head. That in Noe-bleedings, the blood comes out not from the brain, but out of the Veins of the Notrils. The Veins (aith he) do run into the Noe not from the inner Parts of the brain, but out of the Cavities of the Mouth and Palate, which are wide and open enough, o as they eem to be the Emiaries of uperfluovs blood; Even as the Haernorrhoid Veins, and thoe which belong to the Neck of the Womb. Wherefore the brain being burthened with blood is not eaed, if the blood flow not from the Cavities of Dura Mater. But I beleive it flowes out of the brain. And Galen and Areteus do write, that the Veins within the Notrils, beneath the Colander-bone, may be opened by Art.

Sneezing may be aid to belong unto the Notrils, becaue they being vexed doSneezing caue Sneezing. Alo Sneezing is referred to Dieaes of the Head, and epecially to the Epilepie or Falling-Sicknes, becaue it is a momentany Concuion or Convulion of the brain. So aies Hippocrates in the eventh Book of his Aphorimes. It is caued by heating or moitning of what is contained in the Ventricles of the brain.

div.head: Chap. 7. Of the Neck.
div.p: THat Part which is interpoed between the Head and the Chet, is termedThe Necks ue Collum, and Neck: ordained for the Service of the Wind-Pipe and Lungs, and as a Pillar to utain the Head upon.

It ought to be of an indifferent length, that it may be healthy and ueful for theIts Length. body: becaue a Neck too hort coniting of but ix Vertebraes, by reaon of the hortnes of thoe Veels which are carryed into the Head, is liable to the Apoplexy or Sleepy Dieaes; and a Neck too long containing eight Vertebraes, does at length bring a Conumption: becaue the Lungs being hut up in o trait a place do by little and little Wax overhot, and wither away by degrees.
The Neck is made up of divers Parts, which are divided into Conteining andIts Parts. Conteined. The Conteining are common or proper, the contained are manyfold.
There are reckoned two common containing Parts, the Scarf-Skin and the Skin. The containing proper Membrane is its Coat viz. The Muculus Latus, which eems to be a Propagation of the Membrana Carnoa.

The Parts contained are manyfold viz. The Mucles of the T. 13. f. 18. T. 14. f. 4. &c. Head, of the T. 13. f. 18. T. 14. f. 2. 3, 4. Neck of the T. 13. f. 13. &c. Os Hyoides, of the T. 13. f. 14. Tongue, of the f. 8 9, 10. &c. Larynx and he T. 3. f. 2. 3. Pharynx; which being orderly diected and taken away there comes in view the f. 8. 9. &c. Larynx, the f. 11. 12. A B C. Os Hyoides, the Pharynx, the f. 15. A. Tongue, the f. 16. 17. &c. Kernels, The T. 12. f. 1. e e. • f.
• our jugulars, the two f. 2. a a. Carotick Arteries, A Nerve of the T. 3. f. 8.
• ixt Conjugation both decending and Recurrent, the Cervical T. 12. f. 1. g g. Veins and f. 2. d d. Arteries; and the greater number of the • e Parts, is placed in the foreide of the Neck: in the hinder Part thereof are the T. 13. f. 19. Vertebraes, and the hinder T. 14. f. 2. 3, 4. &c. Mucles ordained to move the Head and Neck.
I wil reerve the Explication of the Mucles to my Myöl • gia or Hitory of Mucles, where the Reader may look, if he denre to know the Mucles of every Part.

But you mut diligently oberve the Kernels placed upon the T. 13. f. 1, 2. 8. Cartilago Thuroides or Door fahiond Gritle, which are larger in Women than in Men. In this order therefore you hal earch for the Parts of the Neck, and eparate them if you can one from another, or take them out.

And firt of al, the Muculus Latiimus being taken away, you hal earch diligentforIts Veels. the Nerve of the T. 3. f. 8. A B. &c. Sixt pair, placed between the internal jugular Vein and the Carotick Arteries. The T. 12. f. 1. e e. Internal Jugular has little values or hutters near the Claves, but the f. 1. f f. external Jugular has none.
The Carotick Artery at its entrance into the Skul, has two very mal thin bones, which hinder and keep back the Arterial blood, when it would flow in too violently.
The Nerves of the ixt Pair being both of them tied in a living Dog, he cannot bark having lot his voyce, if one only be tied, he barks but faintly and by halves: which is diligently to be oberved.

Then you hal conider the Os T. 13. f. 11. 12. A B C. Hyoides, how it is upended with trong bandsOs Hyoides. and firmly fatened to the Apophyes T. 15. f. 6. D D. Styloides; how it utaines the Larynx, the Epiglottis and the Tongue. For the Cartilago f. 1, 2, 8. A. Thyroides, is by its Hornes annexeded to the Os Hyoides.

And therefore the Os Hyoides is the Foundation of thoe Parts, and yet is it moveable in wallowing: and Rondeletius aw one taken Speechles as in a Palie, by reaon of the diolution of the Reluctancy of the Mucles of Os Hyoides. Which is a thing to be oberved in that bone.
Beides thoe Kernels reting upon the Cartilago Thuroides, there are other littleKernels. ones, placed al along the internal jugular and orderly dipoed, into which the brain disburthens it elf.
Under the lower Jaw, in the upper and foremer Part of the Neck, are een two other Kernels, which do often wel, and in them the Kings-Evil is bred.
At the Root of the Tongue are the T. 15. f. 16. and 11. Tonillae, termed Antiades; certain Kernels o called. Whoe pain and welling are by lpian termed Antiagri.

Al thee Kernels are diligently to be conidered in Fl •• ions which happen in the Neck, whether they be the Scrophulae Kings Evil or Bronchacele.
e f. •• a a.

div.head: The Medicinal Conideration.
div.p: The Neck is ubiect to Similar Dieaes ariing from ditemper, and to DieaesSimilar Dieaes of the Neck. The Organical Dieaes. as Bronchocele. Organical, coniting in bad Conformation: if it be too long, or too hort, or the Vertebraes thereof be out of Joynt, epecially the econd; in Magnitude, if it be welled, as in the Bronchocele, Kings-Evil and Squinie.

Bronchocele is a Swelling in the Neck, near the Larynx, ariing from an humor collected in that place, or from the Kernel of the Cartilago Thuroides being longer than ordinary and producing uperfluous fleh; or it is an Impotum proceeding from the Tumor Atheroma or Steatoma, or it is a Dropie. Bronchocele does not proceed, as many have imagined, from immoderate Clamors and Cryings out, or by drinking of melted Snow, as the fahion is among the Inhabitants of the Alpes or other high Mountaines; but from thick and clammmy Flegm, which lides thither by bittle and little out of the Head and the external Parts thereof, down behind the Eares. Which is the Judgment of Fernelius.

It may be quetioned, whether the matter be contained between the Muculus latus and the Skin, or whether it lie al concealed under the Muculus Latus. For if the matter be collected there, it cannot be drawn out, becaue it is crept in between the paces of the Mucles.

If it lie outward to the ight, it may be rooted out and cured. It is wont to begin with a wind, which ditends and eparates the Skin from the Membrana Carnoa: or the Muculus Latus it elf, is eparated from the Parts which lie beneath the ame.
Into the which pace the matter flows by degrees, which differs according to the various temperament and Contitution of the Patients.
It grows by little and little, and receives nourihment, not by the Veins, but by certain little Pipes which Nature creates.

Bronchocele differs very much from the Kings-Evil-Swellings, which rie underKings-Evil the Jaw and in the Neck, of a rounder hape, ditinct one from another, or clutered together. They pring from a Flegmatick clammy matter, which drenches the Kernels and makes them wel; and therefore look where there are Kernels, there the wellings arie.

Scirrhous Tumors have in them omwhat of the Nature of the Kings-Evil-Swellings, which makes them upected. They happen under the Jaws, in the Groins, behind the Ears, and in al Parts of the Body where there are Glandules or Kernels. And omtimes in certain places of the Body, a portion of Fat grows hard and makes a Scirrhous Tumor and omtime the Kings-Evil.
The Tumor Gongroni is mutered among the external wellings ofGongrone. the Neck. It is cau • ed by an Humor, not o thick as that in the Kings-Evil, or Bronchocele.
Angina the quinie, is a Tumor of the Neck either internal or external: or anSquinzie. internal or external inflamation of the Neck.

The external is properly called Synanche, the Internal is termed Cynanche. Galen conceives that this ditinction of Names is vain and of no ue in Practice. But I account the ame neceary. For although general Medicines do erve for both, yet in Cynanche where the Patient can neither fetch breath nor peak, the danger is greater: and therefore Medicines are to be peeded with al hat poible: yea and the Wind-Pipe mut be opened ere twenty four hours are pat, that the Patient may by that means receive breath, til uch time as the upper Part of the Larynx be untopped. For in that kind o • Squinie, where no outward welling appears, the Larynx alone is inflamed and obtructed. In other Squinies the Circumjacent Mucles of other Parts are affected: In the Cynanche, the Fluxion is in the Arytaenois and the Glottis, and in other Muculous Carnoities of the Larynx, by which means the paage of the Larynx is topped, and death follows unvoidably,
for though there is ome little paage left for Liquors, yet no man can live without fetching his breath.

A Leek thrut into the Throat, with ome harp biting Powder prinkled upon it may do good, as alo ome trong drawing Medicine or a Veicatory applied to the Larynx, and Scarifications made here and there about the Larynx. Touching the Squinie, read Hippocrates in the 27. and 34. Aphorimes of his ixt Book. In the third Book of his Prognoticks, And in the 49. Aphorime of his eventh Book.

div.head: Chap. 8. Of the Teeth and Gums.
div.p: I Return now unto the inner Parts of the Mouth which are there conteined, and may be een with the Eyes, uch as are the Teeth, Gums, Palate, vula and Tongue, of which in order.

I wil begin with the Teeth, the Intruments of Chewing and of peaking; forue of the Teeth. thoe that are Tooth-les cannot wel chew and grind their Meat, neither can they pronounce their words clear and plain as they ought to do.
There is a twofold conideration of the Teeth; as they are in Infants, til they are two or three years Old, and as they are in perons of riper years.

In Infants they break out by Coure, firt the Cutters, then the Dog-Teeth, afterCondition of the Teeth in Infants. them the Grinders, and they have but twenty til they are three years Old, at which time the ret break forth.
Thee firt Teeth are called Dentes Lactei, the milk Teeth, which have under them another branch, which wil hoot forth another Tooth, if the firt be pluckt out, or come out of it elf.

There are two eaons oberved in which Children are mot tormented with Tooth-breeding: the one is when they firt prout within the Gum, the other is when they break out of the Gum. And under the Term of Tooth-breeding Hippocrates does in a manner comprehend al Childrens Dieaes, becaue Children are troubled with many Dieaes upon that account, pringing from the pain of Teethbreeding, and bringing them to their Graves.

In Perons grown up the Teeth are ditributed into two ranks or T. 14. f. 3. rows, accordingIn grown Perons. to the two Jaws in which they are fixed. In each Jaw are reckoned fifteen or ixteen Teeth, and they are of three orts. The firt four placed in the forepart of the Jaw, are called T. 15. f. 6. m. Cutters: next them on either ide, are the two T. 15. f. 6. n n. Dog-Teeth, and after them on each ide five Grinders. They are immovably fatened in their Holes called Alveoli, by that kind of Articulation which is termed Gomphois.
They are bound and fatened both by their proper Ligaments and by the Gums.

They recive Nerves, Veins and Arteries within their Roots, which are hollow,Their Veels. and therefore they are pained more than any other of the bones. The external and bare Part of the Tooth, is termed its Bais, the internal which is covered, is called the Root, which is double or triple.
d T. 15. f. 6. o o o o.

div.head: The Medicinal Conideration.
div.p: Tooth-Sicknees of Infants, have two times in which they are wont to tormentDieaes of the Teeth in Infants. and kil. The firt is when the Tooth firt prouts within the Gum, which is called Odaximos, which caues the Gums to Swel and be inflamed, brings Feavers, continual Vomiting and Loones: the other is the time of the breaking forth of the Tooth, which is called Odontophua, and then the poor Infants are mot of al vexed and tormented with pains.

The teeth of grown Perons are troubled with divers Dieaes, as Ditempers, Drynes In grown perons. through Age, and Loones; with Organick Dieaes in Number Deficient, when they fal out; or in Number exceeding, when there are two or three rows of Teeth: or when there is but one Bone, in the place of o many Teeth.
In Magnitude exceeding or deficient, as when there be long gag Teeth, that go out of their Rank, or when the Teeth are too little and worn away.
In Scituation, when they tand not cloe together, or when the lower Teeth are not jut againt the upper, or when the upper Teeth fal within the lower, or when Teeth grow in the Palate of the Mouth.
Dieaes common are, when the Teeth Scale and moulder away with rottenes,Symptomes of the Teeth are. Setting on edge Tooth-ach. or when they are broken.

Symptomes of the Teeth, are the hurting of the proper and peculiar feeling of the Teeth, which is called Haemodia, Setting of the Teeth on Edge; or the hurting of the common feeling of the Teeth, which caues the Tooth Ach, which is termed Odontalgia or Odontagra for the liknes it has to pains of the Gout. Pain of the Teeth is reckoned among the greatet torments which are in the world, although a Tooth be o mal a Part. Celus Book the ixt Chap. 9.
Simple Affections of the Teeth are Blacknes, Rutynes and a clammy gluihnes (which Hippocrates counts the ign of a trong Feaver) alo a tony Crut which grows upon them.

Symptomes in the Irregularity of things voided, are, A Stinking of the Teeth,Stinking. Excrecence. Worms. Bleeding. an excrecence and Worms, which are bred within the Cavities of the Teeth, or a flux of blood immoderately flowing, after the drawing of a Tooth, which is omtimes a caue of Death. See Duretus in his Comments upon the Coicks of Hippocrates, where he explains what is the grinding of the Teeth in Dieaes.
Drynes of the Teeth in Sick people, foretels a Convulion or Madnes.

It is worth the enquiry. Whether into the plaee of a Tooth drawn out, anotherWhether a Tooth may be fatened in the place of one drawn out? may be thrut in at the ame moment, and fixed in the Room thereof, o as to tick fat and be cloathed with the Gums fleh, and to abide and erve to chew the Meat with the other Teeth?

He that hal conider that the Teeth have Life, do receive Veins, Arteries and Nerves; do feel, are pained; and firmly tied and fatened with certain bands into the Gums: wil never ay that a trang Tooth, thrut into the place of one pluckt out, can be made o like to the other Teeth, as to perform the ame Office with them and tick there as long as they hal do. Yet ome Phyitians in favour of a Norman Tooth-drawer, would perwade Men that it is poible to ubtitute uch a Tooth, and they have upbraided me with Incredulity and Ignorance, becaue I am not of their mind.
You are to conider the holes in the upper and lower Jaw-bone, through which are drawn the Nerves Veins and Arteries, which are inerted into the Roots of the Teeth.

In the upper Jaw there creeps an Artery which running towards the Eare, is there burnt, or eared up, and to that place and upon the Temples, an atringent plater is laid to top the Veins by which the Flux of Rheum does come.
There creeps an Artery in the Lower Jaw near the Corner, which is to be eared where it beates, or topicks are to be laid thereupon, to eae the Tooth-Ach of the lower Jaw.

Somtimes a bony Fungus or Spungy ubtance grows out of the hole of a Tooth,How the Spungy excrecence is taken out of the Tooth-hole. and comes to be o big as to fil the Patients Mouth, and at length to choak him, if prevention be not ued, by cutting off the aid excrecence and burning the Root thereof.

You hal oberve that the brain hurts the Teeth by Ditillation of Rheum, the Stomach hurts them by Fumigation or raiing fumes and teems which annoy them: and that the Lungs likewie do in ome Meaure dammage the Teeth.

That there is a Regeneration of the Teeth, and that Teeth grow out in every AgeWhether Teeth do breed in al Ages? of Man, is mot certain: yet mut we not rely upon this Regeneration of Teeth,
o as certainly to make account thereof, and expect it after even years are over.
To Clene the Teeth you hal find an Admirable Water, in the 96. Counel of Fernelius

div.head: Chap. 9. Of the Gums.
div.p: THe Gums are certain parcels of Fleh folded about the Teeth, which cover theThe natural Contitution of the Gums. Preternatural. holes of the Teeth within and without: but without they are wider and more welling. When this Fleh of the Gums grows Proud and covers the Teeth more than it hould, it caues pain and hinders Chewing, alo the Loones of the aid Fleh is troubleome, becaue it makes the Teeth to become looe.
Inflamation of the Gums is called Parulis: if the Fleh grow from an Ulcer, itsParulis. Epulis. Cancer. termed Epulis. Somtimes the Gums are Cancerated, and omtimes they bleed immoderately.
The Gums are Eaten up by Ulcers called Aphthae: in the Scurvy (which the Old Phyitians called Stomachache and Ocedo) the Ulcers of the Gums are Malignant.

Somtimes thee Aphthae or Ulcers of the Gums are o Malignant, that they eateApthae. into the Tongue, vula, and Tonillae, without upition of the Venereal Pox. uch are decribed by Aretaeus, and uch appear in that trangling Spanih Dieae, which the Spanjards cal Garotillo, and which is common to the inhabitants of Naples (who cal it lcus Syrianum Faucium) perhaps by reaon of their Commerce with the Spanjards, who are much ubject to the Kings-Evil: and therefore the Malignant Humor of the Kings-Evil does Produce uch Symptomes in the Mouth and Jaws.

div.head: Chap. 10. Of the Palate.
div.p: THe Palate is the T. 15. f. 5. L L. &c. Vaulted Roofe of the Mouth, which is a very thin bone,The tructure of the Palate. cloathed with a T. 13. f. 15. D. Nervous Skin, which is wrinkled, by reaon of the Crevees which are ingraven in the bone: and therefore it ticks very hard to the bone, which has no Periotium

This mot tender bone does many times become rotten in the Whores-Pocks,Its Rottennes. the Palate being boared through (if care be not taken in time) whether the infection be lodged in the Mouth, or within the Noe: which Hole o boared does much hinder the Patient in chewing of Meat and in peaking unles it be topped with a plate, Cotton, or Spunge.

div.head: Chap. 11. Of the Uvula and Ithmus.
div.p:
AT the inner part or further part of the T. 13. f. 15. D. Palate hangs the T. 13. f. 15. A. Gargareon orThe e of the vula.
vula, a Flehy Particle, which is given to mankind to help his peech, and to ome birds which imitate the peech of Man: it hangs therefore at the farthet end of the Palate, to help our peech, being that to the voyce, which the Quil is to the Muical Intrument, whoe trings are truck therewith. It is therefore called the triker bp Paulus Aegineta in the 51. Chapter of his ixt Book.

It hinders liquid things from running back into the Notrils, and it purifies the Air which enters into the Wind-Pipe. Therefore uch as have no vula, are hoare in peaking, part of what they drink runs into their Noe, and becaue of the impurity of the Air which they draw into their Lungs, they fal into a Conumption.

It has T. 13. f. 15. B B. C C. &c. Mucles for motion, though it be moved very obcurly or rather upendedIts Mucles.
in Aequilibrio. Of thee Mucles you may read in my Hitory of the Mucles. Lib. 5.

To this Particle are adjoyned certain Lateral Ligaments, which being widenedLigaments. and pred forth by a Defluxion of rheum, they reemble the wings of Bats or Flitter-Mice, and are very troubleome to the Patient. Naturally they ought to be dry, and drawn back toward the Palate bone: they are two, and do include the T. 13. f. 17. and 18. Kernels termed Tonillae.

div.head: The Medicinal Conideration.
div.p:
This Part, viz. The vula o •
Gargareon is Inflamed Swelled, Lengthened Its Dieaes. Staphyle. Columella. Chalais. and grows Lank. When it is inflamed it repreents a Grape, and is termd Staphyle, if it repreent a Pillar, tis called Columella and Chion; if it grow looe and lap by reaon of the Rheum, tis called Chalais Gargareonis; and then it is contracted and drawn back, by princkling alt or Peper upon it, whereby the moiture thereof is dried up.

If it hang down too much, part of it is cut away; if the lateral Membranes are relaxed it is called Imantis by Aretaeus; who elegantly decribes the Relaxation ofImantis. thoe Ligaments in his firt Book de Cauis Acutorum, Chap. 8. Of the Gargareon read Hippocrates, in his third Progn, ent. 31.

div.head: Of the Ithmus.
div.p: Ithmus is a place or pace between the Larynx and Pharynx, eated in theIthmus defined. Dieaes of the Tonill • . Throat, like a Neck of land between two Seas, which is an Ithmus.

The Kernels there placed are called a Antiades and Parithmia. The welling of thoe Kernels is called by the ame names by which the Tonillae are called when they are inflamed. Somtimes they wel and grow to uch a greatnes, that they decend into the Throat like two Apples and hinder the Patient from wallowing and fetching breath.

They are often inflamed and Impotumated, and then they mut be pricked deep in with a lancet, to let out the blood or quittor, otherwie they choak the Patient. Somtimes they are inflected with Cancerous Tumors, which are incurable.

div.head: Chap. 12. Of the Tongue.
div.p: THe Tongue, which is the Intrument of tating peaking and wallowing; isThe Tongues Subtance. Number. made up of a T. 13. f. 14. A. &c. Flehy and Spungy ubtance, compaed about with a thin Membrane. Although it eem one, yet is it divided into two Parts, which are o eparated, although cloly connexed; that one ide may have the Palie and the other be free, and the one ide may be dicoloured and the other not.

It is placed in the Mouth and throat, born up by the Bais of the T. 13. f. 11. and 12. A. Os Hyoides, Scituation. and tied with a trong band. It was very conveniently thus eated, that it might dicover the Dieaes which lie hid in the three Cavities of the Body viz. The belly Chet and Head. For it is oaked and tainted with the moit and fuliginous Excrements of thoe Parts, and has the Color of that Humor which bears mot wey in the Body.

And therefore becaue it is the Intrument of Tat, of peech and of the Mind, it was requiite that it hould correpond and communicate with thoe principal Bowels: and therefore as the Urin is in al Dieaes lookt upon and examined, o ought the Tongue to be diligently conidered. Hippocrates Lib. 6. Epidem: Sect. 3. Text 14.
The Tongue hews what the Urin is: which Galen has confirmed in his Commentary upon that place.

The Magnitude of the Tongue is to be conidered: for naturally it ought to beMagnitude. as long as a mans middle Finger, but hardly o thick as the aid Finger, and not broader than the breath of two Fingers. Such is the natural greatnes of the Tongue, that it may be fit to peak with, otherwie a thick, over-long and overbroad Tongue, doth much hinder a mans Speaking.

The T. 13. f. 16. and 17. pointed end of the Tongue, which mites againt the Teeth, is termed Proglois: Proglois the broad end which lies hid in the Throat, is called Bais Linguae, the bottome of the Tongue. That it may not run out to far or wander from its bounds, it is retained by a band under neath, which is called Fraenum Linguae, the bridleFraenum of the Tongue.

It has Veins from the Jugular, Arteries from the Carotick. The Veins underIts Veels. Kernels. the Tongue are called Hypoglottides or Ranulae: and two Kernels placed there are likewie termed Ranulares, in which, grown round and hard, the foundation of the Elephantiais, a kind of Leproie, is bred, as appeares by the welling of the Lips, Puhes of the Face, and thicknes of the Tongue.Mucles It has T. 13. f. 14. a a. b b. Nerves for tating and motion. For though it be of it elf Voluble in peaking, yet for the more trong motions of chewing, wallowing and pitting, it tands in need of T. 13. f. 14. B. C. D. E. Mucles, of which you may read in my Hitory of Mucles Lib. 5.
a T. 13. f. 14. A.
b T. 13. f. 14. B B.

div.head: The Medicinal Conideration.
div.p: The Tongue is ubject to divers Dieaes, Similar, Organick, and common.Dieaes of the Tongue. Similar. Organical. For it is liable to al kinds of ditempers; to loones or oftnes, hardnes, Denity and Rarity of ubtance.
It is Organically Dieaed, when it is wollen in al its dimenions and cannot be conteined within the Hedg of the Teeth.Common.

It is inflamed, when the Tumor called Batrachium ries under the Tongue, and turnes to an Impotum: out of which being opened, there flowes a ubtance like the white of an Egg and omtimes true quittor. If it be removed never o little from its place, the Caue is in the Os Hyoides, or in its Mucles, being either Palied or Convuled.
It is alo Ulcerated by thoe imple Ulcers termed Aphthae, and omtimes with Malignant Ulcers, which putrifie, Eat and conume the ame.Whether its ubtance wil grow again.
That the ubtance of the Tongue may grow again is confirmed by many Hitories, and that the ame being lot, a man is not wholly deprived of peech.

There have been ome een who could peak ditinctly enough, o as to be undertood, without a Tongue. But peradventure they had ome Part of their Tongue remaining far within, which with the Glottis and vula did frame the Speech.Its Symptomes

Symptomes of the Tongue, of the firt kind, are two, the Marring of Speech and Tating. Speech is marred three waies, by Abolition, Imminution and Depravation.Speech Abolihed. Traulotis. Pallotis. Stammering Abolition of Speech is termed Anaudia. Depravation of peech is of two orts, Traulotis, Pallotis or Balbuties. Traulotis is when the Patient cannot pronounce ome one letter, and Pallotis or Pellimos is, when he cannot pronounce divers letters. Ichnophonia, Stammering, is a toppage of the Tongue, o that the Patient cannot proceed in his dicoure, but repeats one and the ameTonguetied. letter often over before he can proceed. Anchylogloos and Mogilalia are when the Tongue is tied either too trait or too looe.Tat Vitiated
There is a threefold marring of the Tat, not ditinguihed by names: for it is abolihed, depraved and diminihed.

The depravation of tat happens when the Tongue is filled with ome evilTat depraved Humor. So that what ever it tats is infected with that Humor and tats thereof. Tat is abolihed when the Tongue perceives no tat in any thing.
The motion of the whole Tongue is abolihed in the Palie, diminihed when thePalie of the Tongue. half of the Tongue is Palied, without any hurt to the Tat.

In a total Palie of the Tongue, there is great fear that the Patient wil fal into an Apoplexy, though Fernelius aw none to follow: but we mut not be too confident, but meet the Dieae when it is coming.
In a total Palie of the Tongue the Patients are dumb: in a Palie of half the Tongue, they peak untowardly.
A imple affection of the Tongue, is its Color changed, which comes not onlyTongue dicoloured. from the primary ditempers thereof, but cheifly by Sympathy with the Bowels.
There is a certain trembling or wavering of the Tongue oberved in Dieaes of the Brain, which is a forerunner of the Phrenie, according to Hippocrates in his Coicks.

div.head: Chap. 13. Of the Larynx, or Head of the Wind-pipe.
div.p: THe Larynx is the Head of the T. 13. f. 9. and 10. E E. Apera Arteria or Wind-pipe, the intrumentThe Larynx. its of modulating our peech, and the Channel by which Air is breathed in and out.
Tis eated in the Forepart of the Neck which is termed the Throat.Scituation

In Men it bunches out more than in Women, for the Women have two Kernels placed thereby, which wel more than they do in men, and o make the Neck even, taking away that ame deformed Protuberancy, which is een in Men.

It conits of five Cartilages or Gritles, whereof the two greatet do make upGritles Thuroides Cricoides. Arytaenoides. Glottis. the Body of the Larynx: the firt is called T. 13. f. 1. and 2. f. 8. A. Thuroides, the econd T. 13. f. 3. and 4. f. 9. and 10. D D. Cricoides, and thoe are the two larget and hardet. The third is the f. 5. and 6. f. 10. a a. Arytaenoides, which is placed upon the Cricoides and huts up the Larynx. Within there is oberved a fourth, which is called f. 10. beneath A. Glottis, being the principal Intrument of framing the Voyce, which is contracted and dilated with the Arytaenoides: but the Arytaenois with the Glottis, is o firmly hut, when we draw our Breath in, that it trives againt the Mucles of the Throat and Chet which reit the ame, to hinder Expiration or the going out of the breath, by which al the Mucles are looned, and Expulion ceaes from the inferior Parts. Only the Glottis Acts, in the Modulation of our Speech.

And that nothing either olid or Liquid might fal into the Larynx, it has a cover, which is called T. 13. f. 7. 9. and 10. A A. Epiglottis. It tands alwaies open for Repiration ake, nor is itEpiglotti • . depreed ave by the weight of what is eaten and drunk.
The whol Larynx is Moveable by way of Acent and Decent, through help of Mucles, for to Facilitate our wallowing.Its Moti •… .

Again, two Cartilages or Gritles are moved by themelves viz. The Thyrois and the Arytaenois. The former is widened and contracted, the latter is hut and opened. For thoe are contrary motions, which are performed by f. 8. 9. 10. &c. eparated Mucles, which pring from the Cricois an immovable Gritle, which is placed toIts Mucles. faten the Gritles and Mucles, as a foundation to make the Circle of the Larynx. Touching the Mucles, I hal peak in my Doctrine of Mucles.

The Larynx though it be Gritly, yet in Old Men it becomes boney, and it has been found to be o in ome that were to be hanged, whom the Halter could not choak: and not only the Larynx, but alo the gritly Channel of the f. 9. and 10. E E. Apera Arteria. Either thoe parts were boney or the Halter way too thick, o that it could not ufficiently force and rend the ame.

div.head: The Medicinal Conideration.
div.p: The Larynx is ubject to a ditemper, a Tumor and Inflamation, which whenDieaes of <…> Larynx. it happens, it hinders Speech and Breathing and trangles the Patient without any appearance of welling, without.

Within fifteen or twenty hours it kils a Man, his mind and ences remainingSquinzie. ound and perfect. An Horrid Symptome it is, in which beides general Remedies, if Scarrification of the Neck, wil do no good, we mut proceed ad Bronchotemiam, viz. To open the Part by Section.
And this Dieae is that mot Pernicious Angina which Hippocrates make • mention of: Liquid things penetrate into the Stomach, but al breathing is topped, and conequently udden death mut needs follow.

The Action of the Larynx is breathing, and the forming of peech and inging.Privation of Speech. Hoarnes. want and dificulty o • b • eathing. Privation of peech is termed Aphonia, the depravation thereof is Raucedo Hoar •
nes: the Imminution thereof is called Ichnophonia.
The Interception of Repiration is termed Apnoia, the Imminution thereof Dypnoia.

Both thee Actions are hurt, either by a proper Dieae of the Larynx, or of the neighbouring Parts, or of the Parts remote, epecially of the Lungs, from whence the matter of peech is upplied and repiration proceeds. For the Larynx affected, does only top the waies of breathing.
The Epiglottis has its Dieaes; either it is relaxed, or it is too much contractedDieaes of the Epiglottis. and traitned, or it becomes hard, whence proceeds difficulty in wallowing.

Some there are who can more eaily Swallow meat than drink, and in uch the Epiglottis is become hard and ti • , o that it wil not be born down ave by the weight of olid meat, with which that which is liquid lips along.

When it is become looe and Flaggy by reaon of a Catarrh, it cannot be conveniently raied up; and when it is become traiter and narrower than it ought, it does not exactly hut the Arytenoides: which caues that crumms of bread and ome portion of what is drunk, do lip into the Wind-pipe.

Nature has provided againt this inconvenience, having by the ides of the Glottis, which is almot alwaies hutting, framed and et certain Cavities, which receive, uch portions of meat or drink as lip beide, o that they are cat out again by coughing. f f. 9. and 10. between A. and E.

div.head: Chap. 14. Of the Apera Arteria or Wind-Pide.
div.p:
IN the Fore-part of the Neck is placed the T. 13. f. 9. and 10. E E Channel of the Apera Arteria, the e of the ••
and. Intrument of peech and breathing, becaue it brings Air into the Lungs and carries out ooty Vapours; alo there the Voice is formed and begins to be Articulated.

It conits of many Semi-circular Gritles, which are evered one from another,Its Gritles. and are imperfect behind, not filling up the Circle, by reaon of the Oeophagus or Gullet which lies beneath it, being the Channel of Meat and Drink.
The Apera Arteria or Wind-pipe is lined within by a Membrane,Its Membrane. which is drawn from the Mouth into the inner parts of the Wind-pipe and Oeophagus.

div.head: The Medicinal Conideration.
div.p: The Pipe of the Apera Arteria is troubled with an hot or cold ditemper, with an Humor flowing from the Brain, whence comes Branchos, Raucedo or Hoarnes.
The Wind-pipe being wounded is curable and may ecurely be cut, under theWhether the wouds of the wind-pipe are Curable? Larynx, between two Gritles, in a very choaking Squinie.

May we not experiment this operation in a choaking • oppage and whe • zing with rattling in the Wind-pipe, eeing that it may be as afely practied in this cae as in the other? that weet attenuating and cutting Liquors may be taken or forced in, to cut the Flegm and bring it up, if it be poible, and pain, caued by Choughing, hinder no • ?

div.head: Chap. 15. Of the Oeophagus, or Gullet.
div.p: THe Oeophagus is the T. 3. f. 2. E E. f. 3. E F. &c. way for the meat to pas into the Stomach. The beginningWhat the Pharynx is. thereof is termed Pharynx, which is moved by the help of Mucles, T. 3. f. 2. and 3. A B C. &c. to thrut or wallow the meat.
It is made up of a proper Flehy Membrane. Woven together with traight andMembrane of Oeophagus. circular Fibres. It has another internal Tunicle which hath its original from the T. 3. f. 3. D. Mouth.
Within the Chet, that it may give way to ths Aorta Artery, leaving the Backbone, it inclines and is wreathed a little towards the right hand.
Two Kernels upport that part which is o turned aide, and tay it on eitherIts Kernels. hand, which being drenched and welled with ome Humor, do bring a great Impediment to the wallowing.

Oftentimes the end of the Oeophagus which is joyned to the Stomach, and is inObtruction of the Oeophagus. Latin termed T. 3. f. 3. H. f. 4. A. Stomachus, is obtructed by a Tumor either proceeding from Flegm or Melancholy, which turnes at lat unto an Ulcer and brings Death
Which Dieae is known by the hard decent of oild meat into the Stomach, which omtimes taies, and many times is vomited up again.

div.trailer: The End of the Fourth Book.

div.head: THE FIFTH BOOK OF THE ANATOMY AND PATHOLOGY OF John Riolanus, THE KINGS PROFESSOR OF PHYSICK.
Chap. 1. Of the Limbs.
div.p: HAving gone over and finihed the Trunk of the Body, I proceedThe Method of handling. unto the Limbs, whoe Mucles, Veins, Arteries and Nerves with the Dieaes of thoe Parts, I intend to explain, which cannot be done without Anatomical diection.

But before I proceed to that work: it wil do very wel to contemplate the lex • eral Conformation of the Limbs, and and withal to hew you what Veins are wont to be opened, and in what places Iues may be made.

The Limbs are made up of the Scarf-Skin, the Skin, the fatty Membrane, theParts of which the Limbs are compounded. Fleh of Mucles, Veins, Arteries, Nerves, Bones, Ligaments, Gritles and Kernels. Thee Parts I hal o divide in the Limbs, as I did in the Trunk of the body viz. Into parts containing and Parts contained.

The Parts containing are the Scarf-Skin, the Skin, the fatty Membrane, and the common Membrane of the Mucles. Al the other Parts are conteined, being comprehended by thee. Touching the Scarf-Skin and the Skin, I hall repeat nothing,
becaue they are the ame and al a like in al Parts. The Membrana Adipoa or fatty Membrane, is pred out in the Arm as far as the Writ: and in the Leg, from the Groin unto the Ankles.
After that, follows the common Membrane of the Mucles, which comprehends the Mucles in their natural Scituation. In the Thigh the Facia Lata upplies its place.

div.head: The Medicinal Conideration.
div.p: The Univeral Dieaes of the Skin are divers ditempers, imple,Dieaes of the Skin. or with Humors conjoyned. If the ditemper be with Humor it makes the Skin rough or wollen, whence prings the Scab, the Mange, the Morphew, Scurfe, Leproie, Tetters, Itch, Putles, Blains, Water-Bladders, Yellow-Bliters, Warts, Scalds, Moles, Biles, Night-Blains, Ring-worms, Lowie-Evil, Chops, Black and Blewnes, Smal Pocks, Meazles, Whores-Pox and Elephantiais or a Cancerous Tumor, over the whol body.Of the Fleh.

The Fleh is infeted with al kinds of Tumors, Inflamations, Carbuncles, Cholerick Tumors, Phlegmatick Tumors, Melancholick Tumors, Cancers, Watry Tumors, Windy Tumors, Impotums of al orts, Steatoma the Fat impotum, Atheroma the Pap impotum, Meliceris the Hony impotume, an Ulcer, a wound and a Gangrene.

An Athletick or Champion-like contitution of body, high fed, and as we ay, luty and ful of Beefe, is dangerous. Hippocrates hews the Reaon in his 1. Book, Aphorime the 3. and Celus aies, that when a Man becomes Corpulent, he ought to upect leat he be fatted to the laughter. And in Hippocrates his Aphorimes we are told, that fat Men are not o Long-lived as lean Men are, and there are ome of cold Contitutions. who have hot Stomachs.Of the Veels. Of the Bones.

Veins and Arteries have Dieaes proper to themelves, the Nervs have their peculiar Dieaes, and the Joints have theirs. And the bones are ubject to fractures, Drynes, Disjoynting, Rottennes, &c. Which hal be explained when we come to treat of the bones.

div.head: Chap. 2: Of the Superior Limbs.
div.p: The Limbs both Superior and inferior are divided into three principal Parts: theThe general diviion of the Limbs. Special diviion. Arm into T. 21. f. 1. C. Brachium from the Shoulder to the Elbow, f. 1. D E. Cubitus from the Elbow to the Hand, and the f. 1. F G H I. Hand: The Leg into the f. 1. K. Thigh the f. 1. M N. Shank, and the f Foot. And foramuch as the whol Arm hangs upon the f. 1. O P Q. Shoulder bone, as the whol Leg upon the f. 4. A. Huckle bone, and thoe bones are not reckoned to appertain unto the Back-bone, the bet way is to begin our decription of the Limbs from them, viz. Of the Arm from the Shoulder-blad, and of the Leg from the Huckle-bone.

div.head: Of the Shoulder-blade and the Arm from the Shoulder to the Elbow.
div.p: The Shoulder-blade f. 1. A. Joyned to the f. 1. C. Arm, makes a Joynt: in the bending of which Joynt beneath, Kernels are placed, which are counted to be the Cloe tooles of the Chet or Heart, as the Parotides or Kernels behind the Ears, are of the brain, into which thoe Parts do empty their Excrements. The place of thee Kernels is called the Arm-Pit.Dieaes of the Kernels.
Thee Kernels do frequently Swel, Impotumate, are infected with the Kings-Evil, and ubject to Buboes, yea uch as accompany the Whores-Pox, as in the Groin.Of the whol Joynt.

This Joynt is liable to be disjointed, but it is more often vexed with the Gout, Rheumatime, and other Fluxions. The trong mel of the Arm-Holes proceeeds from thee Kernels. Upon which Martial has wittily and neatly played in one of his Epigrams.
Laedit te quaedam mala fabula, qua tibi fertur
Valle ub alarum trux habitare caper:
Hunc metuunt omnes, neque mirum, nam mala valde et
Betia.

That is,
An ill Report your Credit (Sir.) does wound,
How that a tinking Goat has dwelling found
Within your hollow Arm-Pits hady Grove,
A beat which al Men fear, and none do love;
And good Caue why &c.

div.head: Of the Cubit or part of the Arm from the Elbow to the Hand.
div.p: The Articulation of the Brachium with the Cubit, is more hardly disjoynted; admits Fluxions which do there breed divers Tumors hard to cure. In which cae,The Dieaes of the Joynts of thee Parts. unles diligent care be taken, the very bones are altered and the Cubit is made crooked, and uch as are on that manner crook't, are by Hippocrates termed Galliaggones.
If uch a croockednes be caued by a retraction of the Mucles, it is more eaily cured, than if it come from a repletion of the Cavities by a thick, clammy, condened and dryed Humor.
The Articulation of the Cubit to the Writ is ubject to many Dieaes, the Gout, the Rheumatime, the Tumor Ganglium which poees the tendons of the Mucles; Flegmatick Knobs and other Tumors.

div.head: Of the Hand.
div.p: The Hand is divided into thef. 1. F. Writ thef. 1. G H. After-Writ and thef. 1. l. Fingers. ToDieaes of the Hand. thee Parts the Dieaes lately named are common. A Dieae in number is here uual in Children from the Womb, viz. A Sixt Finger growing to the Thumb o • little Finger. It is eaily taken away, by the Inciion Knife.

div.head: Of the Nailes
div.p: The Fingers are cerminated and cloed up by the Nailes, which are liable toDieaes of the Nails. divers Dieaes, in Figure, in Magnitude, wh • l they grow thick, wrinkled, unequ • l, rough, • ooked as in leprous perons; they are alo Cleft; and fal off in the time of Sicknes and afterwards breed again. The Color of the Nailes is changed in time of Sicknes. Alo there is a ore Dieae of the Nailes termed a Whi • e-Loafe o • Felon.

A Whey i • h very harp Humor is bred under the Naile near the bone, which caues mot bitter and intollerable pains, and brings an Inflamation firt of the Hand, and after of the Arm alo, unles the Humor be let out, by cutting the pappy fleh of the Finger to the very bone.

The Pappy Ends of the F •• gers are aften corrupted, and pu • rifie, and omtimesOf the Pappy Ends of the Fingers. the lat Joynt of a Finger mut of neceity be out off, by reaon of a phacelation of the bone.

Paronyc • ia Gr • corum, viz. Opening of the Skin at the corners of the Nailes and Iuing of blood therea • , is a • leight Dieae, which does not affect the tendons and Nerves of the Fingers Ends, as that Panaritium Arabum, a Dieae of this Part decribed by the Arabia • Phyitians.

The Ancient Phyloophers, and Phyitians, were wont to Divine, and tel Fortunes, by the Nails of Mens Fingers: touching which kind of Divination, Camillus Baldus has lately written. g f. 1. A.
a T. 21. f. 1. C.
b f. 1. D E

div.head: Chap. 3. Of the Inferior Limbs.
div.p: The Inferior Limbs are commonly divided into three Parts; The Thighs, theDieaes of the inferior Limbs. Shank, and the Foot. The Os Ilium is joyned to the Thigh, and from thence we are to • ake meaure of the length of the Leg. In the bending of the Os Ilii, and the Thigh, are placed many Kernels, above and beneath; in which divers Buboes arie, both Petilential, Venereal, and pringing from common Caues: of which we have poken in our Chapter of the Per •• o • eum.

Thee inferior Limbs are liable to the ame Dieaes with the uperior, which I wil not repeat. Proud Fleh is often bred in the hinder parts by contuion of the Thighs, occaioned by long and hard itting, or riding. Fernelius does elegantly explain the material Caue hereof.

It is not caued by afflux of Humors, but only by the nourihment of the Part, which being ulcerated within or without, if it be not topped, it is by continual acces of Nutriment pread abroad, and welled, and produces oftentimes as it were certain Pipes of Veins and Arteries, by which it is nourihed. So, when the Skin remaining whol, the Fleh underneath is bruied and • orn, a mighty Swelling does arie by little and little, without any pain, but furnihed with exquiite ence, and Natural Heat.

In the Joynt of the Thigh, about the Cavity of the Huckle bone, is bred the GoutThe Sciatica. called Sciatica. If the Humor flow into the Ace • abulum, and caue the Head of the Thigh-bone to lip out of its place, it breeds a Dieae in Scituation hard to cure, and which at lat caues the Patient to hault.

If a very harp pu • rid Humor does corrode, and bring corruption into the Joynt,The Hip-Conumption. it produces a Dieae called Phthii • Coxaria, the Hip-Conumption, which makes an end of the Patient by degrees. If an Humor flow into that part where the great Nerve aries, which creeps up and down the hind parts of the Leg, Notha Ichias, The Batard Sciatica. o • a Batard Sciatica is produced.
Swellings of the Knee, either pringing from a Flegmatick Humor, or from Inflamation,Swellings of the Knee. are oftentimes very dangerous, or long-lating, and at lat do haten the Patients Death.

The Foot is divided into theT. 21. f. 1. O. Ta • us, f. 1. P. Metatarus, and thef. 1. Q. Toes. The firt Bone of the Tarus calledf. 5. B. Pte • na, is ubject to a Dieae pringing from Cold or Fluxion, which i • called Pernio, a Kibe: And becaue this Bone receives a veryKi • es. thick Tendon, if it be bruied and wounded, it caues in • vitable death, by the very Convulions thereby raied.
The Toes of the Feet, by comp •• ion, and traitnes of Shoo • or Boots, have painful Corns breeding upon them, the unw •• y ex ••• pation whereof has omtimesCorns. brought a Gangrene into the Part.

The whol Leg from the bending of the G • oyn unto the T •• s, is omtimes exceedinglyThe Legs. Elephantiais, of the Arabia ••
wollen with an hard, and il-favored Tumor, which is called Elephantiais, Arabum: The Arabian Phyitions, Elephants Leg, becaue it makes the Leg of the Patient reemble that of an Elephant.

But the Shank and Foo • are chiefly • iable to defluxions which are caued either inSwellings. uch as are newly recovered out of icknes, by • he Humors falling down into thoe parts; or primarily by the evil Dipoition of the aid parts.
The principal matter of thee Tumors, is Wind or Water, or a clammy Flegmatick Humor, which produces the welling called Oedema.

Somtimes the Toes of the Feet, as wel as the Fingers of the Hand, are deficient or uperfluous in their Number. There is a little knob grows omtimes under the little Toe called Gemura, becaue it makes the Patient groan.

Di • eaes coniting in the Evil-haping of the Shank and Foot are frequent.Ill hape Hence aroe thoe nick Names Varus, one that has crooked Legs bending inward; Valgus, one that has Legs bending outward; Compernis, one narrow between the Knees; Scauripeda, one that has hunching Ankles, that interfer and hinder his going; Panus, one that has a broad or Splay foot; Atta, he that treads only on the fore part of his Feet, as it were on Tip Toes; Plautus, he that is Splayfooted or Broad-footed, al which Infirmities are een in grown Perons and in Children.

Some are borne with their Legs contracted, others become o by ill Swadling in the time of their Infancy, and by untoward Carriage in their Nures Arms. Somtimes one foot is longer than the other which Caues halting.

Somtimes the Feet do Stink intollerably, by reaon of their much heat andStink Palie Sweat; which mut be helped. Oftentimes there happens a Palie of the lower Limbs, by reaon of a Defluxion of Humors out of the Meentery, into the Lumbal Nerves. Many times a batard Sciatica does poes the whol Thigh as low as to the Ankle-bone, even as far as that mot thick Nerve does reach, which comes from the Os Sacrum. Pains of the Knees are extream bitter and make tout Men cry out.Knees pains. Becaue of the conent the Knees had with the Veins in the Mothers Womb. And Pliny aies that a Mans life lies in his very Knees.

Fluxions of Rheum into this Joynt are long lating, dangerous and hard toWounds of the Ankle. Cure, in the Judgment of Pardus, which daily experience does confirm. And a blow or wound in the Anckle, that ame great Tendon being bruied or wounded, do bring Death, not without great Convulions, o aies Hippocrates.

div.head: Chap. 4. In what places Iues are commonly made.
div.p: NOw I wil hew you in what places Iues are to be made to purge out WheyihPlates of Iues. in The Crown of the Head. Humors, which flow either through the Veels or betw • een the Skin. I wil begin at the Head.

And firt of al an Iue may be made where the agittary and coronal Sutures meet. You may find the place by applying your Writ to the Noe of the Patient, and oberving how far you can reach upon his head with your middle Finger, for there the Iue mut be made.

Alo in the hollow part of the Occiput or hind part of the Head. But if youThe Hind part of the Head. find no fitting Cavity there, you may apply your Cautick on either ide of the Additions of the Sutura Lambidoides.
Likewie in the hollow behind the Ears, when the Eyes or Ears areFore part of the Head. Dieaed.
Somtimes on either ide of the Neck, as far as the third or fourth Vertebra. The Neck The Arm The Bret
In the middle of the Arm between the Mucles Deltois and Biceps.
In the Bret, two or three may be made according to the Longitude thereof, in Dieaes of the Chet and Lungs.

At the bending of the Buttocks, at the Ends of the Mucles cald Gloutii, whereThe Thigh the Thigh is perceived to move upon the Joynt, an Iue may be made, in a perfect Sciatica when the Humor poees the Cavity of the Joynt.
Iues are made within ide the Thigh, two Fingers above the Knee; alo on theThe Leg inide of the Leg, two Fingers beneath the Ham.
Somtimes to turn away Fluxions into the Thigh, Iues are made upon theThe Loins Loins, near the Back-bone, on each ide the aid bone.

div.head: Chap. 5. Of Veins uually opened.
div.p: I Proceed unto uch Veins of the whol body as are uually opened. VeinsThe Veins which are wont to be opened. in The Fore head Hind part of the Head. which now adaies are opened in the Head, are in the Forehead, the hinderpart of the Head, and in the Temples.

The Forehead Vein is termed T. 1. f. 1. L. T. 24. f. 1. B B. Praeparata or the ready Vein, becaue it is evident, and there is no need to Shave the Hair to come at it, as mut be done in the Vein behind the Head, which is termed Vena Puppis, the Aftenhip-Vein.

The ancients did open the Veins behind the Ears, but that operation is now out of ue: Hippocrates aies the cutting of thoe Veins made the Scythians barren; perhaps he meant the Arteries in thoe Parts. The manner of opening thee Veins Albucai does • each us in his 2. Book Chap. 97.
Neither is it unprofitable to open the Veines of the Head, by reaon of the external Veins, which through the holes of the Scul have communion with the Menings.

I know Hieronimus Fabricius ab Aqua Pendente diallowes the opening of thoe Veins, becaue oftentimes they do not appear. But if the Head be rubbed, and the Hair haved off and then again rubbed, they wil be more evident, provided you throa • le the Neck a little with a Towel or Napkin.
The b temporal Vein is alo cut as is the Artery, in great and continual pains ofIn the Temples In the Noe the Head.

The Antients did open the inner Veins of the Noe, as appears out of Hippocrates in divers places, and from Galen his 6. • o • k of Epidemicks. The later Greek writers, Paulus Aegineta and Aretaeus, men •• on •• e opening of inner Veins of the Noe: and Areteus himelf, declares the Int • u • ents which the Ancients ued, to provoke thoe Veins to bleed. • ut if • he blood, according to the Opinion of Fernelius, do flow from the Veins o • the Face, which creep into the inner Parts of the No • t • ils; the Head being opp • eed with plenty of blood, cannot be eaed, becaue that ame Irritation and opening of the Veins, ought to be per • ormed nea • the Colander bone, h • t • he Longitudinal paage creepi • g unto the Not •• ls may be opened. therefore • conceive thoe Parts are frequen • ly to be fomen • ed with Lukewarm Water, before we ue tho • e Intruments p • opounded by Aretaeus.
The manner of opening thoe Veins propounded by Albucais, may be admitted, but it does not pene • rate to the inmot Part of the No ••• ls, as far as the Colander bone.

The Veins under the Tongue termed Ra • ulares are more frequently openedIn the Mouth with good ucces, in Dieaes of the Throat and Head. Only Aurelianus againt Diocles has diallowed that Practice, alleadging that it fills the Head, and the blood cannot be topt. Lib. 1. Acut. c. 12.

True it is that in ome the blood has Iued o plentifully, that it could very hardly be topped, as was oberved in a Capuchin Friar, Father Joeph. le Clerc, the great Polititian and • amiliar friend of the Cardinal Richelieu; as Simon Pimpernel a mot expart Surgeon of Paris, hi • elf told me, he having opened the aid Veins, in the Fria • aforeaid.

In the Neck theT. 1. f. 1. H. external Jugular is opened. T • alli • nus in Cure of the SquinieIn the Neck. opened the ame with good ucces Lib 4. Cha • . 1. And Soranus Epheius, in his Introduction Chap. 12. Commends the opening of this Vein. In like manner Actuarius commends this Practice in dangerous Diea • es of the Head. Caealpinus Lib. 2. Quaet: Medic. Chap. 12. Commands the opening of this Vein in a Squinzy, becaue the Jugular Veins are more filled, than the hut cover and Mouth of the Larynx.

Proper Alpinus in his 2. Book of the Aegyptian manner of healing Dieaes Chap. 9. Writes that this is a common Remedy in that Contrey. b T. 1. f. 1. I.
c T. 1. K.

p.hi: Jacobus Corpus in his Anatomical Introductions,
p.U: hews the way to open thoe Veins. Read Paulus Magnus Lib. de Phlebotomia printed in the Italian Tongue. And Rondeletius in his Me • hod •• s Medendi; Lud • v • cus Mercatus Chap. 13. Method; Medend. And Albucais Lib. 2. Chap. 97.

div.p:
Rondeletius
• els us of a Vein in the Back Lib. 1. Methodi Melendi. Chap. 37.In the Back Which he aies is to be found, in the firt Vertebra of the Back; it is een elevated on the top of the Vertebraes, creeping down the back, as far as Os Sacrum. It eems to flow from the brain according to the Longitude of the pinal Marrow. He lets us know that this Vein is profitably opened, in the Tetanus and Falling-Sicknes, and if it be not o viible as to be opened, in that place mut Cupping-Glaes be fatened with Scarification.

Ludovicus Mercatus in Lib. 1. Practicae Cap. 19. Commends this Remedy againt the Convulion. Hippocrates in his Book de Viu, burnes and pricks the Veins of the back: which Remedy is propounded by Alexander Benedictus Lib. 1. de Morbis Curandis, c. 5. And Gattiuaria advies to open the ame in in his Comment upo • the 9. Book of Rhais.

In the Arm three Veins are opened, the Cephalick or Head Vein accompanyedIn the Arm by an T. 1. f. 1. Q. R. T. 24. f. 4. a a a. &c. Artery without any Nerve, and therefore it is opened without danger. The Bailica and Mediana are opened, but the T. 1. f. 1. M. T. 24. f. 1. C C. Bailica mut be opened with prudent warynes, by reaon of an Artery near the ame and the Tendon of Muculus Biceps, which lies beneath it: neither is the T. 1. f. 1. N. T. 24. f. 1. f f. &c. Mediana void of the like danger.

In the Hand between the Ring Finger and the little Finger the T. 1. f. 1. P. Salvatella is opened, the opening thereof many account upertition: howbeit Hippocrates opened the Veins of the Hands: and this Remedy has not been rejected by learned Phyitians, epecially in long lating Sicknees, and in the Quartan Ague at the Conjunction of the Sun and Moon: which I have known to have ucceeded happily both to other Phyitians, and to my elf, in old Quartans, after the ue of divers Medicaments.

It is not our Cutom to open the Veins in the lower part of the Thigh above the Knee: yet Lazarus Sotus aies that they are opened in Portugal in his 1 Book of Animadverions, Chap. 4. Sect. 61. To top gouty Defluxions into the Legs, and to diminih the deformity of the Varices or black woln Veins of thoe Parts, the Ancients were wont to open them. And Platerus commends this Remedy to to diminih the Varices. Which may be confirmed out of Galen Lib. 2. Method • ad Glauconem.

In the • oot is opened the a Saphena, which is above the Malleolus internus o •
In the Foot. inner Ancle bone; or the continvation thereof in Taro, or the welling ide of the Foot between the Heel and the great Toe.

Somtimes the T. 1. f. 1. SS. T. 24. f. 4. m. Ichiadica Vena or Sciatica Vein, is opened, which is Scituate in the external Ankle. But this Vein ought not to be opened without very great heed to the place where the Orifice is made, becaue of an Artery near, and Tendons very near the ame.

'Twas uual with the Ancients to open the T. 24. f. 4. f f. Ham Vein, which is now a daies eldom performed, and quite out of ue: never • heles the opening thereof would be as beneficial as is the opening of the Arm Veins.

It might be conveniently opened if the Leg be put into a Veel of hot Water above
••
• hether the Foot Veins may be opened and how? the Knee, and rubbed, as is uual in bleeding at the Arm; alo a double Ligature may be ued, one above and the other below the Knee. It is eaily found and afely opened, below the hollow of the Ham, at the beginning of the Muculi Gemelli: and a ick Woman as he lies in her bed, may as conveniently preent her Leg as the Arm, being covered with the heet or other fitting covering.

Though the Sciatica Vein and the Saphena are branches of the Crural Vein yet, becaue the Sciatica Vein does anwer the Bailica, as the Saphena does t •
Cephalica of the Arm; certain it is, blood is drawn by a more direct way fro •
the Sciatica Vein, then from the Saphena. Howbeit Galen in his econd Book Secundum Locos Chap. 2. The Sciatica Vein not appearing admits the Saphena to be opened in tead thereof. And if it appear not in the outward Ankle, its branch mut be opened, on the Tarus or pulp of the Foot beneath the Ankle, or above the Ankle, if it be viible.

Its alo poible to make it the more apparent by uch a kind of Ligature as the Author of the Book de Anatomia Vivorum has decribed, made with a long and broad Swath-band brought from the top of the Hip as low as the Ankle.

div.head: Chap. 6. Of the Arteries which are opened.
div.p: THe Ancient Phyi • ians were wont to open Arteries as wel as Veins. HowbeitWhether Arteries may be opened? Horatius Augenius in his Book of Blood-letting, diwades the opening of Arteries, becaue he never aw any Artery opened, that could be topped again, Aurelianus, Favours his Opinion, in his 1. Book of Chronick Dieaes Chap. 5. Howbeit Galen in his Book de Venae Sectione, commends the opening of the Smaller Arteries in very bitter and old paines of the Head.

Heurnius did wih, that in ome part or other it might be afe to open an Artery in burning Feavers, becaue one Porringer of the Arterial blood drawn out, would cool the Patient more, than to looe ten Porringers of the venal blood. And in his Commentary upon the 23. Aphorime of the 1. Book, he aies that in the HungarianWhat Arteries are to be opened? Feaver, when very red blood drops out at the Noe, it would do the Patient good to draw a little blood from an Artery. But who (aies he) dares open an Artery? I deire that al learned Artits would think of it.

I ay therefore, and aver, That in Paris, the Arteries of the Forehead andIn the Forehead. In the Temples Temples, before and behind the Ears, are uccesfully opened in Ancient or very acute pains of the Head, in the Phrenie, Inflamations and extream pains of the Eyes and Ears.
As for the opening of the temporal Artery Thadaeus Dunus, in the 12. Chap. Of his Micellanies, hews how profitable a Remedy, it is.
Lazarus Sotus aforementioned, in the ame place, oberves that the Arteries behind the Ears are profitably opened in Portugal.
Ludovicus Mercatus a Spanih Phyician upects this opening of thee Arteries, for fear it hould make Men Barren. But daily experience has delivered us from that fear.

An Artery eated in the hinder Part of the Head is opened, the Hair being firtIn the • ind Part of the Head. Shaven of, and the Head and hand being • omented in hot water, or rubbed with a Spunge, that it may appear. The manner of opening this Artery, is not unlike that of the temporal Artery, and therefore that ame way of Paulus Aegineta, Aetius and Albucais, is to be rejected, who did firt cut the Skin before they opened the Artery.
Galen in his Book of Blood-letting near the end, in an Inflamation of the LiverIn the Hand opened the a Artery, which Runs out between the Thumb and Fore Finger.

Which, Proper Alpinus oberves to be very uual in Egypt, in his third Book and 12. Chap. De Medicina Egypt. And Septalius in his 6. Book of Animadverions Article 122. Judges that in a Palpitation of the Heart, theIn the Foot Arteries which Run along the Fingers may afely be opened. Which may likewie be done in the Tarus and Meta-Tarus of the Foot, according to the Advice of Galen in his 3. Book of Anatomical Adminitrations, and the lat Chapter.

In other Parts Arteries may not in any wie be opened, unles they have a bone under them, that they may be preed cloe down to make the Orifice grow together again: and therefore in a lean Body, an Artery being unawars opened in the Arm, may be cloed again, if it be timly and cloely tied as is itting, to avoid Aneurima.

Before we think of opening the Arteries of the Head to turne away Fluxions,An experiment of Benedictus • or the Rheumatim. that experiment of Alexander Benedictus wil not be unprofitable, to apply unto the Shorn Head, Medicines that are to top Rheums falling into the Eyes, mut be applied from the Eye-brows unto the Crown of the Head: if the Eyes begin to appear dry, it is manifet that the Rheum falls into them by thoe Veins which are under the Skin: but if they continue moit, it is evident the Humor flows into them from under the bone.

Now the foreaid Mixture of Alexander Benedictus which tops Rheums is this. Make a Cataplame of Coure bran, • ine Frankincene, the white of an Egg, a little Vitriol and Stone Alum • and apply it as a foreaid.

div.head: Chap. 7. Of the Mucles and firt of the Forehead Mucles.
div.p: INtending to explain al the Mucles of the Body, I wil begin at the Frontal orThe Forehead Mucles hould rather be called the Eye-brow Mucles. T. 15. f. 1. E E. Forehead Mucles, which I conceive are ordained rather to move the Eyebrows, than the Forehead it elf.

They have their original from the upper Parts of the Forehead, and being pread ou • upon the bone thereof, they end at the Eye-brows, that they might lift them up. They are evered in the midt of the Forehead, right above the Noe. And becaue we do at our pleaure depres and draw together our Eye-Lids into wrinkles, we mut aigne to each of them its Mucle, and I can find no other ave the Orbicular T. 15. f. 1. F F. Mucle of each Eye-Lid; for the Eye-brows cannot be drawn down without the Eye-Lids be cloly <> .

div.head: Chap. 8. Mucles of the hinder Part of the Head.
div.p:
IN the after Head are found Mucles, or rather flehy Membranes, which draw backwards the Skin of the Head in uch perons as have the aid Skin movable. Thee Mucles, as alo thoe of the Forehead, are portions of the Muculus Latus or Broad <> ; which Sylvius does neatly compare to a riding Hood, taking away only as much as is covered with a little cap on the top of a Mans Head: and therefore the broad Mucle does cover the Neck, Face, Fore and ide Parts of the Head. a T. 15. f. 1. E E.
b T. 15. f. 1. F F.

div.head: Chap. 9. Mucles of the Eye-Lids.
div.p: THe two Eye-Lids are moved by four Mucles, of which three are orbicular, and one is traight belonging to the upper Eye-Lid, which aries at the internalThe firt. Cavity of the Eye, and being pred out upon the Mucles, which lifts up the Eye, it <> unto the Eye-Lid.

The firt of the <> or round Mucles, is the Muculus Ciliaris, whichThe econd. compaeth about each of the Eye-Lids. The other is drawn out under the Eyelid, ariing from the Circumference of the Orbita or Socket of the Eye.

The • third round Mucle being of a Fingers breadth, compaes the Surface of theThe Third. Orbita or Socket, and being placed under each Eye-Lid, and reaching as far asThe fourth the Eye-brow, and cloly hutting the two Eye-Lids, it lifts up the lower and draws down the Eye brow.

div.head: Chap. 10. Mucles of the Eyes.
div.p: THere are reckoned ix Mucles of the Eye, four Straight and two Oblique, The Attollens. which are named from their Scituation and action. One is termed T. 19. f. 3. A. 4. 5. A. Supernus and Attollens Oculum, the upper, and the Eyes up lifter; another is called f. • . 4. 5. Infernus The Deprimens and Deprimens Oculum, the lower and Eye Depreer; of the two Lateral or ide Mucles, one at the greater corner of the Eye is termed f. 3, 4, 5. C. Lectorius, theThe Adducens Readers or the Students Mucle; the other placed at the maller corner is called f. 3, 4, 5. D. Indignatorius, the Dideigners Mucle.
They al arie from the Cavity of the Socket of the Eye and the broad NervousThe Abd •• ent production, and are inerted into the Cornea Tunica under the Conjunctiva.
The Contranitency of thee Mucles pulling one againt another is neceary, that the Eye might be movable to and fro, which being depraved, the Eye is drawn to ome one ide, and o abides in that poture.

And that the Eye might be drawn back towards the greater Corner, and might be fixed in continual reading or looking upon omwhat, Nature has framed two other Mucles, which are termed Oblique, becaue they direct the Oblique motion of the Eye, which is none at al, neither can the Mucles themelves perform uch a Motion in regard of their Original and Inertion, which ought to be contrary and oppoite.

The Muculus Obliquus T. 19. f. 1. A B. Major, greater Oblique Mucle, or Trochleator, conteinsThe Obliquus Ma •• r. in it a wonderful peice of Workmanhip, which is found in Mankind, detected by Rondeletius and oberved in ome great Fihes: for taking its rie from the Cavity of the Orbita, it produces a thin Tendon, which being drawn through a Tranvere T. 15. f. 1. F F. Gritle affixed unto the bone, by and beneath the Glandula Lachrymalis or weeping Kernel, is after widened and pread out upon the Eye.

The Obliquus f. 3. and 4. E. Minor drawn out externally by the greater Corner, and rowledThe Obliquus Minor. athwart about the Globe of the Eye, comes as far as the Tendon of the greater Oblique Mucle, that the Nervous productions of both the Oblique Mucles might meet together to draw back and • ix the Eye towards the Noe, that from both the Eyes beholding, one Pyramid Li • e may pas unto the viible Object. a T. 19. f. 3. and 4. F.
b f. 3. and 4. G.

div.head: Chap. 11. Mucles of the external Ear.
div.p: THey are common and proper, which are Seldom moved, becaue the Ear itOf the external Ear. elf is rarely moved. They are therefore rather marks and igns of Mucles, than true ones, uch as are found in Brute Beats which move their Ears.

And therefore a portion of the frontal Mucle reaching unto the Ear, a portion ofThe common. the Cutaneous or Skin Mucle drawn unto the Pulp of the Ear, and a Part of the Occipital or after Head Mucle, tretched out behind the Ears, do make the common Mucles.
There is only one proper Mucle, which lurks under the LigamentOne proper. of the Ear, it aries, from the Mammillary Proces, and is inerted into the Root of the Ear.

The later Anatomits do make reckoning of two Mucles appertaining to the internalInternal Ears Ear, one of which is T. 19. f. 3. and 4. F. external in the auditory paage or hole of the Ear,Firt. Second which draws back the Membrane of the Ear: the other is within the f. 3. and 4. G. Concha, fatened to the Mallet or Hammer.

In Bruts the Mucles of the internal Ea • are more evident than in Men 3 f. 3. and 4. E.
• T. 20. f. 5. A.
b T. 20. f. 5. C C.

div.head: Chap. 12. Mucles of the Noe.
div.p: THey are common and proper.One Common.
The common is only one, being the upper portion of that Orbicular Mucle which compaes the T. 15. f. 1. N N Lips, which draws the No • e downwards, when the upper Lip is drawn down.

Two T. 15. f. 1. G. Mucles do lift up the Noe, on each ide one, drawn from the pace between
••• proper. the Eye-brows and fatened to the bone of the Noe, and o carried to the wings or battlements thereof; the motion of thee Mucles, when they act together is eaily perceived in the drawing up and cri • ping or wrinkling of the Noe.
In Perons that are largly Noed, twoT. 15. f. 1. I. little Mucles are found, pred upon the extream Gritles of the No • e, which do widen the Laps of the Noe, without any elevation or lifting up.

Within the Notrils under the Succingent Coat, there lies lurking a little Mucle of a Membranous Na • ure, which does tick to the internal Parts as far as the Laps of the Noe, it is aid to contract the Notrils.

div.head: Chap. 13. Mucles of the Lips
div.p: SEeing there are two Lips, each has its Mucles, and there are two common to both.

The upper Lip is drawn upwards by a T. 15. f. 1. K. Mucle which taking its rie from the hollowThe fi • t of the proper ones. of the Jaw, benea • h the Cheek bone, de • cends obliquely or la • ting to the upper Lip.
It is moved downwards by a f. 1. M. Mucle brought from the middet of the lower Jaw,The econd. into the aid Lip.
The nether Lip is drawn upwards by a Mucle, which being drawn out of theThe third. lower Parts of the Cheek bone, does • nd ide waies upon the nether Lip.
I • is moved downwards by a f. 1. N. Mucle, which Springing out of the Chin, is inertedThe fourth. into the middle Lip.

The common Mucles are the lateral on ••
which do draw the Lips to the right orThe common ones. 1 Zygomaticus. 2 Buccinator. left ide
The firt is called f. 1. L. Zygomaticus, being omwhat long and thin, and ariing from the bone Zygoma, it is • erminated in the meeting of each Lip.

The ot • er common one, is vulgarly termed f. 1. O. Buccinator or the Trumpeter, it were more rightly called Bucco the Cheek driver, becaue it tirs the Cheeks, wh ••
•• drives the meat this way and that way, in the action of chewing.

It aries • rom the top of the Gums or the bones in that place near the farthet grinders, and ends in each Lip. It is looe and • ack, that it may give way inwards, and perform its Office of forcing, as the Mucles of the belly do; and that it may give way, when the Mouth • apes wide.

There is added a round f. 1. NN Mucle, which makes the proper ubtance of the Lips,Sphincter of the Mouth by the ervice whereof the Mouth, is drawn together, the Lips are opened, go inwards, and wel. It might wel be called the Sphincter of the Mouth, or the Pylorus.

div.head: Chap. 14. Mucles of the lower Jaw.
div.p: THey are on either ide ix. TheT. 15. f. 1. P P. f. 2. A A. Temporal Mucle, being a very trong oneThe Temporal li • ts up the Jaw. It aries from the whol Cavity of the Temples, and being carried along under the Os Zygoma, it is by a very trong nervous Tendon inerted into the harp a proces of the Jaw-bone.

This Mucle is aited by the Pterygoideus f. 2. D D. Internus, ariing from the Cavity ofPterygoideus Internus. the Apophyis Pterygoides, and terminated at the corner of the inferior Jaw. It is called by Galen Maeter Internus.
The Jaw is drawn down wards by the Digatricus or Twi-Belly'd Mucle, andDigatricus. the Muculus Latus or Broad Mucle.

The Digatricus or Twi-Belly, being in thef. 1. T T. f. 2. C C middle Nervous and flehy at the Ends, prings from the Apophy •• Styloides, and being in the Middle reflexed about the Stylo-Ceratoides, it is inerted into the Chin, under the bending of the Jaw.

The Muculus
T. 10. f. 1. < in non-Latin alphabet > . T. 15. f. 2. F. Latus or Broad-Belly, aries from the upper Part of the Bretbone,The Latus. the Clavicula and Shoulder point, and cleaves firmly to the Bais of the inferior Jaw, mu • fling the Neck and whol Face; and by reaon of the afore-aid Adheion, it is aid to draw the Jaw downwards.

Pterygoideus
T. 15. f. 2. E E E E. Externus, the external wing fahiond Mucle forces the JawPterygoideus Externus. forwards, which being welled does lightly drive the Jaw-bone forewards: which happens in the overhooting of the Jaw-bone, when the lower Teeth are above the upper Teeth.

The Jaw is plucked about this way and that way by the Maeter or Chaw Mucles being in its Original Twi-Headed, one of whoe heads aries from the Os Zygoma, Maeter. the other beneath the aid bone; each of which being furnihed with divers Fibres which Cros one another, is inerted into the Corner of the inferior Jaw. It may eaily be divided into two Parts.

div.head: Chap. 15. Of the Mucles of the Os Hyoides.
div.p: BEcaue the bone termed T. 13. f. 11. and 12. A B C. &c. Hyoides, is placed in the Neck to a prop and foundation for the Tongue and Larynx, it has obtained Mucles as wel as Ligaments, by which it is held upended, that it might be moved with the Tongue and Larynx.
And therefore its Mucles are common to the Tongue and the Larynx.

The bone Hyoides has ten Mucles, on each ide five, for I add the Mucle termed Myloglous (which is commonly attributed unto the Tongue) and I cal it Mylohyoideus, becaue, it does not any waies touch the Tongue. b T. 15. f. 2. a a.
f f. 1. S. f. 2. B B.

The Os Hyoides is l •••• d up by the MucleT. 13. f. 13. B B. Geniohyoideus, it aries from withinThe Genio
• yoideus. Mylobyoideu the Chin and is inerted into the Ba • is of the Hyoides.
Aitant hereunto is the Muclef. 4. E E. Mylohyoideus, i • aries from within the Jaw in the Quarters of the Grinding Teeth, and reaches to the Bai • of the Bone Hyoides.

The bone Hyoides is drawn downwards by the Mucle c S • ernohyideus which
<>
prings from the top of the Bret bone, and drawn o • t upon the Wean • is inerted into the Bais or bottom, of the aid bone Hyoides.
The Muclef. 13. D D. Stylocerathyoideus, from the Apophyis Styloides is carriedStylocerathyoideus. into the Horns of the Os Hyoides.

div.head: Chap 16 Mucles of the Tongue.
div.p: THe Tongue is forced forward by the Mucle f. 13. C C. Genyoglous, which growing outGenyoglous. of the inner ide of the Chin, is terminated to the Tongues Root.
It is drawn back by the Mucle f. 14. B B. Baiglous which takes its rie at the Bais ofBaiglous. Os Hyoides, and is carryed unto the Root of the Tongue.

It is forced idewaies to the right and left, by the Mucle
