• . 14. D D. Stylogous, whichStylogous. taking its beginning at the Apophyis Styloides, is extended into the middle, very near of the Tongue. d f. 1. E E.

div.head: Chap 17 Mucles of the Larynx.
div.p: THe whol body of the Larynx coniting of five Gritles, is moved upwards and downwards.
It is drawn upwards by the Mucle T. 13 f. 8. B B. Hyothyroideus, which ariing from theHyothyroideus. Bais of the Hyoides bone, is inerted into the external middlemot of the Thyroides.

The Mucle f. 8. C C. Bronchius draws it downwards, which taking its rie, from the
<> . inner ide of the Bret bone, and tre • ched out upon the Channel of the Apera Arteria or Weand, it acends unto the Ba • of Thyroides.

Two only of the Gritles of the Larynx are movable, viz. The f. 1, 2. 8. A. Thyroides and the f. • . and 6. A • yt • noides, and to procure their motion they have little Mucles, which pring out of the immovable Gritle Cricoides.
The Thyroides is dilated by the Mucle Cricothyroideus Anticus, which beginsCr • cothyroid ••• Anticus. at the ou •• er forepart of Cricoides, and ends within the internal ides of Thyroides.
The aid Thyroides is contracted by the Mucle f. 9. C C. Cricothyroideus Lateralis, Lateralis. which pri •• ing from the lateral part of Cricoides, is inerted externally into the ides of Thyroides.

The A • ytaenoides is opened by the Mu • cle f. 9. B B. Thyroaryt • noideus, which pringingThyroaryt •
noideus. from the inner and foremot part of the Thyroides, ends into the ides of the Ary • enoides: or rather it takes its rie from the Cricoides and Thyroides, being placed between both.

The Arytaenoides is hut by one only Mucle called Arytaenoideus, which f. 10. B B. compaes about and huts the Arytaenoides, like the Sphincter Mucle, and aloAryt • noideus. with its Bais it Streightens the Glottis, • or to make the voyce • ound the better.

The Epiglotti •
has f. 9. and 10. A. no Mucles to lift it up and hut it down in Mankind, as it has in Brute •• ats.f. 3. and 4. f. 9. and 10. D D.

div.head: Chap 18 Mucles o • the Pharynx.
div.p: THe Pharynx which is the beginning of Oeophagu • or the Gullet, has obtained from <> even Mu • cles, of which three have • ellows and the fourth is without companion namely that which is termed Oeophag • us.

The ••• t is T. 3. f. 2. and 3. B B. Spheno-Pharing • us, which aries from a certain harpSpheno-Pharing •• . point of the Sphenoides nea • the Styloides, and bending a little downwards, it ends in the ides of the Jaws, that it may draw the Pharynx upwards.

The econd is f. 2. and 3. A A. Cephalo-Pharyngaeus, which aries from that part where theCephalopharyngaeus. Head is Joyned to the Neck, and decending is pread out into the Pharynx, and eemes to make the very coat thereof.
The third is f. 2. and 3. C C. StyloPharyngaeus, which aries from the Apophyis Styloides, Stylopharyngaeus. Oeophagaeus. and is implanted into the ide of the Pharynx, to erve to widen the • ame.

The Mucle Oeophageus, does draw together and cloe the f. 2. and 3. D D. Pharynx, which growing out of one ide of Thyroides, and compaing round the hinder part of Oeophagus, is implanted into the other ide of Thyroides; or being outwardly fatened to both ides of Thyroides, it draws together the beginning of the Oeophagus and purles the ame like the Sphincter Mucle of Anus.

div.head: Chap. 19. Mucles of the Gargareon, Uvula, or Mouth Palat.
div.p: THe vula has two Mucles T. 13. f. 15. A. on either ide.

The Mucle Ptery-Staphylinus f. 15. B B. externus, taking its Rie from the upperPterytaphylinus externus. Jaw under the lat grinding Tooth, ends in a mal Tendon f. 15. b b. which paes through a chink ingraven on the upper ide of the Pterygoides: and there being turned back, as it were through a pulley, it is inerted into the ides of the vula.

The Ptery-Staphylinus f. 15. C C. internus, cat out of the nether part of the inner SkirtInternus. of the Pterygoides, it has a peculiar movable Gritle ordained for its original, and acending according to the Longitude of the internal Wing or Skirt of the Pterygoides, it ends at the vula.

div.head: Chap. 20. Mucles of the Head.
div.p: THe Mucles of the Head are proper or Common.
The Common are thoe which move the Neck and Head both; uch as are the Mucles of the Neck: the proper are uch as move the Head, the Neck remaining unmoved.
Now the proper are fourteen, on each lide even, ix of which are placed in the hinder part.

There is one only in the Fore part, which is called T. 14. f. 2. K K. f. 3. H. f. 4. F F. Matoideus, andCaput flectens. Matoideus. bows the Head; it aries from the top of the Bret bone and middet of the Clavicula, and is obliquely inerted into the Apophyis Matoides.

Somtimes in the forepart of the Neck, there is another Mucle next the Long Mucle, which helps the Motoideus to bend the Head: and I have many times hewed this Mucle, and omtimes I have een it wanting.
Six Mucles do extend the Head: of which two are large, the otherExtenders. four mal

The firt of the larg ones is calledf. 2. H H. Splenius; which ariing from the harp pointsSplenius. of the • ive uppermot Vertebra's of the back, and the four lowet of the Neck, it is in • erted into the hinder part of the Head.

There comes the other large Mucle to ait the former, and is called f. 2. I I. f. 3. E F. Complexus.
• omplexus. It prings from the tranvere or overthwart Eminencies or Apophyes of the foreaid Vertebra's, and is terminated in the after part of the Head.
The leer Mucles are ome traight, others crooked, and of both thee, omeRectus major are greater, others le • s.
The greater f. 3. and 4. I I. traight Mucles, ariing from the Spine or point of the econd pondile, Vertebra or Knuckle, are inerted into the after ide of the Head.
Under them the f. 3. i. f. 4. K K. two leer ariing from the hinder part of the firt Vertebra, areRectus minor terminated in the after ide of the Head.

The greater T. 14. f. 3. L. f. 4. G G. Oblique ones do arie from the pine or point of the econd Vertebra Obliquus mijor. Obliquus major. and reach unto the overthwart Eminence or Apophyis of the firt Vertebra; and from the ame place the Leer T. 14. f. 3. K. f. 4. H H. Oblique or crooked ones do arie and are terminated in the Occiput, or after Part of the Head.

div.head: Chap. 21. Mucles of the Neck.
div.p: THe Neck has eight, on each ide four, being placed before and behind, to bendThe Neck benders. The Longus. the Neck and extend the ame again.
It is bent by the Muculus Longus and the Mucle Scalenus or the unevenided Mucle.

The T. 13. f. 18. A A. Long Mucle being ituate under the Oeophagus, prings out of the body of the third Vertebra or Knuckle bone of the back, and acends laterally connexed or knit unto al the bodies of the Vertebra's, ending into the former part of the firt Vertebra.

The Scalenus ariing from the T. 13. f. 18. B B. firt Rib of the Chet, it is inwardly ingraftedThe Scalenus. by oblique Fibres into al the overthwart or tranvere Eminencies of the Neckbones: through it the Veels are drawn, which are to be ditributed into the Arm.
The Neck is extended or tretched out by two Mucles.The Extenders Spinatus
The Spinatus Mucle T. 14. f. 4. D D. aries from the Roots of the even uppermot Vertebra's of the Chet and five of the Neck; and is inerted into the Spina or point of the econd Vertebra of the Neck.

The Mucle Tranverarius, ariing from the T. 14. f. 4. E E. tranvere Apophyes or EminenciesTranverarius. of the ix uppermot Vertebra's of the back, is planted externally into al the tranvere Eminencies of the Neck.

div.head: Chap 22, Mucles of the Shoulder-blades.
div.p: THey are four in Number. The Mucle Levator g Proprius, does lift up theShoulder blads liter. Shoulder blade. It aries from the tranvere or overthwart Apophyes or Emineneies of the econd, third and fourth Vertebra of the upper part of the Neck, and ends in the uppermot Corner of the Shoulder-blade.

The Mucle Trapezius a aries from the hinder part of the Head, at the PointsTrupezius. of five Vertebra's of the Neck, and of eight or nine of the uppermot Vertebra's of the Chet, and is inerted into the Bais of the Shoulder blad and the Spina, as far as the houlder tip. It caues divers motions according to the original and direction of the Fibres; that is, according to their Rie and inertion.
The Shoulder-blad is drawn forwards by one only Mucle termed Serratus Serratus minor b Minor, which aries out of the four upper mot Ribs, and ends in the Coracoides.

It is drawn backwards by the c Rhomboides o • lozing fahioned, or diamandRhomboides fahond Mucle, which aries from the three points of the lower Vertebraes of the
Neck, and the three points of the uppermot ertebraes of the Chet, and is inerted into the external Bais of the Shoulder-blade.

Although by its own weight it return to the natural Scituation: yet a d portion of Muculus Latiimus, running out unto the Arm, cleaves by a loop to the lower Corner of the Shoulder-Blade, and is aid to draw the Shoulder-Blade downwards.

div.head: Chap. 23. Mucles of the Arm.
div.p: THey are nine. The Mucle Deltoides and Supra Spinatus do move it upwards.Arm lifters.
The Deltoides e does arie from the middet of the Clavicula, the Shoulder tip,Deltoides the whol pine of the Shoulder-blade, and is carried out unto the middle of the Arm.
The Suprapinatus being thrut into the Cavity above the Spina or harp pointSuprapinatus of the Scapula, and being conveighed under the Shoulder tip, is inerted into the Neck of the Arm.

The Latiimus and Rotundus Major, do move the Arm downwards: the Latiimus The depreers Latiimus. g prings from the harp prominencies of the Os Sacrum, of the Vertebraes of the Loins, and of nine Vertebraes of the Back: it is inerted into a part of the Arm, not far below the Head.
It is aited by Rotundus a Major or the larger round Mucle, which aries fromRotundus major. the whollower Rib of the Shoulder-blade, and ends very near in the middle of the Arm.

The Pectoralis and Coracoidaeus draw it forward. The Pectoralis aries outThe drawers to. The Pectoralis. of the firt ixt and eventh true Ribs, the Bret-bone and more than the middle of the Clavis; and it is inerted by an acute Tendon into the middle of the Arm between the Deltoides and the Biceps.
The Mucle Coracoidaeus c prings out of the Apophyis Coracoides, and endsCoracoidaeus. very near in the middle of the Arm; it draws the Arm towards the left Shoulder.
The Arm is moved backwards by three Mucles, Infrapinatus, Rotundus Drawers back. Minor, and Immerus.
The Infrapinatus ariing in the middle between d the leer round Mucle andInfrapinatus the Spina, ends into the Neck of the Arm which is muffles about.
The Rotundus e minor begins at that Cavity which appears under the lower RibRotundus minor. of the Shoulder-blade, and ends in the Neck of the Arm.
Immerus or the f Subcapularis does poes the hollow and inward Part of theImmerus Omoplata or Shoulder-blade, and is carryed out unto the Neck.
The three lat Mucles which act al at once, do carry about the Arm upwards with a udden motion flanting outwards, o that the motion eems to be doubled.

div.head: Chap. 24. Mucles of the Cubit.
div.p: THe Cubit conits of two Bones, which as they are Knit together by divers Articulations, o do they perform divers motions.
The Cubitus guides the motions of the Bending and extending. The Radius directs the motions of Pronation and Supination, and therefore they have proper Mucles for thee motions.
The Cubit is bended by two Mucles Scituate in the internal Part of the Arm viz. Cubit benders The Biceps and Brachiaeus internus.

The Biceps aries from a a double beginning, the one of which from the extremityBiceps of the Cavity of the Glenois is conveyghed through the cleft of the Arm, the other taking its Rie from the Apophyis Coracoides, they are after united and make one
Tendon, which is inerted into the inner Part of the Radius, there where is bunches out.

The Brachiaeus b Internus, being placed beneath the Biceps, takes its rie from the middle of Os Brachij, unto which it firmly adheres, a • d is terminated betweenBrachiaeus internus. the Radius and the Cubitus, in that Part where they are fatened together.
The Cubit is extended by •• ur Mucles, Viz. Longus, Brevis Brachiaeus Cubit extenders. Longus externus, and Angoneus or Cubitalis.
Longus, the long Mucle c aries from the lower Rib of the Shoulder-blade near the Neck, where it has a peculiar Cavity, and it is terminated into the Elbow.
Brevis, the hort Mucle, d prings from the hinder Neck of the Arm and endsBrevis. likewie at the Elbow. Both thoe Mucles do make up one trong and inewy Tendon.

For the third Mucle Galen in the firt Book and lat chapter of his Anatomical Adminitrations, reckons a lump of Fleh which is confounded with the two foregoingBrachiaeus externus. Mucles, and inerted into the ame place. I cal it Brachiaeus externus, becaue being pred upon the outide of the Arm, it is placed beneath the other two lat mentioned. In the ame place Galen does acquaint us, that any man may accurately eparate thee three Mucles following the rectitude of the Fibres.

The fourth Mucle called e Angoneus, is Scituate in the bending of the Cubit onAngoneus. the hinder ide, which is called Agcoon or Ancoon and anwers to the Muculus Poplitaeus. It aries out of the lower and hinder Part of the Arme, being Scituate between the Radius and Cubitus: and it is inerted by a inewy Tendon into the ide of the Cubitus, a Thumbs length below. Somtimes •• cleaves o fat to the Flehy end of Brachiaeus Externus, that there is no apparent difference to be dicerned between them; and then it is Judged to be a portion of the Brachiaeus externus, extended o far as to that place.

div.head: Chap. 25. Mucles of the Radius.
div.p: THe Radius is bowed downwards by the two internal Mucles, o called becaueThe Radius its they are placed in the inner Part of the Cubit; and one is called Inferior Pronator, and the other Superior Pronator.

The Superior being a T. 22. f. 1. and 3. D. round Mucle, prings form the inner Part of the inner knob of the Arm, and ends with a Membranous Tendon, obliquely carried untoPronator uperior. Pronator inferior. the Radius.

The Inferior Pronator
T. 10. f. 1. A. B. T. 12. f. 1. E. Quadratus, is carried overthwart from the lower Part of the Cubit unto the lower Part of the Radius, and is thereinto inerted, being altogether Flehy. Alo it Knits the lna to the Radius, as if • t were a Ligament.
The Radius is drawn down backwards by two external Mucles.

The Longus T. 22. f. 1. H. Supinator, prings out of the top of the Arm, above the externalSupinator Longus. Supinator Brevis. Knob, and being drawn out upon the Radius, it is inerted on the inide of the lower Epiphyis thereof, being flehy.

Brevis Supinator, ariing out of the T. 22. f. 3. B. outide of the inner Knob, is carried obliquely very near to the middle of the Radius, and turning back does traitly comprehend the ame. a T. 22. f. 1. G. d T. 22. f. 1. I I. f. 2. B. c T. 22. f. 3. E. d T. 22. f. 3. F. e T. 22. f. 3. • . f. 4. G.
a T. 22. f. 2. C. b T. 22. f. 2. D. c T. 22. f. 4. E. d T. 22. f. 4. F.
e T. 22. f. 2. and 3. C.
f T. 22. f. 1. B.

div.head: Chap. 26. Mucles of the Writ.
div.p: THe Writ is bended, tretched forth and laterally moved by two Mucles, the bender and extender of each ide, acting both together.
It is bended by two inward Mucles, of which the one may be termed Cubiteus, Writ-benders the other Radieus, by reaon of their Scituation.

The Cubiteus T. 22. f. 1. N. internus takes its rie from the inner part of the inner Knob of theCubiteus Internus. Arm, and being fatened unto the Cubit and to the fourth Writ bone of the firt Rank, it is drawn out aloft.

The Radieus T. 22. f. 1. M. Internus, having its original in the ame place, and being tretchedRadieus Internus. out upon the Radius, is inerted into that bone of the Metacarpium, which utaines the fore Finger.
The Writ is extended by two external Mucles, which hold the ame way withWrit extenders the internal, and are therefore called by the ame names.

The Radieus T. 22. f. 3. H. externus or Bicornis, takes its rie from that bony point which isRadieus Externus. in the Arm above the Knob thereof, and reting upon the Radius, it ends forth a double Tendon, the one of which is inerted into the Writ bone lying under the Radius, the other into that bone of the Metacarpium which is eated under the fore Finger.

Some wil have this Mucle to be a double one, becaue it appears wholly ditinct in its original and inertion. For that which is carryed to the Writ grows out of the bony point of the Arm: the other aries out of the external Knob of the Arm and extends the Metacarpium with the Writ.
It has its Tendons eparated and incloed in peculiar caes and heaths, which are of a inewy Gritly ubtance, without the Ring fa •… iond Ligament of the Writ.

The Cubiteus T. 22. f. 3. G. externus, ariing from the outward Apophyis of the Arm, andCubiteus externus. being carryed along the Cubit, it inerts its Tendon into the fourth bone of the Metacarpium, Scituate beneath the little Finger.

div.head: Chap. 27. Mucles of the Palme of the Hand.
div.p: IN the Palm or Hollow of the Hand are found two notable Mucles, which are termed the Palmar Mucles, the one of which is hort, the other long.
The long Palmar Mucle growing out of the T. 22. f. 1. K. inner ide of the knob of theLong Palmar Mucle. Arm, is pred into the hollow of the Hand, as far as the firt Articulation of the Fingers.

In its original it is Flehy and preently after leens it elf into a mal Tendon, which paing above the Ring-hap'd Ligament of the Writ, and not included with the ret of the Tendons, it is widened into a inewy Membrane, which is o firmly fatened unto the Skin (to make the ence of feeling the more quick, and that the Hand may hold things the fater) that it is a very hard thing to ever it from the Skin.

Beides the Palmar Mucle in the hollow of the Hand, a Certain peice of Fleh Short Palmar Mucle. four Square of a Thumbs breadth is found upon the Ring-haped Ligament, which is redder then the Fleh, between the Thumb and the middle Finger, and is omtimes ingle and omtimes double, looking like two Mucles: and being carryed under and implicated with the Palmar Mucle, it eems to take its rie from the Root of the Flehy part of the Hand called Thenar, and to be inerted into that ame eigth bone of the Writ, which is placed out of order.
Its Office is to hollow the Hand and o to make Diogenes his Dih to drink on of, together with the Mucles of the Thumb and the Hypothenar. This Mucle hal be named Palmaris brevis; the hort Palm Mucle.

div.head: Chap. 28. Mucles of the Fingers.
div.p: THe Fingers are bended, tretched out, and moved idewaies.Four Finger benders.
There are two Mucles which bend the four Fingers, viz. The Muculus Sub • imis, and the Muculus Profundus.

The Sublimis aries from the inner, T. 22. f. 1. O. f. 5. A. part of the inner knob of the Arm, and producesSublimis foure T. 22. f. 5. a a a a. Tendons about the Writ, which are terminated at the econd Articulation of the Fingers, and have holes bored in them, to give paage to the Tendons of the Muculus Profundus.

The Profundus prings out of the T. 22. f. 1. P. f. 5. B. upper parts of the Cubitus and Radius andProfundus. being T. 22. f. 5. b b b b. divided into four, it is carryed through the holes of the Tendons of the Sublimis, unto the third Articulation of the Fingers.

Do but oberve the Indutry of Nature, who to the end the Fingers might be rightly bended, on the inide according to their length, he has framed a Channel of mot hard Membranes reembling Ligaments, which Channel does traitly infold the Tendons of the Muculus Profundus and Sublimis, leat in the bending of the Fingets the Tendons being bowed hould be drawn out of their place, and like ropes rie up and lift up the Skin.
And although the Tendons be cloely comprehended within the aid Channel, yet have they their fre • coure and paage, becaue the Channel is meared with a fat a • d Oyly Humor.

Out of the very Tendons of Muculus profundus by the Writ, do arie theLumbricales four T. 22 f. 5. C C C C. Lumbricales, being firmly fatened thereunto, and carried to the firt Articulation of every Finger, where they unite themelves to the Interoeans.
The Mucles which extend the Fingers are Common and proper. Extenders Extenor Magnus. •

I cal them common, which erve the four Fingers, uch as the Extenor magnus Digitorum [the great extender of the Fingers] or which beide extenion, do caue other motions, as the Lumbracales and Interoei joyned together.
The proper are they which belong and are attributed only to certain Fingers, as the Extenor Indicis [tretcher out of the fore Finger] and the Extenor Auricularis [tretcher out of the little Finger.

Magnus Extenor Digitorum, the great T. 22. f. 3. K. Finger tretcher aries out of the outward Knob of the Arm, and by the f. 3. e. Writ is cloven into four f. 3. f f f f. Tendons, which end into the two lower Joynts of each Finger.
The Fingers are moved idewaies, which motion is commonly termed adductionSide way movers. and Abduction.

The Adduction or drawing to, is when they are drawn towards the Thumb; Abduction or drawing from, is when they are moved idewaies from the Thumb And this motion is performed by the Interoean Mucles: of which there areInteroeans three f. 4. I I I I. External and as many f. 2. f f f f. Internal, pred in the paces between the Bones of the Metacarpium.

They arie from the upper Parts of the aid bones near the Writ, and in the firt Internodeum or pace between the Joynts, with a very mal Tendon, they creep ide longs over the three bones of the Fingers, until they come unto the Roots of the Nailes; in the former and upper Part whereof, the Tendons, being firt united are terminated. And therefore the Interoean Mucles acting together, do keep the Fingers both tretched out, and one cloe to another, jut as we hold out hands when we wim.

Moreover you hal oberve two Mucles, which are as it were external interoeans,Proper. which are pred without, upon the • irt and fourth bone of the Metacarpium, the one of which called f. 2. g. h. f. 1. S. Hypothenar, is Peculiar to the little Finger, andAbductor minimi. may be divided into two.
It aries from the third and fourth Writ bone of the econd Rank, and is idewales inerted into the Joynts of the ame Finger, to draw the ame towards the outide.

The other belongs unto the fore Fingers, and lying beneath the Antithenar, itAbductor Indicis. it grows out of the inner Part of the firt bone of the Thumb and is inerted into the Joints of the Fore Finger, to draw the ame unto the Thumb. So that it may be called Muculus Abductor Indicis.

Beides the Tendon of the common extender, it has a Peculiar extenive Mucle, Proper extenders. Of the fore Finger. which may be termed Indicator the
• . 3. I. Pointer, becaue this Mucle erves the Finger to point withal.
It aries from the middle and external Part of the Cubit, and is inerted by a forked Tendon into the econd Articulation: and the other Tendon grows together with the Tendon of the greater extender.

There is a Proper extender acribed to the little Finger. It aries out of the upperOf the little Finger. Part of the Radius being eated between the Cubitus and the Radius, and it is with a double Tendon planted into the little Finger on the outide thereof, but with another tendon it is mingled with the Tendon of the greater extender.

Mean while you hal oberve the Lumbrical or worm Mucles, which are omtimes three, other whils four, eldom five: which though they are implicated with the Tendons of Muculus Profundus, and are contantly thought to arie there from; yet I conceive, they are bred out of the inewy and orbicular T. 22. f. 3. • . Ligament of the Writ, that it might have a firm and table Original.

div.head: Chap. 29. Mucles of the Thumb.
div.p: THe Thumb has peculiar Mucles, whereby it alone is bended, extended and moved idewaies.Thumb Mucles

It is Extended by two long Mucles. One of which ariing out of the T. 22. f. 3. M. upperExtenders and outward ide of the Cubit, goes up upon the Radius, and being carried beyond the Writ, it is inerted into the firt and econd Joynt of the Thumb, by a double and omtimes a triple Tendon.
The other aries from the T. 22. f. 3. L. ame Part of the Cubit, but lower, near the Writ, and is inerted into the third Joynt of the Thumb.
The Thumb is bended by T. 22. f. 2. D. one Mucle, which growing out of the Inide of theBender. Cubit, it carryed unto the econd and third Joynt thereof.
It is moved idewais by two Mucles.Lateral movers.
The Thenar T. 22. f. 4. K. aries from the inide of the Writ, beneath the Thumb, and is inerted into the econd Joynt of the Thumb, to draw it from the Fingers.

The other Mucle termed T. 22. f. 1. Q. f. 2. F. Antithenar, draw • the Thumb towards the • ore
Finger. It grows out of the external ide of the firt bone of the Metacarpium which utains the Thumb, and is inerted into the firt Joynt of the aid Thumb.

It is drawn to the four other Fingers by a T. 22. f. 1. R. f. 2. G. Mucle, which being Joyned unto, and eated beneath the Thenar, grows out of the three lower bones of the Metacarp • um, and is inerted into the econd Joynt of the Thumb. It may be called Hypothenar Pollicis, becaue it is pread out under the Thenar.

div.head: Chap. 30. Mucles of the Chet.
div.p: THe Mucles of the Chet are Proper or Common.

Thoe are aid to be Proper, which particularly and properly belong unto the Chet; the Common are uch as being detinated to ome certain Part, yet do ait the Breat with their help, as Auxliaries, uch as are the upper Mucles of the Shoulder blade.

The Chet is widened or lifted up by five Mucles. Three of which are beforeWhich widen. The Chet. viz. Subclavius, Serratus major, and the Triangularis or Pectoralis internus. One is hinderly Scituate viz. Poticus Serratus uperior: and the fift is the External Intercotal.

The Subclavius aries from the T. 10. f. 1. F. inner part of the Clavicula, near the ShoulderSubclaviu •
tip, being of a Flehy ubtance, and is inerted into the firt Rib, near the Bret bone.

The Serratus T. 10. f. 1. C D. Major, reaches from the inner Bais of the Shoulder blade, untoSerratus major ix, and omtimes even Ribs, of which the five lowet are true Ribs, and the two uppermore are batard one.

The Serratus T. 14. f. 2. E. Poticus Superior, being Scituate beneath the Romboides, Serratus Poticus Superior grows out of the harp points or pines of the three lower Vertebras of the Neck, and the firt pine of the Back; and ends into the three upper Ribs, and omtime the fourth.

The eleven T. 10. f. 1. G G. External Intercotals, hold the place of one Mucle, which is carriedExternal Intercotals. Obliquely forward from the lower ide of the upper Rib, into the upper ide of the lower Rib. Unto thoe Mucles which widen the Chet, we mut add the Diaphragme or Midrif.
The Triangular Mucle, growing out of the middle and inner Part of the Bretbone,Triangular Mucle. is inerted into the Gritles of the lower Ribs, as far as the third or fourth batard Ribbs.
Three Mucles there are which Contract the Bret, the Sacro-Lumbus, Intercotalis Contracters. internus, and Serratus Poticus inferior.

The Sacro-Lumbus, takes its original from the Os T. 14. f. 1. L L. f. 3. B B. Sacrum and the Spiny productionsSacrolumbus. of the Loins, and is terminated into the upper Ribs, near unto their Roots; betowing upon each Rib a double Tendon or Tendinous handle or clape, an internal and an external; and therefore it erves both to depres the Ribs and to raie the Back-bone, when it is bowed and bended forward.

The Eleven internal Intercotals, which fil up the paces between the Ribs, areInternal Intercotals. reckoned to be but one Mucle. It is carryed obliquely from the nether Rib to the upper more. It has Fibres contrary to thoe of the external, cros wie interected.

The Serratus Poticus T. 14. f. 2. F G. inferior, growing out of the pines of the three lowetSerratu • p •
ticus inferior. Vertebraes of the Back, and the firt of the Loins, is Terminated into three or fower of the lower Ribs.

This ame Serraticus Poticus inferior, is jut oppoite to the Serraticus Poticus uperior, and both of them by a broad and Membranous Aponeurois, do o grow together, that they erve intead of a band to bind and keep together the hinder Mucles of the Back-bone.
Others do ad eight Mucles of the Belly, becaue more Mucles are requiite to caue violent Expiration. e T. 10. f. 1. H H.

div.head: Chap. 31. Of the Midrif.
div.p:
THe Diaphragme or Midrif is an T. 10. f. 1. I I. f. 6. and 7. the whol. admirable kind of Mucle, both in regard of
• e of the Midrif. its compoition and continual Action, whiles it does night and day inceantly fan the Natural and Vital Parts, erving nevertheles as a Wal of partition to ever the one from the other.

It aries from the Circumference of the batard Ribs, through which it is obliquelyIts Original. drawn about, as far as to the Vertebraes of the Loins: the end or Sinewy Part thereof, is in the Nervous Centre.

When we draw in the Air, it is contracted and bent, and when it draws the lowerIts Motion. Ribs downwards and of convex becomes traight and even. When we blow the Air out, it is by help of the Mediatinum drawn upwards, and of traight is made Convex or bunching like the urface of a Bucklar.

div.head: Chap. 32. Mucles of the Back and Loyns, wherewith the Back-bone is moved.
div.p: THe Back is not moved, becaue of the Ribs interpoed, and the Penury of MuclesThe Back properly is not moved. both internal and external; it has indeed Mucles pred upon the outide thereof, but they are for another ue. So that between the Neck and the Loyns it remaines immovable, whiles the extream Parts are moved.

Now the motion is made in the lat Vertebra of the Back which is received on all hands by its neighbouring Vertebraes, and receives none; and becaue it is Contiguous with the Loins, The Motion is attributed to the Loyns rather than to the Back: although it belong to the whol Back-bon.
The Back-bone therefore, as the Loyns, are bowed and extended and drawn to the ides.

They are bowed by two Mucles, on each ide one. The Muculus T. 14. f. 2. O O. f. 4. C C f. 1. N N. Quadratus Back is bowed by the Quadratu • . takes its rie from the hinder Part of the Os Ilij and from the inner ide of the Os Sacrum, being inerted into the tranvere Apophyes of the Loins as far as the lat Rib, and of a Flehy ubtance.

I for my Part would rather ay it aries from the tranvere Productions or Apophyes of the two lower Vertebraes of the Back and the lat Rib, that it might together with the oblique decending Mucles and the traight ones, tir and move forwards the whol frame of the Oa Ilium.

The Mucles of the Abdomen which erve for Inpiration or drawing in of the Air, do alo further the bending of the Loyns and of the whol Back-bone; for whiles they bear down the Chet, they do withal bow the Back-bone if lying along upon your Breech, you would lift up the Trunk of your Body; or would leap up upon your Fee • , without the Aitance of your Hands.

The Loins are ditended by four Mucles, on either ide two, which are o infoldedExtenders. al along the Back-bone, that either we mut make o many pares, as there are Vertebraes, or we mut ay there is only one Pare of Mucles ditributing Tendons to al the Vertebraes, according to the Opinion of Ga • en.
The Semi-Spinatus Mucle, takes a T. 14. f. 3. D D. f. 4. A A. inewy beginning, from al the Spines ofSemipinatu • . the O • Sacrum, and ends into the tranvere Apophyes of the Loyns and whol back.
The Muculus Sacer with a T. 14. f. 4. B B. pointed Flehy beginning grows out of the hinder Part of Os Sacrum and terminates into the Roots of the Spiny points of the Vertebraes of the Back,
The Spina or Loins are laterally moved, when the Mucles on the contrary ide do act by themelves, both the benders and extenders.

It the Mucles which extend the Spina or Back-bone, are oppoite to the oblique Mucles of the Belly decendent and the tiaight ones, which move the frame of Oa Ilii, they mut needs grow out of the upper Parts of the Spine, that they may be inerted into the Oa Ilium and Os. Sacrum. And although they arie from the upper Parts of the Spina, they wil nevertheles erve to erect the Spina; and they wil be ever more Antagonits againt the Mucles which bend the Spina, viz. The Quadratus and the Muculus Obliquus acendens.
For they receive Nerves, as wel in their upper as middle Parts.

div.head: Chap 33 Mucles of the Belly:
div.p: BEcaue thoe a ten Mucles, which are found diplayed upon the Belly, were accuratly dicribed, At the beginning of the firt Book, I wil not here repeat them, becaue they are excepted from this Dicoure.

div.head: Chap. 34. Of the Motion of the Ilium Bones and Os Sacrum Joyned together.
div.p: THe frame of the Ilian Bones and Os Sacrum Joyned together, is moved backwardBy what Mucles its moved forwards. and forward in the Genial Embracements tending to Procreation.

The aid Conjunction of bones is moved forwards by the b Right and Oblique • decending Mucles of the Belly, the Chet reting and the Thighs remaining unmoved, unles they follow the Motion of the Ilium Bones.

It is moved backwards by the Muculus T. 2. f. 8. A B. f. 9. A B D. Sacer and the T. 2. f. 9. B C. Semipinatus, whichBy what moved backwards arie from the upper Parts of the Back: which I have demontrated by many reaons and experiments in my Anthropographia.

div.head: Chap, 35. Mucles of the Teticles.
div.p: THey are Proper or Common.

The Proper is that which is peculiar to each Teticle calledT. 2. f. 8. A. &c. Cremater. ItProper Mucle of the Stones. Cremater. grows out of the lower T. 14. f. 4. B B. fore Part of the pine of Os Ilium: or rather it is the fag-end of the Oblique acending Mucle, bordering upon the Os Pubis, whoe Fleh is redder, thinner and as it were evered from the Fleh of the aid oblique acendent Mucle. ••
••• olds ext •• necally the production of the Peritonaeum, and is carried together with the Seminary Veels unto the Teticle.
It draws the Teticle upwards and retains it upended in that Poture.

The Common Mucle is the Membrane of the Scrotum or Cod termed T. 6. f. 2. B B. Dartos, The Common •
• a tos. being a Continuation of the Flehy Membrane. And this Muculous Membrane upend both the Teticles.
Women have likewie their Cremater, horter than that of Men, Scituate upon the production of the Peritonaeum.

div.head: Chap, 36, The Bladders Mucle.
div.p:
LEt the Urin collected in the Bladder hould run out of it elf againt ones wil;Office of the Sphincter of the Bladder. their is a T. 6. f. 5. F F. round flehy Mucle which being rould back over the Protatae, does
hut the bladders Neck; and being made broad it expels the Urin; and by wringing or queezing the Protatas or Auxiliary Teticles, it quirts out the Seed in Venereal Conflicts. Now the Neck of the Bladder being Flehy, performes the office of an internal Sphincter Mucle, and exactly cloes the Bladder. b T. 14. f. 3. D D. f. 4. A A.
c T. 6. f. 2. D D.

div.head: Chap. 37. Mucles of the Yard.
div.p: THe Yard has four Mucles, two on each ide.

Muculus T. 6. f. 1. a a. f. 5 H H. Erector is bred out of the innermore bunching out of the Ichium, Yards Erectors and being knit unto the Ligament of the Yard, it reaches idewaies as far as the middle of the Body thereof. The Accelerator takes his Ri • e not only from theAccelerators. phincter of the Anus or Fundament, but alo from the internal Tuberoity of the Ichium or Huckle-bone, and being with his Mate pred out under the Vertebra or Pis-pipe, it is drawn out as far as to the middle of the Yard.

It hatens the quirting out of the Seed, and forces out the drops of Urin, in the concluion of Piing. And becaue it is in its Original twofold, it may therefore be accounted a double Mucle; but becaue I attribute that portion which aries from the Tuberoity of the Huckle-bone, unto the Fundament and cal it Levator externus Ani [the external Are-heaver] therefore the true Accelerator, according to mine, and other Anatomits Opinion, mut arie only from the external Sphincter of the Fundament.

div.head: Chap. 38. Mucles of the Clitoris.
div.p:
THe Clitoris in Women repreents the Mans Yard, and therefore is furnihed with Mucles alike, though not erving for the ame of Office. Of which I have treated in my firt Book, in the Chapter which decribes the Womb
b T. 6. f. 1. b b. f. • . I I.

div.head: Chap. 39. Mucles of the Fundament.
div.p: I Have decrided the Mucles of the Fundament very ufficiently in the 33. Chap. of my econd Book.

div.head: Chap. 40. Mucles of the Thigh.
div.p: THe Thigh is extended, bended, drawn to a man, and from a Man and oblicklyExtenders of the Thigh. wheeled about.

It is extended when we tand, our Thigh being Perpendicular to our Hucklebone, which poture is caued by three Mucles which contitute the Buttocks, and are therefore by Authors termed Muculi Gloutii; that is the Buttock Mucles.

Maximus and ex • imu •
T. 23. f. 2. B. f. 3. A. Gloutius, the greatet and outmot buttock Mucle isGloutius m ••
imus.
•• ed out of the pines of Os Sacrum and more than half of the Ilium Rib; and is inerted four Fingers •• neath the great Trochanter, where a certain Eminence of the • one is • icer • ed.
Secundus and medius Gloutius, the econd and middle buttock Mucle, pringsMedius out of the external Pa •• of the Os Ilium, and is inerted into the great and external Trochanter.
Tertius and intimus T. 23. f. 4. B. Gloutius, the third and innermot buttock Mucle, ariingMinimus from the outward and lower ide of Os Ilium, is implanted into the Top of the great Trochanter.
The Thigh is bended by three Mucles.Benders. Poas.

Primus Lumbaris, The firt Loyn Mucle called T. 10. f. 1. O O. T. 23. f. 1. A. Poas, pred over the bodies of the Lumbal Vertebraes, in the Cavity of the belly; is bred out of the tranvere Apophyes of the lower Vertebraes of the back, and being carryed along upon the inner urface of Os Ilium, it is inerted into the mal Trochanter.

I have in Men, oftimes found a little Mucle pred over this, which in its original, being of the length and thicknes of a Mans little Finger and flehy, with a mal and flat Tendon is carried above the Poas, and when it is come to the Illiac, it looes it elf into a broad and very trong Aponeurois, which firmly combines the Iliac and Poas Mucles. And therefore I conceive it is added, in trong Men, that it might traitly embrace the Poas and hold it firmly in its eat.

It is called Pa • vu • Poas, and is more rarely found in Women than in Men: Howbeit in the year 1631. In a very tout Virago or kind of Mol Cut-Pure, it was my hap to ee one of thee Mucles, he having been hangd for Robberies and Murthers by her committed. b T. 23. f. 3. B. f. 4. C.

Iliacus Muculus, the Iliac Mucle, takes its rie out of the T. 23. f. • . B. internal Cavity ofIliacus. Os Ilium, and being by its Tendon Joyned with the lumbal Mucle, it is terminated between the great and little Trochanter,
T. 23. f. 1. C. below b. Pectineus Muculus, The Combe Mucle hootes out of the upper Part of Os Pectineus. Pubis, and is inerted a little below the Neck of the Thigh, on the foreide.
The Thigh is drawn to the inide by the Muculus Triceps or T. 23. f. 1. and 2. C C. three headedDrawer to. Mucle, which has three originals and as many ditinct Inertions.

One of its Heads aries from the upper Part of the hare bones or Oa Pubis; theTriceps. other aries from the middle of the aid bones, and the third from the lowet Part of the aid bones and they are inerted into the hinder line of the Thigh, being dipoed by coure.
The Action of this Mucle is trong and Praevalent, drawing the Thighs inward, when we Climbe Trees, acend to the Main mat and Ride on Hor-back.
This trebble headed Mucle is the firt that receives the Excrementitious Humors of the body which fal into Legs, becaue of the Veels which pas that way.
The Thigh is drawn to the outide by very mal Mucles, becaue the drawing ofWith drawrs. the Thigh outwards is not very neceary.
The Muculi Quadrigemimi, are four little Mucles, interchangably placed uponThe Quadrigeminals. the Articulation of the Thigh in the hinder Part thereof.

The firt and T. 23. f. 3. C. f. 4. D. uppermot of the Quadrigemini being longer than the ret and asFirt it were p • ar fahiond, is by others termed Iliacus externus. It aries from the lower and external Part of Os Sacrum.
The T. 23. f. 3. b. f. 4. G. econd of the Quadrigemini, aries from the Tuberoity or bunchy PartSecond of the Huckle-bone.
The third which is contiguous unto the former, aries from the ame Part, andThird thee three are inerted into the Cavity of the great Trochanter.

Thee three of the Quadrigeminal Mucles, being included in the Cavity of the great Trochanter, do erve likewie to thrut downwards or lengthen out the Thigh When it is tretched a little beyond its natural length, which you may oberve in a Man that l •• s upon his Back, with his body and Leg treched out.
They perform this Action in the ame manner as the Pterygoideus internus, interpoed between the two Jaws, does drive the lower Jaw forwards.

The Quartus Quadrigeminorum T. 23. f. 3. D. f. 4. E. Quadratus, is broader and more flehy thanThe Fourth. the other three, being ditant from the third of the Quadrigemini two Fingers
breadths; and is propagated from the inner Part of the Procuberance of the Huckle-bone, and fatened into the external Part of the great Trochanter.
The Thigh is obliquely wheeled about by the two Obturators, the external andOblique wheelers. Obturator Internus. the internal.

The Internal T. 23. f. 3. E. and 4. F. grows out of the inner Circumference of that hole which is in the Os Pubis or hare bone; and being carryed along thorough that hollownes which is between the Knob of the Huckle-bone and its Acetabulum or Socket, it is by a tripartite Tendon inerted into the Cavity of the great Trochanter.
Its Tendon is folded up and incloed by the econd and third Quadrigeminal Mucles, which reemble a pure. Its action is to direct the external wheeling motion of the Thights.

The Externus a Obturator, taking its revolution from the external CircumferenceObturator externus. of that hole, which is in the hare, and being Circumducted through the Neck of the Thigh as through a pully, it is carryed unto the Cavity of the great Trochanter under the fourth Quadrigeminal Mucle.
It governs the internal wheeling motion of the Thigh.

When the Quadrigeminal Mucles and the Obturatores, are oaked in Wheyih Humors, they caue mot bitter pains, which counterfeit the true Sciatica, and lengthen the Thigh, as if it were half out of Joynt, which is diligently to be noted and ditinguihed.

div.head: Chap. 41. Mucles of the Leg.
div.p: THe Leg is Joyned with the Thigh, by that kind of Articulation which is calledThe Motion of the Leg. Gynglymus, and therefore it is only moved by bending and extending; but becaue the Articulation is looe, it uffers a man to draw his Leg idewaies: for which Caue Laurentius and other latter Anatomits, wil have the Leg to be turnd inwards and outwards by certain Mucles ordained to that end.

It is drawn inwards or towards the other Leg, by the Sutorius, a very long Mucle. It is drawn outwards or from the other Leg, by a Membranous Mucle, or broad w • th. I leave it free for any Man thus to divided the Mucles, which I ditinguih into benders and extenders.
The Leg is bent by four hinder Mucles. The Leg benders. The Semi. Nervous. The Semi-Membranous.
The firt of thoe four, is called T. 23. f. 3. G G. Semi-Nervous, the Half innew Mucle. It aries from the Tuberoity or bunching Part of the Huckle, and ends in the hinder and inner Part of the Leg.

The other is termed T. 23. f. 3. H H. Semi-Membranous Muculus, the Half Membranary Mucle, which proceeds from the ame bunching Part of the Hip or Huckle-bone, with a beginning which is Nervous and Membranous; and with a larger Tendon, is inerted into the inner and hinder Part of the Leg. a T. 23. f. 4. e.

The Mucle T. 23. f. 3. III. Biceps prings from the foreaid Tuberoity of the Hip or Hucklebone,The Biceps and being carryed along the outward Part of the Thigh, about the middle thereof it becomes flehy, which flehynes I have een eparated as a econd Mucle, as far as the Head. It is by one only Tendon inerted, into the ourward Part of the Leg.

The fourth being commonly termed Poticus T. 23. f. 3. F F. Gracilis, aries from that •… neThe Gracilis. which hews where the Hip-bone and the Share-bone grow together, and decending along the Inide of the Thigh, it is inerted into the inner Part of the Leg.

The Mucle called T. 23. f. 4. H. Poplitaeus, is to be reckoned among the ••• ders, it lies lurkingThe Popliteus. in the Cavity of the Ham, above the Head of the Soleum. It aries out of the external welling or bunching out of the Thigh, and is Obliquely inerted into the hinder and upper Part of the Leg, which it cloely embraces.

The Leg is extended by ix Mucles. The firt we meet with <> the T. 23. f. 2. F F. Membranous, which is drawn out of the upper pine or harp point of the I • ian bone andExtenders. The Membranous. The Sutorius carryed into the fore part of the Leg, or rather of the Thigh, and g •• ts in the Mucles of the Leg it elf, like a e Membranous
• wath, al ave the Muculus utorius.

This Mucle taking its rie from the upper f Spine and fore Rib of the Ilium, and liding down Obliquely by the inner Parts of the Thigh, ends into the inide of the Leg, which it is aid to bring to and place over the other, as Tailors are wont to do when they would it Cros-Leg'd.
The Rectus g Gracilis, Springing out of the lower Spine of Os Ilium, and beingR • ctus •• acilis. carryed right out al along the Thigh, ends on the fore Part of the Leg, beneath the Epigonatis.
The other which is T. 23. f. • . H H. internal, aries from the Root of the mal Trochanter, andVatus internus fals into the inide of the Leg, a little below the Patella.

The Mucle termed T. 23. f. 1. &c. Crureus placed under the two Muculi Vati, prings out ofCrureus. the fore bone of the Thigh, between the two Trochan • ers, and cleaving to the whol body of the Thigh, it produces its Tendon over the Epigonatis, unto the fore part of the Leg.

Thee five Mucles, the Re • tus, the Gracilis, Duo Vati and the Crural Mucle, being united al together about the Knee, the produce one only Tendon, very broad and trong, wherewith the Patella is infolded.

div.head: Chap. 42. Mucles of the Feet.
div.p: AS the Hand is divided into three Parts, o is the Foot into the Tarus, MetatarusMotion of the Foot. and Phalanx or Row of Toes. And as in the H • nd, the Writ is moved while the Parts after the Writ remain unmoved: o in the Foot, the Tarus is moved, the Metatarus remaining unmoved. And therefore the Tarus is bowed, when it is moved forward, and it is extended, when it is forced backwards.

In the meane while you hal oberve that the bowings of the Members in the whole Leg and Foot are contrary; in the hand they are like one another, for the conveniency of taking up of any thing; in the Leg and Foot they are contrary, to make us tand firme, and for the performance of different actions. For the flexion or bowing of the Thigh is performed forwards, the bowing of the Leg is performed backwards the bowing of the Foot is done • orwards, the bowing of the Toes of the Foot, backwards.
The Foot is bowed by two Mucles eated before, which are called Tibiaeus andFoot-benders. Peronaeus.

The Tibiaeus T. 23. f. 1. K. anticus, taking its rie from the upper Epiphyis of the Leg neareTibiaeus anticus. the Fibula, and cleaving to the Tibia all along, about the middle of the bone, it degenerates into a Tendon, which beneath the T. 23. f. 1. . Ring-fahion'd Ligament of the Foot, is •• it into two Tendons, the one of which is inerted into the O • primum innominatum or firt nameles bone, and the other is lengthened out as far as to the Bone of the Me • ata • us which is placed unde • the Great Toe.

The Peronae ••
T. 23. f. 1. L L. Ant ••••
is in it • Original • oyned to the Peronaeus Poticus, althoughPer ••• us anticus. though both ••• Tendons are d • awn through the cleft of the external Ankle, yet in their • nd and ine •• ion they are eparated. The Anticus has its rie from the middle
and external part of the Perone, and being led through the cleft of Malleolus externus, it is inerted on the foreide into the bone of the Metatarus, which uteines the little Toe.

The Foot is extended by the after Mucles. The firt and outmot are theExtenders. T. 23. f. 1. d d. f. 2. D D. f. 3. K K. Gemell • or twins, o called becaue they are equal • n Bulke, Strength and Action. They are al • o termed Gatrocnemij, becaue they make the Belly or welling of the Calf o • the Leg: and the one of them is internal, placed in the inner ide of the Ti • i • or hank, the other is external, and poees the outide thereof.

The internal Twin-Mucle, aries from the inner knob of the Thigh; the external Gemellus internus. externus. Twin-Mucle aries from the ex • ernal knob of the aid Thigh. They are evered in the • beginning, but grow together at l • t into one Belly, which by a trong Tendon is • engthened out unto the hinder part of the Heel. Vealius was the firt that ob
• erved that. To everal beginnings of every one of them, there are everal little c T. 23. f. 3. o o. Bones placed like unto Se • amine Seeds or like Tares or Ve • ches, to the end that with their mooth and lippery urface, being placed between the Mucles and the Bones, they may hinder the Mucles from being hurt, when the leg is turned this way or that way.Plantaris.

Plantaris T. 23. f. 3. M. Muculus, which lu • ks between the Twins and the Soleus, aries from the external knob of the thigh, being flehie on the upper part, and quickly ending into a very • mal and longih tendon, it is drawn under the Heel, by the inner Ankle-bone, and diffued into the ole of the Foot.
It performes the ame office in the Foot as in the hand; that the Foot might anwer to the hand, and that whilet the Foot is hollowed, the Skin, by the Tendons lieing under, might be firmly fatened.

The T. 23. f. 3. f. 3. L L. Soleus, a broad and thick Mucle, takes its original from the upper part ofSoleus. the Leg, or from the upper and hinder cloure of the Tibia and Perone; and is inerted by a tendon mixed with the Gemelli or Twins, into the hinder part of the Heel.
Under the Mucle Soleus remarkeable veels have their paage, both Veins, and Ar • eries and Nerves: whence it comes to pas that the pains of the Calfe of the Leg are deep and lating.

Of the T • ins and the Soleus mingled together in their inferior parts, is made that The Chorda of Hippocrates. ame common Tendon, which is o exceeding thick and trong, which Hippocrates terms the Cho • da m • gna, the Hurts, Brui • es and wounds whereof, do caue death.
The foot is extended by two hinder Mucles, the Tibiaeus poticus and the Peronaeus Tibiaeus poticus. poticus.

The Tibiaeus poticus does arie from the upper part of the Tibia, and being a ••• xed to the whole bodie thereof, through the cleft of the inner Anckle bone, it produces two Tendons, the one of which ends at the Scaphoidean Bone, and the other is carried as far as to the primum Os innominatum.

The Peronaeus f. 23. f. 2. F F. Poticus, does arie from the upper and hinder part of thePeronaeus poticus. Perone, And being carried with the Peronaeus anticus through the cleft of the external ankle bone into the bone of the Metatarus, which utaines the greate toe, under the ole of the Foot, it tranmits its broad, hard and gritly kind of Tendon, under the Tendinous head, of that Mas of fleh, which does produce its internal inter-oeans.

The Mu • cles Peronaeus anticus and Poticus, as they are ditinct in their original, o are they alo ditinct in their inertion, although they are drawen through the pulley of the external ankle: but the Tendon of the other Peronaeus Flexor, is i • erted into the outide of the Os metatari which uteines the little Finger.

The Tendon of the other Peronaean Mucle, whoe office is to extend the part,
being cituate behind, is carryed further and more inwardly under the M • cle called Pediaeus. Thee two tendons are eparated one from another, b •• ng incloed in two ditinct heaths or cabberds, of a nerve-gritly ubtance. b f. 2. E E.

div.head: Chap. 43. Mucles of the toes.
div.p: THe Toes have their proper Mucles, fitted to procure their bending, extending,The Annular Ligament. and lateral motion from one ide to another: alo their tendons are comprehended within a Ring-fashioned or circular and tranverse T. 23. f. 1. g. ligament, which does incompas them beneath the Ankles, jut as we ee in the Writ.
They are extended by the Muculu • longus and Brevis. Toe-tretchers. cnimodactylius

The longus, or T. 23. f. 1. M M. long-Toe-tretcher called in Greek Cnimodactylius, takes its rie from the fore and inner ide of the Tibia, there where it is joined to the Fibula, lurking cloe under the Tibieus anticus, and goes down-right all along the Fibula, till haveing paed the Ring-fahioned ligament, it ends into the three Articulations of the T. 23. f. 1. f f. foure Toes that it might at once and by one motion, move the three • oyntings of the foure Toes aforeaid.

Brevis Digitum tenor, or the T. 23. f. 2. G. hort Toe-tretcher, or Pediaean Mucle, pringsPedi • us. out of the Heel and the external and upper part of the neighboring Atragalus or bone o called, and being pred under the Superior, it is with its tendons inerted into all the Joynts of the Articulation.
The Tendons of thee Mucles, as well the long as hort, do pas cros-wie one over another, above the Metatarus.
The Toes are bowed by two Mucles the Brevis and Longus, which anwer toThe Toe-benders. Perodactyleus. thee Mucles of the hand which are called Profundus and Sublimis.

Longus T. 23. f. 4. II. f. 6. C. Digitum flexor the Long Toe-tretcher called alo Pero-dactyleus, aries out of the hinder and upper part of the Perone or Fibula, and being carryed along under the inner anckle, through a peculiar cavety of the Heel, it is divided into foure tendons, which are drawne through the lits of the hort Toe-bending Te •
don (as we ee likewie in the Hand) and then inerted into the third Joynt of foure Toes.

Brevis T. 23. f. 4. • . f. 6. A. Digitum flexor, or the Pediaeus internus, or hort Toe-Bender, pringsPediaeus internus. from the inner and net her part of the Heel, and being parted into foure it is terminated into the econd Articulation of the Toes.
The Tendons of this Mucle have holes bored in them for the Long Toe-benders Tendon to pas through.

Moreover, the Toes are drawn idewaies by the Interoean Mucles. They areThe oblique movers. eight in number, foure internal and as many external, which are otherwie dipoed in the foote than they are in the hand.

The T. 23 f 2. a a a a. external arie from the paces of the Bones of Metatars • s: the internal,The Interoeans. being cituate in the T. 23. f. 5. d d d d. f. 6. f f f f. Hollow of the foote, and knit unto the bones, and eeme to take their original from that lump of T. 23. f. 6. D D. Fleh, which poees and fils up that ame Cavity of the Bones of the Metatarus: but the membrane being taken away, they are eene to arie from one nervous pointed or acuminated Original, fixed on the inide neare the Heele, and divided into four tendons, and to end into the econd Articulation, whereunto the worme-fahiond or lumbrical Mucles do cleave.
And therefore the external inter-oean Mucles, doe fill up the empty paces of the Bones of Metatarus.

The Lumb • ical or wo •• -fahion'd T. 23. f. 6. e e e e. Mucles, do not arie from the tendons of the long Toe-bender, as in the Hand, but from a fle •• y lumpe, which lies hid underneath the hort Toe-bender; and that has its original from the Heel.

div.head: Chap. 44. Mucles of the Great Toe.
div.p: THe great Toe T. 23. f. 4. K. f. 6. B. Bender, being cituate neare the long Toe tretcher, and of aThe great toebender. flehy ubtance, aries out of the upper Part of the fibula, where it is joyned with the Tibia, and paing along under the inner Ankle bone and the Sole of the Foote, it is iner • ed into the firt bone of the Great Toe: and before it comes unto the econd bone a little Seamoidean Bone is prepoed; and the Tendon for ecurities ake is intercepted, with two greater Seamoidean Bones.

Somtimes under the ole of the Foot it is divided into two Tendons, the one of which is tranmitted to the great Toe, the other to the econd of the little Toes; and then the great Toe-bender is divided only into three.

Extenor T. 23. f. • . N. Pollicis the great Toe-tretcher, aries from the external ide of theThe Stretcher. Tibia, where it is eparate from the Fibula and creeping along the urface of the Foote, it is inerted into the whole great Toe, in its upper ide. The other ends into the Bone of Metatarus, which is pred beneath the great Toe.

The great Toe and the little Toe, have two notable Mucles, externally cituate,The Abductor, which draw thee Toes outwards from the ret o that one of them, being externally fatened unto the bone of the Metata • us, which is placed under the great Toe, is termed Abductor T. 23. f. 3. O. f. 5. b b Policis, the Drawer aide of the great Toe.

The other being externally pread upon the firt • one of Metatarus, may beThe little Toes Abductor. called Abductor T. 23. f. 3. P. f. 5 c. minimi digiti, the drawer aide of the little Finger. It anwers to the T • enar and Hypo • henar of the Hand.

Furthermore the Great Toe has in the ole of the Foot another Tranvere The great t ••• drawer •• . T. 23. f. 5. a. Mucle, like the Anti-thenar, which ariing out of the Ligament of that Bone of the Metatarus which is placed under the leat or next Toe, and going obliquely upon the other Bones, it ends with a trong Tendon into the firt Joynt of the great Toe, beneath the ame.
This Mucle is oppoed to to the Abductor, that it might draw the great Toe back againe.
The fleh being taken away, we find a threefold or fourfold Membrane, I uppoe it is that M • s of fleh which fils the Cavitie of the ole of the foot.

In the lowet p •• t of the Foote which is termed Vetigium, there is contained aThe Maa Ca •••• .
T. 23. f. 6. D D. Lump of fleh which • ils up the Cavity and empty pace of the firt Joynts: from whence writers ay Tendons are drawn to the everal Toes.

I coneive the ue of this fleh is rather to trengthen the Toes and to combine theirIts Ve. firt Articulations, than to move the ame, alo like a oft Cuhion, it is pred under the Tendons of other Mucles.

div.head: Chap. 45. An Introduction to the Art of Mucular-Diection, hewing an Accurate Method to cut up the Mucles of the whol Body.
div.p:
Whooever has perfectly learned the Hitory of the Mucles, will eaily undertandThe Method the Art of their Diection, and be able of himelf without any help, to adminiter this part of Anatomcal ection, which many account the hardet of all, provided he diligently oberve the Method which I here deliver. And therefore having finihed our Myologi •
or Hitory of Mucles, Myotome or the Art of their Diection, will eaonably follow.

div.head: The Frontal Mucle.
div.p: The Skin of the forehead, being circulary cut off above the Eye-brows and drawnThe frontal Mucle. away as far as to the Coronal Suture, or to the beginning of the Haires, you meet with the two frontal Mucles, which are mot exactly to be eparated from the frontal or forehead bone which lies beneath, beginning from above and cutting all away into the very Eye-browes. They are in the middle of the Forehead ditinct one from another. b T. 15. f. 1. E.

div.head: The Orbicular Mucle of the Eye-Lids.
div.p: The Skin of the Eye-Browes and of the whole face being indutriouly diected,The Orbicularis The Ciliaris. there appears a double T. 15. f. 1. F F. orbicular Mucle, which does circularly cover the ocket of the Eye a Fingers-breadth on al ides, and is pred under each Eye lid. Alo, you hal • ind the Muculus Ciliaris, • ierched out orbicularly under the Tarus.

div.head: Mucles of the Lips.
div.p: After wards, the whol Face being made bare and the Skin flead off, a little belowZeugomaticus. the Eye-hole, we meet with a little lean longih Mucle, placed athwart and called T. 15. f. 1. L. Zygomaticus. For it is produced from the Zygoma unto the opening of the Lips. This Mucle mut be eparated from the Fat; for much Fat (which is alo crowded into the Mucles) does cover the whole face, which you hal pluck away with your nailes or with a paire of piners, or with a very harp pen-knife, that the Muculous fleh may more evidently be ditinguihed.

From the Zygoma towards the Lips, you hal earch for five Mucles beidesLip-heavers. the Zygomatick mucle: and you hal find two above the upper Lip; each of which is exactly to be eparated from the other. That Mucle which is neeret the Zygoma, belongs unto the neather Lip, which is lifted up thereby. The other beingBuccinator. very neare to the T. 15. f. 1. H. Not • ils, is reckoned to belong to the upper Lip. The lateral T. 15. f. 1. O. Mucle broad and Flehy which opens and forms the Cheeks, and therefore is called Bucco, mut not be tirred out of its place.

In the neather jaw, as far as to the middle of the lower Lip, you hal earch forLip depreers. two Mucles having firt taken away the skin. b T
• 9. f. 1. C C.
d T. 15. f. 1. K.

That T. 15. f 1. n. which is nearet the Chin, does depres the lower Lip. That which lies T. 15. f 1. M. beyond next the Maeter or fatend to the Corner of the mouth, drawes the up
• er Lip downwards. Thee two Mucles, though mot •• actly united, are yet ditinguihed one from another by the various poture of their fibres; namely, in amuch as the Fibres of the former Mucle, do • eeme to go upwards from the Chin to the <>
<> do it were contitute a pyramidal Mucle, whoe Bais rets beneath and its top reaches to the Lip: the Fibres of the other Mucles do acend unto the Meeting of the Lips.

div.head: Mucles of the Noe.
div.p: The Skin of the Noe being curiouly taken away, two Mucles dicover themelvesNoe- • i • ers being •• t • ned unto the bones and laps of the No •• ils, which ariing out of T. 15. f 1. G. the <> between the Eye-Browes, are carried into the laps of the Notrills.

Other Anatomits ad (but only in uch as have great Noes) two little
T. 15. f 1. I. Mucles Notril widners. pred athwart upon the ends of the Noe laps, which widen the Notrils, as the former do lift them up.

Other Anatomits ad (but only in uch as have great Noes) two little
f. 3. and 4. F. Mucles Notril widners pred ath • art up in the Ends of the Noe-Laps, which widen the Notrils, as the former do lift them up.
In the Inter • m you hal oberve, that all thee Mucles are o trictly conjoined, that one of the Lips, or the Noe cannot be moved without the motion of the Neighboring parts.
The internal Mucles of the Notrils are eldome found, and only in uch as have • olly • oating Noes.

div.head: The Temporal Mucle.
div.p: That ame thick and fibrous Fleh which is ituat between the maller CornerTemporalis. of the Eye and the Ear, is called the T. 15. f. 1. P P. f. 2. A A. Temporal Mucle; whoe tendon being drawn along under the Zygoma, is T. 15. f. 2. a a. terminated into the Top of the lower Jaw.

div.head: The Maeter Mucle.
div.p: From the lower part of the Zygoma, aries the Mucle T. 15. f. 1. S. f. 2. B B. Maeter, which makesMaseter up the flehy ides of the Face. It is inerted into the Corner of the Lower Jaw; and •• may be divided into two, the internal and external fibres being cro • s-waies interected.

div.head: The Parotick Kernels.
div.p: Above the Joynt of the lower Jaw, behind the Ears, there are cattered certainContitution of the Parotis. Kernels, of which one great kernel is made, called Parotis. this cannot be een unles the broad Mucle, which reaches unto the Eare, b • torn away. This Kernel being plucked out, you may proceed to the Mu • cles of the Eares.

div.head: The Mucles of the Eares.
div.p: Although the Eares in Man-kind remaine firme and immoveable, yet have they their T. 15. f. 1. Q. R. T. 20. f. 1. H I. &c. proper mucle placed behind them. The firt is a very litle one, divided into two or three flehy fibres, very friendly imbraceing the ligament of the Earth. you mut earch for it at the root of the Ear.
The other Mucles of the Eare, are only portions of the frontal mucle, the br • ad Mucle, and the Hinder-Head Mucle; all which are bred out of the flehy pannicle.

div.head: The Mucles of the Eye.
div.p: Within the Eye-hole are contained even Mucles, uch as are the Attollens Palpebram The Eye-lidli •• er the Eye-lid li •• er, Four traight ones and two oblique. Six of thee arie out of the deepeet part of the Eie-ho • e;

You hall find two above the globe of the Eye, of which the one being firt in ituation,Four right mucles of the Eye. is the T. 19. f. 1. A A. Lifter-up of the upper Eye-lid; and the other is called Attollen •
f, 3. 4. 5. A. Oculi the Eye-Lifter. You hal earch for three other f. 3. 4. 5. B. C. D. treight Mucles, every one •• its itvation uitable to the action which it is to perform.

••• you hall diligently oberve the ix •
d large oblique Mucle, which at theObliq •• s ma •••
great corner of the Eye, or by the pace betweene the Eye-browes above the Tearepipe or foramen lachrymale, runs back about the Cartilage or Gritle, as about a pulley, or as a bridle about the Annulary or ring-fahioned ligament.

Be very careful that you do not break this Conjunction. For which caue you hall begin your Anatomical adminitration of the Eye in that place, that is to ay from the greater corner of the Eye, that you may pre • erve entire the f. 3. and 4. G. Pul • y and the
Inertion of the Te • don, which is incloed within a mall nervous Ligament which receives the Te • don it elf, and accompanies the ame unto the Eye. The fleh of that mucle is fixed to the boney ides of the Eye-Hole at the greate • corner.

The eptimus Muculus Obliquus
f. 3. and 4. E. minor, eventh Mucle, being the leer of theObliquus m •
nor. crooked ones, is bred out of the inide of the lower part of the Eye-hole, near the Tear f. 1. D. Kernel, and taking its revolution above the Mucle Humilis, but below the f. E. 4. and D. Indigna • ori • s: it is terminated aloft upon the Globe of the Eye, by the Mucle called f. 3. 4. &c. A. upe • bus.
In he Ana • omical Diection of the Eye, this Mucle is to be lookt a • ter in the econd Place, and to be warily preerved, leat we teare it in peices, while we eek for the ret.

If with the point of your Pen-knife you pluck back the Coat of the E • e called Conjun •• va, you hall ee that all the Mucles of the Eye, do Terminate by a fine Membranous Aponeurois (conjunction or Contexture of many Nerves) into the Tunica Cornea. But they do not make a peculiar Membrane, as Columbus imagined, becaue the Aponeurois (nerv • contexture) of every Mucle, is ditinct by it elf. h f. 3. 4. and B.

But you cannot ee or demontrate the Mucles of the Eye, unles with a pair of Sciers you take away the fat placed about them; and a • ter that you have hewn the Mucle which is the Up-lifter of the upper Eye-lid, with the four treight Mucles and the little crooked one.

That you may plainly dicover the Obliquus Major or greater Crooked Mucle, with its revolution to the pully, you hall take out the Eye, leaving that greater oblick Mucle, but cutting the ret away with your ciers.

div.head: Mucles eated in the Neck.
div.p: The Neck, which we make account reaches from the Bais of the Head unto the houlder-blades, comprehending even •• ondyl • or Vertebra's, has divers Mucles in its fore ide; of which ome appertain unto the Head, to the Os byoides, ome to the Larynx, others to the tongue, and others to the Pharynx.

And firt we met with the Muculus
T. 15. f. 2.
• . T. 15. f. f. 1. g g.
• atus, the broad Mucle, which infolds theLatus. whol Neck. It •• e • ds out of the Clavicul • and Bret-bone, and being atened to the Ba •• of the neather Jaw, it is laterally carryed forth unto the Eare; it mut be very exactly e • ara • ed from the Flehy parts which lie beneath it, becaue it is an exce •• in • thin Mucle.
The Muculus Latus being revelled or drawn back, in the fore part of the Neck under the Chin you hal find nine as • ar as to the Larynx, and beneath the Larynx ix.

T • wards the outward part of the Neck, there appeares the thick and round Mastoid • us. Mucle Matoid • us, which ace • ds lan ••• g from the Cl • vicula to the Matoides. this Mucle <> to be eparated at its original, that the others may be eene. But oberve, by the way, that this Mucle is very often broken aunder by the Halter in uch as have bin hang • d.

V • der the Ma ••• ideus there lies l •• keing the Coraco- • yo-ideus, a • ean and longihCoracohy • ideus. Mucle, • bl • k • y tr •• ched out •• om the Scapu • a, to the Os Hyoides, for the re •• action whereof, it is ordained. b T. 14. f. K K. f. 3. G.
c T. 13. f. 13. F F.

Then you hall ee afterwardes the Carotick Arterie, and the internal Jugular Veine, and the Nerve of the ixt Conjugation, interpoed betweene the aid two Veells. And then you hal pas unto the Mucles e ••• beneath the Laxy • x.

The firt which preents it •••• is the T. 13. f. 13. D D. Sterno • yo-ideu • , which is bred out of the top of the • er •• m or •• et bone. Under this lies the T. 15. f. 1. T T. f. 2. C C. Bronchius which belongs to the Larynx.
Then you hal di •• ect and hew the Mucles placed above the Larynx and under the Chin.

The firt is Digatricus maxillae internae, or the Twi-bellyed Mucle of the lower Digatricus. Jaw, which is mal and nervie in the middet thereof, that it might be turned back about the Stylo-cerato-ides, and ends into the Chin, inwardly.

There are two Glandules or kernells under the Chin neare neighbors to this Mucle, which in r • eumatick defluxions do often wel. They are termed by Vealius, I know not why, Animellae. You mut remove thee Glandules that the ret of the Mucles may be dicovered, alo you mut eparate the Digatric or Twibelly from the Chin.

Vnder it lies the Mucle T. 13. f. 14. E E Mylohyo-ideus with his Mate mot traightly tyed andMylo • yoideus. united, but a line drawn from the no • ch of the Chin as far as to the middle of Os Hyoides within, will hew you how to diect.

Under this Mylo-hyo-ideus are found two remarkable Nerves, Branches of the Seventh Pair, and the Mucle T. 13 f. 13. B B. Genio-Hyo-ideus, riing from the inide of theGeniohyoideus. Chin and ending into the Os Hyodes, but o cloely linkt with his Ma • e, that it is ditinguihed no otherwie, than by a white line which is manifet within.

Under thee lurks the T. 23. f. 13. C C. Genio-Glous, by the outer ide whereof lies the Meloglous: Genio-glous Baiglosus. under which lies the T. 13. f. 14. C C. Cerato-glous, or rather Baiglous.
b T. 13. f. 5. C C.

Afterward you hall come unto the hollow of the Neck under the lower cornerStyloglous. of the Jaw, where the Kernel was cituate, which was formerly taken out. In this place is found the T. 13. f. 14. D D. Stylo-glous, which is inerted into the Ceratoglous.

Beneath there appear two Mucles, the one of which being lean and altogether •• ehy,Stylo • yoideus is called Stylo-hyo-ideus, the other which is next unto it and touches it, being flehy in its original at the Styloides Proces, and mall as a t • ing in its middle, is called T. 15. f. 1. T T. Digatricus or Twi-belly. The firt was oberved in the Neck under the Chin.

Under the Stylo-glous, lies culking the Stylo-Pharingaeus. Under the cornerStylophary •
gau • . P • erygoid • u • internus. of the lower. Jaw-bone, there is internally and immediately fatened the Pterygoideus T. 15. f. 2. D D. internus; which takeing its rie from the Cavity of the P • erygoides, ends into the Corner of the lower jaw, on the inide. You mut not remove it from its poture.

From the Bais of Os Hyo-ides on the outide, preents it elf the hort MucleHyothyroideus. T. 13. f. 8. B B. Hyo-thyro-ideus, which is inerted into the middle of the Thyroides. This whol Mucle, is commonly found broken by the Haltar, in uch as have been hanged.

Al thee Mucles having been hewed and taken away, there appears the T. 3. f. 2. and 3. D D.
Oeophagaeus, Oeophageu • . a broad and Membranous Mucle pread under the Oeophagus, which it embraces, and is externally terminated in the Wings or Skirts of the Car • ilago Tyroides, or Gritle o called.

div.head: Mucles of the Larynx, Pharynx and Gargareon.
div.p: The Oeophageus being hewed and eparated, take away the whol Larynx that you may ee thoe little Mucles which are proper to it. You hal oberve eight or ten of them, of which • ome are ordained to move the Thyroides, and others pertaine to the Arytaenoides.

In the formot and lowet part of the T •• roides, are placed the two MuclesCricoarytenoid ••
called Crico-arytaeno-idei antici.
c T. 3. f. 2. and 3. C C.
g T. 13. f. 8. D D.

By the ides and lower Corners of Thyroides are ituate the Mucles called T. 13. f. 9. CC Crico-arytaeno-idei • aterales. In the hindermore and outward ide of the Cricoides,
you hal find the two Mucles called Cricoarytaenoidei. Haveing eparatedThy <…> Ar •• eno • deus. the Tyroides, inwardly and towards one ide you hal ee the Mucle Tyroarytaenoideus. To thee is added the f. 10. BB. circular Mucle inolding the whol Arytaenoides.
But al thee Mucles cannot be een unles the Oephageus be taken away, and the f. 16. & 17. Parithmian Kernels pluckt of, with which the Cartilage Thyroides or Gritle o called, is covered.

The Epiglott ••
f. 7. 9. & 10. A. in Mankind, has no Mucle; in Brutes, two pretty ones are found, which you may ee in the Larynx of an Ox. But in Mankind, we find only a inewy Ligament, which keeps the Epiglottis continually erected, unles it be depreed with the weight of the Nutriment paing by.
Afterwards you hal earch for two other Mucles of the Pharynx, viz. the T. 3. f. 2. & 3. BB. Sphenopharyngeus The Pharyngei. and f. 2. & 3. AA. Cephalopharyngeus.
And then you may eaily find the other two T. 13. f. 15. BB. CC. Mucles of the Gargarreon, if you have learned their Originals and Inertions out of the Hitory of the Mucles.

div.head: The Mucles of the hinder-part of the Head and Neck.
div.p: The Skin being removed, and the Fat of the hinder part of the Neck and of the whole back as far as Os acrum being pluck away, you hal oberve many Mucles; the firt of which is called Trapezius or Scapularis, which with the Latiimus doesTraptzius. cover the Neck, Back and Loynes, at it were a cloak.

Now the capular T. 14 f. • . & 2. AA. f. 2. AA. I. f. 1. CC. Mucle, which belongs unto the houlder, its broad end reaching out as far as the Occiput or Hind-part of the Head, does compas al the Mucles of of the Neck, and mut in the lower part thereof be eparated from the i Latiimus Muculus, and wholly plucked up from the roots of the Spines or pointed Bones of the whole Back-bone as far as to the hinder part of the Head, from which it mut be eparated, and only left ticking to the houlder-blade. b f. 10. CC.
c f. 9. BB.

This Mucle being taken away, the T. 14. f. 1. B B. f. 2. • . C. Rhomboides a Mucle of the Shoulderblade,Rhomboides. Servatus minor. mut be cut from the pines of the Backbone. Under thee lies the f. 2. E. Seratus Supernus minor poticus, the upper and maller Saw-Mucle ituate behind.
Thee Mucles being plucked away as far as to their Inertion, the Mucles of theThe plenius. Head do hew themelves. And the firt that occurs is the f. 2. H H Splenius.

Neare unto which is placed on the ide of the Neck, Levator f. 2. D D proprius Scapulae Levator capulae. or the Mucle appropriated to pluck up the houlder; whoe orginal cannot be dicovered, unles the Matoideus haveing been hewed, be taken out of the way.

The Splenius Muculus, towards the Roots of the pines of the Neck, being taken away, there lies under it the f. 2. I I. f. 3. E E. Complexus, neare unto which at the ide of theComplexus. Neck, lie certain portions of Muculus Spinatus, and the Sacrolumbus arieing as high as the econd Vertebra of the Neck.

The Complexus being taken away, below the econd Vertebra of the Neck, areTranverarius een two Mucles which ow their ervice to the Neck. The firt of thee is f 4. E E. Tranverarius, inter-poed between the tranvere and Spinie Apophyes of the Neck and Back.
Under this is pread the f. 4. D D. Semipinatus immediately covering the Bodies of theSemipinatus. Vertebra's.

Upon the firt and econd Vertebras of the Neck, are een eight mal Mucles, Obliquus major. in each ide four, of which the two Greater f. 2. L. f. 4. G G. Oblique Mucles, are carried from the tranvere Apophyis of the econd Vertebra, to the tranvere one of the firt. The two f. 3. & • I I. Recti Majores, do begin at the Spina of the econd Vertebra, and end intoRectus major. the Occiput.

Under their upper ends are ituate the two Muculi minores, or leer Mucles,Rectus minor.
the Streight and the Crooked, or the Rectus and Obliquus. The f. 3. 1. f. 4. K K. Minor Rectus lies hid under the Major Rectus, which you hal unlooe at the Head and pluck it a ide, that the minor Rectus may appeare.

The Mucle called Obliquus T. 14. f. 3. K. f. 4. H H. minor, is carryed from the Hinderpart of the HeadObliquus minor. by the Minor Rectus, into the Tranvere Apophyis of the firt Vertebra: But you mut free and lay bare of fat thee Mucles, as wel the t • eight as the Oblique or crooked ones, that they may be the more appa • ently een. And you hal begin your Section of the Mucles of the Head and Neek at the repective Spines or pointed Eminencies of the Back-bone.

When you have viewed the Mucles aforeaid you hal then make diligent earch after one that lies cloely ci • lking, above the Articulation of the inferior jaw and under the Zygoma; it is it •• ate upon the external wing o • Lap of the Pterygoides, and being altogether flehy and round in a manner, it is •… erted into that ame li • which is interpoed between the Coronis and the knob of the Lower Jaw bone.
It may be termed the Pterygoideus Externus to difference it from the InternusPterygoideus externus. decribed before.

div.head: Mucles of the Arme.
div.p: Thee Mucles being adminitred, you may proceed to others. And firt youThe pectoral mucle. hal eparate the T. 10. f. 1. A. B. T. 22. f. 1. E. Pectoral Mucle either from the Bret-bone, or from its lowet part, by which it is joined to the Serratus Major.

Meane while oberve that the Serratus Minor or T. 10. f. 1. E. Smaller Saw-Mucle, liesSerratus minor under the Pectoral or Ribs: leat you hould teare the ame, whiles you diect the pectoral Mucle, which you mut cut up, as far as to the middle of Clavicula. To which place being come, you hal eparate it from the Deltoides or Delta-haped Mucle, unto which it is fatened by a firme, but obcure band. Then you hal eparate the Delto-ides from its original.

From thence you hal proceed to the Mucles which are pred out upon the houlder-blade.Infrapinatus. One lies upon the Spina or Back-Bone, three are eated beneath the ame. That which is Next the Spina, is called T. 22. f. 3. B B. f. T. 22. f. 1. & 3. C. Infra-Spinatus.

div.head: Next thereunto, is the Rotundus f Minor. b T. 15. f. 2. E E E E.
div.p: Beneath that, you find the T. 22. f. 1. and 3 D. Rotundus major, tretched out beneath the lowerRotundus major. Rotundus Immerus. Rib of the Omo-platae or houlder-blade.

Under the capula you hal find the Mucle called Immerus o •
T. 22. f. 1 B. Subcapularis: it fills the Hollow of the Shoulder-Blade.

You hal leave the Original and Inertions of thoe Mucles untouched, only you mut eparate the ides of one Mucle from another, that they may be di •…
guihed aunder, one from another.

div.head: Mucles ituate upon the Back and Loines.
div.p: From the Omoplata or houlder-blade, decend unto the Back & loins which pa •• sLatiimus are covered with a Mucle called Ampliimus and Latiimus, or the T. 14. f. 1. C C. D D. T. 22. f. 1. F. Large •• and broadet Mucle.
