This Mucle mut be eparated from the Os Sacrum and the external Rib of Os Ilium, as far as to the lower Angle or Coruer of the houlder-blade, and its inertion at the Os Brachij a little beneath the Neck.

You mut while you cut it up at the Spines of the Vertebra's, take heed of poileingSerratus poticus a Mu •• le which lies beneath it, and is termed Serratus
d T. 14. f. 2. F. G. poticus infernus, the Hinder and lower Saw-Mucle, being a little one.
Which after you have pluckt off, from its original by the Os acrum, as far as its Inertion, you hall hew three other Mucles, tretched out from the Os acrum, all along the Spina or Back-bone.

Of which the firt being lateral and eated towards the Ribs, is called T. 14. f. 1. L L. f. 3. B B. Sacro-Lumbus. Sacrolumbus. You hall begin your diection of this Mucle at the upper part by the Root or the Ribs. A white line of fat wil guide you from the top to the bottome, where you may eparate it from the T. 14. f. 2. O O. Muculus quadratus which belongs unto theQuadratus. Loins, but in its original it is exceeding hardly eparated from the Spinatus.
Note by the way that the Sacro-lumbus does reach as far as the Hinder part of the Head, and that it does betow a double Tendon upon every Rib.

Now you hal eparate the T. 14. f. 3. D D. f. 4. A. Spinatus from Os acrum, by eaily and gingerly takingSpinatus. away the hard Aponeurois which is pred out over theSacer. Muculus acer; which being taken off, if you lengthen out your ection above, you wil dicerne the difference between the Spinatus and the T. 14. f. 4. B B. Sacer.
Which when you have attained, thruting your pen-knife treight in, as far as to the tranvere Apophyes, you will eaily eparate thoe Mucles.
The Spinatus, goes as high as the econd Vertebra of the Neck, being in the middet between the Tranverarius and the Complexus.
The Spinatus being fatened to the tranvere Apophyes, does alo arie as far as the Neck.

div.head: Mucles of the Breat.
div.p: The Bodie being turned and laid with the face upwards, you hall ever the T. 10. f. 1. C D. Serratus Serratus major Major laterally, and putting in your hand underneath, you hal find it tretched out under the Omoplata or houlder-blade as far as to the Clavicula. And then you hall ee the T. 10 f. 1. F. Mucle ubclavius placed between the Clavis and the firt Rib.Subclavius. Triangular is.

You hall look for the Pectoral Mucle internal or the Triangular Mucle, in the inner part of the Breat-bone pluckt off. Afterwards you hal carefully and gingerly eparate the T. 10. f. 1. G G. external intercotal Mucle form the T. 10. f. 1. H H. internal. The fibresIntercotalis. Cro waies interpoed, will ditinguih the one from the other.

div.head: Mucles of the Cubit.
div.p: When this is done, you hall returne unto the Arme to make obervation of the Mucles of the Cubit, which are eated in the Arme.
Five Mucles do infold the whole Arm, two in the fore parts, and three behind. You hall eparate the two Benders of the Cubit, on the former and inner part.

The firt, which preents it elf is the T. 22. f 1. G. Biceps or Twi-headed Mucle, whichBiceps. from its Original to its Inertion, may very eaily be divided into two. But you mut mark, that one Head of the Biceps, which growes out of the Coracoides, has a certain fleh adjoyned to it, which creep along the ide of the Pectoral Mucle, as far as to the midle of the Arme, unto which it is fatend mot firmly; and this Portion of Fleh makes a Mucle, which is ordained to draw the Arm forwards, which from its original I call T. 22. f 1. H. Coraco-ideum, the Coraco-idean Mucle. Coracoideum.

I have oberved the Biceps or Twi-Head in a very trong and brawnie Man to be a Triceps or Tri-Head, being exquiitely eparated into three parts, both in the Original and end thereof. The third Head prang out of the tendon of the pectoral Mucle.

Under the Biceps is placed the T. 22 f 1. I I. f 2. B. Brachieus internus or Inner Arme-Mucle, Brachieus internus. whoe original is at the end of the Mucle T. 22. f. 1. A. Deltoides. This Mucle mut be eparated idelongs from uch as border upon it.
In the outer part of the Arme three Mucles are placed, viz. the Longus, Brevis and Brachieus externus, and beneath the Elbow, the Angoneus is eated.

The external are the T. 22. f. 3. E. Longus and T. 22. f. 3. F. Brevis which embrace that Mas of flehLongus Brevis which makes the Brachieus externus. In their original they T. 22. f. 3. above E are ditinguihed by the tendon of Muculus • a ••
•• nus which comes between them: but at their •… on they grow together by a firme and inewy tendon. And therefore they are eaily, in their upper-part, eparated from the Brachieus externus; but in their lower partsBrachiaeusexternus. towards the Elbow, they are very hardly divided from the Brachieus.

Now thus you hal proceed: you hall curiouly take away the nervous tendon neare the Elbow, and goeing upwards by little and little, you hal gently <…> on the one ide and the other, alo inwardly; diligently oberveing the line which eparates the long Mucle from the hort, until you have eparated the Brachieus externus; from the Mucles which are placed above it. Then you hall ee it <…> from the Bone of the Arme, a little beneath the Neck thereof, with a flehy ubtance.

The Mucle Angoneus T. 22. f. 3. a. f. 4. G. cannot be een til you have pulled away the •• newy membrane wherewith it is covered. It aries at the lower part of the Arme neare the Elbow, lying hid between the Radius and the cubitus, and it is inerted into the Cubit. It is of the Length and thicknes of a Mans fore-finger.

div.head: Mucles of the Radius, the Writs, the Fingers, and the Thumb.
div.p: In the Cubit you hal find the Mucles of the Radius, the writs, the Fingers, and the Thumbe. And in the Inide of the Cubit as far as to the writs, you hal find Nine Mucles; on the outide you hal meet with even.

In the Inide you hal find them dipoed in this Situation and order following.Longus-Supinator radij Writ-benders. The firt that preents it elfe is the Longus T. 22. f. 4. E. Supinator Radij, which aries from the external apophyis of the Arme, and is tretched out upon the Radius.
Next to that, is the Radieus T. 22. f. 1. M. Flexor Carpi, after which follows the T. 22. f. 1. K. Palmaris Remarkable by a very mall and very long Tendon.
By the Palmaris is eated the T. 22. f 1. O. f 5. A. ublimis Digitorum Flexor, and next to it, o as to touch the ame, you have the T. 22. f 1. M. Cubiteus Flexor Carpi.

On the upper part of the Cubit, near the Joint, between the Longus Supinator and the Radieus flexor, the round Head of the Pronator T. 22. f 2. C. Radij hewes it elfe;Pronatoacs-Radij. which is a very hor • Mucle, arieing from the internal Apophy • is of the Arm and obliquely carried to its inertion into the Radius.
Vnder the Radieus, lies the Flexor T. 22. f. 2. D. Pollicis.

Beneath the Sublimis, lies the Profundus T. 22. f. 1. P. f. 5. B. Flexor Digitorum, and in the lowerFingerbendexs part of the Cubit, by the writs, lies the T. 22. f. 2. D. Quadratus pred under the Tendons of the Mucles, being three Fingers broad, and immediatedly fatened Cros-w •• es, into the Radius and Cubitus.
On the outide of the Cubitus above the Radius, the Extenor T. 22. f. 3. H. Carpi is tretchedExtenders of the writ. out.
Next to it, is the Alter T. 22. f. 3. G. Extenor, which is carried obliquely to the Cubit, and being fatened thereunto, takes its coure downwards.

Between the Radius and the Middle-part of the Cubitus, the Extenor T. 22. f. 3. K. D • g • torum is placed, which has a parcel of fleh annext unto it, pread under the Mucle ofOf the fingers. the Extenor Pollicis.
Vnder it, near the Cubit, lies the Extenor parvi Digiti, by the Writ.

Under the Tendons of the Extenor Digitorum you hal find two other fial Mucles, the one of which is the Extenor T. 22. f 3. M. Policis, the other is the T. 22. f. 3. • . Indicator ordained to wait upon the Index or Forefinger, whoe Tendon is united by certaine Fibres with the Tendon of the Extenor Digitorum.

The dviion of all thee Mucles is eaie on the upper part of the Cubit, both on theThe bet way to diect thee mucles. inide, and on the outide, and in the aid upper part, you mut begin your ection. For if you hould begin at the Tendons you would multiply Mucles, and make as many Mucles as you find Tendons. Thus therefore, neare the Writ, on the inner ide of the Cubit, you hal ditinguih the Tendons of the ublimis and the Proundus, allotting • ou • Tendons to each Mucle, and then take your coure upwards.

Radieus Externus extenor Carpi, is termed alo Bicoruis twi-horned, by reaon of its double Tendon. You may divide this Mucle into two, Mucles, ditinct in their original and inertion, but you hall do better to make but one of it.
In the Hand, you hall find Seventeen Mucles. Mucles of the Hand.

In the Palm or Inide of the Hand there are Thirteen; viz. the four T. 22. f. 5. C C C C. f. 2. f f f f. Lumbricales, the T. 22. f. 1. S. f. 2. h. Hippothenar, the T. 22. f. 4. K. Thenar, the T. 22. f
• . R. f. 2. G. Anti-thenar, the Abductor Indicis, the Maa Carnea, and the four Interoei T. 22. f. 2. f f f f. interni.

In the outide of the Hand you hal find only the four Interoei
f. 2. I I I I externi; with the Tendons of the Finger-tretchers, or of the Thumb-tretcher, and of the little Finger-tretcher.

div.head: Mucles of the Abdomen or Belly.
div.p: In your anatomical Adminitration of the Mucles of the Belly you hal thus proceed. The firt you meet with, which mut be plucked out, is the Muculus T. • . f. 2. H H. T. 2. f. 8. A. Obliquus decendens, which you hal ee conjoyned with the e erratus major, T. 2. f. 8. a a. toothObliquus decendens. within tooth, as if the Edges of two S • wes were Put togeher, and Joyned one within another, or as ome parts of the Scul are coupled by the utures. You hal know the difference of the Serratus and Obliquus one from another, by certain white lines and by the different poture of the Fibres. You hal eparate the Muculus Obliquus from its intanglements with the Teeth of the erratus major, with help of a very mal and harp Pen-knife.

The firt tooth is interpoed between the Muculus rectus and a portion of the Serratus: the econd and the T. 1. f. 2. F F. T. 10. f. 1. C. D. third are very hardly eparated. The other four lie lurking under a portion of the Latiinus, not receiving the flehy Productions of the Serratus.

To bring them therfore into ight, it wil be convenient to pluck up a portion of the Latiimus, as far as to the hinder pine of the Os Illium; and th • n you hal take thoe four Teeth off from the Ribs, and in concluion you hal cut off the Mucle, from the whol Rib which appertains to the Os Ilium.

If you be indutrious and can endure to take pains, you hal oberve that the econd, third, and fourth Tooth [or Finger] of this Mucle, doe creep higher up under the Serratus, than vulgar Anatomits imagine, and that this Mucle does there attain a inewy tendinous Head, which cleaves fat to the lower ide of the Rib.
A tendinous Head receives a portion of the intercotal nerve.

For the nerve, when it is come thither, it is divided into two parts, the one of which does ininuate it elf into the inewy Head of the Tooth of the Mucle: the other ticking fat unto the Rib, does make theT. 2. f. 9. d d d. nervous interections of the Muculus Rectus. The Mucle being thus cut up, mut be turned back upon one ide of the Belly.

You hal in the meane while oberve, that theT. 2. f. 8. b b. Aponeurois of this Mucle, is bored through near the Os pubis; as theT. 2. f. 8. B. Aponeurois of the Obliquus • acendens, and of the Tranverus are perforated, near the foremot and lowet Spine of the Os Illium; and therfore the Holes of the two oblique Mucles are not et jut one againt another, but at a ditance one after another, that the Gut might not be o apt to fall down into the Groine or Cod.
Thee Holes are broken in Ruptures into the Cod or ele dilated, which are diligently to be oberved, in reduceing of the Gut when it is trangled in the Groine.
And if at any time an Inciion be made in the Groine, to reduce the Gut, that hole ought to be made wider by Inciion, that the Gut may more eaily returne into the Bellie.

Above the Obliquus acendens towards the Hypogatrium, you hal find a little Nerve which ininuates and winds it elfe into the Apophyis of the Peritonaeum that it may be carried to the Teticle, becaue it penetrates the tranvere Mucle. It aries from the Nerves of the Loines, and is a portion of thoe nerves which are dieminated into the Oblique Acendent and the Tranvere Mucles.

When you have cut theT. 2. f. 8 B. c c. Oblique Acendent from the Rib of Os Ilium to which it cleaves very fat, you hal bring it to the Loines, where it may be eparated from the Tranvere. Then you hal eparate it from the Ribs themelves as it returnes upwards. And it wil be convenient to turne back this Mucle to the contrary ide, after the manner of the primus Obliquus; and when you hal come unto the Muculus Rectus, you hal oberve that this ame Oblique Mucle does embrace the Muculus Rectus or treight Mucle above the Navel, and below the Navel it tranmies a ingle Tendon under the Rectus which notwithtanding by the Edge of the Rectus does cleave o obtinately to the Aponeurois of the Oblique Decendent, that it is not poible by any Art to eparate or pul them aunder, without rending them. d T. 2. f. 9. A.
e T. 2. f. 8. d d. f. 9. bb.

While you cut the Tendons of the oblique Mucles from the hare Bones, be very careful leat you mangle the Apophyis of theT. 2. f. 9. E E. Peritonaeum which is carryed through thoe Tendons, and teare theT. 6. f. 2. D D. Mucle Cremater placed upon the aid Apophyis, and alo leat you teare the Tendon of the Tranvere Mucle lieing beneath.

You hal know the Mucle Cremater by its colour and Conitence. For it isHow the cremater is knowen. a peice of red fleh, thin, princkled with treight fibres, evered ome pace from the fleh of the Oblique Decendent, and according to the Length of the Groine, incloeing the Apophyis of the Peritonaeum. You hal find uch a parcel of fleh in women, but horter and narrower, placed upon the production of the Peritonaeum.

Between the Oblique acendent and the tranvere Mucle towards the Loins, many veins are een, which are the ofpring of the Lumbal and the Hypo-gatrick Veins. But you hal take precie notice of two remarkable nerves or innewes, which beides the little intercotal twigs inerted into the Teeth of the Oblique Decendent Mucle, do arie out of the two inner Vertebra's of the Back, and creeping obliquely upon the batard Ribs, are by the lat Rib dipered into the fleh of this Oblique and the Tranvere Mucles.

You may conveniently eparate theT. 2. f. 8. • e. f. 9. C. Muculus Rectus following the whiteMuculus rectus. Line, but not medling with the ends thereof. If you hal diligently and leaurely pare off the extremities thereof oppoite unto the Linea Candid • or white Line, you wil find the intercotal Nerves which bore their way through the peritonaeum, that they might come unto and contitute the nervousT. 2. f. 9. dd. interections of the Mucle, which now and then are wanting, as I have oberved in ome Bodies. I have often found two imperfect ones above the Navel; if a third be found, it is alwaies directly oppoite unto the Navel; you hal very rarely find a fourth Interection.

Towards the end of Rectus Muculus, on the inide you hal oberve the EpigatricaWhich is the true Linea candida. T. 2. f. 8. e acendens and the MammariaT. 2. f. 8. d. decendens toT. f. 8. f. meet together about the middle of the Mucle, where they grow into one by a cloe Anatomois.

That which eparates the right Mucles is a real T. 1. f. 2. K K. white Line treched out from
the xiphoides as far as to the Conjunction of the Share-Bone; and it is imply done of them, who cal the growing together of the nervous conjunctions or Aponeuroes of the Obliquus decendens, the White-Line, eeing the Aponeuroes themelves are united continually and not dijoyned by any apparent Line.

In big-belly'd women when their Bellies are very much ditended, in the lat months of their going with Child, by reaon of the Drawing of the Muculi Re •… aunder, a certaine black-blewih Line remaines for two or three months after the woman is delivered, which begins at the xiphoides and reaches unto the place where the hare-bones grow together, which vanihes away by little and little, the Right Mucles being reunited and growing together againe.

Over the lower end of the Right Mucles lies a mal Mucle called T. 2. f. 9. D D Pyramidalis Pyramidalis. which you mut curiouly part into two, and haveing taken away one, you hal ee a mot trong inewy Tendon of the Muculus Rectus, fatend to the Os pubis or Share-bone.
The Lef • Pyramidal Mucle is oft times horter and narrower than the right.

The tranvere T. 2. f. 9. A f. a a &c. Mucle which cleaves to the Peritonaeum, is not eaily drawne offTranverus. yet if you are deirous to take it away, you mut cut it from the Loines, and then gently eparate it from the Peritonaeum with your fingers alone.

div.head: Mucles of the Yard.
div.p: In a Mans Yard on either ide in the Groine and the peritonaeum you hal earch forThe Yard Erector. two Mucles, haveing firt removed a great deal of fat wherewith they are covered. The one of thee Mucles is T. 6. f. 1. a a. f. 5. H H. Erector Penis the Raier of the Yard, which a •• es from the Sphincter Ani or Are-mucle o called, and is inerted into the hollow and pungy Ligament of the Yard.

The other being placed upon the Urethra or Pis-pipe is called T. 6. f 1. b b. f 5. I I. Accelerator orThe Accelerator. the Speeder, it aries out of the ame Tuberoity beneath the pungy T. 6. f. 5. K K. ligament of the Yard, although it be fatened by a bit of fleh to the foreaid phincter or Are-Mucle, that it may beare up the fundament which flehy portion or bit of fleh forementioned I am wont to hew for the Levatores externi ani, or external Are-Heavers.

div.head: Mucles of the Fundament.
div.p: The Fundament has ixe external Mucles belonging unto it. The Sphincters, The phincters of Anus. The Levatores ani. and foure external Lifters, for the Levatores interni or inner-lifters do lie • ut of igh •… women there is a fift Mucle which belongs to the Coccyx or Crupper-Bone.

In the firt place you hal anatomie and hew the Sphincter T. 3. f 4. O. Cutaneus, then another larger red Mucle, and then the ide-mucles before and behind, the T. 6. f 3. N N. Levatores which arie out of the tuberoity of the Huckle-bone, you hal eek for them behind the Crupper bone and above the accleratores on the foreide, putting your hand in beneath, or putting in a little knife made of boxe-wood. But you hal more evidently dicerne the largenes of the Levator Ani, if you hal take away the Bladder, the Intetinum Rectum or Are-Gut and the womb of a woman, and withal hal ever the Conjuction of the hare-Bones.

For then you hal ee a br • ad but thin peice of fleh, drawn out from the Os Sacrum as far as to the Spine of the Os Ichij, underproped with a firme ligament, which is in that pace, and produced as far as to the Os Ichij it elf: which flehy Membrane ought to be taken for the Levator: for under it the Obturator Internus is ituate.

Beides thoe Levatores there is another ound to arie from the far • h • t extremityThe Mucle peculiar to the Coccyx in women. of the Os acrum and the Crupperbone, viz. a thin and harp pointed peice of fleh trewed with right fibres, encloeing the lateral parts of the Crupper-bone or
Coccyx on either ide, which holds up the Sphincter, and o the external Orifice of the Privy Parts in Women are widened, this Mucle drawing the Crupper-bone backwards, that in Child-birth the paage may be more free for the Infant.
I have eldom een uch a Mucle in the Bodies of men, and the ue of it when it is extant in men, is, to render the voidance of Dung more eaie, by drawing back the Crupper-bone when men are at tool.

The internal Sphincter (if we mut needs admit, and allow of a third) is no otherThe internal Sphincter. than a Membranous parcel of fleh, omwhat black and blue, which comprehends the Rectum Intetinum, or Are-Gut, like a Sheath or Scabberd, being adorned with treight Fibres and interwoven with a few circular ones; which if the Coat of the Guts is flehy, it differs from that common Coat of the Guts, which covers their in-ide. So the Rectum Intetinum is ditinguihed from the ret, neither is the Scituation of the Membranes, or Coats, varied.

div.head: The Bladder-Mucle.
div.p: The Bladder-Mucle T. 6. f 5. F F. Sphincter, is placed in a Man above the Protatae, The Bladdermucle in men. which it imbraces for the Space of two fingers breadth, and is eaily found without the Channel of the Pi • s-pipe: If you hal cut up the Pipe with a pair of Sciers from the N •• of the Yard, as far as to the Protatae.
You hal examine if you can find two Sphincters of the Bladder, one beneath, and the other above the Protatae, which I never oberved. a T. 2. f 5 Q.

Now that part of the Neck of the Bladder, which repects the Bones of the Share, is manifetly flehy, between the two Kernels called Protatae and there a twofoldDemontration of the Double Sphincter. Sphincter may be allowed; one fle • hy, placed upon the Protatae, and in that ence above them; but under the Protatae, is the Membranous Mucle of the Neck of the bladder: the other broad Mucle above the Protatae, and turned back under the ame, wil • e the Second Sphincter Mucle, becaue it does circularly imbrace the Protatae, above and beneath.

The Neck of the Bladder in women, is very neer as long as ones Thumb, beingThe Bladder-Mucle in Women. Nervous, Spongy, and black within, like the P •• s-pipe, or Urethra in Men, and compaed about with reddih fleh, which is taken to be the phincter: and while the Neck of the Bladder in women wells, if you put your finger within the watergate, you hall percive an hard and long tumor or welling and the uppermore carnoitie of the Privie Part, which cloes and tops the end of the Bladder, is both in Girles and women allwaies found larger than the ret, and the other glandules being by frequent child-bearing torne and defaced, this allwaies remaines to the End of their lives.

div.head: Mucles of the Clitoris.
div.p: You hall eek the Mucles of the Clitoris, after this manner; having leaurelyLatus. taken away much fat till uch times as rudd • fleh appeares, you hall ever the Latiimus Muculus which lies very low, growing out of the phincter of the Fundament, and inerted into the very Lips of the Water-Gate or female Privity, for the moveing or traitening whereof, I concevie this Mucle is ordaind. The other isGracilis. the Gracilis Muculus fatened to the Ligement of the Clitoris.

div.head: Muclus of the Thigh.
div.p: In the Cavity of the Belly, when the Entralls are removed, you hall oberve abovePoas. the Loyns the Muculus longus and rotundus, the long and round Mucle which is termed T. 10. f. 1. O. O. T. 23. f. 1. A. Poas, which you hal eperate from its original to its inertion which is in the mall Trochanter

I have oftentimes in Men, and omtimes in Virago's, or manly Women, oberved another • ank Mucle placed over the Poas aforeaid. It eems for this Caue added, that as a Ligament or Band it might trengthen, and as it were gird in the • o • t • nd looe fleh of the Mucle Ploas.

The Cavity of os Illium is filled by the Muculus latus T. 23. f. 1. B. Iliacus or broad i •• ak Iliacus. mucle, which together with the Poas being conveighed along upon the Os Pub • s and by its tendon united to the Poas, is terminated in the mall Trochanter.
Having turned the Body, you hal proceed to the Mucles which make the Buttocks, called Gloutii that is buttock Mucles. There are three of them reting one upon another.
The firt and greatet T. 23. f. 2. B. f. 3. A. Buttock Mucle, you hal eperate towards its tendon,Gloutius major both before and behind, having firt made it cleane and freed it from the fat.

Then you hal proceed in your ection upwards til the whole is on all ides cut of, til you come to its inertion, which is in the great Trochanter, and there you hall leave it, or having firt taken away the broad band, you hal cut off the aid Mucle in the fore part.

Under this lies the Gloutius T. 23, f. 3. B f. 4. C. Medius or middlemat Buttock mucle, which mayMedius. eaily be eparated in its upper and lateral part towards the Os acrum. But bene •• h the middle part of the Gloutius Secundus the T. 23. f. 4 B. third is placed, immediately fatenedMinimus. to the Os Ilium: this Mucle you mut not cut of.

Between the middle and the leer Buttock Mucles there are two remarkable veins, which from the Hypogatrica doe creep over the Obturator Internus • with an A •• e •• e, Hand in Hand, and a portion of the Nervus major poticus, they pread themelves into numerous branches: and there arie mot cruel pains in the inmot parts of the Buttocks, which counterfeit the ciatica or Hip-gout. Would not drawing blood from the Haemorrhoid Veins, erve well to dibu •• hen thee parts?

In the next place you hal proceed to the Quadrigemini and the Obturatores, Quadrigemini which are een beneath, the greater Buttock Mucle being taken away. The uppermot being the firt and longet of all, is called the T. 23. f. 3. • . f. 4. D. Pyriformis unto which the two
T. 23. f. 3. b f. 4. G. Purvi or little ones doe follow in order, coupled together, that between them •… d in their Boome as it were, they might contein the Tendon of the Obturator internus.
To thee two there is orderly adjoyned the T. 23. f. 3. D. f. 4. E. Quratus Quadrigeminus being broader and more flehy than the ret.

The Obturatores are two, the T. 23. f. 3. E. f. 4. F. internall and the
T. 23. f. 4. • . external, the Internal has itsObturator internus. orginal out of the Circumference of the Oval hole; and its Tendon being carried along between two Ligaments, and being hid in the boome or holownee of the econd and third Quadrigeminal Mucles, it is carried into the Cavity of the great Trochanter. And therefore you mut pul aunder the econd and and third Quadrigeminals, before this Mucle can come in ight.

Now the Ligaments through which the Tendon of the Obturator Internus is carried, are two; the one being external is carried from the Os acrum to the Tuberoity of the O Ichij: the other being internal and placed beneath the external, is carried from the ame Os acrum, into the pina of the Os Ichij.

The Obturator externus cannot be dicovered unles the fourth broad Quadrige •… nalExternus. Mucle be plucked back, and that the Propagation thereof may more evid ••• ly appeare, you hal take away the Muculus Triceps or Three-Headed Mucle.

Sometimes I have oberved above the Primus Quadrigeminus, the Iliacus exter
•… Graci •… , which from the lower and tranvere pines of the Os acrum, did • nd into the top or the great Trochanter. You hal therefore anatomie and hew eleven Mucles of the Thigh, placed above the Os Ilium.

In the hinder part are nine, Three Gloutij or Buttock Mucles, which being drawen aide, there appeare four Quadrigemini and two Obturatores. In the fore
part and hollownes of the Os Ilium are found two Mucles, the Poas which indeed has its original higher than from the Os Ilium, and the Iliacus.

div.head: Mucles of the Leg.
div.p: In the Thigh from the Haunch to the knee and Ham you hal oberve and hew eleven Mucles.

In the fore part you hal find even, the Longus, the Facia lata, the Rectus Sutorius. Membranous. Rectus. Vati. Crureus. gracilis, the D •• o ati, the Crureus and the Triceps; which are o ituate, that in the firt place you meet with the longus or
• u • orius, then the Membranous or Facia • ata. According to the treigh •• e • s and length of the thigh the Rectus Gracilis is drawne out. Neare and bordering upon this are the Vati d • o, under which lies the Crureus which immediately covers the Os femo • i • , or Thigh-Bone, Adjoyning to the vatus internus is the Triceps, which lie • cu • keing within the Thigh.

In the hinder-part of the thighs you hal find four, dipoed after this manner. Unto the Triceps on the Inide is •••• ened the Gracilis Poticus: bordering upon it, is the eminervous, with the Semimembranous, and between this and the vatus externus is the Muculus Biceps placed.

In the forepart of the thigh, you mut begin at the T. 23. f. 1. l l. Long Mucle; which being cut of, you hal cleverly take away the Facia f. 1. E. c c c.
••• a, either all of it or as much as you can, and you hal bring it as far as to the knee.
Then you hal cut of the Gracilis f. 1. F F. Rectus.
Afterwards you hal proced unto the two vati, which that you may more eaily eparate from the Crureus, they are ditinguihed one from another by a line running between them, which you hal cut up.
Then you hal diect the Vatus f. 1. G G. Externus by the latus externum; but it is harder to eperate the Vatus f. 1. H H. internus.

And you hal begin to eparate the ame at the lower part neare the Patella, and thruting in your hand, and neatly mannageing your penknife, you hal cut it towards the upper parts: and o the two Vati hal be evered from the T. 23. f. 1. &c. Crureus.

From thee, you hal come unto the Triceps, which may more truly be termedTriceps. quad • icep •
or rather quadrigeminus, becaue of foure Heads and as many ditinct • mer • ions.
It is placed in the inner part of the Thigh, and its firt and upmot portion growingPectineus. out of Os Pubis, eems to be a Ditinct Mucle, which in regard of its ituation may be termed Pectineus.

I have ometimes found four other portions perfectly ditinct one from another, beides the Pectineus, and the lat portion was ve •• e long, like a emi-nervous Mucle, and was carried on with a inewy tendon as far as to the Leg.

I conceive this is the Mucle, which has been in women oberved ditinct from the ret, in the hinder part of the thigh, and is wont to be joyned as a fift, unto the four P • tici. For it aroe from the Tuberoity of the •• chium and was inerted into the H •• der Part of the Tibia.
It is found in Women, becaue they were to have broader Buttocks and larger Thighs than Men.

It is an ea •• e matter to eparate thoe four Mucles placed in the hinder part ofSeminorvou • . Semimembranou • . • iceps. Gracilis. the thigh, viz the T. 23. f. 3. G G. Seminervous, the T. 23. f. 3. H H. Semimembranous, the T. 23. f. 3. •
•
• . Biceps, & the Gracilis T. 23. f. 3. F F. internus. I have often ound the Biceps ditinct both in its Original and Inertion. b T. 23. f. 1. &c. C C.

div.head: Mucles of the Tanus.
div.p: In the Leg from the knee unto the Tarus are found 13. Mucles; in the hinder part you hal find five placed after this manner.Gemelli Popliteus. Plantaris. Soleus.
The firt are the T. 23. f. 1, d d, f. 3. K K. Gemelli; under their Heads lies the f, 4 H. Popliteus hidden; between the Gemelli and the Soleus, the f. 3. M. Plantaris hides it elfe.
The Soleus lieing beneath the Gemelli, does immediately cover the hin-bone.
In the lateral and external Part of the Tibia, by the Spine, there appeares theFoot-benders Peroneus f. 1. L L. Flexor pedis, Neighbour to which is the Longus f. 1. M M. Extenor Digitorum.

After which followes the Extenor Pedis, tibieus f. 2. E E poticus. Under the Extenor Extendors. longus Digitorum, lies the Extenor f. 1. N pollicis; and beneath the Flexor pedis Peroneus, lies the Extenor f. 2. F F. Peroneus.

The Flexor f. 4 K. f. 6. B. pollicis does take up the internal and lateral part of the Tibia. In the lower part of the Tibia, between the flexor pollicis and the Tibieus poticus, the Flexor f. 4. l l f. 5. C. digitorum medius holds its place.

It is eaie to eparate the Mucles which infold the Tibia on all ides, providedThe eparateon of thee Mucles. you do fir •• pluck off the facia f. • E. c c c. lata, which is carried out as far as to the foot. Having divided the Heads of the Gemelli, you hal diligently earch for the Popliteus or Ham-Mucle, ituate obliquely over the Head of the Soleus. Then you hal oberve the flehy Head of the Muculus Plantaris, which lies lurkeing between the Gemelli and the Soleus. The Plantaris is like the Palmaris.

In the fore part of the Tibia the Peroneus externus and Peroneus internus eem to make one Mucle, becaue they arie from one and the ame part, and are carried through the Cleft of the external Ankle-bone.

But the one is internally inerted into the Os meta-tari, which utaines the little Toe: The other being drawen under the ole of the • ee • , is carried into the Os metatarie which uta • es the Great Toe. d f. 3. L L.
In the Foote you hall take notice of eventeene Mucles. In the out ide of the Foote the • e are five, viz the T. 23. f. 2. G. Pedieus and the foure interoei f. 2. a a a a. externi.

In the ole of the Foote you hall oberve twelve, viz. the Brevis Digiti f. 4. L. f. 6. A. Flexor or little-Toe bende • , the three f. 6. e e e. Lumbricales, thoe which are made out of the Maa
f. 6. D D. Carnea, the foure external Interoeans and as many f. 5. d d d d. internal.

Upon each ide of the Foote is placed one Mucl, viz. the Abductor
• . f. 3. O. f. 5. b b. Pollicis; and Minimi Digiti abductor.

In the hollow of the foote, there is placed another Maa carnea, pread under the firt, and cleaving immediately to the Bones. it may be perfectly divided into foure or five portions, although in the middle paces of the Bones of Metatar • us the Muculi Interoei are conteined.

Furthermore in the Sole of the Foote you hal find that ame Internal Mucle which is oppoed to the Abductor Pollicis or Great-Toe withdrawer, like unto the Antethenar in the Hand. It may be calledf. 5. b b. e Muculus Tranveralis.

div.head: Chap. 46. Of the Veines, Arteries and Nerves belonging to the Limbes.
div.p:
The Veines of the Limbes begin in the Arme at the Arm-pit, and in the Feet they
<…>
the Veines of the upper Limbes Axillaru. take their Original from the Groines.

The Vena T. 24. f. 1 A. Axillaris neare the Arme-pits does produce the Humeralis, which is called thef. 1. B B B. Cephalica or Head-Veine. It has no Arterie to accompanie the ame, and it holds its Coure through the whole Radius.
A little after it endes forth the f. 1. • . m m. Thoracica which is expanded into external partsThoracica. of the Chet, and meets with mal twigs of the Vena T. 12. f. 1. a a a a. azygos.

It is afterward termed T 24. f. 1. C C. Bailica and by the Bending of the Arme, it is dividedBailica. into two branches. The f. 1. e e. &c. one of which creeps all along the inide of the Cubitus; the other being T. 24. f. 1. x. y. &c. external decends beneath the Skin unto the Hand. h f. 3. P. f. 5. c.

The Ramus internus or inner branch is called Mediana 1. t t. &c. Vena, and it receivesMediana. a branch of the f. 1. f f. Cephalica below the bending of the Arme, where it is called the Cephalica or Bailica. Thee three Veines are opened beneath the Bending of the Arme.

But the Bailica has an f. 2. A. by L. Artery under it or very neare it, and a f. 3. • . 1. &c. Nerve and the Tendon of Muculus T. 22. f. 1. G. Biceps, which bends the Arme: which parts mut (in the opening of a veine) be avoided, for if they happen to be cut, they bring great Inconveniencies to the Arme.
The Cephalica being treched out upon the T. 24. f. 1. i i. &c. Radius neare the writ, diverts to that part of the hand termed Metacarpium, that it might with its twigs water the Hollow of the Hand.

Between the Ring-finger and the little finger, they place the f. 1 •
Salvatella veine,Salvatella. which is wont to be opened; between the thumb and the fore finger, there is another opened, which is called Vena
f. h pollicis or the thumbe veine.
The Mediana f. 1. g vena is to tally external and runs under the Skin, into the palme of the Hand.
The Bailica creepes through the f. 1. o o. x. y. &c. internal and external parts of the Cubit, with a two-headed branch.

Now the Veines have one thing peculiar to them in the Limbes viz that theyAnatomois of the Veines and Arteries. manifetly do communicate with the Arteries. This Galen proves in his third Book of Natural faculties, the lat Chapter, And up and down in other parts of his works. Which thing is o ma •• tet that it ought not to be called into quetion.

Moreover the veines in the f. 7. the whol Limbes and internal Jugulars have Valves. In theThe Valves of the Veins greater channells and in the diviion of the leer ones there are f. 8. the whole two on each ide one oppoed to the other and placed interchangeably.

Now we may doubt of their ue ince the circulation of the blood has been foundTheir ue. out, for the common opinion was that they were placed in the Limbes and in the internal jugular to top the exceeding flux of blood into thoe outmot parts which are in continual motion. But thoe that hold the Circulation of the blood, do ay their ue is to hinder the flowing back of the Blood which acends upwards unto the Heart, according to the opinion of Dr. Harvy, unto which I willingly give my Aent.

Let us pa • son from the Veines to the Arteries of the Arme. The Ramus upe •
•• av • us The Arteries. Axillaris. proceeding to the Arme-pits, is termed T. 24. f. 2. A. Axillaris. It accompanies the Vena Bailica, whereas there is no Arteria Cephalica.

Neare the Arme-pits it produces the f. 2. c. d. Thoracica and in its progres betowesThoracica certaine twiggs upon the bordering Parts, and being lengthened out as f • r as to the bending of the Arme, it is divided into two f. 2 C. B. branches, which are carryed o • , to the Inide of the Hands.
For the outide of the Hand above the Metarcarpium, is void both of Mucles and Arteries.
The other f. 2. B. Branch being drawn out upon the Inide of the Radius, is felt to beatRam • minores. in the writ.
The other running treight along the Ulna is with its Coin pread out into the hand according to the length of the Thumbe and of the little Finger, o as to betow of their twigs upon every Finger.
I hall in the ame Method dipatch the Nerves of the whole Hand.The Nerves.

Out of the Holes of the foure lower Vertebra's of the f. 3. 4. 5. 6. 7. Neck, and the two firt Vertebras, of the f. 3. 1. Back, f. 3. a. b. c. d. e. five or ixe Nerves take their Original, which being ouerwhelmed under the Mucle calenus, they are brought under the Clavicula, as far as to the Arm-hole, where they aref. 3 X X. twited one within another, like the trings of a Cardinals Hat. e f. 2. C.

Afterwards the foure uperior ones are under the Deltoides cattered over the internal part, accompanying the Vena bailica and the Artery of the Arm, and creeping betweene the Mucles Biceps and the Brachieus externus.
The T. 24. f. 3. f f. fift and ixt T. 24. f. 3. I I. Nerve, being bowed back under the capulary Mucle Rotundus major, they are dieminated into the hinder Mucles of the Head.
There remaine then the Quatuor Primi alreadie decribed, which being carryed through the Arme and Cubit; they are dipered into the aid Cubit and the Hand

The Primus T. 24. f. 3. g g. Nervus beneath the head of the houlder is over-whelmed in thePrimus. Coracoidaeus and drawne along under the inner ide of the Biceps, and lurking under the Tendon of the aid Mucle, it joines it elf to the Vena Cephalica, where it growes mall: alo it is placed beneath that Veine, below the bending of the Arme.

The Second T. 24. f. 3. K K. Nerve being undivided and thicker, does decend to the bending ofSecundus. the Arme, being covered only with fat, and at the bending of the Arme it is placed beneath th Arteria and Vena Bailica.
Howbeit the Vena Bailica a little below the Cubit does, towardes the interior part, recede a little from that Nerve, that it may be united to the Vena Cephalica.
But foure fingers beneath the bending of the Arme, being alwaies uperintendent to the Bailica, it paes undivided along, unto the writ, the veine appeares above.
At the Writ tis cleft into ten mall branches affording two little twigs to every inger, which crepe along the ides of the aid ingers.

You hall oberve by the way, that three fingers breadth beneath the bending of the Cubit, it is covered by the Mucles which bend the writ and Cubit, which arie cut of the internal Tuberoitie of the Arme.

The third T. 24. f. 3. h h. Nerve is carryed along undivided unto the Angona, where beingTertius. conveighed through a Cleft which is betweene the Elbow and the inner Condylum or Tuberoite of the Arme, according to the length of the Cubit, and being drawne out over the Cubitaeus externus, it is carryed unto the writ, towards the little finger. And therefore by leaneing on the elbow, the whole Arme is benummed. Being divided neare the Hand into foure branches, it is pred into the out-ide, of the Hand or Back of the Hand.

The fourth Nerve is the thicket of all interwoven with Veines and Arteries, andQuartus. unk deep in the Brachiaus externus; it is carryed from the forepart of the Arme into the Hinderpart, and decending there through unto the Radius, and being carried all along the ame, it is joyned to the vena Cephalica, and looes it elfe at lat into the writ.

I proceed unto the veels of the Inferiour Limbes. The Crural T. 24. f. 4. A. veine, does inThe veines of the lower Limbes. Poplitea. the groine produce a remarkable branch viz. The T. 24. f. 4. a a a. aphena, which according to the longitude of the utorius Muculus decends unto the Ham. Beneath which, in the Anckle it contitutes the vena poplitea, which was opened in Times pat. There it tranmics the branch which is in the upper part returrent, above the Ham, unto the crural veines, or the arhena receives that ame branch, from thoe cruralls.

Afterward being divided into two parts it lips down unto the two external Ankles, but the greater portion takes its coure unto the internal Ankle, where it formes the true T. 24. f. 4. a. beneath Saphena which is uually opened.
It is termed corruptly Saphena, as if one would ay Saphaia becaue of the Apparencie,Saphena. which is a new name brought into ue by the late Greekes, unknowen to Galen.

When the crural veine has produced the Saphena, it is oon after divided into four branches, of which, the two T. 24. f. 4. b b. &c. external and lateral ones which are the hortet are dieminated into the uperior Mucles of the Thigh, both the internal, namely the Biceps, and the external viz. the vati and the Muculus Cruraeus. a T. 24. f. 3. i i.
d T. 24. f. 4. f f f.
The Ramus • er • ius which penetrates into the inner parts, is termed Ichiadicus. Ichiadicus.
The fourth is called T. 24. f. 4 d d. T. 24. f. 4. g g. Mucularis. Mucularis.

Thee branches being propagated, the Trunke of the Vena cruralis being plit into two, decends unto the knee, being attended with the crural Artery branhchedThe leer branches. into two: But one of the T. 24. f. 4. h h. branches is aloft and waters the external parts, the other is more T. 24. f. 4. g g. deep: both of them do afford twigs to the neighbouring parts, and when they have reached unto the Ham, being pread along between the Soleus and the Gemelli, they decend to the two Ankles.
But the external Ankle is princspally watered from the low-laid crural veine, yet o that in the compas of the Ankle two notable veines are oberved.

That which quarters upon the Malleolus internus or inner Ankle-bone, is the branch of the Saphena. That which takes its coure beneath the malleolus, being pread out above the Tarus, is a branch of the crurall Veine.

Neither of thee Veines can be afely opened unles they wel, by reaon of the neighbouring arteries, which the Vena Saphena placed in the inner Ankle is free from. And this Veine is opened in all dieaes awel of Men as of Women. Yet nevertheles in the Sciatic, the Veine beneath the Malleolus externus, is more advantageouly opened, becaue it has greater Communion with the Part affected, namely the Coxendix or Hip.

The Ditribution of T. 24. f. 5. A A. Arteria Cruralis, is not equal to the Vena Cruralis, becaueThe Arteries. it produces no Saphena. For a little lower than the Groine, it tranmits twoCruralis. T 24. f. 5. &c. within the Muculus triceps, which are lengthened out as far as to the Gloutij.
Afterwards it ends forth T. 24. f. 5. d d. &c. two, into the former parts of the Thigh. a T. 24. f. 4. c c. &c.

And then the Cruralis decends undivided as far as to the Ham, Where it is dividedIts branches. into two Branches; the T. 24. f. 5. i i one of which does laterarlly creepe all along the outide of the Leg upon the Muculus Peroneus. The other being thrut into the Mucle oleus, and liding downe unto the Heele, is dieminated into the ole of the Foot; and the other is branched forth into the outide of the Foot.
The Vena Saphena has no Artery to attend it, and there is not any nerve near it, and therefore it may afely be opened.

The Nerves of the foreide of the Thigh are two, ditinguihed in their original,The Nerves of the fore par • . The firt. but o as they oon grow together and become one cord, which is carried entire without any diviion, unto the Groin. Where it is ditributed into five T. 24. f. 6. B C D. &c. branches, commonly wrapped up in a Membrane, which being dipered on every hand into the Mucles of the fore part of the Thigh, they are branched out as far as to the whirlbone of the Knee.
Now the Rie of thee Nerves is in the T. 24. f. 6. 3. 4. 5. three lowet Vertebra's of the Loyns, neither is it viible, unlee the Mucle Poa be torn aunder, within which they lie hid.

Then beides thoe fore-mentioned, you hal ee another mal Nerve, drawn
•… e econd. through the oval hole of the Os Pubis and pent upon the neighbouring Mucles viz. the Triceps.

A great and very thick Nerve does glide along the hinder part of the Thigh, whichOf the Hindpart. The firt. in its Original is made up omtimes of three, oftener of four portions, which are bred out of three or four of the upper holes of Os acrum, and being carried along through the cavity of Os Ichii, which is eated between the pines of the aid Os Ilium through the internal and hindermot Mucles of the Thigh, undivided, ometimes doubled and olitary without the ociety of a vein and Artery, as is ordinary in other Nerves of the Body, it is carried into the Ham; where being divided into two, omtimes into T. 24. f. 6. i. k l. &c. four, it betows little mal twigs (conidering its bulk) upon the Neighbouring Parts. b T. 24. f. 5. I I.
e T. 24. f. 6. E E.
f T. 24. f. 6. 6.

The other a Branch decends through the Calf of the Leg to the Heel, dealing outIts Branches little Nervs in its paage, and being drawn through the Cleft of the inner Anklebone, it is ditributed into the ole of the Foot in as many Branches as there are Fingers.

Another is carryed into the b fore part of the Foot, fatened unto the Perone, and o lipping downe along unto the external ankle, and when it is come thither, it is pread abroad into the upper ide of the Foot, as was aid of the former.

This exceeding great and thick Nerve being ill dipoed or dieaed, a BatardA Batard Sciatica what? Sciatica is thereby caued, which conits wholly therein; there is a grievous paine, which afflicts not only the Hip, but reaches into the Thigh, the ankle and Foot, namely to all places whether the Nerve which comes from the dieaed Hip does reach. Fernelius in the 18. Chap. of the 6. Book of his Pathology. and therefore in this batard ciatica Cauticks are to be applied, and Iues made at the bending of the Buttocs, alo thoe parts mut be anoynetd and meared with an Epipatick or drawing Plater.

You hal oberve by the way in a batard ciatica, that thoe nerves are watered by the Hypogatrick veines and the Arteries above the ame, and therefore the nerves cannot be dried unles the Hypogatrick veines are emptied, by many times letting blood in the Armes and Feet, and by Hor-leeches often applied to the Veines of the Fundament.

Now Galen in the 8 Chap. of his 16. Book of the ue of the parts of our Body, hewes the reaon why this ame Nerve is not mixed with other fore nerves as it is in the Nerves of the Arme, but is carried behind the thigh; viz. Becaue the joynt of the Arme tands farther from the Vertebra's of the Neck, than the joynt of the Thigh does from the Vertebra's of the Loines and Os acrum.

About the Beginning of this great Nerve, there is another adjoined, which rieingThe econd. out of the third hole of the Os acrum, and being carried along above the pine of Os acrum, it is branched out into the Muculi Gloutij and the Flexores Tibiae, as far as to the Ham.

div.head: The Medicinal Conideration.
div.p: Dieaes of the Veines belonging to the Limbes, epecially to the Leg and Thigh,Varices what they hee? are the Varices which are knottie dilatations, in which the Blood is collected, as it were into Certaine Satchels. Now they are cured with atringents with a cloe andTheir Cure. convenient ligature. Or the veines are pricked and the blood let out, or at the beginning of the varix the larget vein which gives nourihment to the ret, or the beginningWhether a veine cut off will grow againe? it elfe, is tied up and cut off. Many conceive that the veines cut off are bred againe; they bring for an example the veines which are een in a very great Sarcoma or flehy Excrecence; but Fernelius has rightly oberved, that they are not veines, but channels between the Skin which nature has framed as gutters to water and nourih the Sarcoma or flehy Excrecence.
Many thinke that the veines which are cut, being tied together with a tring do grow againe, which I do not beleive.

Hippocrates cals the veines Spiracula Corporis, the vents of the body or the breathing holes thereof, which being opened, the Body is aired: and he aies that when the Veines are dried, they draw harp and cholerick humors in burning fevers. Alo the ame Author aies, that the veines do draw more than the fleh Lib. 1. de Morbis. Epecially if they be more hot and dry than ordinary.
• Bloody weats whence they proceed?

When the Veines being debilitated through Sicknes of the Liver, become naueant and enclined as it were to vomit, they uffer the Blood to run out, not only through the mouthes of the upper and lower veines, but alo through the Skin of the whole Body, in manner of a bloody weat, which I have oberved two or three times.

A toppage of the Veines and Arteries, does often happen in Pleth •… ck bodies,The motion of the veels how abolihed? o that in all places in which the pule is wont to be felt, the motion of the Arteries is abolihed; <> which cae Hippocrates commends blood letting, as a meanes to put the veells into motion againe.

Somtimes the Pulle of all the Arteries is intercepted, not excepting the Groine or crurall Arteries, the Motion of the Heart til remaining, which dipoition if it continue long it kills the Patient. But if the motion of the Heart be perihed likewie, the Patient dies uddenly. I have een two that had no pule at all, only their Heart continued beating, who lived ixteen yeares, but in extreme weaknes. Balduinus Ronaeus aw one in the ame condition, as he affirms in his medicinal Epitles.

Hereupon, a quetion may be raied, how the pulation of the Arteries can beHow the motion of the pule in the Arteries can be topped, while the Heart moves. topped whiles the Heart beates after its wonted manner, though lowly; whether it be not neceary in uch a Cae that the Aorta be obtructed neare the Heart, and that the irradiation and influlx of the arterial blood be by that meanes interce •• ped. And then the Blood of the veines approaches the Heart, being drawne thither in the diatole or dilatation thereof, that it may receive the eale of Vitality in the right ventricle; and being afterwards driven forth by the Sytole or Contraction into the vena cava, the vital pirits are forcibly carried into the length of the channel, and by the mutual anatomoes of the veines and Arteries, they are communicated to the aid Arteries with the blood. I have in ome perons oberved that the motion of their Arteries hath been frequently intercepted or became very unequal for ome daies together, afterwards the impediment being removed which was near the Heart, I found the ame inequality in the Caeliac Arterie, which did beat vehemently, although the pule appeared equal and wel ordered in the ret of the body. This, I conceive happened by reaon of a little bit of fleh or fat, which acending to the Gates of the Heart did caue uch a pule o inordinate, and being repelled or drawen back unto the Caeliac Arterie which is a branch of the Aorta, it did produce uch an irregularity as aforeaid.

The Crural Arterie, eeing that it is evident in the Groine, and ubject to our feeling,The Pule is lat felt in the crural Arterie the pule thereof is eaily dicerned, being vehement in regard of the greatnes of the Arterie, and the lat which remaines after the pule is extinguihed in other extreme parts of the Body, wherein it is uually felt to beate. And therefore when no pule can be felt in the other uual places, it mut be ought for, e examined in this crural Artery, not only in Men but in women alo, provided the Rules of Honety be not broken. And if when a dieae is at the Heigth, we can feel no pule in this part, death is neare at hand.

The Dilation or Section of an Arterie happens chiefly in the external parts,Aneurima, what it is? where the leer Arteries reide which are branches of the great Trunk. And this dieae is termed Aneurima. It is eldome een in the trunk of the Aorta becaue of its thicknes.

div.trailer: The End of the Fift Book.

div.head: THE SIXTH BOOK OF THE ANATOMY AND PATHOLOGY OF John Riolanus, THE KINGS PROFESSOR OF PHYSICK.

argument.head: A new Oteologia or Hitory of the Bones.

p.hi: Wherein he treates of the Bones, Ligaments and Gritles of the whole Body, by which the frame of the Body is compacted together, the Mucles being removed, handling al the Dieaes and ymptomes which happen unto the Bones.

div.head: CHAP. 1.
div.p:
THe Scope of Nature and of the Phyitian about the Body of Man its Fabrick, are contrary, the one unto the others Nature intending to make up the Body of Man, begins at the mot imple parts, and o proceeds by little and little to the more compounded ones, until heThe Method. finih her work. But the Phyician, that he may attaine unto the knowledg of this workmanhip of Nature, proceeds gradually from the more compound unto the mot imple parts; o that in his Analyis or Reolution, thee parts are lat which were firt in the Compoition. So when we pul
down an houe, firt we throw off the Ceeling, then we demolih the walles, andWhy we treat of the Bones in the lat place? latly we d • g up the foundation. Wee in like manner in our takeing aunder this Houe of Mans body by Anatomical Adminitration, do now in the lat place treat of the Bones which are the foundation of the whole Body, and placed before al other parts. we hal conider of them in the way of a new kind of Oteologia or Hitory of the Bones, which is no les, • neceary than the doctrine of the Skelleton of the Bones.

Having therefore explained and demontrated the ofterparts of the Body by way of Analyis, I proceed to the lat and more olid parts thereof, which according to the Synthetick method, or order of compoition, are the firt, uch as are the Bones, which are now otherwie conidered than when they are boiled and dried and o demontrated.

div.head: Chap. 2 Of the great Profit of this new Oteologie, or Doctrine of the Bones.
div.p: THere is a two-fold Doctrine of the Bones; one is demontrated in dried Bones,The Doctrine of Bones demontrated in a dead body, is better, & more neceary. which have been prepared by boyling; the other is hewed in the Bones of the Body, whiles they remain naturally fatened one unto another. Both thee Doctrines are ueful in the Art of Healing, and for uch as would have a perfect knowledg in the Body of Man.

For in the dried Bones, in which commonly this Doctrine is taught, nothing is learned, aving the external hape, poture, and compoition or frame of one withFor the perfect knowledg of Mans Body. another: But a diligent obervation of the Bones, while they are knit and fatened one unto another, is more conducing to practice. Becaue the fatenings of the Bones one unto another by Gritles and Ligaments, alo by the everal orts of Articulation, or joynting, are in ome dried Bones quite different from what they are in uch as be moit; for in dried Bodies you would think that ome Cavities are hollow, and Cup-fahioned, the Cavities being empty, and bereaved of their Cartilages; which notwithtanding appear hallow in a freh Body, the Cavities being full of Gritles; and contrary-wie, you would in a Skeleton ay, that ome CavitiesAnd are hallow, which are deep in a freh Body, the hollownes being encreaed by a Gritle brim.

Moreover, The external Conformation and Quality of the Bones, is more evidently dicerned in the Bones of a Carkas, which loes much in Bones that are prepared by boyling: as for example, the Gritly incrutations of the extremities, the Membrane which is about the Bones, and the Mucous, or limy ubtance lodged between the Bones; alo the internal ubtance, or Marrow, or Marrowih Juyce, are manifetly dicovered in the Bones of a freh Body, which are not at all in dry and withered Bones.

And therefore in repect to the Practice of Phyick, and the Cure of vitiatedFor the Practice of Phyick bones, and uch as are broken, or out of Joynt, it is neceary, diligently to look into, and carefully to axamine in a dead Body, the Natural Conformation of the Bones, and their conjunction one with another. I do not dilike the ue of dried Bones, to teach and demontrate the vulgar Oteology, or Doctrine of bones, atThan the Vulgar. which we mut begin, as we have done in this Treat • e; provided the Demontration of the bones in a dead Body, be afterward added to the former.

For by this Repetition, and Repreentation of the bones, we hal imitate the OrderWhere notwithtanding we ought to begin. and Deign of Nature, which in the Generation of the Parts of our Body, is wont in the firt place to form the bones; but he finihes, and perfects them after al other parts, for they grow as long as the body encreaes, according to Aritotle. And if we beleeve Hippocrates in the Sixt Book of his Epidemicks; Women have their Coures, til their bones have attained their utmot perfection.

div.head: Chap. 3. What is to be oberved in the Bones of a dead Body not boyled.The Natural Contitution of a Bone in what it coits?
div.p: IN the firt place, you hal oberve the Natural Contitution of the Bone, that you may dicern the fault of a bone which is out of Order.

A bone in a living Body naturally dipoed, ought to be, 1. Hard, to procure the bodies tability. 2. It ought to be Oyly without, becaue it is nourihed. 3. It mut be covered with the Periotean Membrane, that it may have ence; for if it loe the Periotium, it becomes enceles. 4. It mut be white tinctured with a moderate rednes, becaue it is a Spermatick part, and is nourihed with the dewy vapor of the blood. 5. It mut be hollow, or pongy, that it may continue the ubtance of Marrow, or a Marrowy Liquor to nourih it elf withal. 6. It mut be at the ends cruted with Gritles 7. It mut be anointed as it were with an oyly moiture, to facilitate its motion. 8. It mut have a continued and even ubtance. And therefore you hal know that a Bone is miaffected, if it be oft, as Ruellius, In what the preternatural. Fernelius and Hollerius have oberved, that in ome perons the Bones of their Bodies were by icknes become o oft and flexible, that you might bend them which way you pleaed, like wax. Aritotle in the third book of his Hitory of Animals, aies that bones are not flexible, neither are they apt to plit, but only ubject to break. Scaliger in his commentary adds: I have een the thigh bone by reaon of the venerious dieae, or by ue of I know not what medicaments, bowed like an horne. Geographers write that in a Country of Ethiopia, the inhabitants have naturally from their birth bodies o flexible, that they can turne and wind them into any poture. I have red in Hippocrates of a boy that was borne without bones, haveing the Principal parts of his body otherwie ditinct. Foretus aw a boy made after the ame manner in ome of his members.

Wherefore if a bone hal be drie without, it declares a ditemperature of the part: if it be white it argues want of heat, if red, inflammation; if black, rottennes and blating. If a bone be enible, there is ome ecret fault in its ubtance, or in its periotean membrane. If it be olid and concrete without cavities or parts it renders the body heavie and luggih, and can containe no marrow. Plinie relates that there are ome that lived having olid bones and without marrow, which are very rare and are termed Cornei. The igne of uch a Contitution is never to thirt and never to weat. They are called Cornei from the Cornel or Dog-tree; becaue the male Cornel has no pith or marrow. See Rhodiginus. Such a one the Syracuian Lygdamus is reported to have been, who in the three and thirteth Olymp • ade was the firt who at the Olympick Games, became Victor at all Exercies and won the Paneratian Crowne: his bones were found to have no marrow in them, as Solinus relates in his 4 Chapter. Antigonus in his Book of wonders Chap. 8 Writes that the bones of a Lion are o olid that you may trike fire out of them as out of a flint; Howbeit Columbus denies that uch bones are void of marrow. Which Epicurus, contradicting aritotle maintaines, as poible in the 8. Booke of Athenaeus his Deipnoophits. Aldrovondus has oberved that among Fowles the Etrich has olid bones, void of marrow. But in cae a bone hould be deprived of its Gritly Crut and of its periotean Membrane, it is moved with difficulty, and has no feeling at all. If a bone become uneven and prominent o as to have bunches upon it, it is termed Exotois, which is an effect and concomitant of the venereous pocks when it is of long tanding and confirmed, howbeit it may pring from ome other caue. Finally being depraued and mihapen, or dijointed, it hinders and mars the Action of the whole body or its parts; and being divided in its ubtance, it argues olution of Continuity by ome cleft or fracture. and although a broken bone by the mediation of a Callus becomes oddered together one the outide: Yet does it till remaine divided within.

div.head: Chap. 4. Of the Nourihment, Sence, and Marrow of the Bones.
div.p:
While the Bone did live and was nourihed, it had a twofold utenance, the oneThe remote matter that nourihes the Bones. remote, the other conjunct or immediate according to Aritotle, in his Book of the parts of live-wights. The remote Sutenance of the Bones, is the thicker and more earthy part of the blood. The next or immediate is the marrow, or marrowy liquor, which is contained in the hollownes and poroitie of the bones. Hippocrates in hisThe immediate matter. Book de Alimento, aies that the marrow is the Nutriment of the bones, and therefore it is that they are Joined together or oddered up by a callus. How can it beWhether the Bones have Veines? (may ome man ay) that the blood hould nourih the bones, eeing they have no veines, which are the channels to conveigh blood to all parts? Hippocrates aies in his book de Oium Natura, that of all the bones, the lower Jaw-bone alone has veines. Galen indeed in his 8. Booke de Placitis, attributes unto every bone a Veine greater or Leer according to the Proportion of the Bones: and in his Comment upon the firt Booke of Humors, he aies that there is a Veel ditributing blood allowed to every bone. But he confees in the lat chapter of his 16. Booke de u Partium, that the veines of the Bones are o mall and fine, that thay are not o much as viible in the larger ort of Animals or Live-wights, becaue nature according to the Neceity and Indigence of the Parts, betowes upon ome greater, upon other leer Veines, moreover the little holes which are found about the extremities of the bones,Whether they have Arteries? do manifetly declare that omwhat there is which goes into the aid Bones now their is nothing goes into the bones but little Veines. If we beleive Platerus, the Arteries doe no where enter into the bones, eeing the pirits can eaily penetrateOr Nerves? into any of the bones without the ervice of the Arteries to carry them. Neither do I conceive that there are little nerves diffued through the ubtance of the Bones to give them the ene of feeling, becaue all the feeling they are capable of, is by means of the periotean Membrane which does incompas them. Nevertheles Nicolas Maa call's God to witnes that he aw a Man, who had an ulcer in his thigh, o that the bone was bare, in which bone there was a ence of paine, o that he could not endure to have it touched with a rough intrument in regard of the paines it caued, and it was freed from the periotean Membrane. Yea and he bored the bone, and found that it had the ene of feeling within the ame, which he therefore thought good to declare, that Anatomits might be moved to conider, whether ome branches of nerves do not Penetrate into the ubtance of the bones.
• Threefold Marrow of the Bones.
We canot looke into the Cavities and Marrowes of the Bones; unles they be firt broken. I oberve a threefold Cavity of the bones and a threefold marrow.
In the greater Cavites of the larger Bones, the Marrow is reddih; in the leer Cavities of the maller bones the marrow is white; In the pungy bones there is contained a marrowy Liquor.

In the meane while you hall oberve, that the marrow within the Cavity of theWhether the Marrow of the Bones be compat with a Membrane. Bones is compaed with no membrane, neither is it made enible by any little nerves penetrating the ubtance of the bone, as Paraeus does imagine. Hippocrates himelfe, in his Booke de Principlis was the firt that noted this. The Marrow of the Back-bone is not like that marrow which is in other Bones, for it alone has membranes, which no other marrow has beides it.

div.head: Chap. 5. Of Articulations or Jointings of the Bones.
div.p: LET us proceed to the Joinings-together of the Bones.To the Articulation of the Bones there concurs. an Head.
There does concur to the Articulations of the Bones, the Head, the Cavitie, the Gritle, the Flegmatic moiture, and the Ligament.
Every Head is in its owne nature and original an Epiphyis, but in proces of time it degenerates into an apophyis.

The Head is within of a Light pungie and porous ubtance, being filled with blood or with a marrowy Juyce, on the outide it is covered with a very hard hell or bark, very thin and compact, which is cruted over with a mooth and polihed Gritle.
Now the Head of a Bone is T. 21. f 1. d d. f 4. a. great and long, or hort and flat, which is termed T 21. f 1. & 2. I I. Candylos

The Cavity of the Bone which receives the Head, is alo cruted over with a Gritle, A cavity which if it be deep, it is called in Greek T 21. f 4. B. Cotyle, if hallow, 'tis called T 21. f 4 F. Glene. It is omtimes encreaed with a Gritlie brim, let the bones hould too eaily lipA Gritle. aide, and fal out of their places.

And in the Cavities themelves, there is contained a clammy, thick, and OylyA flegmatick Humor. Pituitous Humor, to procure a more eaie, and expeditious motion of the Bones, o we greae the Axle-trees of Coaches and Carts, that the wheels may turn more eaily and quickly. Through want of the foreaid Humor in uch as have the conumption, and are extreamly dried, while they go and tir their Limbs, one may hear as it were their bones knock one againt another, and rattle in their Skins: As is proved by a memorable Hitory, recorded by Symphorianus Campegius, in the Medicinal Hitories of Galen; and as I my elf have often times een.

Now that the bones might be o knit together, as to make a Joynt, there is needA Ligament. of a Ligament or Band, whoe ubtance is broad and round, its color white or bloody, uch as is the round Ligament which fatens the T 21. f 7. a a. Leg, and the T 21. f 8. a Thigh, and that which unites the T 21. f 5. A. Atragalus with the T 21. f 5. B. Pterna, and that of the Atragalus with the three Bones of the Tarus, which are termed T 21. f 5. E E E. Aeneiformia. For thee bloody, or bloodyih Ligaments, are alwaies interpoed between the bones, and are very hard; but thoe which are drawn about the Articulations, do alwaies appear white. So the Nerve-Gritly Ligaments, which are interpoed between the Os Sacrum, and Os Ilium, are oberved to be bloody in a Woman newly delivered of her Child.

Now every Conjunction of the Bones is made by Nature, either for Motions Why the bones are articulated. ake, or for Perpiration, or for the Paage of ome certain Subtance, or for the differencing of Parts, or for Security, and to preerve from violence.
Conjunctions of the bones for Motions ake, are een in the Fingers, Writs, Elbows, Shoulders, Hips, Shanks, Ankles, Ribs, Spondyls; in a word, in al movable Articulations.
For Perpirations ake, we ee bones joyned together in the Sutures of the Skul.

For to give paage to ome ubtance or other; we ee the like conjunction at the production of the Pericranium, and at the through-fare of ome certain Veels, which go partly out, and partly in; to which intent the Sutures of the Skull were contrived.
For Securities ake, and to avoid the violence of breaking, &c. we ee the aid Conjunction in al uch bones as are compounded of divers maller ones.
For the differing of parts, certain conjunctions of bones eem to have been contrived in the Bones of the upper Jaw.
Having laid this Foundation out of Galens 11. Book, de u Partium, chap. 18. it is an eaie matter to prove the orts and differences of Articulations, out of the Doctrine of Galen himelf.
The Bones are joyned one with another, ome by Articulation, or joynting; othersTwo-fold conjunction of bones. What a joyne is Sorts of joynts. by Symphyis, or cleaving together.
A Joynt termed Articulus, is a Connexion of Bones, ordained either for motion, or for ome other Caue.

In repect of motion, there are two orts of Joynts The one is contrived for manifet and trong motion, which is called Diarthrois: The other is ordained for
an obcure and difficult motion, or for none at all, and it is called Synarthrois.
Of the former kind of conjunction of bones, viz. Diarthrois, there are threeParticulars of ea •• ort. orts; Enarthrois, Arthrodia, and Gynglymos.

Of the econd kind of Articulation, viz. Synarthrois, there are in like manner three orts, Enarthrois, Arthrodia, and Gynglymos; becaue Synarthrois, and diarthrois, do differ only in the quantity of the motion; as Galen does teach in his Book de Oibus, which alo he manietly declares in his Book de Diect Mucul. Chap. 22. neare the end. and in the 13. Book de Oibus.

But becaue a Synathrois is ordained not only for motion, but for ome other caue, as namely for perpiration, the tranmiion of ome ubtance, the differencing of Parts, and to ave from harm by tres and violence; it comprehends three other orts under it, viz. Sutura, Harmonia, and Gomphois.

Thee ix differences of Synarthrois or joynting may be proved by ene and byExamples of the orts. Example. The T. 10. f. 2. 1. 2. 3. &c. Ribs are joyned to the f. 2. A A. Bret-bone by an Arthrodia, which in regard of motion may be referred to a ynarthrois. The T. 21. f. 1. & 2. F. Bones of the writ are coarticulate with the bones of the f. 1. H H. f. 2. G. Metacarpum (Galen de uu partium Lib 2 Chap. 8.) but that ynarthrois is made by the way of Arthrodia. The f. 5. A. Atragalus is joyned to the f. 5. C. Scaphoides with an obcure motion, which is Enarthrois Lib. de Oibus, Chap. 24. Gynglymos is found in the Vertebras of the T. 10. f. 3. Back, which is to be counted as a kind of Synarthrois; the Gynglimos of the other Vertebras, is a kind of Diarthrois. Galen in his 26. Book de Compos. Med. ecundum locos, and in his 12. Book de uu Partium, calls the utures T. 15. f. 1. a a. &c. of the Head ynarthroes. Alo he cals the harmonia of the T. 8. f. 4. D. inferior Jaw-bone, ynarthrois, in his Comment upon the Ninth part of the econd book de Fracturis. The bones of the Ste ••• n or Bret-blade T. 10. f. 2. A A. being immovable, are joined together by a ynarthrois. From Galen in his book de Oibus and other places of his Writings, I could prove, that the Jawbone and the bones of the Bret-blade are Joined together by ymphyis, becaue they grow together as the Peron comes to yeares, o that no markes are remaining of their former ditinction. So Galen in his Book de Oibus, calls the Conjunction of the inferior Jaw-bone with the Chin, Symphyis.
Symphyis is an immovable union of the Bones, which is performed either withSymphyis, what it is? Its Differences. omwhat intermediate or without.

In regard of the threefold Medium, ome Symphyis is called Synchondrodis, from the Cartilage Gritle which is the Medium of the Union a econd is termed yneurodis, from the nerve which is the medium, a third is called Syarcodi •
from the flehy Medium. To which we may ad a fourth termed Neurochondrodis, becaue the Union is made by a Medium which is of a mixt nature, being partly nervy, and partly gritly. But more may be een of this, in Galen his Doctrine of Bones.

The differences of ymphyis, do appeare in the bones of the a lower Jaw, in theIts differences exempli • ied Bodies of the b Vertebras, in the bones of the c hare one with another, and in the conjunctions of the d
• l • an bones with the e Os acrum, in the growing together of the vertebras of Os acrum one to another, and of the epiphyis; and in the conjunction of the Os
•
Sphenoides with the Occiputs bones, and in the conjunction of other bones, which in children were divided, but in perons come to years, they are found growing together by Symphyis, ine Medio; uch as are decribed by Galen in his Book de Oibus.

The Ligaments which knit the bones together and that flegmatick humor wherewith the bones are meared, and the Gritles, both uch as are common to divers bones articulated together, and likewie uch as are proper to the particular bones to crut the ends of each of them: al thee hal be treated of in our particular Muter and Surveigh of the Bones.

div.head: The Medicinal Conideration.
div.p:
The General Dieaes of the Bones are, Caries or Rottennes, and putrefaction,
which proceeds from a common, or extraordinary Caue, uch as is the Venereal Pox.
Exotois, or a welled knot upon a bone, which aries from the foreaid Caues.Exotois.

Kedmata, mentioned by Hippocrates, which are Chronical Dieaes, proceedingKedmata. from defluxions, common to al Joynts, but epecially infeting the Hip-bone. Of thee kind of Dieaes, • ead the Medicinal Definitions of Gorraeus, and Foeius in his Oeconomia Hippocratis.

Of kin to this, is Paracelus his Synovia, or Hydarthrois, which is a continualHydarthrois. Flux of wheyih or blood-watry Humor, out of exulcerated Joynts, epecially if the Nerves or Ligaments be Dieaed. Hildanus in a peculiar Book on this Subject, proves that this Dieae Synovia (which was firt o called by Paracelus) is the ame with that Dieae which is termed Meliceria, by Cornelius Celus, Lib. 5. Cap. 26.
A ure thing it is, that the bones being dieaed, do drop blood, and Galen oberved as much.

The bones are likewie ubject to Fracture, or breaking, and Luxation, Dilocation,Fracture. or disjoynting. Now a Fracture of a bone, is a Diviion made in a bone by ome external Caue, cutting, or bruiing the ame.
There are two orts of Fractures, a traight one, and an oblique, or crookedIts kinds. one. The former is according to the length of the bone, or overthwart.

The latter, or oblique is (if we beleeve Galen) too curiouly differenced by the latter Phyicians which have ucceeded Hippocrates; for it is aid to be Nailfahioned, when the Fracture is partly traight, and partly circular; another ort is called Alphi •• edon, when the bone is broken all to hivers.
Another ort there is, which is called Apotrauis, or Detractio, whereby a Fragment of the bone is o taken away, that there remains a mark in the urface of the Bone.
Another ort of Fracture, Hippocrates mentions, which he cals Apoclama, and Galen terms Hapagma, when a bone is broken there where it is joyned with another bone.
Luxation, or Disjoynting, is a Dieae of the bone in Scituation, when it is removedLuxation. out of its place.
There is a two fold Luxation, or disjoynting of a bone; the one compleat, when the Head of the bone is lipt out of its ocket, and this is called Exarthrema, a being out of Joynt.

The other is Incompleat, and termed Pararthrema, when the bone is in omeIts orts, meaure only removed, and lengthened as it were, which is motly een in the ubluxation of the Thigh. In an Exarthrema, the Leg eems horter than it was wont to be; in a Pararthrema it eems longer than uual.

The Caues of Luxation and Subluxation, that is to ay, of perfect, and imperfectCaues, disjoynting of any Member, are external, or internal: The External are, a blow, a violent ditorion, or wrenching, a fall, and extenion of a Member. The Internal caues are, a thin Humor, which does relax the Ligaments, or a thick Humor which by little and little, fils the Cavity of the Joynt, and at lat thruts out the bone, by reaon of an Anchylois, which is bred.

Now Anchylois, is a fault in the Articulation of bones, whereby the Cavity ofAnchylois. a bone, which ought to receive the Head of another bone, is filled up; be it what kind of Articulation it may be, either Enarthrois, Arthrodia, or Gynglymos. Hereupon the bone thus dieaed, either is held bowed in, or remains tretched out, and tiff. And in cae without the foreaid Anchylois, the Tendons of the one ide hal in the Limbs be cut in under, the traight or crooked bones do no longer erve to bend or tretch out the aid Limbs.

div.head: Chap. 6. Of the Bones of the Skull.
div.p: HAving diligently conidered the Articulations, or joyntings of the Bones oneThings to be oberved principally. unto another, let us now take notice what is obervable in every particular bone being freh, which is not to be een in the Skeleton, or in dried bones. I will proceed from Head to Foot, according as I am wont to do in my Diection, and Demontration of thee parts. Now my Demontration of the bones is two-fold; the one I call Oteotome, or Bone-Diection, in which the bones are eparated each from other; the other I term Oifragium, in which the bones are broken, that their inner tructure may be dicerned.
And in the firt place, let us contemplate the two-fold Table of the Skull, orTwo-fold plate. the double Skul-board which is thinner in Women, than it is in Men.

The uppermore is thicker, and harder, and more moothly polihed than the neather: but the lower is rough and furrowed as it were, that it might afford place for thoe Veels which creep along the Dura Mater, from which ome notable Veels arie, which by the Ears do ininuate themelves between thoe two plates, or boards of the Skull, for to irrigate the intermediate pace.

Now that ame intermediate pace, is a certain pongy Subtance, which receivesIntermediate pace and contains a Marrowy Juyce, erving for the nutriment of thoe bones. The which Marrowy Juyce is reddih, by reaon of blood flowing out of the mal Veins cituate in thoe parts; which is wont • hen to flow out when the Skul of a living man is boared through with a Wimble, or other boaring Intrument. Now the Skull, according to Hippocrates in his Book de Vulneribus Capitis, is double in theWhy the Skull is double? middle of the Head, that is to ay, hollow between two plates and boards, that it might contain a Marrowy Juyce to nourih the bones. Hippocrates adds, The whol Head, a mal part excepted, reembles a punge ful of mal Caruncles, or little bits of fleh, which if you pres, and queeze with your finger, you hal perceive blood to drop out of them: alo you hal ee mal Veins running up and down, which abound with blood.
