Out of the foreaid Caruncles, being bruied with a vehement blow, the blood is queezed, which putrifying, does corrupt the bone, which in the mean while appears ound on the out ide: but the Sanies weating out from the inner plate or Skul-board, does corrupt and putre •• e the very • rain it elf. And if o he when the Skul is razed, you ee blood come forth, do not therefore conclude that the Fracture: penetrates the inner plate; becaue that blood flows out of the pace which is between the two plates, or boards of the Skul.

That ame pungy Hyperarcois or breeding of proud fleh, which grows up inProud fleh in Head-wounds, whence it proceeds? wounds of the Head, is bred out of the foreaid Duplicature of the Skul-bone; as Hippocrates has oberved. Touching the Fungous Excrecences of the brain, whether they are bred from the broken bone, or from the Dura Mater, ee Sennertus in the firt Book of his Practice.

But Hippocrates his Caruncles are vainly ought for in this intermediate pace, whatever Fallopius pleads to the contrary in his Book of the Wounds of the Head, unles a man would call the pungy ubtance of the bones Sarcia, or Caruncles, in regard of their Function.

This intermediate pace interpoled between the two plates of the Skul, is calledThe pace between the skulplates, how called. by Hippocrates, Diploe. Howbeit, Galen contrary to the Opinion of the Antient Phyitians, cals the econd, and inmot plate of the Skul, Diploe, in the ixe Book of his Method of Healing.

The Ue of this Diploe, Duplicature, or pungy ubtance, is three-fold FirtThe ue thereof. to receive blood for the nourihment of the Skul Secondly, That the Flehy Excrecence in the Fractures of the Skul, might grow out of it: Thirdly, That the Fumes of the Brain might more eaily be exha • ed.

Somtimes an Humor is collected between the two plates by way of trancolation,Why there are two plates.
which being in proces of time corrupted, does caue mot exceive pains, which often happens in an • iveretate Venereal Pox, when the Skul is knobbed, and bunched with a certain Exotois.

This double pla • e or board, of the Skul has been made by a wonderful contrivance of Nature, let in al blows upon the Head, the wound hould penetrate the whol ubtance of the bone. Hence it comes to pas, that omtimes one plate is cleft while the other remains unhurt.

The Whore-maters Pox does often-times eat through the external plate, and omtimes through both the plates, without killing the Patient, who lives a long time after; as Palmarius avouches in Chap. 4. of his Book de Lue Venerea. The like Example you may read in the 18. Chapter of Benivenius his Book de Abditis Morborum Cauis. And I my elf have often oberved the ame.

The Sutures, although they are T 15. f 3. a a. b b f 4 b b. &c. very cloely united in living Perons, yet areThe Sutures. they omtimes very a • t to gape, and to move pain, as Galen reports, towards the end of his third Commentary in Officinam Hippocratis.

But they eem not at al inclined to any loones, or gaping about the meeting togetherWhether an Iue may be made in the Crown of the Head? of the Sagittal and Coronal Sutures in Perons come to ripenes of Age, where a Fontanel is a made; and therefore I have often found by Experience, that this part may without any detriment have a Cautick applied thereunto. Which kind of Practice, Fabricius commends in his Chyrurgery; others dilike it as dangerous, viz. Mathaeus de Gradis, Vealius, Lib. 1. Cap. 6. of his Anatomy. Baptita Montanus in his 36. Counel. Zechius in his Counels. And Baptv
•• a Carcanus in hi • Book of Head-wounds. See Claudinus his Counels. I confes, that omtimes in Children, this part being oft and gritly, is long ere it grow hand over that it is in grown perons; and Galen has een it in uch Yonglings to move and pant, Gal. Lib. 13. Method. Cap. 22. And in uch a cae to apply a Cautery, were dangerous. The Africans did burn an Iue in the Crown • of their Childrens Heads; as Mercurialis hews from Herodotus. They did burn the Veins of the Crown of their Heads, with calding Oeypus, or Sheeps Greae and in cae any Convulion happened they did Remedy the ame by the prinkling of Goats pis thereon.

It is written by Herodotus, Aratus, and Arrianus in the Life of Alexander the Whether Blackmeers have Sutures in their Skuls? great, that the Heads of the Aethiopians, and Egyptians had no Sutures, which gave Pareus occaion to write, That the Aethiopians and Moors, and thoe which inhabit hot Regions towards the South, and the Aequinoctial Line, have Skuls harder than ordinary, having none, or very few Sutures in them. The fality where of did plainly appear, when I diected a very wart • y Black-moor publickly in the Medicinal Schools whoe Skul was in al things like one of ours.

In the Head there are many remarkable Cavities, which the Anatomits callCavities of the Head. Sinus. Thee you hal diligently earch for, that you may know whether they are void and empty, covered with a thin Membrane, and what communion they have one with another.

Now the Cavities are, on each ide four. The Maxillary Cavity, which lies concealed within the upper Jaws. The Frontal Cavity, eated in the Forehead, by the Eye-brows. The Sphenoidean Cavity, which lies hidden under the Seat or Saddle of the Sphenoides. The Matoidean, which is contained within the Matoides. They are al empty, and covered over with a thin Membrane, only the Matoidean, is hollow indeed but has no Membrane, but is ditinguihed into even, eight, or nine little Cels, as we ee in a Bee-hive.
The Entrance of the Maxilary Cavity within the cavity of the Notrills, is to be een on the ide of Os Spongioum.
The Entrance of the Frontal Cavity is een in the highet and inmot pa •• s of the Notrills.
The Entrance of the Sphenoidean Cavity we find to be deep. Within the notrils the pongy bones being taken away.

The Ingres of the Maxillary Cavity, is evident without cutting the Bones. The Ingres of the Frontal Cavity is evidently perceived, the Frontal bone being cut in under above the Eye-brows: The Ingres of the Sphenoidean Cavity, is dicerned, as oon as the inner plate of the Sphenoides is taken away. The entrance of the Matoidean Cavity, is contained in the left ide of the Concha, neer the Apophyis Matoides, and cannot be een unles the arched Vault of the Concha be broken, or the porus auditorius pulled in peices.

Sylvius conceives and demontrates from Galen that flegm being tranmitted through the little holes of the upper plate, is collected and heaped up within theWhether flegm may be collected within the Cavity of the Sphenoides. Sphenoidean cavity, and thence conveighed into the Palate: which way of the paage of Excrements, is by Vealius, Columbus, Falopius, and Valverda rejected: who contradict Galen in this point, and maintain that this excrement is voided through the neighbouring holes which ret upon the Sella Sphenoidea.

The reaon of Gallen and Sylvius is, that it is better the excrements hould be trained, and kept up for a eaon in thoe Cavities, than that a man hould be continually pitting, and holding his mouth evermore open. For although the Sphenoidean Cavities, are in the diections of dead bodies empty, and appear not to be ful either of flegm or eroities: probable notwithtanding it is, that the erous humor which flowes and ditils out of the Choana, through the ive-like plate of the Sella equina, is trancolated into the Cavities which are beneath, and from them powred back by certaine oval and ufficiently wide Holes, and voided forth into the pungy bones of the Notrils: neither do they deny, that a part of the eroities, does weat through the poroities of the inferior table or plate, into the palate. But the erous humor received in the pungy bones of the Notrils, does by little and little weat out and pas away, when by its quantity or quality, it provokes nature to an exctetion. For to what purpoe think you has Nature framedThe ue of the inus Sphenoides. thoe cavities? Has he done it to make the cul o much the lighter? or that they might be conduit heads or torehoues of aire, which is of neceity breathed in, for the Generation of animal pirits? But they cannot be torehoues, becaue they are a fingers breadth ditant from the frontal Cavities, nor have they any continuation or conjunction with them. Againe the Aire which is required to be exceeding pure, would be defiled by paing to and fro through the pungy bones. Furthermore in the many dead bodies which I have diected, ome of which might be notty and flegmatick, I never found the mammillary Procees any larger than uuall. But by thoe paages flegm ought to be derived unto the Os Ethmoides or Colander Bone; or fluctuating unto the Bais of the brain, it ought of its own accord to flow unto that place, becaue the foremot Ventricles of the Braine, are eldom perforated before, o as to have a through fare into the Notrils.

Wherefore I conceive that al the not and flegm of the notrils is not traindBy what waies the flegm of the noe paes? through the Colander Bone, but that it flows down into the Palate through the four pipes or channels of the Choana, or that being collected in the Cavities of Os-Sphenoides, if it pas through the little holes of the Plate of Os Sphenoides, it may be derived into the Spungy bones of the Notrills.
The aid pungy bone is ful of holes being ditinguihed, with bony Cells, in which mal Caruncles or bits of fleh are contained, which being welled, the dieae Polypus is bred.

Afterward you hal conider the Paage of the Notrils into the Palate, by theeThe paages from the Notrils to the Palate. cavities which are ditinguihed by the Os T. 15. f. 6. 1. Vomer. At the roote of the pterygoidean Apophyis, there appeares an hole compaed with a Gritle, which is the extremity of that paage, which reaches from theFrom the Eare to the Palate. Ear to the Palate, by helpe whereof Deafe perons heare, it a man peak into their mouth when it is wide open. Alo by help hereof the Ear is mot eaily purged with maticarories.

div.head: The Medicinal Conideration.
div.p: In the Skul, by reaon of the pace contained between the two plates thereof, hardPrimary dioaes of the Scul. Tumors tumors are bred, and almot of a bony nature; yea and ome are truly bony, uch as are hornes. An hard, ful and oblong tumor is called Teiudo, of kin to which is the Tumor Talpa, which alo is called Topinaria.

There is another tumor which is termed Natta, and growes ometimes chiefly in the Back, which hangs by a mal root. This threefold tumor, if timely care prevent not, is wont to grow to a greater Bulke. Hornes are wont to grow out in the Skul, the forehead, and ele where; yea and upon other bones. I have een an horne a finger long, which grew out of the lower part of the Leg, like a pu • . Of thee kind of Hornes Sennertus has neatly treated, in the fit Book of his Practice.
Beides thee Tumors the Fracture of the cul is frequent, which proceeds fromFracture a Violent and external Caue. And it is either without or with Contuion.

There is a threefold fracture without Contuion, the firt is termed diacope, when an Arrow or dart falls upon the Head and peirces deep, the econd is called Apocheiparnimos, which is a kind of planing or having as it were, when a piece of the bone is pared away: the third is termed Hedra which is a gap or ra • e made by the cut of a weapon.

A fracture with Contuion, if it be trait and in the bone mitten, and immovable,Kinds of fractures. it is termed Fiura or Rima, by the Greeks Rogme: if it be in another bone beides that which was mit, it is termed apeichema, that is to ay, a reulting clet, like the Rebounding of an Echo. If the bone be moved and broken, there is a threefold fracture reckoned; viz. engeioma, which is a depreion of the skul to the Membrane or Meninx of the Braine; Ecpie •… a which is a depreion of the aid Scul divided into thinner and maller bits: camaroois which is a vaulted Elevation of the broken Skul. Enthlais o called, is indeed a contuion but without fracture, being as it were a flexure or bowing of the oft cul. Which kind of contuion is een in braen veells, as pans and kettles &c. when they are battered only and not broken.
In the Bones of the cul we often find a Caries and Exotoois proceeding from aCaries Exotois common Caue, but more often from the Whores Pox.

div.head: Chap. 7. Of the Inferior Jaw-Bone.
div.p: The inferior T. 15. f. 3. L. Jaw-bone is in uch as are of yeares one continued bone, withoutIts ubtance. Articulation. any hew of diviion, as far as to the Chin.
Its Articulation is very looe, being fatened with an orbicular Ligament.
A movable Gritle is pread over the knob thereof, to procure the freeer motion

Within the Jaw-bone there is a creae or Channel cut out, ordained to containe the Veells, which is eparated from the cavity which containes the marrow, that is might afford a mal potion of the veels to every tooth.Channell.

This Channell of the Veels is ituate in the middle of the Jaw-bone, and is manifet; and therefore Hyppocaates writ in his book of the Nature of the Bones, that of all bones only the lower jaw-bone has veines.

div.head: Cahp. 8. Of the Teeth.
div.p: Afterwards you hal with an Intrument made for that purpoe, draw out by the roots one tooth of every ort, that you may contemplate the Roots and Ligaments of the Teeth, and the forme of their holes or ocke • s.
When the Teeth are broke, you hal find them tuffed with a limy ubtance and with threds, which are the veels.
The Cavities are more evident in teeth which are withered and dried; it is the bet way to compare the freh teeth and the dried ones together, and to oberve the difference.

But that you may dicerne your elfe and demontrate unto others the ditributionThe way to hew the veel appertaining unto the Teeth of veels, viz. of little veines, arteries and nerves into the Teeth: you hal take this coure. You hal take an Oxes or a Rams neither jaw (in which thee veels are more apparent) and cut it on the inide, and open it until the marrow and Nerve appeare. The marrow being taken away, And the Membrane of the nerve being torne, the Nerve comes in ight, being compoed of many little trings, from which certaine fine threds and other things reembling veines and Arteries, being wove together, do enter beneath into the Cavities of the Teeth roots.

To the T. 15. f. 6. n n. Dog-teeth and the T. 15. f. 6. m. Cutters a nerve is carried which is more thick than ordinary. To the T. 15. f. 6. o o. Grinders according to the quality of their Roots, there is a triple or quadruple very mal and exceeding fine nerve ditributed.
Then drawing a Grinder or Cutter leiurely out of its hole, you hal ee very mal ibres inerted into the roots of the Teeth, which you hal reckon to be nerves.

The teeth being pulled up cleane by the Roots, in the lowet part of the aidWhat mut be oberved in a Tooth that is drawn out? roots, there appeares a matter which is partly fibrous, bred of the veels, and partly clammie, which fatens the tooth into its hole as it were with Glew, by the way of Syarcois. An Oxe or Sheepes-tooth being cut aunder in the middet, the internal ubtance being clammie, is manifetly interwoven with veels.

All thee things may be evidently demontrated in the teeth of an Oxes, Calves, or Sheeps Jaw; they are not o clearly dicernable in Man; nevertheles you may perceive the roots of the teeth to be bloody and that a nerve creeps cloely into the Roots. But in dried teeth the roots are hollow.

div.head: Chap. 9. Of the Bone Hyoides, and of the Ligaments.
div.p: There is a Ligament placed under the Beginning of the Muculus Digatricus or twibellie; which is produced from the Apophyis tyloides as far as to the Angle of the nether jaw.
The ituation, colligation and tructure of the T 15. f 11, 12, 13. Os Hyoides ought diligently toThe Situation of the Os Hyoides. be oberved in a dead Body, becaue they cannot be een in a skeleton.
It is placed in the Throat under the lower jaw-bone, hanging upon the Apophyis of the Styloides by the helpe and aitance of Ligaments.

It is made up of five bones, the middlemot of which being the greatet and theIts tructure. Its fatening. broadet, is termed Bais T 13. f 11, & 12. A A. linguae, from which on either ide there hoo • es forth a little T 13. f 11, & 12. B B. horn, which is for the mot part gritly, eldom bony, being fatened to the upper ides of the Cartilago Thuroides, which two little hornes are accounted for the ixt and eventh bones.

It is worth our conideration which Galen oberves in his eventh book of the ueWhy it has many Ligaments? of the Parts Chap. 19. How that this ame bone is kn •• and fatened not only by Mucles; but it fatened by Ligaments and membranes unto the Apophyes of the Styloides, and to the upper Hornes of the Thyroides; leat one Mucle being palied, that ame counterpoie and equability in the motion of the Mucles hould be diolved, whereby it hould come to be drawen on one ide more than the other, or lip downwards, which would bring great detriment, and dicommodity not only to the voice, but alo to the wallow.
Nature providing againt this Inconvenience, hath tied and fatened it by four Ligaments to the Stoyloidean Apophyes, and to the Cartilage or Gritle which is called Thyroides.
Howbeit, the Hyoidean Bone does in women appear maller and thinner, and conits of fewer little Bones, whoe ue is upplied by the upenory Ligaments, which in them are longer than in Men.
You hal likewie oberve that only the Epiglo •••• is received in the Cavity of Hyoides, the Tongue reting it elf upon the upper ide of the bais.

div.head: Chap. 10. Of the Heads Motion, and Ligaments
div.p: THe Head is moved by a traight, or oblique motion upon the • econd Vertebra, Which Vertebra the Head is moved upon. which in its hinder part is a fingers bread • h ditant from the firt b Vertebra. And the firt Vertebra is o cloely and firmly fatened to the hind part of the Head, that it cannot be tirred, or agitated o much as with ones Hand.
Alo the Tooth-fahioned c Apophyis is o fatly united to the • ody of the econd Vertebra, that in the bending, and oblique motion of your Head, you may not hurt the Spinal Marrow.
Hence you may be aured of the verity of that Opinion of Vealius, and other Anatomits, touching the motion of the Head, how it is moved upon the econd Vertebra, both in its right, and oblique motions.

For eeing the Head cannot be moved with a circular motion upon the firt Vertebra, becaue uch things as are moved with a circular motion, ought to ret upon one ingle Bafis. Yet the Opinion of Galen might be confirmed, by that Natural growing together of the two firt Vertebra's of the Neck, which were joyned and fatened together in a certain Soldier, who having in the year 1611. killed a Man in a Tavern, was hanged, and his body brought into the Anatomical Theatre of the Univerity: where while his bones were boyling to make a Skeleton, it was oberved that the two firt and uppermot Vertebra's of the Neck, did Naturally grow together; yet did he in his life time freely move his head every way, as I have been informed by others. Celus, before Vealius and Columbus, decribed the motions of the Head, in thee words:

The upmot Vertebra does altogether utain the Head, receiving the mal procees thereof through two a Cavities: whence it comes to pas that the head is bunched above, beneath, on every ide. The econd is inerted into the firt, for as much as concerns the circuit thereof. The upmot part is terminated with a maller circle, and therefore the upmot incompaing the econd, gives way to the Head to be moved ide-longs alo.
In the Articulation of the Head, three Ligaments are oberved; the one is circular,The Ligaments of the Head. which compaes the firt and econd Vertebra within, as far as to the hindpart of the Head.

The other two do appertain unto the Tooth-fahion'd Apophyis: the one fatens the aid Apophyis unto the body of the firt Vertebra; the other ariing from the top of the Apophyis Odontoides, is inerted into the Hind-part of the Head.

div.head: Chap. 11. Of the Inide of the Ear.
div.p: LEt us now approach unto the internal Cave of the Ear, which has been inacceibleThree Cavities of the Ears. to the antient Phyitians, and let us diligently urveigh the admirable Architecture thereof.

There are contained three Cavities within the ame, dipoed in the ciruation and order following. The firt is the T 20. f 7. B. &c. Concha, the econd f 9. B B. Labyrinthus, and the third is the f 9. A A. Cochlea.

In the Porch of the Concha, is placed the f 4, 5. B. Tympanum, which is not green asWhy the Drum is placed obliquely. Pauvius imagines, neither is it directly oppoed to the external hole of the Ear, but
tretched out lantwa • es before the ame, let any mal matters hould fall, or fly into the Ear, and finding the paage cleer and open, hould hurt the Drum. Whether anything be fallen into the Ears, may in uch as are living, and have wide Ears, be een in the Sun, or by holding a Candle neer the ame.

Now the whol tructure of theT 8. f 6, 7, 8, &c. Concha wherein three little Bones, the Timpanum; The Parts of the Concha. the tring annexed to the Tympanum, and a Mucle are contained, are to be een at one cat of the Eye in yong Children and Infants: The Au • icular Apophyis, which is then an Epiphyis, being pluckt away with the point of a Penknife; which mut be done within the Skul.

But in grown Men, which are come to maturity, all thee cannot o well be eenThe way to hew the parts of the Ear. and demontrated, becaue whiles the Os Lithoides, is cut up towards the hindpart of the head, it is impoible but that omwhat appertaining to the internal tructure of the Ear, hould be pulled in pieces.
And thus you hal break the Os Petroum, the Marrow of the Brain being taken away, and the Ear pluck't up by the Roots, and the circumjacent fleh being removed.
The Os Lithoides, comprehending the Aediice of the Ear, you hal cut aunder with very wel-teeled, and extream harp K • ives, beginning at the external paage.

Then having pulled back the vaul • ed roof of the Ear, that is to ay, having taken off the upper part of the Os Lithoides, you hal ee the three little Ear-bones,The Mallet, Anvil, and Stirrup. viz. The Malleolus, or Mallet; the Incus, or Anvil; and the Stapes, or Stirrup.
f T 20. f 7. A.
g f 7. B.
h f. 7. C.

Then you hal ee the a Drum with its tring, and mal Mucles fatened to the little bones, both within and without the Drum; which are indeed more plainly to be een in other living Creatures, than in Men.
For in Men you can dicern only one Mucle, which is eated on the left ide of theThe Mucles internal Eare towards the hind-part of the head, being fatened to the little head of the Maller or hammer.
But there are found two Tendons, or rather Ligaments; one which taies the tailthe Ligaments. or handle of the Mallet; and a econd which is fatened tothe up per corner of the Sti ••• p.

<> , or little Nerve, is tretched out upon the Mallet, that it may hold andThe Drum
•• ring.
<> Mallet upon the Drum.

Moreover, in a Skul newly boyled or dried, you may dicern the three little Earbones within the Concha. If you hal peep in fore-right into the external paage, and hold your Eye cloe, with benefit of a cleer day-light, or of a Candle, you may draw the aid little bones every one of them out with a pin.

div.head: Chap. 12. Of the Clavicula.
div.p: THe Clavicula in its d Articulation to the Sternum, has a oft Cartilage, orThe Gritle of the Clavicula. Gritle interpoed, that it might more eaily give way, in motions of the Arm and Shoulder-blade.
You hal oberve why it is formed after the manner of an Italian S. The ClaviculaeIts Ligament. are tied and fatened together, by the Mediation of a trong Ligament.

div.head: Chap. 13. Of the Breat-bone.
div.p:
THe Sernum, or Breat-bone, is in perons come to yeers, of a bonyT 10. f 1. A A. T. 8. f. 2. A. ubtance, but different in Nature from the ret of the bones, becaue it is of a reddih color. a T 20. f 4, & 5. B.
b T 21. f 1. B B. f 2. a.

Galen wil have it compounded of even Bones, o as that the everal bones of theOf how many particular bones, the Bret-bone is made up. Bret do by way of mutual articulation, anwer to the everal true Ribs, which Hippocrates eems to confirme. The Bret bone T. 10. f. 2 A A. T. 8. f. 2. A. growing together in it elfe, has oblique dicriminations, there where the Ribs are fatened unto it. Howbe • t in perons growne up, there are three, eldom four diviions remaining in the Bret bone.

p.U: aies that the Bret-bone is compounded for the mot part of ix or even bones, which in elderly perons, do o grow together, that it eems compoed, only of two or three Bones.

div.p: Sometimes alo, though very eldom, it conits of eleven bones, as I aw at Rome in the yeare 1554. • n a girle about even years old, this bone divided into ixe bones, of which the five lat, were cut from the bottome to the top, through the length of the Bone.

Bartholomew Eutachius ads, how that it many times fals out, which none has yet oberved, that the Bones of the Bret-bone, the firt and lat excepted, viz. al the middle ones, or at leat ome of them, are divided by a mot evident line, omtimes treight and omtimes crooked, through the midle longwayes: by which meanes it comes to pas, that the Bret bone is reckoned to conit frequently of ten nine, even, or eight bones.

Somtimes the Bret-bone is peirced through the middle with a large Hole, whichThe Hole of the Bret bone. was oberved by Sylvius and Eutachius, being ordained for the tranmitting of Veels. I have my elfe often oberved the ame, epecially in women.
In one woman the hole was o large, on the inide of the Bretbone, as that a man might put his little inger into it, and her Chet did conit of thirteen ribbs on each ide.

Nicolas Maa brags that he was the firt oberver of that Hole in the Bretbone, that omwhat might thereby breath forth of the Mediatinum and the neighbouring parts of the Bret, or rather to give paage to the Vena Mammaria which is pred and branched forth into the Duggs.

In large-dugd and corpulent women, their larg dugs being removed, I have oberved the Bret-bone to be harpe and the Bret narrow, which was the Caue of hortnes of Breath in uch women, the which narrownes of Bret was caued, <> the weight of their Duggs.

That repreentation of the Breatbone as branched or jagged, is not true no • natural:The Natural hape of the Bret-Bone. for the Bret-bone according to Galen reembles a Dagger or word, whereupon the whole Bone, is by ome termed Xyphoides or word-like bone.

The Gritly T. 8. f. 2. C C. Branches being taken away from either ide, which are parts of the Ribs, the Hat of the Dagger or word Handle, wil be in the upper part, and its point in the Cartilago T. 8. f. 2. B. Xiphoides.

The figure of which Swordlike Gritle or Cartilago Xiphoides, by uch as areOf the Cartilago Xiphoides diligent obervers, is found to be various: for omtimes it is ingle and triangular, omtimes it is double, and like the Herb Hippogloum, Horecongue or Tongue wort it has the larger part reting upon the maller: omtimes it is tripartite and reembles a Trident; and other whiles it is bipartite reembling a • ork or Rake.

p.U: aies that the Barbarous writers call it malum Granatum, the Pomgranate, as reembling the flower of that Apple.

div.p: Galen conceives that it is placed there to defend the tomach and the SeptumIts e. Tranverum. But becaue the tomach is far ditant there from, it eemes to be framed only for the midtifs ake, or rather to hold up the Liver, fatened thereto by a ligament.

Amatus Luitanus, in the 95. Cure of his fift Centure, oberves that the CartilagoIts Hole. Xiphoides is bored through for perpirations ake, that the filthy vapors of the the tomach might by that hole breath out; which is a imple Conceit.
For unles the Cartilage is biparti • e, it is perforated to give paage for the vena mammaria interna, and in wounds if there be no hole in the Bret-bone, it is found in the Cartilago Xyphoides.

This Cartilage being pre • ed down and crooked in, does o hurt the Liver beingIts crooking eated beneath it, that infants are by that means killed with an Atrophy or Conumption, and in growen perons it • au • es perpetual vomiting, until it is reduced to a natural poture.

div.head: Chap. 15. Of the Ribbs.
div.p: Every Rib does conit of a twofold ubtance, the one of which is T. 8. f. 2. 1. 2. 3. &c. bo • y, whichTwofold ubtance of the Ribbs. makes up the greatet part •• of the Rib; the other is T. 8. f. 2. C C. gritl • e, of unequal length, which is joined to the Bret-bone, by that ort o • Articulation which is called Arthrodia, that in the •• eing and falling of the Chet, it may yeild more eaily. But they have another a ••• culation with the vertebras of the Back-bone which is twofold in every Rib.

Now there are even, which are called true and perfect Ribs, becaue they areThe true Ribs joyned to the Bret-bone by way of Arthrod • a; unto which ometimes an eighth is added, which has been found more than once in the diection of ome bodies, being fatened to the Roo • e of the Cartilago mucro • ata.
And • his is the Caue why Aritotle, whom Plinie thought it no diparagement to imitate, has reckoned up ixteen true Ribs.

The five lower are called T. 8. f. 2. 8. 9. 10. 11. 12. Batard and Imperfect Ribs, becaue they do notThe Batard Ribs. reach unto the Bret-bone, but are terminated in a long Cartilage which is revered upwards, and o grov one unto another. c T. 8. f. 2. 1. 2. 3. 4. 5. 6. 7.

div.head: Chap. 16. Of the Back-Bone.
div.p: The Muculous fleh wherewith the Back-bone is covered being removed, its admirableThe hape of the Back-bone. figure is e • il • dicerned, which is partly treight and partly oblique, omtimes bending inward and ometimes outward, which Hippocrates firt dicovered, and Duretus, Hippocrates his Ghot has decribed in Coacis.

Every where between two vertebras, a thick cartilage is placed in the middleThe Gritles of the Vertebras •
like glue. Galen •• his Booke de Oibus, writes that it is an hard and in ome ort Gritlie Ligament.

All the vertebrae o • turning Joynts of the Back, are covered on the outide withTheir Membranes. an hard membrane; and within they have a trong membranous ligament, drawen a long from the hig • et vertebra as low as to the Os acrum, which is there placed and wrapped about (beides two other membranes) to defend and preerve the pinal Marrow.

I have often found in bodies that were hanged and burnt, and have been informedA fable of the Cabalits touching a bone which they cal Luz. by the Executioner, that it is a ridiculous fable, which the Cabalits relate of a certaine Vertebra, viz. that in the Back is found a certaine Vertebra which they have termed Luz. out of which as from a eed, the Bones hal be regenerated and pring up at the General Reurrection. This Bone Luz
• o called, Cornelius Agrippa and Vealius wil have to be in the foote.
Howbeit Hieronymus Magius in his ift Book de Exutione Mundi, relates that Adrianus learned experimentally of Rabbi Johua Ben Anime, that the foreaid Bone is one of the Vertebra's of the Back.

For he found in the Back bone, one bone that a miltoneturning upon it would not breake, the fire could not burne it, the water would not diolve it, and at lat being layed upon an Anvil and mitten with a ledge or miths-hammer, it was o
far from being broken in the leat, that the Anvil was crackt and the ledge broken the Bone receiveing in the meane while no detriment. Which is as fale as fale can be. For all the Vertebrae, may be broken in peices, burnt and reduced to ahes.
Whence we may judge what credit is to be given to the Cabalits, who in things manifet, do o impudently mock and abue us.

If Aritotle had oberved the tructure of the eleventh or twelfth vertebras, heThe tructure of the Loines would not have written in his third Book de part Anima, That the Back is flehy, but the Loines without fleh, becaue the Bending-places of al parts are voide of fleh.

But the Loines are more flehy than the Back. But the Articulation of the twelfth vertebra is different from al the ret, being the Caue of all Motion which is performed thereupon, for both above and beneath, it receives, and is not received, as is oberved, in other Articulations of the Vertebrae.
From the Loines you hal decend to the Coccyx or Crupper-Bone, and you hal oberve its tructure coniting of three bones, its pungy reddih ubtance andCrupper bone. triangular hape.

Which Part we read does in ome Nations prout out like a taile. Pliny records in the 22. the Chapter of his eventh Book, that in India there is a race of Men that have hairie tailes, and are incredible wift. And Paulus venetus, in the 28 Chap. of the fift Book of his Travells, does avouch that in the Kingdom of Lambri, there are men that have tailes like doggs a pan long: who dwel not in Cities but in the Mountaines.

The Nubienian Arabick Geographie mentions a tailed Nation, in an Iland of the Eatern eas which is called Namaneg. Page 70. I uppoe that it is but a fable which Hitorians relate touching the Kentih-long-tailes in England, how that God to revenge the Injury done to Tho. Becket the Archbihop of Canterbury, caued Tailes to prout out of the Kentih Crupperbones.

When the Crupper-bone uffers a Luxation inwards, a man cannot (according to Avicen) draw his Ankles, towards his buttocks, neither can he bend his Hams, which is confirmed by the Experience of Ambroius Pareus. This Impediment is caued by compreion of a very thick nerve eated on the hind-ide of the Leg, which creeps along neare the Crupper-bone. The aid bone is eaily reduced, by a mans finger put into the fundament.

In the next place you hal fal to diect the Vertebras of the back, that you may contemplate the admirable fabrick of the pinal Marrow, wiz. how in the extreemThe way to diect the ver
•• a's of the Back. parts thereof the nerves are parted, ending in the hape of an Hore-taile; by reaon of millions of little nerves woven together, which being agitated in water and dihevelled, do expres the hape of an hores taile.

Now you hal diect the Vertebre in this manner; Haveing taken away all the ribs at their joynts, you hal faten the Back-bone to the table with two iron hooks above and beneath your ection, as • oiners are wont to faten their boards. Then with your inciion knives you hal forcibly cut on every ide about the conjunction of each Vertebra, in order cutting off every vertebra, with their oblique apophyis which helpe their articulation, til you come unto the Os acrum. This is a painful work; but he that would eate the kernel, mut of neceity crack the hell.
Before the fitula oea be cut off to dicover the pinal marrow: a few things are to be premied touching the natural contitution of the pinal marrow, and the Origination of the Nerves.

The Spinal Marrow prings from the Braine and pettiebraine, and though itThe Naturall contitution of the pinal marrow. appeare like the marrow of the Braine, yet is it in ome things unlike, becaue ofter and beides its two membranes propagated from the Menings, wherewith it is infolded, it is incompaed with a third membrane trong and nervous, which hinders the pinal marrow from bruieing or breaking, when we toop or any waies bend our Backs. I am not certaine whether or no, that ame membrane which is propagated from the Craa Meninx have any pulation: nor whether the pinal marrow be divided into two cavities according to the length of the back-bone as far as the loines.

Certaine it is, that the pinal T. 18. f. 5. A. marrow decending by the T. 2. f. 2. a. &c.
• itula oea, grows
continually harder, and maller, til it come unto the Loines, where it pends it elf into littleT. 18. f. 2. o. cords, and prings reembling an hore-taile; that in that part where it uffers violent motions, it might be out of danger of breaking.

The Nerves of the pinal Marrow are made up of divers little threds, fatened T. 24. f. 9. &c. 10 &c. one to another, and contained in the tenuis Meninx: which little filaments or threddy ubtances, do rie o much the higher, by how much more the pinal marrow decends.

And that nature might by all meanes poible provide for the ecurity of the Nerves;Its Original. when they come forth of the holes of the vertebras, he has compaed them aboue with a thick ubtance, which does o cloely and firmely knit and bind •… ogether the ibres of the nerve, that they cannot be drawen aunder one from another.

After which knot and egres, they are eaily eparated. But I beech you oberveProgres the cunning Indutry of Nature in the going forth of a nerve. Which that it might be les ubject to rupture, eeing that it is as yet cloathed only with the tenuis Meninx, he has not drawen it through that hole which is nearet its original, but through a lower, which when the nerve has paed, it does not go unto the next rib, but decends to a lower, which when it has reached, it is divided into two, and turnes back the leer branch towards the pina, and carries the greater to the fore parts.

It is a Quetion amonget Anatomits how the Animal faculty can with the piritHow the animal pirit is carried through the Nerves? be carried through the Nerves into the whole Body; becaue in none of the Nerves except the optick, there is found any hole or pore or pungy ubtance; but we find them all olid, woven together of many mal threds according as the Bulke and magnitude of every one requires.

p.hi: Caealpinus in his 5 Book of Peripatetick Quetions,
p.U: uppoes that thoe little threds are a multitude of mal veines and Arteries, which make up one body as it were a fagot, being continuations of the Branches of the Rete mirable, which may be imagined, but cannot be demontrated: or at leat that between the little membran •… Co •… ry nerve, a very thin animal pirit is diffued which runs wiftly to the utmot <> the limbs.

div.p: But I ee • ot how Caealpinus can demontrate uch a continuation of the Rete mirabile with the Nerves of the pinal marrow.

Out of the pinal marrow T. 18. f. 1. D. I. K. &c. 28 pare of nerves do take their Rie, even out of the How many Nerves proceed from the pinal marrow. Neck; twelve out of the Back; five out of the loines; foure from the Os acrum, the branches whereof to earch out, is a wearyome peice of worke, and mut be done in a dead body provided for that intent alone, and with diligent Inpection.

div.head: The medicinal Conideration.
div.p: The dignity of the pinal marrow with reference to the neceity of Life, is equalThe Dignity of the pinal marrow. to that of the Brain, and therefore Hyppocrates termed it Aion, becaue he beleeved that the vitality of the animal was placed therein: as Erotianus proves in his Onomaticon and after him Foeius in his Oeconomia Hippocratis.

Plato in his Timeus does acknowledge the pinal marrow to be the foundation of Life Beneath the Head. and Hippocrates himelfe teaches that men have mot grievous icknees and hard to cure a • ieing from the marrow of their Back: for a fluxion thereinto caues a conumption, and its drying up and withering is a greivous dieae, and a Man dies if the marrow of his Back be wounded. In a word, Hippocrates in the 2d of his Predictions aies that if the pinall marrow be dieaed, either by reaon of a fall or upon any other occaion, or its owne accord, the Patient becomes both • ame in his Thighs, o that he feels not when he is touched; and alo in his Belly
and bladder impotent, o that at firt he voids neither Urine nor dung, ave upon meer neceity but when the dieae growes older, both dung and Urine come away of themelves, without any forcing of the Patient, and a hort while after he dies the death.

From a flux into the Back-marrow an hidden and undicernable Conumption aries: but when it flows back into the Vertebra's and the fleh, a Dropie is ingendred; o aies Hippocrates in his Book de Locis in Homine. How the conumption of the Back proceeds from the Marrow, the ame Hippocrates does accurately teach us in his •
Book De Morbis. The natural figure of the Back-bone.

Before we declare the Dieaes of the Oea • itula, I mut hew you the natural figure of the pina or Back bone; which is Ithucolios treight bow'd through the whole length of it: but in the Neck and Loyns it is Ithu-lordos treight bowed inward, in the back it i Ithu-cuphis treight bowed outward, and therefore it is eaie
•… aes of the Back-bone. to declare the diea • s which viciate the Backbone, uch as are Lordois, Cuphois, Scoliois, and, Seiis.
Lordois, is a dieae of the Backbone, when the vertebras thereof, are out of theirLordois. place, and turned inward or forward.
Cuphois, is a dieae of the Backbone, when its Vertebra's are dipointed andCuphois turned outwards or backwards.
Lordois happens in the Back, as Cuphois in the Neck and Loins.
Scoliois is a crooking or wreathing the Backbone to one ide.Scoliois.
Sciis is uch a Commotion of the Vertebra's of the Backbone, as that they remaine indeed in their places, but o as their frame and fahion is diordered.Sciis.

Scoliois is the Inclination of the Back-bone to one ide or another, when we goe, depends upon ome fault in the twelft Vertebra of the Back, where the motion of theThe caue of Scoliois. Back-bone, is performed.
This Vertebra is received by its Neighbours above and beneath, and does not receive, as all other Vertebra's doe beide.

For it is Joynted not by way of Gynglimus but by way of Arthrodia; and therefore if its Apophyes either upper or nether hal be depreed; it cannot utaine the • ru • ke of the body bolt upright in motion, but it mut of neceity leane to one ide or another: and this fault comes to People when they are Childr •… being brought into the world with them, or caued by ill carrying, or b •… of the oftnes of thoe Vertebra's while the Child is forced to ue its Legs, •• oner than is fitting.

I have hewed another Caue of halting according to Galens doctrine in my Chapter of the Thighs. Thoe two Caues of halting are irreparable and incurable. The Luxation of the econd Vertebra of the Neck, caues a quinzie, which in few hours does choak the Patient, becaus it cannot be retored into its place.

The dieaes of Os acrum are of great Moment, whether they be tumors or ulcers, by reaon of its natural contitution, the whole Bone being in a manner pungie, • itulous, and perforated within and without: and therefore when this Bone is Dieaed, • he Patien is in danger of his Life, as Hippocrates oberves in his Book de Glandulis.

In his third book De Fracturis he gives us to undertand, that the Os acrum being exulcerated, is not cured without very great difficulty, which Galen alo con
•… s in his Comments. Langius in his Epitles, relates, that he aw two gallant Gentlemen worne away with incredible raging pain, their Os acrum being putrified: o that in concluion they conumed away and dyed.

div.head: Chap. 16. Of the Scapula.
div.p:
Having diligently Viewed the trunk of the Body, you hal proceed unto theIts Articultion with the Brachium. Limbs and you mut principally oberve the Articulation of the T. 21. f. 1. A. Scapula or Shoulder-blade with the T. 21. f. 1. C. Arme, which is made by the way of Arthrodia, by the
coming between a mot thick and nervous Ligament, which does round about embrace the whol Joynt.

Alo four mucles viz: the T. 22. f. 3. A. Suprapinatus, T. 22. f. 3. B. infrapinatus the T. 22. f. 1. & 3. C. Rotundus minor, Its Mucles. and T. 22. f. 1. D. Subcapularis, doe with their broad tendons incompas the aid joynt.

The Cavity of the T. 21. f. 2. c. Head Omucopole, being not ufficiently proportioned to receiveIts Cavitie. the Shoulder: which was o contrived to make the motion more eaie and free, but it is augmented with a Gritle which crowns the Lips of its Cavity.

Then you hal dicover under the T. 22. f. 1. A. Deltoides a broad and remarkable Ligament,Its Ligament. which reaches from the Shoulder-tip as far as to the Coracoides Apophyis, that it may hold in the Arme aloft, to prevent Luxation upwards.

Afterwards you hal oberve the extremity of the T. 21. f. 2. • Clavicula articulated withIts ArtiCulation with the Clavicula. the Shoulder-tip or Acromium, which is therefore termed Catapleis, although Galen in the 12. Chapter of his Book of the diection of Mucles, does call the firt upper Rib by that name, becaue its placed beneath the Clavis. Ruffus Epheius cals the Acromium, the couplingband of the Clavis and Scapula: but Eudemus aies that it is a very little Bone, which in children is a mot exact gritle, which though in proces of time it degenerate into a Bone, yet until they be 18. years old, it retains much of the ubtance of a gritle contrary to the nature of al the other bones. Some whiles it grows o highly together with the pine of the Scapula, that in a peron of middle age wratling or exerci • eing it may eaily be eperated, which happened to Galen, as himelf tels us in his firt Book de Articulis.

The like accident he oberved in another, as he relates in Comment. ad Part. 1. Sect. 1. de Officina. Hippocrtes himelf takes notice of the Luxation of this Bone, in his Articulis: where he aies that the Acromium or houlder-point is of a different nature in mankind, from that which it is in other Creatures.

Upon the Neck of the capula rets an a Apophyis which in children is an Epiphyis: The ue of the Apophyis coracoides. from the likenes to a Crowes bil or an ancher, it is termed coracoides and ancuroides. It prohibits the houlder from lipping out on that ide, according to Galen in Com. in part 1. Sect. de Art; and therefore it was framed for the ecurity and trength of the Articulation.

For when the Actions of the Hand and arme are forwards, the houlder would eaily be unjointed, unles it were retained by the coracoides: and therefore the laxation of the houlder is eldome towards the fore part; Hippocrates did oberve it once, and Galen aw it five times at Roome, as himelf relates in his comment: ad Part. 4. Lib. 7. de Articulis.

Now the pars of the Scapula he thus ditinguihed: as much of the whol CommiureThe parts of Scaplua how named by Galen. or Joynting, as is ubiect to the ight he caled Omos; & that part which is under the knitting of the houlder, he called Epome, which we terme Acromion: and that broad part of the Scapula which is cituate behind, and is covered with mucles, is by Galen termed Omoplatae.

From this place we may gather & fih out the Interpretation of an obcure paage in Cornelius Celus, in his eighth Book Againe from the Neck two broad bones on either hand doe goe vnto the Scapulae, our Countrymen call them Scoptula operta, the Greeks terme them omoplatas, Celus cals them Scopula operta, becaue they tick outBy Celus. like boughs of Trees, and are cituate in the upper part of the Chet. For the tops of Mountains were by the ancient Latins termed Scopula, which Tertullian in his Book de Pallio, cals Montium Scapulas. Alo the mal branches of trees were called Scopi, hence the phrae Vvarum copi vine branches ued by Varro in his firt Book de Re Rutica. Cato peaks of Scopulae myrti Myrtle branches.

It is worth obervation which Women by long experience have learned viz. thatWhether broad houlder'd Men beget large children. broad houlderd Men doe for the mot part beget great Children, becaue they are very hot hearted. And Galen ais in his Arsparva, that by how much the Heart is hotter,
by o much the Chet is larger. And therefore Foretus his wives Mother, would not marry her daughters to broad breted and broad houldered Men: for he was afraid leat they hould die in their travil by reaon of the largnes of their Children, which Foretus aies he had often een come to pas in the 70 Obervation of his 28. Booke.

The Caue of this is as hard to aigne as of another inconvenience, with whichWhy french maidens have their right houlder higher than the left? the young maides of France, epecially the Gentry are infeted: Whoe right houlder is frequently higher and fuller than their left: o that among an hundred virgins you hal hardly find ten that have wel proportioned houlders.

Whether it is caued by the more frequent and tronger motion of the right arme, whereby the houlder blade in widened, and raied up, by meanes of the interjacent mucles lifting themelves up. Ad thereunto that in perons that are growen up; their right houlder is more heavy than there left, if we beleeve Amatus Luitanus in the lat Cure of his 4 Centure.

Why is the right Hand tronger than the left? and why are there o few AmbodextersWhy o few that can ue both hands alike? that can ue both hands alike? Is it becaue the Lungs and Liver doe incline more to the right ide than to the left? Or is it becaue Nures when they teach children to go, do draw them on by their right hand.

Is it becaue Mothers would maketheire daughters low houlderd while they tudy to make them mal and wape-wated? For as Terence long ince aid, if a Girle have a good habit of Body and burnih a little, they ay he is a champion or wratler, and therefore they pinch their bellies and withdraw their food, and though naturally of good contitutions, they never leave tampering til they make them like Bull-ruhes; mere wape-wated Ruh-Candles. Which is done, not without manifet detriment to their Health; whiles by the overgreat pinching in of the lower part of their Chet, the upper parts thereof are inlarged, whence proceedes that ame ticking out of their houlders, or from contorion of the Back-Bone, its natural hape is vitiated and depraved.

div.head: Chap. 17. Of the Humerus, Cubitus and Radius.
div.p: In all houlders about the middle and inward part towards the Ribs, there is aThe houlderhole. manifet open hole tending downwards, and evidently percing into the ubtance of the Bone, through the which a remarkable veine does ininuate it elfe into the Cavity of the Bone, that it may nourih the inner Marrow; whence it comes to pas, that the whole marrow of this Bone appeares bloody when the Bone is broake.
The Articulation of the T. 21. f. 1. C. Brachium with the T. 21. f. 1. D. Cubit, is fatned and incompaedIts Ligament. with a membranous and nervie Ligament.

The T. 21. f. 1. E. Radius is adjoined to the Cubit, that it might direct the oblique motions ofWhy the Radius is joined to the Cubitus? the Arme, which are performed downwards and upwards, which motions, haveing taken away the Mucles, you may oberve, by turnning the Radius to and fro backwards and forwards.

The T. 21. f. 2. c. Cubitus and the T. 21 f. 2. d. Radius, do in the middle way part one from another,Why they part one from another? that the Radius in a emicircular motion, might be more freely moved, and that a larger eat might be afforded for the mucles, which in that part are many.

Between this pace there is interpoed a membranousT. 22. f. 2. e e. Ligament, by helpe ofWhy a Ligament is interpoed? which the Cubitus and Radius are more nearely and traitly combined, and the interior mucles are eparated from the external. It helpes alo the equality of their motion, that both might be bent, or tretched outright at one and the ame time.

Thee two Bones, are in their extremities fatened together, by a very differentTheir Articulation with other Bones. joint; above, the Cubitus receives the Radius, but beneath, the Cubitus is received
by the Radius, the Bulke and thicknes of the ubtance being changed. For the Radius is at the writ thicker, that receiveing the greater part of the writ, it might more conveniently move the ame by an oblique motion. But the Cubitus at the Brachium is broader, becaue that bone alone is articulated with the brachium; the Articulation of the Radius with the knob of the Brachium, is thin.

Latly you hal oberve, whether or no the tyloidesT. 21. f. 1. apophyis of the Cubit do touch the writ, being fatened thereunto by way of a joint. Hippocrates oberved the external part of the Cubit to be dilocated, in Lib de Artick. Which kind of Luxation Dalechampius oberved, as himelf avers in his Comments upon the Surgery of Paulus Aegineta.

They who deny that the Cubit in a Man does touch the writ, do alleage that there comes between them a thick and moveable Gritle, which fills that pace; and in very deed that ame Cartilage or Gritle, eemes to be adjoyned by way of a upplement.

div.head: Chap 18. Of the Writ.
div.p: TheT 21. f. 1. F F. writ and T. 21. f. 1 D. E. Radius, are joyned one to another by a nervous Ligament, which infolds the Articulation.

Moreover another e Nervous ligament, is oberved, being hap'd like a Ring, which compaes the writ round about, which conteines within it the tendons which are carried through the cavity of the writ, and which lie upon the back of the writ, aveing ome particular ones: howbeit on the outide it eems mal.
The WritT. 21. f. 3. bones are eight, dipoed into two orders or rankes.Number of the writ bones.
The firt order conits of three bones.

The econd is made up of foure bones. The fourth bone is over and above, out of ranke and order; but we may with Sylvius refer it to the firt order, Seeing it rets upon the third bone of the firt order. Howbeit Vealius accounts it a eamoidean bone, becaue in this place it fills an empty pace. But how can it have the ue of eamoidean, eeing it is not interpoed between Bone and Bone? It hangs over another, that it might forme that cavity, which is in the inner part of the writ, and to this bone the Mucle Cubiteus flex or carpi does adhere.

The three writbones of the firt order, being joyned together, do make a cavity,Their Articulation. which receives two Bones of the econd order, which being joyned one with another, do make the joints Head: whence you may know that the firt order is obcurely moved with the econd, and that c the articulation is by way of Arthrodia, and in a dead body, having taken away the tendons, you may dicover this motion.
The ret of the writ bones, being articulated with the Metacarpium, do caue no motion at al, or a very obcure one. It is very rare to find nine bones, in the writ; howbeit ome have found o many.

div.head: Chap. 19. Of the Metacarpium, Fingers and Seamoidean Bones.
div.p:
After the writ followes the T. 21. f. 1. H H. f. 2. G.
Metacarpium which is framed of five bones, if we beleive
• elus and Rufftus, whom Plinie does favour, when he attributes only two joints unto the thumb; Lib. 11. Cap. 43.

Galen does better, who eparates the firt bone of theT. 21. f. 1. G G. f. 2. H. Thumbe. from the Metacarpium,Of how many Bones the Metacarpium. conits? becaue it is joined to the writ by an Arthrodial diarthrois, with evident
motion. But the bones of the metacarpium are articulated to the writ by way of ynarthrois, without motion. Ad hereunto, that this bone is horter than the bones of Metacarpium, is not conterminous to them; has a contrary ituation and a different motion.

For the Thumb is termed pollex a pollendo, becaue it alone is equivalent to theThe Bones of the Thumb. other four fingers. That it might be trong and ubtantial, it was requiite that it hould have three bones; & that it might performe manifet and trong motions, it has peculiar mucles and they are affixed unto the firt Bone. When the Athenians would render the Aeginetae, their emulators, wholy unfit for warfare and Navigation, they cut their Thumbs of. And we cal uch as are caheired for their cowardize Polletrunci, thumb-les companions. They were by the antients in way of merriment termed Murci.
The Metacarpium therefore is compounded, only of four bones, two of which are immoveable, the other two which are under the ring finger, are manifetly moved.

In that ame pace where the Thumb is joyned to the Brachialis, there is a certaine cavity, in which the Arabian Cautery was uually celebrated, which is largely and elegantly decribed by Generus in his Appendix to the Art of Chirurgery.
And it is no wonder if ome at this day undertake to cure the venereal pox, by applying mercurial water to this part, which ea • es, through the skin, and pe • ces o deep as to flux the patient.
In the hollw of the hand, a tranvere ligament is oberved, which connects theThe Ligaments of the Hand. The Seamoidean Bones. row of fingers to the bones of the Metacarpium.
Within the palme of the Hand you hal find divers Sinewy-Ligaments.
There are a few eamoidean bones found in the Inide of the Hand There are none in the outide. They are found hidden among the firt jointings of the fingers.
The Thumb in its econd and third joint has ome eamoidean bones; in the firt joint it has none.

Now to find the eamoidean Bones either in the hand or foot, you hal this do.The way to find thoe Bones. You hal o cut out the tendons that tretch out the fingers, that you be careful not to take away the cartilages of the joints which are under them, which may eeme to be the eamoidean bones.

Under thee tendons, mot frequently in the hand, epecially in hard bodies, you hal perceive a certaine hardnes ometimes gritlie, ometimes bony. Then you hal cut crowie the Ligaments of al the joints, until you make them appeare, their inide in the hand, their outide in the foote; in which ide, you hal find the eamoidean bones; haveing firt cut aunder the ligaments wherewith they are infolded, or drawing them a little back, upwards towards the roots of the fingers.

div.head: Chap. 20. Of the Os T. 2. f. 3. & 4. A. &c. T. 21. f. 2. A. Ilium and T. 21. f. 1. K. f. 2. C. . Thigh-bone.
div.p: From the Armes you hal proceed unto the Inferior Limbs.Their Ligaments.
Between the Os acrum and the Tuberous bunching out of the Ichium, there intercedes a Great and trong Ligament.
Beneath the eame or growing together of the hare-bone there is another Ligament tretched out.

And a T. 21. f. 7. a a. T. 21. f. 7. b. circular Ligament comprehends the Articulation of the Thigh with the ocket of Os Ichij, which being cut away, another d Ligament omwhat long and bloody appeares.

The aid bloodynes is caued by reaon of Certaine little veines which creepe
through the Acetabulum of the Huckle-bone.

That ame Ligament which is brought out of the top of the thigh-bone, is fatened and trongly driven into a cleft which is in the foreide of the Acetabulum: which being relaxed, and drawn from its place, there fals out uch an halting as is incurable: in which the Thigh, though perfectly put in Joint, will till tip out again.

That ame tabes Coxaria, P •• iis ichiadica, mentioned by Hippocrates in hisConumption of the Hip. Book De morbo Sacro, and elwhere, it is worth youre obervation: when by reaon of an Impotume or a fluxion into the Hip-bones Cavity of Acetabulum, the Ligaments cotrupt and putrify, and the Hip grows lank and leane. It was an ingenious obervation of Hippocrates: all Bones vitiated, ceae to grow; if the part containing be corrupted, it infects the part contained. wherefore if the Hucklebone be corrupted, the Thigh-bone cannot remain untainted; which dieae I have often oberved.

The oval hole of the T 2. f 3. & 4. B. Huckle-bone called thuroides, from its reemblance of aThe ovall hole of the Huckle-bone door, is acribed unto the hare. It was contrived for lightnes ake, and is exactly covered with an hard membrane, which does ever the Muculos obturatores, which ret on either ide thereupon.
That is fale which Aritotle has written in his fourth Book of the Live-wights Chap. 10. that no four footed Beat has Huckle-Bones.The natural hape of the hip.

In the Thigh-bone you hall oberve the T 21. f 1. K. f 3. G. hape thereof, bunching out on the foreide, and addle-fahiond behind, for the convenience of itting and firme walking. Which figure Hippocrates obervs in his Book of fractures, and advies when this bone is broken, that care be taken to preerve the ame.
For uch whoe Thigh-bone is treighter than it ought to be, are crook-legd, and are ame in their knee; and they cannot tand nor goe, with-out trembling.
But they whoe thigh-bones are very crooked, they tand more firmly either on one Leg or on both, than they who have treight thigh-bones.

The Neck of the Thigh-bone, is omwhat long-fahioned and oblique, that itThe Neck of the Thighbone why longfahioned. may pas along the tendon of the Rotator Infernus. But Galen uppoes it was made for that end, viz. to leave pace for mucles, which were to be placed in the lower part, and for great Veins, Arteries, nervs and kernels, which are quartered neare the diviions of the Veels.

They whoe Thigh-bone is horter-necked than ordinary, have their groins narrow and compreed, and when they walk are contrained to halt on one ide, and are termed Vatii. o ais Galen in his third Book de u Partium.

For the Thigh-bone does contribute much to the rectitude and tability of the Body, by that ame oblique Longitude of its Neck; whence the caue may be given why men naturally halt to the one ide or the other, or to both ides, their Feet and Legs being of equal length; which no man yet aigned, nor oberved.
The lower end of the Thigh-bone Joind to the Leg is termed the Knee, which isLigaments of the Knee. fatned by a two-fold ligament. One of them is b circular, and compaes both the Bones round about.

The other being c placed between the two bones, is omwhat Long-fahioned and bloodyih, through neighbourhood of uch veins, as decend through the Ham into the Leg: it aries, from the middle-pace of the knobs of the Thigh-bone, and is inerted into the middle Eminency of the Knobs of the hank. Sick people often peak of this Ligament when they talk of a burning heat in their Knees.

Upon the Knobs of the hank-bone two emicircular Gritles are fatened, which hold the ame Knobs more table, that they may not werve, in violent motions and contorions of the thigh. See Galen touching the of the hank-bone, in its Articulation with the Thigh-bone. Lib. 2. de fracturis.

That Part which is oppoite to the knee behind, is termed Poples the Ham, beingThe void pace in the Ham. empty and void. The Ueells which pas that way being removed, an empty pace is oberved, interpoed between the two knobs, which Pliny eems to have undertood
in the 45. Chapt. of the. 11. Book of his Natural Hitory. In the knee it elf, the conjunction of both, as well the right as the left, is on the foreide double (it hould be on the hinder ide) there is a certain emptines like cheeks, which being perced, the pirit fl • es out as from a Cut Throat.

Wherefore I have alwaies oberved the wounds of the Ham to be deadly, not onlyWhy wounds in the Ham are deadly? for the diipation of the pirit, but alo by reaon of cutting aunder uch remarkable veels, viz. Veines, Atteries and nerves, which creepe through that hinder part of the thigh, which being cut, inevitable death follows.

The ociety and ympathy between the knees and Cheeks is wonderful, which isWhence proceds that ympathy which is between the knees and the cheeks? decribed by the Author of that Book De Ordine Membrorum, which is fal • ely acribed to Galen: How that the knees being affected and afflicted, the eyes condole and weepe, by reaon of that old acquaintance of the knees and eyes, or Eye lids in the womb, where the child touches its Eyes and Sutaines them with its knees.

div.head: Chap. 21. Of the Patella.
div.p: Upon the Articulation of the thigh and leg a mal bone is placed, which theyIts connexion. call T. 21. f. 1. LL. Mola or Patella, the whirle bone of the Knee.
It growes unto the knee, not fatened by any Ligaments: but only being T. 21. f. 8. d. glewed to the tendons of the mucles of the hanke, it is o held cloe upon the knee.
If you take a diligent view, you hal oberve a Ligament omewhat bloody, whichIts ue. does firmely knit and b • nd the Patella to the hard fat which is palced beneath.

The office of this bone, is to defend the joint to guard the bowing and bending of the Part, and to render the motion more facil: for it hinders the extenion of the leg from paing out of a right line; and when we it with our knees bent, it keepes the thigh from luxation forward. And becaue the whole Body incl • nes forward, it hinders us from falling when we go downe a teepe Hil.

This Galen found by experience, in a certaine young man that was a wratler, in whom, as he was wratling, the Patella was dijointed, and did a • c • nd towards the thighbone, whereupon two inconveniences followed, viz. a dangerous bending in his knee, and a trouble in going down Hil: and therefore he could not go down hil without a taf. Paraeus oberves in the 22. Chapter of his 14 Book, that he never aw anie that had the Patella broken, but they halted. I have een uch whoe Patella was luxated and drawn upwards, who could not o eaily go up hil and downhill as formerly.

Notwithtanding Vealius in his Surgery denies that the Patella confers any thingVealius his opinion touching the ue of the Patella. to the firmnes of the joint, and that a man does halt, when it is broken or taken out, as he avers he had found by many examples, only he aies it is placed upon the knee for to defend and ecure the joint.
And he goes not much from the ame opinion in his Anatomy, where he aies it performes the ame office in the knee, which the Seemoidean bones do in other joints.
Hippocrates in his book de locis in Homine, aignes another ue of this Bone, namely to prohibit moiture from decending out of the fleh into uch a looe joint as the knee is.

Seeing there • ore the Neceity of the Patella is o graeat, I conceive it is but a fable which is reported of the Thebans, who, that they might be able to run more wiftly, took certaine Bones out of their knees.

Yet there have bin found about Nova Zembla certaine Pigmies or little Men, who could bend their knees backward and forward, and were o wift of foot that
none could overtake them, if we give credit to the relations of eafaring Men.

div.head: Chap. 22. Of the Tibia and Fibula.
div.p: The Tibia has two Bones, the one T. 21. f. 1. M. f. 4. D. larger and more inward, which • ea •• s theThe raon of thee names. name of the whole; the other is maller and more external, called T. 21. f. 1. N. f. 4. E. Fibula. But Perone (which is rendred fibula) does ignifie two things in Hippocrates, the whole Fibula, and appendix of that bone, as Galen expounds it, in his Interpretation of the words of Hippocrates.

It is termed Perone from peiro, which ignifies to boare or thrut through. Tis called Fibula in Latine from the Greek word phible, which ignifies mal and lank; howbeit in Latine writers of Architecture, certaine beames or joices of wood placed to give trength to other parts of the building, are termed Fibule. For this Bone fibula does utaine the outer knob of the hanke-bone unto which it is • ixed, becaue the weight of the Thigh and of the whole Body, does mot of all beare upon that part.

The lower ends of the Tibia and Fibula are termed T. 21. f. 1. I. K. f. 4gh. Malleoli Ankle-bones, bothWhat the Malleoli are? being fatened together by a a trong circular Ligament, through which the tendons of the Mucles are drawn, as was aid of the writs.

div.head: Chap. 23. Of the Foot.
div.p: The Articulation of theT. 21. f. 5. A. Atragalus with theT. 21. f, 5. C. Scaphoides is very cloe, o that it eems altogether immoveable, o that any man would thinke, that the foot is not moved laterally by that Articulation.

Two Seamoidean Bones are fatened behind the great toe, that they might giveThe Seamoidean Bones belonging to the Foote. The Ligaments of the Foot. a ecure paage to the tendon of that Mucle which bends the Great toe.

In the Sole of the foot, you hal find very many Ligaments, by which the Bones are traitly united, that the foot might become hollow. You hal therefore oberve t • e Tranvere Ligament, which binds up the Bones of the Metatarus, with the firt ranke of Toe-joints, like that which we find in the Hand.

div.head: Chap. 24. The number of Bones for a Sceleton.
div.p: Two hundred thirty and two Bones are required to make a celeton, fifteen being taken from the number, two hundred forty even. Becaue the bretbone is reckoned but for one, as alo the Os acrum and the Cocyx or Crupper bone, becaue in the boiling and cleneing of the Bones, they do not eparate Neither wil the T. 2. f. 5. & 6, b, Coccyx, T. 13. f. 9. 10. &c. Larynx, T. 13. f. 11, ii. &c. Hyoides, nor T. 10. f. 2. AA, Sternum endure boileing.

I omit the ixe little Eare-bones, the Os hyoides and the Larynx, becaue they are not joined by way of Articulation with other bones. c T. 23. f. 3. N. &c.
h T. 20. f. 7. A B C.

div.head: Chap. 25. Of Breaking the Bones.
div.p: When you are ufficiently intructed in the number of the Bones, you hal break in peices every particular bone, that you may enquire into the inner tructure thereof.

The profit of this knowledge is evident in fractures. For hereby may be collected in how long time a broken Bone may be oddered together again. Hippocrates writes in his Book de Alimentis: that the nourihment of a Bone may be known by the breaking thereof. The Noe bone requirs ten daies to grow together, the Jaw-bones and the claviculae and ribs twenty; the Cubit requirs thirty, the Tibia and Brachium forty, and the thigh-bone fifty, little more or les as occaien ervs.

Inamuch therefore as the Quantity of a Bones norihment, and the pace of time requiite thereunto, does alwaies hold proportion to the Bones thicknes: to that if the Noe-bone, that is to ay the Bone of the upper Cheek which reaches to the Noe, doe require ten degrees of nutriment: the nutriment of the other Jaw-bone of the Ribs and Jugular, which are twice as thick as the Noe-bone, mut be double in proportion to the nutriment of the other, and will require twice as long time to grow together which is known by their breaking, or by the Cu • e of their repective fractures.

And therefore by how much thicker the Bones are, by o much the more norihment, and the longer time they require to be oddered together; to that uppoe the Noe-bone require ten parts of nutriment, and the Noe being broken hall need ten daies time to grow together: the Aliment of the ribs, Jawbone and Jugular, (which are twice as thick) mut be double in quantity, and they hall require tw • ce the time (being broken) ere they can grow together again.
And the Cubit-bone, becaue it is thrice as thick as the Noe-bone, therefore it will need thrice as much nutriment, and thrice as long time to grow together.
The Tibia and Brachium becaue they are four times as thick as the Noe-bone, will require four times as much nutriment and four times longer pace to grow together.
Finally, the Thigh-bone being five times as thick, will require five times as much nutriment, and five times as much pace to grow together, after they have bin broken.

Celus writes in his eventh Book, out of Hippocrates, that between the fourteenth and twentieth day the T 15. f 3. L. jaw-bone, T 15. f 1 E. Cheek-bones, the T 21. f 1 B B. f 2. A. Jugular, T 10. f 2. A A. &c. Bret bone the T 21. f 2. B. Shoulder blades, the T 10. f 2. & 3. Ribs, the T 13 f 19. T 10. f 2. & 3. T 2. f 1. Back-bone, the T 2. f 3. & 4. &c. Hip-bones, T 21. f 5. A. the anklebones, the T 21. f 5. B. Heel-bones, the T 21. f 2. G • . Hand, and the T 21. f 4. G H. Foot- • ole are healed. between the twentieth and thirtieth daies the T 21. f 1. M N. Thighes and T 21. f 2. D E. Arms: between the eaventh and twentieth and fortieth the T 21. f 1. C C. Arm-bones and T 21. f 1. K K. Thigh-bones are healed. the ence of which place cannot be undertood, but by conideration of the threefold cavity and marrow of the Bones.A Threefold Cavity in Bones. A Threefold Marrow.

For I find a threefold marrow contained in the Bones in three different Cavities. The marrow of the greater bones as of the Arme and Thigh, is reddih: the marrow of the middle •• z'd bones which are hollow in ome good meaure, is white. The ret of the bones being of a pungy ubtance, or full of little Cavities, are replenihed with marrowy Juice, but not with red marrow.

Howbeit the inferior jaw-bone is hollowed in the bae, and in the Chin it is of a tony ha • dnes, it conteins red marrow, which does not fluctuate from one end of the Iaw-bone to the other, becaue of the hardnes and olididity of the jaw-bone in the Chin. Whence it is eaie to be demont • ated that the Maxilla is a double bone.

The Clavicula, which Galen writes is fitulous, we find to be every where of a pungy ubtance. The R • bs, the Vertebrae, the houlder-blades, the Hip-bones, the Tarian and Metatarian bones, alo the writ and afterwrit-bones, are pungy and like Pu • ice-tones. The bones of the fingers are hollow and contain a whitih marrow. In the Feet, only the great Toe is fitulous or hollow-bon'd.

div.head: Chap. 26. The Collection and ordering of Bones for a Sceleton.
div.p: But if you are not minded to breake the bones, but deire to preerve and prepareTwo parts of this works. them for a celeton. You hal oberve that there are two things required thereunto; firt the purifieing and clening of the bones, econdly their apt uniting and fatening together, which may be termed Sceleto-paeia.The Cleneing of the Bones.

As for what concerns the clening of Bones, Scaliger in his Exercitations oberves, that the tone termed Sarcophagus does in a hort pace eat off and conume the fleh from the Bones. And o the bones remaine bare and naked.
Pauanias in Eliacis relates that the Divel Eurynymus eates off the fleh of dead People, o as nothing but the bones remaine.
The Jewes imagine that there is an internal Divel named Azazel; who in Leviticus is named Princeps deertorum, and eates and devoures the fleh of the dead, leaveing only the bones behind.

But we are not wont to ue the tone arcophagus, becaue we have it not; neither are we acquainted with its operations. Neither do we ue the aitance of the Divel Eurynomus, becaue we defie and execrate thoe wicked pirits.

Wherefore haveing cut the Bones one from another and taken their fleh off, you hal cat them into a large Kettle or Caldron, except the Bret-bone, the Hyoides, and Coccyx. Then fil the Caldron with calding water, o as to cover all the Bones and et them on the fire and boile them foure or five houres.
You hal be careful while they are boiling that no bone tick out, o as to be fainted by the moak.
Alo you hal ever and anon take off the cum and fat which wims aloft, that the Bones may be the more neat and cleane.
Which that it may be more effectually performed, you hal perce the larger bones that are ful of Marrow, in the Head with an Awle that all the uperfluous marrow may flow and oake out.
You may throw away the firt water and boile them in a econd, that all the marrow may be drawn forth.
Then take them out while the water is hot (for if it be cold they wil be greaie) and crape and clene them with a mal knife.

Some, while they are boyling, throw in a pound of Lime or Chalke, to make them the whiter, but this eates off the Epiphyies and the Gritles which do crut the extremities of the Bones; which you mut take heed you pul not away, when you crape the Bones.

Then you hal put the Bones againe into mot pure water boiling hot, and boile them for an houre, that all the marrow and fat may be eparate and exhauted. After that cat them into cold water, and take them out and wipe and rub them wel with coure linnen cloaths.

When the Bones are thus prepared, many lay them two or three moneths in the open aire to bleach and grow white. Others put them into a wooden cae, bored ful of holes and hang them in a running brooke, or in the treames of a wift River, that the rubbing of the treame may whiten them.
I had rather lay them under the falling of a Mil-tream for the pace of ten or twelve daies.

Bellonius in his Book de Admirandis, relates that he aw in the hoare of Bononia in Picardy, an inumerable company of exceeding white bones of Bodies which had been drownd and cat out upon the hore haveing been buried in the Sea and. He aw the like by the Red-ea, o that the bones o prepared, and ticking and growing together by their nerves and Ligaments, are exceeding neate, and cleane and whiter then Snow. Such as were thoe two Sceletons which Galen had to erve him in Anatomy. Bellonius oberves in the ame place, that dead bodies are preerved
from corruption if they be anointed with the Balme that drops out of Cedar trees; alo that bones moitened with the ame juice remaine uncorrupted.

The Bones accurately clened and dried, you hal preerve in a Chet, or you may faten them together with bras-wire, and o keep them tanding in a Cae. It is needful that you have bones both waies, viz. ingle and united. And the truth is, as Vealius has rightly oberved, the Bones united erve more for otentation than Intruction.

Moreover by long boileing, firt in water, and then in oile, al the Bones of theThe manner of fatening the Bones to make a Skeleton. Head and of the upper jawbone are eaily eparated, as I have often oberved: and by this meanes you may have them evered one from another, that you may view and meaure the ize and dimentions of every one. The manner of fatening the bones together, depends either upon the Indutry of the Artit; or it is done by imitation of another Sceleton neatly compoed. You may read more of this ubject in Vealius and Columbus. Alo Carolus Stephanus, has noted ome things upon thoe Authors, worthy of Conideration.
